site_title: UBS sees exits of Credit Suisse wealth veterans in Hong Kong
summary: At least six Credit Suisse bankers, including market group head Martin Loh and Joe Lau, have left UBS' wealth division in Hong Kong, less than two months after the merger. The exits follow the announcement of a new leadership structure, which has led to some roles becoming redundant. UBS plans to retain around 1,200 relationship managers in Asia, with global wealth boss Iqbal Khan touring the region to retain talent. The departures are part of a larger restructuring effort within the firm.

images.alt_text: The logo of a Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch beyond a UBS Group AG office building walkway in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. UBS attracted $28 billion from wealthy clients in the months running up to its takeover of Credit Suisse Group AG, in an early indication of how many assets the combined firms will be able to retain. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore tech workers face volatile share price, tax burden with stock options
summary: Singapore tech workers are facing financial uncertainty due to the recent slump in tech stocks. Generous stock grants and options, once a windfall, are now causing tax bills that are eating into employees' paychecks. The situation is complicated by selling restrictions and the "deemed exercise rule," which taxes the hypothetical gain on unvested stock awards. Experts recommend that employees educate themselves on stock option plans and consider alternative award instruments to manage timing of taxation. Some tech companies are also adjusting their generous stock grant schemes, such as Amazon, which reduced RSU awards amid uncertain economic conditions.

images.alt_text: A valuations soften, some startups are raising money to make acquisitions.
The days of unicorns running rampant may well be over.
ESOP fables: A cautionary tale for those joining startups

site_title: Hong Kong removes requirement to flag China risk in listing applications
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange has removed the requirement for companies to disclose China-related business risks in listing applications, aligning with changes ordered by Beijing. The move, effective August 1, repeals a section focusing on risks from China's policies and business environment. The revision aims to simplify listing rules and doesn't diminish scrutiny for China-incorporated issuers, which remain subject to the same disclosure requirements as other overseas-incorporated companies.

images.alt_text: The HKMA is the key manager of the Exchange Fund, which is under the control of the financial secretary and invests in equities, bonds, foreign exchange and other securities and assets.
Ant’s current international business includes a transaction network known as Alipay+ that facilitates cross-border payments among a number of digital wallets in a wide range of countries.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Hong Kong SAR’s Chief Executive John Lee on 24 July 2023.
The platform also has a new public offer pre-funding model designed to help alleviate large sums of funds being locked up in over-subscribed IPOs.

site_title: Bursa Malaysia Q2 net profit jumps 28% to RM76.2 million
summary: Bursa Malaysia's net profit rose 28% to RM76.2 million in Q2, driven by resilient domestic demand and returning interest from foreign investors. Revenue fell 4.8% to RM144.6 million due to declining trading revenue. The exchange announced a dividend of 15 sen per share and maintained its target of achieving a profit before tax of RM326 million for FY 2023. Despite declining revenue, the exchange's chairman remains optimistic about future improvements, citing anticipated reversals of international investment and stabilisation of the global interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Bursa's key stock index has sorely disappointed this year.

site_title: Haunted Mansion extends Disney’s box office cold streak
summary: Haunted Mansion, a big-budget Disney movie, has become the first major film to be impacted by the Hollywood actors' strike, with union members barred from publicity efforts. The movie earned $24 million at the weekend box office, a disappointing result considering its $200 million production cost. It trails behind Barbie ($750 million worldwide) and Oppenheimer ($400 million worldwide) in box office collections.

images.alt_text: Strike rules prevent actors represented by the SAG-Aftra union from participating in red carpet premieres, press interviews and film festivals to promote their projects.

site_title: China developer Country Garden to raise US$300 million
summary: China property developer Country Garden Holdings plans to raise US$300 million through a primary placement of 1.8 billion shares at HK$1.30 per share, a 17.7% discount to Monday's closing price. The move aims to repay debts amid liquidity concerns and a recent warning of an unaudited net loss for the six months ending June 30. This follows a string of debt defaults by cash-squeezed developers in China's property sector.

images.alt_text: Markets have expected policymakers to signal more property stabilisation steps after the Politburo meeting.
Shanghai-based Greenland has failed to make a payment for the 6.75 per cent June 2024 bond with an outstanding US$432 million.
China’s property sector has over the past two years been grappling with a severe debt crisis.
The property firm’s move last week to refinance part of a 2019 loan facility failed to assure investors of its ability to repay debt due in the coming months.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of property developer Country Garden is seen on a building in Dalian, Liaoning province, China May 7, 2017. Picture taken May 7, 2017. REUTERS/Stringer  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT./File Photo

site_title: US reviews record number of foreign investment transactions in 2022
summary: The US Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) reviewed a record 286 "covered notices" for transaction approvals in 2022, up from 272 in 2021 and 187 in 2019. Chinese investors filed 36 notices seeking approval for deals, while 88 transaction notices were withdrawn or refiled with changes. CFIUS opened 162 investigations, with 80% involving finance, information, and services, and manufacturing. The committee's focus has shifted to sensitive data, cyber security, and areas like microelectronics and artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: The American flag flies over the U.S. Treasury building in Washington, U.S., January 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Jim Bourg/

site_title: Switzerland and Singapore deepen partnership to chart fintech’s future
summary: Switzerland and Singapore are deepening their partnership in fintech, with Swiss direct investment into Singapore more than doubling to S$88 billion in 2021. The countries have strong economic ties, with significant jumps in Swiss foreign direct investment and trade. The Point Zero Forum, a not-for-profit gathering in Zurich, promotes policy and technology dialogue about financial services. Swiss companies have established a presence in Singapore's fintech ecosystem, with examples including regtech Apiax and digital asset bank Sygnum Bank. Despite a decline in the number of Swiss individuals registered with the embassy, the Swiss community in Singapore remains strong, with over 400 companies employing more than 25,000 employees.

images.alt_text: Michele van der Walt, Head of Regional Innovation, APAC Taste & Wellbeing division, Givaudan

site_title: Keppel Reit units: To have and to hold – or not?
summary: Keppel Corp is celebrating its 55th anniversary by proposing a special dividend in-specie of 352.4 million units in Keppel Real Estate Investment Trust (KReit), representing a 9.4% interest in the trust. KReit, one of the largest pure-play office S-Reits in Singapore, has a portfolio of S$9.2 billion, with over 98% committed occupancies. The proposed distribution is seen as a significant gesture of appreciation to shareholders, but the value of the units is uncertain, raising questions about whether the gift should be accepted.

images.alt_text:
“The first six months of 2023 were
transformational and productive for Keppel", said CEO Loh Chin Hua (centre) at a results briefing on Thursday

Keppel Reit has a 79.9 per cent interest in Ocean Financial Centre. On Friday, its shares fell as much as 3.2 per cent in early trading after Keppel Corp said it would distribute the Reit's units to mark an anniversary.

site_title: Choppy yen at three-week low, euro firms after GDP, inflation data
summary: The yen dropped to a three-week low against the US dollar, while the euro firmed up after data showed economic growth and lower inflation. The Bank of Japan loosened its grip on interest rates, and the US dollar is expected to decline monthly for the second straight month. The euro is on track for a 1% monthly gain, and the eurozone inflation fell further in July. The Bank of England's policy meeting this week will also influence currency markets, with sterling poised for a 1.3% monthly gain.

site_title: Glencore to buy Pan American's stake in Argentina copper project for US$475 million
summary: Glencore is set to acquire Pan American Silver's 56% stake in the Minera Agua Rica Alumbrera copper project in Argentina for US$475 million. The project has 5.4 million tonnes of copper and 7.4 million ounces of gold reserves, with an initial mine life of 28 years. This sale is part of Pan American's efforts to divest assets, including a US$118 million deal with Rio Tinto and other non-controlling investments.

site_title: Big X taken down from Twitter roof after San Francisco squabble
summary: Elon Musk's company X, formerly Twitter, removed a giant, glowing X logo from the roof of its San Francisco headquarters after receiving 24 complaints from neighbors about intrusive lights. The logo was erected after Musk announced the company's intention to remain in San Francisco despite the city's "doom spiral." The structure's removal was deemed voluntary by X, and the company will be assessed fees for the unpermitted installation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A screen capture of Twitter's official page with an "X" on the profile image is seen on July 23, 2023 in this screengrab obtained from a social media website. via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Pakistan central bank keeps key rate steady, inflation to decline in coming months
summary: Pakistan's central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged at 22% on July 31, after a scheduled meeting, amid inflation expected to decline gradually in the coming months. Governor Jameel Ahmad stated that the country's inflation outlook is between 20% and 22% for the next fiscal year, in line with government projections. The decision follows a new $3 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and comes after a 12.25 percentage point increase in the key rate since April 2022 to curb soaring inflation.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Pakistan has raised its key policy rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022, mainly to curb soaring inflation.
Pakistan secures a last-gasp US$3 billion IMF bailout on Jun 30.
Improving finances will ease Pakistan into elections later this year.
Inflation has rocketed, the rupee has plummeted, and the country is struggling to afford imports, causing a severe decline in industrial output.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on cooling inflation, healthcare boost
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.1% on Monday, driven by gains in healthcare stocks and a report showing eurozone inflation eased to 5.3% in July, down from 5.5% in June. The index climbed 2% in July, marking its second consecutive month of gains. Despite mixed data, including a contraction in Italy and no growth in Germany, optimism about a potential pause in interest rate hikes persisted.

images.alt_text: Germany’s DAX index has hit an intraday record and has held on to most of the gains to close 0.4 per cent higher.

site_title: Morgan Stanley strategist says US stocks in 2019-like rally
summary: Morgan Stanley strategist Michael Wilson says US stocks are experiencing a policy-driven, late-cycle rally similar to 2019, which resulted in a 29% return for the S&P 500. Wilson attributes this year's rally to a decrease in interest rates and an expansion of the Federal Reserve's balance sheet, driving a focus on multiples rather than earnings.

images.alt_text: stock, trading, monitor

site_title: Stablecoin Tether’s reserves hit record US$86.5 billion in Q2
summary: Tether, the world's largest stablecoin, reported record assets of $86.5 billion in the second quarter of 2023, a 5.7% increase from the previous quarter. The stablecoin's operational profits exceeded $1 billion, a 30% increase from the previous quarter. Tether's reserves include $55.8 billion in US Treasury bills, $62.9 million in non-US Treasury bills, and $1.7 billion in bitcoin, among other assets. The stablecoin's holdings make it the third-largest cryptocurrency overall, according to market tracker CoinGecko.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with Tether logo is placed on displayed U.S. dollars in this illustration taken, May 12, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
Tether now commands 52.6 per cent of the stablecoin market.
Crypto-lending and stablecoins are struggling to overcome a series of scandals, most notably the collapse of TerraUSD, an algorithmic stablecoin.
The remarks come after Circle received a licence as a major payments institution in Singapore.

Coinbase said that it’s particularly interested in these so-called “flatcoins,” adding that exploring the potential of stablecoins is “more important than ever” given the recent woes of the banking system.

site_title: TPG, Francisco to take software firm New Relic private in US$6.5 billion deal
summary: TPG Capital and Francisco Partners have agreed to take software firm New Relic private in a US$6.5 billion all-cash deal. The offer of US$87 per share represents a 17.5% premium to New Relic's closing price on Friday. The deal comes amid stiff competition from rival software companies Datadog and Dynatrace. New Relic's shares rose 13% following the announcement, and the company has a 45-day window to seek other acquisition proposals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Members of New Relic Inc's management team ring the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange to celebrate the company's IPO December 12, 2014. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Toyota to boost EV development and technology in China
summary: Toyota plans to accelerate electric vehicle development in China, partnering with suppliers Denso and Aisin and local design firms to create "smart cockpits" tailored to the Chinese market. This move aims to catch up with local competition and maintain market share in the world's largest auto market. Toyota's strategy includes an overhaul of its supply chain and the development of long-range batteries. The company seeks to strengthen its electric vehicle technology in China, a key market for the world's top-selling carmaker.

images.alt_text: In June, Toyota sold 10,191 battery electric vehicles worldwide.
The joint venture between Toyota and China’s state-owned Guangzhou Automobile Group (GAC) lays off the workers over the weekend and offers them compensation.
Toyota has teamed up with Japan’s space agency since 2019 to develop the manned lunar rover – which it dubbed the Lunar Cruiser – that they hope can be put on the Moon in 2029.

site_title: Tan Kin Lian submits presidential election forms; will decide after other candidates confirmed
summary: Tan Kin Lian, a former head of insurance cooperative NTUC Income and 2011 presidential election candidate, has submitted forms for the 2023 presidential election. He will wait for the Presidential Elections Committee to confirm candidates before deciding whether to contest. The 75-year-old believes he meets the requirements to run, as set out in the Constitution.

site_title: Can innovation save innovation?
summary: Innovation continues to drive progress, with digitalization and AI playing a crucial role in addressing challenges and delivering impact. However, the rapid advancement of these technologies also raises concerns about the digital divide, potential misuse, and the concentration of market power. To steer innovation towards social good, experts suggest adopting open ecosystem platforms and ensuring human oversight over autonomous systems. This includes fostering collaboration between governments, businesses, and academia, and implementing regulations that prioritize accountability, transparency, and adaptability. By doing so, innovation can be harnessed to benefit humanity, rather than just individual or corporate gain.

images.alt_text: The IT Literacy programme conducted by Daughters of Tomorrow is one of several projects  supported by StanChart's contribution to IMDA's Digital for Life fund.
New initiatives bring innovation collaboration into sharp relief

site_title: Terraform Labs must face US SEC fraud allegations, judge rules
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that Terraform Labs and its founder Do Kwon must face fraud allegations brought by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The SEC claims Terraform Labs misled investors about the stability of its stablecoin, TerraUSD, and that its crypto tokens would increase in value. The judge denied Terraform Labs' motion to dismiss the allegations, allowing the SEC to proceed with its case. This ruling comes after a similar decision in the Ripple Labs case was disputed by SEC attorneys.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Do Kwon, the cryptocurrency entrepreneur, who created the failed Terra (UST) stablecoin, is taken to court in handcuffs, to face charges of forging official documents, in Podgorica, Montenegro, March 24, 2023. REUTERS/Stevo Vasiljevic MONTENEGRO OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN MONTENEGRO/File Photo

site_title: Japan megabanks report solid Q1 profit amid hope of BOJ windfall
summary: Japan's two largest megabanks, Mizuho Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, reported solid Q1 profits amid expectations of a BOJ windfall from its policy change. The central bank's relaxation of bond yield caps boosts the prospect of a steeper yield curve, lifting returns on bond holdings and sending Japan's banking stocks to eight-year highs. Both banks stuck by their full-year net profit forecasts, pointing to their highest earnings since the mid-2010s.

images.alt_text: Sumitomo Mitsui plans more offerings in the coming months, including a savings product.
The fund will provide financing to middle and late stage startups without diluting their existing shareholder equity, says Kazutoshi Isogai, Mizuho’s retail and business banking chief.
The bank is pursuing its hiring drive even as a global dealmaking slump prompts giants including Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley to cut jobs.

FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian holding her mobile phone walks past electronic boards showing the Japan's Nikkei average (top L) and the Japanese yen's exchange rate against the euro (top R) outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, February 9, 2016.  REUTERS/Yuya Shino/File Photo

site_title: Not the Best World for shareholders
summary: Best World's executive directors receive substantial pay despite the company's poor performance. Dora Hoan, co-founder and CEO, earned S$12.5 million to S$12.75 million in FY2022, while Doreen Tan, another co-founder, received the same amount. The remuneration is all short-term, with 92% of Hoan's and Tan's pay coming from annual incentive bonuses. The company's profit has declined since FY2018, and its share price is now 53% of its peak value. The remuneration policies for the three executive directors are questioned, with some arguing that it is excessive and not linked to individual performance.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Tony Tan, CEO of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial T

A trading suspension is a good way for companies to avoid a plunge in their share prices as they iron out problems, whether solvency issues or regulatory investigations, but this comes at the cost of investors.
全美世界（Best World International）总部外观。

site_title: Japfa sinks into the red for H1 2023, reports loss of US$53.6 million
summary: Japfa, a Singaporean agri-food company, reported a loss of US$53.6 million for the first half of 2023, down from a profit of US$25.5 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 4% to US$2.1 billion due to compressed margins caused by external factors, including high raw material costs and inflationary pressures affecting production costs and average selling prices.

images.alt_text: Singapore experienced a disruption in chicken supply after Malaysia halted the export of chickens to Singapore between June and October last year to address the country’s surging prices and shortage of poultry.
Japfa chief executive officer, Tan Yong Nang, says the company will be recalibrating its growth plans in light of the current economic situation.
Japfa’s chief executive Tan Yong Nang said the listing of AustAsia also splits Japfa’s business neatly in terms of geography.

site_title: Singapore stocks gain in line with region on Monday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Monday, following a regional rally, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,373.98. The gains were driven by easing US inflation data and a rally on Wall Street. Top gainers included Keppel Corp, Sats, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Despite this, Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust fell 3.2%. The market remained complacent ahead of the next Fed meeting, with some analysts expecting the Fed to have reached the end of its tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Lebanon's incoming interim central bank chief urges reform
summary: Lebanon's incoming interim central bank governor, Wassim Mansouri, has urged the government to undertake long-delayed reforms to address the country's deep financial crisis. Mansouri plans to restrict central bank lending to the state, limit government financing requests, and phase out the controversial exchange platform Sayrafa. He also vows to implement a capital control law, a financial restructuring law, and a state budget within six months, calling it Lebanon's "last chance" to enact reforms. However, analysts question whether Mansouri can change course with the same factions in power, which may resist reforms.

images.alt_text: Caretaker Prime Minister Najib Mikati decided on Thursday to roll clocks forward an hour on Apr 20, instead of entering daylight savings time on the last weekend of March as is usually the case in Lebanon, Europe and other regions.

site_title: Chinese firms ramp up investment in South Korea to get US EV tax credits
summary: Chinese companies are investing heavily in South Korea to meet US electric vehicle tax credit requirements, with projects worth around $4.4 billion announced this year. Five battery materials plants worth $6.3 billion have been announced, including by battery firms POSCO Future M and SK On. The investments aim to diversify supply chains and alleviate geopolitical risks, following the introduction of the US Inflation Reduction Act, which requires at least 40% of critical minerals to be sourced from the US or a free trade partner to qualify for tax credits.

images.alt_text: Net profit for the three months ended June comes in at 10.895 billion yuan, up 63.22 per cent from a year earlier, according to a Reuters calculation based on CATL’s company filing.
Indonesia has been trying to attract EV makers to invest in the country, enticing them with its rich nickel reserves which can be processed into EV batteries.
The use of silicon-rich anodes will enable Panasonic battery cells to store more energy and charge more quickly.
Stellantis has announced plans to reach 100 per cent electric passenger car sales in Europe and 50 per cent car and light truck electric mix in the US by 2030.

site_title: The gaps get smaller as the Women’s World Cup gets larger
summary: The Philippines Women's National Team pulled off an astonishing upset by beating co-hosts New Zealand 1-0 at the Women's World Cup. The win marked a remarkable turnaround for the team, which had toiled to qualify for the tournament just two years ago by beating Nepal in a qualifying game. The team's first World Cup goal, scored by forward Sarina Bolden, was described as "overwhelming" by Bolden herself. The victory defied rational explanation, with many doubting the team's ability to progress from a low-profile regional tournament to a high-stakes international event.

images.alt_text: Philippines, the footballing minnows stuns women’s World Cup co-hosts New Zealand 1-0 thanks to a first-half Sarina Bolden header.

site_title: Heineken cuts 2023 forecast on Vietnam slowdown
summary: Heineken cuts its 2023 profit growth forecast due to an economic slowdown in Vietnam, one of its largest markets. The brewer reported a 5.6% decline in beer sales and an 8.8% decline in operating profit in the first half, despite a 4.8% decrease forecasted. Beer volumes in the region fell by 13.2% and premium beer sales declined by even more. Heineken expects a strong turnaround in the second half, but now forecasts growth in operating profit before one-offs to be between zero and a mid single-digit percentage.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Heineken beers are seen on a production line at the Heineken brewery in Jacarei, Brazil June 12, 2018.    REUTERS/Paulo Whitaker/File Photo

site_title: Lamborghini could hit 10,000 sales this year, CEO says
summary: Lamborghini is on track to sell 10,000 cars this year, its CEO Stephan Winkelmann said, citing a 4.9% increase in car sales to 5,341 units in the first half. The luxury sports carmaker reported a 6.7% rise in revenue to 1.42 billion euros and a 7.2% increase in operating income to 456 million euros. The company is investing 1.9 billion euros in hybrid and electric car production, with plans to launch its first fully-electric model in 2028 and a battery version of its Urus SUV in 2029.

images.alt_text: Lamborghini will drop US$1.8b on electrifying its supercars

site_title: UBS to dispose of risky Credit Suisse loans to Asian clients
summary: UBS plans to exit billions of US dollars in high-risk structured loans to Credit Suisse's Asian clients, either by winding down or selling them. The loans will be placed in a "Non-Core Unit" for assets UBS doesn't want, while simpler loans with liquid collateral will be kept. This move aims to neutralize risks to UBS's profitability and reputation from Credit Suisse's defunct status.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the Credit Suisse office in Singapore, March 16, 2023. REUTERS/Caroline Chia/File Photo
The merger of UBS and Credit Suisse has created a giant with US$5 trillion of invested assets and a balance sheet twice the size of the Swiss economy.
Under the agreement, UBS is to pay the US Federal Reserve US$268.5 million and the UK’s Prudential Regulation Authority £87 million (S$148.4 million).

The logo of a Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch beyond a UBS Group AG office building walkway in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. UBS attracted $28 billion from wealthy clients in the months running up to its takeover of Credit Suisse Group AG, in an early indication of how many assets the combined firms will be able to retain. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
UBS wealth arm looks for pullback in Japan stocks before buying

site_title: China curbs exports of drone-related equipment amid US tech tensions
summary: China has announced export controls on drone-related equipment, including drone engines, lasers, and anti-drone systems, to safeguard national security and interests amid tensions with the US. The restrictions, which take effect on September 1, will affect some consumer drones and prohibit the export of civilian drones for military purposes. The move is seen as a response to escalating US-China tech tensions, with China's commerce ministry stating that the controls are necessary to protect national security and interests.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A drone is seen in the sky as Chinese drone maker DJI holds a demonstration to display an app that tracks a drone's registration and owner in Montreal, Canada, November 13, 2019. REUTERS/Christinne Muschi/File Photo

site_title: Unesco recommends putting Venice on heritage danger list
summary: UNESCO has recommended adding Venice and its lagoon to its list of World Heritage in Danger due to Italy's inadequate efforts to mitigate climate change and mass tourism's impact. The city has struggled with overcrowding, and a planned fee for day-trippers has been delayed by objections. Venice joins other sites such as Odessa, Timbuktu, and sites in Syria, Iraq, and Libya, which are already on the danger list. The UNESCO World Heritage Centre will review over 200 sites in September to finalize the list.

images.alt_text: Unesco’s work will be rooted in its 2021 Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, which is based on “the promotion and protection of human rights, human dignity, and environmental sustainability”, the organisation says.

site_title: Australian PM raises prospect of early election over housing impasse
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is warning that the government may call an early election if the Housing Bill is blocked by the Senate for a second time. The bill, worth A$10 billion, aims to increase spending on housing and cap rents. The Greens party is refusing to pass the bill without changes, providing the opposition with the constitutional trigger for an early election. The prospect of an early election could happen more than a year ahead of schedule.

images.alt_text: There was also promising news on inflation as producer prices rose at their slowest pace since early 2021 in the second quarter, fuelling hopes consumer prices will continue to cool.

site_title: Shophouse sales rebound to rise 7.2% in H1 following residential ABSD hikes: Knight Frank
summary: The shophouse market in Singapore rebounded in the first half of 2023, with sales rising 7.2% to S$711.6 million, driven by government changes including higher ABSD rates on foreign residential purchases and a rule change on shophouse zoning. This contrasts with the previous year's H1 sales, which were S$663.5 million. The market still lags behind its peak in H1 2022, when 119 shophouses were sold.

images.alt_text: Shophouses in Chinatown, 27 October 2022.

site_title: Thailand's economy on recovery path as tourism rises
summary: Thailand's economy is on a recovery path, driven by a growing tourism sector, according to the Bank of Thailand. In June, economic activity improved, with tourism expanding due to higher foreign tourist arrivals. Exports declined, but are expected to stabilize later in the year. The central bank expects tourism to continue recovering and remain a key driver force, while exports are likely to be stable. This gradual improvement is a positive sign for Thailand's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Industrial goods account for about 80 per cent of Thailand's total exports, which have declined for nine straight months.

site_title: Thailand’s next leader faces hefty task to rebuild confidence after Pita’s exit
summary: Thailand is in a political deadlock, 11 weeks after the general election, following the rejection of surprise winner Pita Limjaroenrat's bid for prime minister by the military-appointed senators. His suspension as a parliament member due to alleged election rule breaches further complicates matters. The spotlight now shifts to the election runner-up Pheu Thai, which is seeking to name a candidate for prime minister and form the next government. A new prime minister will face the daunting task of rebuilding confidence, ensuring a peaceful transition of power, and uniting a divided nation, with the tourism-reliant economy potentially vulnerable to another setback if the impasse drags on.

images.alt_text: Pita Limjaroenrat has lost his first premier vote after members of the Senate and pro-establishment parties voted against him. They are opposed to his election pledge to amend the royal insult law, which penalises criticisms against the monarchy.
Visitors view a BYD Dolphin EV car at the Bangkok International Motor Show in March.
Industrial goods account for about 80 per cent of Thailand's total exports, which have declined for nine straight months.
Two previous attempts by Move Forward party to have its leader Pita Limjaroenrat endorsed as premier have been blocked by conservative and military-nominated lawmakers.

site_title: A 5% US mortgage rate is seen as tipping point to unlock supply
summary: US homeowners with mortgage rates of 5% or higher are nearly twice as willing to sell, with 38% planning to sell, compared to 21% for those with rates below 5%. Existing-home sales have fallen almost every month since last year due to higher mortgage rates. The low inventory in the resale market has led prospective buyers to seek new construction.

images.alt_text: Existing home sales fall 3.3 per cent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.16 million units, the lowest level since January, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) says.

A home being built in Lemont, Illinois, in June. Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, dropped 7.0 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 935,000 units last month.
Lenders’ exposure to commercial real estate has come under growing scrutiny this year.
US mortgage rates jumped, extending a steep climb that is shutting some would-be homebuyers out of the market.
The Mortgage Bankers Association index of applications for home purchases rise 2.8 per cent in the week ended Jun 23 to an almost two-month high of 170.3.

FOLSOM, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 22: A sign is posted in front of an available home at a KB Home housing development on March 22, 2023 in Folsom, California. Homebuilder KB Home will report first quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Japan yields hit 8-year high, spurring BOJ buying to slow ascent
summary: Japan's benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond yield surged to an eight-year high on July 31, reaching 0.605% as the Bank of Japan (BOJ) conducted additional purchase operations to slow its rise. The yield exceeded the 0.5% official ceiling under the central bank's yield curve control but fell back to 0.59% after the operation. The BOJ's actions suggest investors are testing the upper tolerance limit of 1%, which was announced on Friday, but the yield has not yet reached that level, indicating a possible adjustment in expectations.

images.alt_text: The BOJ’s meeting comes after the Federal Reserve’s decision on Wednesday to raise interest rates

site_title: Coco Lee fans bid farewell to pop diva at her funeral in Hong Kong
summary: Coco Lee, a renowned Hong Kong-born singer and songwriter, died at 48 after a suicide attempt in Queen Mary Hospital on July 5. Lee had struggled with depression for several years and had sought professional help. Fans and friends gathered for her funeral in Hong Kong, with many sharing tributes and memories of her career, including her Oscar-nominated song "A Love Before Time" and her groundbreaking performances as the voice of Disney's Mulan. Lee's family and loved ones praised her strength and resilience, with Jackie Chan calling her a "proud" and "groundbreaking" Asian star.

images.alt_text: Coco Lee was born in Hong Kong in 1975 and was the youngest of three children of a Hong Kong Cantonese mother and Malaysian father.

site_title: Teachers in England accept pay offer and will end strikes, says top union
summary: Teachers in England have voted to accept a 6.5% pay rise, ending industrial action and strikes that disrupted schools. The National Education Union (NEU) reported 86% of its teacher members voted to accept the offer, following a recommendation from other education unions to end further strikes. The pay rise is the highest in over 30 years, with joint general secretaries Mary Bousted and Kevin Courtney stating the government must deliver on workload and funding commitments.

images.alt_text: The bitter row between junior doctors and the government has seen them call for their 2008-9 pay levels to be restored – something the government says would mean an average pay award of about 35 per cent.

site_title: Manchester United renews Adidas partnership in £900 million 10-year deal
summary: Manchester United has renewed its 10-year partnership with Adidas, worth £900 million, until June 2035. The deal will continue the club's participation in the Champions League, with a minimum cash guarantee and reduced payments if the team fails to qualify for two consecutive seasons. The renewal comes ahead of the 2023/24 Premier League season and follows a recent increase in the club's annual forecast. Manchester United is still in talks to sell itself after the Glazer family launched a formal sale process last year.

site_title: Australia’s house-price growth momentum slows as property listings jump
summary: Australia's house-price growth slowed to 0.8% in July, marking a fifth consecutive monthly gain. This decline follows an increase in property listings, suggesting sellers are capitalizing on current market strength. The slowdown is attributed to the upper quartile of the market, which may signal a broader easing in growth pace over the coming months, according to CoreLogic research director Tim Lawless.

images.alt_text: Major Reits mark down office portfolios by roughly a tenth or less over the past year.

FILE PHOTO: Sydney office buildings and commercial real estate appear behind Sydney waterfront properties in the suburb of Birchgrove, Australia, November 3, 2016. Picture taken November 3, 2016.  REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St on track for monthly gain on US soft landing hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, on track for a monthly gain, as upbeat company earnings and hopes of a soft landing for the US economy fueled optimism. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 6.68 points, or 0.02%, to 35,465.97. Cooling inflation has also led to bets of a rate-hike pause, further supporting market gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the Nasdaq gaining 21.24 points, or 0.15%, to 14,337.90.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts mixed on Sheng Siong’s near-term prospects for new stores
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its recommendation on Sheng Siong Group to "hold" from "buy" due to lower assumptions for new store openings and cost savings. Phillip Securities maintained its "buy" recommendation with a lower target price of S$1.76 compared to S$1.89 previously. The downgrade comes after Sheng Siong released its half-year financials, showing no new store openings. The company had previously forecast three new store openings in FY2023 and FY2024.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong’s argument misses the point that the independent directors on its board must have more than the ability to spark lively discussions.
RHB raised its target price on Sheng Siong to S$2.04 from S$2, and maintains its "buy" call.
Sheng Siong’s board is currently made up of 10 directors, five of whom are non-executive and independent.
Sheng Siong's board will monitor the progress of the claim and evaluate Tan’s continued suitability.

site_title: Singapore stocks’ market cap up 4.6% in July
summary: Singapore's total market capitalization rose 4.6% in July, driven by a strong corporate earnings reporting season and lifted by tourism data and favorable real estate investment trust results. The Straits Times Index component counters saw a 4.1% increase in market capitalization. Analysts attribute the market's resilience to the soft landing narrative, with the manufacturing sector experiencing the largest percentage gain. However, the commerce industry declined 3.4% month-on-month. The market is now looking ahead to Singapore's July property data and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: Other top gainers in market capitalisation were Seatrium and Sembcorp Industries, whose market values rose S$4.3 billion and S$3.9 billion, respectively, over their values at end-2022.
A growing cohort of investors today are looking for convenience, and appear to take a light-touch approach to portfolio management.

Initiatives to boost the vibrancy of the Singapore market mooted during the recent Mark to Market 'Live' event could become a difficult and disagreeable business if they run up against the vested interests of a company's board and controlling shareholder

site_title: Cambodia’s new PM Manet may seek diplomatic space with cooperative style
summary: Cambodia's new Prime Minister Hun Manet, son of Hun Sen, is likely to maintain his father's policies but may find diplomatic space to improve relations with major Western powers through a cooperative engagement style. Manet, 45, has been groomed by his father and has experience in economics and military affairs, having graduated from the US Military Academy and interned at the World Bank. He has met with leaders from ASEAN and its dialogue partners, and may seek to improve ties with the US, despite his father's close ties with China.

images.alt_text: Hun Manet, eldest son of Prime Minister Hun Sen, hails his party’s victory in the elections.
Hun Sen's Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) is expected to retain all 125 seats in the Lower House, prolonging his grip on power.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore manufacturers and services firms are more positive about business conditions for the next six months, according to separate quarterly surveys. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes new requirements for single family offices to ensure credibility and financial strength. Hiring expectations for the third quarter of 2023 are slightly higher, with 4% of manufacturers expecting an increase in hiring activities. Condo and HDB rents rose in June, with rental volumes recovering. Employment discrimination incidents have fallen for the second consecutive year.

site_title: EU, Philippines agree to relaunch free trade talks
summary: The European Union and the Philippines have agreed to relaunch free trade talks, aiming to accelerate "a new era of cooperation". The talks, which began in 2015 but stalled under former President Rodrigo Duterte, will focus on diversifying supply lines and promoting jobs and growth. The EU will provide $513 million in assistance to help the Philippines develop green energy and plastics recycling, as well as support the country's mining industry. The agreement comes as the Philippines' Generalised Scheme of Preferences Plus (GSP+) status expires at the end of this year.

images.alt_text: Eli Remolona, who sits on the seven-man policy-making Monetary Board, will replace Felipe Medalla, as new Philippines central bank governor,  starting July.

site_title: Court acquits lawyer and MP Christopher de Souza of professional misconduct charge
summary: People's Action Party MP Christopher de Souza has been acquitted by the Court of Three Judges of a professional misconduct charge, clearing him of a four-year suspension from the legal profession. The Law Society had argued that de Souza, who was acting for Amber Compounding Pharmacy and Amber Laboratories, had intentionally helped his client suppress evidence. However, the court found that the Law Society did not prove beyond reasonable doubt that de Souza had intended to help his client suppress evidence, and the charge was therefore dismissed.

images.alt_text: In 2022, Christopher de Souza was found guilty of professional misconduct by a disciplinary tribunal.

site_title: Excavations uncover hints of Nero’s theatre in Rome, and much more
summary: Archaeologists excavating a 15th-century palace near the Vatican in Rome have uncovered hints of a 1st-century theatre believed to have been built by Emperor Nero. The site, which will become a luxury hotel, yielded hundreds of artefacts, including bronze amulets, animal bones, and gold-leaf decoration. The discovery sheds new insight into life near the Vatican across centuries of Roman history, with some artefacts dating back to the 10th century. The excavation's findings are considered a "virtuous example" of archaeology driving a building renovation project, with the artefacts to be showcased inside the hotel after being studied and restored.

images.alt_text: Scientists have recovered the DNA of a woman from the tooth, which was used as a pendant 19,000 to 25,000 years ago.

site_title: China’s Leapmotor unveils new manufacturing platform, wants others to use it
summary: Leapmotor, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, unveiled a new in-house manufacturing platform called "Four Leaf Clover" that integrates computing capabilities for autonomous driving and smart cockpit functions. The company aims to license the platform to other automakers via tech licensing agreements, with two foreign companies in advanced talks. Leapmotor hopes to become a licensor of core technologies, not just an EV brand, and plans to launch the next generation of the platform in 2025.

images.alt_text: Toyota is to accelerate powertrain development with suppliers Denso and Aisin as well as local design and development of “smart cockpits” that meet the needs of the Chinese market.
Over the past four months, Chinese companies and their Korean partners have announced some 5.1 trillion won of investments in five new battery factories in Korea.
Visitors view a BYD Dolphin EV car at the Bangkok International Motor Show in March.
Global automakers, who for years have dominated the market along with their Chinese state-run partners, have been slow to pivot to the fast-growing market for EVs with competitive offerings.

site_title: Panasonic Q1 profit jumps, maintains FY forecast
summary: Panasonic Holdings reported a 42% rise in first-quarter profit to 90.37 billion yen, driven by a weaker yen and stronger sales in automotive and energy segments. The company maintained its full-year forecast of 430 billion yen, despite a slightly lower average forecast of 413.96 billion yen from analysts. Panasonic's battery unit and Subaru have started talks on a battery supply partnership for electric vehicles, with the goal of increasing annual capacity by 2031.

site_title: Adani Group in talks to raise 150 billion rupees from India bond sales
summary: Adani Group plans to raise up to 150 billion rupees (S$2.4 billion) from India bond sales, with the amount potentially doubling in size. The conglomerate aims to shoring up investor confidence after months of damage control following Hindenburg Research's allegations of corporate malfeasance. Adani Enterprises has already raised 12.5 billion rupees through a bond sale, and the group is in talks with Barclays, Deutsche Bank, and Standard Chartered to borrow between $600 million and $750 million to refinance debt. The plans are expected to gather steam in two months.

site_title: Lots of US homeowners want to move, but they just have nowhere to go
summary: US homeowners face challenges in finding affordable homes due to high prices, a critical shortage of listings, and rising mortgage rates. The market's logjam is unlikely to ease soon, as mortgage rates are under upward pressure. Over 46 million US homeowners have mortgage rates below 6%, making it difficult for them to sell their homes and buy new ones, with 67% willing to wait for rates to drop. This is particularly affecting millennials, who are cautious due to past experiences with the housing market.

images.alt_text: FOLSOM, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 22: A sign is posted in front of an available home at a KB Home housing development on March 22, 2023 in Folsom, California. Homebuilder KB Home will report first quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Before suing Coinbase, US SEC asked it to trade only in Bitcoin: FT
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) had asked Coinbase to stop trading in all cryptocurrencies except bitcoin before suing the platform in June, according to CEO Brian Armstrong. The SEC accused Coinbase of operating illegally due to its failure to register as an exchange and trading unregistered securities. Coinbase was given the option to delist all assets except bitcoin, but Armstrong chose to go to court instead, citing the potential impact on the crypto industry.

images.alt_text: Most crypto companies dispute the SEC’s jurisdiction, and have pushed Congress in recent months to write laws clarifying that cryptocurrencies are more akin to commodities than securities.
The market share of peer-to-peer digital asset platforms has dropped to 5 per cent, from a 2023 peak of 7 per cent in March.

site_title: Foxconn to invest US$194 million in new plant in India's Tamil Nadu
summary: Foxconn has signed a deal with Tamil Nadu to invest $194 million in a new electronic components manufacturing facility, creating 6,000 jobs. The facility, Foxconn Industrial Internet (FII), will be built in the Kancheepuram district near Chennai and separate from the existing iPhone assembly plant. The investment aims to spread Foxconn's bets beyond China and bring high-value tech to the state, as part of its plan to quadruple the workforce at its Tamil Nadu iPhone factory by 2024.

images.alt_text: Foxconn is in talks with several local and international partners to make semiconductors in India using mature chip manufacturing technology for products including EVs.

site_title: Western Digital’s first-quarter forecast disappoints as weak cloud demand weighs
summary: Western Digital forecasted a bigger-than-expected loss in the first quarter due to weak demand, mainly for its cloud business. The company expects a loss of $200-$220 million, with revenue below Wall Street targets. To address this, Western Digital plans to significantly cut its capital expenditure in fiscal 2024, citing underutilization of its factories. This move is expected to take another "couple of quarters" to clear excess inventory.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Western Digital office building is shown in Irvine, California, U.S., January 24, 2017.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: MAS proposes anti-money laundering moves for single family offices
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes new anti-money laundering measures for single family offices (SFOs) in the country. Under the revised framework, SFOs must be incorporated in Singapore, report annually on total assets, and maintain a business relationship with an MAS-regulated financial institution. This move aims to strengthen surveillance and defense against money laundering risks in the SFO sector, with the authority launching a public consultation on the revised framework. The changes are expected to enhance monitoring and address money laundering risks in the sector.

images.alt_text: SFOs are entitled to a tax exemption on income from investments managed in Singapore provided they meet some criteria, one of which is a minimum investment in Singapore, but market players said SFOs are unlikely to change tack so easily.
While most family offices welcome the change, there were also calls to go beyond tax incentives in growing the family office space.

Among the 1,400 locals employed by single family offices that receive tax incentives in Singapore, about 900 of these jobs were created in just the last three years, said Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, adding that these are “generally well-paying jobs”.

site_title: Reliance Retail to launch US$200-laptop to replicate phone success
summary: Reliance Retail, an Indian retail company, plans to launch a US$200 laptop called JioBook on August 5, priced at 16,499 rupees (S$266.47). The 4G-enabled laptop will run on JioOS, an Android-based operating system, with pre-installed JioTV and JioCloudGames apps. The move aims to replicate the success of Reliance's low-cost cell phones, which disrupted the Indian mobile market with cheap Internet plans in 2016.

site_title: German data watchdog probing Worldcoin crypto project, official says
summary: A German data watchdog is investigating Worldcoin, a crypto project requiring users to give iris scans for a digital ID and free cryptocurrency, due to concerns over processing sensitive biometric data on a large scale. The Bavarian State Office for Data Protection Supervision started the probe in November 2022, citing risks including whether users have given explicit consent for their biometric data to be processed. Several European supervisory authorities are monitoring the project, with France's privacy watchdog questioning the legality of Worldcoin's data collection.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Stickers handed out to people who signed up for WorldCoin are seen at a sign-up site in Shoreditch, East London, Britain July 24, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Howcroft/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks end choppy session modestly higher
summary: US stocks ended a choppy session modestly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% at 35,559.53. Analysts attributed the gains to cautious investor positioning ahead of key economic releases, including Apple's quarterly results and the July US labor data. Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee left open the possibility of pausing interest rate hikes, while Johnson & Johnson shares fell 4.0% after a US bankruptcy judge rejected its attempt to avoid talcum powder litigation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 6.68 points, or 0.02 per cent, at the open to 35,465.97.

site_title: Challenges to globalisation may favour some investment themes
summary: Globalisation faces challenges from geopolitical tensions, supply chain disruptions, and security concerns, potentially shifting focus to smart manufacturing, energy transition, and the circular economy. Smart manufacturers, such as those in the semiconductor sector, are expected to benefit from reshoring and near-shoring trends. Energy transition and climate change initiatives, like the US Inflation Reduction Act and EU's Green Deal Industrial Plan, aim to ensure secure supply of critical technologies and create skilled jobs. The circular economy theme is also gaining traction as companies seek to reduce reliance on distant suppliers and simplify logistics.

images.alt_text: GIC will continue to seek out investment opportunities with stable long-term returns, says chief executive officer Lim Chow Kiat.
More multinational companies are introducing “Chinese walls” between their Chinese operations and the rest of the world.

site_title: Eurozone returns to growth while core inflation remains strong
summary: The Eurozone economy returned to growth in the second quarter with a 0.3% increase in GDP, while underlying inflation remained strong at 5.5%, surpassing the headline gauge for the first time since 2021. The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates again in September, with President Christine Lagarde indicating a "pause" or another hike are options. Economists warn of a "hardish landing" due to slowing services and weakening demand for loans, with Germany's largest economy, Germany, also showing signs of weakness.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices grew by 5.3 per cent this month versus 5.5 per cent in June, extending a downtrend that started in the autumn.

site_title: Pimco warms towards China bonds on weak economy, monetary easing
summary: Pimco has shifted its stance on China bonds to neutral, citing a weakening economy and monetary easing, which justifies a more neutral stance on duration. Despite a supportive stance from China's top decision-making body, the probability of a meaningful rebound in China property bonds remains low due to developers' uncertain ability to meet bond payments. Pimco also holds a neutral view on developers' dollar notes until industry support measures improve cash flow and credit profiles.

images.alt_text: Pimco global economic adviser Richard Clarida says the US Federal Reserve is likely to hike rates two more times this year.

Asset manager Pimco is the largest holder of the Swiss lender’s AT1 bonds with around US$807 million of the securities – the riskiest in the bank’s debt stack – according to a person familiar with the matter who is not authorised to speak publicly.
China’s real estate sector is still reeling from its worst-ever debt crisis that triggered a wave of defaults last year.
Pimco CIO Daniel Ivascyn notes that when rates have risen in the past, a lag of five or six quarters for the impact to be felt has been the norm.

site_title: BOJ appoints new head of monetary affairs
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) appointed Kazuhiro Masaki, an expert on monetary policy, as the new head of its monetary affairs department. Masaki replaces Koji Nakamura and will oversee the drafting of central bank policy, including speeches for the bank's board members. This appointment comes as the BOJ shifts its yield control policy, seen as a start of a slow move away from decades of massive monetary stimulus. Masaki brings experience in market operations and was previously head of the financial system department.

site_title: Eurozone inflation falls further in comforting sign for ECB
summary: Eurozone inflation fell to 5.3% in July, down from 5.5% in June, marking a downtrend since autumn. Underlying price growth eased, with services inflation accelerating to 5.6% from 5.4%. The decline may help the European Central Bank consider ending interest rate hikes, potentially pausing at their next meeting. This reading contrasts with the ECB's 2% target, but policymakers may argue that inflation is on a downward path, reducing pressure to raise rates further.

site_title: MPACT reports lower Q1 DPU on stronger Sing dollar
summary: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) reported a 12.8% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0218 for its Q1 FY23/24 due to higher interest rates, utility costs, and a stronger Singapore dollar. Revenue grew 75.6% to S$237.1 million, driven by contributions from acquired properties and higher Singapore property performance. Net property income rose 68% to S$179.2 million. Despite the decline in DPU, MPACT is reasonably positioned to maintain a healthy portfolio occupancy and steady rental income, while managing costs.

images.alt_text: VivoCity shopping mall. 怡丰城外观。
Vivocity’s full year tenant sales improved 30.6 per cent yoy, exceeding S$1 billion, which set a new record.

krhls - Mapletree Anson



Copyright: GOOGLE MAPS
Tenant sales for the full year in VivoCity set a “new record at over S$1 billion, well surpassing pre-Covid levels”, the trust’s manager said.

site_title: Wing Tai’s Holland Tower en bloc buy falls through on planning permission hiccup
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' en bloc contract for Holland Tower, a 14-storey apartment in Singapore, has been cancelled due to planning permission issues. The developer paid a deposit of around S$3.82 million, but failed to meet the required conditions to rebuild the site. The decision has no material impact on Wing Tai's net asset value, and the group will not be able to make claims against the seller. This is the second en bloc deal to fall through in recent months, following a similar incident involving Shun Tak Holdings' High Point condominium.

images.alt_text: Pansy Ho's Shun Tak walks away from S$556m High Point deal amid latest property cooling measures
PropNex, the real estate agency appointed for the mortgagee sale, says the 48 cheques collected were all from Singaporean buyers.
Owners at Peopls' Park Centre are gunning for a collective sales exercise for the third time.
Singapore High Court grants sale order to Chuan Park’s S$890 million en bloc deal

site_title: UK mortgage approvals and consumer credit jump unexpectedly in June: BOE
summary: The Bank of England reported that UK mortgage approvals jumped to 54,662 in June, the most since October 2022, despite rising interest rates. This increase was unexpected, with economists predicting approvals of around 49,000. However, experts attribute the rise to a scramble to secure deals before cheaper mortgage products were pulled from the market. Despite this, the housing market is likely to weaken further due to higher borrowing rates and expectations of future interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Some 79,840 households, which can be comprised of families or single people, are owed help from local authorities to address homelessness or the risk of homelessness, official government data for January to March shows.
The Bank of England has found that it takes those without support 10 years longer to buy a property for the same sum snapped up by a 26-year-old with parental help.
Top UK residential builder Barratt said this month it would build around 20 per cent fewer homes in its fiscal year 2024, while high-end builder Berkeley expects annual sales to fall by a fifth.
Rising mortgage costs and a shortage of stock are pushing up rents to record levels and suppressing an expected dip in house prices, adding to the UK’s cost-of-living crisis.
Britain’s housing market has been hit by rapid increases in interest rates.
The rental figures emphasise the headwinds facing the UK housing market, as interest rates keep rising and add to mortgage costs.

site_title: Philippines central bank sees July inflation easing for sixth month
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) forecasts Philippine headline inflation to ease for a sixth consecutive month in July, with a projected rate between 4.1% and 4.9%. Lower electricity rates, declining food prices, and the peso appreciation are expected to contribute to downward price pressures. However, BSP Governor Eli Remolona cautioned that core inflation remains high at 7.4% and upside risks persist, making it premature to declare victory in curbing consumer price pressures.

site_title: Asti shareholder Ng Yew Nam says he has the relevant  experience to save company
summary: Asti Holdings shareholder Ng Yew Nam is calling for an extraordinary general meeting to replace the company's five directors with himself and four others, citing his experience in managing a semiconductor company since 2005. Ng believes he can turn Asti around and find a buyer for the company, which has been on the Singapore Exchange's watch list since 2019 due to consecutive pre-tax losses. Ng plans to finalize audits, reduce administrative expenses, and potentially address a lack of marketing strategy, which he claims has garnered interest from customers and business associates.

images.alt_text: David Gerald, president and chief exeuctive of the Securities Investors Association (Sias). In response to queries from Sias, Asti says its appointment of a new valuer is likely to indirectly facilitate and expedite a potential exit offer.
Semiconductor company ASTI has updated that the potential offeror has submitted applications to the Securities Industry Council in relation to the offer.
Sias founder and chief executive David Gerald is asking Asti's board to answer a number of questions on behalf of the company's "concerned shareholders".
SGX has directed ASTI to hold its FY2021 and FY2022 AGM by 30 July 2023.

site_title: India’s April-June fiscal deficit at 25.3% of annual target
summary: India's fiscal deficit for the first three months of the financial year reached 4.51 trillion Indian rupees (S$72.9 billion), 25.3% of annual estimates. Net tax receipts were 4.3 trillion rupees (18.6% of the annual estimate), lower than last year. Total expenditure was 10.51 trillion rupees (23.3% of the annual goal), and capital expenditure was 2.78 trillion rupees (28% of the annual target). India aims to narrow its fiscal deficit to 5.9% of gross domestic product by the end of the current fiscal year.

site_title: BOJ flags broadening price, wage hikes in wake of policy tweak
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has warned that price and wage hikes are spreading rapidly among Japanese companies, potentially broadening inflationary pressures. Despite higher core consumer inflation, the BOJ notes that inflation is still driven by cost-push pressure from rising import prices, not wage pressures. The central bank is closely monitoring the situation, with a focus on how wage hikes could impact inflation expectations. This is as the BOJ sharpens its inflation forecast and considers dismantling its bond yield control policy, which has been under pressure to phase out its massive stimulus.

images.alt_text: A return of overseas tourists has been boosting consumption in Japan partly because the weaker yen increases their spending power.

site_title: China’s factory, services sectors show weakness, need for stimulus
summary: China's factory sector contracted for the fourth consecutive month in July, while the services and construction sectors teetered on the brink of contraction, threatening the country's growth prospects. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to 49.3 from 49.0 in June, but below the 50-point mark that separates expansion from contraction. The construction sector activity, a large employer amid a broader unemployment crisis, fell to 51.2 from a high of 65.6 in March. China's top leaders pledged to step up economic policy support, focusing on expanding domestic demand and boosting confidence.

images.alt_text: Chinese consumers cut back on spending on everything but travel and restaurants this month.
Over the past four months, Chinese companies and their Korean partners have announced some 5.1 trillion won of investments in five new battery factories in Korea.

site_title: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate halves to 6.3% in July
summary: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate has nearly halved to 6.3% in July, marking the first time it has dropped to single digits in months. This easing of inflation comes after the government changed the base year of inflation calculation and is attributed to the appreciation of the rupee, making imports cheaper. The economy is expected to record a 2% contraction, but the central bank is expected to continue easing interest rates to improve growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A vendor sells vegetables to a customer amid the rampant food inflation, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, July 29 , 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Sri Lanka food prices rise 2.5 per cent in June, slowing from an annual rise of 15.8 per cent in May, the Department of Census and Statistics says.

site_title: Gold poised to end best month in four as interest rates near peak
summary: Gold prices are set to end the month about 2% higher, the most since March, as expectations that major central banks may be nearing the end of monetary policy tightening cycles. The US dollar is on track for its second straight monthly decline, which could boost gold prices. Annual US inflation rose at its slowest pace in over two years in June, further supporting the expectation that the Federal Reserve may be ending its interest rate hiking cycle.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Asia: Markets join Wall Street rally on US rates, China hopes
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday, following a boost from Wall Street and China's pledges to stimulate its economy. The US Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge fell to its slowest pace in two years, fueling optimism about future interest rate hikes. China announced fresh measures to boost consumption, including a 20-point plan to support housing demand and green consumption. The moves provided much-needed support to markets, which had been subdued despite a recent easing of COVID-19 restrictions.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shed more than one per cent, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were also off.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn plans US$500 million component plants in India
summary: Foxconn, Apple's main supplier, plans to invest $500 million in two component factories in India, with at least one factory producing Apple parts for iPhones. The move is part of the company's diversification from China amid growing tensions between the US and China. This follows an initial agreement with the Tamil Nadu government to set up a similar plant, which is expected to generate 6,000 jobs. The move highlights India's growing popularity as a destination for manufacturers seeking an alternative to China, and is seen as a coup for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government in closing India's tech gap with China.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past the logo of Foxconn outside the company's building in Taipei, Taiwan November 9, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
Foxconn already has a sprawling campus near Chennai city in Tamil Nadu where it assembles Apple’s iPhones.

site_title: Hong Kong’s economic growth cools as spending boom lets up
summary: Hong Kong's economy expanded 1.5% in the April-to-June period, slower than expected, as the spending boom that helped the city exit a recession began to slow. Household spending grew 8.5% year-over-year, down from a 12.5% expansion in the previous quarter. Goods exports declined double-digits, while imports fell 16.1%. Despite this, the government remains optimistic, citing improving labor market conditions and government measures to boost the recovery, but warns of tight financial conditions and pressure on exports.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks extended their gains from last week, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, which tracks the nation’s stocks listed in Hong Kong, jumping as much as 3.2 per cent on Monday.

The new club, called The Residence, will open at the end of this year on the second floor of Cha House, a central Shanghai heritage building where a Harrods tea room and bar, which are open to public, are already located.
Sales increase to HK$34.5 billion (S$6 billion), marking a sixth consecutive month of growth.
Hong Kong's exports to India fell 30.7 per cent; those to the US, Japan and Korea also recorded double-digit drops.

site_title: Swiss-Singapore partnerships thriving in innovation and education
summary: Switzerland and Singapore have thriving partnerships in innovation and education, with Swiss companies experiencing growth in the food tech industry. The Singapore-ETH Centre, a research hub, has collaborated with local universities, industry players, and government agencies to develop practical solutions for pressing issues in urban sustainability, resilience, and health. The centre's "dual-hub" approach, where research is conducted in both Switzerland and Singapore, has proven fruitful. Swiss institutions of higher education are also present in Singapore, with vocational education and training collaborations with Singapore's polytechnics. Global companies such as Givaudan, Nestle, and Zuhlke have set up innovation centres in Singapore to develop products relevant to the Asian consumer. Both countries have excelled in innovation, with Switzerland ranking as the world's most innovative country for a 12th straight year and Singapore consistently ranking within the top 10.

images.alt_text: Frank Grutter, Ambassador of Switzerland to Singapore and Brunei, speaking at the Point Zero Forum in 2022.

site_title: Japanese eateries in China fear ruin as Fukushima water discharge looms
summary: Japanese restaurants in China face uncertainty as imports of Japanese seafood are severely restricted due to concerns over radioactive water from Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant. China, Japan's largest seafood market, has increased checks on imports after the UN nuclear watchdog approved Japan's plans to discharge treated water. Delays at customs and warnings on social media have led to a decline in customers, with some restaurants losing up to a third of their clientele. Japanese officials are appealing to China to avoid a ban, but some Chinese diners support stricter checks for safety reasons.

images.alt_text: Packs of raw fish are pictured at a Japanese food store, in Beijing, China July 25, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Chinese firms are seeking South Korean partners to skirt US EV rules
summary: Chinese companies are investing heavily in South Korea's battery industry to circumvent US regulations on Chinese involvement in the electric vehicle supply chain. Over $5.1 trillion has been pledged for five new battery factories, taking advantage of Korea's free-trade agreement with the US. These investments aim to produce batteries that can qualify for tax breaks under President Biden's Inflation Reduction Act, allowing them to export to European and US markets.

images.alt_text: BYD, which has already invested over US$200 million in India, markets the Atto 3 electric SUV and the e6 EV to corporate fleets and plans to launch sales of its Seal electric sedan later this year.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents rise; rental volumes recover in June: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's rental market for condos and HDB flats recovered in June, with condo units rented rising 12.5% and HDB flats rented increasing 4.6%. Condo rents edged up 0.3% and HDB rents rose 1.4% in June, with overall condo rents up 24% and HDB rents up 24.6% year-over-year. The recovery in rental volumes is attributed to foreigners choosing to rent instead of buy due to cooling measures and increased ABSD stamp duty.

images.alt_text: National Development Minister Desmond Lee (in white, short-sleeved shirt) with participants on July 30 in the ongoing exercise to engage Singaporeans on their housing needs and aspirations.
HDB resale transactions volume down but prices continue to rise 1.5 per cent over the quarter.

site_title: LHN shareholders pave way for China’s Milkyway Chemical to make LHN Logistics offer
summary: LHN Limited shareholders voted in favor of disposing of its indirect stake in LHN Logistics, allowing China's Milkyway Chemical to make a voluntary general offer for the logistics provider. The move fulfills a pre-condition for Milkyway Chemical to proceed with its S$0.2266 per share offer. The deal is expected to generate S$32 million in cash proceeds for LHN Limited, and shares of both companies closed down or remained flat following the announcement.

images.alt_text: LHN Logistics owns a fleet of 74 prime movers and 356 trailers across Singapore and Malaysia.
LHN will hold an extraordinary general meeting at 9.30am on Jul 31 to obtain approval from its shareholders.
LHN Logistics reported a net asset value of S$0.0783 per share as at Mar 31, 2023.
LHN intends to convert its acquired assets at River Valley into serviced residences or a hotel under the Coliwoo brand.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit H1 DPU declines 2% on higher interest expense, enlarged unit base
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's first-half distribution per unit (DPU) declined 2% to S$0.07719 due to higher interest expenses and an enlarged unit base. Despite this, revenue rose 7.7% to S$718.1 million, driven by acquisitions in Chicago and Singapore. Net property income increased 6.7% to S$508.8 million, and the Reit's portfolio occupancy remained stable at 94.4%. The Reit's manager is guiding for "positive high single-digit" growth for the full year, with plans to leverage its balance sheet and diversified portfolio to expand its business.

The valuation of MUST's property on South Figueroa Street in Los Angeles has fallen 44.8 per cent since end-2021.
