site_title: China’s biggest cities vow to introduce steps to boost property sector
summary: China's largest cities, including Beijing and Shenzhen, have pledged to implement measures to boost the property sector, following a Politburo meeting that promised to adjust and optimize property policies. The moves aim to stabilize the sector, which has seen debt defaults by cash-squeezed developers. The housing ministries of these cities will work with relevant departments to implement the pledges, while Guangzhou has also vowed to launch relevant policy measures. This comes after a string of debt defaults by developers, with China Evergrande Group at the center of the crisis.

images.alt_text: The official purchasing managers’ index was at 49.3 from 49.0 in June.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 3,390.24 on Monday, driven by gains in local banks and index stocks like Thai Beverage and Seatrium. The rally follows positive US equities on Friday, which rose on encouraging inflation data. The most actively traded counters included UOB, DBS, and OCBC, with Seatrium's share price remaining flat despite high trading volume.

images.alt_text: Wilmar International’s headquarters at Biopolis Road, one-north. Wilmar to sell Consumar for S$812 million.

site_title: Crypto token of key DeFi exchange Curve Finance sinks after exploit
summary: Curve Finance's native token CRV plummeted 15% after the platform disclosed a vulnerability in its Vyper programming language led to an exploit, resulting in estimated losses of over $40 million. The hacker made away with approximately $20 million of CRV and a version of Ether. The incident has raised concerns about the security of decentralized finance (DeFi) projects, which rely on blockchain-based software. The CRV token traded at around 63 US cents, while the Aave token declined about 4% in the past 24 hours.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Stickers handed out to people who signed up for WorldCoin are seen at a sign-up site in Shoreditch, East London, Britain July 24, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Howcroft/File Photo
"The focus [among Telegram trading bots] is usually on low-market-cap coins, meme coins, and others with low volume," says Philipp Zentner, CEO at cross-chain liquidity routing firm Li.Fi.

site_title: Myanmar junta extends state of emergency, signalling poll delay
summary: Myanmar's junta has extended a six-month state of emergency, delaying elections promised by August. The decision comes as the country remains ravaged by deadly violence since the 2021 coup, with thousands killed and injured. The junta cited ongoing fighting and attacks in various regions as the reason for the extension, and warned that holding elections too soon would be premature. The move signals a continuation of the military's grip on power, despite international efforts to end the conflict.

images.alt_text: Asean, which includes Myanmar among its 10 members, has pushed, without success, for the implementation of a five-point peace plan agreed with the junta shortly after a coup in early 2021.

site_title: More equitable access to housing types for singles being studied: Desmond Lee
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee announced plans to study suggestions for more equitable access to housing types for singles in Singapore, including mature and non-mature estates and prime locations. Ideas being considered include rent-to-own models and buying flats with shorter leases to cater to singles who may rent initially due to financial reasons. The Forward Singapore exercise, which engaged over 16,000 Singaporeans, aims to shape the country's future and social compact, with its findings set to inform the Urban Redevelopment Authority's next draft master plan.

images.alt_text: Maybe how ABSD is levied on family members who jointly own homes here can be tweaked..
Rents for offices in Singapore's central region grew 2.3 per cent quarter on quarter, slowing from the 5.1 per cent rise in Q1.
Generic pix of private housing, condominiums and HDB estates/ public housing in the Katong and Joo Chiat area on Feb 23, 2023.

site_title: Employment discrimination falls further in 2022: MOM
summary: Employment discrimination in Singapore decreased further in 2022, with 8.2% of employees reporting workplace discrimination and 23.8% of jobseekers experiencing discrimination during the job search. This marks a continued downtrend since 2018, when 24.1% of employed workers reported incidents. The top forms of discrimination were age, race, and mental health, with nearly 35% of employees seeking help upon facing discrimination and 59.8% of firms having formal procedures in place to manage workplace discrimination. The Ministry of Manpower attributes the improvement to efforts to promote fair employment practices.

images.alt_text: The requirements of upcoming workplace fairness legislation will be achievable by most employers, and companies need not worry about running afoul of the law.
Wearing headphones all day can  indicate the dynamics of the team’s interaction is ineffective.
Setting an expectation that it’s OK (or even necessary) to work beyond your contracted hours disadvantages those that need more flexibility, such as carers, who are typically women.
Anti-discrimination laws function as an external force to correct conscious or subconscious biases. They are a positive force telling us what not to do.

site_title: Oil on track for biggest monthly gains in over a year
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Monday, but are on track to post their biggest monthly gains in over a year due to expectations of Saudi Arabia extending voluntary output cuts and tightening global supply. Brent crude futures fell 45 US cents to US$84.54 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 33 US cents to US$80.25 a barrel. Analysts predict prices will continue to rise, with Goldman Sachs forecasting US$86 a barrel by December and US$93 in the second quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: A view shows a pressure gauge near oil pump jacks outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk
Bolstered by supply cuts from the Opec+ alliance announced earlier this month, both oil benchmarks have gained nearly 5 per cent for the week.

site_title: Hong Kong’s economic growth slowed in second quarter, Paul Chan says
summary: Hong Kong's economic growth is expected to slow in the second quarter, according to Financial Secretary Paul Chan. The city is recovering from years of pandemic controls and an exodus of residents, but a spending boom that helped it exit recession is losing steam. The economy is still on track to improve this year, driven by consumer spending and a gradually improving external environment, but the year-on-year growth rate is likely to be slightly slower than the first three months of the year.

site_title: China stops short of direct consumer support to spur economy
summary: China has released a policy document to boost consumption and spur economic recovery, but stopped short of providing direct fiscal support to consumers and companies. The document focuses on removing government restrictions, improving infrastructure, and holding promotional events to increase the supply of goods. Instead of cash subsidies, the government will provide benefits and tax breaks to companies. The measures aim to improve the economy's supply chain, but the recovery remains under pressure, with GDP growth expected to slow. The government's approach aims to gradually stimulate the economy without relying on direct consumer support.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An electronic board shows Shanghai and Shenzhen stock indices at the Lujiazui financial district in Shanghai, China, March 17, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Markets have expected policymakers to signal more property stabilisation steps after the Politburo meeting.
The official purchasing managers’ index was at 49.3 from 49.0 in June.
FILE PHOTO: People walk in the Central Business District on a rainy day in Beijing, China. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Barramundi Group stops farming sea bass in Singapore due to deadly virus outbreak
summary: Barramundi Group, Singapore's only fish farm operator, has halted commercial production of Asian sea bass due to a deadly virus outbreak caused by the scale drop disease virus (SDDV). The virus, which affects more than half a pen of barramundi, has resulted in significant mortalities and financial losses for the company. Barramundi Group has harvested all its Asian sea bass and stopped stocking its three ocean-based farm sites with juvenile fish. The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) is working on a vaccine and has launched the Aquatic Animal Health Services to boost the health of farmed fish.

images.alt_text: The landfill space in the southern perimeter bund of Pulau Semakau in 2011. Semakau is “still filling up quite quickly” and the country is considering options on how to deal with the existing ash.

site_title: Lynas Rare Earths’ quarterly revenue slumps 47% on lower product prices
summary: Lynas Rare Earths, the world's largest producer of rare earths outside of China, reported a 47% drop in fourth-quarter revenue to A$157.5 million due to lower product prices. The company attributed the decline to low market prices for neodymium and praseodymium, used in making magnets, and decreased demand from customers outside China. Despite this, Lynas is targeting its first production of mixed rare-earth carbonate from its Kalgoorlie facility in September.

site_title: Indonesia pauses some Australian cattle imports after cows found with LSD
summary: Indonesia has paused live cattle imports from four Australian facilities after detecting LSD in a small number of cattle. The Australian government assures that all exported animals comply with Indonesian requirements. Rapid diagnostic testing has begun to restore exports from the impacted facilities. LSD, a viral disease affecting cattle and buffalo, was first reported in Indonesia last year. Australia remains free of the disease and exports continue from other facilities.

images.alt_text: Barramundi Group has harvested all its Asian sea bass and stopped stocking its three ocean-based farm sites with juvenile fish.
China is the biggest importer of Japanese seafood.
Indonesia’s e-commerce sector reached US$59 billion in global merchandise value last year and is expected to grow to US$95 billion by 2025.

site_title: Businesses must prioritise workplace well-being
summary: Singapore's mental health crisis is costing the economy $16 billion, with 37% of workers at high mental health risk. Employers who prioritize workplace well-being boost employee engagement, productivity, and the bottom line, contributing to a better economy. To address this, businesses should provide access to confidential counseling services, flexible work arrangements, and financial education. Implementing these measures can prevent mental health crises, reduce turnover rates, and improve overall population health.

images.alt_text: Most of the knowledge on supporting mental health in the workplace is based on the experience of larger organisations that typically have a lot of staff to handle these issues.

site_title: Japan’s industrial production rebounds on resilient recovery
summary: Japan's industrial production rebounded 2% in June, exceeding forecasts, as the country's economy continues to recover. The rebound was driven by a return of overseas tourists, who benefit from the weaker yen, increasing their spending power. Meanwhile, the nation's trade balance swung to a surplus for the first time since July 2021, with exports holding up while imports fell due to lower fuel prices. Retail sales also rose 5.9% from a year ago, despite a 0.4% decline in June from May.

site_title: Italy GDP unexpectedly shrinks in blow to Meloni
summary: Italy's economy unexpectedly contracted by 0.3% in the second quarter, contrary to the government's expectations of 1% growth. The GDP growth rate was 0.6% year-over-year, and industry and agriculture output decreased while services grew marginally. The contraction leaves Italy with a "carryover" growth of 0.8% for the year, and the government's forecast of 1.2% growth may be revised downward. The data also showed a slowdown in inflation, with annual inflation easing to 6.4% in July from 6.7% in June.

images.alt_text: When Italy's Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni visits US President Joe Biden this week, both countries are expected to discuss Italy's ties with China.
The Trevi Fountain in Rome. Italy's manufacturing numbers point to a recession ahead, uness buoyant services can prop up the eurozone's third-largest economy.
Shipments abroad rose above 3 billion euros in February, up 131 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Walmart buys out US$1.4 billion Tiger Global stake in India’s Flipkart: WSJ
summary: Walmart has acquired US$1.4 billion from hedge fund Tiger Global to buy out its remaining stake in Flipkart, an Indian e-commerce firm. This deal brings Walmart's stake in Flipkart to 77%, increasing its value to US$35 billion from nearly US$38 billion. The acquisition marks a significant move by Walmart, which had previously acquired a majority stake in Flipkart for about US$16 billion in 2018, and had planned to take the company public in four years.

site_title: LHN Logistics’ takeover pre-condition to get JTC nod, subject to S$4.1 million fee
summary: LHN Logistics' takeover by Milkyway Chemical is subject to two pre-conditions: approval from shareholders and written consent from the Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) for the change in LHN Limited's indirect ownership in Hean Nerng Logistics. JTC has agreed to provide written consent, but the payment of a S$4.1 million fee to the statutory board is contingent on LHN Limited bearing S$3.1 million of the fee. This payment would result in a wider loss per share for LHN Logistics.

images.alt_text: LHN Logistics owns a fleet of 74 prime movers and 356 trailers across Singapore and Malaysia.
LHN Logistics reported a net asset value of S$0.0783 per share as at Mar 31, 2023.

LHN Logistics owns a fleet of 74 prime movers and 356 trailers across Singapore and Malaysia. Its primary customers are international ISO tank operators, chemical traders, freight forwarders and chemical branches of oil majors. It carries out its transportation operations here at its own property at 7 Gul Avenue, as well as at a leased logistics parking yard at 18 Penjuru Road.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing, services business outlook more upbeat for next 6 months
summary: Singapore's manufacturers and services firms have become more positive about business conditions in the next six months, with a net weighted balance of 6% and 8% respectively. Manufacturing sentiment improved from 2% in the previous survey, while services firms are optimistic about prospects from July to December. The optimism is driven by improved conditions ahead in manufacturing, sustained demand for aircraft maintenance, and the return of Chinese tourists. However, sentiments were mixed among clusters, with the biomedical manufacturing cluster being the least upbeat. Overall, hiring expectations were slightly higher for the third quarter of 2023, with a net weighted balance of 4% of manufacturers expecting an increase in hiring activities.

images.alt_text: Private-sector economists polled by Bloomberg had expected a 0.5 per cent year-on-year growth and 0.2 per cent quarterly contraction, which meant they were bracing for a technical contraction, defined as two consecutive quarters of quarterly contraction.
Economists flag risk of technical recession for Singapore as manufacturing contracts further in May

Following three quarters of pessimism, a net weighted balance of 2 per cent of manufacturing firms are now anticipating a favourable business situation from April to September, a survey by the Singapore Economic Development Board showed on Friday (Apr 28).

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, Jardine Matheson, Jardine C&C, Hongkong Land, DFI Retail, Raffles Medical, Mandarin Oriental, Clint
summary: Wilmar International will sell its 30.1% stake in Moroccan sugar producer Cosumar for S$812.3 million. Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a 34% increase in first-half net profit to US$566 million, while Jardine C&C posted a 33% increase to US$648 million. Hongkong Land reported a net loss of US$333 million, and DFI Retail Group returned to profitability with a US$8 million net profit. Raffles Medical Group's net profit rose 0.5% to S$59.9 million, and Mandarin Oriental's net loss widened to US$69.2 million.

images.alt_text: Formerly Sembcorp Marine, Seatrium closed down 2.1 per cent after it posted higher net loss.

site_title: ECB could hike rates or pause at next meeting: Lagarde
summary: European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde hinted at a possible pause in interest rate hikes or another increase at the next meeting, set for September 14, citing the latest economic data. Inflation remains stubbornly high at 5.5%, above the ECB's 2% target. Lagarde emphasized that the decision will depend on data and that a pause in September would not be definitive, with inflation needing to return to its target.

images.alt_text: epa10526628 International banks tower over pedestrians at London's financial district, Canary Wharf, in London, Britain, 16 March 2023. Fears are growing of a new global banking crisis following the losses suffered by Credit Suisse and the collapse of US bank SVB (Silicon Valley Bank). Meanwhile the ECB (European Central Bank) has increased Eurozone interest rates by 0.5 percent and has stated that it will respond to any a further market turmoil.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Kim Heng pursues growth in renewable and fossil fuel-linked projects
summary: Kim Heng, a South Korean offshore marine services contractor, is expanding its renewable energy business, aiming for it to account for half its bottom line by 2024. Despite revenue from its renewable energy segment falling 4% in the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, the company remains optimistic about the sector's growth. Chairman and CEO Thomas Tan believes the industry is still nascent and faces infrastructure and funding challenges, but expects the global transition to renewables to be inevitable, possibly taking a decade or two to occur.

images.alt_text: Kim Heng buys S$10m crane, bags US$7.2m windfarm job
The MOU will remain in force for a year, and is subject to renewal by mutual agreement.

site_title: Raffles Medical H1 profit rises 0.5% to S$59.9 million; chairman says will consider M&A
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 0.5% rise in net profit to S$59.9 million for its first half, driven by lower Covid-related activities and a year-on-year fall in net reinsurance expenses. Despite a 9.5% decline in revenue, earnings per share stood at S$0.0322, up from S$0.0320 the previous year. The company's chairman, Dr Loo Choon Yong, noted that the group's reported topline is still above pre-pandemic levels and plans to expand capacity and acquire more hospitals and healthcare businesses, citing S$299.6 million in cash and cash equivalents.

images.alt_text: operation, operating room, surgery
New hospital fee benchmarks have been introduced for 29 common surgical procedures and medical conditions in MOH's latest update, released on Jun 14.
Analysts from UOB Kay Hian and the Singapore research team remain bullish about Delfi’s growth prospects in Indonesia.

site_title: Sound reasons to support lofty rents for Singapore homes
summary: Singapore's home rental rates have increased sharply, with private homes rising 29.7% in 2022 and HDB flats increasing by 40-45% between Q4 2021 and Q2 2023. However, over a longer time frame, rental rates have risen modestly, with a compound annual growth rate of 3.3% for private homes and 2.3% for HDB flats. The government suggests that sound reasons exist for high rental rates, citing the growing economy, higher wages, and increased demand for luxury homes. As more homes are built, tenants may have greater choice and bargaining power, potentially moderating future increases.

images.alt_text: In May, average median rent for private non-landed properties saw a decline of 2.2 per cent, said Savills.

site_title: Oil prices hit multi-month highs on tightening supply
summary: Oil prices reached a three-month high, with October Brent crude futures rising 1.2% to $85.43 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures increasing 1.5% to $81.80 a barrel. Saudi Arabia is expected to extend a voluntary oil output cut of 1 million barrels per day for another month. Global oil demand rose to a record 102.8 million barrels per day in July, driven by stronger economic growth in India and the US, and supply deficits are expected to worsen, supporting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were down 45 US cents to US$84.54 a barrel by 0315 GMT while US West Texas Intermediate crude was at US$80.25 a barrel, down 33 US cents.

site_title: ‘Barbenheimer’ box office sales keep rolling in second weekend
summary: "Director Greta Gerwig's 'Barbie' continues to dominate the box office in its second weekend, with an estimated $93 million in ticket sales and over $775 million globally since its opening on July 21. The film, starring Margot Robbie, is the highest-grossing opening weekend for a film directed by a woman. In comparison, Christopher Nolan's 'Oppenheimer' made an estimated $46.2 million in its second weekend. The combined sales of the two films have been dubbed 'Barbenheimer' and are giving the summer box office a major boost."

images.alt_text: Grove's Theater marquee announcing the opening of "Oppenheimer" movie is pictured in Los Angeles California, on July 20, 2023. "Oppenheimer" is facing off against "Barbie" in the biggest clash of Hollywood summer blockbusters, with both opening on the same day in a duel the media has dubbed "Barbenheimer". (Photo by VALERIE MACON / AFP)
Enter Barbie and Oppenheimer, two polar opposite movies that debuted simultaneously in a matchup dubbed “Barbenheimer”.
Barbie-mania is everywhere as the hotly anticipated film starring Margot Robbie hits theatres worldwide.

site_title: Lessons from Manulife US Reit’s troubles
summary: Manulife US Reit (MUST) has faced significant declines in the value of its properties, with a 44.8% drop since end-2021, due to the worsening US commercial property market. The Reit's gearing has increased to 57%, putting it at risk of breaching debt covenants. Analysts have downgraded their recommendations, and investors are urged to consider recapitalization exercises to preserve the Reit's viability. Other Reits with similar exposure to the US market are also at risk, with Prime US Reit trading at a 73.3% discount to NAV. A timely recapitalization could transform the market's perception of these Reits and make them more appealing to investors.

site_title: No Signboard CEO says fresh charges related to 2019 probes
summary: No Signboard CEO Lim Yong Sim has been charged with share price rigging offences under the Securities and Futures Act, related to previous probes in January 2019. Lim, the executive chairman and CEO of the restaurant operator, was not asked to assist in other investigations or interviews. He faces up to seven years in jail or a fine of up to S$250,000 if convicted. The fresh charges arose from a joint investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department and the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

images.alt_text: No Signboard's CEO and executive chairman Lim Yong Sim was charged for price rigging offences under the Securities and Futures Act.

site_title: EMA to raise entry bar for electricity retailers to ensure credibility, financial strength
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) will introduce new requirements for electricity retailers in Singapore, starting from August 2023, to ensure their credibility and financial strength. The new rules will require retailers to have a minimum tangible net worth of S$1 million, hedge at least 80% of their retail contract positions, and provide a performance bond for unhedged positions. The enhancements aim to protect consumers against premature contract termination and volatile market conditions, while also promoting a more stable electricity market.

images.alt_text: EMA is looking for proposals that develop more land-efficient, cost-effective and safer ESS solutions suited for the Republic’s tropical and urbanised climate.
The temporary price cap will kick in from Jul 1, 2023, said the Energy Market Authority in a paper published on its website.

site_title: EU’s new AI Act could add to compliance costs for Asean firms: industry players
summary: The European Parliament voted to move forward with the EU's AI Act, which classifies AI systems into four risk levels with different regulations. The act, first proposed in 2021, is likely to add compliance costs for companies in South-east Asia, particularly those developing AI-powered services for the global market. Industry players warn that the new regulations could lead to uneven regulatory approaches, affecting the region's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The government has had early access to some of the latest capabilities of OpenAI, the developer of ChatGPT, said Dr Janil Puthucheary (pictured).
Governments and society will have to grapple with the issue of how to regulate artificial intelligence and who should do so.

Larry Feinsmith (left), JP Morgan Chase’s head of global tech strategy, innovation and partnerships tells Databricks chief Ali Ghodsi about that the bank is working through the risks of AI.

site_title: Musk draws heat from San Francisco over giant X logo
summary: Elon Musk's company, X, has erected a giant X logo on the roof of its San Francisco headquarters, sparking criticism from city officials and residents over intrusive lights. The move comes as the city struggles to recover from pandemic-related losses, with downtown areas experiencing job cuts, reduced tourism, and high-profile crime. Despite Musk's efforts to reassure the city, some residents are unhappy with the display, and the San Francisco Department of Building Inspection is investigating the structure for potential permitting rule violations.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk wants to transform Twitter – now known as X – into a super app, similar to China's WeChat.

site_title: Bearish outlook seen for USDCNH
summary: A bearish outlook is seen for the USDCNH currency pair, with prices having risen 3.74% since the start of the year. A head and shoulders pattern and declining Relative Strength Index (RSI) have further validated the downside bias, suggesting a deeper correction in the medium term. Prices are expected to be capped at 7.19 and a short-term downside target is set at 7.06, with a potential extension target of 7.01.

site_title: Wilmar to sell entire 30.1% stake in Moroccan sugar producer Cosumar for S$812 million
summary: Wilmar International has agreed to sell its entire 30.1% stake in Moroccan sugar producer Cosumar for approximately S$812.3 million. The sale is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2023, subject to regulatory approvals. As part of the deal, Wilmar will acquire two companies from Cosumar, including Wilmaco and Durrah Advanced Development Company, which will become wholly-owned subsidiaries of Wilmar. The transactions are expected to have a minimal financial impact on the company.

images.alt_text: Wilmar International’s headquarters at Biopolis Road, one-north.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust’s H1 DPU falls 22% on higher finance costs, enlarged unit base
summary: CapitaLand India Trust reported a 22% decline in its first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0336, mainly due to higher finance costs and an enlarged unit base following a preferential offering. Total property income rose 18% to 6.8 billion rupees. Excluding the impact of the offering, DPU would have been 2.31 rupees per unit, 3.3% lower year-over-year.

Gains from higher property income are partially offset by an increase in total property expenses.
Total property income for H2 grew 15 per cent to 6.2 billion Indian rupees (S$107.3 million), resulting in a 12 per cent rise for the full year to 11.9 billion rupees.
CapitaLand India Trust's trustee-manager says the acquisition complements an existing portfolio in Bangalore.

site_title: Joko Widodo: A unifying ‘outsider’ with an ambitious Golden Indonesia plan
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has outlined his ambitious plan for "Golden Indonesia 2045," aiming to accelerate the country's development over the next decade. Widodo has led the country since 2014, overseeing significant infrastructure development and economic reforms. China-Indonesia relations have strengthened, with cooperation in high-speed rail and electric vehicles. Widodo's vision for Golden Indonesia is seen as a path to emulate China's rapid development, with the country's elites studying China's rise and seeking to emulate its economic growth.

These transactions require shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting, to be convened.
“The collaboration between the IDX and HKEX aims to strengthen the global position of the Indonesian capital market,” says IDX president Director Iman Rachman.

site_title: China consumer spending slows, reining in growth, survey shows
summary: China's consumer spending slowed in July, contributing to sluggish revenue growth in key sectors as the economy's recovery loses steam. Retail sales declined, while travel and food businesses saw an increase due to "revenge spending". Manufacturing output barely rose, with domestic orders slowing, but export orders improved in Asia and the US. Fiscal activities increased, sending bullish signals to investors, but monetary conditions tightened for companies. The economy is likely to continue to slow, with growth already weakened in the second quarter by a property market slump, falling exports, and sluggish retail sales.

images.alt_text: The light industry, which contributes to more than a quarter of China’s exports and makes up 16 per cent of national industrial value-added, is “key to stabilising the traditional industry” given its massive size, importance for consumption, broad industry coverage and long supply chain, the Miit says.

site_title:
BOJ tweak stirs yen volatility; US dollar 
stays down after economic data
summary: The Bank of Japan tweaked its yield curve control policy, causing the yen to weaken 1.13% against the US dollar. The decision has raised speculation about a potential shift in the BOJ's massive stimulus program. Meanwhile, US dollar and euro prices rose after new inflation data showed a slowdown in the US, potentially pushing the Federal Reserve closer to ending its interest rate hiking cycle. The dollar index fell 0.049%, while the euro rose 0.42%.

images.alt_text: Japanese 10,000 yen banknotes and U.S. one-hundred dollar banknotes are arranged for a photograph in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, May 31, 2013. Japanese shares fell, with the Topix index deepening its correction, as Nomura Holdings Inc. paced declines among brokerages and a stronger yen weighed on exporters earnings outlook. site_title: Thai election winner’s unwavering policy stance is misstep: poll
summary: Thai Prime Ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat's party, Move Forward, has failed to form a new government due to its unwavering stance on amending the royal insult law. A poll by the National Institute of Development Administration found 43% of respondents view this stance as a key factor in the party's inadequate support. The party won the most seats in the election but faces opposition from pro-establishment parties and the Senate. The constitutional court has also suspended Pita as a lawmaker pending a final verdict on his disqualification.

images.alt_text: Two previous attempts by Move Forward party to have its leader Pita Limjaroenrat endorsed as premier have been blocked by conservative and military-nominated lawmakers.

site_title: Insurers’ Shield portfolios mostly in the black; premiums of private hospital riders rise
summary: Integrated Shield (IP) insurers' portfolios are mostly in the black for 2022, with four insurers' medical expense portfolios showing a surplus. However, claims costs rose as policyholders resumed non-critical procedures, exacerbated by medical and expense inflation. Premiums for IP base plans were frozen for two years between September 2022 and end-August 2024, but private hospital riders saw premium hikes, with some insurers raising rates by 15-38%. Insurers face ongoing challenges, including Singapore's ageing population and advancements in medical treatment.

images.alt_text: Cancer is among the top 5 causes of hospitalisation. Singapore's cancer drug list aims to rein in the cost of cancer drugs and treatment.
National Cancer Centre Singapore, taken on 9 Jun 2022.
Some insurers have reduced terminal bonus rates on par products to the long-term sustainability of the par fund.

site_title: Soft landing optimism is everywhere. That’s happened before
summary: The US economy is experiencing a "soft landing" optimism, with inflation cooling meaningfully, but historically low unemployment and robust hiring. However, Fed staff economists now predict a mild recession late this year, and policymakers have lifted interest rates to a range of 5.25-5.5%, the highest in 22 years. Despite this, growth looks resilient, and there is some historical precedent for comfortable cool-downs. Experts caution that it's difficult to predict what might happen with the economy when rates have risen substantially, and the Fed is keeping its options open to ensure inflation is controlled.

images.alt_text: Ryan Reynolds (centre), pictured here in Disney+'s  Welcome To Wrexham, has an impressive portfolio which included a stake in Mint Mobile that was sold to a major telco for US$1.35 billion this year.

site_title: Asia’s richest families fuel race for lucrative finance jobs
summary: Asia's richest families are fueling a global race for lucrative finance jobs as the region's maturing fortunes drive the growth of family offices. With trillions of investment dollars and top jobs up for grabs, governments are offering residency, luxe living, and low taxes to attract booming family office businesses, especially from Asia. However, the industry faces a talent gap, with 80% of surveyed firms established after 2000, and family offices making unique demands for employees, such as discretion and soft skills. To meet this demand, governments and institutions are launching training programs, including the Singaporean Wealth Management Institute and the Hong Kong Academy for Wealth Legacy, to convert finance executives into discrete and flexible workers.

images.alt_text: Vacancies in India’s office market this year through June fall to the lowest level since the second half of 2020, according to real estate broker Knight Frank, highlighting the sector’s resilience.

SFOs are entitled to a tax exemption on income from investments managed in Singapore provided they meet some criteria, one of which is a minimum investment in Singapore, but market players said SFOs are unlikely to change tack so easily.

site_title: IOC asks Singh to continue as acting head of Olympic Council of Asia
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has asked India's Randhir Singh to continue as acting head of the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) after refusing to recognize the governing body's elections. The IOC banned Kuwait's Sheikh Ahmad Al-Fahad Al-Sabah for three years over allegations of interfering in the election process. Singh will remain in the role until a new election is held.

images.alt_text: Some LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton brands have been official partners of global competitions.

site_title: The US political catalyst for stocks is over; the market rally probably isn’t
summary: US President Joe Biden's re-election campaign may hinder major bill passage, reducing the market's rally momentum. Despite this, global stocks, including the Singapore Straits Times Index, have benefited from the "midterm miracle," a historically profitable nine-month stretch. Since 1925, US stocks have risen 6.3-6.6% in the first half and 5.5% in the second half of a president's third year. Fourth years, like 2024, tend to be strong, with US stocks climbing in 83% of election years. This stability is expected to continue, making it a positive time for world stocks.

images.alt_text: A former US president has never before been ordered to stand trial on federal charges. The fact Trump is also his party’s 2024 frontrunner raises the shocking possibility of a nominee seeking the White House under threat of a prison sentence.
China is a major destination for Singapore's exports, but the former's economy has limited bearing on the latter's stock market.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The VLCC market in the Middle East softened, while Atlantic markets gained. The Capesize market surged on Wednesday, reaching $15,180, with a $3,222 week-on-week increase. Solid volume and active business supported the North Atlantic sector. Deliveries in the Continent/Mediterranean were paid close to $36,000 for Far East runs, and a trans-Pacific voyage is valued at $12,000s per day.

images.alt_text: The Pacific capesize market this week was marked by overall sluggishness, experiencing limited activity.

site_title: Profit figure for Sabana Reit’s manager in ESR Group’s letter ‘factually wrong’: Quarz
summary: Activist investor Quarz Capital disputed ESR Group's profit figure for Sabana Reit's manager, stating it was "factually wrong". According to Quarz, the actual profit should be S$2 million in 2022 and S$1.63 million in 2021, not the reported S$1.26 million. Quarz claims this would result in cost savings for unitholders, while ESR Group argues that cost savings are "grossly overstated" and may lead to increased borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
ESR Group said Quarz claims of a financial upside for unitholders are overestimated.
As the EGM for Sabana Reit's unitholders to vote on a controversial internalisation plan draws near, ESR Group has reiterated points on the dangers of passing the two resolutions by Quarz Capital.
Quarz Capital says that legal and regulatory action might be taken against Sabana Reit's current external manager and its directors if it fails to fulfil its obligations.

The Reit's increases in gross revenue and NPI were however partially offset by higher borrowing costs, trust expenses, and finance costs after conducting its recent equity fundraising exercise which resulted in an enlarged unit base.

site_title: Sunak backs plans for new UK oil and gas exploration
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has backed plans for new oil and gas exploration off Britain's coast, including the development of Rosebank near Scotland's Shetland Isles. Sunak said the development would support the UK's energy industry and avoid "the lights going out" in Britain, despite criticism from environmental campaigners and opposition parties. He argued that stopping new fossil fuel exploitation would weaken energy security and strengthen the hands of dictators like Vladimir Putin.

images.alt_text: Britain’s government is looking to boost domestic hydrocarbon output as Europe weans itself off Russian fuel, but climate activists have criticised the licensing round and Greenpeace is working on a legal challenge.

site_title: Vibrant activity among top traded stocks on SGX
summary: About a quarter of Singapore's 100 most actively traded stocks have seen double-digit percentage growth in daily trading turnover from 2022 levels, with 23 stocks averaging S$202 million in daily shares traded. Seatrium, a rebranded company from the merger of Sembcorp Marine and Keppel Offshore & Marine, has significantly increased its trading volume and market capitalization, while Food Empire Holdings and Delfi have also seen substantial price gains. The 23 stocks have generated combined net institutional inflow of S$395 million.

images.alt_text: Overall SGX-listed stocks have booked S$2.8 billion of net institutional fund outflow and S$1.4 billion of net retail inflow in the 2023 year to Jul 18.

site_title: Why we should pity the Bank of England
summary: The Bank of England faces a challenging monetary policy landscape, with a more bumpy inflation path, greater political criticism, and faltering growth momentum for the UK economy. Despite recent positive inflation data, the UK still holds the highest inflation rate among G7 economies at 7.9%. The Bank of England has seen 12 consecutive interest rate hikes but still struggles with forecasting and policy guidance, and has announced an external review of its processes. The central bank's position is further complicated by factors such as labor market resistance, post-Brexit trade disruptions, and limited government support for supply-side enhancement.

images.alt_text: People along a street in the Omotesando area in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Dec. 9, 2022. Economists forecast that Japan’s economy will return to growth again this quarter, pushed up by private sector investment and consumption. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
Britain’s intensifying mortgage squeeze threatens to tip an already stagnant economy into recession and deepen wealth divides that cut across generations and incomes.
The Fed’s benchmark overnight interest rate now stands in the 5.25 per cent-5.50 per cent range

site_title:
Shipping giant CMA CGM paints 
gloomy outlook as profit plummets
summary: CMA CGM, the world's third-largest container line, reported a 83% decline in second-quarter net income to US$1.3 billion, down from a record US$7.6 billion in the same period last year. The shipping giant painted a gloomy outlook for the industry, citing weak freight rates and a persistent slump in US demand for goods out of China. The company expects sluggish economic growth and inflation to impact consumer spending for the rest of the year, further hurting rates. Deliveries of new vessels may also exacerbate the issue.

images.alt_text: Greater data sharing can accelerate progress in decarbonisation in the maritime sector.

site_title: Kanye West has X account reinstated after months-long suspension
summary: Kanye West's X account has been reinstated after an eight-month suspension. The musician's account was reinstated following reassurance from X that he would not use the platform to share harmful language. The suspension was initially imposed in December after West shared an image combining the Star of David and a swastika, which was deemed a breach of X's rule against incitement to violence. The reinstated account will not be eligible for monetization and will not display advertisements.

images.alt_text: In cutting ties with Ye, formerly Kanye West, Adidas will take a €250 million ($246.5 million) hit to net income in the current fiscal year.

site_title: China moves to bolster consumer industries, grow fledgling bourse
summary: China has introduced measures to boost economic growth, focusing on consumer industries and small firms. The government aims to accelerate growth in the light industry, which contributes 16% of national industrial value-added, to 4% by the end of next year. Plans include loosening market maker limits on the Beijing Stock Exchange and providing funding support for breakthroughs in sectors like smart manufacturing. The move follows a series of policies to revive the economy, which has weakened due to the property market slump and decreased consumer spending.

images.alt_text: An aerial view shows flooding in Fuzhou after Typhoon Doksuri made landfall and brought heavy rainfall to Fujian province; Flood control officials upgraded their emergency response order to level two, the second highest in their four-tier system, for Beijing and Tianjin and the provinces of Hebei, Shanxi and Henan on Sunday.

site_title: Banks vote to limit accounting of emissions in bond and stock sales: sources
summary: Banks have voted to limit accounting of emissions in bond and stock sales, with the majority backing a plan to exclude two-thirds of emissions linked to their capital markets businesses from their carbon footprint. The decision, which excludes 33% of emissions, pits banks against environmental advocates who argue the industry should assume full responsibility for emissions generated by activities financed through bonds and stock sales. The move will impact banks' targets for becoming carbon-neutral, with many pledging to bring their emissions down to zero on a net basis by 2050.

images.alt_text: Rising temperatures are disrupting economic activity and daily life across the globe, sapping crops, drying rivers and raising sea levels.

site_title: Arab states sour on Israel in blow to US aim of Saudi peace pact
summary: Arab states, including the UAE and Bahrain, are souring on Israel, three years after historic peace deals, due to concerns over Israel's deteriorating relations with Palestinians. The US aims to integrate the region with Saudi Arabia, but strains are complicating this goal. Saudi Arabia has privately asked for firm defense guarantees, access to US weaponry, and a green light for its nuclear program. Economic ties between Israel and the UAE are expanding, with bilateral commercial flows expected to reach $3 billion this year. Despite this, opinion polls show support for the Abraham Accords has plummeted in the Gulf.

images.alt_text: People demonstrate as a response to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his nationalist coalition government's judicial overhaul, at Ben Gurion International Airport in Lod, Israel July 11, 2023. REUTERS/Amir Cohen

site_title: Stop going it alone
summary: A new study found that a strong leader's centralized approach to organizational change can be detrimental to the company's success. Researchers at KleanCo, a FTSE 100 company, discovered that employees' emotional responses to the CEO's authority went through four stages: compliance, ambivalence, fragmentation, and engagement. As the organization's performance declined, the CEO's authority was questioned, leading to increased anxiety and resistance. To mitigate this, new CEOs should focus on building coalitions, listening to stakeholders, harnessing team diversity, and celebrating milestones to foster engagement and collective leadership.

images.alt_text: What’s stopping some Singapore companies from allowing employees to work from home?
While posturing can help one in the short term to build up confidence, cracks will start to appear in the long run if one does not have the capability required.

site_title: Worldcoin crypto already under scrutiny in Europe
summary: Worldcoin, a cryptocurrency project led by OpenAI's Sam Altman, is under scrutiny in Europe due to its reliance on eye scans to verify user identities, potentially violating strict data privacy rules. France's data protection agency, Cnil, has initiated a probe, and the German state of Bavaria is leading the investigation. Worldcoin aims to create a "world's largest identity and financial public network" using its blockchain technology, which could increase economic opportunity and democratic processes. The project's use of biometric data raises concerns about data privacy and regulation in the European Union.

images.alt_text: "The focus [among Telegram trading bots] is usually on low-market-cap coins, meme coins, and others with low volume," says Philipp Zentner, CEO at cross-chain liquidity routing firm Li.Fi.

site_title: Banks, even state banks, are untold story of Ukraine’s survival
summary: Ukraine's state banks have played a crucial role in the country's survival during the war, providing financing to households and companies despite a 30% collapse in GDP. Despite concerns about the financial system's stability, state banks have remained profitable, with the weighted average of capital adequacy ratios increasing to 14.3%. However, the central bank wants to privatize all state lenders except Ukreximbank once the war ends to avoid distorting competition. The IMF has warned of the risk of blow-ups, but state banks have helped companies like Citius-S and AMP Hydro recover from the war.

site_title: Singapore carbon exchange CIX sticks with Cambodian project amid human rights review
summary: Climate Impact X (CIX), a Singapore-based carbon exchange, has decided to keep credits from a suspended Cambodian project in its flagship contract, Nature X, amid human rights allegations. The project, Southern Cardamom, was suspended by certification body Verra in June due to concerns raised by Human Rights Watch. CIX is taking a wait-and-see approach, allowing the verifier's review to run its course, and has not removed the credits from the Nature X basket. The decision has led to a decline in the value of Southern Cardamom credits, with a 31% drop since June.

images.alt_text: Lush forests seen at the Southern Cardamom Redd+ project, which protects 497,000 hectares of tropical rainforest in South-west Cambodia. The project is one of 11 whose credits are included in the Nature X contract.

site_title: Four-day weeks are good for employee health, study suggests
summary: A year after launching a four-day workweek pilot, research from 4 Day Week Global found that employees' average workweek dropped to less than 33 hours, with benefits to physical and mental health, and work-life balance continuing to improve. Companies found ways to save time by being more efficient, and the study suggests that the benefits may last and grow stronger over time. Employee burnout rates increased, but job satisfaction remained higher than before, with almost a third of employees saying they're less likely to leave due to the shorter schedule.

images.alt_text: Employers can provide workers access to confidential counselling services or partnerships with external mental health providers.
Politicians have gotten in on Barbie-mania, with Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer posting photos of a Barbie meant to resemble herself online.

site_title: Citigroup to track UK office attendance for identifying hybrid holdouts
summary: Citigroup will begin tracking UK office attendance to monitor the effectiveness of its hybrid work policy, with managers using data to determine employee effectiveness and potential disciplinary action for consistent absences. The tracking will start on August 7 and will include aggregated data every two weeks for London, Edinburgh, and Belfast offices. Employees with persistent, unexplained absences will be targeted, with acceptable reasons for absences including site capacity limitations, business travel, and annual leave.

images.alt_text: The moves are all part of Citigroup’s plans to improve its ratio of revenue to risk-weighted assets.

site_title: UK second-home owners may see tax double from 2025
summary: The UK government is planning to allow local councils to double property taxes for second-home owners in 2025 to help finance the construction of one million new affordable homes. Around 25% of England's local councils have already agreed to the move, which could bring in £200 million in annual revenues. The tax hike is part of the government's bill to regenerate local economies and help address the country's affordable housing shortage.

site_title: Vietnam exports post longest stretch of declines since 2009
summary: Vietnam's exports dropped 3.5% in July, marking the country's longest stretch of declines since 2009, and the fifth consecutive month of decline. Imports also fell 9.9% during the same period. Economists had predicted a 6% drop in overseas shipments and a 13.1% slide in imports. The country's inflation rate remained steady at 2.06% in July, giving the central bank room to reduce borrowing costs and support businesses. Vietnam's economy is at risk of missing its 6.5% growth target this year.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s banks are expected to experience non-payment from commercial real estate loans and property-related bonds they hold, said S&P Global Ratings in a report.

site_title: Cost savings from internalisation of Sabana Reit’s manager ‘grossly overstated’: ESR Group
summary: ESR Group has disputed claims by activist investor Quarz that internalizing Sabana Reit's manager will result in significant cost savings for unitholders. ESR argues that potential cost savings will be offset by higher debt costs, which could increase borrowing costs by 1 percentage point, resulting in an additional S$3 million in interest each year. The group believes unitholders will be worse off on an ongoing basis.

images.alt_text: Quarz Capital says that legal and regulatory action might be taken against Sabana Reit's current external manager and its directors if it fails to fulfil its obligations.

site_title: China upgrades flood warning for Beijing, other northern areas
summary: China has upgraded its flood warning to level two for Beijing, Tianjin, and several northern provinces due to heavy rain from Typhoon Doksuri. Over 27,000 people in Beijing have been evacuated, and officials are urging residents to stay indoors unless necessary. The situation is described as "extremely severe and complex" due to poor river discharge capability. Officials are working to ensure no deaths and minimize economic losses, with evacuations and monitoring of mines and construction sites underway.

images.alt_text: An aerial view shows flooding in Fuzhou after Typhoon Doksuri made landfall and brought heavy rainfall, in Fujian province, China July 29, 2023. cnsphoto via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT.
China’s rain and floods come as several other parts of the world have been seeing similar disastrous downpours.

site_title:
Hospitality trusts report 
higher DPU for H1 2023
summary: Thirteen Singapore Reits announced H1 2023 financial results, with 5 trusts reporting higher year-over-year (yoy) distribution per unit (DPU) compared to the same period last year. Hospitality trusts Far East Hospitality, CDL Hospitality, and CapitaLand Ascott Trust saw average DPU increase 22% yoy, while ParkwayLife Reit and Keppel DC Reit also reported higher yoy DPU. Other Reits, such as Keppel DC Reit, attributed stable distributable income to new acquisitions, renewals, and tax savings.

images.alt_text: Sabana Reit's H1 2023 gross revenue is up by 23.2 per cent year on year  to S$55.3 million and net property income rises by 0.5 per cent yoy to S$27.2 million.

site_title: Where investors fear to tread, will angels step in?
summary: Angel investors, who inject capital into early-stage startups, face significant risks due to the high potential for startup failure. Despite the allure of lucrative returns, investors are becoming increasingly cautious due to aggressive rate hikes and concerns over weak growth. To mitigate these risks, diversification is key, with research showing that spreading investments across multiple startups can improve outcomes. Angel networks, which bring together individuals with diverse backgrounds and expertise, can also provide valuable support and mentoring to portfolio companies, helping to reduce risks and increase potential returns.

images.alt_text: VC firms in South-east Asia raised US$3.72 billion in the first half of this year, less than half the amount raised a year ago.
Some of the biggest private equity firms, including Apollo Global Management and Blackstone, have developed massive private-credit operations.
Multiple tales of breakthrough have echoed through the startup ecosystem, making any decision to shutter a tough one for founders to make.

site_title: Swiss fans pay most to see Taylor Swift
summary: Taylor Swift's Eras tour tickets in Zurich will be the most expensive in Europe, costing 167.50 Swiss francs ($256). This is significantly higher than in Warsaw, where tickets will cost about 43 francs. The high production costs in Switzerland are cited as the reason for the higher prices.

Fans queueing for Taylor Swift concert tickets. Even before tickets went on sale, prices for hotels and flights to Singapore were already soaring for Swift's tour dates.

site_title: Montreal’s C$7 billion rail line starts up in test case for Canada’s pension manager
summary: Canada's C$402 billion pension manager, Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec (CDPQ), has completed a $7 billion Montreal rail line, the Reseau Express Metropolitain (REM), after years of delays and cost overruns. The project, which was initially budgeted at $5 billion, was completed with the financial backing of CDPQ and government investments. The REM's performance will determine whether it was a successful experiment or the start of a new business line for CDPQ. A second phase of the system is expected to begin next year, and the airport station is expected to be ready by 2027.

images.alt_text: Flix, set up in 2011 by three entrepreneurs in Munich to try to make bus travel cheap, runs bus and train services across 40 countries.

site_title: Michael Learns to Rock concert to help raise funds for Dementia Singapore
summary: Michael Learns to Rock is set to perform at Dementia Singapore's fundraising concert on Sep 9, with all proceeds going towards supporting people with dementia and caregivers. The event aims to raise awareness and promote inclusiveness, featuring a dance therapy programme and stalls with resources for dementia support. The concert is part of Dementia Singapore's Back to the Heartlands outreach campaign, which aims to engage communities in the heartlands. Tickets have sold out, but donations can be made via dementia.org.sg/donate.

images.alt_text: Young performers sang and danced their hearts out at the ChildAid 2022 concert. This year's ChildAid, however, will be different: It will be a musical dinner theatre where the guest solve a mystery.
