The whey protein in Perfect Day's Very Dairy milk is made in a lab, using a bioengineered form of the fungus Trichoderma reesei.
The days of unicorns running rampant may well be over.

site_title: China’s domestic tourism to hit 90% of pre-Covid levels in 2023
summary: China's domestic tourism is expected to reach 90% of pre-Covid levels in 2023, with 5.5 billion trips anticipated and revenue reaching 5 trillion yuan. Travel demand has surged since Covid-related restrictions were lifted, with the Labour Day holiday and Dragon Boat Festival driving growth. Outbound tourism is also expected to expand, with East Asia and South-east Asia remaining main destinations, while West Asia, Africa, and Belt & Road countries gain popularity. However, international flights and visa difficulties may limit the rebound.

images.alt_text: Visas which have been issued to Singapore citizens are still valid and visa applications that have been lodged before will be processed normally.

site_title: Resale condo prices flat in June, volume down 19.7%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore condominium resale prices remained flat in June, increasing 0.1% month-on-month and 8.5% year-on-year. Resale volumes fell 19.7% to 778 units, with the Outside Central Region recording the highest percentage of transactions. Prices in the Core Central Region slipped 2.6%, while the Rest of Central Region and Outside Central Region saw increases of 1.2% and 0.4%, respectively. Experts attribute the muted market to the school holidays and a wide price expectation gap between buyers and sellers.

images.alt_text: Mortgagee listings in the second quarter of 2023 was down 35.7 per cent to 18, from 28 in the previous quarter.
All the top loss-making deals, by both quantum and percentage, in the second quarter of this year were in Singapore's prime core central region.
Developers sold less private homes in June 2023.
Huttons Asia has found that first owners of ECs tend to sell for higher average gross gains.
HDB resale prices continue to rise 0.6 per cent in June, but volumes were down.

site_title: HK says US should invite Lee to summit after report he’s barred
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee is barred from attending an Apec summit in the US due to US sanctions, citing his role in the city's crackdown on civil liberties. Hong Kong and China have criticized the move, with Beijing saying it "strongly disapproves" and China calling for the US to allow Lee to attend. The ban could exacerbate tensions between the US and China, and has raised concerns about the impact on Hong Kong's freedoms and the presence of Western tech firms in the city.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, China. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia to curb online sales of foreign goods under US$100
summary: Indonesia plans to limit online sales of imported goods below US$100, aiming to protect small and medium enterprises. The move, announced by Trade Minister Zulkifli Hasan, applies to online marketplaces and social media retailers. The country's e-commerce sector reached US$59 billion last year and is expected to grow to US$95 billion by 2025. The new rules, set to take effect by August 1, also require imported goods to obtain a supplementary licence. This follows President Joko Widodo's concerns about predatory pricing for cheap, Chinese-made goods.

images.alt_text: TikTok has in recent months been aggressively courting South-east Asia for its e-commerce business.

site_title: Japan yields hit 9-year high, yen gains after 'stealth' BOJ policy shift
summary: Japan's benchmark bond yield surged to a 9-year high of 0.575% and the yen rallied against the dollar after the Bank of Japan's decision to conduct its yield curve control policy more flexibly. The BOJ allowed the 10-year yield to move 0.5% around the 0% target, but with "references" rather than rigid limits. This move widened the 10-year target band and led to a 1.05% gain for the yen. The Nikkei share average declined 2.6% but the Tokyo Stock Exchange's banking index surged 4.6% on the prospect of a steeper yield curve.

images.alt_text: The BOJ’s meeting comes after the Federal Reserve’s decision on Wednesday to raise interest rates

site_title: Less than half of Apac’s H1 losses from natural disasters were insured: Munich Re
summary: Munich Re reported that natural disasters in the Asia-Pacific region resulted in $7 billion in losses in the first half of 2023, with only $3 billion insured. Flooding and landfall in New Zealand, particularly, accounted for most of the losses, with $2.9 billion insured out of $4.3 billion in assets destroyed.

images.alt_text: Rhodes is a hugely popular holiday destination, particularly with visitors from Britain.
According to Pfizer, the Rocky Mount manufacturing site makes about 25 per cent of the sterile injectables used at US hospitals.
Natural disasters destroyed assets worth more than US$140 billion in the United States last year, of which close to US$90 billion was insured.
Aon estimates 1,739 lives were lost in Pakistan’s monsoonal floods and over 33 million people were affected.

site_title: Retail sector on the road to recovery as tourism rebounds
summary: Singapore's retail sector is showing signs of recovery, with retail space rents in the central region increasing by 0.3% in Q2 2023, reversing five consecutive quarters of decline. Tourism and consumer spending have recovered, with the retail sales index remaining positive. Prime retail spaces, particularly in Orchard, are expected to see rental growth of 4-5% in 2023, driven by the tourism recovery and growing wealth in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Rents for offices in Singapore's central region grew 2.3 per cent quarter on quarter, slowing from the 5.1 per cent rise in Q1.
Located at 545 Orchard Road, the 999-year shopping centre sits on a site spanning 36,014 square feet zoned for commercial use.

epa10747804 Inditex founder Amancio Ortega attends the Casas Novas International Jumping Contest at the Coruna council of Arteixo in Galicia region, north-western Spain, 15 July 2023.  EPA-EFE/Cabalar

site_title: Binance and its CEO seek dismissal of CFTC complaint
summary: Binance and its CEO Changpeng Zhao have filed a motion to dismiss a complaint by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) alleging violations of US laws and operating an "illegal" exchange. The CFTC claims Binance offered and executed commodity derivatives transactions on behalf of US persons from July 2019, but Binance argues it restricted and off-boarded potential US users and only offered the alleged products after July 2019. Binance also cites a 2007 ruling stating US law does not govern the world.

images.alt_text: “Binance confirms it has proactively withdrawn its BaFin (Germany’s financial regulator) application. The situation, both in the global market and regulation, has changed significantly,” a spokesperson for the company says.
Most crypto companies dispute the SEC’s jurisdiction, and have pushed Congress in recent months to write laws clarifying that cryptocurrencies are more akin to commodities than securities.
Binance has taken some steps to expand its Asian footprint elsewhere too, including in South Korea and Thailand.

site_title: Air France-KLM posts higher Q2 profit
summary: Air France-KLM reported a higher-than-expected quarterly profit of 733 million euros, driven by an increase in passengers carried and lower jet fuel prices. The carrier welcomed 24.7 million passengers between April and June, with its capacity standing at 92% of 2019 levels. This summer's situation at airports is better than last year, following strikes and staff shortages. The company's operating margin increased to 9.6% due to higher yields.

images.alt_text: An Air France-KLM aircraft takes off from Toulouse-Blagnac Airport in Toulouse, France.Photographer: Matthieu Rondel/Bloomberg

site_title: China asks tech giants to showcase investments in sign of easing
summary: China has asked its largest technology companies, including Tencent Holdings and Meituan, to provide case studies of their most successful startup investments in consumer, telecom, and media companies, a sign of easing regulatory crackdowns. This move marks a pivot from the government's guidance of the past few years, encouraging Chinese tech firms to back consumer-facing companies. The request comes as China seeks to rebuild confidence in the private sector and rescue its post-Covid economic recovery.

images.alt_text: “Residents’ consumption capacity is insufficient and their willingness to spend is not strong, consumption of big-ticket items is weak,” says China’s National Financial Regulatory Administration.

site_title: Why China’s new central bank chief will defy the easy tags
summary: China's new central bank chief, Pan Gongsheng, is likened to a hawk due to his past regulatory steps, but his true policy stance may be different. Unlike other central bankers, who are often pigeonholed as hawks or doves, Pan's decisions are driven by circumstance, not preconceived notions. China's economy is struggling, with low inflation and stagnant growth, and Pan's predecessor, Yi Gang, had reduced interest rates and reserve requirements to stimulate the economy. Pan's own past actions, such as curbs on the property market, suggest he is willing to take tough steps to mitigate financial risks.

images.alt_text: The BOJ’s meeting comes after the Federal Reserve’s decision on Wednesday to raise interest rates
FILE PHOTO: People's Bank of China (PBOC) Deputy Governor Pan Gongsheng speaks at a news conference in Beijing, China March 3, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Local government debt burdens – which have climbed because of the property market slump that reduced their income – have slowed government spending growth this year.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel Reit hits 16-day low after Keppel says it will distribute units
summary: Keppel Reit's units fell 3.2% in early trading after Keppel Corp announced it will distribute Reit's units to mark its 55th anniversary. The move is part of a larger distribution plan, with each five Keppel Corp shares entitling shareholders to one Reit unit and a cash dividend of S$0.33 per share. The Reit's counter hit a 16-day low, closing at S$0.89.

site_title: Fox likely to push Emmys to January due to strikes: reports
summary: FOX is reportedly set to reschedule the Emmy Awards ceremony from September 18 to January due to ongoing strikes by US writers and actors. The strikes, which began in May, have disrupted numerous TV shows and movies. A resolution to disputes between studios and guilds is contingent on the rescheduled date. The nominations for the highest television honors were announced just before the strikes, and the ceremony's delay was expected. FOX declined to comment, while the Television Academy did not immediately respond to the news.

site_title: Banks to charge for use of Singdollar cheques by Nov 1, to stop taking corporate cheques by end-2025
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority has introduced new rules requiring banks to charge for the use of Singdollar cheques by November 1. Seven major banks will start charging corporate cheque issuers, with other banks to follow by July 1, 2024. The rules aim to reduce cheque-processing costs amid declining cheque usage. The use of corporate cheques will be eliminated by the end of 2025, with individual cheque users still allowed to use them beyond that year.

images.alt_text: With amendments made to regulations governing the nomination of beneficiaries, insurers will be able to provide digital means to replace the current process of hard-copy submissions with in-person witnessing, says the Monetary Authority of Singapore.
Although the increase in the cap could lead to a “substantial rise” in GXS and MariBank’s deposit holdings, this still dwarfs in comparison to Singapore’s trio of local banks, Fitch Ratings said.

site_title: AEM to settle ‘confidential’ arbitration with US$20 million payment
summary: AEM Holdings, a semiconductor equipment maker, has agreed to pay US$20 million to settle a legal dispute with two US companies, Advantest America and Advantest Test Solutions. The settlement, reached without any findings or admissions of a breach or liability, will be made in two installments: US$9 million in the third quarter and US$11 million in Q3 2024. The company's CEO stated that the settlement will not disrupt its operations or product offerings, and aims to clarify its competitive position in the market.

images.alt_text: AEM chief executive Chandran Nair said the company is accelerating development of Test 2.0 solutions, which will be its key driver of growth in the coming years.
The brokerage has revised its forecast earnings estimates for AEM upwards by 30 per cent for FY2023 as the company’s inventories and visibility improve.
Semiconductor equipment maker AEM on Friday reported second half-year earnings of S$44 million, down 30 per cent from S$62.4 million the previous year.

site_title: Asia-Pacific private capital fundraising could hit decade-low in 2023: Preqin
summary: Asia-Pacific private capital fundraising could hit its lowest level in a decade in 2023, according to a report by Preqin. Private equity (PE) fundraising by Asia-Pacific-focused funds increased marginally in Q2, but the total for the first half of 2023 is only 22% of last year's funds. PE-backed deal activity in the region continued to dwindle, with a 38.2% decrease in total deal value to $20.1 billion in Q2. Venture capital (VC) fundraising also fell to a five-year low, with $4.5 billion raised in Q2. Preqin attributes the decline to economic uncertainties, geopolitical tensions, and a weak exit environment.

images.alt_text: In the year to Jul 3, dry powder levels were up 11.2 per cent.
The number of private equity deals fall 23.3 per cent to 46.
The Asia-Pacific witnessed the second-highest private equity deal values in June, with 258 transactions totalling US$7.1 billion.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop after Wall Street loss, yen rises ahead of BOJ
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday following a Wall Street sell-off, as concerns over the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes and speculation about the Bank of Japan's monetary policy shift sent investors into a cautious mood. The yen rose ahead of a potential BOJ policy change, while Tokyo and Hong Kong lost over 1% in morning trade. Investors are worried about Japanese investors repatriating their cash, which could lead to a surge in the yen and a decline in stocks.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong up more than one per cent, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington and Jakarta were also well up.

site_title: China’s housing minister urges efforts to strengthen property recovery
summary: China's housing minister, Ni Hong, urged efforts to strengthen the property recovery by implementing measures such as lower home mortgage rates and down payment ratios for first-time home buyers. The minister promised to ensure the delivery of presold homes and consider mortgage rates based on the number of houses owned rather than previous loan records. The announcement sparked a rally in property shares, with the China CSI Real Estate index rising 2% on Friday. The move aims to address the country's severe debt crisis and promote economic recovery.

images.alt_text: It is unclear how many Chinese have had their pay cut this year, but economists warn the high-profile examples are further weighing on already fragile consumer confidence

epa10771144 Indonesian President Joko Widodo (C) and First Lady Iriana Widodo (R) arrive in Chengdu, capital of southwest China's Sichuan Province, 27 July 2023. President Widodo arrived in Chengdu to attend the opening ceremony of the 31st summer edition of the FISU World University Games and a visit to China.  EPA-EFE/XINHUA / Jiang Hongjing CHINA OUT / UK AND IRELAND OUT  /       MANDATORY CREDIT  EDITORIAL USE ONLY

site_title: Toyota’s global sales rise 5.1% to 4.9 million in first half of 2023
summary: Toyota reported a 5.1% increase in global sales to 4.9 million vehicles in the first half of 2023, driven by easing semiconductor supply constraints and stronger demand in Japan. Sales in Japan jumped 33.2% to 878,215 units, while US sales declined 0.7% to 1 million vehicles. Global hybrid electric vehicle sales grew 37.6% to 292,131 units, accounting for nearly a third of total sales. Toyota sold 10,191 battery electric vehicles in June, bringing the total to 46,171 units for the first half.

images.alt_text: The joint venture between Toyota and China’s state-owned Guangzhou Automobile Group (GAC) lays off the workers over the weekend and offers them compensation.

site_title: Chipmakers signal supply glut easing but demand recovery still slow
summary: Global chipmakers, including Intel and Samsung, are celebrating a decline in the semiconductor supply glut, but demand recovery remains slow due to weak global economy, high inflation, and rising interest rates. The smartphone and PC markets have shrunk, leading to a record operating loss for memory chipmakers. Demand for AI-related chips is recovering, but at a gradual pace, with chipmakers increasing production of high-end chips. A sluggish recovery in China, the world's largest chip buyer, is also dampening the outlook.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers monitor microchip production in the clean room at the UTAC plant in Singapore February 8, 2018.   REUTERS/Thomas White/File Photo

site_title: Meta plans retention ‘hooks’ for Threads as more than half of users leave app
summary: Meta is revamping its Twitter rival Threads to boost user retention, after the app lost more than half of its users following its launch. CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the drop-off was "normal" and expected retention to grow with added features, including a desktop version and search functionality. The company is also exploring "retention-driving hooks" to entice users to return, such as integrating Threads with Instagram. Meta's shares surged 8% after the company reported a rosy revenue growth forecast, and Zuckerberg emphasized the need to invest in metaverse technology to stay ahead of rivals.

site_title: China Evergrande’s rise, massive default and debt restructuring
summary: China Evergrande Group, a major property developer, is undergoing a massive debt restructuring after being declared in default in 2021. The company's heavy borrowing fueled its growth, but the Chinese government stepped in to oversee the rescue, averting a potential economic collapse. Evergrande's restructuring plan proposes new debt instruments, with average recovery rates for bondholders expected to be around 22.5%. The company's finances show significant losses, with $81 billion in combined losses for 2021 and 2022, and a debt pile of nearly $360 billion. The government may still intervene, but the prospect of a full bailout appears unlikely.

images.alt_text: Evergrande NEV’s net loss is 56.27 billion yuan for 2021 and net loss from continuing operations is 14.85 billion yuan for 2022.
The company’s struggles helped set off the initial wave of concerns about China’s property sector.
Evergrande’s financial woes even started to affect operations at the building, which sits in Hong Kong’s busy Wan Chai district.
Evergrande has asked to convene meetings for offshore creditors to approve its credit overhaul plan, after reporting long-delayed financial statements for 2021 and 2022.

site_title: StanChart raises income forecast, adds US$1 billion buyback
summary: Standard Chartered raised its income forecast for 2023, citing a 27% rise in adjusted pretax profit to $1.6 billion in the second quarter. The bank expects income to increase 12-14% for 2023, up from 10%, and announced a new $1 billion share buyback program. The lender's profits were boosted by a strong performance in transaction banking amid rising interest rates. CEO Bill Winters said the bank remains "strongly profitable, highly liquid, and well capitalized."

images.alt_text: Bill Winters, chief executive officer of Standard Chartered Plc, during a Bloomberg Television interview on the sidelines of the Qatar Economic Forum (QEF) in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday, May 23, 2023. The third Qatar Economic Forum will shine a light on the rising south-to-south economy and the new growth opportunities it presents to the global business community. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,347.78 on Friday, driven by gains in banking stocks, despite a mixed performance in US markets. The rally followed a 13-day win streak for the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which slipped 0.7% on Thursday amid interest rate concerns. Local stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and Singapore Airlines, led gains, while Seatrium fell 4.8% and Keppel Real Estate Investment Trust declined 1.6%.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks extend gains amid bets Fed rate hikes likely over; STI up 1%
Singapore Airlines' Q1 net profit is at a record quarterly high.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB expects iFast’s ePension project to go as planned, upgrades to ‘hold’
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded its call on iFast to "hold" from "reduce" and raised its price target to S$4.90, citing the company's ePension project's strong progress and earnings visibility. The project, designed for Hong Kong Monetary Provident Fund schemes, is expected to be fully operational in 2025. Analysts expect iFast's banking division to remain loss-making, but the ePension project's potential revenue inflow could boost the company's earnings.

images.alt_text: Lim Chung Chun co-founded iFast with the launch of its business-to-consumer division Fundsupermart.com in Singapore in 2000, following which the business-to-consumer division iFast Financial was launched in 2001.

Lim Chung Chun, chief executive of iFast was named Outstanding CEO of the year, for his leadership in growing the company into a regional fintech network with over S$18 billion in assets under administration (AUA).
iFast office in George Town, Penang, Malaysia on Aug 20, 2022.

Going into 2024, chief executive Lim Chung Chun said iFast will also be in a position to boost its dividend payouts to shareholders, as the group’s overall cash flow starts to improve “quite significantly”.

site_title: Gold braces for biggest weekly decline in five
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% this week, nearing its biggest weekly decline in five, due to higher US interest rates and Treasury bond yields. The US economy's stronger-than-expected growth in the second quarter may keep interest rate hikes, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold. Analysts have lowered their gold price forecasts for 2023, and other precious metals, including silver and platinum, are also expected to decline.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: BOJ keeps low rates, makes yield control policy more flexible
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained ultra-low interest rates, keeping its short-term interest rate target at -0.1% and 10-year government bond yield around 0%. However, the central bank made its yield curve control policy more flexible by allowing the 10-year yield to move 0.5% around the 0% target, rather than a "rigid limit". The BOJ also adjusted its fixed-rate bond buying operations to 1.0% from 0.5%. The decision comes amid concerns over the rising side-effects of prolonged monetary easing and inflation holding above the 2% target for over a year.

images.alt_text: The increase was driven mostly by stubbornly high food prices in a sign of the strain households are feeling from rising living costs.
Pressure is building on the BOJ to act against creeping inflation.

site_title: South Korea June factory output falls more than expected
summary: South Korea's factory production fell 1.0% in June, exceeding expectations, with automobiles declining 12.9% and oil refining dropping 14.6%. However, semiconductor production rose 3.6% over the month. This marks the fastest loss in four months, with the industrial output index also falling 5.6% over the past year. The data contrasts with economists' expectations of a 5.5% fall.

site_title: Australia retail sales squeezed hard as consumer belts tighten
summary: Australia's retail sales plummeted 0.8% in June, the largest drop this year, as consumers' spending power was squeezed by rising borrowing costs and high prices. Producer prices rose at their slowest pace since early 2021, fuelling hopes for cooling consumer prices, leading investors to expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to keep interest rates at 4.1% for a second month. This decision would be a relief, as rates have climbed 400 basis points since May and added hundreds to mortgage repayments.

images.alt_text: Employment strength has been a key factor in the RBA’s confidence that Australia can avoid a recession

site_title: Private home prices slip 0.2% in Q2, rental increase slows
summary: Singapore's private home prices slipped 0.2% in Q2, marking the first decline in three years. Despite this, overall prices are still up 7.5% year-over-year. Rental increases slowed to 2.8% in Q2, with some property consultants predicting a correction in rents in the second half of the year. The vacancy rate rose to 6.3% due to increased completions, and 11,810 private homes are projected to be completed in H2 this year, alleviating tight supply.

images.alt_text: The second-quarter decline, based on the flash estimate, is the first drop in the price index since Q1 2020 as price momentum eased across all market segments, URA says.
Developers sold less private homes in June 2023.
The Jalan Tembusu site, for private housing development, is near the future Tanjong Katong MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.

site_title:
HDB resale prices rise by modest 1.5% in Q2, 
but volumes fall 6.7%
summary: HDB resale prices rose 1.5% in Q2, the smallest quarterly increase since 2022, amid measures to moderate demand and encourage prudent borrowing. The modest increase may indicate that prices have peaked, with buyers turning to the Build-to-Order (BTO) market for more choices. Resale volumes fell 6.7% to 6,514 units, the lowest since 2020, due to seasonal factors and the introduction of the HFE letter of approval. Experts predict prices may rise 4-6% in 2023, driven by first-time buyers seeking resale flats.

images.alt_text: HDB resale prices continue to rise 0.6 per cent in June, but volumes were down.

Resale prices rose 1.4 per cent from the first quarter. Although this was higher than the 0.9 per cent growth recorded in the first quarter, the Q2 price increase was still lower than the 2022 average quarterly growth of 2.5 per cent.
Resale prices have increased for the 13th consecutive quarter, with 105 flats changing hands for at least S$1 million in Q2.

site_title: White-collar wage cuts in China fuel deflation risks, hurt consumption
summary: China's high-profile wage cuts are fueling deflation risks and hurting consumer confidence, with economists warning that fragile consumer confidence could lead to a self-feeding deflationary spiral. White-collar workers, including credit card salespeople and hospital staff, have seen their pay cut, with some experiencing a 40% decrease. The cuts are part of China's slowing economy, which is complicating efforts to boost workers' incomes and revive household consumption. Economists warn that weak bargaining power among workers and financial insecurity among consumers are exacerbating the issue, potentially derailing the country's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: China’s pledge this week to step up stimulus measures to shore up the economy provides some hope for investors, but it’s too early to say what impact it could have on foreign money inflows.

epa10771144 Indonesian President Joko Widodo (C) and First Lady Iriana Widodo (R) arrive in Chengdu, capital of southwest China's Sichuan Province, 27 July 2023. President Widodo arrived in Chengdu to attend the opening ceremony of the 31st summer edition of the FISU World University Games and a visit to China.  EPA-EFE/XINHUA / Jiang Hongjing CHINA OUT / UK AND IRELAND OUT  /       MANDATORY CREDIT  EDITORIAL USE ONLY
“Residents’ consumption capacity is insufficient and their willingness to spend is not strong, consumption of big-ticket items is weak,” says China’s National Financial Regulatory Administration.

site_title: Inflation in Japan’s capital slows in July, stays above BOJ target
summary: Japan's capital, Tokyo, saw its core consumer price index slow to 3.0% in July, still above the Bank of Japan's 2% target for the 14th consecutive month. Food prices, which rose 4.0%, drove the increase, indicating strain on households from rising living costs. The Bank of Japan is set to keep ultra-low interest rates and may tweak its yield control policy at its upcoming meeting. This maintains pressure on policymakers to dial back monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People shop daily necessities at a market in Tokyo, Japan March 3, 2023. REUTERS/Androniki Christodoulou

site_title: Procedures for internalisation of Sabana Reit’s manager are in place: Quarz Capital
summary: Quarz Capital, an activist investor, warns that legal and regulatory action may be taken against Sabana Industrial Reit's current external manager and its directors if they fail to fulfill their obligations. The Reit's trustee has confirmed that the external manager will only be removed once an internal manager is fully set up and licensed. A vote by unitholders is expected to replace the external manager with an internal one, ensuring no vacancy in the management of the Reit.

images.alt_text: Sabana Reit's manager has said Quarz's internalisation proposal may destroy value for unitholders
As the EGM for Sabana Reit's unitholders to vote on a controversial internalisation plan draws near, ESR Group has reiterated points on the dangers of passing the two resolutions by Quarz Capital.
Unitholders are set to vote on the two resolutions at an extraordinary general meeting to be held on Aug 7.
Sabana Reit’s second major asset enhancement initiative (AEI) at its property at 1 Tuas Avenue 4 is 14 per cent complete as at end-June 2023.

site_title: Singapore office rents expected to soften after 2.3% rise in Q2
summary: Singapore office rents are expected to moderate further after a 2.3% rise in Q2, driven by "tight market conditions." Median rents in Category 1 buildings rose 6.7% to S$11.49 psf per month. Capital values increased 1% due to growing demand for strata-titled office space. Experts predict office demand will soften for the rest of the year due to rising supply and shadow stock, with vacancy rates expected to increase.

images.alt_text: Singapore central office rents rise further in Q1 2023, up 5.1%: URA
