Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) along the Singapore River on Oct 29, 2022.
Can be used for stories on money, job, manpower, tourist, tourism, property, land, commercial, office, finance, financial, and CBD.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)   Singapore Skyline at night
It’s good news for San Francisco office owners who have faced pressure from record vacancies as technology firms cut back on space.

site_title: China Evergrande’s EV unit shares plunge 69% after 16-month halt
summary: China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group (NEV) shares plummeted 69% in early trading after a 16-month trading halt, amid concerns over the company's financial stability. The firm reported a combined net loss of 71.12 billion yuan for 2021 and 2022, with its auditor expressing material uncertainties about its ability to continue operations. The company plans to raise $500 million through equity and debt financing to meet production and sales requirements, but faces capital constraints and late employee salaries.

images.alt_text: Test cars by Evergrande are parked outside the Evergrande New Energy Vehicle (NEV)'s research center, in Shanghai, China October 6, 2021.   REUTERS/Yilei Sun

site_title: GIC cuts key quant unit in ‘tough’ overhaul of investment teams
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has scaled back its Systematic Investment Group (SIG) unit, citing underperformance, following a "tough" internal review of its investment teams and strategies. The unit, set up in 2016, will be reorganized with some staff reassigned or leaving for external quant firms. GIC's worst annualized five-year returns since 2016 were reported, attributed to a slowing global economy and rising inflation. Despite the downsizing, GIC remains committed to quant investing and will continue to use external managers and technology to inform its investment decisions.

images.alt_text: GIC reported an annualised rolling 20-year real rate of return of 4.6 per cent for its latest period ended Mar 31, the highest in eight years.

site_title: Bankman-Fried campaign finance charge dropped, lessening trial’s political focus
summary: US prosecutors dropped a campaign finance charge against Sam Bankman-Fried, reducing the focus of his trial on his alleged theft of billions from cryptocurrency customers. Bankman-Fried, 31, faces seven counts of defrauding customers and investors, as well as a second trial on five charges after his extradition, including foreign bribery conspiracy. The decision may help Bankman-Fried's lawyers focus their narrative on the fraud case, and jurors may react less strongly to the dropped charge, which accused him of directing associates to donate millions to political campaigns.

images.alt_text: In December, Bankman-Fried said he and Ellison had been in a relationship but gave no further details.
The prosecutors argue that Bankman-Fried is trying to malign Caroline Ellison’s credibility.
Sam Bankman-Fried has pleaded not guilty to several criminal charges.

site_title: Global automakers scramble to reset China strategies as sales slow
summary: Global automakers are scrambling to reset their China strategies as sales slow, with foreign brands losing market share to local upstart brands. Chinese brands now hold a 53% share of the market, while foreign brands are focusing on electric vehicles (EVs) with competitive offerings. Volkswagen and General Motors (GM) are partnering with Chinese companies to strengthen their positions, while Toyota and Mitsubishi are scaling back production and cutting costs. The price war has cut into margins for Chinese EV makers, giving foreign automakers the opportunity to play a long game and eventually compete with Tesla and China EV.

images.alt_text: The partnership could help lower Xpeng’s EV production costs by leveraging Volkswagen’s scale and bargaining power in supply.
As the electric vehicle (EV) market grows faster than expected, the new models will target the middle-class segment, a space not yet covered by Volkswagen’s planned vehicle line-up in China.

site_title: Company in auto trade exercises option to buy Sime Darby Business Centre for S$68 million
summary: Eagle Land (Credit), a car dealership company, has exercised its option to purchase the Sime Darby Business Centre at 315 Alexandra Road for S$68 million, approximately S$380 per square foot. The existing gross floor area of nearly 179,190 square feet is subject to JTC Corporation's approval. The buyer, headed by Thomas Yap Leong Guan, is expected to use the property predominantly for owner occupation, with a requirement to occupy at least 70% of the building's GFA under JTC rules.

images.alt_text: 15 Scotts Road, in District 9, is flanked by Scotts Walk and The American Club. It is also near hotels including Royal Plaza on Scotts and Goodwood Park Hotel.

site_title: George Goh calls for more private sector candidates, disagrees with Tharman’s non-partisan stance
summary: Businessman George Goh, a 63-year-old presidential hopeful, calls for more private sector candidates in the upcoming election, disagreeing with Tharman Shanmugaratnam's non-partisan stance. Goh, an independent candidate, believes competition is healthy and more people should step forward with fresh ideas. He also disputes Tharman's claim of being non-partisan, citing his 22-year tenure in the People's Action Party. Goh emphasizes his independence and willingness to serve the nation, awaiting endorsement from the Presidential Elections Committee before finalizing his candidacy.

images.alt_text: Ng Kok Song - who was the founder and chairman of the Singapore International Monetary Exchange before joining GIC - then carefully breaks down the role of the president: to be “the second key when the need arises to use past reserves”, and to rise above politics and “unify the people of Singapore”.
Ng Kok Song and his fiance Sybil Lau arrived at the Elections Department shortly past 10.30am on Wednesday to pick up an application form for the certificate of eligibility
Ng Kok Song retired from GIC in 2013 after 27 years with the sovereign wealth fund.
Goh said he would not publicly disclose any further details of his case for candidature.

George Goh says he decided to run for president after the eligibility requirements for private sector candidates were raised in 2017, as he was “concerned that the more stringent requirements would lead to another uncontested election”.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust’s H1 DPS up 24.7% to S$0.0192
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported a 24.7% increase in its half-year distribution per stapled security to S$0.0192, driven by higher net property income and the distribution of gains from its Central Square divestment. The trust's gross revenue grew 26.9% to S$52 million, with the hotel segment contributing 34.4% to income available for distribution. FEHT's average daily rates rose 71.4% in the hotel segment, while revenue per available unit in serviced residences grew 22.8% year on year.

images.alt_text: The manager expects more properties within FEHT’s portfolio to perform above fixed rents and achieve variable rents on the back of further improvements to visitor arrivals into Singapore.
Located at 20 Havelock Road, Central Square is a 99-year leasehold commercial and residential development in the Singapore River precinct.
Oasia Resort Sentosa, one of Far East Hospitality Trust's assets. The group's gross revenue was up 2.2 per cent to S$42.6 million for the half-year period, from S$41.7 million a year ago.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Keppel, Seatrium, Clas, Sheng Siong, CDLHT, FEHT
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a record quarterly net profit of S$734 million, up 98.4% year-over-year. Keppel Corporation also saw a record profit of S$3.63 billion for the six months ended June. Other companies saw significant changes, including Seatrium's widened net loss of S$264.4 million and Sheng Siong's 3% decrease in net profit to S$65.4 million. Meanwhile, CDL Hospitality Trusts and Far East Hospitality Trust posted significant rises in distribution per stapled security.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks extend gains amid bets Fed rate hikes likely over; STI up 1%

site_title: Oil settles above April peak on tighter supply
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, with Brent crude settling above its April peak at $84.35 a barrel, driven by supply tightness due to Opec+ production cuts and renewed optimism about Chinese demand and global growth. US West Texas Intermediate crude also rose, with prices up 1.7% to $80.09 a barrel. Analysts expect the oil market to remain undersupplied, with Brent prices potentially reaching $85-$90 in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Oil prices have rallied for four weeks, buoyed by signs of tighter supplies, largely linked to output cuts by Saudi Arabia and Russia, as well as Chinese authorities’ pledges to shore up the world’s second-biggest economy.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit’s H2 DPU drops 2% to S$0.0198
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 2% drop in its second-half distributable per unit (DPU) to S$0.0198, from S$0.0202 in the previous period. The DPU was also 3.7% lower than the previous year due to lower net property income and higher finance costs. Net property income for the half-year fell 2% to S$73.6 million, mainly due to foreign currency movements and the divestment of a Tokyo mall. The Reit's full-year DPU remained unchanged at S$0.038, with an annual yield of 7.4%.

images.alt_text: Shopper traffic at Wisma Atria improved by 24.6 per cent year on year during the quarter, while tenant sales increased 13.6 per cent.
Australian department store chain Myer is claiming a breach of its lease at Myer Centre Adelaide.

Starhill Global Reit's manager says that the increase in its NPI for the first half of FY22/23 is mainly due to the completion of asset enhancement works at The Starhill, lower rental assistance and higher rental contribution from Singapore office, partially offset by lower rental contribution from its retail Wisma Atria property and net movement in foreign currencies.

site_title: CDLHT posts 23% rise in H1 DPS on stronger portfolio performance
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) posted a 23% rise in distribution per stapled security for the first half ended June 30, driven by strong leisure travel and event resumption. Revenue grew 20.9% to S$119.2 million, with net property income increasing 23.3% to S$62.9 million. The trust's Singapore properties saw a 45.8% rise in revenue per available room, surpassing pre-pandemic levels. Despite a 37.9% gearing ratio, the trust has S$715.3 million in debt headroom and S$63.8 million in cash reserves.

images.alt_text: CDL H-Trust’s gearing stood at 37.5 per cent in Q1 this year, up slightly from 36.6 per cent in the last quarter.
Accelerated global travel recovery saw most of CDLHT’s portfolio markets experience robust performance growth in FY22.
CDL Hospitality Trusts' net property income for the half-year period increases 48.1 per cent to S$72.8 million from S$49.1 million.
Brokers' take: CDLHT downgraded to 'hold', 'neutral' as it trades closer to long-term mean

site_title: July to be hottest month on record as UN warns of ‘global boiling’
summary: The UN predicts July 2023 will be the hottest month on record, with global temperatures likely to temporarily rise 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels for at least one of the next five years. This "era of global boiling" is attributed to 1.2°C of global warming since the late 1800s, driven by fossil fuel burning, leading to intense heatwaves, devastating wildfires, and extreme weather events. UN chief Antonio Guterres warns of an "existential threat" and urges immediate action to cut planet-heating emissions, with scientists calling for drastic reductions in carbon pollution to avoid worse impacts in the future.

images.alt_text: Members of the Group of 20 major economies could not agree on a call to triple renewable energy capacities by 2030.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Dow streak ends at unlucky 13
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, snapping a 13-day winning streak for the Dow, as concerns about higher interest rates led to a 0.7% drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined 0.6% each. A rise in Treasury bond yields after the US GDP exceeded expectations and the European Central Bank lifted interest rates contributed to the market downturn. Meta's earnings beat expectations, while Southwest Airlines plummeted 8.9% due to concerns about operating expenses.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., July 12, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust posts 31% higher H1 gross profit at S$154.4 million
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust (Clas) reported a 31% year-on-year increase in H1 gross profit to S$154.4 million, driven by new acquisitions and stronger operating performance. Revenue rose 30% to S$346.9 million, with key markets performing above pre-pandemic levels. The trust expects continued demand for its properties, with international arrivals projected to recover to 80-95% of pre-pandemic levels by the end of 2023. Clas' distribution per stapled security increased 26% to S$0.0278, and the trust plans to exercise financial discipline while seeking investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit is the best performing Reit in the year so far, with 18.2 per cent total returns.

site_title: Volkswagen-Xpeng EV models to use Xpeng platform in boost for Chinese startup
summary: Volkswagen and Xpeng have partnered to use Xpeng's G9 'Edward' platform for their jointly developed electric vehicles, potentially boosting Xpeng's sales and profitability. The partnership could also lower Xpeng's production costs by leveraging Volkswagen's scale and bargaining power. Analysts view this as a "quick and capital-efficient" way for Volkswagen to fill its gap in the Chinese middle-class EV segment. Xpeng will receive technology service revenue from Volkswagen starting next year, overturning a traditional model of foreign automakers charging Chinese partners for technology licensing.

images.alt_text: As the electric vehicle (EV) market grows faster than expected, the new models will target the middle-class segment, a space not yet covered by Volkswagen’s planned vehicle line-up in China.

site_title: Ticketmaster parent Live Nation’s revenue surges on red-hot concert demand
summary: Live Nation Entertainment, the parent company of Ticketmaster, reported a 27% surge in revenue to $5.63 billion in the second quarter, beating Wall Street estimates. The surge was driven by high concert ticket prices and pent-up demand after the pandemic, with 37.1 million fans attending shows, nearly double the previous quarter. The company's total estimated events fell 2.4% year-over-year to 12,241, but ticket sales increased to 150.1 million.

images.alt_text: American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift.

site_title: Intel forecasts third-quarter profit above estimates
summary: Intel forecasts third-quarter profit above estimates, with shares rising 6% after the company reported a surprise profit amid a easing PC market slump. The PC market has seen a decline, but shipments are falling at a slower rate, boosting Intel's results. The company expects profit margins to improve in the second half and remains on track to deliver five generations of advanced chip production capabilities within four years. Intel's foundry business saw a significant increase in revenue, driven by advanced packaging.

images.alt_text: Intel has lost its lead in manufacturing the smallest and most power-efficient semiconductors to rivals such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

site_title: Merger-related provisions, expenses drag Seatrium deeper into the red with S$264.4 million H1 loss
summary: Seatrium reported a net loss of S$264.4 million for the first half of 2023, up from S$142.9 million in the same period last year, due to merger-related expenses and higher costs. The company's acting group finance director attributed the wider loss to "completion" of its combination with Keppel Offshore & Marine. Without provisions for merger expenses, the net loss would have been S$33 million. Seatrium's top-line figures appeared more optimistic, with revenue from its rigs, repairs, and upgrades businesses contributing S$2.9 billion. The company expects to make a net loss for FY2023 and is undergoing a strategic review, which is on track to be completed by the end of the year.

images.alt_text:
“The first six months of 2023 were
transformational and productive for Keppel", said CEO Loh Chin Hua (centre) at a results briefing on Thursday
An artist’s impression of an offshore substation platform for the Empire Wind project, which Seatrium has been contracted to build.

FTSE Russell said the STI is reviewed semi-annually in March and September where all SGX-listed securities will be screened based on the eligibility criteria in conjunction with Section 4 and Section 5 of the Straits Times Index Ground Rules.
Both the former Keppel O&M and former Sembcorp Marine have been linked to corruption in Brazil.

site_title: US dollar tumbles as Fed hike seen as its last; markets await ECB
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.5% to 100.60, marking a day after the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, which some expect to be its last. The market's focus shifted to the European Central Bank's rate announcement, with investors anticipating a 25-basis-point hike. The euro rose 0.5% to $1.1144, while the Japanese yen strengthened against the US dollar. The US dollar's decline was attributed to the Fed's dovish stance, with traders believing the hiking cycle is nearing its end.

site_title: No Signboard’s board says no knowledge CEO was investigated for rigging share price
summary: No Signboard's CEO, Lim Yong Sim, has been charged with share price rigging offences under the Securities and Futures Act. The board of No Signboard stated it had no knowledge of the investigation and was not notified by Lim. If convicted, Lim may face up to 7 years in jail or a fine of up to $250,000. The charges arose from a joint investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, alleging Lim created a false appearance related to No Signboard shares' prices between 2018 and 2019.

images.alt_text: 位于义顺纳福城的“无招牌生煎”（nosignboard Sheng Jian），是无招牌海鲜目前经营的两家餐饮门店之一。
The company says it will continue to engage GuGong and its lawyer to reach an in-principle agreement by Jun 26.
No Signboard's now-closed Esplanade outlet. The group is liquidating its various loss-making and non-core subsidiaries.

site_title: Kering takes 30% stake in Italian luxury brand Valentino
summary: Kering, a French luxury group, acquired a 30% stake in Italian fashion label Valentino for 1.7 billion euros. The deal includes an option for Kering to purchase Valentino's entire share capital by 2028. Valentino, with 211 stores and 1.4 billion euros in revenue in 2022, will have board representation at Kering. Mayhoola, the majority shareholder with 70% of the share capital, will continue to execute its brand elevation strategy.

site_title: TikTok won’t launch cross-border e-commerce services in Indonesia amid concerns
summary: TikTok has announced it will not launch cross-border e-commerce services in Indonesia amid concerns from the Indonesian government that it could flood the country with Chinese products, hurting small businesses. The move comes after the company expressed plans to replicate the success of e-commerce platforms like Shein and Temu in Europe and the US. Indonesian Minister of Cooperatives and Small and Medium Enterprises Teten Masduki expressed concerns that a launch of such a programme could create an "unequal playing field and predatory pricing" for small businesses, prompting TikTok to commit to supporting local Indonesian micro, small, and medium-sized businesses.

images.alt_text: The reported move comes at a time when TikTok is facing heightened scrutiny from US officials over concerns about data security.
ByteDance’s TikTok plans to invest billions of dollars in South-east Asia over the next three to five years.

site_title: Meta’s Reels revenue narrows in on TikTok, boosted by AI
summary: Meta's Reels has seen rapid growth, with 200 billion daily video plays, up from 140 billion last fall. The platform's annual revenue run rate has jumped to $10 billion, comparable to TikTok's business. Meta's improved recommendation software and seamless ad placement on Reels have contributed to its growth. While Reels is expected to earn less than Meta's other ad-generating features, its growth creates a base for further monetization, according to Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg.

images.alt_text: “Advertisers are gaining confidence in Meta’s enhanced and AI-powered campaign planning and measurement capabilities, and spending more," says analyst.

site_title: Global central banks begin policy shift as inflation cools
summary: Global central banks shifted their policy stance, continuing interest rate hikes but adopting a more cautious approach, amid cooling inflation. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank raised rates by a quarter percentage point, while the Bank of England is expected to follow suit next week. The Bank of Japan may discuss ending its ultra-loose policies. The rate hikes have left room for a global pause, with the ECB and Fed indicating they may be done raising rates, and policymakers now favor a more comprehensive approach to inflation management.

images.alt_text: The ECB’s problem is that inflation is coming down too slowly and could take until 2025 to fall back to 2 per cent.
Pressure is building on the BOJ to act against creeping inflation.
Stocks briefly took flight after Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell (right) noted the progress the US central bank had made in bringing inflation down.
The increase, after a brief pause in June, brings the Fed’s key lending rate to a range between 5.25 per cent and 5.5 per cent.

site_title: China’s video game player population rises to a record at end-June
summary: China's video game player population has reached a record 668 million, accounting for about half of the country's population, according to a government-run game industry association. The number of gamers is up from the pre-crackdown level, with sales revenue reaching 144.263 billion yuan (S$26.7 billion) for the first half of the year. Despite a sluggish global gaming market, China's gaming industry is showing an upward trend, with regulators loosening regulations and approving new games. The industry is expected to continue growing, with up to 1,000-1,100 domestic games approved for 2023.

site_title: Killjoy for Kim Kardashian and other financial influencers
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is launching guidelines to regulate celebrities and social media influencers who promote financial products, amid concerns over the rise of "finfluencers" and the potential for scams. The FCA, which has fined celebrities like Kim Kardashian for breaking rules when promoting cryptocurrencies, aims to educate influencers on what they can and cannot say online. The regulator is also working with online platforms to monitor and moderate illegal financial content, and has created a seven-point checklist for influencers to follow. The move aims to protect consumers and prevent the spread of scams.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Kim Kardashian poses on the red carpet as she arrives for the Time Magazine 100 gala celebrating their list of the 100 Most Influential People in the world in New York City, New York, U.S., April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Sheng Siong H1 profit falls 3% to S$65.4 million as staff costs, utilities rise
summary: Sheng Siong's first-half net profit fell 3% to S$65.4 million, driven by higher staff costs and utilities. Revenue rose 2% to S$690.5 million due to new store openings. Gross profit margin improved to 29.7%, and the group proposed a 70% dividend payout ratio. CEO Lim Hock Chee attributed the decline to climate change and El Nino weather affecting food prices, while maintaining its expansion strategy.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong expects competition to remain keen within the supermarket industry as consumers lean towards cheaper alternatives.

site_title: US regulators propose ordering banks to hold 16% more capital
summary: US regulators have proposed a 16% increase in capital requirements for large banks, aiming to strengthen the banking system. The plan, set to be voted on by the Federal Reserve, would raise capital requirements for banks like JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, and Morgan Stanley. Industry officials warn that the increased costs could force banks to trim services or raise fees, potentially harming consumers. Regulators argue that the benefits outweigh the costs, and the plan will be open to public input until November 30.

images.alt_text: epa10549245 Vice Chair for Supervision of the Federal Reserve Michael Barr (L), with Chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) Martin Gruenberg (R), testify during the House Committee on Financial Services hearing on Federal Regulators' Response to Recent Bank Failures on Capitol Hill in Washington, DC, USA, 29 March 2023. Gruenberg said in his prepared testimony that the FDIC, which insures bank deposits, will investigate and potentially impose financial penalties on executives and board members of the two failed banks.  EPA-EFE/SHAWN THEW

site_title: This summer, pause for the vermouth hour
summary: New Yorkers can adopt the Spanish "vermouth hour" custom, pausing for a glass of vermouth before meals. Vermouth is a fortified wine infused with botanicals, offering a variety of flavors and sweetness levels. The author recommends 10 excellent vermouths from Spain, Italy, and the US, including Valdespino Vermouth, Bordiga Vermouth, and Color Collector Vermouth. Vermouths are best refrigerated and can last at least a month after opening. To try vermouth, find a specialty store or good wine shop that carries distinctive bottles, and experiment with different flavors and pairings.

images.alt_text: Alberto Orte makes wine across spane but in recent years has focused on researching and finding grapes that disappeared long ago.

site_title: Keppel Corp H1 profit rises to over S$3.6 billion, highest in 55-year history
summary: Keppel Corporation reported its highest profit on record, exceeding S$3.6 billion for the first half of 2023, driven by a S$3.3 billion disposal gain from the divestment of its offshore and marine business. Excluding discontinued operations, net profit attributable to shareholders rose to S$445 million, with earnings per share increasing sixfold from the previous year. Revenue from continued operations grew 11% to S$3.7 billion, fueled by higher contributions from the infrastructure and connectivity segments.

images.alt_text: Keppel currently manages a diverse portfolio of 2.6 trillion won, or S$2.6 billion, in assets in South Korea.

site_title: Europe: Blue-chip shares at 15-year high as ECB fans rate pause hopes
summary: Europe's blue-chip shares hit a 15-year high as investors anticipate the European Central Bank (ECB) to pause interest rate hikes. The Euro Stoxx 50 index rose 2.3% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 1.4%, with regional markets such as Spain and Italy also experiencing gains. The ECB's decision follows a US Federal Reserve rate hike and a shift in the bank's messaging, with traders now seeing a 38% chance of a September rate hike. This has led to a shift in market expectations, with hopes of an end to rate hikes and signs of resilience in the US economy offsetting concerns about the eurozone economy.

images.alt_text: THE pan-European Stoxx 600 index shed 0.5 per cent after recording its longest winning streak since January on Tuesday.

site_title: Thai parliament to meet again on choosing PM on Aug 4
summary: Thailand's parliament is set to meet on August 4 to choose a new prime minister, following two previous attempts by the Move Forward party's leader Pita Limjaroenrat to be endorsed as premier being blocked. The Pheu Thai party, which came second in the May election, is expected to make the next bid. However, a court review of a previous decision to block Pita's candidacy may delay the vote, which could be postponed to the following day if the court accepts the petition. The stalemate drags on after a national election in May.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Move Forward Party supporters and pro-democracy activists gather to protest the day after Move Forward Party Leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat failed to secure the parliamentary vote for the premiership in Bangkok on July 14, 2023. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Exiled former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, who turns 74 on Wednesday (Jul 26), will arrive in Bangkok on Aug 10, his youngest daughter Paetongtarn Shinawatra, says in an Instagram post.

The vote was scheduled to be held on Jul 27 following two previous attempts by the leader of the election-winning Move Forward Party, Pita Limjaroenrat, that were blocked by conservative and nominated lawmakers.

epa10751685 Pheu Thai Party's Prime Ministerial candidate Srettha Thavisin leaves party’s headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 17 July 2023. The Pheu Thai Party, which came in second place in the 14 May Thai general elections, is in talks to coalition parties and the progressive Move Forward Party ahead of the second round of Parliament's voting to elect next prime minister on 19 July.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK
“I would like to say goodbye until we meet again,” Pita Limjaroenrat tells the chamber, raising his fist as he leaves the assembly floor to the cheers of fellow lawmakers.

site_title: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly rise in June
summary: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly rose 0.2% in June, a sign that business spending on equipment could continue to grow after rebounding in the second quarter. This data contradicts economists' forecasts of a 0.1% decline. The 3.4% annualized growth rate in the second quarter, after a 2.0% pace in the first quarter, indicates the economy is rebounding. The increase in core capital goods orders suggests business spending plans may remain strong, supporting the economy's recovery.

site_title: ‘Our present is related to our past’: Presidential hopeful Ng Kok Song on Tharman’s independence
summary: Singaporean presidential hopeful Ng Kok Song emphasized the importance of a person's past affiliations in shaping their present, responding to Tharman Shanmugaratnam's comments on independence of mind. Ng stated that his 45-year public service background and Tharman's years in political leadership are crucial in understanding their presidential qualities. Ng also highlighted his vision for a balanced presidency, where the president is above politics and has no affiliation.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises on Meta boost, soft landing hopes
summary: Wall Street rose on Thursday, July 27, driven by hopes of a soft landing for the US economy and a strong third-quarter revenue forecast from Meta Platforms. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 38.67 points, or 0.11%, to 35,558.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher. The positive sentiment was partly attributed to expectations that the Federal Reserve's policy tightening may be ending.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., July 12, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: ECB scraps interest on minimum reserve in hit to bank income
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has scrapped interest payments on minimum reserve requirements, a move expected to cut into bank income. The decision aims to maintain control over monetary policy and ensure interest rate decisions are fully passed through to money markets. This move follows previous reductions in interest payments, which have reduced windfall profits for lenders. The effect of the previous interest rate increases on lenders' profits is starting to taper off, and the ECB believes this decision will preserve its monetary policy stance.

site_title: China open to deepen partnership with Indonesia, says Xi
summary: China is open to deepening its strategic partnership with Indonesia, with President Xi Jinping expressing willingness to enhance cooperation in areas such as the Jakarta-Bandung high-speed railway, new energy automobiles, and smart cities. Xi also proposed expanding imports of Indonesian bulk commodities and agriculture products. The remarks came during a meeting with Indonesian President Joko Widodo in Chengdu, China, where Widodo attended the opening ceremony of the FISU World University Games. The high-speed rail project has faced budgetary issues and delays, but Xi urged both countries to complete it to a high standard.

images.alt_text: epa10771144 Indonesian President Joko Widodo (C) and First Lady Iriana Widodo (R) arrive in Chengdu, capital of southwest China's Sichuan Province, 27 July 2023. President Widodo arrived in Chengdu to attend the opening ceremony of the 31st summer edition of the FISU World University Games and a visit to China.  EPA-EFE/XINHUA / Jiang Hongjing CHINA OUT / UK AND IRELAND OUT  /       MANDATORY CREDIT  EDITORIAL USE ONLY
The railway was initially scheduled to be completed in 2019 but has faced several delays due to the cost overruns and accidents.

site_title: Sony PlayStation 5 console sales pass 40 million
summary: Sony's PlayStation 5 console sales have surpassed 40 million units, exceeding expectations. The milestone was achieved due to the easing of supply chain problems, allowing for well-stocked inventory to meet pent-up demand. This marks a record for any PlayStation device, with Sony expecting to sell 25 million units this year. The PS5 is closing the gap with the PS4 console, according to analyst Piers Harding-Rolls.

images.alt_text: Logos of Sony PlayStation 5 are displayed at the consumer electronics retailer chain Bic Camera ahead of its official launch, in Tokyo, Japan November 10, 2020.  REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Shanmugam, Vivian to sue Lee Hsien Yang for defamation over Ridout Road claims if he does not apologise
summary: Ministers K Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan plan to sue Lee Hsien Yang for defamation if he doesn't apologize for making false allegations about them receiving preferential treatment for renovations at Ridout Road properties. Shanmugam claims the allegations are false and have sent lawyers' letters to Lee.

images.alt_text: The bungalow at 26 Ridout Road rented by Minister KShanmugam as seen on June 29, 2023.
The bungalow at 26 Ridout Road rented by Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam as seen on June 29, 2023.
For the black-and-white bungalows located in an area zoned for landed properties such as Ridout Road and Nassim Road, the room for redevelopment is limited.

PM Lee Hsien Loong said there is nothing wrong with Cabinet ministers K. Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan renting the bungalows from the SLA, provided it is properly done and all procedures are followed.

site_title: Singapore expansion delay sends Neste’s shares tumbling
summary: Neste, a Finnish oil refiner and biofuels producer, missed second-quarter operating earnings expectations due to a delayed expansion of its Singapore renewables plant, which was caused by equipment repairs. The delay resulted in a negative sales volume impact of approximately 230,000 tonnes, equivalent to 10% of its forecasted sales volume for the second half. Neste expects to complete the expansion by the end of the year and plans to start sustainable aviation fuel production in Singapore during the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Neste produces renewable fuels, mainly from waste and residues such as used cooking oil and animal fat from food industry waste.

site_title: Design solution: How new and interesting spaces were created in this family home
summary: A Singaporean couple with two children engaged architect Lawrence Puah to re-imagine their 1,200-square-foot condominium apartment, which had small spaces and limited functionality. Puah created a modern European-inspired design with a black-and-white color scheme, wainscoting, and timber panels to enhance the space. The focal point is a suspended mezzanine floor above the television console, creating visual interest and translucency. The design also features built-in shelving, glass sliding doors, and vertical timber screens to create a cohesive and airy feel throughout the home, transforming the original small spaces into functional and aesthetically pleasing areas.

site_title: Mastercard beats profit estimates on spending boost
summary: Mastercard reported a higher-than-expected second-quarter profit, driven by resilient spending despite a stormy economic environment. The company's earnings beat expectations, with earnings per share of $2.89, driven by 12% growth in gross US dollar volumes to $2.3 trillion and 24% growth in cross-border volume. Net revenue grew 14% to $6.3 billion, as Mastercard's customers continued to spend heavily on travel and entertainment. The strong earnings report contrasts with peers Visa and American Express, which reported smaller jumps in quarterly profit.

images.alt_text: Tencent, operator of the popular chat app WeChat and payment network WeChat Pay, says that WeChat users overseas can link credit cards issued by Visa to their WeChat app from next month.
Each year, Mastercard estimates around 600 million cards are produced by the industry, each with a life span of around five years.
Visa and Mastercard are each being sued by hundreds of claimants at London’s Competition Appeal Tribunal, which is currently managing the various cases together.

site_title: Keppel posts bumper S$3.6 billion net profit in H1 from sale of O&M unit
summary: Keppel Corp, a global asset manager and operator, reported a record net profit of S$3.63 billion for the six months ended June, up from S$498 million the previous year. The profit boost came from the sale of its offshore and marine (O&M) unit to Seatrium, resulting in a gain of S$3.3 billion. Excluding the discontinued O&M operations, net profit rose 2.5% to S$444.95 million.

site_title: US economic growth accelerates in Q2; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: The US economy grew faster than expected in the second quarter, with a 2.4% annualized rate, driven by resilient labor market and consumer spending. The labor market showed signs of strength, with initial jobless claims falling to 221,000 and continuing claims at low levels. Business investment accelerated, with spending on equipment increasing, and government spending contributing to GDP growth. However, some economists remain concerned that higher borrowing costs and slowing job growth could eventually lead to a recession.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in Union Square in San Francisco, California, US, on Monday, June 26, 2023. California led a nationwide jump in job vacancies in April that reversed recent declines and keeps pressure on the Federal Reserve to consider more interest-rate hikes. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Hangzhou to host largest-ever Asian Games: organisers
summary: Hangzhou, China, will host the largest-ever Asian Games, featuring over 12,500 athletes from 45 countries and regions. The Games, postponed from 2022 due to Covid-19 restrictions, will take place in September and include 40 sports, including emerging disciplines like Go and Esports. Organisers have confirmed that all 56 venues are ready, with athletes staying in a Games village equipped with transportation and media services. The event aims to showcase Asian culture and characteristics, with preparations nearing completion.

site_title: Recovering China sales boost profits at Prada
summary: Prada's net profits soared 62% to 305 million euros in the first half of 2023, driven by strong retail sales in China and Europe. Retail sales rose 21% to 716 million euros in the Asia-Pacific market, with clothing and footwear sales increasing by 36% and 20%, respectively. The company's sister label Miu Miu saw a 50% jump in retail sales, attributed to a strengthened identity and increased visibility. Prada retains its ambition to deliver solid, sustainable, and above-market growth for the current year.

images.alt_text: A model seen here with a range of long and short white skirts embellished with white flowers.

site_title: China to boost credit support to consumer sector
summary: China's financial regulator plans to guide banks to boost credit in the consumer service industry, aiming to bolster a flagging post-pandemic economic recovery. Residents' consumption capacity is insufficient, and their willingness to spend is weak, according to the regulator. Financial institutions are encouraged to step up credit support for firms in service industries, such as wholesale and retail, accommodation, and cultural tourism. China's bad loan ratio stood at 1.68% at the end of June, and outstanding non-performing loans totaled 4 trillion yuan. The move aims to address structural problems and improve private sector economic growth.

images.alt_text: Industrial profit numbers cover firms with annual revenues of at least 20 million yuan from their main operations.
The economy faces new challenges and the post-pandemic recovery will be tortuous, Xinhua reported, following a Politburo meeting chaired by President Xi Jinping.
Analysts are not ruling out the possibility of more rate reductions this year, as the People's Bank of China puts a greater emphasis on financial stability.
China will promote the transformation of “urban villages” – or underdeveloped areas – in megacities.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks in the Central Business District on a rainy day, in Beijing, China, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Zara billionaire founder’s real estate fortune hits 18.1 billion euros
summary: Amancio Ortega's real estate portfolio, managed by Pontegadea, has reached a value of 18.1 billion euros (S$26.6 billion) in 2022, a 19% increase from 2021. Ortega, 86, has expanded into logistics with US investments, including warehouses for Amazon.com, TJX, and FedEx. He also acquired luxury apartment buildings and residential properties, marking a diversification from his historically commercial real estate focus.

images.alt_text: Inditex founder Amancio Ortega has the biggest real estate portfolio among Europe’ super-rich, valued at 15.3 billion euros (S$22.4 million) as of 2021, according to the most recent data available.
Zara's In-store and online sales rise 13 per cent to 7.6 billion euros in the first quarter.

site_title: Michelin chefs Mano Thevar and Sun Kim bring heartfelt Korean-Indian cooking to Tambi
summary: Singaporean restaurant Tambi, co-owned by Michelin-starred chefs Mano Thevar and Sun Kim, serves a fusion of Korean-Indian cuisine. The casual counter-style setup offers a range of dishes, including bibimmyeon, beef tartare, and crispy murtabak. Most dishes on the menu are priced between S$18 and S$28. The chefs' Michelin know-how is evident in the food, which is guided by comfort and flavor. With a focus on simplicity and down-to-earth goodness, Tambi is a great option for those looking for affordable, delicious meals.

images.alt_text: Tajine's colourful interiors.

site_title: US pending home sales rise for first time since February
summary: US pending home sales rose 0.3% to 76.8 in June, the first increase since February, indicating the housing market is recovering from recent declines. Despite a 15.6% year-over-year decline, the National Association of Realtors' chief economist, Lawrence Yun, says the housing recession is over, citing multiple offers and homebuilders ramping up production. Existing home inventory remains historically low, driving homebuilding, and mortgage rates are predicted to fall to 6.4% this year and 6.0% in 2024. The housing market's resilience hinges on the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: US MANHATTAN united states housing Photographer: Alex Kent/Bloomberg

site_title: As US economy heads for a soft landing, Asian currencies to rise against the dollar
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 5.25-5.5% amid expectations of a softer landing for the US dollar, driven by market beliefs of a pause in rate hikes. Asian currencies are expected to rise against the dollar, with stocks rallying, including the Hang Seng Index, Nikkei 225, and Korea Composite Stock Price Index. Analysts forecast a narrowing rate differential between the US dollar and other economies, supporting Asian equity markets and rates, and predict a potential pause in rate hikes, easing recession concerns.

images.alt_text: US Consumer spending edges up 0.1 per cent last month, the Commerce Department says.
Sterling hits a near 15-month high of US$1.2933 after UK wage growth reaches a joint record high.

site_title: Vietnam’s property strain could spill over to banks: S&P
summary: Vietnam's property market is experiencing strain due to a real estate correction that began nearly a year ago, which may lead to non-payment from commercial real estate loans and property-related bonds held by banks. S&P Global Ratings estimates that sector-wide non-performing loans could hit about 4.5% in a worst-case scenario, but banks are expected to manage the stresses. The government's measures, including interest-rate cuts and forbearance, will mitigate the impact, and large and well-established developers are likely to have financial buffers to tide through the rough period.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand was reported in talks to buy Vietnam property assets from Vinhomes against the backdrop of a cash crunch in local property market

site_title: ECB raises rates to 23-year high; keeps options open for September
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates to a 23-year high of 3.75% as it struggles to combat stubborn inflation and a growing risk of recession. This is the ninth consecutive rate hike, increasing borrowing costs by 425 basis points since last July. ECB President Christine Lagarde said the bank is determined to cool inflation, but kept options open for further tightening, including a possible hike in September. The decision comes as inflation remains above target, and the labor market remains exceptionally tight, fueling concerns about a potential wage surge.

images.alt_text: "The cumulated net tightening since the beginning of 2022 has been substantial," the European Central Bank says, noting that lenders expect more to come in the third quarter.

site_title: Hollywood talent manager sees rising demand for Asian actors
summary: Hollywood talent manager Andrew Ooi notes that the Oscar success of films like "Everything Everywhere All At Once" and "Minari" has led to a shift in opportunities for Asian actors, with more plum roles being offered. Ooi, who represents numerous Asian actors, sees a greater demand for Asian talents across the US entertainment industry, including voiceover work and TV shows. He attributes this change to the growing popularity of South Korean entertainment and the increasing disposable income of Asian Americans. Ooi remains cautious about expanding his roster and signing new talent, prioritizing talent over looks.

images.alt_text:
hyooi27 - Andrew Ooi with actress Celina Jade on the red carpet.

PHOTO: Courtesy of Andrew Ooi

site_title: McDonald's beats sales estimates as cheaper items draw consumers
summary: McDonald's reported a 11.7% increase in global comparable sales for the second quarter, beating analysts' estimates of an 8.88% rise. The company's US sales rose 10.3%, while international sales increased 11.9%. McDonald's lower prices compared to competitors, along with promotional deals and improved staffing, contributed to the strong sales performance. The company's shares rose nearly 2% to $297.09, and its net income nearly doubled to $2.31 billion in the quarter.

images.alt_text: McDonald’s sold about 80 per cent of its China and Hong Kong operations for around US$1.7 billion in 2017, valuing the business at as much as US$2.08 billion.
McDonald’s says the latest round of hikes would range from 10 to 90 yen per item or set.
McDonald’s total revenue increased 4 per cent from the prior year to nearly US$5.9 billion in the three months ended Mar 31, the company said in an earnings release.

McDonald’s restaurants in Belarus, all 25 of which had been operated by local licencee KSB Victory Restaurants, were set to be rebranded as Vkusno & tochka, the successor to McDonald’s restaurants in Russia.

site_title: US homeowner equity climbs to a record high
summary: US homeowners now hold a record-high equity stake in their properties, accounting for 49% of the national total in the second quarter of this year. This represents a 2 percentage point increase from the previous quarter and is higher than the peak levels reached last year before interest rates slowed the housing market. The proportion of equity-rich mortgage-payers increased in 45 of the 50 US states, with only 5 having relatively high shares, and 92% of homes facing foreclosure still having at least some equity.

images.alt_text: Existing home sales fall 3.3 per cent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.16 million units, the lowest level since January, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) says.

site_title: Meta rallies as AI-powered ad sales drive 'monster' forecast
summary: Meta's shares surged 10% after the company reported a strong second-quarter earnings forecast, driven by AI-powered ad sales. Analysts expect a 15-24% growth rate, beating expectations. Meta's ad revenue surpassed Google's 3% growth, and the company's Reels short-form video format saw an annual revenue run rate exceeding $10 billion. The positive forecast has lifted Meta's market value by over $70 billion, with analysts raising their target price on the stock.

images.alt_text: The new version of the AI model, called Llama 2, will be distributed by Microsoft through its Azure cloud service and will run on the Windows operating system, Meta says.

The Threads application on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Tuesday, July 11, 2023. Meta Platforms Inc.'s answer to Twitter Inc. has rocketed to 100 million users in less than a week, Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg announced on Monday. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: Google, Microsoft and Alphabet logos and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains amid bets Fed rate hikes likely over; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore stocks extended gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1% to 3,337.42, despite the Federal Reserve's 25 basis point rate hike to 5.25-5.50%. The US central bank believes the world's largest economy might stave off a recession. Analysts expect the hiking campaign to be over, with UOB's 27% jump in second-quarter net profit and Olam's share price closing 0.8% higher.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 04, 2022 the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC. - The annual personal consumption expenditures price index eased to 4.2 percent in March from a revised 5.1 percent a month earlier, with a sharp decline recorded in energy prices, according to data released April 28, 2023 by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Microsoft in EU antitrust crosshairs over Teams, Office tying
summary: Microsoft is under EU antitrust investigation over tying its Teams chat and video app with Office, potentially leading to a hefty fine. The European Commission, citing competition concerns, seeks to ensure the markets for these products remain competitive. Microsoft has previously been fined 2.2 billion euros in the EU for similar practices, and the company has been working to adopt a more conciliatory approach with the European Commission. The investigation follows a complaint by Salesforce-owned Slack and Microsoft's failure to offer remedies to address the EU's concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft Teams app is seen on the smartphone placed on the keyboard in this illustration taken, July 26, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's employment levels expanded by 23,700 in Q2, but at a slower pace than before, indicating cooling labour demand. Meanwhile, UOB posted a 27% rise in Q2 profit, citing a positive outlook on net interest margin growth. Yields for 12-month T-bills rebounded to 3.74% in July, while industrial space prices and rents continued their upward trend in Q2. Singapore Airlines also reported a record quarterly profit of S$734 million for Q1 2023.

site_title: Cortina sets up hotline, steps up staff training after data leak
summary: Cortina Holdings, a luxury watch dealer, has set up a hotline to answer customer queries about a June data leak, which involved the theft of over 7 GB of data, including customer and staff information. The company has also deployed managed detection and response services and stepped up staff training to strengthen its cybersecurity defenses. Despite the incident, Cortina said it has not had any discernible impact on its business, citing its enduring relationships with customers. The company prioritizes IT security and customer privacy.

images.alt_text: A Cortina shop at Raffles City, taken on 17 November 2020.

site_title: Global coal consumption hit an all-time high in 2022: IEA
summary: Global coal consumption reached a record high in 2022, with 8.3 billion tonnes consumed, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). Strong growth in Asia, particularly China and India, offset declines in the US and Europe, with the two countries accounting for nearly 70% of global coal consumption. The IEA predicts coal demand will remain near this level in 2023 and 2024, with industrial use driving growth despite small declines in power generation. Coal remains a significant source of carbon emissions, with the IEA warning of its stubborn demand in Asia despite increasing renewable energy adoption.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Labourers work next to electricity pylons in Mumbai, India, October 13, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: 💬 We need to talk about suicide
summary: Singapore reported 476 suicides last year, a 26% increase from 2021, with young people (10-29 years) and the elderly disproportionately affected. Suicide remains the leading cause of death for youths for the fourth consecutive year. Many people who died by suicide gave signs to loved ones, highlighting the importance of recognizing these warning signs. Having supportive friends who spend time with the individual can help them feel better, but it's essential to approach the situation with empathy, compassion, and avoiding judgmental or solution-focused conversations. Several helplines and online resources are available for support.

site_title: London rent increases starting to slow
summary: Rent increases in London are slowing, with Foxtons Group predicting single-digit growth in the second half of the year. The rate of rent increases moderated in the first half of the year, with average monthly rent in Greater London surging 13% year-on-year to £2,271. Despite this, landlords are passing fewer costs onto tenants, offering a glimmer of hope for renters. However, the gap between supply and demand will continue to drive up costs, creating a "serious issue" for renters, according to Foxtons.

images.alt_text: UK residential rents have risen to an all-time record average of £1,199 a month.

site_title: STMicro boosts quarterly revenue as auto demand drives sales
summary: STMicroelectronics reported a 13% increase in revenue for the second quarter, reaching US$4.33 billion, slightly beating analyst estimates. The company's Automotive and Discrete unit, its largest, saw a 34% revenue boost to US$1.96 billion, driven by demand from the auto industry. STMicro narrowed its full-year revenue guidance to US$17.4 billion, citing growth in Automotive and Industrial segments.

images.alt_text: The venture will produce silicon carbide devices exclusively for STMicroelectronics which are used in electric cars and other industrial power and energy applications.
Demand for STMicro products has been driven by customers such as Tesla in its automotive unit, which is the company’s largest business area and has benefited from growing electric vehicle sales.

site_title: SIA posts record quarterly profit of S$734 million for Q1 2023
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted a record quarterly profit of S$734 million for Q1 2023, a 98.4% increase from the previous year. The airline's revenue rose 14% to S$4.5 billion, driven by a 37.4% growth in passenger flown revenue, while cargo flown revenue declined 50.6%. Operating profit reached S$755 million, with earnings per share increasing to 14.3 Singapore cents. The company expects robust demand for air travel through the summer peak, but faces challenges from cargo demand and macroeconomic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: The group’s passenger load factor for June also reached a monthly record of 90.6 per cent.
A Singapore Airlines (SIA) plane being refuelled with blended sustainable aviation fuel at Changi Airport, 7 July 2022.

Unlike other carbon-intensive sectors, which may have various avenues to decarbonise, the only way SIA is able to reduce its carbon emissions is by switching its fuel, which are currently fossil fuel-based, to sustainable aviation fuel, said Dilhan Pillay, chief executive officer of Temasek.
“We are committed to the long-term success of SIA and continue to maintain a majority stake in it,” Juliet Teo, Temasek’s head of Transportation & Logistics, said in an emailed statement.
CEO Goh Choon Phong’s pay has risen 86 per cent compared with his S$3.6 million compensation from a year earlier, according to the company’s annual report.
Scoot itself flew over 1 million passengers in May, more than double from 418,700 passenger count in the same month last year.
Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplanes at Changi Airport on Dec 24, 2022.

site_title: Thai household debt at 15-year high as economic recovery slows
summary: Thailand's average household debt has reached a 15-year high of $16,438.70 in 2023, up 11.5% from the previous year, due to a slower-than-expected economic recovery and high living costs. The country's tourism sector has just started to recover from the pandemic, while soft global demand continues to impact exports. Survey respondents expect to continue borrowing for at least six months, with economists predicting the debt levels will peak in 2024. The delayed government formation has also impacted economic growth expectations, with the economy expected to grow 3.0-3.5% this year.

images.alt_text: The central bank aims to reduce household debt to 80 per cent of gross domestic product from about 90.6 per cent – the highest among major Asian economies.

site_title: Thai June factory output drops more than forecast amid weak exports
summary: Thailand's factory output declined more than expected in June, falling 5.24% from a year earlier, as global demand weakened exports. This marks the ninth straight month of decline, largely due to a global economic slowdown. Despite domestic consumption increasing due to the tourism sector's strength, the industry remains impacted. The decline in exports has been attributed to sluggish global demand and ongoing political uncertainty following the May elections.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Commerce Ministry is targeting annual export growth of 1 per cent for 2023.
The next parliamentary vote for a new prime minister is set for Thursday.
The BOT has raised its key rate by a total of 150 basis points since August to 2 per cent to curb inflation.

site_title: Former Malaysia central banker deposes in Najib’s 1MDB trial
summary: Former Bank Negara Malaysia chief Zeti Akhtar Aziz testified against ex-Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB trial, stating she expressed concern over 1MDB's rising debt and had no knowledge of funds being transferred to Najib's accounts from the state fund. She denied any involvement in the scandal and claimed the allegations against her and her family are "completely false and malicious." Najib faces charges of money laundering and abuse of power over alleged misuse of RM2.3 billion from 1MDB.

images.alt_text: Jasmine Loo is said to be a close associated with Low Taek Jho, also known as Jho Low (above), a fugitive businessman wanted for his role in the 1MDB scandal.
Fugitive financier Jho Low.
The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission had earlier confirmed it suspected Low was in gambling haven and Chinese special administrative region Macau.
Kee Kok Thiam, an associate of fugitive financier Jho Low (pictured), died in a hospital of a “sudden massive stroke” on Monday, Valen, Oh & Partners said in a statement.

site_title: BNP cost controls drive earnings beat as debt traders trail
summary: BNP Paribas reported a better-than-expected profit in the second quarter, driven by tight cost controls and lower provisions for bad loans. Operating expenses rose only 1.6% from the previous year, less than analyst estimates. Revenue weakened due to an 18% slump in debt trading, but equities trading and global banking units performed well, with revenue increases of 15% and 3.3%, respectively. The bank's CEO, Jean-Laurent Bonnafe, has pledged to cut annual expenses by 2.3 billion euros through 2025, and plans to return excess cash to shareholders through share buybacks and targeted investments.

images.alt_text: Flix, set up in 2011 by three entrepreneurs in Munich to try to make bus travel cheap, runs bus and train services across 40 countries.

site_title: Digital Core Reit’s H1 DPU falls 6.8% to US$0.0192 after two tenants go bust
summary: Digital Core Reit's distribution per unit fell 6.8% to US$0.0192 for its first half-year ended June, due to lower rental income from two tenants who filed for bankruptcy. One tenant has vacated the data centre, while the other, Cyxtera, remains current on rental obligations. Net property income fell 0.7% to US$35.1 million, while income available for distribution declined 7.6% to US$21.5 million. The Reit aims to expand its asset base and diversify its customers, while preserving its balance sheet and debt headroom.

images.alt_text: DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.

site_title: Fed chief Powell has reason to celebrate as US inflation continues to moderate
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell celebrated a moderate inflation rate as the central bank raised interest rates a quarter-of-a-percentage-point to 5.25-5.5% on Wednesday. Recent inflation data shows prices have moderated to around 3%, largely due to the Fed's rate policy. Powell's cautious tone on wage inflation and potential risks from global events, such as Russian President Vladimir Putin's efforts to disrupt grain trade, may temper the celebratory mood. Economists praise Powell's efforts to achieve a "soft landing," avoiding a recession while defeating inflation, but warn that the stock market's enthusiasm about the Fed's strategy could pose new complications.

images.alt_text: The central bank on Wednesday raised its policy by 25 basis points to a 5.25-5.50 per cent range.
Many who had placed a low probability on the Fed achieving a “soft landing” now see that as the likelier outcome than recession.
Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Barclays reports first half profit meets expectations; bad loans rise
summary: Barclays reported a pretax profit of £4.6 billion (S$7.89 billion) for the first half of the year, meeting analyst expectations and surpassing the £3.7 billion profit from the same period last year. The bank's consumer and credit card business drove the increase, offsetting declining revenues in its investment bank due to stagnant corporate dealmaking. The result highlights a shift in global banks' business lines, with more stable areas like retail and corporate banking benefiting from rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Daniel Hanna, global head of sustainable finance at Barclays

site_title: Shell Q2 profits drop to US$5 billion after energy prices cool
summary: Shell reported Q2 profits of US$5 billion, down 56% from last year, as oil and gas prices cooled after rallying due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. This missed analyst forecasts of US$5.8 billion. The company increased its dividend to US$0.33 per share and announced a US$3 billion share repurchase. Record quarterly earnings were US$11.5 billion in the same period last year, and US$9.65 billion in the previous quarter.

site_title: No Signboard CEO Lim Yong Sim charged with share price rigging
summary: No Signboard Holdings CEO and executive chairman Lim Yong Sim was charged with price rigging offences under the Securities and Futures Act. He allegedly created a false appearance of No Signboard shares' prices between 2018 and 2019. If convicted, Lim may face up to seven years in jail or a fine of up to S$250,000. The charges arose from a joint investigation by the Singapore Police Force, Commercial Affairs Department, and Monetary Authority of Singapore.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo has urged No Signboard to announce the company’s FY2022 and FY2023 unaudited financial results and hold its FY2022 AGM, among other things, “as soon as possible."
The company says it will continue to engage GuGong and its lawyer to reach an in-principle agreement by Jun 26.
No Signboard's now-closed Esplanade outlet. The group is liquidating its various loss-making and non-core subsidiaries.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices ease in June for a second straight month
summary: Hong Kong home prices fell 0.5% in June for the second consecutive month, easing due to expectations of more interest rate hikes and weak consumer confidence. The drop was revised down to 0.9% from 0.7%. Experts attribute the decline to mortgage rate hikes and new apartments entering the market, which may keep prices under pressure. Major banks are expected to raise lending rates on Thursday, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority raised its base rate by 25 basis points to 5.75%.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s monetary policy moves in lock-step with the United States as the city’s currency is pegged to the greenback in a tight range of 7.75-7.85 per US dollar.
Malaysia’s move to grant Hong Kong the visa-free extension would be an easy win for John Lee to show he’s forging closer ties with South-east Asia.

site_title: Governance body rules out carbon credits that lock in fossil fuel emissions, technologies
summary: The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) has ruled that carbon credits from enhanced oil recovery and coal-fired electricity generation will not receive its approval due to concerns of locking in fossil fuel emissions. The council's new criteria state that credible carbon credits must be compatible with the global goal of net zero, discouraging mitigation activities that lead to short-term emission reductions. The framework also rules out projects that "lock in fossil fuel emissions or technologies" and requires projects to monitor and report on emissions reductions for at least 40 years.

images.alt_text: ICVCM states that forestry projects under Redd+ – a UN framework created to guide activities in the forest sector that reduces emissions from deforestation and forest degradation – must also conform to the Cancun safeguards.
The prices of Redd+ credits have fallen 19 per cent since coming under intense scrutiny earlier this year, Trove noted.

Climate Impact X chief executive officer Mikkel Larsen said a large part of the challenge the voluntary carbon market deals with today is educational in nature. The market has to be able to explain an “imperfect product”.

site_title: Netflix reworks Microsoft pact, lowers ad prices: WSJ
summary: Netflix is restructuring its advertising partnership with Microsoft, lowering ad prices. The streaming company had previously selected Microsoft to provide technology and sell ads on its behalf, with Microsoft offering a revenue guarantee. Netflix is now reworking the agreement to reduce the guarantee, settling the terms. This move comes as Netflix has had discussions with other potential partners to sell ads. The exact terms of the revised agreement have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Netflix logo is pictured in Los Angeles, California, U.S., September 15, 2022. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank re-initiates coverage on AirAsia X with ‘buy’, forecasts record net profit
summary: Maybank Securities has resumed coverage on Malaysia-listed AirAsia X (AAX) with a "buy" call and a price target of RM3.58, citing the airline's effective debt-free status and potential acquisition of Capital A's four short-haul airlines. Analyst Yin Shao Yang forecasts AAX to deliver record core net profits of RM160 million for FY2023 and RM256.5 million for FY2024, driven by falling aircraft lease rates and rising unit passenger fares.

images.alt_text: which started Philippine operations in 2012, was looking at raising up to $250 million in 2018.
AirAsia Ride, the super app's ride-hailing service, will be made available on the Foodpanda app.
ADE, a subsidiary of Capital A, has inked a partnership agreement with OCP Asia to develop an MRO centre in Sepang, Selangor.
Tony Fernandes, the larger-than-life character credited with revolutionising budget air travel in Asia, plans to focus more on areas such as health, education and private equity.

site_title: Yields for 12-month T-bill rebounds to 3.74% in July
summary: Yields for the 12-month T-bill in Singapore rebounded to 3.74% in July, higher than the cut-off yield in April (3.58%) but lower than January's (3.87%). The median yield was 3.5% and the average yield was 3.09%. The July issuance was the largest of the year, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.11. This comes after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter point, leading to a drop in US bond yields.

images.alt_text: The latest T-bill auction received a total of S$12.2 billion in applications for the S$5.6 billion on offer, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.18.

site_title: Malaysia plans to build region’s largest solar hybrid plant
summary: Malaysia plans to develop the region's largest solar hybrid plant, valued at RM6 billion, as part of its goal to achieve 70% renewable energy capacity by 2050. The project, led by Khazanah Nasional, aims to rapidly scale up installed capacity with the right infrastructure and technology. This move follows the country's recent lift of an export ban on renewable energy and its increased renewable energy target from 40% to 70%. The solar hybrid plant is part of 10 projects worth RM25 billion under the National Energy Transition Roadmap.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s data centre market was estimated to be worth nearly US$1.1 billion in 2021 and it is expected to grow to US$1.6 billion by 2027.

site_title: BT reiterates 2024 outlook on cost control and broadband demand
summary: BT Group reported a 5% increase in adjusted core earnings to £2 billion in the first quarter, in line with analyst forecasts. The company attributed the growth to cost control and demand for broadband, which offset inflationary pressures. BT's Openreach network division is 44% through its full fibre build, with 3.5 million total fibre connections. Despite this, the company's shares are down 30% over the past year due to the cost of building new networks and hit to free cash flow. CEO Philip Jansen will step down within the next year.

images.alt_text: UK mobile networks Vodafone, O2 and Three tackle rural coverage

site_title: Nestle beats first-half organic sales expectations
summary: Nestle reported better-than-expected first-half organic sales, with 8.7% growth beating the analyst estimate of 8.1%. The company's 9.5% price increases were ahead of the average estimate, but its real internal growth fell 0.8%. Nestle narrowed its full-year organic sales growth guidance to 7-8%, citing confidence in delivering a positive combination of volume and mix. The company cited higher input costs and the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The British company has reported a 7.9 per cent rise in underlying second-quarter sales, beating analysts’ average forecast of 6.4 per cent.

site_title: Moderate US economic growth expected in second quarter
summary: The US economy is expected to maintain a moderate pace of growth in the second quarter, driven by labour market resilience, consumer spending, and business investment. The Commerce Department's GDP snapshot is expected to show the housing market slump nearing an end, while interest rate hikes have largely weathered the economy. Economists forecast a 1.8% annualized GDP growth rate, with consumer spending remaining a key pillar of support despite a slowdown in growth. A recession remains a possibility, but the soft-landing scenario envisaged by the Fed appears feasible.

images.alt_text: Many who had placed a low probability on the Fed achieving a “soft landing” now see that as the likelier outcome than recession.
The increase, after a brief pause in June, brings the Fed’s key lending rate to a range between 5.25 per cent and 5.5 per cent.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB cuts Kore’s target price on lower DPU forecast
summary: RHB Research has lowered its target price for Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (Kore) to US$0.56 from US$0.64 due to lower distribution per unit (DPU) forecasts. The research house trimmed its DPU forecasts by 6% and 7% for FY2023 and FY2024, respectively, citing lower occupancy rates and higher financing costs. Despite this, RHB maintained its "buy" call on Kore due to its modest gearing level and safe debt profile.
