Keppel Pacific Oak US REIT to expand portfolio with acquisitions of Nashville and Denver assets for US$105.1 million

site_title: The harsh truth: We’re using more oil than ever
summary: Global oil demand has surpassed the monthly peak set in 2019, with a record high of 102.5 million barrels a day, likely reached in the last few weeks of July. Despite the rise of electric vehicles, oil consumption continues to rise, driven by factors such as an increase in petrol-powered cars, delayed upgrades to fuel-efficient models, and a shift from diesel to petrol cars in Europe. The International Energy Agency predicts global oil demand will increase by 3-4% over the next five years, making it unlikely that the world will meet its net-zero emissions targets by 2030.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled up 90 US cents at US$83.64 a barrel, after hitting US$83.87 earlier, the highest since Apr 19.
Opec members are on a treadmill of meeting their growing populations’ needs with fluctuating oil revenues while also, in some cases, trying to fashion an economic transition.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust posts 8.8% drop in H1 DPU to S$0.0374
summary: CapitaLand China Trust reported an 8.8% drop in its first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0374, mainly due to foreign currency translation. Gross revenue fell 7.4% to S$184.5 million, while net property income (NPI) decreased 7.4% to S$129.2 million. The retail portfolio showed a stronger performance, with occupancy improving to 96.8% and tenant sales exceeding pre-Covid-19 levels. However, the new-economy segment saw lower contributions. The Reit's gearing stood at 40.2%, and it plans to continue reconstituting its portfolio to achieve its long-term roadmap targets.

images.alt_text: Meanwhile, revenue from CLI's real estate investment business rose 11 per cent to S$447 million in Q1 2023, from S$403 million in the previous year.
Overall SGX-listed stocks have booked S$2.8 billion of net institutional fund outflow and S$1.4 billion of net retail inflow in the 2023 year to Jul 18.

site_title: Anwar unveils new economic framework to reboot Malaysia’s economy
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has unveiled a new economic framework, titled "Madani," aimed at rebooting the country's economy. The 10-year plan includes seven benchmarks to guide Malaysia towards becoming one of the world's top 30 economies, with a focus on fiscal sustainability, human development, and competitiveness. Anwar aims to achieve a fiscal deficit of 3% of GDP or less and improve the human development index ranking to enter the world's top 25. The plan also includes measures to boost exports, attract foreign investments, and support local companies.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s move to grant Hong Kong the visa-free extension would be an easy win for John Lee to show he’s forging closer ties with South-east Asia.

Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah with Queen Azizah Aminah Maimunah, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr with First Lady Maria Louise Araneta Marcos, and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim with his wife Wan Azizah Wan Ismail pose for photograph during a state welcome ceremony at the National Palace in Kuala Lumpur on Jul 26, 2023.
Malaysia’s data centre market was estimated to be worth nearly US$1.1 billion in 2021 and it is expected to grow to US$1.6 billion by 2027.

site_title: UOB positive on net interest margin growth, posts 27% rise in Q2 profit
summary: UOB's Q2 profit rose 27% to S$1.4 billion, driven by higher net interest income and trading income. Despite a 2.12% net interest margin, the lender expects margins to stabilize and potentially rise due to interest rate hikes. UOB's loan margin held steady at 2.62%, and the bank posted new net money inflows of S$12 billion. The lender lowered its fee growth guidance to a high single-digit due to uncertainty in the market. Total allowance on loans rose 37.6% to S$238 million, but the bank maintains its credit cost guidance of around 25 basis points for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: The earnings are in line with a S$1.4 billion consensus forecast in a Bloomberg survey of six analysts.

Earnings for the three banks are expected to peak in 2023, as loan growth and fee income taper off, while the market braces itself for yet another potential round of rate hikes by the Fed within the year.
United Overseas Insurance, the general insurance arm of UOB,
Although the increase in the cap could lead to a “substantial rise” in GXS and MariBank’s deposit holdings, this still dwarfs in comparison to Singapore’s trio of local banks, Fitch Ratings said.

site_title: Singapore completes first marine methanol bunkering, paving way for future use as fuel
summary: Singapore has completed its first marine methanol bunkering operation, transferring 300 tonnes of green bio-methanol to a dual-fuelled container vessel. The success paves the way for methanol to be used as a marine fuel, with Singapore aiming to adopt a multi-fuel approach. Methanol is seen as an important alternative to decarbonise the shipping industry, which accounts for 3% of global greenhouse gas emissions. A technical reference for methanol bunkering is being developed, and the Singapore Chemical Industry Council and Maritime and Port Authority will lay out groundwork for commercial methanol operations.

site_title: Investors dumping China load up on other emerging markets
summary: Global investors are shifting away from China, favoring emerging markets that are less exposed to the country's economic and geopolitical risks. A Reuters analysis shows a significant increase in assets of emerging market mutual funds and ETFs excluding China, as US and European investors become more wary of China's market. This trend is driven by China's faltering post-Covid economic rebound, lack of policy response, and renewed Sino-US tensions.

images.alt_text: Markets were tricky to navigate as the exuberance over China’s exit from Covid restrictions petered out and uncertainty reigned over the Federal Reserve’s fight to contain inflation.

site_title: Demand for industrial space remains healthy; prices, rents continue rising in Q2: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space sector remains healthy, with industrial rents increasing by 2.1% and prices rising by 1.5% in Q2, according to JTC's quarterly market report. This marks the 11th consecutive quarter of upward trend, despite global economic uncertainties. Multiple-user factory space saw the largest increase, while business park rents rose 1.3% in Q2, but face headwinds from the Punggol Digital District and softer office leasing momentum.

images.alt_text: JTC Corporation's review comes amid rising demand for self-storage services, and a corresponding surge in demand for industrial space by industry players.

JTC's (from left) Yve Xu, deputy director; Nikki Yong, assistant manager; Bryan Ong, assistant manager; Lim Kian Wee, senior project engineer; Tan Chee Kiat, chief sustainability officer. Apart from having a simpler and more intuitive interface, JTC's new web-based embodied carbon calculator also localises carbon emission factors. Yve Xu, Deputy Director; Nikki Yong, Assistant Manager; Bryan Ong, Assistant Manager; Lim Kian Wee, Senior Project Engineer; Tan Chee Kiat, Chief Sustainability Officer.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Olam, MIT, KIT, CLCT, OUE C-Reit, AA Reit
summary: UOB reported a 27% increase in Q2 net profit to S$1.4 billion, beating consensus estimates. Olam Group's net profit is expected to be "materially lower" due to a one-off US$83 million charge related to an unprecedented crop yield in Australia. Other companies, including MIT, KIT, CLCT, OUE C-Reit, and AA Reit, saw varying changes in distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half of 2023. The Singapore dollar's strength against the RMB also impacted gross revenue for some companies.

images.alt_text: A unit of Singapore Airlines providing aviation maintenance, repair and overhaul services, SIA Engineering share price was 1.2 per cent higher at S$2.45, a day after it posted its first quarterly operating profit since the pandemic hit.

site_title:
Employment growth loses steam in Q2; 
wage hike plans, hiring also ease: MOM
summary: Singapore's employment levels expanded by 23,700 in Q2, marking the seventh consecutive quarter of growth, but at a significantly slower pace than previous quarters. This slowdown in employment growth suggests labour demand is cooling.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of office workers crossing a traffic junction along Cecil Street in the Central Business District (CBD) during lunchtime on May 09, 2023.

NTUC secretary general Ng Chee Meng (centre), assistant secretary-general Desmond Choo (left) and Young NTUC executive secretary Wendy Tan briefed the media about the NTUC youth taskforce's findings after engaging more than 10,000 youth over a year.

“With frequent tech disruptions, shortened half-life of skills and knowledge, and new jobs emerging every day – our workforce must retool, at scale and at speed,” says Education Minister Chan Chun Sing.

site_title: Hong Kongers set to get longer visa-free time in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia is set to grant Hong Kongers longer visa-free stays in the country, extending the period from 30 to 90 days without a visa. The move, expected to be announced on Thursday, is seen as a reciprocation of Malaysia's current 90-day visa-free travel to Hong Kong. The decision is part of Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee's efforts to forge closer ties with South-east Asian nations and support the city's bid to join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s monetary policy moves in lock-step with the United States as the city’s currency is pegged to the greenback in a tight range of 7.75-7.85 per US dollar.
Mirxes co-founder Zhou Lihan said the company hopes to tap Hong Kong and China's healthcare and biotech investor base.

site_title: Can UBS make the most of finance’s deal of the century?
summary: The merger of UBS and Credit Suisse has created a financial giant with $5 trillion in invested assets, a balance sheet twice the size of the Swiss economy. The deal, announced on March 19, is the first between two "global systemically important banks." Following the acquisition, Sergio Ermotti returned as UBS CEO, and the combined financial statements were released in May. The deal has led to a significant exodus of Credit Suisse bankers, with many leaving the firm. The merged entity is poised to challenge the dominance of American financial behemoths in the European market.

images.alt_text: The exit of bankers at places like Credit Suisse and Barclays and cuts at Goldman and Morgan Stanley mean hiring opportunities for others.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at the company's office at the Bahnhofstrasse in Zurich in this July 1, 2009 file photo.   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
UBS has decided to indefinitely suspend works in preparation to set up a wholly-owned mutual fund business in China.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as traders bet on end to US Fed rate hikes
summary: Asia's equity markets rallied on Thursday, July 27, as traders bet that the US Federal Reserve's latest interest rate hike will be its last, amid data indicating inflation is being brought under control. Hong Kong and Tokyo led the gains, while the Dow rose for a 13th-straight day. Analysts say the Fed's hawkish tilt suggests the hiking campaign may be over, with the US economy appearing set to avoid a recession. The news boosted the euro and weighed on the US dollar, while markets await the European Central Bank's policy decision and the Bank of Japan's meeting.

images.alt_text: Regional equities surged on Tuesday in response to Beijing’s pledges of stimulus, particularly the property sector, after a string of readings showed the post-Covid recovery was going off the rails.

site_title: HKMA ups rates, matching US Fed, says banks’ bad loans remain steady
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) raised its base rate by 25 basis points to 5.75% on July 27, matching the US Federal Reserve's rate hike, in line with the city's currency peg to the US dollar. The rate increase strengthens the Hong Kong dollar to its strongest level in eight months. Despite higher funding costs for corporates, banks' bad loans remain steady at 1.4%, and analysts expect the rate to remain high due to the Fed's tightening policy and end of dividend flows from Hong Kong-listed Chinese companies.

images.alt_text: A security guard walks past a directory board of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) in Hong Kong December 20, 2012. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
“The collaboration between the IDX and HKEX aims to strengthen the global position of the Indonesian capital market,” says IDX president Director Iman Rachman.
The HKMA is the key manager of the Exchange Fund, which is under the control of the financial secretary and invests in equities, bonds, foreign exchange and other securities and assets.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 24.03 points, or 0.7%, to 3,328.99, driven by gains from local banks UOB and DBS, which rose 1.4% and 1.4% respectively after their Q2 financial results were released. Other heavily traded stocks, including Seatrium and Thai Beverage, also saw gains. The broader market saw 94 gainers outnumbering 41 losers, with 76.3 million securities changing hands worth S$66.6 million.

images.alt_text: UOB's net profit for Q2 is up 27 per cent, in line with consensus estimates.

site_title: Irish singer Sinead O’Connor dies aged 56
summary: Irish singer Sinead O'Connor, known for her iconic 1990 cover of Prince's "Nothing Compares 2 U," has died at 56. Born in County Dublin, O'Connor converted to Islam in 2018 and was ordained as a priest in 1999. Her family has requested privacy as they grieve her passing, with Irish President Michael Higgins praising her "fearless commitment to important issues" and Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar calling her "talent unmatched and beyond compare." O'Connor's outspoken views and mental health struggles were well-documented throughout her career.

images.alt_text: Swift has also become the first living artist in nearly 60 years to have four albums in the top 10 at the same time.

site_title: BOJ to keep ultra-low rates, may debate fine-tuning yield cap
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its ultra-low interest rates and yield curve control targets, but may debate minor tweaks to the policy, including widening the allowance band around the 10-year yield target. The decision comes as inflation has held above the BOJ's 2% target for over a year, with pressure building to act against creeping inflation. The BOJ is wary of premature monetary tightening, which could hurt the economy, and is instead focusing on ensuring the sustainability of its yield curve control program.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk in front of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) head office building (C) in Tokyo on April 27, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
BOJ officials, including governor Kazuo Ueda, have stressed the need to keep ultra-loose policy until there is more evidence inflation will sustainably hit 2 per cent backed by strong wage growth.
Japan’s 2023 growth projection is roughly around the average 1.5 per cent expansion estimated by the IMF for advanced economies.

site_title: Bank of Korea tweaks lending facility to boost liquidity
summary: The Bank of Korea has tweaked its lending facility to boost liquidity, lowering lending rates for loans taken out from the facility to 50 basis points above the base rate from 100 basis points. The decision aims to prepare for large-scale deposit withdrawals under the digital banking environment, following the US Silicon Valley Bank incident. The changes will come into effect on July 31. The central bank also plans to accept additional kinds of bonds as collateral and extend loan maturities. This move aims to strengthen the bank's role as a liquidity backstop for banks and non-bank financial institutions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Bank of Korea is seen in Seoul, South Korea, November 30, 2017.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: China industrial profits extend double-digit slide on weak demand
summary: China's industrial profits declined 16.8% year-to-date, extending a double-digit slide for the sixth consecutive month, due to weak demand. Industrial earnings shrank 8.3% in June and 12.6% in May. State-owned enterprises, foreign firms, and private-sector companies all posted declines, with 29 of 41 major industrial sectors experiencing a drop. Analysts expect a potential turnaround in 2024, driven by expected stimulus, but concerns over debt risks remain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People's Bank of China (PBOC) Deputy Governor Pan Gongsheng speaks at a news conference in Beijing, China March 3, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Aims Apac Reit Q1 DPU rises 1.3% to S$0.0231 on enlarged unit base
summary: Aims Apac Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 1.3% to S$0.0231 for its first quarter ended June, driven by a 4.5% increase in gross revenue to S$43.2 million and 4.2% growth in net property income to S$32.3 million. The Reit's gearing ratio fell to 32.9% after a S$100 million equity fundraising to reduce gearing and fund asset enhancement initiatives. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rose to 98.1% and its weighted average lease expiry stood at 4.3 years.

images.alt_text: Approximately S$67 million of the S$100 million that was raised as part of AIMS Apac Reit's equity fundraising exercise has gone towards repaying existing debts.
The manager also intends to declare an advanced distribution of between S$0.017 and S$0.019 per unit in connection with the private placement.

site_title: Samsung to extend production cuts after 8.9 trillion won chip loss in H1
summary: Samsung Electronics announced plans to extend production cuts for its chip division due to a 4.36 trillion won loss in the April-June quarter, a record loss for the company. The chip industry downturn is largely constrained to high-end chips used in artificial intelligence, with demand recovery expected to be gradual. The company's mobile business reported a 3.04 trillion won profit in the June quarter, forecasting the overall smartphone market to return to year-on-year growth in the second half.

images.alt_text: Samsung, the world’s largest smartphone maker, announces full second-quarter earnings later on Thursday.
The new Galaxy Z Flip 5, a 6.7-inch smartphone that folds down into a square shape, now has an external display covering the majority of one side, making it more useful when closed.

site_title: Japan property lures Singapore investors on Osaka casino bet
summary: Singapore investors are flocking to Osaka, Japan, due to a weaker yen and the city's growing tourism potential. International property agents report a five-fold increase in inquiries since Japan reopened its borders in October, with Singapore accounting for 70% of the 800 requests. The city's upcoming World Expo and casino resort are expected to boost tourism and drive demand for residential units and tourist accommodation. Osaka city authorities estimate 20 million visitors annually, helping Japan reach a 60 million annual foreign tourist target by 2030.

images.alt_text: The Tsutenkaku tower in the Shinsekai neighborhood in Osaka. Photographer: Soichiro Koriyama/Bloomberg

CAAS director-general Han Kok Juan (left) and JCAB senior deputy general-director Onuma Toshiyuki at the CAAS corporate office. The initiatives will help save fuel, reduce carbon emissions and shorten flight times.
The Londoner Macao celebrated its grand opening in Macau in late May, complete with replicas of London landmarks such as the Big Ben.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit secures new 15-year lease at Netherlands property
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has secured a 15-year lease at its Haagse Poort office building in The Hague, Netherlands, with a global asset management firm set to take over the space in two years. The lease covers 10,000 square meters of space, with a tenant-only break option at the 10th year. The move is expected to maintain Haagse Poort's 99% occupancy rate.

images.alt_text: Cromwell E-Reit’s light industrial and logistics sector valuation reversionary yield now stands at 6.8 per cent, 1.1 percentage points lower than its office portfolio at 7.9 per cent.
Cromwell E-Reit has sold its office, Piazza Affari 2 in Milan, for 93.6 million euros.

The manager of Cromwell E-Reit, which also owns Via Nervesa 21 in Milan (pictured), says the proposed divestment of the Bari asset is in line with its strategy to divest non-core and non-strategic assets within the Reit's portfolio.

site_title: Airbus posts higher profit, removes near-term output goal
summary: Airbus reported higher-than-expected underlying operating profit for the second quarter, with adjusted earnings before interest and tax rising 34% to 1.845 billion euros. The company reaffirmed its financial goals for the year, including 720 jet deliveries and 6.0 billion euros of adjusted operating profit, despite removing an interim industrial target for its A320neo-family jets production goal of 75 jets a month by 2026. Airbus cited the goal's irrelevance as it had already surpassed it, and will instead focus on meeting the 75-per-month rate as its key reference point.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Boeing 737 Max aircraft during a display at the Farnborough International Airshow, in Farnborough, Britain, July 20, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Cziborra/File Photo
Airbus has only a handful of delivery slots left for its A320neo family of narrowbodies before 2030, while Boeing’s 737 Max is effectively sold out into 2028.

site_title: LG Energy Solution quarterly profit misses forecasts, shares slide
summary: LG Energy Solution reported an operating profit of 461 billion won for the April-June period, missing forecasts and sending shares down 4.5% due to a one-off cost for General Motors' Bolt EV recall. Revenue rose 73% to 8.8 trillion won. The company had estimated a profit of 612 billion won earlier and analysts forecast 641 billion won. The recall cost was driven by higher material costs, and shares fell 1.9% in trading after the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee walks past the logo of LG Energy Solution at its office building in Seoul, South Korea, Nov. 23, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: US commercial property delinquencies rise further in July: report
summary: US commercial property delinquencies rose further in July, with nearly $12 billion of loans becoming delinquent, pushing the late payment rate up to 3.93% from June. This marks the fourth consecutive month of increase, with a total rate of 6.44% for delinquent loans. Office loans accounted for 35% of newly special serviced loans, followed by retail property loans at 26.4%, and mixed-use properties at 23.7%. The total special servicing balance increased $830.7 million to $14 billion, the largest rise since August 2020.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A carpenter works on building new townhomes that are still under construction while building material supplies are in high demand in Tampa, Florida, U.S., May 5, 2021.  REUTERS/Octavio Jones

site_title: Gold prices hovers near week-high after US Fed chair Powell’s statement
summary: Gold prices hovered near a week-high after US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's statement, with spot gold up 0.2% to $1,975.05 per ounce. The Fed raised interest rates by a quarter-of-a-percentage point, setting the benchmark overnight interest rate in the 5.25-5.50% range. Powell stated that the economy still needed to slow and the labor market to weaken for inflation to return to the 2% target. Despite the US dollar and US Treasury yields edging up, gold prices remained stable, influenced by the Fed's comments and data releases.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: PropertyBT: Strike real estate gold by living near popular schools? (Ep 21)
summary: A premium is paid for homes near popular primary schools in Singapore due to high rental demand, but this can be affected if the school relocates. Experts analyze the phenomenon, noting that while proximity to schools is a key factor, it's not the only consideration. The podcast discusses the importance of understanding the Singapore property landscape and the potential risks and rewards of investing in areas near popular schools.

images.alt_text: Do resale homes offer better value than new homes?
The move by Anglo-Chinese School (Primary) from its current Barker Road campus to Tengah in 2030 is expected to boost prices and rentals of homes in the new town.
HDB Flats in the Bishan Ang Mo Kio area as seen from Ang Mo Kio Central on September 17, 2021.

site_title: US commerce chief says China export controls will hit companies’ revenue
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stated that the Biden administration is updating rules to restrict China's chip industry and outbound investment, aiming to balance revenue loss for US companies with national security concerns. The rules, expected to be implemented soon, will target exports to China without broadly impacting American businesses. Raimondo emphasized that the administration is working with companies to find the right balance, with China's semiconductor purchases accounting for nearly a third of the global total last year. The move aims to limit China's access to US technology to advance its military capabilities.

images.alt_text: China's chip companies told the Ministry of Commerce that US export controls have resulted in significant uncertainty and harm to various stages of the supply chain.

site_title: Mattel expects Barbie bounceback to spark toy sales
summary: Mattel expects a boost in toy sales following the success of the Barbie movie, with CEO Ynon Kreiz citing positive trends and plans to expand Barbie-related products in the second half of the year. The company posted a surprise profit in the second quarter and exceeded market expectations, with Barbie sales falling 6% and Hot Wheels sales rising 10%. Despite this, Mattel maintains its full-year sales and adjusted profit forecast, and shares were down 1.8% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: The craze has affected people of all ages, with Barbies in all skin tones seeing strong sales, says Hylton Bannon, managing director at South African toy store chain Toy Kingdom.
Directed by Greta Gerwig and starring Margot Robbie (above), Barbie has already sold US$356.3 million in theater tickets globally.

Skincare brand mtm labo, headed by managing director Kelly Keak (left), collaborated with Barbie collector Jian Yang (right) to showcase Barbie at her most diverse.  The dolls include Barbie on wheelchairs, albino Barbie and pregnant Barbie.

site_title: Fed staff drop US recession forecast, Powell says
summary: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell stated that Fed staff no longer forecasts a US recession, citing a "noticeable slowdown in growth" but acknowledging "a lot left to go" for a "soft landing." This shift comes as private-sector economists also upgraded their outlooks, with the consensus estimate suggesting a 1.8% annualized GDP growth rate for the April-June period, indicating a "moderate" rate of growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Federal Reserve building is pictured in Washington, March 18, 2008. REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

site_title: LHN to acquire River Valley assets for S$23.3 million
summary: LHN Limited has entered into options to purchase a portfolio of units at River Valley Road in Singapore for S$23.3 million. The acquired assets will be converted into serviced residences or a hotel under the Coliwoo brand, expanding LHN's portfolio and increasing brand value. The acquisition is expected to take 10 weeks to complete and will be funded through internal funding and bank borrowings. The properties, comprising 12 units, are currently leased out, with monthly rentals ranging from S$1,600 to S$8,300. Approval from the Urban Redevelopment Authority is required for the change of use to serviced apartments or hotel uses.

images.alt_text: Lim & Tan Securities believes co-living to be the key growth driver over the next few years for LHN.
Co-living operators, such as LHN's Coliwoo (above), have seen their tenant profile skew towards younger people, who enjoy having shared spaces for a community lifestyle.
The GSM Building has a total land area of 1,115.1 square metres, with a tenure of 99 years starting from May 2, 1978.

site_title: Brazil’s postal service inks deal with Shopee to sell products to Asia
summary: Brazil's postal service, Correios, has signed a deal with Shopee to boost exports of Brazilian products to Southeast Asian markets. The agreement aims to help small and medium companies export to Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Vietnam, and Thailand. Correios will provide training, shipping, and distribution logistics support, and exports are expected to start this year. The move follows Shopee's expansion in Brazil and aims to tap into the trade bloc's $16.6 billion in trade with Brazil in 2022.

images.alt_text: The latest cuts affect fewer than 500 full-time and contract workers in Shopee’s customer service team in Indonesia.
Shopee has been operating in Poland since the autumn of 2021.

site_title: US: Stocks end near flat after Fed hikes rates again
summary: US stocks ended near flat after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates again, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.2% to 35,520.12. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index slipped less than 0.1% as investors awaited data to determine future rate hikes. Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments were non-committal, meeting market expectations. Strong earnings from companies like Boeing, Alphabet, and Coca-Cola offset losses from Microsoft and Texas Instruments.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., July 24, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Consider new safeguards to keep Singapore free of corruption
summary: Singapore's reputation as a corruption-free country is under scrutiny following recent investigations and revelations, including Transport Minister S Iswaran's alleged involvement in a graft probe and extramarital affairs involving MPs. Despite ongoing CPIB investigations, no charges have been filed, and foreign investors' confidence remains unaffected. Experts emphasize the importance of transparency, consistency, and strengthening the code of governance to prevent corruption and protect whistleblowers.

images.alt_text: Allegations of an affair between Mr Leon Perera and Ms Nicole Seah had made their rounds amongst WP members.
PM Lee says the resignations of Tan (left) and Cheng (right) are necessary to “maintain the high standards of propriety and personal conduct which the PAP has upheld all these years”.

DPM Lawrence Wong says that he and PM Lee Hsien Loong are “fully committed” to keeping and preserving the trust that the people have in the government.
Iswaran will take a leave of absence until the investigations are complete.

site_title: EBay’s higher investments weigh on profit forecast, shares fall
summary: eBay forecasted third-quarter profit below market expectations, with shares falling 4.5% after the announcement. The company's higher investments in categories such as auto parts, refurbished goods, and collectibles, as well as its recent acquisitions, have raised concerns about profitability. eBay's gross merchandise value fell 2% in the second quarter, and the company forecast third-quarter revenue between $2.46 billion and $2.52 billion, below analysts' average estimates. The company's shares have declined following the forecast, citing concerns about its ability to maintain profitability amid increasing costs.

images.alt_text: The San Jose, California-based company is aiming to sell more luxury items like watches to boost revenue while also offering refurbished items to appeal to price-conscious shoppers.

More than 270 employees, whose roles include inspecting cards as well as packing and shipping them from an authentication center in Syracuse, New York, will be members of the Communications Workers of America.

site_title: Global standards launched to boost US$2 billion voluntary carbon market
summary: A global initiative has launched voluntary standards for the $2 billion carbon offset market, aiming to increase transparency and environmental quality. The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market has published criteria for projects to achieve its Core Carbon Principle standards, which include quantified monitoring and verification standards. The new standards exclude projects involving coal-fired power generation and oil recovery, and will require companies to disclose the name of the company retiring a carbon credit. The initiative hopes to issue labelled credits by the end of the year, bringing clarity to the unregulated market.

images.alt_text: The latest sustainability reports of the 20 largest primary-listed companies on the SGX average 45,939 words – three times the word count of their financial statements for the corresponding FY.

site_title: Samsung going in ‘right direction’ in China market, mobile chief says
summary: Samsung's mobile chief, TM Roh, says the company is "going in the right direction" in China, where it's making small gains in single-digit market share. Samsung aims to boost premium offerings and partnerships with local content firms to recover its 1% market share, down from 20% in 2013. The company is also working towards a lower-priced foldable model to widen its customer base, particularly in China and India.

images.alt_text: The new Galaxy Z Flip 5, a 6.7-inch smartphone that folds down into a square shape, now has an external display covering the majority of one side, making it more useful when closed.

site_title: ECB to hike rates again but keep options open for September
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to raise interest rates for the ninth consecutive time, with a possible additional hike in September, as inflation remains above target and economic growth slows. The decision comes as policymakers weigh the risks of further rate hikes against the potential for a recession. ECB President Christine Lagarde is expected to take a cautious tone, while some analysts predict the end of rate increases, citing signs of weakening economic prospects and a decrease in inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters building is pictured ahead of the start of the press conference on the eurozone's monetary policy in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany on February 2, 2023. The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to raise interest rates again on June 15, 2023, while signaling that it does not intend to stop there even though inflation is falling and the eurozone has entered recession. (Photo by Daniel ROLAND / AFP)

site_title: Foxconn unit in talks for US$200 million components plant in India’s Tamil Nadu: sources
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, is in talks to invest up to $200 million in a new plant for electronic components in India's Tamil Nadu state. The proposed plant, valued at $180-$200 million, aims to be completed by 2024 and will be the company's second facility in the state, where it already assembles Apple's iPhones. The investment is part of Foxconn's entry into India's semiconductor sector, with the company also exploring opportunities in western Gujarat state.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman carrying an umbrella walks past the logo of Foxconn outside a company's building in Taipei, Taiwan October 31, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins/File Photo

site_title: Startup Cerebras takes on Nvidia with AI supercomputer
summary: Startup Cerebras Systems has built the first of nine artificial intelligence supercomputers in partnership with Abu Dhabi, aiming to provide alternatives to Nvidia technology. The Condor Galaxy 1 supercomputer, costing over $100 million, is now operational and will be doubled in size in the coming weeks. Cerebras' novel approach uses massive chips made from whole silicon wafers, allowing for large data sets to be processed in one go. The company hopes to demonstrate that AI computing can be accessible to more than just large tech companies, with plans to offer excess capacity commercially as a service.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is the world’s top maker of graphics processing units (GPUs), which are in high demand because they can be used to speed up artificial intelligence work.
Google CEO Sundar Pichai (left), and a Google researcher with Google's quantum computer, a supercomputer, in October 2019.
Anthropic, Google, Microsoft, and ChatGPT-maker OpenAI say the newly created Frontier Model Forum will draw on the expertise of its members to minimise AI risks and support industry standards.

Biren’s fundraising efforts come as the Chinese government accelerates its campaign to develop its domestic semiconductor industry, after a US-led effort that blocked Chinese companies’ ability to buy advanced chips

site_title: Asian hedge funds outperform with bets on AI, Japanese and US stocks
summary: Asian hedge funds outperformed their peers in the first half of the year, with returns driven by bets on artificial intelligence, Japanese and US stocks. The average Asia hedge fund gained 1.4%, trailing the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index's 4.8% advance. Funds focused on AI-related shares, such as CloudAlpha Tech Fund's 36% return, and volatile trading in convertible bonds and stocks, contributed to the gains. Notably, some funds made money by betting against Chinese companies that had benefited from Covid restrictions, taking advantage of increased competition and decreased margins.

images.alt_text: A man looks at an electric monitor displaying a stock quotation board outside a bank in Tokyo, Japan, June 5, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: US urges appeals court to lift curbs on social media contacts
summary: The Biden administration has asked a federal appeals court to lift an order curbing government officials' communications with social media companies, citing a lower court judge's decision that US officials coerced social media companies to censor posts during the Covid-19 pandemic. The administration argues the lower court's order is overly broad and would hinder the government's ability to combat misinformation. A panel of 5th Circuit judges is set to hear the case next month, with the May 2022 lawsuit alleging US officials coerced social media companies to censor posts on vaccine hesitancy and election interference.

images.alt_text: The order referred to speech protected by the US Constitution’s First Amendment, which bars the government from “abridging the freedom of speech”.

site_title: Europe: LVMH knocks shares lower after six-day winning streak; US Fed decision eyed
summary: European stocks dropped 0.5% after a six-day winning streak, with luxury goods giant LVMH falling 5.2% due to underwhelming sales results. This suggests a weakening in consumer demand, which may impact economic growth. The European Central Bank is expected to hike interest rates by 25 basis points, while the US Federal Reserve is anticipated to raise rates by a quarter of a percentage point, further dampening investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5 per cent, marking its sixth straight session in the green.

site_title: BT Podcast: Strategy and collaboration a must on path to net zero
summary: Schneider Electric's cluster president Yoon Young Kim emphasizes the challenges of achieving net zero, but notes it's achievable with strategy, collaboration, and digitalization. Key takeaways include the importance of baseline decarbonization, a "stick and carrot" approach with suppliers, and balancing short-term economic goals with long-term sustainability investments. The right talent is also highlighted as crucial for a successful transition to net zero.

images.alt_text: Schneider Electric and BT event: Navigating to Net Zero in a fast changing world

While almost all survey respondents agree that 80 per cent of Singapore's buildings should be "green" by 2030, only 38 per cent say they have a full and comprehensive understanding of green buildings.

site_title: UOB Q2 profit rises 27% to S$1.4 billion
summary: UOB's net profit for the second quarter rose 27% to S$1.4 billion, driven by higher net interest income and trading and investment income, which reached an "all-time high". Fee income dipped 8% and allowances rose 37.6%. Excluding one-off expenses, net profit would have been 35% higher than the same period last year. The bank declared an interim dividend of S$0.85 per share and its core net profit climbed 53% to S$3.1 billion for the six months ended June.

images.alt_text: UOB's card applications have surged since Taylor Swift announced her stop in Singapore – the only one in South-east Asian for her Eras Tour.

UOB’s newly-acquired Citi consumer portfolio will likely double contributions from the bank’s unsecured lending business by the end of 2023, said Jacquelyn Tan, UOB head of group personal financial services.

Earnings for the three banks are expected to peak in 2023, as loan growth and fee income taper off, while the market braces itself for yet another potential round of rate hikes by the Fed within the year.
Although the increase in the cap could lead to a “substantial rise” in GXS and MariBank’s deposit holdings, this still dwarfs in comparison to Singapore’s trio of local banks, Fitch Ratings said.

site_title: Amazon has drawn thousands to try its AI service competing with Microsoft, Google
summary: Amazon has attracted thousands of customers to its AI service, Amazon Bedrock, which competes with Microsoft and Google. The service allows businesses to create applications using AI models, producing new text, images, and content. Amazon announced new AI tools, including a conversational customer-service agent program and technology access from startup Cohere. The company's mission is to make every company an AI company, with Amazon Bedrock drawing interest from organizations like Ryanair and Sun Life.

site_title: Is your company ready for workplace fairness legislation?
summary: Singapore's upcoming workplace fairness legislation aims to promote a fair and progressive workplace culture by balancing flexibility for employers with proportional redress for workplace discrimination. The Singapore National Employers Federation supports the proposals, which are expected to be passed into law by 2024. The legislation is designed to prevent workplace discrimination without creating a litigious culture, and most employers are expected to be able to meet the requirements.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad hopes that employers and employees will "continue to uphold  the overarching principles of merit-based employment."
More remedies for workers, employer penalties proposed for Singapore’s anti-discrimination law

site_title: Barbie sales shoot up as movie frenzy hits South Africa
summary: Barbie sales in South Africa have surged by 30% following the release of the movie "Barbie," with toy stores seeing a significant increase in sales. The craze has affected people of all ages, with Barbies in all skin tones experiencing strong sales. The movie's success has contributed to a boom in sales, with the iconic toy becoming a cultural phenomenon in the country.

images.alt_text: Directed by Greta Gerwig and starring Margot Robbie (above), Barbie has already sold US$356.3 million in theater tickets globally.
Politicians have gotten in on Barbie-mania, with Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer posting photos of a Barbie meant to resemble herself online.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau overhauls Cabinet to focus on economy
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau made significant changes to his Cabinet, tweaking or changing job descriptions of about three-quarters of the positions. The focus shifts to economic issues, including housing and the rising cost of living, amid sagging poll numbers. Trudeau kept key ministers such as Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland and Foreign Minister Melanie Joly in their portfolios, while appointing former immigration minister Sean Fraser to the newly formed Housing, Infrastructure and Communities ministry.

site_title: US Fed lifts rates to highest since 2001 and hints at more to come
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark lending rate to 5.25-5.5% on July 26, the highest level since 2001, to combat above-target inflation. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that policy will remain restrictive until inflation is brought down sustainably and prepared to further tighten if necessary. The move comes amid improving economic prospects, with unemployment near historic lows and resilient consumer spending. Powell reiterated the possibility of a "soft landing" and a recession, but now expects a noticeable slowdown in growth starting later this year.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six major peers, edges 0.2 per cent lower to 101.09.
Most crypto companies dispute the SEC’s jurisdiction, and have pushed Congress in recent months to write laws clarifying that cryptocurrencies are more akin to commodities than securities.

site_title: Samsung rolls out thinner foldable phones, tablet and watch upgrades
summary: Samsung has released its fifth-generation foldable smartphones, the Galaxy Z Flip 5 and Galaxy Z Fold 5, with improved hinges and external displays. The new devices retain their pricing, with the Flip at $999 and the Fold at $1,799. Samsung also unveiled updates to its Galaxy Watch 6 and Galaxy Tab S9 tablets, as well as new smartwatches. The company aims to expand its ecosystem of complementary devices, competing with Apple's products in the market. Foldables now account for about 5% of the overall smartphone market, with Samsung seeking to capitalize on this growth.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi’s offline push comes months after it lost its leadership position to Samsung, which had a much bigger portfolio of premium phones now in vogue.

In December, Samsung Display filed a complaint with the US International Trade Commission, alleging patent infringement by numerous companies selling OLED screens as replacement displays for mobile devices.
The world’s largest memory maker is looking to catch up with TSMC while also fending off a nascent challenge from Intel, which is pushing into the foundry market.
Samsung is expected to unveil its latest foldable smartphones later this month in Seoul.
Samsung is due to release detailed earnings on Jul 27.
The memo from Samsung  advises staff to refrain from uploading work-related information to ChatGPT when logging in on personal computers outside company premises.
Samsung Electronics said operating profit fell to 640 billion won (S$639 million) for the January-March quarter, from 14.12 trillion won a year earlier.

site_title: US new home sales cool slightly as lack of supply weighs on market
summary: US new home sales cooled slightly in June, reaching an annual rate of 697,000, seasonally adjusted. This was in line with analyst expectations, but slightly below May's revised rate. New home sales were 23.8% higher than the same period last year, with a median price of $415,400. Despite elevated mortgage rates, a lack of existing properties has driven demand for new homes, leading to steep discounts and temporary mortgage buydowns. The sales rate in the second quarter was higher than the average in the first three months of the year.

images.alt_text: Existing home sales fall 3.3 per cent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.16 million units, the lowest level since January, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) says.

site_title: Evergrande EV unit reports about 71 billion yuan loss for 2021, 2022
summary: Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group (NEV) reported a combined net loss of 71.12 billion yuan (S$13.2 billion) for 2021 and 2022, citing weakening demand and a price war in China's largest auto market. The company had warned of potential operations closure unless new funding was secured. Despite delivering over 1,000 units of its flagship model, Hengchi 5, by May 2022, the firm's financial struggles continue, with only 25-30 of 167 NEV brands in China expected to survive by 2030.

images.alt_text: The company’s struggles helped set off the initial wave of concerns about China’s property sector.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the electric vehicle (EV) factory of China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group in Tianjin, China October 20, 2021. Picture taken October 20, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun/File Photo
Evergrande NEV’s woes underscore how difficult it is to manufacture cars at scale, even when a company has many billions of dollars behind it.

site_title: Oil falls 1% after US Fed rate hike, smaller-than-expected US crude stockdraw
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Wednesday after US crude inventories drew 600,000 barrels less than expected, and the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. The rate hike, the 11th in 12 meetings, sets the benchmark overnight interest rate in the 5.25-5.50% range. Oil prices had rallied for four weeks due to tighter supplies, but higher interest rates could slow economic growth and reduce demand.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled up 90 US cents at US$83.64 a barrel, after hitting US$83.87 earlier, the highest since Apr 19.

site_title: Chinese automakers drive Thailand’s aggressive EV push
summary: Thailand is poised to become a leading automotive manufacturing hub in South-east Asia, with Chinese automakers driving the country's aggressive electric vehicle (EV) push. Between January and May, 33,367 imported BEV models were sold in Thailand, a significant increase from 2022 and 2021. The Thai government's subsidies and supportive policies have made EVs comparable to internal combustion engine vehicles, attracting investments from Chinese brands like BYD, Great Wall Motor, and SAIC-MG. Thailand aims to have 30% of local automobile production be electric by 2030 and 50% of newly-registered cars be electric.

images.alt_text: Both Renault and Nissan are under pressure as competition from Tesla and Chinese EV makers intensifies.
Ion Mobility electric motorcycle motor and battery layout.
Net profit for the three months ended June comes in at 10.895 billion yuan, up 63.22 per cent from a year earlier, according to a Reuters calculation based on CATL’s company filing.

site_title: Tottenham owner Joe Lewis surrenders in insider trading case
summary: Billionaire Joe Lewis, owner of Tottenham Hotspur soccer club, turned himself in to US authorities to face charges of abusing his access to corporate boardrooms to pass on inside information to friends, staff, and loved ones. Lewis faces over a dozen counts of securities fraud and is expected to appear in court in New York. The Securities and Exchange Commission also filed an insider trading lawsuit against Lewis, his private pilots, and a former girlfriend.

images.alt_text: Investors have accused Musk, the world’s second-richest person according to Forbes magazine, of deliberately driving up Dogecoin’s price more than 36,000 per cent over two years and then letting it crash.

site_title: GM, Stellantis unite to build North American EV charger network
summary: General Motors and Stellantis are partnering to build a North American electric vehicle charger network, investing at least $1 billion to install 30,000 fast chargers across the US and Canada. The joint venture will support both Tesla's North American Charging Standard and the Combined Charging System, with the first chargers set to open in summer 2024. The move aims to expand charging availability as electric vehicle adoption accelerates, with automakers such as GM and Stellantis seeking to meet lofty sales goals.

images.alt_text: GM is still tied overwhelmingly to internal combustion engines, and can lean into that legacy business if demand for EVs isn’t blazing away.
Within GM’s EV portfolio, the Bolt has represented more than 90 per cent of its EV sales so far this year.
GM says net income for the second quarter rises by nearly 52 per cent to US$2.6 billion.
Starting in 2025, Nissan will equip its EVs with the Tesla-developed North American Charging Standard (NACS) port, as it targets 40 per cent of US vehicle sales to be fully electric by 2030.

The administration’s proposal “underestimates key challenges, including the scarcity of minerals to make batteries, the fact that these minerals are not mined or refined in the US, the inadequate infrastructure and the high cost of battery-electric vehicles,” Toyota says.
Ford Motor and General Motors say their future electric vehicles would use Tesla’s charging gear, with Rivian, Volvo and Mercedes-Benz quickly following.

site_title: US President Biden’s son Hunter’s plea deal over tax charges falls apart
summary: US President Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden's plea deal to plead guilty to failing to pay income taxes fell apart due to concerns over a provision that would have allowed him to avoid prosecution for a separate gun-related charge. The deal, which would have allowed Hunter Biden to enter a pretrial diversion agreement, was nullified after prosecutors expressed concerns about the provision. The case stems from Hunter Biden allegedly not paying taxes on over $1.5 million in income in 2017 and 2018 despite owing more than $100,000.

images.alt_text: Hunter Biden, son of U.S. President Joe Biden, arrives at federal court to plead guilty to two misdemeanor charges of willfully failing to pay income taxes in Wilmington, Delaware, U.S., July 26, 2023. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posts 17.2% fall in H1 DPU to US$0.025
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit reported a 17.2% decline in first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.025, due to higher financing costs, rising interest rates, and divestments of two Atlanta properties. Despite this, net property income grew 2% to US$43.9 million, and gross revenue increased 2.4% to US$75.9 million. The Reit's distribution yield was 16% and will be paid out on September 29. The manager attributed the decline to a cash fee decision and hedged long-term loans with interest rate swaps.

images.alt_text: The upgrading and addition of amenities such as in-house cafes, gyms and conference facilities have helped Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit outperform its peers, analysts say.

site_title: US SEC set to adopt new cyber rule, unveils brokerage AI proposal
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is set to adopt a new cybersecurity rule requiring publicly traded companies to disclose hacking incidents within four days, with some exceptions for national security or police investigations. Additionally, the SEC will issue a proposal governing conflicts of interest in broker-dealers' use of artificial intelligence, aiming to prevent AI-driven trading that prioritizes the broker's financial interest over clients'. These measures are part of the SEC's broader efforts to protect the financial system against data theft and cyber-intrusions.

images.alt_text: Microsoft says its decision was “in response to increasing frequency and evolution of nation-state cyberthreats.”
The hacking group, which Microsoft dubbed Storm-0558, forges digital authentication tokens to access webmail accounts running on the firm’s Outlook service, Microsoft says.

site_title: Volkswagen to expand China EV line-up with Xpeng, SAIC partnerships
summary: Volkswagen has partnered with Chinese electric vehicle maker Xpeng to develop two new models in China, targeting the middle-class segment. The partnership includes Xpeng software on autonomous driving and will be rolled out from 2026. Volkswagen will invest $700 million in Xpeng and purchase a 4.99% stake. The company also announced plans for cooperation with Chinese heavyweight SAIC, including joint model development and a new platform. These partnerships aim to strengthen Volkswagen's position in the Chinese market and play catch-up with premium brands like Audi.

images.alt_text: Other issues also weigh on Volkswagen’s stock market performance, from high capital costs and risks in China to concerns over its ability to maintain market dominance in an electric age.
Some larger chip manufacturers view China’s export controls on gallium as more of a warning shot about what economic pain the country could inflict.
Ford, General Motors and ChargePoint are among the companies that have signed up for Tesla’s charging design in the past few weeks.

site_title: Adani’s unit secures US$394 million financing facility for solar module plant
summary: Adani Enterprises' unit, Adani New Industries Limited (ANIL), secured a US$394 million financing facility from Barclays and Deutsche Bank for its integrated solar module manufacturing facility. This comes as the Adani group revisits its expansion plans after a short seller's report in January impacted investor confidence. The facility is seen as a positive sign of improving investor sentiment, with Australia-listed investment firm GQG Partners and other investors increasing their stake in Adani Group companies. The Adani group has denied allegations of improper use of tax havens and concerns over debt levels.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Big Tech results roll in; Fed in focus
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, July 26, as investors assessed mixed earnings from Microsoft and Alphabet ahead of a potential Federal Reserve rate hike. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 92.08 points, or 0.26%, to 35,345.99. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the Dow Jones down 0.26%, the S&P 500 down 0.19%, and the Nasdaq Composite down 0.15%. The mixed earnings results and potential rate hike have investors on edge, leading to a decrease in the market.

site_title: Insurance policyholders can nominate beneficiaries online from 2024
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced that insurance policyholders will be able to nominate beneficiaries online from January 2024. This change aims to replace the current hard-copy submission process with in-person witnessing through digital means. Insurers will use secure electronic signatures and online witness or attestors to ensure the authenticity and integrity of records. The move is expected to provide policyholders with greater flexibility and convenience in nominating beneficiaries, with industry associations welcoming the enhancement.

site_title: CEL starts preview of TMW Maxwell; units priced upward of S$3,000 psf
summary: TMW Maxwell, a 20-storey mixed-use development, will launch for preview on July 29, with prices starting above S$3,000 per square foot (psf). The 41,799.5 sq ft project, developed by CEL Development, SingHaiyi Investments, and Chuan Investments, comprises 324 residential units and a commercial podium. The development occupies the site of the former Maxwell House and is the first of four residential projects in Singapore's central business district, with indicative price ranges between S$1.5 million and S$2 million.

images.alt_text: Non-PR citizens from the US purchased 56 such non-landed homes in Q2, marginally higher than the 51 units bought by non-PR mainland Chinese buyers.

site_title: Boeing boosts monthly 737 production to 38, posts upbeat earnings
summary: Boeing boosts monthly 737 production to 38, exceeding expectations, as the company recovers from a supplier error that had slowed its ramp-up. Boeing posted upbeat second-quarter earnings, beating Wall Street expectations, and reiterated its plan to generate $3 billion to $5 billion in free cash flow this year. The company also plans to deliver at least 400 single-aisle 737s and 70 787 Dreamliners in 2023, amid heightened travel demand. Despite challenges, Boeing's CEO says the company is on track to meet its goals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Ryanair Boeing 737-800 aircraft approaches Paris-Beauvais airport in Tille, northern France, September 27, 2018.  REUTERS/Christian Hartmann/File Photo

site_title: Geo Energy buys stakes in Indonesian coal-linked companies for US$154 million
summary: Geo Energy Resources has agreed to acquire stakes in Indonesian coal-linked companies, Golden Eagle Energy and Marga Bara Jaya, for US$154 million and US$49,000, respectively. The transactions require shareholder approval and will give Geo Energy a 58.7% stake in Golden Eagle Energy and a 33% stake in Marga Bara Jaya. The acquisition aims to increase coal production to 25 million tonnes per annum with "lower costs and greater operational efficiency."

images.alt_text: A generic photo of coal barge berthing in Indonesia. Geo Energy noted that cash cost per tonne has increased to US$52.6 per tonne in Q1, from US$36.6 per tonne a year ago.
Discussions with the third-party coal mine owner over several potential avenues of repayments for the settlement of the outstanding receivables are ongoing, Geo Energy said.

The grouping Opec+, which comprises members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) as well as major non-Opec oil producers such as Russia, on Sunday (Apr 2) announced it would cut oil output by about 1.2 million barrels per day (bpd).

site_title: Olam Group expects one-off charge of US$83 million for H1 2023; net profit to be ‘materially lower’
summary: Olam Group expects a one-off charge of US$83 million for the first half of 2023 due to a 35-40% lower crop yield in its Australian almond orchards. The decline is attributed to lower bee activity, unseasonal cold, and wet conditions. Despite this, Olam expects its overall net profit to remain positive for H1 2023 and FY2023, with the impact of higher interest costs partially recovered through increased selling prices.

images.alt_text: Olam Group says it continues to seek the concurrent listing of Olam Agri on the exchanges of both Singapore and Saudi Arabia.
Singapore Exchange Centre at 2 Shenton Way, taken on 15 Feb 2019.

Olam among first in Singapore market to report detailed natural capital accounts

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust Q1 DPU falls to S$0.0339 after May’s private placement
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 2.9% to S$0.0339 for Q1, due to a private placement in May increasing the number of units in issue. The trust's net property income rose 0.7% to S$130.8 million, while gross revenue increased 1.7% to S$170.6 million. The trust's CEO, Tham Kuo Wei, stated that the addition of a high-quality data centre will improve the stability of MIT's income stream, but warned of potential pressure on distributions due to rising operating expenses and borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Industrial Trust's manager expects the acquisition to be distribution per unit and net asset value per unit accretive to unitholders.

site_title: Singapore could mine its only dump as waste keeps piling up
summary: Singapore is considering mining its only landfill site, Pulau Semakau, to recover incinerated waste ash and extend its lifespan. The landfill, about 8km off the coast, is projected to run out of space by 2035 due to a rising volume of rubbish. Minister for Sustainability and the Environment, Grace Fu, has proposed using the ash for a second lease of life, providing an additional 10-15 years of space.

images.alt_text: The landfill space in the southern perimeter bund of Pulau Semakau in 2011.

site_title: Investors are seized by optimism. Can the bull market last?
summary: The US stock market has entered a full-blown bull market, with investors experiencing optimism despite the recent AI boom. Legendary fund manager John Templeton's philosophy of buying during periods of maximum pessimism seems to be working, as investors took advantage of the 2009 and 2020 market downturns to buy stocks. The bull market has broadened beyond tech firms, with various industries contributing to the growth.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.5 per cent at 35,411.24 as the index touched a fresh 15-month peak during the trading.

A man watches a 300mm Wafer manufactured by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) during the World Semiconductor Congress in Nanjing in China's eastern Jiangsu province on July 19, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Binance withdraws application for crypto licence in Germany
summary: Binance has withdrawn its application for a crypto licence in Germany due to changing market and regulatory conditions. The company's application for a crypto custody licence was denied by German regulators. Binance still intends to apply for licensing in Germany, but with revised submissions. The move follows a lawsuit from the US Securities and Exchange Commission accusing Binance of operating a "web of deception" and comes amid pressure from regulators worldwide.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum, DogeCoin, Ripple, and Litecoin are seen in front of a displayed Binance logo in this illustration taken, June 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Binance has taken some steps to expand its Asian footprint elsewhere too, including in South Korea and Thailand.
Binance faces a web of regulatory probes around the world as well as a decline in its market share of spot digital-asset trading volumes.
The layoffs at the world’s biggest crypto exchange come at a time when the industry’s future in the US market is uncertain.
Binance faces a web of probes around the world.
Binance typically accesses Sepa via payment intermediaries.

site_title: Rice surges to three-year high as Indian export ban roils market
summary: Rice prices in Asia have surged to a three-year high, reaching US$572 a ton for Thai white rice 5 per cent broken, the most expensive level since April 2020. The price increase is attributed to India's export ban, which has raised concerns about global supplies of the food staple. This surge in prices could exacerbate inflationary pressures and boost import bills for buyers, affecting the diets of billions in Asia and Africa.

site_title: Actor Kevin Spacey acquitted of all nine sexual offence charges
summary: Kevin Spacey, 64, was acquitted of nine charges, including sexual assault and causing a person to engage in sexual activity without consent, in a London court. He was found not guilty by a jury of committing historical sex offences against four men. The charges dated back to incidents between 2004 and 2013 at London's Old Vic theatre and his apartment. Spacey began crying in the dock after the verdict.

images.alt_text: Actor Kevin Spacey walks outside Southwark Crown Court, as the jury consider their verdict over charges related to allegations of sex offences, in London, Britain, July 26, 2023. REUTERS/Susannah Ireland

site_title: Why Italy’s PM will get warm White House welcome
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni is set to discuss Italy's ties with China during her visit to the White House, with the US hoping for Italy's withdrawal from China's Belt and Road Initiative. The move would be a significant shift, given Italy's 2019 signing of the BRI project, which has sparked concerns over Beijing's influence in Europe. US officials have long been wary of the initiative, citing its ambitious nature and potential to overshadow the post-war Marshall Plan. A reversal from Rome would be welcomed in Washington, with the Biden administration seeking to strengthen the Italian-US bilateral relationship.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Italy's Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni attends the European leaders summit in Brussels, Belgium February 9, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni says that the country can have “good relations” with China “even in important areas of interest with Beijing without necessarily being part of an overall strategic plan”.
China and economic security will be main topics when G7 leaders meet in Japan next month, according to an official familiar with the discussions.

site_title: Amazon offers up marketplace rule change to ease UK antitrust concerns
summary: Amazon has agreed to change its treatment of third-party sellers on its UK marketplace after an investigation by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA). The company has promised to treat all sellers equally and to share sales data with rivals, addressing concerns over unfair advantages. The CMA will consult on the proposals before deciding whether to accept them, which could help ensure third-party sellers can compete on a level playing field and ultimately benefit UK customers.

site_title: Indonesia to make it less painful for exporters to keep earnings onshore
summary: The Indonesian government is developing a scheme to make it easier for exporters to keep their earnings onshore, addressing concerns raised by business groups that new rules were hindering their ability to cover operational costs. The government is finalizing rules to allow a back-to-back loan using exporters' funds as collateral and introducing new tax incentives to ensure attractive returns for onshore funds. The move aims to alleviate the impact of a rule requiring exporters to retain 30% of their proceeds in the domestic financial system for three months.

images.alt_text: BI governor Perry Warjiyo says monetary policy remains focused on ensuring inflation stays within target and the rupiah currency remains stable.
Shell had been looking to sell its 35 per cent interest in the project since 2019.

site_title: AT&T tops profit, cash flow estimate while customer growth slows
summary: AT&T reported second-quarter earnings that topped analyst estimates, with 63 cents a share in profit and $4.2 billion in free cash flow. The company reiterated its target of reaching $16 billion or more in free cash flow this year. However, customer growth slowed, with 326,000 new mobile phone subscribers added in the second quarter, below expectations. AT&T also faces challenges from high debt, a heavy restructuring effort, and potential costs associated with cleaning lead out of its copper phone network.

images.alt_text: Vodafone will own 51 per cent and Hutchison 49 per cent of the combined group, which will be led by current Vodafone UK boss Ahmed Essam, the companies say.

site_title: Trans-cab purchase signals grab for drivers and maybe profits
summary: Grab's acquisition of taxi operator Trans-cab signals a potential shift in the point-to-point transport market in South-east Asia, where companies are competing for drivers and profits. The deal, valued at over S$100 million, may lead to further consolidation in the industry, raising concerns about pricing power for consumers. With Trans-cab's fleet of 2,200 taxis and 300 private-hire vehicles, Grab gains a significant advantage in the market, which is expected to close in the fourth quarter this year.

images.alt_text: Grab's proposed acquisition of Trans-cab will still require approval from the authorities.
Grab will acquire Singapore's third-largest taxi operator, Trans-cab, through its subsidiary Grab Rentals.

site_title: Alphabet rallies as Google Search unfazed by challenge from Microsoft's Bing
summary: Alphabet's shares rallied over 5% on Wednesday, adding more than $100 billion to its market capitalization, as Google Search business showed resilience despite competition from Microsoft's AI-powered Bing. Analysts attributed the company's strong quarterly earnings to its dominant search position, steady cloud growth, and ability to compete in AI. Jefferies and other brokerages raised their price targets, citing AI's contribution to Google's cloud revenue and growth. The median price target now stands at $145, nearly 19% higher than the stock's last close.

images.alt_text: Anthropic, Google, Microsoft, and ChatGPT-maker OpenAI say the newly created Frontier Model Forum will draw on the expertise of its members to minimise AI risks and support industry standards.
Microsoft has started integrating AI functionality across its products such as Azure,
Microsoft 365 Copilot will be offered for subscription plans that currently range in price from US$12.50 to US$57 a user each month.
Alphabet’s results were helped by steady demand for its cloud services and a rebound in advertising.
Microsoft said costs rose sharply as it built new data centres to support AI.
FILE PHOTO: Google, Microsoft and Alphabet logos and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US dollar slips before Fed, euro rises on ECB rate hike bets
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% to 101.09 against six major peers, hovering near a two-week high ahead of the Fed's interest rate hike. Investors await Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments and expect a quarter-point hike, with market reaction also influenced by ECB and BOJ policy decisions. The euro rose 0.2% to $1.1081, while the Australian dollar slid 0.5% to $0.6757, following slower-than-expected inflation data.

site_title: JPMorgan sees gold charging to records in 2024 as Fed cuts rates
summary: JPMorgan Chase predicts gold prices will reach fresh records in 2024 as interest rates start to fall, with an average price target of US$2,175 an ounce. The bank attributes gold's 15% rally over the past year to signs of the US rate-hiking cycle ending, central bank buying, and haven demand. A mild US recession forecasted for 2024 is expected to drive gold prices, with falling real yields in the US being a significant driver.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

An employee places a storage tray containing two hundred and fifty gram gold bars, produced by Swiss manufacturer Argor Hebaeus SA, into the safe at Aranypiac Kft in Budapest, Hungary, on Wednesday, July 20, 2016. Precious metals are back in demand as renewed concerns over Britain's decision to leave the EU have investors fleeing for gold. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg
Net gold imports into China stand at 34.648 metric tons in June, compared with 49.056 metric tons in May, Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department data shows.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 1% rise in H1 DPU to S$0.0193
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 1% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half of 2023 to S$0.0193, translating to a 7.5% distribution yield. The DPU growth was driven by a 51.8% increase in distributable income to S$132.9 million, mainly due to contributions from piped gas distributor City Energy and new acquisitions. The trust's energy transition segment saw a 165.8% increase in distributable income, while its environmental services segment saw a 3.7% increase.

images.alt_text: Following “strong demand” for the placement and an oversubscription rate of about 4.2 times, KIT's manager says it will increase the number of placement units to 383,648,000.
The exercise comprises a private placement at a price between S$0.464 and S$0.477 per placement unit and a non-renounceable preferential offering at a price between S$0.464 and S$0.467 per new unit.
For the full year, distributable income was up 15.8 per cent to S$222.5 million, while full-year DPU rose 1 per cent to S$0.0382.

site_title: Coca-Cola raises revenue, profit forecasts on resilient demand, higher prices
summary: Coca-Cola raised its annual revenue and profit forecast due to resilient demand for its sodas, despite higher prices and rising costs. The company's average selling prices rose 10% in the second quarter, while unit case volumes remained flat. Coca-Cola now expects organic revenue growth of 8-9% for the full year, and core earnings per share to rise 5-6%. The company's shares rose 1% in premarket trading, driven by its ability to offset rising costs with higher pricing.

images.alt_text: “Coca-Cola has one of the best production and distribution systems globally... who have successfully navigated plenty of hurdles in the past, like sugar taxes and reformulations associated with that,” says Charlie Higgs, an associate partner at Redburn.
Average selling prices rose 11 per cent in the first quarter, Coca-Cola said, while unit case volumes rose 3 per cent.

site_title: Banks’ US$118 billion buffer likely wiped out by new capital rules
summary: US banks' excess capital of $118 billion may be wiped out by new capital rules, potentially limiting shareholder buybacks for years. The Federal Reserve and FDIC are set to vote on the proposals, which are part of a sweeping review led by Fed Vice Chairman Michael Barr. The changes, aimed at implementing international banking standards, could make US banks less competitive against European rivals and impact lending ability to repurchase shares. The proposals are expected to be implemented over several years, with some analysts predicting stingier buybacks and dividends until 2025.

images.alt_text: IMF chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas says the biggest threat to the world economy remains inflation.

site_title: Malaysia PM raises prospect of Asean engaging informally with Myanmar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim discussed the possibility of allowing Asean member countries to engage informally with Myanmar's junta without compromising human rights concerns. This move comes after Thailand hosted an informal meeting with Myanmar earlier this year. Ibrahim, a vocal critic of the junta, emphasized the need for flexibility in Asean's engagement with Myanmar while maintaining its five-point peace plan. The discussion was held with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr during bilateral meetings in Kuala Lumpur.

images.alt_text: Asean, which includes Myanmar among its 10 members, has pushed, without success, for the implementation of a five-point peace plan agreed with the junta shortly after a coup in early 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong, Indonesia’s stock exchanges explore cross-border listings
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) is exploring opportunities with Indonesia's stock exchange (IDX) for cross-border listings, product development, and environmental, social, and governance initiatives. The collaboration aims to strengthen the Indonesian capital market's global position. This move comes after a meeting between Hong Kong's chief executive and Indonesian President Joko Widodo to enhance connections with Asean member states. IDX president Iman Rachman stated that the collaboration will benefit the Indonesian capital market.

site_title: Singapore-listed companies’ codes of conduct least effective compared to global peers: LRN report
summary: Singapore-listed companies' codes of conduct are the least effective compared to global peers, according to a report by ethics and compliance company LRN.
