The report found that companies in the Straits Times Index (STI) scored the lowest in terms of code-effectiveness, contrasting with US S&P 100 companies, which outperformed other indices overall. This is the first time Japan and Singapore are included in the study, which covers 200 top-traded companies in Asia, Europe, and North America.

images.alt_text: The recent cases of independent directors being hauled to court for disclosure-related offences have sent shockwaves to many independent directors.
Generic photo of greenery in city state Singapore. For stories regarding ESG, sustainability, sustainability investing, and business environmental governance
New code of conduct launched to level playing field for retail tenants and landlords

site_title: Rolls-Royce leaps as airline and defence demand lifts profits
summary: Rolls-Royce has raised its full-year operating profit forecast by 45% due to operational improvements, increased military spending, and a recovery in long-haul flying. The company now expects profit of between £1.2 billion and £1.4 billion, up from its previous guidance. Shares jumped 20% to 183pence, the highest level since the pandemic, after the company reported a stronger-than-expected first half.

images.alt_text: Part of the turnaround plan will see the combination of non-manufacturing departments in each of the company’s civil aerospace, defence and power systems divisions.
“Our transformation programme will improve our efficiency and commercial outcomes, and deliver a sustainable reduction in working capital,” Rolls-Royce CEO Tufan Erginbilgic said.
Rolls-Royce has posted an underlying operating profit of £125 million (S$209.8 million) for the first 6 months, down from £307 million a year earlier and lower than predicted by analysts.

site_title: Tech giants form AI group focused on ensuring safety
summary: Tech giants Anthropic, Google, Microsoft, and OpenAI have formed the Frontier Model Forum to address AI risks and support industry standards. The group aims to minimize AI risks, share best practices, and develop robust technical mechanisms such as watermarking systems to ensure users know when content is from AI. The Forum will also support applications tackling challenges like climate change and cyber threats, with the goal of advancing AI responsibly and benefiting humanity.

images.alt_text: GIC group chief investment officer Jeffrey Jaensubhakij said it’s still early days, with a new AI company being set up every week and dozens attacking the same problem.
Microsoft said costs rose sharply as it built new data centres to support AI.
FILE PHOTO: Google, Microsoft and Alphabet logos and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
OpenAI, whose AI chatbot ChatGPT, has stormed the world, has said it depends on its trust and safety team to build “the processes and capabilities to prevent misuse and abuse of AI technologies”.
Apple has created a chatbot service that some engineers call Apple GPT.

site_title: Volatile electricity prices zap number of Singapore households on retail contracts
summary: Singapore's electricity retail market has seen a decline in switch rates, with 39% of households on retail contracts as of July 1, down from 48% in 2021. The drop is attributed to reduced power-bill savings and less competitive rates since the energy crisis. However, business consumers have seen an increase in retail contract uptake, with around 3,000 contracts signed per month. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) plans to strengthen consumer protection by enhancing regulatory requirements for electricity retailers, with a new framework expected to be announced later this week.

images.alt_text: Back in the ‘heyday’ of Singapore’s OEM in 2019/20, residential consumers were spoilt for choice as frenzied competition among retailers eager to grow market share resulted in super competitive rates (BT File photo)

site_title: Ho Kwon Ping, Royston Tan among official backers of Tharman’s presidency bid
summary: Tharman Shanmugaratnam, a former senior minister, has officially launched his presidential bid in Singapore, with 10 prominent individuals backing his candidacy. They include businessmen, former public servants, and a film director, who praise Tharman's leadership experience, independence, and vision for the country. Tharman, who has spent 22 years in public service, promises to bring his expertise in finance, unifying Singaporeans, and representing the country internationally to the presidency. He urges voters to look beyond party affiliations and focus on candidates' track records, warning that judging candidates solely by their government connections could weaken the system.

images.alt_text: Going by election results, Tharman is one of the most popular politicians around.

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.

George Goh says he decided to run for president after the eligibility requirements for private sector candidates were raised in 2017, as he was “concerned that the more stringent requirements would lead to another uncontested election”.
Ng Kok Song and his fiance Sybil Lau arrived at the Elections Department shortly past 10.30am on Wednesday to pick up an application form for the certificate of eligibility

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Most manufacturing segments in Singapore recorded declines in June, with factory output contracting for the ninth straight month. Singapore's factory output fell 4.9% year-on-year, beating expectations. Meanwhile, 40% of households are now on retail contracts for electricity, down from a peak in 2021, and prominent businessmen have backed former senior minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam's bid for Singapore's presidency.

site_title: Singapore shares up 0.6% ahead of Fed’s policy decision
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, July 26, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision. The Straits Times Index gained 18.8 points to 3,304.96 points. SIA Engineering's share price closed 1.2% higher at S$2.45, after posting its first quarterly operating profit since the pandemic. The market is expecting interest-rate hikes by the Fed and European Central Bank, but investors are looking for signals that the hike cycles may be ending.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares close a whisker shy of its 52-week high at S$1.52, up 1.3 per cent.
Singapore shares are little changed in early trade after US and Europe markets posted strong overnight gains.
Sembcorp Industries is no longer planning to sell its waste-management business and its energy-from-waste plant.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.1 per cent higher at 35,437.93, extending its winning streak for a 12th straight session.
Brent futures settled up 90 US cents at US$83.64 a barrel, after hitting US$83.87 earlier, the highest since Apr 19.

site_title: GIC’s view of investing in a world of disruptions
summary: GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, remains committed to seeking stable long-term returns despite a challenging global investment environment. The fund has strengthened its portfolio resilience by integrating sustainability and diversifying exposures. Amidst persistent inflation, geopolitical risks, and potential structural shifts to a higher interest rates world, GIC will continue to navigate disruptions. The fund has also been building up its infrastructure assets and integrating sustainability into its investment processes, focusing on green transition opportunities.

images.alt_text: GIC group chief investment officer Jeffrey Jaensubhakij said it’s still early days, with a new AI company being set up every week and dozens attacking the same problem.
GIC reported an annualised rolling 20-year real rate of return of 4.6 per cent for its latest period ended Mar 31, the highest in eight years.

site_title: OUE C-Reit posts 23.1 per cent rise in H1 net property income to S$115.3m
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 23.1% increase in net property income to S$115.3 million for the first half of 2023, driven by stable or improving occupancy and positive rental reversions in its commercial segment. Revenue rose 19.8% to S$138.8 million, with its hospitality segment benefiting from Singapore's tourism sector recovery. However, distributable income fell 3.3% to S$57.6 million due to higher financing costs. The company's office segment had an occupancy of 96.1% and positive rental reversion of 8.1%.

images.alt_text: Generic picture of OUE building along Shenton way.
SLLs now comprise 69.6 per cent of OUE C-REIT’s total borrowings as of end-March.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia to cut at least 100 jobs
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia plans to cut at least 100 jobs, primarily in its retail bank and technology units. The move comes after Westpac Banking laid off 300 jobs earlier this month. The bank, which employs around 50,000 people, stated that customer-facing roles will remain unaffected. The decision is part of the bank's focus on business improvement and restructuring.

site_title: Singtel, StarHub and M1 to retire 3G services, freeing spectrum for 5G
summary: Singapore's major mobile network operators, Singtel, StarHub, and M1, will retire 3G services by July 31, 2024, freeing spectrum for 5G investment. This move follows a 99% mobile subscriber base switching to 4G and 5G. The operators will offer individual users equivalent or better terms to convert to 4G plans, and retailers will no longer sell 3G mobile phones. A one-year transition period will ensure minimal disruption to existing services. The retirement aligns with international trends, with US and Malaysian operators already retired.

images.alt_text: Malaysia had in 2021 announced that state-owned DNB would own the full 5G spectrum.
Intel has lost its lead in manufacturing the smallest and most power-efficient semiconductors to rivals such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.
The Digital Connectivity Blueprint has plans to enable seamless 10 Gbps connectivity across different network types indoors and outdoors.

site_title: Tesla and GM sold more cars; only one made more money
summary: General Motors (GM) sold more cars than Tesla in the second quarter, despite Tesla's higher sales volume. GM's higher average selling price, driven by its focus on higher-margin trucks, contributed to its 32% increase in operating profit, while Tesla's operating profit fell due to lower prices. GM's flexibility in managing its legacy internal combustion engine business allows it to invest in electric vehicles without being overly reliant on EV sales. The company's surprise announcement of a revived Chevrolet Bolt EV production also suggests it can adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An automated guided vehicle carrying a battery pack moves under a partially assembled 2018 Chevrolet Bolt EV vehicle on the assembly line at General Motors Orion Assembly in Lake Orion, Michigan, U.S., March 19, 2018.  Photo taken March 19, 2018.   REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo
Within GM’s EV portfolio, the Bolt has represented more than 90 per cent of its EV sales so far this year.
FILE PHOTO: Tesla super chargers are shown in Mojave, California, U.S. July 10, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Why a crisis is looming in commercial real estate
summary: A crisis is looming in commercial real estate, driven by rapid interest rate hikes and increasing demand for yield in illiquid assets. The US, Europe, and Hong Kong are among the regions experiencing challenges, including sharp share price falls, declining asset values, and rising debt burdens. As central banks reduce lending, landlords may be forced to sell assets at discounted prices, leading to a vicious feedback loop of lower valuations and reduced borrowing capacity. Investors with access to new funds may benefit from the crisis by snapping up distressed properties, while developers with green credentials may also thrive.

images.alt_text: Retail properties including malls were the most troubled type of real estate, with nearly US$23 billion of distressed assets tied to the sector. About US$18 billion of office buildings were considered distressed at the end of March, according to the report.

site_title: A*Star starts R&D programme to develop Singapore EV suppliers
summary: A*Star has launched an R&D programme to develop Singaporean companies' capabilities in manufacturing high-performance electric drivetrains for electric vehicles. The programme, involving 10 industry partners, aims to improve energy efficiency and performance in drivetrains, enabling Singapore to become a "one-stop solution provider" for electric drivetrains in South-east Asia. The programme focuses on developing technology for road-going electric motorcycles, scooters, and tricycles, with initial phases including market analysis and partnerships with companies inside and outside the EV industry.

images.alt_text: Singapore electric scooter company Scorpio says it is in collaboration with Shenzhen BYD Electronics to produce pre-production prototypes of the X1.
GrabExpress partners with Hanoi-based EV maker Selex Motors
Singaporean electric motorcycle and mobility startup Charged has three models (left to right): the Anoa cargo bike, Rimau urban commuter, and Maleo ride-hailing model.
MAKA Motors co-founders Arief Fadillah (left) and Raditya Wibowo.

site_title: Thai exports fall less than forecast in June
summary: Thai exports declined 6.4% in June, beating analysts' average estimated decline of 7.3%, but remained a ninth consecutive month of contraction. Despite this, the Commerce Ministry still expects 1% annual export growth for 2023. Exports rose 2% from May, with some sectors performing well, such as cars and parts, which increased 7.2% year-on-year. The ministry aims to meet its export growth target, but faces challenges due to global demand and high inflation rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the port of Bangkok, Thailand May 26, 2016.  REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo                   GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD PACKAGE - SEARCH BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD SEPTEMBER 26 FOR ALL IMAGES/File Photo

An electric vehicle on display at the Fast Auto Show Thailand and EV Expo 2023 trade show in Bangkok on Jul 5;  the country is already a major regional car manufacturing hub, and is promoting EVs as it also aims to become a hub for EV manufacturing in South-east Asia.

site_title: Lynas Rare Earths asks Malaysia court to review licence
summary: Lynas Rare Earths has asked Malaysia's top court to review its licence due to conditions that limit operations at the facility, which bars the miner from importing and processing lanthanide concentrate from January. The Australian company claims the conditions vary from those under which it initially invested in Malaysia. If not removed by 2024, Lynas would have to shut down a processing plant, potentially disrupting the supply of neodymium and praseodymium, used in critical components such as magnets in iPhones and weapons systems.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A small toy figure and mineral imitation are seen in front of the Lynas Rare Earths logo in this illustration taken November 19, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Lynas produces Neodymium and Praseodymium (NdPr) used in magnets in high tech sectors from electric vehicles to military applications.

site_title: Cambodian PM Hun Sen to step down after four decades
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, one of the world's longest-serving leaders, announced his resignation after nearly four decades of rule, paving the way for his eldest son to take over. Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party won a landslide victory in the election, with 82% of the vote, despite Western powers condemning the poll as neither free nor fair. The government hailed the high turnout as evidence of "democratic maturity," but critics have long accused Hun Sen of suppressing opposition and human rights. Hun Sen's son, 45, is expected to become the new prime minister in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Hun Manet, eldest son of Prime Minister Hun Sen, hails his party’s victory in the elections.
Hun Sen's Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) is expected to retain all 125 seats in the Lower House, prolonging his grip on power.
Hun Manet, son of Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Sen, is a candidate for the election, making his debut.

site_title: Singapore’s shoemakers put their best foot forward
summary: Singapore's shoemakers struggled during the pandemic, with a shift to work-from-home lifestyle leading to a decline in sales. However, with more people returning to the office and retail sales improving, the industry is showing signs of recovery. Local shoe brands are adapting to the changing market, and entrepreneurs are finding new opportunities. Meanwhile, Asian talents in the movie industry are experiencing a surge in popularity, with Singapore and Malaysian actors gaining more opportunities in Hollywood.

site_title: iFast CEO urges investors to bear with global bank’s teething losses
summary: iFast Corporation CEO Lim Chung Chun expects the company's global banking business, iFast Global Bank, to break even in the second half of 2024, despite reporting losses of S$2.2 million in the second quarter and S$3.9 million for the first half of the year. Lim urged investors to look past the initial losses, citing the small scale of the losses and the significant improvement in overall cash flow. iFast is also expected to boost dividend payouts to shareholders in 2024 and drive growth through its e-pension services, particularly in Hong Kong, where its Orso e-pension services are expected to contribute significantly to its assets under administration from 2025.

images.alt_text: Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast, which posted a net profit of S$3.6 million in Q2 2023.

Lim Chung Chun, chief executive of iFast was named Outstanding CEO of the year, for his leadership in growing the company into a regional fintech network with over S$18 billion in assets under administration (AUA).
Lim Chung Chun, chief executive officer, iFast Corporation said that the launch has been able to add value to stakeholders by further innovating and digitalising pension services and processes.

site_title: Porsche’s profit climbs on robust 911, Macan combustion-car sales
summary: Porsche reported a 11% increase in operating profit to 3.85 billion euros in the first half, driven by strong demand for its combustion-engine models, including the Macan and 911. Unit sales rose 15% despite a 5% decline in Taycan deliveries due to parts shortages. The company plans to launch all-electric versions of its Macan and Cayenne SUVs, and has partnered with Mobileye Global on autonomous driving and Cellforce on high-performance battery cells. Porsche reaffirmed its full-year outlook, citing challenges including rising costs and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Venice Film Festival line-up largely unscathed by Hollywood strikes
summary: The Venice Film Festival's line-up remains largely unaffected by the Hollywood strikes, with artistic director Alberto Barbera describing the impact as "modest". The festival announced a star-studded line-up despite the loss of opener Luca Guadagnino's "Challengers", which was pushed back to next year due to the actors' strike.

images.alt_text: Disney has already shaken up its release schedule once this year, delaying some major films by as long as three years.
The two A-listers do tremendous justice to Gerwig’s sparkling dialogue, and take full advantage of the opportunity to flex their physical comedy muscles with hilarious results.

site_title: Glitzy Dubai hungry for culinary fame
summary: Dubai is rapidly emerging as a culinary capital in the world, with 13,000 restaurants and cafes, and 11 of its restaurants receiving Middle East's first Michelin stars last year. French chef Renaud Dutel and others, including Gordon Ramsay and Nobu Matsuhisa, have joined the city's roster of celebrity chefs, while local stars are also gaining recognition. The city's gastronomy scene is being driven by its cultural diversity, with a mix of Emirati, French, Japanese, and other influences. With a focus on local ingredients and sustainability, Dubai is poised to become a top destination for foodies, with many restaurants prioritizing sourcing from hydroponic farms and local suppliers.

images.alt_text: While some consumers think eating insects is just gross, Japan has a rich culinary history of insects as food.

site_title: ESG investing set to get boost in India as more funds permitted
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has authorized asset managers to launch multiple environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investment plans, potentially boosting the ESG investing theme in the country. Funds can now launch plans under six ESG strategies, with a minimum 80% investment in equities. This move is expected to increase ESG investing's foothold in emerging economies like India, where fossil fuels are dominant. The new rules will allow funds to invest in companies that perform better on ESG metrics and facilitate environmental transition.

site_title: SK Hynix says memory chip recovery has begun, flags robust AI demand
summary: SK Hynix, South Korea's second-largest memory chip maker, reported a second-quarter operating loss of 2.9 trillion won (S$3 billion), down from a profit a year earlier, due to weak memory chip pricing and demand. However, the company's shares rose 1.8% on the news that memory chip demand from corporate buyers and gaming PCs is expected to increase in the second half of the year, driven by robust artificial intelligence (AI) demand. SK Hynix's AI chip business saw a boost in sales, and the company expects its Dram business to swing to a profit in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Hynix’s losses show the slump that has gripped the US$160 billion global memory industry.

site_title: Rio Tinto cuts dividend as H1 profit falls to lowest in three years
summary: Rio Tinto reported its lowest first-half profit in three years, with underlying earnings of $5.7 billion, down from $8.63 billion last year. The miner attributed the decline to easing iron ore prices, despite a 7% increase in shipments from its Pilbara operations. Iron ore prices are expected to improve as Beijing announces policies to boost growth. Rio Tinto cut its interim dividend to $1.77 per share, below last year's $2.67. The company remains optimistic on China's economy, citing its ability to manage the economy during challenging times.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign adorns the building where mining company Rio Tinto has their office in Perth, Western Australia, November 19, 2015. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: Canadians swarm property market despite interest-rate hikes
summary: Canada's housing market continues to defy interest-rate hikes, with many consumers skeptical that rates can keep going up. Despite the Bank of Canada's pause on rate hikes earlier this year, home prices rebounded, and buyers swarmed back into the market. Many consumers believe rates will eventually drop, and they're taking out variable-rate mortgages to take advantage of potential future rate cuts. This mentality has led to a surge in housing activity, putting upward pressure on inflation. The Bank of Canada has resumed interest-rate hikes, citing housing market strength as a reason, but market expectations have shifted, and bond yields remain near their highest in over 15 years.

images.alt_text: Home prices have also been pushed up by a population boom and a materials shortage that caused a gauge of residential construction prices to rise 51 per cent since the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room revenue steady in June, overall room revenue slips
summary: Singapore hotels' average room revenue remained steady in June, increasing 0.3% to S$273.85, a 14.2% year-over-year jump. Revenue per available room and average occupancy rate also rose sequentially, but overall room revenue slipped 2.3% due to fewer available room nights. The luxury segment saw a 14.2% year-over-year increase, while tourist arrivals surpassed one million for the fourth straight month, driven by eased border restrictions and increased flights from China.

images.alt_text: Average room rates generally inch up across hotel categories in May, with the exception of the luxury segment.
Indonesia is the top source of visitors to Singapore in June, with India, China, Australia and Malaysia rounding out the top five.

site_title: Nissan to invest 600 million euros in Renault EV unit as alliance rejigged
summary: Nissan is investing 600 million euros in Renault's electric-vehicle unit Ampere, rebalancing the troubled automotive alliance. Renault will reduce its ownership of Nissan to 15% by placing the rest of its 43% shareholding in a French trust. The deal aims to generate hundreds of millions in value and provide strategic agility to both companies. The agreement marks a vote of confidence for Renault CEO Luca de Meo's strategy to revamp the manufacturer and tackle the shift to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Seven of the 10 manufacturers showed worse progress towards their goals than in the first half of last year.
Starting in 2025, Nissan will equip its EVs with the Tesla-developed North American Charging Standard (NACS) port, as it targets 40 per cent of US vehicle sales to be fully electric by 2030.

site_title: Hyundai Motor’s Q2 net profit jumps 15%, slightly misses expectations
summary: Hyundai Motor reported a 15% increase in second-quarter net profit to 3.2 trillion won, slightly missing expectations. The company's solid sales of high-margin sport utility vehicles and increased output after easing global semiconductor shortages contributed to the growth. Revenue rose 17% on-year to 42 trillion won. However, economic uncertainty and supply chain bottlenecks may put pressure on margin growth in coming quarters.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Hyundai booth displays the company logo at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Michigan, U.S. January 16, 2018.  REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo

site_title: GoTo launches financial services app GoPay in Indonesia
summary: GoTo Group, the parent company of Gojek and Tokopedia, has expanded its financial services app GoPay to all cities in Indonesia, allowing non-users to download the app. The app offers various financial services, including free money transfers, phone credit purchases, and expense report features. GoTo aims to remove barriers to accessing financial services through the app, making it simple and user-friendly for those with limited phone capacity. The expansion follows a pilot run in April and is part of the group's efforts to meet the financial needs of Indonesians from all walks of life.

images.alt_text: GoTo believes its profitability measures will pay off by the end of this year, but at the expense of GTV and transaction growth.
Maybank Securities initiated coverage on GoTo Group with a "buy" call and 153 rupiah target price.

site_title: US congressional committee set to weigh crypto bills
summary: A US congressional committee is set to vote on several bills regulating the cryptocurrency industry, marking a significant milestone in federal oversight. The bills aim to clarify the distinction between securities and commodities, and establish a framework for stablecoins. Industry advocates, including the Blockchain Association, have pushed for regulatory clarity, but the bills' fate in the Democratic-led Senate remains uncertain, with some lawmakers expressing skepticism about the need for additional legislation.

images.alt_text: A number of countries including the Bahamas and Nigeria have already launched CBDCs, and around 130 more representing 98 per cent of the global economy are exploring whether to do the same.

site_title: Nissan roughly doubles Q1 profit, lifts outlook
summary: Nissan Motor reported a Q1 profit nearly doubling to 128.6 billion yen, driven by higher production and sales in North America and Japan, as well as a weaker yen. The company raised its full-year forecast to 550 billion yen, up 6% from the previous estimate, citing cost discipline and a favorable foreign exchange rate. This is despite Nissan shares closing down 1.2% earlier in the day.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Logo of the Nissan Motor Co. is displayed at the 44th Tokyo Motor Show in Tokyo, Japan, November 2, 2015.   REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Premier League chief expects more foreign bids for English clubs
summary: Premier League CEO Richard Masters expects an increase in foreign bids for English clubs, citing their "investability" and global appeal. Sovereign wealth funds and American investors are leading the charge, with existing owners including Newcastle United and Manchester City. Manchester United is currently being bid on by Qatar's Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad JJ Al Thani. The Premier League's average revenue of £332 million makes it the largest of the big five European leagues, according to Deloitte's 2023 annual review. Masters sees no letup in investment trends, with the league promoting its US tournament.

images.alt_text: Financial experts estimate promotion to Premier League to be worth around £170 million for Luton that have been through turmoil since they last played in the top flight 31 years ago.

Manchester City's Ilkay Gundogan lifts the trophy as its players celebrate winning the title at the presentation ceremony following the English Premier League football match between Manchester City and Chelsea at the Etihad Stadium in Manchester, England, May 21, 2023.
Manchester United fans display banners in protest of the Glazer family’s ownership of the club.

site_title: BlackRock sees ‘huge opportunity’ in cast-off banking assets
summary: BlackRock sees a "huge opportunity" in buying assets from struggling banks as the industry faces years of upheaval due to high interest rates, regulations, and consolidation. The firm's vice chairman, Gary Shedlin, is leading efforts to position BlackRock funds as sources of capital for banks looking to sell asset-backed securities or large portfolios of loans. This comes as lenders offer assets daily, and private capital is expected to play a larger role in supporting lenders. BlackRock may start new investment vehicles targeting bank assets and could compete with other financial giants like Blackstone.

images.alt_text: Mandy Lui (left) and Dennis Quah.
CEO of Aramco Amin Nasser provides BlackRock with “a unique perspective” on key issues facing the company and its clients.

site_title: IMF urges BOJ to move away from yield control, prepare for future tightening
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to prepare for future monetary tightening by moving away from its yield control policy. IMF chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas stated that while inflation remains above the 2% target, the BOJ should remain accommodative but prepare to hike interest rates. The BOJ is expected to keep its yield curve control policy unchanged this week, but some officials are leaning towards tweaking the policy to mitigate potential side effects.

images.alt_text: Japan’s 2023 growth projection is roughly around the average 1.5 per cent expansion estimated by the IMF for advanced economies.
Economists largely agree that a change to the BOJ’s minus 0.1 per cent short-term interest rate is still a ways off.

site_title: Temasek, Morgan Stanley join A$435 million Australia-backed fund
summary: Main Sequence, a venture capital firm backed by Australia's national science agency, has raised A$435 million for its third fund to invest in deep technology deemed crucial to the country's national interests. The fund is supported by global investors including Morgan Stanley, Temasek Holdings, and existing backers. The firm aims to drive investment in areas such as decarbonisation, cybersecurity, and advanced semiconductor technology. Since its launch in 2017, Main Sequence has backed 53 companies with assets under management of over A$1 billion, and the Australian government has added A$75 million to the fund via the Economic Accelerator program.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley’s purchase of Eaton Vance – and thus, Parametric Portfolio Associates – closed in 2021.
Temasek has been ramping up investments in India in the last five or six years, buoyed by the performance of its own portfolio, attractive demographics and increasingly deeper capital markets.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as US Fed rate decision looms, China rally fades
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday as the previous day's China-induced rally gave way to cautious trading ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision, with fresh data reviving the possibility of more rate hikes. Regional equities surged on Tuesday in response to Beijing's pledges of stimulus for the property sector. The Fed is expected to deliver another increase in borrowing costs, with debate centered on whether it will announce another hike later in the year.

images.alt_text: Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta also rose, though Tokyo and Wellington dipped.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit posts 5.6% drop in H1 DPU to S$0.01378 on enlarged unit base
summary: ESR-Logos Reit reported a 5.6% drop in half-yearly distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01378 due to an enlarged unit base. However, the Reit's balance sheet has been strengthened by a S$300 million equity fundraising and divestments of non-core assets, reducing gearing to 33.6% from 39.4%. Despite higher borrowing costs, gross revenue and net property income grew 33.3% and 37% respectively. The Reit's manager, Adrian Chui, emphasized the need to pay bills and undertake asset enhancement initiatives, with plans to reduce leverage to 34-35% and pursue organic growth.

images.alt_text: DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.
Overall SGX-listed stocks have booked S$2.8 billion of net institutional fund outflow and S$1.4 billion of net retail inflow in the 2023 year to Jul 18.
Sembcorp Industries is no longer planning to sell its waste-management business and its energy-from-waste plant.

site_title: Gold trades narrow range as traders await US Fed decision
summary: Gold prices held steady at $1,964.14 per ounce as traders awaited the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, expected to keep rates in the 5.25-5.5% range until March 2024. The metal is sensitive to rising interest rates, which increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. US consumer confidence rose to a two-year high, but fears of a recession persisted. Net gold imports in China fell 29% in June, reflecting a sluggish economic recovery.

images.alt_text: The hallmark details on a one kilogram gold bar are seen at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: A safer way to save farmed fish
summary: Singapore-based biotech startup TeOra is developing a safer alternative to antibiotics for farmed fish, using "vaccine-like" biologics that can be applied as a coat on fish feed. The company's proprietary technology, Solaq, identifies virus fragments relevant to a particular disease, overcoming regulatory barriers. TeOra aims to improve fish health, reduce mortality rates, and increase farm profitability, with plans to expand its solutions to crops and livestock. The startup has secured S$1 million in grant funding and S$100,000 in investment, with a goal to achieve profitability within two years.

images.alt_text: Tan Chong Hui, CEO of JAH Tech

site_title: Former PM Thaksin to return from exile amid Thai post-election chaos
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, who has lived in self-imposed exile for 15 years, plans to return to Bangkok on August 10, amid post-election chaos in Thailand. Thaksin's return coincides with efforts by his party, Pheu Thai, to form a new government and end military-backed rule. His daughter Paetongtarn has expressed concerns about his plan, while Pheu Thai faces a hurdle in reaching a majority threshold in a joint assembly to take power. Thaksin faces corruption charges and denies reports of seeking an amnesty, but will enter the legal process upon his return.

images.alt_text: The vote was scheduled to be held on Jul 27 following two previous attempts by the leader of the election-winning Move Forward Party, Pita Limjaroenrat, that were blocked by conservative and nominated lawmakers.

Move Forward Party leader Pita Limjaroenrat says his party is committed to helping Pheu Thai form a “government of the people” to prevent parties that align with the establishment from returning to power.

epa10751685 Pheu Thai Party's Prime Ministerial candidate Srettha Thavisin leaves party’s headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 17 July 2023. The Pheu Thai Party, which came in second place in the 14 May Thai general elections, is in talks to coalition parties and the progressive Move Forward Party ahead of the second round of Parliament's voting to elect next prime minister on 19 July.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK
“I would like to say goodbye until we meet again,” Pita Limjaroenrat tells the chamber, raising his fist as he leaves the assembly floor to the cheers of fellow lawmakers.

site_title: Visa looks to soothe spending slowdown fears after tepid quarter
summary: Visa reported a 14% increase in international transaction revenue, lower than expected 18% growth, as consumer spending slowdown fears linger due to high inflation and rising borrowing costs. The company's quarterly profit was its smallest jump in over two years. Executives attributed the slowdown to moderating inflation, which typically hurts credit card companies. Despite this, Visa forecast annual results in line with Wall Street estimates, and CFO Vasant Prabhu expressed confidence in delivering low double-digit net revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Pismo will retain its current management team and the deal is expected to close by the end of 2023, Visa said.
Visa and Mastercard are each being sued by hundreds of claimants at London’s Competition Appeal Tribunal, which is currently managing the various cases together.

site_title: Silkworm sashimi, cricket curry on menu as bugs make a comeback in Japan
summary: In Japan, entomophagy, or eating insects, is gaining popularity as a sustainable source of protein, with many consumers trying bug-based dishes like cricket curry and silkworm sashimi. The trend is driven by concerns over climate change, food security, and the growing global population. Japan has a long history of insect consumption, and companies like Takeo are embracing entomophagy with products like cricket flour and bug-infused foods. As the world's population is expected to reach 9.7 billion by 2050, entomophagy is being seen as a viable solution to meet the world's protein needs.

images.alt_text: The Japanese government has confirmed that some shipments of Japanese seafood have been held up at China’s customs.

site_title: Slowing Australia Q2 inflation lessens rate hike pressure
summary: Australia's inflation rate slowed more than expected in Q2, rising 0.8% from the previous quarter, as domestic holidays and petrol costs decreased. This easing inflation suggests less pressure for another interest rate hike, sending the local dollar lower. Investors now see a 31% chance of a quarter-point rate hike in the next RBA meeting, down from 50% before the data release.

images.alt_text: Employment strength has been a key factor in the RBA’s confidence that Australia can avoid a recession

site_title: After the steep selling, what’s next for unitholders of Manulife US Reit?
summary: Manulife US Reit's market value has plummeted over 37% after the office trust announced it had breached loan covenants, potentially impacting distributions. The trust's real estate portfolio valuation declined by 14.6% to US$1.6 billion as of June 30, 2023, and aggregate leverage reached 57%, exceeding the regulatory limit. Analysts have slashed their target prices, and the manager is exploring alternative methods to address liquidity needs. Investors may consider cutting losses and moving on, or exploring asset sales or liquidation to recoup value.

images.alt_text: The Reit’s aggregate leverage rises to 57 per cent.
The manager expects the Reit to report a loss in the first half of 2023.

site_title: Elon Musk pursues banking in wake of rivals’ failed attempts
summary: Elon Musk is pursuing a plan to turn Twitter into a one-stop shop for financial services, building on his experience with PayPal. Despite failed attempts by other tech giants, such as Facebook and Google, Musk is moving forward with his vision, which includes payments, banking, and multimedia features. Twitter has already obtained licenses to operate as a money-transmitter in four US states. Musk's plan faces challenges, including regulatory scrutiny and competition in the US banking market, but he is confident in his ability to succeed, citing his experience in the financial technology space.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk wants to transform Twitter – now known as X – into a super app, similar to China's WeChat.
Elon Musk has talked about modelling X on WeChat, the Tencent Holdings super-app used by the majority of Chinese for everything from payments to messaging.

site_title: Limited support for central bank digital currencies in global investment industry survey
summary: A comprehensive survey by the CFA Institute found limited support for central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) among the global investment industry, with only 42% of respondents believing they should be launched. The survey also revealed a general feeling of scepticism about CBDCs' benefits, particularly in developed economies. Key countries like China and India showed higher support rates, while the US, EU, and UK had lower support rates. The main concerns were cyberhacking risks and data privacy, with younger respondents more receptive to CBDCs.

images.alt_text: Central banks around the globe have been studying and working on digital versions of their currencies for retail use to avoid leaving digital payments to the private sector amid an accelerating decline of cash.

The finance ministry and Bank of England have launched a public consultation on whether to issue a so-called central bank digital currency or CBDC, mirroring moves by many central banks across the world.

site_title: Singapore’s factory output contracts at slower pace in June, beating expectations
summary: Singapore's factory output contracted 4.9% year-on-year in June, slower than the previous month's decline, according to data from the Singapore Economic Development Board. The electronics segment showed a smaller decline, and sequential growth has moved "decidedly higher" year-to-date, with economists predicting a modest manufacturing recovery in the second half of the year. The sector has been impacted by China's reopening and global trade contraction, but some clusters, such as transport engineering, showed year-on-year growth.

images.alt_text: The production process at the ResMed Advanced Manufacturing Centre, 16 November 2022.

site_title: Japan’s population falls while foreign residents rise to record high
summary: Japan's population decreased by 800,000 to 122.42 million in 2022, marking a 14th consecutive year of decline, largely due to its low birth rate. The number of foreign residents reached a record high of nearly 3 million people, with Tokyo being the prefecture with the largest share. To address the issue, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's government plans to spend 3.5 trillion yen annually on childcare and other measures to support parents.

images.alt_text: New orders fell at the fastest pace since March while output and new export orders extended their falls, albeit at a slower pace.

site_title: Invest in AI? GIC CIO says it ‘pays not to put in too much, too broadly, too early’
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, is cautious about investing in generative artificial intelligence (AI) due to its early days and unclear dominance among companies. However, GIC sees great potential in AI's transformative power and is instead focusing on infrastructure investments, which have grown by five times since becoming a standalone strategy in 2016. GIC is analyzing AI's impact on its investment universe and is optimistic about the long-term growth of infrastructure, citing its stable cash flows and potential for strong returns despite high interest rates.

images.alt_text: AI startup SambaNova raises US$676m from investors including Temasek, GIC
The application of artificial intelligence and machine learning in the investment world has so far yielded poor results.
GIC will also invest 5.19 billion rupees via its Chiswick Investment in Genus Power through warrants, representing 15 per cent in the Indian company.
A “Too Little Too Late” climate scenario, with high transition and physical risks, has emerged as the most likely to become reality, based on GIC’s assessment.

site_title: South Korea to ease loan curbs for some homeowners paying ‘jeonse’ deposits
summary: South Korea will temporarily ease loan regulations for homeowners struggling to repay "jeonse" deposits, a unique house-renting scheme, starting July 27. The measures aim to minimize market shocks and reduce household debt. The eased regulations include a 60% debt-to-income ratio and a 100% rent-to-income ratio, replacing the current 40% and 125-150% limits. This comes as a sharp downturn in South Korean home prices has led to a rise in troubled homeowners failing to pay deposits, creating financial market concerns and social impact worries.

site_title: Snap shares fall on softer Q3 outlook as app tries to revamp ads
summary: Snap shares fell 17% after the company provided softer-than-expected third-quarter guidance, citing a weaker outlook for advertising revenue. The Santa Monica-based company estimated Q3 revenue between $1.07 billion and $1.13 billion, below analyst expectations. Snap is trying to revamp its ads strategy to compete with tech giants like Facebook-owner Meta Platforms. The company's AI-powered chatbot and photo filters have attracted hundreds of millions of users, but revenue growth has been inconsistent.

images.alt_text: Snap’s revenue for the first quarter ended March 31 was US$989 million, down from US$1.06 billion in the same period last year, and missing analyst expectations for US$1.04 billion.

site_title: San Francisco’s office demand surges, largely thanks to AI companies
summary: San Francisco's office demand surged 10% in Q2 from the previous quarter, according to VTS, driven largely by the growth of artificial intelligence companies. This marks a positive trend for the city, which has struggled with record vacancies and a pandemic-affected downtown core. Mayor London Breed notes that while progress is being made, the city still has a long way to go to recover, with average weekday office utilization rates still below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Office buildings are seen in downtown San Francisco as the city struggles to return to its pre-pandemic downtown occupancy rate, falling behind many other major cities around the country, according to local media, in California, U.S., June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Barria

site_title: Singapore biotech Mirxes files for Hong Kong IPO after raising US$50 million
summary: Singapore-based biotech company Mirxes has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) on Hong Kong's stock exchange, raising US$50 million ahead of its potential listing. The company, which values itself at around US$600 million post-money, aims to tap Hong Kong and China's healthcare and biotech investor base. Mirxes, which develops cancer diagnostics, has received funding from Chinese state-owned fund Beijing Fupu and Japanese conglomerate Mitsui, among others. The company plans to use the funds to scale its flagship stomach cancer blood test in South-east Asia, China, and Japan.

images.alt_text: Before he co-founded Mirxes, Zhou led a research team at A*Star. This, he said, is his first commercial role and it required him to “learn on the job”.
Mirxes would be one of the rare biotech startups to go public on the Singapore bourse, amid a broader push by the government to have tech startups listed locally.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Hong Kong SAR’s Chief Executive John Lee on 24 July 2023.

site_title: Deutsche Bank flags cost cuts as investment bank slump lowers profit
summary: Deutsche Bank posted a 27% fall in second-quarter profit due to a slump in investment banking revenue, despite higher interest rates boosting its retail division. The bank warned of the need for cost cuts and downgraded its investment bank revenue outlook. This follows broader trends in global banking, with investment banks struggling amid paused deals and higher interest rates. The bank's retail division is expected to become its main revenue driver, overtaking the investment bank.

images.alt_text: An ECB supervisory team has told Deutsche Bank that it needs to improve oversight and checks at its business that pitches FX derivatives such as swaps to European companies.

site_title: AI lesson for Microsoft and Google: Spend money to make money
summary: Microsoft and Alphabet are investing heavily in artificial intelligence, with costs expected to rise sharply as they build new data centers and power AI systems. Microsoft's costs are expected to continue to rise as it buys chips from Nvidia, while Alphabet is keeping costs down, but expects spending to impact profit and growth. Both companies expect AI to generate revenue in the second half of 2024, with Microsoft's service expected to start generating revenue sooner. Analysts say the investment is necessary to stay competitive in the market, but investors are looking for more immediate returns.

images.alt_text: GIC group chief investment officer Jeffrey Jaensubhakij said it’s still early days, with a new AI company being set up every week and dozens attacking the same problem.

site_title: Singapore shares open muted on Wednesday; STI up 0.02%
summary: Singapore shares remained little changed on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.02% to 3,286.97. Despite strong overnight gains in global markets, including the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq, local stocks were muted. Gainers outnumbered losers 58 to 51, with Mapletree Logistics Trust rising 0.6% after its manager reported a distribution per unit for the first quarter. Local banks DBS and OCBC were also mixed, while UOB dipped 0.8% following its insurance arm's higher net profit.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries is no longer planning to sell its waste-management business and its energy-from-waste plant.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher as markets await US Fed rate decision
summary: US stocks ended higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.1% to 35,437.93, extending its winning streak for 12 straight sessions. The S&P 500 Index gained 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6%. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, expected to lift rates for an 11th consecutive time, with some speculating the central bank may hint at the end of the tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 10.25 points, or 0.03 per cent, at the open to 35,421.49.

site_title: Alphabet profit beats expectations, CFO Porat to assume new role
summary: Alphabet's second-quarter profit exceeded Wall Street expectations, driven by steady demand for cloud services and a rebound in advertising. The company's shares jumped 8% in after-hours trading. CFO Ruth Porat will assume a new role as chief investment officer and president, while the company seeks a new finance chief. Alphabet's cloud revenue rose 28% to $8.1 billion, and ad sales for YouTube rose 4.4%. The company's generative AI technology is being tested in its search engine, with plans to integrate it into other products.

images.alt_text: Since Alphabet unveiled its latest AI tools at a developer’s conference last week, its stock has advanced 9 per cent, adding US$115 billion in market value and erasing its underperformance against peers like Apple and Microsoft.

site_title: GM does a U-turn to save the Chevy Bolt
summary: General Motors (GM) has reversed its decision to phase out the Chevrolet Bolt, citing its success as a best-seller and most affordable EV in North America. The company plans to launch a second-generation Bolt with a new, more efficient Ultium battery pack, expected to cost 40% less than the current model. The revamped Bolt should retain its current design and cost, with a starting price of $27,495, and will be produced at a Mexican assembly plant or possibly a Michigan-area plant.

images.alt_text: GM says net income for the second quarter rises by nearly 52 per cent to US$2.6 billion.
The Lyriq, a luxury crossover based on GM’s Ultium EV architecture, is now priced from 379,700 yuan.

site_title: 17 female business leaders honoured at Women Entrepreneur Awards 2023
summary: Seventeen female business leaders were honored at the Women Entrepreneur Awards 2023 in Singapore, recognizing their contributions to the country's business and social landscape. The awards, which marked their return after a three-year pandemic hiatus, acknowledged the resilience and transformation of women entrepreneurs during the pandemic. The winners included Althea Lim, co-founder and CEO of Gushcloud International, who took home the overall SME category award, and five women who received the Phoenix Award for emerging stronger from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: From left: Speedoc's Shravan Verma, Lumos Labs' Eu-wen Ding, and AP Technologies' Charles Tang, at the Emerging Enterprise Awards on Tuesday (Nov 22).

Speedoc, Lumos Labs and AP Technologies were the top three winners of the Emerging Enterprise Awards 2022. From left: Speedoc's Shravan Verma, Lumos Labs' Eu-wen Ding, and AP Technologies' Charles Tang at last year's event.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 3.3% rise in H1 DPU to S$0.0729
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 3.3% rise in its first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0729, driven by higher rents from Singapore properties and contributions from five Japanese nursing homes acquired in 2022. Gross revenue grew 23.6% to S$74.4 million, while net property income increased 25.1% to S$70.1 million. The Reit's aggregate leverage stood at 35.3% as of June 30, 2023, and the CEO expects the healthcare industry to benefit from Asia-Pacific's ageing population.

images.alt_text: The brokerage’s upgrade is based on Parkway Life Reit’s recent unit price decline of almost 10 per cent since March 2023.
As the healthcare Reit makes distributions on a semi-annual basis, the DPU will form part of the Reit’s distribution for the first half of this year, says its manager.

site_title: Counting Pikachus: Pokemon sleep app entices fans to go to bed
summary: A new sleep app, Pokémon Sleep, has been released by Pokémon and Niantic, rewarding users with Pokémon characters when they wake up and providing a deeper sleep experience. The app monitors sleep through a phone placed on the bed, with users earning more Pokémon for the deepest slumber. This is the latest addition to the Pokémon franchise, which originated in Japan in the 1990s and has since become a global media phenomenon. The app aims to encourage users to get a good night's sleep while interacting with the Pokémon universe.

site_title: Challenger privatisation offer closes with 97.8% valid acceptances
summary: Challenger Technologies' voluntary unconditional cash offer closed with 97.8% valid acceptances, receiving 394.3 million shares. The offeror, DigiTech Holding, is a consortium formed by Challenger's majority shareholders aiming to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to low trading volume. The offer price of S$0.60 per share represents a 10.5% premium over the volume-weighted average price, providing shareholders with a "clean cash exit opportunity". The delisting will give the company more flexibility in managing its business and optimise resource use.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Challenger Technologies requested for a half in trading effective immediately on Monday (May 29).

site_title: Top Global sells two ground-floor retail units in 15 Scotts for S$31.08 million
summary: Top Global sold two ground-floor retail units in 15 Scotts to House of Hung for S$31.08 million, or S$4,828 psf. The sale price is lower than the indicative price of S$38.8 million or S$6,027 psf. The units are part of 23 strata units acquired by Top Global in 2019, and most have been sold in the past two years. The sale comes as interest in prime strata office and retail properties in Singapore has been boosted by URA restrictions on strata subdivision of commercial property.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
15 Scotts Road is a District 9 freehold nine-storey commercial building located near the Tanglin Club and various hotels
Assuming the Thye Hua Kwan entities receive regulatory nods to purchase levels 10 and 14 at Solitaire on Cecil, eight of the freehold project's 15 office floors would be sold.

krpenang - VisionCrest Commercial along Penang Road


Source: CBRE

site_title: US consumer confidence rises to two-year high in July
summary: US consumer confidence reached a two-year high in July, rising to 117, the highest reading since July 2021, according to a survey by The Conference Board. Despite increased concerns about a recession, with 70.6% of consumers believing it is "somewhat" or "very likely" in the next 12 months, optimism about the labor market continued to drive the increase. Economists attribute the boost to confidence across all age groups and income levels, with no significant impact from recession concerns.

site_title: Microsoft beats quarterly estimates as AI boosts cloud business and spending
summary: Microsoft surpassed Wall Street estimates for fourth-quarter revenue and profit, driven by its cloud business benefiting from AI technology. The company integrated AI functionality across its products, including Azure, Microsoft 365, and GitHub. However, costs rose sharply due to increased capital expenditures to support AI, and shares fell 3% in after-hours trade. Microsoft's CFO expects capital expenditures to continue increasing throughout fiscal 2024.

images.alt_text: Microsoft says its decision was “in response to increasing frequency and evolution of nation-state cyberthreats.”

site_title: Europe: Miners boost shares on China stimulus talk
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% on Tuesday, marking their sixth consecutive gain, driven by miners' 4.24% surge as metal prices climbed on hopes of improving demand in China. China's pledge to step up policy support for its slowing economy boosted global growth expectations. However, a cautious mood prevails ahead of monetary policy decisions from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, which are expected to deliver 25 basis point rate hikes each.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 edged up 0.1 per cent, hovering near its five-week highs.

site_title: IMF lifts world GDP outlook on US stability, but risks linger
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its global GDP outlook for 2023 to 3% due to reduced US debt risks and a stabilizing banking sector. However, the fund warns that inflation remains a significant threat and that growth prospects look weak compared to pre-pandemic averages. The IMF expects the US to grow 1.8% this year and 1% in 2024, while China is forecast to expand 5.2% this year. Despite a slightly more optimistic view, the IMF cautions that risks to global growth remain tilted to the downside, with higher interest rates and potential shocks from the war in Ukraine and climate disasters.

images.alt_text: International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief economist, Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas  participates in a news conference on the IMF release of the World Economic Outlook Update, at IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, on July 25, 2023. (Photo by Brendan Smialowski / AFP)

site_title: Inflation weighs on Asian bond sentiment, despite expected pause in Fed rate hikes
summary: Asian bond sentiment remains cautious despite expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate hike pause, with inflation concerns keeping some analysts from calling a fresh bull cycle. Analysts favor high-yield bonds from companies in Macau's gaming industry and government policy-supported sectors in India, as well as investment-grade bonds from banks and high-quality corporates in emerging markets. However, some caution that it's too early to conclude a long-term bull market, citing the potential for persistently elevated inflation and central banks' possible rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The firm’s flagship private real estate investment fund for wealthy investors has limited withdrawals for eight straight months, though there are signs that a backlog of redemption requests is easing.
Issuance of sustainability-linked bonds have come off their peak in 2021, with zero new deals in South-east Asia in the first half of 2023.

site_title: Fed set to raise rates to 22-year high and decide if it’s done hiking
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates to a 22-year high, with a quarter-point increase to 5.25-5.5%, as policymakers aim to keep inflation under control. The decision, expected to be announced Wednesday, follows recent softer inflation data and a pause in June. Chair Jerome Powell is expected to hold a press conference, where he will address concerns about a potential recession and the possibility of additional rate hikes later in the year.

images.alt_text: IMF chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas says the biggest threat to the world economy remains inflation.
Consumers’ perceptions of the likelihood of a recession over the next 12 month tick up, but remain below the recent peak earlier in the year.

site_title: Intel, Ericsson to work together on custom 5G chip
summary: Intel and Ericsson announced a collaboration to develop a custom 5G chip for Ericsson's networking gear, utilizing Intel's 18A manufacturing technology. This marks the first time an external customer will use the technology. Intel aims to regain its lead in manufacturing the smallest and most power-efficient semiconductors, a key goal since 2021. The chip's release is expected, but no specific timeline was provided.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 27.7% drop in H1 DPU to S$0.03476
summary: Suntec Reit posted a 27.7% drop in its first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.03476, despite a 10.2% year-on-year increase in gross revenue to S$224.3 million. The decline was attributed to higher financing costs and a weaker Australian dollar, offsetting revenue growth from Suntec City and other properties. The Reit's manager expects interest rates and energy costs to remain high, impacting distributable income for the rest of the year, but plans to explore divestment of mature assets to strengthen its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.
Suntec Reit has its target price slashed to S$1.13 in anticipation of a potential downcycle in the office property market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, SIA Engineering, MLT, Keppel Reit, Suntec Reit, ESR-Logos Reit
summary: Sembcorp Industries scrapped plans to sell its waste-management business, while SIA Engineering's net profit for the first quarter more than doubled to S$27 million. Mapletree Logistics Trust's DPU fell 0.1%, and Keppel Reit's DPU dropped 2.4%. Suntec Reit's DPU plummeted 27.7%, while ESR-Logos Reit's DPU fell 5.6%. In contrast, Parkway Life Reit's DPU rose 3.3%, and iFast reversed into the black with a net profit of S$3.6 million.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares close a whisker shy of its 52-week high at S$1.52, up 1.3 per cent.

site_title: TikTok to launch e-commerce platform in US to sell China-made goods
summary: TikTok plans to launch an e-commerce platform in the US in early August, allowing users to buy China-made goods. The platform will be responsible for storage and shipping on behalf of Chinese manufacturers and merchants. This move comes amid heightened scrutiny over data security concerns, with US officials considering a ban. TikTok faces a bill that would grant the Biden administration authority to ban apps posing security risks. The platform aims to replicate the success of Chinese shopping platforms Shein and Temu in the US market.

site_title: Oil prices hit three-month highs on tightening supplies
summary: Oil prices rose to three-month highs on July 25, with Brent futures settling up 90 US cents at $83.64 a barrel. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 89 US cents to $79.63. Tightening supplies, driven by OPEC output cuts, and Chinese authorities' pledge to support the economy contributed to the price increase. Despite some economic data limiting gains, analysts say the market is becoming increasingly concerned about tightening oil supplies.

images.alt_text: Strong demand boosted US petrol futures to their highest since October 2022, which caused the petrol crack spread, a measure of refining profit margins, to rise to its highest since July 2022.

site_title: India’s Tata Motors profit races past estimates on strong JLR sales
summary: Tata Motors, India's largest automaker, exceeded quarterly profit expectations with a 32.03 billion rupees profit, driven by strong demand for its luxury Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) cars. Revenue rose 42% to 1.02 trillion rupees, mostly due to JLR's 70% contribution. JLR logged its highest production levels in nine quarters and saw a 66% surge in revenue, while passenger vehicle sales in India rose 11%. The company expects robust demand for passenger vehicles in the coming quarters, despite a planned price hike.

images.alt_text: Tata had been choosing between a site in Somerset, southwest England, and one in Spain to supply a new range of electric Jaguar and Land Rover vehicles.
The price hike is meant to offset the residual impact of past input costs, the company said.

The decision by the Indian blue-chip company would give a boost to the British car industry, coming days after major automakers including Vauxhall owner Stellantis and Ford warned that looming post-Brexit trade rules risked making it unviable.
FILE PHOTO: Tata Motors logos are pictured outside their flagship showroom in Mumbai May 28, 2013. Picture taken May 28, 2013. REUTERS/Vivek Prakash/File Photo
Vehicles across segments in India have gotten costlier with the government mandating automakers to fit their vehicles with a special device to monitor emissions, leading to extra costs.

site_title: Greyhound owner Flix picks JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, BNP Paribas for 4 billion euros IPO
summary: Flix, a German bus services firm, has selected JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, and BNP Paribas as advisers for a planned 4 billion euros initial public offering (IPO) in the first half of 2024. The company, which operates bus and train services across 40 countries, could reach a valuation of 4 billion euros. Flix, founded in 2011, saw its revenue jump 185% last year to over 1.5 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Fondul Proprietatea, an investment vehicle managed by Franklin Templeton, sells a 17.3 per cent stake in the utility during the IPO, reducing its holdings from nearly 20 per cent.
Nvidia is a long-time partner and client of Arm.

site_title: Will Biden ever get credit for his policies?
summary: Despite the US economy's recovery from the pandemic, President Joe Biden's approval ratings remain low due to polarized American politics and public life. The economy has added 13 million jobs since his presidency, but consumer sentiment remains low, and public confidence in the economy is in negative territory. Biden's foreign policy successes, including leading the Western alliance's response to Russia's aggression in Ukraine, have not translated into higher approval ratings. His handling of the economy, environment, energy policy, and foreign affairs also receives low ratings, with only 40% of Americans approving of his handling of China.

images.alt_text: Initial claims for state unemployment benefits drop 9,000 to a seasonally adjusted 228,000 for the week ended Jul 15, US Labor Department says.

In America, money makes the campaigns go around, and a candidate can even be measured by his or her ability to attract political donations – the theory being that if enough influential people are willing to donate, that person is a winner.

site_title: GIC 20-year annualised return at 4.6%, highest in eight years
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) reported a 20-year annualized return of 4.6%, the highest in eight years, as of March 2023. The fund attributes its success to investments in real estate, infrastructure, and inflation-linked bonds, aiming to protect against sticky inflation and geopolitical risks. GIC's portfolio allocation remains focused on stable long-term returns, with a share of real estate investments increasing to 13%. Despite uncertain market conditions, GIC is optimistic about its investment opportunities, particularly in dynamic investments with higher expected returns.

images.alt_text: GIC group chief investment officer Jeffrey Jaensubhakij said it’s still early days, with a new AI company being set up every week and dozens attacking the same problem.
MAS believes the prevailing monetary policy stance was sufficiently tight and appropriate for securing medium-term price stability.
Temasek Holdings said that persistent inflatoin, geopolitical tensions and rising nationalism and protectionism led to an increase in the firm's cost of capital.
Temasek developed its T2030 strategy in 2019 as its 10-year roadmap to guide strategic planning and capability building for the organisation.

site_title: Bullion’s golden moment may happen sooner than later
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, potentially signaling the end of the current rate-hiking cycle. This could benefit gold prices, which have been rising due to factors such as geopolitical tensions, inflation, and recession fears. The global macroeconomic backdrop remains uncertain, with the post-pandemic growth recovery in China and the eurozone region facing challenges. A break above the $2,000 per-ounce level could mark a "golden moment" for gold, but it remains to be seen whether the rally will fizzle out or continue.

images.alt_text: The dollar index wobbled near a more than one-year low, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies.
Physical gold demand stalled in India in the week ending Jul 21, while bullion was sold at high premiums in top consumer China.

site_title: IMF sees Japan's economy growing 1.4% in 2023, warns of inflationary pressures
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has projected Japan's economy to grow 1.4% in 2023, slightly above the 1.0% growth in 2022, due to the removal of pandemic curbs boosting consumption. However, the IMF warns of mounting inflationary pressures, which may prompt the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates. The IMF advises Japan to be flexible with its monetary policy, potentially moving away from yield-curve control, and to prepare for potential interest rate hikes. Growth is expected to slow to 1.0% in 2024 as stimulus measures dissipate.

images.alt_text: Economists largely agree that a change to the BOJ’s minus 0.1 per cent short-term interest rate is still a ways off.
New orders fell at the fastest pace since March while output and new export orders extended their falls, albeit at a slower pace.
As inflation perks up, markets are simmering with speculation the BOJ could soon phase out its controversial yield curve control policy.
Imports fell 12.9 per cent year-on-year in June, versus the median estimate for a 11.2 per cent decrease.
Japan's inbound visitors rise to 2.07 million in June, clearing the 2 million mark for the first time since February 2020.

site_title: South Korea consumer sentiment climbs for fifth month
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment index rose to 103.2 in July, marking a fifth consecutive month of improvement and the highest reading since April 2022. The index was driven by an improvement in consumers' outlook for the economy, current economic conditions, and living conditions. Inflation expectations also resumed a decline, according to the Bank of Korea's survey. This uptick in consumer sentiment suggests a boost to the country's economy.

site_title: Apple supplier Corning Q3 revenue forecast hit by consumer electronics slump
summary: Corning, a specialty glass maker, forecast Q3 core sales below Wall Street estimates due to a slump in the consumer electronics market. The company expects $3.5 billion in core sales, down from analysts' estimates of $3.70 billion. Corning's shares dropped 1.5% before the bell. The company has seen a drop in demand from its consumer electronics clients, but has managed to expand its core gross margin by 100 basis points to 36.2%. CEO Wendell Weeks expects to continue improving profitability and cash flow despite the muted sales environment.

images.alt_text: China’s Xiaomi holds the smartphone lead in India for years before regulatory headaches and a too vast product portfolio – which by its own admission confuses customers – lead to its decline.

site_title: Spotify’s user growth beats expectations, revenue misses
summary: Spotify reported a 25 million increase in monthly active users to 551 million, beating expectations, and 17% growth in premium subscribers to 220 million. However, the company's quarterly revenue fell short of estimates at 3.18 billion euros, and it posted a bigger-than-expected loss. Despite this, CEO Daniel Ek expressed optimism, citing the growth's "gift that keeps giving." Shares initially rose but later declined 10% due to the revenue miss.

images.alt_text: Spotify's price increases come at a time when streaming services, both audio and video, are under rising investor pressure to boost profitability after years of prioritising user growth.

Dubbed “Supremium” internally, according to people familiar with the strategy, the new tier will be Spotify’s most expensive plan and likely offer a HiFi feature the company first announced it was working on in 2021.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at open ahead of Big Tech results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by upbeat annual profit forecasts from companies and anticipation of quarterly earnings reports from major tech firms. The Dow Jones rose 10.25 points, or 0.03%, to 35,421.49, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. Investors await earnings reports from tech companies, including Big Tech firms.

site_title: ChatGPT now on Android in some countries including US
summary: OpenAI has expanded the rollout of its chatbot ChatGPT to Android users in the US, India, Bangladesh, and Brazil, following its initial release on iOS in May. The move aims to capitalize on the growing popularity of the AI tool, which has been used for various tasks such as content writing and coding. OpenAI plans to further expand the rollout to additional countries over the next week. This expansion marks the latest development in the company's efforts to establish itself as a leader in the AI market.

site_title: Quarz’s push to internalise Sabana Reit’s manager ‘wilfully ignores’ hurdles: ESR Group
summary: Quarz Capital is pushing for Sabana Industrial Reit to internalize its management through a vote at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting (EGM). However, ESR Group, the Reit's manager and a 20.6% shareholder, warns that this would be "wilfully ignoring" hurdles, including the lack of an existing blueprint for internalization. ESR Group urges unitholders to vote against the resolutions, citing the potential for a prolonged period of uncertainty and the significant time and costs required to establish a new internalized management structure.

images.alt_text: Sabana Reit's manager has said Quarz's internalisation proposal may destroy value for unitholders
Unitholders are set to vote on the two resolutions at an extraordinary general meeting to be held on Aug 7.
The trustee of Sabana Reit, HSBC Trustee, is urging unitholders to carefully consider the resolutions and note the uncertainty and risks associated before voting at an upcoming EGM.
Sabana Reit's manager ought to obtain clarity from UOB and other lenders on whether they plan to pull back their credit facilities in the event unitholders vote for internalisation.
A six-storey industrial building with a ground level carpark. 151 Lorong Chuan, New Tech Park, Singapore 556741.
The EGM requisitioned by activist investor Quarz Capital is set to take place on Aug 4.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. Quarz Capital had requisitioned the EGM, which was slated to take place on Aug 4, to vote on two resolutions.
Sabana' Reit's upcoming extraordinary general meeting involves two resolutions - one for the removal of its Reit manager and second on the internalisation of the Reit management function.
At an upcoming extraordinary general meeting, unitholders will vote on whether to remove Sabana Reit’s current manager and replace it with an internal one.

site_title: Sharp Chinese rebound pushes LVMH sales up 17% in second quarter
summary: LVMH, the world's top luxury group, reported a 17% sales increase in the second quarter to 21.2 billion euros, driven by a sharp rebound in China, which saw 34% growth. This offset a decline in US sales, where inflation and economic turbulence affected demand. Finance chief Jean-Jacques Guiony attributed the Chinese rebound to "normalisation" rather than revenge buying, and refrained from giving an outlook for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Some LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton brands have been official partners of global competitions.
Chanel's regal Tweed Royal necklace.

The funds, which claim either to “promote” environmental, social and good governance principles, make ESG an outright “objective” or simply put ESG in their names, have amassed a combined LVMH stake worth more than US$17 billion.
LVMH will use Epic’s 3D creation tools to create immersive products and experiences.
Bad weather was likely not top of mind when the storied luxury label chose Isola Bella as the venue for its Cruise 2024 collection.

site_title: Homelessness rates in England hit five-year high
summary: Homelessness rates in England have reached a five-year high, with 79,840 households in need of help from local authorities due to homelessness or the risk of homelessness.
