This includes 18% from London, and 104,510 households in temporary accommodation, a 10% increase from the previous year. The increase is driven by the termination of assured shorthold tenancies, allowing landlords to evict tenants without a reason, and soaring rental prices, which have risen 123% compared to the previous year. The government is urged to reform renting laws and build more affordable housing to address the crisis.

images.alt_text: The rental figures emphasise the headwinds facing the UK housing market, as interest rates keep rising and add to mortgage costs.
The Bank of England has found that it takes those without support 10 years longer to buy a property for the same sum snapped up by a 26-year-old with parental help.
Top UK residential builder Barratt said this month it would build around 20 per cent fewer homes in its fiscal year 2024, while high-end builder Berkeley expects annual sales to fall by a fifth.
Rising mortgage costs and a shortage of stock are pushing up rents to record levels and suppressing an expected dip in house prices, adding to the UK’s cost-of-living crisis.
Britain’s housing market has been hit by rapid increases in interest rates.

site_title: India’s largest engineering firm plans 100 billion rupees buyback
summary: India's largest engineering firm, Larsen & Toubro (L&T), plans to buy back up to 100 billion rupees (S$1.6 billion) of its stock through a tender offer, with shares to be purchased at a maximum price of 3,000 rupees each, a 17% premium. The move aims to improve return on equity for shareholders and reflects the company's confidence in achieving its growth plans. This is L&T's first buyback since 2019, when a previous attempt was halted due to regulatory issues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the Larsen and Toubro (L&T) head office in Mumbai, India, September 2, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas//File Photo

site_title: India pharma exports surging despite cough syrup deaths
summary: India's pharmaceutical exports are expected to grow nearly twice as fast as last year, reaching $27 billion, driven by strong US buying despite concerns over Indian-made cough syrups linked to deaths in Gambia and Uzbekistan. The country's overall pharma exports in the April-June quarter rose 5% to $6.58 billion, with sales to the US increasing 6.2% to $7.5 billion. India has taken steps to improve the quality of its pharmaceuticals, including mandatory testing of cough syrups before export, and is seen as a major advantage due to its lower manufacturing costs.

site_title: High Court rules crypto asset holder has legally enforceable property right in landmark decision
summary: The Singapore High Court has ruled in a landmark decision that a crypto asset holder has a legally enforceable property right. ByBit Fintech successfully recovered quantities of the US dollar-pegged stablecoin Tether from an employee, Ho Kai Xin, who had held the assets on trust. The court found that Ho had fraudulently transferred the crypto assets to herself, and ordered her to pay with interest nearly S$120,000 and US$647,880. Ho is also liable for any shortfall and profits made from the transferred funds. This is the first time a common law court has recognized a crypto asset holder's property right.

images.alt_text: The FSB publishes final recommendations requested by the G20 on supervising firms that trade cryptoassets such as bitcoin.
Crypto-lending and stablecoins are struggling to overcome a series of scandals, most notably the collapse of TerraUSD, an algorithmic stablecoin.

site_title: EU ready to move almost all of Ukraine's grain exports via solidarity lanes
summary: The EU is ready to export almost all of Ukraine's grain exports via "solidarity lanes" after Russia pulled out of a UN-backed Black Sea grain deal. EU Agriculture Commissioner Janusz Wojciechowski said it's not the first time Russia uses food as a weapon, comparing the situation to the beginning of the war. The solidarity lanes, which include rail and road transport connections through EU member states bordering Ukraine, aim to cover the additional transport costs.

images.alt_text: A farm worker checks grain moisture content during the summer wheat harvest by the Ukrainian seed agricultural company Peremoga, meaning 'Victory', in the Fastiv district of Kyiv region, Ukraine, on Monday, July 24, 2023. Wheat fell more than 4% as traders shrugged off concerns about Ukraine’s exports and escalating tensions in the Black Sea amid ample global supplies. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

site_title: Fidelity fund sees rebound for Korea chip stocks
summary: Fidelity International's Global Technology Fund manager Hyun Ho Sohn expects a rebound in Korea's chip stocks due to a "trough" in the memory cycle and strong demand recovery driven by AI applications. The fund, which has returned 24% this year, is increasing holdings in Samsung and SK Hynix, and betting on "underappreciated" beneficiaries of AI, including data infrastructure companies. Sohn is also turning "more positive" on Chinese tech stocks and "underweight" on the US due to less attractive valuations.

images.alt_text: The chip industry’s workforce is projected to grow to 460,000 by the end of the decade, up from roughly 345,000 this year.
TSMC’s position as the leading manufacturer of AI chips  has not offset broader end market weakness as the global economy recovers more slowly than it had expected.

A man watches a 300mm Wafer manufactured by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) during the World Semiconductor Congress in Nanjing in China's eastern Jiangsu province on July 19, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: UOI’s H1 net profit jumps 70% to S$12.2 million
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI), the general insurance arm of UOB, reported a 70.2% increase in net profit after tax to S$12.2 million for the first half of 2023, driven by a 17.5% rise in insurance revenue. However, overall income from insurance services declined 27.8% due to higher expenses. Non-underwriting income and other comprehensive income also showed improvements. Despite stiff competition in the insurance market, UOI plans to maintain its prudent stance and focus on cross-selling and digital capabilities to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Although net underwriting profit fell 38 per cent to S$3.5 million, this was more than offset by a rise in non-underwriting income to S$2.2 million, which turned profitable after the group recorded a loss of S$0.12 million in the corresponding period last year.
Wee Ee Cheong will take over his father as chairman of UOI on 14 April 2023.
Singapore Budget 2021 generic pictures

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust’s committed retail portfolio occupancy at 98.7% in Q3
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's committed retail portfolio occupancy rose 1.6 percentage points to 98.7% in Q3, driven by firm leasing demand and increased shopper traffic. Prime retail rents rose 3.1% and Orchard Road prime rents 2.9% year on year. The trust will continue to curate and refresh retail offerings, bringing in new tenants. As of June 30, the trust's gearing levels stood at 40.2% and average debt maturity extended to 2.53 years.

images.alt_text: Proceeds from the green loan will go into procuring energy-efficient technology for Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Tampines 1 retail mall, among other general corporate purposes.

site_title: Biogen announces job cuts, turns focus to Alzheimer’s drug launch
summary: Biogen is slashing 1,000 jobs, or 11% of its workforce, as it prepares to launch its new Alzheimer's drug, Leqembi. The company aims to reduce costs, with a focus on higher-growth products like Leqembi, which was recently approved and will be sold with partner Eisai. CEO Christopher Viehbacher said the company needs to "critically look at all current operations" to return to growth. The cost-cutting program will reduce net operating expenses by $700 million by 2025, with $300 million reinvested in launches and research.

site_title: Chinese battery giant CATL posts 63% growth in Q2 profit
summary: Chinese battery giant CATL reported a 63.22% increase in net profit for the second quarter, reaching 10.895 billion yuan (S$2 billion). This growth comes as the company faces competition in the electric vehicle (EV) battery market. Despite a slowdown in auto sales, CATL's net profit surged, contrasting with a 558% increase in the first quarter. The company is struggling to maintain its industry leadership amid weakening demand and cost reduction pressure from EV makers.

images.alt_text: Ford announced in February it is spending US$3.5 billion to build a battery plant in Michigan using technology from CATL, the world’s largest battery maker.
CATL, the world’s largest battery maker, currently holds a 20 per cent stake in CNTE.
The planned expansion of the service in Europe and North America is a sign that CATL is looking to exert greater dominance throughout the EV battery supply chain.
The agreement connects CATL, the world’s largest manufacturer of electric vehicle batteries, with Bolivia’s salt flats that are home to the world’s largest lithium resources.
Narit Therdsteerasukdi, Secretary General of Thailand Board of Investment (BOI), says: "We are talking to many companies, not only CATL but many companies in the battery industry.”

site_title: iFast swings into the black with S$3.6 million net profit in Q2
summary: iFast, a fintech platform, has reversed into the black with a net profit of S$3.6 million for its second quarter, driven by stabilizing financial market conditions and positive net inflows. The company's core wealth management platform business benefited, while its banking business reported a loss. Assets under administration grew 8% year-on-year to S$18.8 billion, and iFast expects improved revenue and profitability in the future. An interim dividend of 1.10 Singapore cents per share was proposed.

images.alt_text: Lim Chung Chun, chief executive of iFast was named Outstanding CEO of the year, for his leadership in growing the company into a regional fintech network with over S$18 billion in assets under administration (AUA).

site_title: China replaces foreign minister Qin Gang after mysterious absence
summary: China has named Wang Yi, 69, as its new foreign minister, replacing Qin Gang after a mysterious one-month absence from duties. Qin, 57, who took over the ministry in December, was not seen in public since June 25, sparking speculation over his health and the secrecy surrounding China's leadership. Wang, who previously held the post from 2013-2022, has filled in for Qin and represents China at international meetings. The decision was made by President Xi Jinping via a presidential order, but no explanation has been given for Qin's removal.

site_title: ‘Barbie’ storms the box office but won’t boost Mattel just yet
summary: The film "Barbie" directed by Greta Gerwig and starring Margot Robbie has sold US$356.3 million in theater tickets globally, making it the biggest opening of the year. Despite this, analysts expect Mattel's sales to tumble 19% to US$1 billion in the second quarter, and the company is expected to post a loss. The film is expected to generate about US$100 million in revenue for Mattel, including US$75 million in toy sales. The movie's success may have a "halo effect" on the Barbie brand, with sales predicted to rise 1.7% to US$1.52 billion this year.

images.alt_text: Enter Barbie and Oppenheimer, two polar opposite movies that debuted simultaneously in a matchup dubbed “Barbenheimer”.

site_title: Global securities watchdog backs new company climate disclosures
summary: The International Securities and Commissions Organization (IOSCO) has endorsed new international company climate disclosures, backed by the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB). The standards, approved last month, require companies to disclose climate-related financial information starting in 2024. Regulators aim to replace voluntary norms with more rigorous rules to prevent greenwashing and provide investors with better information on sustainability risks and opportunities. IOSCO has called on its member jurisdictions to adopt the ISSB standards, with Britain indicating it will make them mandatory for listed companies, and other countries considering similar actions.

images.alt_text: The mercury soared last weekend in the centre of Messina, on the Italian island of Sicily (above). Record temperature forecasts over parts of the US, Europe and Asia are just the latest example of the threat from global warming.

The new sustainability standards provide a structured framework for companies to assess and disclose their resilience to sustainability-related risks, allowing investors to understand the company’s long-term prospects better.
Singapore-mandated issuers demonstrate strong disclosure practices under the governance pillar but lag the global average for disclosures across other pillars of the TCFD's recommendations.
The Sustainability Reporting Advisory Committee has recommended that non-listed companies with an annual revenue of at least S$1 billion make mandatory climate-related disclosures from FY2027.

site_title: China city party chief gets life in jail for taking bribes
summary: A Chinese court has sentenced former Communist Party secretary Zhou Jiangyong to life in prison for taking over 182 million yuan (S$33.8 million) in bribes. Zhou, who was party chief of Hangzhou, was found guilty of aiding deals such as construction and land acquisition in exchange for bribes. He was initially placed under investigation in 2021 and later expelled from the party. The sentence will be commuted to life imprisonment after two years.

images.alt_text: nil

site_title: Unilever sees Chinese consumer confidence at ‘historical low point’
summary: Unilever reports that China's consumer confidence has reached a historic low due to the country's declining property market and exports. Despite this, the company notes that underlying sales growth in China recovered in the second quarter. This contradicts Unilever's earlier forecast of a "consumption boom" in China, which was based on excess household savings estimated at $1.5 trillion to $2 trillion. The company's prediction of a consumption boom was made in February, highlighting the shift in China's economic landscape.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company logo for Unilever is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., February 17, 2017. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Key Chinese indexes are down for the year, losing out on a rally seen across Japan, India and the US.
The blue-chip CSI 300 Index snaps a six-day losing streak by closing up nearly 3 per cent to record the best day since last November, while the Hang Seng Index jumps 4.1 per cent.
The British company has reported a 7.9 per cent rise in underlying second-quarter sales, beating analysts’ average forecast of 6.4 per cent.

site_title: How to get the most out of annual general meetings
summary: Singapore companies' annual general meetings (AGMs) are back, offering investors a chance to meet company leaders, ask questions, and clarify doubts. To maximize time at AGMs, investors should come prepared with questions, review company reports, and assess management's plans for growth. This includes evaluating their responses to challenges, understanding strategic plans, and assessing their track record of delivering promised initiatives. By attending AGMs, investors can refine their investment process, gain insight into companies' operations, and make informed decisions about their shares.

images.alt_text: A growing cohort of investors today are looking for convenience, and appear to take a light-touch approach to portfolio management.

site_title: Indonesia's big gas projects to proceed after global majors sell stakes
summary: Indonesia's major gas projects, including the Masela and IDD gas blocks, will proceed after global majors Shell and Chevron sell their stakes to local companies Pertamina, Petronas, and Eni. The deals aim to boost Indonesia's flagging oil and gas production, with the Masela project expected to produce 9.5 million metric tonnes of LNG per year. Eni and Petronas have agreed to fast-track the development of the IDD project, which will integrate nearby blocks and leverage existing infrastructure. The deals are seen as a significant step towards Indonesia's goal of achieving 12 billion standard cubic feet of gas per day by 2030.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s energy minister told Reuters last month that Petronas and Pertamina had planned to take over Shell’s stake in Masela.

site_title: UK’s wealthy parents give their kids a 10-year head start in housing
summary: The Bank of England found that individuals without parental support take 10 years longer to buy a property for the same price as a 26-year-old with parental help. Deposits are 2.5 times bigger, loans are 30% smaller, and properties cost £15,000 more when younger buyers receive assistance. This advantage, known as "inheritocracy," raises concerns about unequal access to homeownership.

images.alt_text: Rising mortgage costs and a shortage of stock are pushing up rents to record levels and suppressing an expected dip in house prices, adding to the UK’s cost-of-living crisis.
Top UK residential builder Barratt said this month it would build around 20 per cent fewer homes in its fiscal year 2024, while high-end builder Berkeley expects annual sales to fall by a fifth.
Construction starts and completions were both just over 4,000 between April and June, compared with about 3,550 and 3,090, respectively, in the previous quarter but below the three-year average.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The overall incidence of employment claims and appeals in Singapore rose to 1.97 per 1,000 employees in 2022, driven by a higher proportion of group claims from companies in financial difficulty. Singapore and Japan agreed to jointly implement green aviation initiatives. Local medtech companies gained access to business and research opportunities with the UK's NHS, while Sembcorp Industries decided not to sell its waste-management business. Singapore shares rose 0.6% amid Wall Street gains and Asian markets' support for China's economy.

site_title: De Beers' new South Africa mine delivers first diamonds
summary: De Beers' new South Africa mine, a $2.3-billion underground operation, has begun producing its first diamonds, marking a key milestone for the mining giant. The mine, located beneath the Venetia diamond mine, is expected to produce 4 million carats of diamonds annually. The facility, employing 4,300 people, is 70% complete and is expected to enhance De Beers' production for the long term.

images.alt_text: The 10.57 carat rock will go on show in Hong Kong next week and later will be exhibited in Dubai, Singapore, Shanghai, Taiwan and Geneva. It will be up for sale on June 8 in New York as the showpiece lot in a Sotheby’s jewels auction.

site_title: US SEC readies penalty for DWS in greenwashing probe by end September
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is preparing to resolve a two-year probe into DWS' alleged greenwashing by the end of September, with a potential fine. The probe, sparked by a whistleblower, alleges DWS misled investors by marketing its funds as greener than they actually were. DWS has denied the allegations and cooperated with investigators. The SEC's crackdown on greenwashing comes under Democratic leadership, following a $4 million fine on Goldman Sachs last year. German authorities are still investigating and DWS has earmarked 8 million euros for civil litigation.

images.alt_text: Activists stack washing machines in front of the Deutsche Bank headquarters to protest against greenwashing during the bank's annual shareholders meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, May 19, 2022.
Currently, most large companies report how many tonnes of carbon they emit into the atmosphere each year, but the data is often not reliable.
Germany’s Lufthansa says it plans to slash its net emissions by half by 2030 compared to 2019 levels and has a “constant dialogue” with customers.
Generic photo of greenery in city state Singapore. For stories regarding ESG, sustainability, sustainability investing, and business environmental governance

site_title: Finding value in Asia-Pacific real estate after the great reset
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate values are expected to fall by less than 10% on average, peak to trough, due to a global pricing reset. Despite market fluctuations, demand for data centers, affordable housing, and logistics remains robust, with opportunities for investors willing to take on greater risk. Key sectors and markets to watch include Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, and Hong Kong, which are expected to continue growing and maturing in the coming years. Investors should target sectors with resilient income profiles, driven by long-term structural trends, and be cautious of the ongoing uncertainty about rental growth outlook.

images.alt_text: Keppel currently manages a diverse portfolio of 2.6 trillion won, or S$2.6 billion, in assets in South Korea.
Oakwood Apartments Roppongi Central condominium in Tokyo.

site_title: Euro slips further on gloomy data; China’s yuan surges
summary: The euro slipped 0.15% to $1.10455, marking its fifth consecutive decline, amid evidence of a slowdown in Europe. China's yuan surged 0.5% following the Politburo meeting, with Chinese stocks and the Australian dollar also rising. The US Federal Reserve concludes its rate-setting meeting on Wednesday, while the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan follow on Thursday and Friday, respectively. Market analysts expect the ECB to maintain a 25-basis-point rate hike, but traders have trimmed expectations for further rate hikes later in the year.

site_title: Come on Barbie, let’s go argue about politics
summary: US politicians, including Governor Gretchen Whitmer, Representative Matt Gaetz, and Senator Raphael Warnock, have used the release of the film "Barbie" to make ideological points and attract attention. The film's themes of feminism and empowerment have been seized upon by Democrats, while Republicans have criticized it for promoting a "patriarchy" and appeasing China. The film's success has also sparked debate about the role of politics in Hollywood and the impact of cultural trends on box office performance. Despite criticisms that the film's politics may have detracted from its entertainment value, "Barbie" has become a cultural phenomenon, with a bipartisan coalition of commentators and politicians weighing in on its significance.

images.alt_text: The two A-listers do tremendous justice to Gerwig’s sparkling dialogue, and take full advantage of the opportunity to flex their physical comedy muscles with hilarious results.
Enter Barbie and Oppenheimer, two polar opposite movies that debuted simultaneously in a matchup dubbed “Barbenheimer”.

site_title: Opec’s war chest for an energy transition is shrinking
summary: OPEC's energy transition war chest is shrinking due to fluctuating oil revenues, population growth, and reduced exports. Despite a 54% increase in nominal revenue in 2022, real per capita export revenue is less than in 2009. OPEC's structural weaknesses, including rivalry with US shale and mainstreaming of clean technology, make it difficult to control prices. Saudi Arabia's efforts to support prices through production cuts have been short-lived, and the group's ability to manage the oil market is becoming increasingly difficult.

images.alt_text: Strong demand boosted US petrol futures to their highest since October 2022, which caused the petrol crack spread, a measure of refining profit margins, to rise to its highest since July 2022.
World fuel consumption will increase by 2.2 million bpd – or about 2 per cent – in 2023, the IEA estimates.
FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: Keppel Reit H1 DPU falls on higher property expenses, borrowing costs
summary: Keppel Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 2.4% to S$0.029 in the first half of 2023, due to higher property expenses and borrowing costs. Despite this, the Reit maintained a "healthy" operating performance, with 94.9% portfolio occupancy and stable leasing momentum. The Reit aims to keep up the momentum in the second half, targeting single-digit rental reversion. Keppel Reit's profit before tax dropped 60.4% to S$82.3 million, mainly due to a net fair-value loss on investment properties.

images.alt_text: DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.

site_title: China’s June gold imports via HK lowest in five months
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong fell 29% to 34.648 metric tons in June, the lowest in five months, due to sluggish economic recovery. Total gold imports via Hong Kong slipped 26% to 38.395 metric tons. Analysts attribute the decline to retail demand concerns over the economic outlook. China's central bank may be defending the currency, leading to higher premiums. Despite this, gold demand is expected to rise, with Citi projecting 700 metric tons of gold jewelry demand this year, up 22% from last year.

images.alt_text: People’s Bank of China (PBOC) holdings of bullion rose by 680,000 troy ounces in June, according to official data released.
Net imports into China stand at 49.056 tonnes in May, compared with 49.906 tonnes in April, Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department data shows.

An employee places a storage tray containing two hundred and fifty gram gold bars, produced by Swiss manufacturer Argor Hebaeus SA, into the safe at Aranypiac Kft in Budapest, Hungary, on Wednesday, July 20, 2016. Precious metals are back in demand as renewed concerns over Britain's decision to leave the EU have investors fleeing for gold. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg
Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.
Physical gold demand stalled in India in the week ending Jul 21, while bullion was sold at high premiums in top consumer China.

site_title: UK data watchdog to make enquiries about Worldcoin crypto project
summary: The UK's Information Commissioner's Office will investigate Worldcoin, a cryptocurrency project by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, after it launched with 2 million users and scaled up iris scanning operations in 20 countries, including London. The project assigns digital IDs to users, which it claims can distinguish humans from AI online. The regulator's examination comes after the project's cryptocurrency, Worldcoin token, rose to a peak of US$3.30 following its launch.

site_title: China appoints Pan Gongsheng as new central bank governor
summary: China has appointed Pan Gongsheng as its new central bank governor, replacing Yi Gang, in a move that reflects the government's tough stance on currency speculators and financial regulations. Pan, a veteran technocrat, has taken a tough stance against speculators and has been involved in state banking reforms. He faces challenges in wrestling with a downturn in China's property sector and local government debt. The new governor will serve both as Communist party head and central bank governor, with the central bank now reporting to new regulators as part of China's efforts to tighten party control over the financial system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People's Bank of China (PBOC) Deputy Governor Pan Gongsheng speaks at a news conference in Beijing, China March 3, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust posts 0.1% rise in Q1 DPU to S$0.02271
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a 0.1% rise in first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02271, despite a 3.1% decline in net property income to S$158.1 million. The decline was attributed to weaker exchange rates, particularly the depreciation of the yuan and other currencies. Despite this, the trust's portfolio occupancy rate remained stable at 97.1%, and rental reversions increased by 4.2%. The manager cited high borrowing costs, economic uncertainty, and geopolitical risks as headwinds, but emphasized the trust's focus on maintaining portfolio stability and rejuvenating its portfolio.

While interest rates were kept unchanged, the Federal Reserve signalled that interest rates could see two more increases for the rest of this year.
Vivocity’s full year tenant sales improved 30.6 per cent yoy, exceeding S$1 billion, which set a new record.

Of the 32 S-Reits that provided gross revenue figures in the latest reporting period, 23 reported an improvement while nine saw their topline decline.

site_title: SIA Engineering Q1 net profit more than doubled to S$27 million
summary: SIA Engineering Company's net profit more than doubled to S$27 million in Q1 2023-2024, driven by a 52.7% increase in gross revenue to S$261.9 million. The company's basic earnings per share rose to 2.41 Singapore cents, while operating profit turned black for the first time since the pandemic at S$0.4 million. Despite higher expenditure, the company's line maintenance unit handled 84% of pre-pandemic flights, and demand for maintenance, repair and overhaul services remains strong.

images.alt_text: SIAEC's aircraft engine services facility at 36 Changi North Crescent. The group is partnering New York-listed Eaton to set up a 49:51 joint venture in Malaysia.
SIA Engineering Company's engine imaging robot uses artificial intelligence (AI) to speed up the inspection process.

site_title: 3M raises full-year profit forecast on higher prices, cost-cut measures
summary: 3M, a US industrial conglomerate, raised its full-year profit forecast due to higher prices and cost-cut measures, including 10% layoffs. The company now expects a profit between $8.60 and $9.10 per share, up from prior guidance. To offset mounting commodity costs, 3M has been raising prices and reducing its global workforce. The company's cost-cut measures are expected to contribute to its improved profit outlook.

images.alt_text: Under the agreement, 3M will pay a minimum of US$10.5 billion and as much as US$12.5 billion.

site_title: China property firms rally after Beijing pledges economic support
summary: China's top leaders pledged economic support, including adapting to market supply and demand changes and optimising property policies. This led to a sharp rally in the property sector, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index jumping 14% and major developers' shares soaring. The rally put the sector on track for its first monthly gain after four months of losses. While analysts expect further easing, they believe it will be limited and focused on city-by-city basis, with no quick fix for the sector's debt crisis.

images.alt_text: The economy faces new challenges and the post-pandemic recovery will be tortuous, Xinhua reported, following a Politburo meeting chaired by President Xi Jinping.
The blue-chip CSI 300 Index snaps a six-day losing streak by closing up nearly 3 per cent to record the best day since last November, while the Hang Seng Index jumps 4.1 per cent.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange Fund’s investment income back to black in H1, outlook uncertain
summary: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund, which backs the Hong Kong dollar, reported a significant investment income of HK$110 billion in the first half of 2023, reversing a HK$165.4 billion loss in the same period last year. This growth was driven by rebounds in foreign equity and bond markets. However, the fund's chief executive expressed uncertainty about the rest of the year due to geopolitical instability and potential economic recession, leading to a cautious outlook for the remainder of 2023.

images.alt_text: The blue-chip CSI 300 Index snaps a six-day losing streak by closing up nearly 3 per cent to record the best day since last November, while the Hang Seng Index jumps 4.1 per cent.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Hong Kong SAR’s Chief Executive John Lee on 24 July 2023.

site_title: Binance to scale up services on new Japan platform in Aug
summary: Binance plans to launch full services on its new Japan platform in August, following the purchase of Sakura Exchange BitCoin last November. The move aims to comply with local rules and tap into Japan's stablecoin market. The company's local General Manager, Takeshi Chino, also hinted at the possibility of issuing stablecoins in Japan, which has recently implemented a stablecoin law. This expansion is part of Binance's efforts to expand its Asian footprint, following similar moves in South Korea and Thailand.

site_title: GM puts profit ahead of growth, veering away from Tesla
summary: General Motors (GM) has raised its full-year profit guidance, citing a 52% increase in net income to $2.6 billion in the second quarter. The company now expects $9.3 billion to $10.7 billion in net income, up from a previous forecast of $8.4 billion to $9.9 billion. GM plans to invest less in new products and cut operating costs by an additional $1 billion, with a focus on profitability and simplicity. In contrast to Tesla's strategy of cutting prices, GM has pushed average transaction prices up by $1,600 to about $52,000 in North America.

images.alt_text: The Lyriq, a luxury crossover based on GM’s Ultium EV architecture, is now priced from 379,700 yuan.
The joint GM and Samsung SDI plant near New Carlisle, Indiana aims to have an annual production capacity of 30 gigawatt hours (GWh).

site_title: Philippines stun New Zealand for historic first World Cup win
summary: The Philippines stunned women's World Cup co-hosts New Zealand 1-0, securing their first-ever World Cup win, thanks to a first-half header from Sarina Bolden. Ranked 46th in the world, the underdogs defeated New Zealand, ranked 20 places higher, in front of 32,357 in Wellington. The victory blows Group A wide open and sets the Philippines up for a spot in the last 16, with a guaranteed win if they beat Norway on Sunday.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Philippines' forward #07 Sarina Bolden celebrates scoring her team's first goal during the Australia and New Zealand 2023 Women's World Cup Group A football match between New Zealand and the Philippines at Wellington Stadium, also known as Sky Stadium, in Wellington on July 25, 2023. (Photo by Marty MELVILLE / AFP)

site_title: ECB hiking sends corporate loan demand down most on record
summary: The European Central Bank's interest-rate hikes have led to a record decline in corporate loan demand in the eurozone, with a 7.5% drop in the second quarter. This drop, along with further declines in mortgage and consumer borrowing, signals that the ECB's efforts to combat inflation are affecting the economy. The ECB's net tightening since 2022 has been substantial, with lenders expecting more rate hikes in the third quarter. The central bank is set to raise its deposit rate by another quarter-point on Thursday, and may consider one final move.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) is pictured outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, April 26, 2018. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach//File Photo

site_title: Local medtech consortium partners UK’s NHS for business, research opportunities
summary: Singapore's medtech consortium partners with the UK's National Health Service (NHS) for business and research opportunities, providing a pathway for Singaporean companies to expand in the UK and vice versa. The collaboration, facilitated by the NHS, offers access to pre-existing business networks, incubation, and clinical trials. Medtech players can also utilize the network to access capital and expand in Singapore. The agreement aims to create an entry point for entrepreneurs from both nations to explore commercial opportunities in the UK, Singapore, and the broader South-east Asian region.

images.alt_text: Nirdesh Gupta (left), chief executive of Coronet Ventures, with CSIP president James Laur
The interest in preventive health technology has been rising globally.

site_title: Singapore shares rise 0.6% amid gains on Wall Street, Asian markets
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% on Tuesday, tracking overnight Wall Street gains and Asian market rallies, amid China's pledge to support its economy. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares closed near its 52-week high, up 1.3%, while DFI Retail Group was the worst performer, down 2.2%. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,286.16 points. Analysts expect China's new market approach to have a significant impact on the financial markets, with the execution of these policies to be closely watched.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares muted at open after global markets end mostly higher
Keppel DC Reit's data centre in Guangdong. The Reit's distribution per unit for H1 FY2023 is up a marginal 0.04 per cent at S$0.05051.

The pan-European Stoxx 600 edged up 0.1 per cent, hovering near its five-week highs.

site_title: Indonesia grants Amman Mineral export permit valid through May 2024
summary: Indonesia has granted PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara a permit to export 900,000 wet metric tonnes of copper concentrate until May 2024, despite the country's ban on raw mineral exports starting in June to attract investment into its metals processing industry.

images.alt_text: The Jakarta-based company’s IPO was the biggest since the US$1.1 billion listing of tech firm GoTo in April 2022.

Exports of copper, iron ore, lead, zinc and anode mud from copper concentrates will be allowed until smelters, many of which were delayed by the pandemic, are ready to handle the materials, says Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Arifin Tasrif.

site_title: Parliamentary vote to select Thailand PM postponed
summary: Thailand's parliamentary vote to select a new prime minister has been postponed due to a political deadlock. The vote, initially scheduled for July 27, was blocked by conservative lawmakers and will now be held on August 3. The move comes after the leader of the winning Move Forward Party, Pita Limjaroenrat, failed to secure the necessary majority in a joint sitting of both houses. A review of a decision to block Pita's re-nomination as a prime ministerial candidate is ongoing, and talks between parties are underway to find a way forward.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader Pita Limjaroenrat says his party is committed to helping Pheu Thai form a “government of the people” to prevent parties that align with the establishment from returning to power.

epa10751685 Pheu Thai Party's Prime Ministerial candidate Srettha Thavisin leaves party’s headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 17 July 2023. EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK
“I would like to say goodbye until we meet again,” Pita Limjaroenrat tells the chamber, raising his fist as he leaves the assembly floor to the cheers of fellow lawmakers.
With Pita Limjaroenrat out of the running, Thailand remains in political limbo as the country awaits the identity of its next prime minister.

site_title: Asia: China stimulus hopes help boost markets, US Fed in focus
summary: Chinese leaders pledged fresh measures to boost the nation's stuttering economy, building on optimism that central banks are nearing the end of their rate-hiking cycle. The announcement sparked a surge across most Asian markets, with Hong Kong leading the gains. Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, and Jakarta also rose, while Tokyo and Wellington dipped. Investors are cautiously optimistic, expecting further policy easing, but note that the measures fell short of expectations, and a sustained impact on the market remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Shanghai, Taipei, Manila, Jakarta and Wellington were all up, but Hong Kong and Singapore retreated.

site_title: Distressed debt: Which sectors offer value?
summary: Credit investors may find an ideal time to invest in stressed and distressed debt, as the current environment offers high-quality companies at attractive prices. With central banks' quantitative easing regime, bond prices have dropped, creating opportunities for credit investors. Companies experiencing credit stress can be found in various sectors, including utilities, real estate, and healthcare, offering margins of safety not seen in decades. Investors should focus on risk-focused, high-quality investments with appealing risk/reward ratios, as the current environment may be the best for credit investors in at least a generation.

images.alt_text: wanda17 - The newly built Wanda Mall, operated by Dalian Wanda Group Co., stands near residential buildings in this aerial photograph taken in the Wuxiang New District of Nanning, Guangxi province, China, on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2019.

For investors the risk focus has shifted from the rising cost of capital to refinancing. Some companies are rolling over debt early even at higher rates, to avoid potentially not being able to do so at all later on.

site_title: TikTok chef whips up real-life restaurant after virtual success
summary: TikTok chef Tue Nguyen has opened her first restaurant, Di Di, in West Hollywood, California, after gaining popularity on the platform by sharing her Vietnamese cooking videos. Nguyen, 25, credits her mother and stepfather as her culinary influences and has a unique blend of culinary school techniques and her heritage in her cooking style. She hopes her personal brand and online presence will help her succeed in the competitive Los Angeles dining scene, where her restaurant is a celebration of her Vietnamese culture.
