ByteDance’s TikTok plans to invest billions of dollars in South-east Asia over the next three to five years.

site_title: Dulux maker Akzo Nobel lifts outlook on easing raw material costs
summary: Akzo Nobel, the maker of Dulux and Flexa paints, has raised its annual profit outlook due to easing raw material costs. The company expects adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) to be 1.4-1.55 billion euros, up from 1.2-1.5 billion euros. Raw material costs started to decline in the second quarter, with prices up 5% from a year earlier to offset inflation. The company's adjusted Ebitda rose 18% to 397 million euros in the quarter, slightly missing analyst expectations.

images.alt_text: Akzo Nobel, the maker of Dulux and Flexa paints reiterated its full year outlook, saying falling raw material costs should help its profitability.

site_title: US will be short 67,000 chip workers by 2030, industry group says
summary: The US semiconductor industry faces a projected workforce shortage of 67,000 workers by 2030, despite a growth to 460,000 by the end of the decade. The Semiconductor Industry Association and Oxford Economics attribute the shortage to a lack of qualified graduates, which cannot keep pace with industry demands. This comes as the US strengthens its domestic chip sector with the CHIPS Act, signed into law in August.

images.alt_text: S&P Global says its flash US Composite PMI index, which tracks manufacturing and service sectors, falls to a reading of 52 in July from 53.2 in June.

The Conference Board says its Leading Economic Index (LEI), a measure that anticipates future economic activity, declines by 0.7 per cent in June to 106.1 following a revised decrease of 0.6 per cent in May.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits drop 9,000 to a seasonally adjusted 228,000 for the week ended Jul 15, US Labor Department says.

The  National Semiconductor Technology Center will be an independent nonprofit so that it’s trusted by companies in the industry and viewed as neutral and science driven, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said.

site_title: Seven & i unit Sogo & Seibu's labour union confirms right to strike
summary: A labour union of Seven & i Holdings' department store unit Sogo & Seibu has confirmed its right to strike over a proposed sale of the subsidiary to US fund Fortress Investment Group. The sale, agreed to last year, aims to preserve jobs. The union plans to vote on a strike this month, as part of negotiations to ensure job preservation. A spokesperson for Seven & i was informed of the strike vote confirmation, but union representatives were unavailable for comment.

site_title: China's stocks surge, yuan firms as leaders pledge to shore up economy
summary: China's stocks surged, with the CSI 300 Index rising nearly 3% and the Hang Seng Index jumping 4.1%, marking the best day since November. The yuan firmed to a near two-week high against the US dollar after Chinese leaders pledged to roll out further policy support to shore up the economy. The decision comes as data showed China's growth lost momentum in the second quarter. Tech giants and property developers led the gains, with shares rising 6% and 14.1% respectively. China's top leaders will step up economic policy support to focus on expanding domestic demand and preventing risks.

images.alt_text: Local government debt burdens – which have climbed because of the property market slump that reduced their income – have slowed government spending growth this year.
The economy faces new challenges and the post-pandemic recovery will be tortuous, Xinhua reported, following a Politburo meeting chaired by President Xi Jinping.
A special fund from the central government budget will be set up by the NDRC to give annual support for 20 cities with high private investment growth and strong policy implementation.

The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) asks local lawyers to refrain from including negative descriptions of China’s policies or its business and legal environment in companies’ listing prospectuses.
Key Chinese indexes are down for the year, losing out on a rally seen across Japan, India and the US.

site_title: Key roles for Singapore at IMO but difficult times ahead
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has elected Arsenio Antonio Dominguez Velasco of Panama as its new secretary-general, effective January 1, 2024. The appointment comes amidst challenging times for the organization, including Russia's decision to scrap the grain export deal from Ukraine's Black Sea ports, which has disrupted global shipping and food supplies. Despite this, the IMO remains committed to its core mission of ensuring the safety of life at sea and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Singapore, a long-time supporter of the IMO, congratulated Dominguez Velasco on his election and expressed its commitment to working with him to advance the interests of the international maritime community.

images.alt_text: White hydrogen is created through fracking, a process that involves the explosive fracturing of deep underground layers of sediments.

site_title: Xiaomi to slash smartphone line after conceding India missteps
summary: Xiaomi plans to slash its smartphone line in India, focusing on 5G models and a leaner product portfolio to regain market share lost to rivals. The company, which previously held the lead in India, admitted to confusing customers with too many products. Xiaomi will simplify its offerings, increase focus on customer experience, and deepen local sourcing. The company has laid off 30 employees and may cut more jobs to reduce spending. Xiaomi aims to unveil a new 5G smartphone priced between $200-$250 in August.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi’s offline push comes months after it lost its leadership position to Samsung, which had a much bigger portfolio of premium phones now in vogue.

Xiaomi Corp. Mi smartphones on display inside the AliExpress plaza retail store, operated by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, Jan. 13, 2020. U.S. officials deliberated but ultimately decided against banning American investment in Alibaba and Tencent Holdings Ltd., a person familiar with the discussions said, removing a cloud of uncertainty over Asia’s two biggest corporations. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
Court documents show Xiaomi’s frozen assets are spread across accounts at various banks including Deutsche, Citi and HSBC.
Xiaomi was once an unrivalled leader in India’s smartphone market, but lost steam after facing heightened regulatory scrutiny and stiff competition.
Xiaomi's Indian arm is targeting a 50 per cent increase in the production of components locally sourced by 2025.

site_title: Business confidence slips further as Germany faces sluggish recovery
summary: Germany's business confidence has slipped further, with the Ifo institute's business climate index falling to 87.3 in July, down from 88.6 in June. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, as analysts warn of a sluggish recovery. The country slipped into a technical recession in early 2023 and is expected to experience only slight growth in second-quarter GDP, followed by a slide in the third quarter. Global economic concerns, including a weaker-than-expected Chinese reopening and ongoing monetary policy tightening, are cited as factors contributing to the economic downturn.

images.alt_text: The plan for chip support means at least 3 billion euros is available for additional projects. That could benefit other companies active in Germany.

A classic Citroen 2CV automobile parked outside residential apartment blocks on the Carl Legien modernist housing estate, operated by Deutsche Wohnen SE, in Berlin, Germany, on Monday, Aug. 2, 2021. Vonovia SE nudged up its offer for rival German real estate company Deutsche Wohnen SE to about 19.1 billion euros ($22.7 billion), sweetening an attempt to woo shareholders after last months bid narrowly failed. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg via Getty Images
A slump in German property prices and a subsequent jump in loan-to-value ratios have spurred worries about refinancing, making real estate the worst-performing sector in Europe in the past year.
Germany's average GDP growth is expected to fall back below 1 per cent due to accelerating headwinds from population aging and a lack of significant increases in productivity.

site_title: Workers’ Party MP Faisal Manap in ICU for cardiac condition
summary: Workers' Party MP Faisal Manap, 48, was hospitalized on July 24 for a cardiac condition and is currently in the ICU. He is conscious and in stable condition, with his family requesting privacy to focus on his recovery. Remaining Aljunied GRC MPs will cover his constituency duties in his absence. This comes after fellow MP Leon Perera resigned on July 19 for lying about an affair.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS raises target price for Keppel DC Reit on steady growth
summary: DBS Group Research has increased its target price for Keppel DC Reit to S$2.45, maintaining its "buy" call, citing the Reit's strong financial performance for the first half of FY2023 and accretive acquisitions. The analysts project higher DPU forecasts for FY2024 and FY2025, driven by the completion of Guangdong DC 3 and structural tailwinds in the sector. The revised target price implies a forward yield of 4.1-4.4%, in line with the four-year average.

images.alt_text: Data centre in Guangdong acquired by Keppel DC Reit.
DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.
Keppel DC Reit was the best performing S-Reit in the first half of 2023, driven by stronger growth in distributable income and distribution per unit.

site_title: Driving innovation with resilience and risk tolerance, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The article suggests that Sam Bankman-Fried (SBF), the founder of FTX, may offer assistance to companies struggling with worker training due to lack of resources. Key facts include: FTX's extensive network and resources could be leveraged to provide training services. SBF's company has experience in the cryptocurrency industry, which may be beneficial for training in this field. The potential partnership could help bridge the gap in training for companies in need, ultimately benefiting the workers and the industry as a whole.

site_title: Singapore, Japan to jointly implement green aviation initiatives
summary: Singapore and Japan have agreed to collaborate on green aviation initiatives, including the implementation of green air travel management (ATM) measures that can save fuel and reduce carbon emissions. The two authorities will work together to expand a multi-regional trajectory-based operations project and materialize an Aviation Green Lane comprising airline operations, airport processes, and ATM. The collaboration aims to establish tangible measures that can be implemented immediately and serve as a pathfinder for wider adoption by more countries.

images.alt_text: A Singapore Airlines (SIA) plane being refuelled with blended sustainable aviation fuel at Changi Airport, 7 July 2022.
Passengers in the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 3 in March. The airport handled 5.12 million passengers in June, crossing the five million mark for the first time since January 2020.
Japan's inbound visitors rise to 2.07 million in June, clearing the 2 million mark for the first time since February 2020.
The group’s passenger load factor for June also reached a monthly record of 90.6 per cent.

site_title: TotalEnergies takes control of renewables firm for 1.5 billion euros
summary: TotalEnergies agreed to buy the remaining 71% shares of Total Eren for 1.5 billion euros, gaining full control of a firm with 3.5 gigawatts of renewable energy in operation and a project pipeline of over 10 gigawatts. The purchase is expected to increase TotalEnergies' power division's net operating income by 160 million euros and operating cash flow by 400 million euros. This move boosts the oil major's foray into renewable energy, with CEO Patrick Pouyanne pledging to spend $5 billion on low-carbon energies this year.

site_title: Adidas and Puma bet on 'terrace' sneaker trend in tough market
summary: German sportswear giants Adidas and Puma are re-releasing old "terrace" sneaker styles from the 1970s and 1980s, driven by renewed interest in the shoes. This trend may give Adidas an advantage over Nike this summer, but may not offset weakening US and Chinese demand. Adidas has seen a surge in searches for its "Adidas Samba" style, while Puma is likely to benefit less due to its lower name recognition. However, investors will be pushing both companies on broader strategies to navigate weak consumer demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Adidas logo is pictured during celebrations for German sports apparel maker Adidas' 70th anniversary at the company's headquarters in Herzogenaurach, Germany, August 9, 2019. REUTERS/Andreas Gebert/File Photo

The German sportswear giant has been in a predicament over the Yeezy stock since it cut ties with West over his anti-Semitic comments late last year, with the controversy weighing on its stock and hitting its bottom line.
“Their numbers there have been just abysmal. They’ve clearly lost market share, and that has a bigger impact in the long term than even Yeezy does,” says Morningstar analyst David Swartz.

site_title: Indonesia central bank keeps rates on hold as uncertainties ease
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, kept interest rates steady for the sixth consecutive review, maintaining a focus on controlling inflation and stabilizing the rupiah currency. The benchmark seven-day reverse repurchase rate remains at 5.75%, unchanged since January. Governor Perry Warjiyo expects global uncertainties to ease, predicting the rupiah will appreciate. The bank also relaxed rules on required reserves for banks lending to certain sectors to support credit growth, with a forecast of 9% to 11% credit expansion this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Indonesia's Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo speaks during a media briefing at Bank Indonesia headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, December 19, 2019. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana/File Photo

site_title: S&P lowers Bangladesh’s outlook to negative from stable
summary: S&P Global Ratings lowered Bangladesh's outlook to negative from stable, citing risks to its external liquidity position and foreign exchange reserves. The agency expects the economy to expand 6-6.4% over the next three years, but notes that favourable trade and financial flows are necessary to stabilize its external settings in the next 12 months. Bangladesh's US dollar reserves have shrunk to $29.85 billion, and the country is struggling to pay for imported fuel due to a US dollar shortage.

site_title: Unilever quarterly sales beat estimates as prices rise
summary: Unilever reported a 7.9% rise in underlying second-quarter sales, beating analysts' average forecast of 6.4%. The company's underlying price growth was 8.2%, while underlying volumes fell by 0.3%, exceeding expectations. Unilever expects underlying sales growth for the full year to be above 5% as it continues to moderate price hikes. The company's new CEO, Hein Schumacher, attributed the results to the company's strong fundamentals.

images.alt_text: PepsiCo’s revenue rose 16 per cent in Russia and profits quadrupled, and the soda maker said operations in Russia accounted for 5 per cent of consolidated net revenue for 2022, up from 4 per cent a year earlier.

site_title: From bench to bedside: Developing early-detection tests for cancer, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The 38th Singapore Business Awards honored top business leaders for their outstanding contributions to the country's business landscape. The awards ceremony recognized individuals and organizations that have demonstrated exceptional leadership, innovation, and commitment to excellence. Winners were chosen from a pool of nominees across various categories, including entrepreneurship, innovation, and corporate social responsibility. The awards aim to promote and celebrate Singapore's business achievements, inspiring future generations of entrepreneurs and business leaders. The ceremony was attended by prominent business figures, government officials, and industry experts.

site_title: BYD widens lead over Volkswagen as China’s top-selling car brand
summary: BYD has widened its lead over Volkswagen as China's top-selling car brand, with 595,300 sales of plug-in hybrids and fully-electric vehicles in the quarter through June, increasing its market share to 11.2%. This marks the first time BYD has dethroned Volkswagen, which had held the top spot since at least 2008. The trend reflects the growing influence of Chinese electric vehicle makers, with BYD's affordable models driving sales. BYD's market share has surpassed Volkswagen, while Tesla ranks 12th in EV sales in China.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has been trying to attract EV makers to invest in the country, enticing them with its rich nickel reserves which can be processed into EV batteries.
FILE PHOTO: A truck transports new Tesla cars at its factory in Shanghai, China, May 13, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Jul 31 court date set for MP Christopher de Souza’s professional disciplinary case
summary: MP Christopher de Souza, Deputy Speaker of Parliament and an MP for Holland-Bukit Timah GRC, will face the Court of Three Judges on Jul 31 to decide the final outcome of his professional disciplinary case. In 2022, he was found guilty of professional misconduct by a disciplinary tribunal for not making full and frank disclosure to the court while acting for Amber Compounding Pharmacy. The tribunal found he helped his client suppress evidence and breached his paramount duty to the court. De Souza's lawyers argue the one charge should be dismissed, while the Law Society seeks disciplinary sanction.

site_title: UK battery startup Nexeon to supply Panasonic with advanced material
summary: UK battery startup Nexeon will supply Panasonic with advanced silicon-rich anode material, enabling the company's battery cells to store more energy and charge more quickly. The material will be used in Panasonic's new US plant, set to open in 2025, allowing for smaller, lighter packs with similar range to current battery cells. Nexeon's partnership with Panasonic is a significant move in the development of silicon-rich anodes, which are being pursued by several startups, including Group14 and Sila Nanotechnologies.

images.alt_text: While Panasonic has been a key supplier to Tesla from its early days, the Japanese manufacturer has been slower to build scale compared with rivals LG Energy Solution of South Korea and China’s Contemporary Amperex Technology Co.

site_title: Bitcoin retreat puts crypto’s 2023 lead over stocks in jeopardy
summary: Bitcoin retreats below $30,000, putting its 2023 lead over stocks in jeopardy. The year-to-date climb in digital assets has cooled to 46% compared to the Nasdaq 100 Index's 41% jump. A court setback for a US regulatory crackdown and optimism over spot Bitcoin ETFs have lost momentum, with investors assessing the impact of an expected Federal Reserve interest-rate hike. Bitcoin's 20-week Bollinger bandwidth has shrunk to its narrowest in seven years, suggesting intense moves could be on the way down.

images.alt_text: The collectibles sold for US$15 each, Kartoon Studios’ partner Veve said on its website, meaning the drop of 8,294 netted about US$120,000 in revenue.

When available, spot Bitcoin ETFs will become a fixture in many portfolios, and deservedly or not, the conversation will be less about whether Bitcoin is a fraud and more about its merit relative to traditional investments such as stocks and bonds.

site_title: Musk explains why he’s dumping Twitter name and iconic bird logo
summary: Elon Musk has explained his decision to strip Twitter of its iconic blue-bird logo, renaming the platform to X, as part of a broader effort to remake it into a comprehensive communications and financial transactions platform. The new X app aims to layer communication, multimedia, and financial capabilities, similar to China's WeChat super-app. Twitter's advertising revenue has fallen, and the rebranding effort is seen as a bid to restore trust with advertisers and users. Musk envisions X as an "everything app" with fintech features like payments and banking.

site_title: LVMH to sponsor Paris Olympics in a first for luxury group
summary: LVMH, the luxury conglomerate led by Bernard Arnault, has agreed to become a premium sponsor of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, marking the first time the company has participated in the event. The deal, worth an undisclosed amount, includes designing Olympic and Paralympic medals and serving Moet Hennessy wines and spirits to hospitality guests. The partnership aims to heighten the appeal of France globally, according to Arnault.

site_title: ‘I’m back for good’, HSBC tells wealthy Indians over 3-Michelin-star dinner
summary: HSBC has announced its return to private banking in India, a move that marks a significant shift for the global bank after it exited the market eight years ago. The bank's efforts to convince wealthy Indian clients that its wealth management services will not retreat again are a key part of its ambitious plans in the country. With invested assets in India more than tripling in 2022, HSBC plans to recruit over two dozen wealth bankers and double its headcount in the next five years, aiming to triple assets under management.

images.alt_text: HSBC has stepped up expansion in China despite criticism from some lawmakers in the West of the bank’s conduct in the region.
HSBC says the trial will help it better analyse threats and work out how to protect data.

site_title: Moody's cuts Thames Water unit credit rating, issues new warning
summary: Moody's downgraded Thames Water (Kemble) Finance's credit rating to B2 from B1, maintaining a negative outlook, due to concerns over the water regulator Ofwat's potential "dividend block" and the company's struggling finances. The downgrade reflects increased public criticism of Thames Water's sewage dumping practices. Moody's warns the rating could be cut again if the company's financial situation doesn't improve.

images.alt_text: Thames Water has been at the centre of a crisis in the sector as rising interest rates cause payments on inflation-linked debt to surge.

The entrance to the headquarters of Thames Water in Reading, UK, on Monday, July 3, 2023. The bonds of the UK's biggest water provider climbed on Monday as investors bet a selloff driven by fears the utility would be nationalized had gone too far. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
UK media said ministers were in talks about the possibility of temporarily bringing the utility company back into public hands under a so-called special administration regime.
The utility, which is carrying £14 billion in debt, said the fine related to an incident at its West Sussex site in southern England due to the running of a storm pump in error.

site_title: Indonesia plans incentives for EV makers, sets up meeting with BYD, Tesla
summary: Indonesia is finalizing incentives to attract electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers, with a focus on its rich nickel reserves. The country aims to attract companies like Tesla and BYD, with a meeting scheduled with BYD executives in China and Tesla's CEO Elon Musk in California. The incentives will be benchmarked against those offered by regional rivals Thailand and Vietnam, but details remain unclear. The move follows years of efforts to woo Tesla, which has been in talks with Indian officials for an EV factory investment.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has already implemented a 35 per cent mandatory blend of palm oil in its biodiesel.
Growing revenue will be a challenge in the third quarter because Tesla has scheduled shutdowns at its factories for upgrades.

site_title: Financial analytics platform Bunker raises over US$5 million in pre-seed, seed funding
summary: Bunker, a Singapore-based financial analytics platform, has raised over US$5 million in pre-seed and seed funding. The platform, founded by Shivom Sinha, a former finance strategist of Uber and Gojek, aims to help businesses spot vendor-specific costs and negotiation opportunities for payment terms. The funds will be used for product development and team growth, integrating with popular business software such as Xero and SAP. Bunker's platform went live in 2021 and has customers in Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Singapore's top-funded position in South-east Asia is in contrast to the regional decline in tech funding, data from Tracxn shows.
From left to right: Eyeball Games' Philippines marketing manager Chris Johnson, world no. 1 pool player and Eyeball Pool ambassador Efren Bata Reyes and Eyeball Games CEO Jonathan Ivarsson.
MAKA Motors co-founders Arief Fadillah (left) and Raditya Wibowo.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sets sights on next round of ETFs in comeback bid
summary: Morgan Stanley is seeking to launch three new exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and an additional ETF, following its re-entry into the industry in February. The proposed ETFs, including the Eaton Vance Ultra-Short Income ETF and Parametric Dividend Premium Income ETF, were submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission. This marks the firm's next step in its comeback bid, nearly three decades after helping to birth the US$7.5 trillion ETF industry. Morgan Stanley's six environmental, social and governance-focused ETFs have accumulated nearly $400 million in assets.

site_title: Indonesia’s Pertamina launches sales of petrol with 5% ethanol mix
summary: Indonesian state-owned energy company Pertamina has launched sales of 95-octane petrol mixed with 5% bioethanol, called Pertamax Green 95, in Jakarta and Surabaya. The move aims to expand the availability of renewable fuels in the country, which plans to eventually mandate a 15% bioethanol content in petrol nationwide by 2031. This is part of Indonesia's efforts to increase the use of bioethanol, which is currently limited due to a lack of ethanol supply.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has been working to introduce bioethanol mandates for petrol to further cut fuel imports and carbon emissions, but securing adequate feedstock is a key hurdle.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank initiates CSE Global with ‘buy’ on strong profitability prospects
summary: Maybank Securities has initiated coverage on technology group CSE Global with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.62. The analyst expects strong revenue growth, driven by the global oil and gas upcycle, data centre projects, and infrastructure projects in Australia and Singapore. CSE Global is forecast to post a 250% year-on-year surge in profitability and strong revenue of S$850 million in FY2025, translating to a 15% compound annual growth rate. The stock is considered undervalued, trading at 13.7 times FY2023 earnings, making it an attractive entry point.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB analysts expect CSE Global to have faster orderbook executions from easing supply chain pressures.
Lim Boon Kheng, CSE Global's group managing director, noted that the company's diversification strategy has turned its infrastructure segment into a key revenue growth driver for the group.

site_title: Driven by AI boom, TSMC to invest T$90 billion in advanced chip plant in Taiwan
summary: TSMC plans to invest nearly T$90 billion in an advanced packaging facility in northern Taiwan, driven by the surge in demand for artificial intelligence (AI). The new plant will create about 1500 jobs and roughly double TSMC's capacity for advanced packaging, which involves placing multiple chips into a single device. Despite its position as the leading manufacturer of AI chips, TSMC's broader end market weakness has not been offset, and the company expects this tightening to be released next year. The facility will be built in the Tongluo Science Park in Miaoli county.

images.alt_text: TSMC is viewed as among the earliest beneficiaries of efforts from the US to China to develop AI platforms.

site_title: Singapore shares muted at open after global markets end mostly higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index edged up 0.07 point to 3,265.21 after a mostly higher close on global markets. The US and European markets ended higher, with the Dow notching its 11th straight gain. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB losing 0.6% and 0.01% respectively. The most active counter by volume was Seatrium, holding steady at S$0.145 with 41.7 million shares traded.

images.alt_text: SGX: Asia’s international, multi-asset exchange

site_title: Gold struggles for direction as traders await US Fed decision
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,958.20 per ounce in early Asian trading on Tuesday, awaiting US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates and monetary policy. A near-two-week peak in the US dollar index weighed on gold, making bullion more expensive for buyers holding other currencies. The Fed's rate hike and European Central Bank's decision are expected to be closely watched for their impact on gold prices. A slowing US business activity and shrinking European economy imply that central banks may be nearing the end of their rate-hike cycles.

images.alt_text: Physical gold demand stalled in India in the week ending Jul 21, while bullion was sold at high premiums in top consumer China.

site_title: Vietnam aims to raise annual raw rare earths output to 2 million tonnes a year by 2030
summary: Vietnam aims to increase its annual raw rare earth output to 2.02 million tonnes by 2030, with the goal of reaching 2.11 million tonnes by 2050. The country has the world's second-largest reserves of rare earths, estimated at 22 million tonnes, and plans to develop 3-4 new mines after 2030. Additionally, Vietnam seeks to invest in rare earth mining facilities, with a target of producing 20,000-60,000 tonnes of rare-earth oxides by 2030 and 40,000-80,000 tonnes by 2050.

images.alt_text: Vietnam calls on rice traders to balance between exports and domestic sales to stabilise domestic prices.
The skyline of Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Climate tech startup Zuno Carbon raises US$2.5 million in seed funding
summary: Climate tech startup Zuno Carbon has secured US$2.5 million in seed funding led by Wavemaker Partners, with participation from Enterprise Singapore's Seeds Capital and Blue InCube Ventures. The funds will be used to enhance sales and marketing efforts, launch new features, and support decarbonization efforts. Founded in 2020, Zuno Carbon provides a decarbonization solutions platform, Veridis, which helps companies track and report greenhouse gas emissions through artificial intelligence. The platform has been deployed in various sectors, including oil and gas, logistics, and real estate, to lower carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: The new sustainability standards provide a structured framework for companies to assess and disclose their resilience to sustainability-related risks, allowing investors to understand the company’s long-term prospects better.
The latest sustainability reports of the 20 largest primary-listed companies on the SGX average 45,939 words – three times the word count of their financial statements for the corresponding FY.

site_title: Pertamina, Petronas buy Shell’s stake in Indonesia’s Masela gas block
summary: Pertamina and Petronas have signed an agreement with Shell to buy its 35% stake in Indonesia's Masela natural gas fields for up to $650 million. The deal, worth $325 million, will see Pertamina Hulu Energi take 20% and Petronas Masela take 15%. The transaction is expected to be completed in the third quarter, subject to regulatory approval. The purchase aims to ensure adequate oil and gas supply for national energy needs, with the Masela fields set to produce 9.5 million metric tons of LNG per year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company Shell is displayed during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: Apple faces £785 million UK lawsuit by apps developers over app store fees
summary: Apple is facing a £785 million UK lawsuit by over 1,500 app developers over its App Store fees, which have been criticized for being excessive and abusive. The lawsuit, brought by Professor Sean Ennis on behalf of the developers, claims that Apple's 15-30% commission charges harm both app developers and consumers. The UK Competition Appeal Tribunal will hear the case, which is the latest in a series of antitrust investigations into Apple's App Store practices.

images.alt_text: Apple is aiming to hold shipments steady despite tumult in the global economy and a projected decline in the overall smartphone market.

site_title: What to expect from the rest of the year for US monetary policy
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again in July, with a 25-basis-point hike, as inflation remains high. The dollar's upside may be limited as the Fed's rate-hiking cycle nears its end. Markets anticipate a soft landing for the US economy, which could lead to a modest softening bias for the dollar over the rest of 2023. However, the dollar's trajectory will be influenced by global economic developments, including European Central Bank and Bank of Japan policies, as well as China's monetary stance.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve Building is seen in Washington, DC, May 3, 2023. - The US Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise its benchmark lending rate for a 10th -- and possibly final -- time, as it aims to bring down inflation while preventing fresh banking concerns from spreading. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)

Minutes published by the Fed on Wednesday showed that some FOMC members had initially supported another interest rate hike last month to tame inflation, before backing off to unanimously back the pause.

site_title: Disney considers delaying some 2023 movie releases over strikes
summary: Disney is reviewing its 2023 film release schedule due to striking actors, who won't help promote the movies. This may impact films like "Poor Things," "Next Goal Wins," and "Wish." The decision will depend on the outcome of the review, and some films may be too far along in marketing to change. This comes after Disney delayed some major films by up to three years earlier this year, following disappointing box office results for recent releases like "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny" and "The Little Mermaid."

images.alt_text: “We’re going to be open-minded... not necessarily about spinning ESPN off but about looking for strategic partners that can either help us with distribution or content,” says Disney CEO Robert Iger.

site_title: Elon Musk’s X misses the spot in several ways
summary: Elon Musk's rebranded social network, now known as X, has faced criticism for its lack of execution and vision. The platform has lost many users, advertisers, and employees, and its operational stability has been compromised. Musk's goal of transforming Twitter into a "super app" with multiple services, similar to China's WeChat, has been met with skepticism. The app's logo and branding have been criticized, and experts argue that the conditions that made super apps successful in Asia do not apply in the US market. Musk's vision has been described as "out of touch" with the needs of everyday internet users, and his grand ideas have been met with criticism for being unrealistic and poorly thought through.

images.alt_text: Twitter's new logo is seen projected on the corporate headquarters building in downtown San Francisco, California, U.S. July 23, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Barria     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
Elon Musk stressed that he uses Twitter a lot and that he has ideas on ways to make the platform “radically better”.

site_title: FDIC warns banks after errors in reporting uninsured deposits
summary: The FDIC warned US banks about errors in reporting uninsured deposits after 55 banks revised their figures amid increased scrutiny. In some cases, banks incorrectly excluded deposits collateralized by pledged assets and those held by subsidiaries. The FDIC stated that the existence of collateral has no bearing on federal deposit insurance coverage. The agency advised banks to submit revised reports if necessary, with Bank of America updating its uninsured deposits by the largest dollar amount and Huntington Bancshares by the largest percentage decline.

images.alt_text: SVB Financial owned Silicon Valley Bank before it was seized by the regulator in March, and the firm is attempting to sell its remaining assets in bankruptcy.
SVB Financial owned Silicon Valley Bank before it was seized by the US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in March.

site_title: Tesla looks abroad to keep growth going as US revenue plateaus
summary: Tesla reported a 103% increase in international revenue to $7.86 billion in the second quarter, driven by sales in Malaysia and the UK. US revenue plateaued at $11.3 billion, while China revenue fell to $5.7 billion. Production is expected to be down slightly in the third quarter due to factory shutdowns for upgrades, potentially weighing on Tesla shares. This may indicate that the company has reached a "local maximum" for the Model 3 and Y, its best-selling models.

site_title: Kitchen Culture pays up rental arrears, appoints five new directors
summary: Kitchen Culture, a kitchen solutions provider, has paid S$430,662.13 to landlord CDL Properties to settle four months of unpaid rent. The company also appointed five new directors as part of efforts to recover from legal and financial woes. The payment includes reinstatement costs, interest, and legal fees. The board has confirmed with CDL Properties that the sum has been received and no further claims will be made. The company is also seeking legal advice over a S$1.5 million loan dispute.

images.alt_text: An independent review of Kitchen Culture flagged potential payroll irregularities, as well as uncovered unauthorised transactions by the company.
Private investor Tan Gin Tat had loaned S$1 million and S$500,000 to Kitchen Culture in two separate loan agreements in August and December 2022.
Kitchen Culture said the redesignation is due to the need for the chairperson of the board to lead the company forward following the recent changes made to the board announced on Jun 26.
Kitchen Culture has also secured a S$4 million loan to pay its debts and for general working capital.
Kitchen Culture receives letter of demand from CDL unit for S$250,970 in unpaid rent

site_title: Binance, Billionaire Zhao to seek dismissal of CFTC lawsuit
summary: Binance, the world's largest digital-asset trading platform, plans to seek dismissal of a Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) lawsuit. The CFTC alleged that Binance and CEO Changpeng Zhao (CZ) broke US derivatives rules, failing to register with the agency and continuing to violate rules. Binance faces a decline in market share and regulatory probes worldwide. The company's native token, BNB, fell 2% in value amid the lawsuit. Binance will submit motions to dismiss the CFTC complaint, citing the complexity of the case and the number of arguments they anticipate making.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with displayed Binance logo and representation of cryptocurrencies are placed on keyboard in this illustration taken, November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China stocks, yuan jump as Beijing vows more support for economy
summary: China stocks surged 4.4% and the yuan rose 0.6% after Beijing pledged support for the struggling economy, including policy easing for the housing sector. China's top leaders announced plans to boost consumption and offer more support for the property sector. The move triggered a rebound in developers' US dollar bonds, while the benchmark CSI 300 Index climbed 2.2%. The rally came as traders sold haven assets and state-owned banks sold US dollars for yuan.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Hong Kong SAR’s Chief Executive John Lee on 24 July 2023.
Alibaba’s historic split is set to energise competition in areas such as the cloud, online commerce and logistics.

site_title: More salary claims filed in 2022 as more companies fall into financial difficulty: report
summary: Singapore's employment claims and appeals rose to 1.97 per 1,000 employees in 2022, up from 1.73 in 2021, driven by a higher proportion of group claims from companies in financial difficulty. Salary claims by local and foreign workers increased to 1.68 per 1,000 employees, lower than the pre-Covid figure of 2.68 in 2019. The report attributed the increase to companies facing financial difficulties, with a higher proportion of group claims lodged.

images.alt_text: Grab is cutting more than 1,000 staff to streamline costs.
Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad hopes that employers and employees will "continue to uphold  the overarching principles of merit-based employment."
More remedies for workers, employer penalties proposed for Singapore’s anti-discrimination law
Office workers walk out for a lunch break at Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on May 10, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: US: Stocks rise as Dow extends winning streak
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing up 0.5% at 35,411.24, reaching a 15-month peak. The gains followed optimism that the Federal Reserve won't remain hawkish and may signal one more interest rate hike and pause for a long time. The S&P 500 advanced 0.4% and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.2%. Chevron and Mattel also saw gains, with Chevron announcing higher-than-expected profits and Mattel expecting a boost from its Barbie movie.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average is  in its strongest rally in almost six years.

site_title: BOJ set to stick with easing as markets see clock ticking on yield curve control
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its negative interest rate and yield curve control at its upcoming meeting, despite rising inflation concerns. Officials may consider bumping up their inflation forecast for this year to 2.5% and discuss tweaking the cap on benchmark yields. Despite speculation about a possible adjustment, economists largely agree that a change is unlikely, with 82% of surveyed economists expecting the BOJ to leave rates and YCC unchanged for now.

images.alt_text: The central bank’s policy board is likely to mull raising the consumer inflation projection to around 2.5 per cent for the year ending in March, up from 1.8 per cent in the April estimate.

FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks about his parent policy at a press conference at his official residence in Tokyo on March 17, 2023. YOSHIKAZU TSUNO/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit
summary: Keppel DC Reit announced it will divest Basis Bay Data Centre in Cyberjaya, Malaysia, for RM55.6 million (S$16.9 million), with the sale expected to be completed by the third quarter of 2025. The Reit's share of the consideration is RM55.1 million, based on its 99% shareholding in Basis Bay Capital Management. This move is not expected to impact the Reit's operations.

site_title: Europe: Shares hold steady, Spanish stocks lag on election jitters
summary: European shares edged up 0.1% on Monday, near five-week highs, despite Spanish stocks falling 0.3% after the country's general election yielded no clear winner, raising recession fears. Energy and telecom shares countered losses, with energy shares adding 1.5% and Vodafone Group rallying 4.1%. The downturn in eurozone business activity deepened, with a survey showing demand in services industry declined and factory output fell at the fastest pace since Covid-19. Markets await the ECB's interest rate decision later this week, with investors pricing in a quarter percentage point increase to 3.75%.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 is up largely due to a rally in British shares following evidence of slowing domestic inflation.

site_title: TikTok rivals Twitter with new text format
summary: TikTok has announced a new text-only post feature, rivaling Twitter's Threads. The new format, similar to Instagram's, will allow users to add color backgrounds, music, and stickers. The feature aims to expand content creation on TikTok and tap into user creativity. With 1.4 billion monthly active users, TikTok's move is seen as a response to Twitter's struggles, which have lost roughly half of its advertising revenue. The feature will be integrated into the app, rather than launched as a separate product, marking a key difference from Meta's Threads.

images.alt_text: The Threads application on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Tuesday, July 11, 2023. Meta Platforms Inc.'s answer to Twitter Inc. has rocketed to 100 million users in less than a week, Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg announced on Monday. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
ByteDance’s TikTok plans to invest billions of dollars in South-east Asia over the next three to five years.

site_title: Private companies should get more involved in tackling the world’s water crisis
summary: The world is facing a severe water crisis, with two billion people relying on unsafe drinking water sources and 3.6 billion lacking basic sanitation. Private companies are urged to invest in water conservation, technology, and infrastructure to help address the issue. Governments, NGOs, and the private sector must work together to mitigate droughts, floods, and pollution. The UN estimates that water demand will exceed supply by 40% by 2030, highlighting the need for swift action. Private companies can provide funding, expertise, and innovative solutions to create new water sources, such as hydropanels, and improve water management.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - This picture taken on June 24, 2023, shows a boy walking through a drying river at  the marshes of Chibayish in Iraq's southern Dhi Qar province. (Photo by Asaad NIAZI / AFP)

site_title: What comes next as China’s tech crackdown winds down
summary: China's tech crackdown is winding down, with President Xi Jinping's government signaling a shift towards lifting restrictions on private technology companies, including Alibaba Group, Tencent Holdings, and Didi Global. A US$1 billion fine on Jack Ma-backed Ant Group in July marked a significant easing of regulations, followed by a manifesto calling for a revival of the private sector. However, analysts say the government will maintain oversight power, with a focus on social stability, data security, and cutting-edge technologies. The sector is expected to drive China's economy, but pre-crackdown heights are unlikely to be regained.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Hong Kong SAR’s Chief Executive John Lee on 24 July 2023.

The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) asks local lawyers to refrain from including negative descriptions of China’s policies or its business and legal environment in companies’ listing prospectuses.

site_title: US business activity growth slows as services soften
summary: US business activity slowed to a five-month low in July, with the services sector experiencing softening conditions, according to S&P Global's flash US Composite PMI index. The index fell to 52 in July from 53.2 in June, indicating restrained growth. Despite this, the slowdown may be viewed positively by the Federal Reserve, which is aiming to cool activity to lower inflation. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates by a quarter percentage point on Wednesday, potentially marking their last increase of the current cycle.

images.alt_text: “Incoming data now point to a more comfortable soft landing than we had anticipated, led by public investment in infrastructure and nonresidential structures investment,” Morgan Stanley economist says.

The Conference Board says its Leading Economic Index (LEI), a measure that anticipates future economic activity, declines by 0.7 per cent in June to 106.1 following a revised decrease of 0.6 per cent in May.
Existing home sales fall 3.3 per cent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.16 million units, the lowest level since January, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) says.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits drop 9,000 to a seasonally adjusted 228,000 for the week ended Jul 15, US Labor Department says.

site_title: Google owes US$338.7 million in Chromecast patent case, US jury says
summary: A US jury has ordered Google to pay $338.7 million in damages for violating a patent held by Touchstream Technologies, related to streaming videos from one screen to another. Google's Chromecast and other devices were found to infringe on Touchstream's patents, which were allegedly copied in 2013. Google has announced plans to appeal the verdict, stating it has "always developed technology independently and competed on the merits of our ideas."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Google, Microsoft and Alphabet logos and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Disney’s lawsuit is the latest and most high-profile challenge to Google’s policy of imposing a “service fee” of 11-26 per cent on in-app payments in India.
Google’s latest Supreme Court filing shows its deepening disagreement with how the CCI conducted its Android investigation.

Visitors cast their shadows past a Google logo at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France, June 15, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes

site_title: Shein being sued by H&M for copyright infringement in Hong Kong
summary: Hennes & Mauritz (H&M) is suing Shein for copyright infringement in Hong Kong, seeking unspecified damages and an injunction to stop Shein from infringing on its trademarks. The lawsuit, filed in 2021, claims Shein stole designs from H&M and is among dozens of items listed as evidence. This is a rare case of an established fast-fashion rival filing suit against Shein, which has faced numerous allegations of intellectual property infringement in the past three years.

images.alt_text: Clothes displayed at the Shein office in Singapore. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: South Korea’s economic growth ticks up in second quarter
summary: South Korea's economy experienced a 0.6% growth in the second quarter, exceeding market expectations, driven by a net export contribution of 1.3 percentage points. Exports fell 1.8% and imports dropped 4.2%, while private consumption, facility, and construction investments declined. Government spending also dropped 1.9%, the largest since 1997. Despite the growth, concerns remain about the strength of momentum, particularly in the key chip sector and China's demand. The Bank of Korea is expected to focus on growth rather than inflation, with interest rates remaining steady.

images.alt_text: The BOK said that recent weakness in China-bound exports was 35 per cent due to structural factors such as higher competitiveness of Chinese companies.

site_title: Sustainability-linked bonds still useful if flaws can be fixed
summary: Sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs) have seen a decline in issuance in South-east Asia and globally since their peak in 2021. Despite criticisms over the structure's flaws, including questionable targets and escape routes for borrowers, SLBs remain valuable for their ability to generate entity-level impact. The industry is working to address these concerns, and SLBs could stage a comeback if the financial industry can improve the structure.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of greenery in city state Singapore. For stories regarding ESG, sustainabilty, sustainabilty investing, and business environmental governance

Bankers pointed out that the downtrend comes amid an overall drop in bond and loan issuances, including non-ESG financing instruments, as global macroeconomic factors such as rising inflation and interest rate hikes have increased the costs of capital.
nature, earth, sustainability

site_title: Shein posts US lobbying tab as it stays in lawmakers’ crosshairs
summary: Shein, an online discount clothing retailer, spent $600,000 on lobbying in the US in the second quarter, its first filings showed. The move comes as lawmakers question the company's labor practices in China, including allegations of using forced labor. Shein has denied these claims and planned to go public in the US this year, but a bipartisan group of US representatives urged the Securities and Exchange Commission to halt the IPO until the company verifies its practices. Shein's lobbying outlay is moderate, and the company plans to continue engaging with policymakers to support the US economy and consumers.

images.alt_text: Shein only uses 10 per cent cotton but has found itself in the spotlight due to concerns about its sourcing practices.
China fast-fashion retailer Temu blasts rival Shein over ‘exclusionary tactics’

site_title: Stan Lee NFT collection sells out almost instantly, rises 500%
summary: Stan Lee's NFT collectibles sold out almost instantly, selling for $15 each, resulting in about $120,000 in revenue. The collectibles, part of a broader universe, rose 500% in value, with the cheapest listed at $81 and the most expensive at $749. This sale marks strong demand for virtual assets, despite the slow recovery of the NFT market, which has seen a 19% increase in value for CryptoPunks this year.

site_title: Spain’s messy election demonstrates Europe’s rightward shift
summary: Spain's recent election, held on July 23, has resulted in a rightward shift in the European Union. The conservative People's Party (PP) won the most seats but lacks an outright majority, necessitating a coalition government. This outcome is part of a broader conservative revival in EU nations, including Sweden, Finland, and Italy, with potential implications on policies such as immigration and green issues. The election marks a significant development in the EU's political landscape, contributing to a trend of rightward movement.

images.alt_text: At 2 pm Madrid time (8 pm Singapore time), turnout had reached almost 40.5 per cent, higher than the 37.9 per cent in the previous election in 2019, as Spaniards braved the summer heat to cast ballots.
Campaign signs for the leaders of Spain's right-wing People's Party and far-right party Vox.

site_title: ‘I’ve not been put up to split the votes’: presidential hopeful Ng Kok Song
summary: Singaporean presidential hopeful Ng Kok Song, 75, has announced his candidacy, emphasizing the need for a president to rise above politics and unify the country. He stresses that the president should be able to veto key public service appointments and intervene to uphold the integrity of institutions. Ng, a former GIC chief investment officer, believes that Singapore's political governance needs to find a new equilibrium and that he can provide a fresh perspective. He denies rumors that he was put up by the government to split the votes, stating that he is doing it for the good of the country. Ng's background includes a 45-year career in public service, with notable roles including founding chairman of the Singapore International Monetary Exchange and executive chairman of Avanda Investment Management.

images.alt_text: Ng Kok Song and his fiance Sybil Lau arrived at the Elections Department shortly past 10.30am on Wednesday to pick up an application form for the certificate of eligibility
Ng Kok Song retired from GIC in 2013 after 27 years with the sovereign wealth fund.

George Goh says he decided to run for president after the eligibility requirements for private sector candidates were raised in 2017, as he was “concerned that the more stringent requirements would lead to another uncontested election”.

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.

site_title: Tesla is lapping Germany’s automakers in the global EV race
summary: Tesla has surpassed Germany's automakers in the global electric vehicle (EV) market, delivering nearly 890,000 cars in the first half of this year. Volkswagen, BMW, Mercedes-Benz Group, and Porsche combined delivered fewer than 890,000 EVs during the same period. The German companies are struggling with software issues, waning sales in China, and a lack of competitive EV offerings. Despite plans to introduce new EV models and platforms, Tesla's lead in the market appears insurmountable, with analysts predicting that the company will continue to dominate the EV market in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Tesla has expressed an interest in building a factory in India that would produce low-cost electric vehicles (EVs) for the local market and for export.

site_title: Perfection through problem-solving, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Two Singapore-based funds managed by 65 Equity Partners are focusing on driving growth in companies, regardless of their former listing status. The funds, which are focused on Asia's growth markets, target companies with strong growth potential and are willing to invest in private companies or those that have gone private. This approach allows the funds to take a more hands-on approach in driving growth, without being limited by the constraints of a public listing. The funds' strategy is designed to deliver long-term growth for investors.

site_title: Meme stock AMC jumps as investors cheer stock conversion plan halt
summary: AMC Entertainment Holdings' shares surged on Monday after a US court blocked the company's stock conversion plan, which would have diluted investors' holdings. The plan, aimed at raising capital to pay down debt, was met with opposition from common stock holders. The company has filed a revised petition addressing concerns, and retail traders' interest in the stock is high, with a short squeeze expected to drive buying pressure. This move is seen as a win for theatre chains globally, following successful movie releases such as Barbie and Oppenheimer.

images.alt_text: AMC theatres could serve as a platform for the 12 to 15 movies Amazon plans to release in cinemas annually.

site_title: How banks can shore up defences against illicit financial flows
summary: Banks must strengthen their anti-money laundering (AML) and countering the financing of terrorism (CFT) defences to combat the increasing use of technology by criminals to launder illicit funds. Recent penalties in Singapore highlight the need for improved protocols, including verifying sources of wealth, unmasking real beneficiaries, and continuous customer profiling. Leveraging technology, such as artificial intelligence and data analytics, can enhance banks' ability to detect and respond to suspicious activities. Collaboration between banks, regulatory authorities, and law enforcement agencies is also crucial in detecting and preventing illicit financial flows.

images.alt_text: MAS said the breaches were identified during its examinations following news of irregularities in Wirecard’s financial statements, and the alleged involvement of Singapore-based individuals and entities in the matter.
MAS says it discovered inadequate controls when looking into the alleged involvement of Singapore-based individuals in the fraud case of Wirecard – a German payment company.

site_title: Singapore banks’ Q2 to be weighed down by higher costs, weaker loans: analysts
summary: Singapore banks' Q2 earnings are expected to be weighed down by higher costs and weaker loan growth, with loan volumes contracting further due to China's tepid recovery. Analysts predict a peak in earnings for the year, with DBS likely to be the least affected due to its low-cost liquidity base. Higher deposit caps and reduced loan appetites are also expected to impact banks' non-performing loan ratios. Despite these challenges, analysts maintain "hold" ratings on UOB and OCBC due to their high dividend yields and potential upside risks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Jamie Dimon, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of JPMorgan Chase & Co., gestures as he speaks during an interview with Reuters in Miami, Florida, U.S., February 8, 2023. REUTERS/Marco Bello/File Photo
Although the increase in the cap could lead to a “substantial rise” in GXS and MariBank’s deposit holdings, this still dwarfs in comparison to Singapore’s trio of local banks, Fitch Ratings said.

site_title: Tata Steel's Q1 profit slumps on spike in expenses, price drop
summary: Tata Steel reported a 92% slump in Q1 profit to 6.3 billion rupees due to lower alloy prices and increased expenses, including a non-cash deferred tax charge related to a British pension scheme. Total revenue fell 6.2% to 594.9 billion rupees. The company attributed volatility in steel markets to impacting working capital and cash flows. Despite domestic demand rising, subdued demand from China remains a drag on prices. The board reappointed CEO TV Narendran for five years.

images.alt_text: Tata Steel's quarterly profit jumped 47 per cent as demand for the alloy boomed, and the company announced a stock split amid a sharp run-up in its share price.
Tata had been choosing between a site in Somerset, southwest England, and one in Spain to supply a new range of electric Jaguar and Land Rover vehicles.

site_title: Oil prices up 2% to 3-month high on tight supply, China stimulus hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to a three-month high on Monday, driven by tightening supply, rising US petrol demand, and hopes for Chinese stimulus measures. Brent futures climbed to $82.89 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $79.03. The price increase comes despite market expectations of further interest rate hikes from the US and European central banks, which are expected to slow economic growth and reduce oil demand. Analysts expect the price increase to continue through the third quarter of 2023 due to Opec's supply cuts and speculation of further Chinese stimulus.

images.alt_text: Oil pumping jacks, also known as "nodding donkeys", operate in an oilfield near Dyurtyuli, the Republic of Bashkortostan, Russia, November 19, 2020.

site_title: US: Wall St rises ahead of megacap growth results, Fed decision
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Monday, driven by anticipation of megacap growth and technology company earnings, as well as a Federal Reserve rate decision later this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 3.10 points, or 0.01%, to 35,230.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, at 4,543.39 and 14,081.63, respectively. Investors are bracing for the Fed's decision, which may impact market sentiment and economic growth.

site_title: SoftBank forms joint venture to build AI-powered warehouses with Symbotic
summary: SoftBank is forming a joint venture, GreenBox Systems, with supply chain services provider Symbotic to build AI-powered warehouses. The venture, majority owned by SoftBank, will invest $100 million and purchase $7.5 billion worth of AI-powered systems from Symbotic. SoftBank will hold a 65% stake in GreenBox, with Symbotic owning the remaining 35%. The deal is part of SoftBank's shift to "offense mode" amid excitement over AI advancements, with CEO Masayoshi Son overseeing the investment.

images.alt_text: PayPay, which offers QR-code payment services, is used by more than 55 million people in Japan, making it a top player in a crowded digital-payments market.

site_title: Cambodian heir apparent hails poll victory, defying international criticism
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen's heir apparent, Hun Manet, hailed his party's predicted victory in the elections, defying international criticism that the polls were not free or fair. The ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP) is expected to win all but five parliamentary seats, with Hun Manet thanking voters for their support. The US condemned the polls, saying they were "neither free nor fair," and warned of visa restrictions and aid program halts. China praised Hun Sen's win, and Hun Manet's succession is seen as a continuation of Hun Sen's nearly 40-year rule, with little chance of substantial change.

images.alt_text: Hun Sen's Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) is expected to retain all 125 seats in the Lower House, prolonging his grip on power.
Hun Manet, son of Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Sen, is a candidate for the election, making his debut.

site_title: UBS agrees to pay US$388 million over Credit Suisse’s Archegos failings
summary: UBS has agreed to pay US$388 million to US and UK regulators over its dealings with Archegos Capital Management, following Credit Suisse's failure. The settlement includes US$268.5 million to the US Federal Reserve and £87 million (S$148.4 million) to the UK's Prudential Regulation Authority. This payment resolves several legal battles and comes after UBS' takeover of Credit Suisse last month.

site_title: Malaysia takes larger bite of thriving global semiconductor industry
summary: Malaysia is emerging as a key player in the global semiconductor industry, with Penang's strategic location and comprehensive ecosystem making it an attractive investment destination. The country aims to move up the semiconductor value chain from back-end assembly to front-end design, with initiatives such as developing additional industrial land and attracting skilled talent. As the industry grows, Malaysia can capitalize on its strengths to become a vital player, but it must also navigate geopolitical challenges and secure factory spaces, skilled talent, and participation in the value chain.

images.alt_text: Hua Hong will sell 407.75 million shares priced at 52 yuan per share, it said in a statement to the Shanghai stock exchange.
Qualcomm gets more than 60 per cent of its revenue from the China region, where it supplies components to smartphone makers such as Xiaomi.
Silicon Box's semiconductor manufacturing facility will be worth US$2 billion when it is fully fitted out.

site_title: Italian asset manager Azimut targeted by BlackCat hackers
summary: Italian asset manager Azimut was targeted by the BlackCat ransomware group on July 21, with DarkFeed listing it as one of the group's 477 victims. Azimut stated that the attack did not harm customers' sensitive data, and it received a ransom request which was rebuffed. The company detected unauthorized access to its IT systems and ran an internal safety procedure, successfully limiting the impact of the attack. Azimut manages $125.4 billion in assets, with just over half based in Italy.

images.alt_text: Ferrari Classiche cars in a garage at the Ferrari factory in Maranello, Italy; Ferraris are the most prized vintage autos, according to Adolfo Orsi, founder of the Classic Car Auction Yearbook, which has been tracking auction sales data since 1990, who described them as “absolutely the blue-chips of this sector”.

site_title: Warning signs were long there for Ukraine grain deal
summary: The Black Sea Grain Initiative, a UN-brokered deal between Russia and Ukraine, has collapsed, potentially disrupting global food supplies. The deal, which allowed 33 million tonnes of food to be exported from Ukraine, was extended multiple times but ultimately collapsed due to Russia's demands, including an end to sanctions on the Russian Agricultural Bank. The collapse may lead to an outbreak of famine in parts of Africa and Afghanistan, and highlights the need for countries to diversify their food supply and maintain stockpiles of essential commodities.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A photo shows the filling of the hold on the UN-chartered vessel MV Valsamitis while it is loaded to deliver 25,000 tonnes of Ukrainian wheat to Kenya and 5,000 tonnes to Ethiopia, at the port of Chornomorsk, east of Odessa on the Black Sea coast, on February 18, 2023, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The African Union expressed "regret" on July 18, 2023 over Russia's decision to suspend a deal allowing safe passage for grain cargo ships from Ukrainian Black Sea ports. (Photo by OLEKSANDR GIMANOV / AFP)

site_title: Keppel DC Reit H1 2023 DPU inches up 0.04% to S$0.05051
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 0.04% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.05051 for the first half of 2023, driven by acquisitions of data centres in Guangdong, China, and tax savings. However, distributable income rose only 0.2% due to higher financing costs and lower government incentives. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 98.5% and its aggregate leverage was 36.3%. Despite macroeconomic headwinds, the manager remains cautiously optimistic about growth opportunities and plans to continue growing the portfolio through acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit was the best performing S-Reit in the first half of 2023, driven by stronger growth in distributable income and distribution per unit.
DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.

0620 Yy / Media Release: Keppel DC REIT strengthens portfolio with two data centres in Guangdong, China
/ 20 June 2022, Singapore – Keppel DC REIT has entered into agreements with Guangdong Bluesea Data Development Co. Ltd. (Bluesea) and its parent company, Guangdong Bluesea Mobile Development Co. Ltd., to acquire two data centre facilities, on a fully-fitted basis, in Jiangmen, Guangdong Province, for RMB 1,380.6 million (approximately S$297.1 million).

site_title: PSG say Saudi's Al Hilal can talk to Mbappe after 300-million-euro bid: source
summary: PSG has given permission to Saudi club Al Hilal to speak with Kylian Mbappe, who has a 300-million-euro bid on the table. The 24-year-old forward has one year left on his contract with PSG and is refusing to sign a new deal, leading the French club to believe he has already agreed to join Real Madrid next year for free. Mbappe's agent has not commented on the matter, but the bid from Al Hilal, one of the handful of clubs owned by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, is a world record offer.

images.alt_text: Cristiano Ronaldo (left) scored 14 goals in 16 matches for Saudi Arabia club Al-Nassr last season.
Bayern Munich's new signing Kim Min-jae takes a selfie with fans after a training session in Germany. The South Korean defender could be in Singapore to face Liverpool on Aug 2.
Lion City Sailors are the latest addition to the Singapore Festival of Football.
Gary Lineker was taken off air in March after criticising the government’s immigration policy on Twitter, but he was reinstated after a public backlash and a staff near-mutiny.

site_title: Connecting China with the world a top priority for HKEX, says CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) CEO Nicolas Aguzin stated that connecting China with the world is a top priority for the company. HKEX aims to help Chinese investors tap into international investment opportunities and vice versa. The Chinese onshore market has seen significant activity, with over $1 trillion in daily turnover, despite global market downturns. This is part of a broader effort to strengthen economic ties between Hong Kong and Singapore, as highlighted by a meeting between Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee.

images.alt_text: Fans queueing for Taylor Swift concert tickets. Even before tickets went on sale, prices for hotels and flights to Singapore were already soaring for Swift's tour dates.
The border reopening with China has given Hong Kong's financial industry a huge boost, with mainland customers flocking back to open bank accounts, invest money and take out insurance policies.

site_title: Spotify raises prices for its premium plans across several countries
summary: Spotify has raised prices for its premium plans across several countries, including the US and UK, with a $1 price increase for US plans. The premium single now starts at $10.99, duo at $14.99, family at $16.99, and student plan at $5.99. The move aims to boost profitability in an uncertain economy, following hundreds of layoffs and a restructuring of the podcast unit. This price increase joins those of rival streaming services, including Apple, Amazon, and YouTube, as investors pressure companies to boost profitability.

images.alt_text: Dubbed “Supremium” internally, according to people familiar with the strategy, the new tier will be Spotify’s most expensive plan and likely offer a HiFi feature the company first announced it was working on in 2021.
A man checks his smartphone with the Spotify Technology logo behind him in an arranged photograph in London. MUST CREDIT: Bloomberg photo by Chris Ratcliffe.

site_title: India markets regulator to consider permitting delisting via fixed price
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) plans to consider permitting the delisting of companies via fixed price, replacing the reverse book-building procedure to prevent potential manipulation. Sebi will issue a discussion paper on the subject by December. The regulator will not suspend trading in the shares of a company during the delisting process. Additionally, Sebi aims to strengthen rules for corporate disclosures related to insider trading regulations and work on a mechanism for instant settlement of trades.

images.alt_text: The Securities and Exchange Board of India, in a consultation paper, said that institutes such as cooperatives, housing finance companies, non-bank financial companies, refinancing agencies, pension funds, re-insurers, small finance banks and universities should be included as qualified buyers.

site_title: Tesla to discuss factory plan for new 2 million rupee car with India commerce minister: source
summary: Tesla representatives are set to meet India's commerce minister to discuss plans for a factory producing a low-cost electric vehicle priced at $24,000 (2 million rupees), 25% cheaper than its current Model 3 sedan. The meeting comes after Elon Musk met India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi in June and expressed interest in making a significant investment in the country. The proposed factory would produce vehicles for the local market and for export, with discussions focusing on setting up an EV supply chain and land allotment for the factory.

images.alt_text: While 84-month car loans have been gaining in popularity, the trend slowed early this year, according to credit-reporting company Experian
The launch comes a week after Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim held a virtual meeting with Tesla founder Elon Musk on investments involving the EV giant and SpaceX’s satellite Internet service.
