Tesla wants to double capacity to 1 million cars per year and 100 gigawatt hours of battery production at a plant that would make even more cars than produced by Volkswagen at its Wolfsburg headquarters

site_title: Domino's Pizza misses revenue estimates as higher prices squeeze demand
summary: Domino's Pizza missed Wall Street estimates for second-quarter revenue due to higher delivery fees and prices, hurting demand for its pizzas and chicken wings. The company's US same-store sales rose only 0.1%, below analyst expectations. To boost its delivery business, Domino's partnered with Uber, allowing customers to place orders on Uber Eats and Postmates. Despite the revenue miss, the company reported a profit of $3.08 per share, above estimates. Shares dropped 4% in pre-market trading.

images.alt_text: Domino's Pizza China franchisee Dash mulls Hong Kong IPO

site_title: Apple aims to keep iPhone shipments steady despite 2023 turmoil
summary: Apple aims to maintain steady iPhone shipments of around 85 million units in 2023, despite a projected decline in the global smartphone market and turmoil in the global economy. This is roughly in line with last year's shipments. The company is expected to increase revenue overall due to price hikes for Pro models. Apple's production schedule is closely monitored by its suppliers, including Samsung and Foxconn, and the company's fortunes have a significant impact on the global economy.

images.alt_text: An Indian subsidiary of Foxconn acquires equipment from Apple Operations for operational needs, according to a filing from Foxconn’s Taipei-listed flagship unit Hon Hai Precision Industry.
Wechat users can buy Apple products including iPhones, iPads and Macs from its store.

site_title: Vietnam approves commercial use of first African swine fever vaccines
summary: Vietnam has approved the domestic commercial use of two African swine fever vaccines, making them the world's first commercial vaccines against the deadly disease. The vaccines, developed by Navetco Central Veterinary Medicine and AVAC Vietnam JSC, have shown a 95% efficacy rate in testing on hog herds in 40 provinces. The Ministry of Agriculture has instructed the companies to work out production plans for domestic sales and exports, potentially paving the way for sales abroad to tackle the disease that has disrupted the global pork market.

images.alt_text: African swine fever has plagued China for years, with an initial wave during 2018 and 2019 killing millions of pigs and leading to a dramatic decline in meat output that roiled global markets.

site_title: India's Vedanta CFO confident of meeting debt maturities in FY24
summary: Vedanta's CFO, Sonal Shrivastava, is confident that the company will meet its US$2.7 billion debt maturities in FY24, citing the generation of healthy cash flow from "high-quality" assets. The company aims to reduce debt and has entered the market for chip and display manufacturing. Vedanta reported a 41% slump in Q1 profit due to weak commodity prices and a 13% fall in quarterly revenue. The company is committed to prudent capital raising and awaiting government approval for incentives under a modified semiconductor production plan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the logo of Vedanta outside its headquarters in Mumbai, India January 31, 2018. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Taiwan's Foxconn to take 50% stake in ZF axle system unit
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn is acquiring a 50% stake in ZF Group's axle system assembly unit, creating a joint venture aimed at growing automotive and supply chain opportunities. The deal values ZF Chassis Modules at 1 billion euros (S$1.5 billion) and allows Foxconn to expand its product offerings in the internal combustion engine and electric vehicle space. ZF aims to use the proceeds to reduce debts, while Foxconn seeks to capitalize on fresh capital and growth opportunities. The joint venture agreement is expected to become effective within six to nine months pending regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: An Indian subsidiary of Foxconn acquires equipment from Apple Operations for operational needs, according to a filing from Foxconn’s Taipei-listed flagship unit Hon Hai Precision Industry.
Foxconn says revenue in the April-June period reaches NT$1.3 trillion (S$56.4 billion), in line with its expectations.
Workers assembling an truck at Foxconn's production facility in Lordstown, Ohio, US; has big ambitions in the EV market as it seeks to diversify its revenue base.
The move to seek Chapter 11 protection from creditors follows a protracted dispute with Foxconn over a deal to make pickup trucks for Lordstown at an assembly plant in Ohio.

site_title: Germany readies 20 billion euros in aid to bolster chip production
summary: Germany is set to provide 20 billion euros in aid to bolster chip production, with at least 3 billion euros available for additional projects, by 2027. The money will be drawn from the Climate and Transformation Fund and will support German and international companies, including Intel, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, and Infineon Technologies. The move aims to reduce dependence on Asian supplies and secure critical components amid geopolitical tensions. The subsidy package is part of Germany's efforts to diversify its tech sector and attract future technologies.

images.alt_text: Infineon, which recently broke ground for a fourth fab in the city, has employees from more than 50 countries in Saxony.

A classic Citroen 2CV automobile parked outside residential apartment blocks on the Carl Legien modernist housing estate, operated by Deutsche Wohnen SE, in Berlin, Germany, on Monday, Aug. 2, 2021. Germany's average GDP growth is expected to fall back below 1 per cent due to accelerating headwinds from population aging and a lack of significant increases in productivity.
Most analysts agree the gloomy trend is set to continue in the coming months, with leading economic institutes now expecting the German economy to shrink by 0.2 to 0.4 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Red Bull challenges EU antitrust raid, says allegations unfounded
summary: Red Bull has contested EU antitrust raids, claiming allegations of anti-competitive behavior are "manifestly unfounded". The company wants Europe's second-highest court to annul the commission's decision ordering the raids and return documents taken from its premises. The European Commission had alleged Red Bull may have violated EU antitrust rules against cartels and abuse of a dominant position. Red Bull criticized the EU watchdog's raids for an unlimited period, saying it "interferes excessively with the applicant's rights". The company's appeal aims to nullify the commission's decision.

images.alt_text: MONTREAL, QUEBEC - JUNE 18: Red Bull drink cans are pictured during the F1 Grand Prix of Canada at Circuit Gilles Villeneuve on June 18, 2023 in Montreal, Quebec.   Jared C. Tilton/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Jared C. Tilton / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Primary 6 pupil overcomes fear of maths with support from volunteers and initiatives
summary: A 12-year-old Primary 6 pupil, Darshika Ganesh, has overcome her fear of math with the help of volunteers and initiatives. She scored 70 out of 100 in her school's practice exam after attending regular tuition sessions under the Ministry of Social and Family Development's Community Link initiative. Darshika also benefited from the UOL-PPHG Community Uplift Programme, which provides experiential rewards and learning opportunities for underprivileged children. The programme aims to encourage children to stay in school and improve their grades, and has seen positive results, including increased motivation and confidence among its participants.

site_title: Toyota's China venture dismisses some factory workers as sales fall
summary: Toyota's China joint venture, GAC Toyota, has laid off some workers over the weekend as sales slump in the country's largest auto market. The workers, hired by labour service companies, were offered compensation. The move comes after peer Mitsubishi cut staff costs at its Chinese joint venture. Toyota's sales in China fell 9% in the first six months, and the company is trying to revive sales with its electric vehicle models. The GAC Toyota factory, which produces 1 million vehicles annually, employs 19,000 people.

images.alt_text: Toyota has teamed up with Japan’s space agency since 2019 to develop the manned lunar rover – which it dubbed the Lunar Cruiser – that they hope can be put on the Moon in 2029.
Toyota topped overall passenger car registration figures for Singapore with 2,867 units in the first six months of 2023.

The administration’s proposal “underestimates key challenges, including the scarcity of minerals to make batteries, the fact that these minerals are not mined or refined in the US, the inadequate infrastructure and the high cost of battery-electric vehicles,” Toyota says.
Toyota says US sales in June come to 195,448 vehicles, up 15 per cent from a year ago.

site_title: Meta's Threads could lure ads from Twitter but it's early days, analysts say
summary: Meta's Threads, a social media platform launched on July 5, has become the fastest-growing platform to reach 100 million users, posing a threat to Twitter's dominance. Analysts forecast Threads could lure ads away from Twitter, with potential annual ad revenue reaching $5 billion. Meta's experience with Instagram and Facebook is seen as a factor in Threads' success, and some brands are already considering allocating budgets for Threads ads. However, Threads still has a long way to go to match Twitter's reach, and Meta has stated it won't monetize the platform until it reaches 1 billion users.

images.alt_text: Meta has left the door open for a Threads launch in Europe and few expect it to maintain its embargo indefinitely.

site_title: Beijing pushes for toning down of China risks in IPO prospectuses: sources
summary: The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has asked local lawyers to refrain from including negative descriptions of China's policies or business environment in companies' offshore listing prospectuses. This move, aimed at toning down China risks, comes as Beijing tightens scrutiny of Chinese companies' offshore listings and steps up controls over cross-border information transfers. Failure to comply could result in regulatory green light being denied for IPOs, potentially forcing Chinese companies to delay or put on hold their US listings.

images.alt_text: Key Chinese indexes are down for the year, losing out on a rally seen across Japan, India and the US.
Sponsors would be assessed by the “quality” of listed firms they assisted, according to a statement jointly issued by the Shanghai stock exchange and Shenzhen stock exchange.

Previous Chinese law requires company insiders such as board directors to return profits earned from short-term share trades to the company. The new rules would help clarify when those requirements apply.

site_title: UK homebuilders under pressure as lofty mortgages deter first-time buyers
summary: UK homebuilders are under pressure as high mortgage rates deter first-time buyers. Top builders Barratt, Berkeley, and others have reduced plans and offered incentives, such as discounts and mortgage-free deals, to boost demand. Despite potential government support, experts say purchasing power remains depressed due to elevated mortgage rates. The Bank of England's rate hikes aim to combat inflation, leaving the housing sector uncertain about its recovery path.

images.alt_text: Advertising hoardings outside a new housing development by St. Modwen in Uxbridge in London, UK, on Monday, July 17, 2023. The looming by-election for Uxbridge and South Ruislip in northwest London on July 20 will loom large in UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s thinking. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Peer-to-peer crypto exchanges lose ground in shrunken market
summary: Peer-to-peer crypto exchanges have lost ground in the market, with their market share dropping to 5% from a peak of 7% in March. Despite efforts to improve services, monthly spot trading volumes on decentralised exchanges slid 76% to $21 billion in June, compared to a 69% drop for centralised exchanges. Decentralised platforms appeal to crypto enthusiasts but face challenges such as complex interfaces and lower liquidity. Institutional investors are also hesitant to trade on peer-to-peer exchanges, but improvements in design and increasing user base may help.

images.alt_text: In December, Bankman-Fried said he and Ellison had been in a relationship but gave no further details.

When available, spot Bitcoin ETFs will become a fixture in many portfolios, and deservedly or not, the conversation will be less about whether Bitcoin is a fraud and more about its merit relative to traditional investments such as stocks and bonds.

site_title: Nico Steel to delist on Aug 7
summary: Nico Steel will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on August 7, following an extraordinary general meeting in June where shareholders approved the delisting without an exit offer. The company posted a loss of $149 million for the six months ended February 28, 2023, due to market disruption and supply chain issues. Nico Steel had received questions from the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) about its delisting plans, but the company stated that a sale of its key operating asset, the Loyang property, would significantly affect its operations.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo is issuing the Guide on Independent Financial Advisers as a starting point to improve the standards, clarity and consistency of advice that IFAs render in their opinions

site_title: Bank of Japan mulls sharp increase in 2023 inflation outlook
summary: The Bank of Japan is likely to raise its consumer inflation projection to 2.5% for the year ending in March, up from 1.8%, according to officials familiar with the matter. This would be the first time the BOJ upgrades its economic assessment since last year, potentially characterizing the economy as in recovery. The BOJ's policy board will also discuss concerns about sustaining the upward inflation trajectory. The decision will be released on July 28.

site_title: Euro drops after weak business activity data, central banks in focus
summary: The euro dropped 0.4% to US$1.1083 after weak business activity data in the eurozone, exceeding expectations. Investors await central bank meetings, expecting rate hikes in Europe and the US. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank are set to meet this week, with traders predicting 25 basis point rate hikes. Softening inflation gauges may allow the Fed to hint at a pause. The yen strengthened against the dollar, while the Swiss franc remained steady.

site_title: UK's M&C Saatchi's CEO to step down
summary: M&C Saatchi's CEO Moray MacLennan, 61, will step down at the end of September, amid weak revenue and competition from new technology tools. MacLennan, who has been with the company since 1995, led the group through various challenges, including accounting probes and takeover talks. A new CEO is expected to be named within the next 12 months, with Zillah Byng-Thorne acting as executive chair from September 1.

images.alt_text: FCA research shows that estimated crypto ownership has more than doubled from 2021 to 2022, with 10 per cent of 2,000 people surveyed stating they own crypto assets.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation eases to 2.4% in June; core inflation moderates to 3.1%
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate moderated to 2.4% in June, down from 2.8% in May, as prices of food and hospitality increased at a slower pace. Core inflation, excluding volatile items, grew 3.1% year-over-year, also slower than the previous month. Economists expect inflationary pressures to ease, with Bank Negara Malaysia likely to pause interest rate hikes in the second half of 2023. The easing inflation rate is seen as a positive sign, allowing the central bank to remain on a prolonged pause through 2023 and into 2024.

images.alt_text: The improved factory output of domestic-oriented industries contributed to the growth of Malaysia's  industrial production index in May.
Malaysia's inflation continued to ease further in May, as food and transport prices rising at a slower pace

site_title: Eurozone economic downturn steepens in July
summary: The Eurozone experienced its fastest economic contraction in eight months in July, with manufacturing output declining at an accelerated pace, according to the HCOB Flash Eurozone PMI survey. The index fell to 48.9 from 49.9 in June, indicating a contraction. The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates this week to tame inflation, further exacerbating the economic downturn.

images.alt_text: The downturn was broad-based, with surveys published on Monday (Jul 3) showing that factory activity in all four of the eurozone’s biggest economies contracted last month.

site_title: Six bubble tea chains plan IPOs in bet on China consumer revival
summary: At least six Chinese bubble tea chains are planning initial public offerings (IPOs) in Hong Kong and the US, as regulators discourage certain types of companies from listing in China's domestic market. The companies, which include Mixue Bingcheng and XSQ Tea, are seeking to raise less than $500 million each and are likely to get less regulatory scrutiny overseas. The move is seen as a bet on a wave of fresh Chinese consumer spending following the lifting of Covid restrictions, although evidence of a rebound has been lacking.

images.alt_text: Biren’s fundraising efforts come as the Chinese government accelerates its campaign to develop its domestic semiconductor industry, after a US-led effort that blocked Chinese companies’ ability to buy advanced chips

The bubble tea market in China, estimated to have an annual turnover of US$20 billion, has already seen some of its popular Chinese brands like Mixue, Chagee and Heytea segue into Southeast Asia, joining earlier counterparts like Gong Cha and Koi.

site_title: Philippines' Marcos says inflation 'moving in right direction'
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. said the country's inflation rate is moving in the right direction, with prices of critical commodities stabilizing. After a year in office, Marcos cited successes in battling inflation and steering the economy back on track. He aims to increase local food production, particularly through timely and calibrated imports, and developing the long-neglected farm sector, which contributes 10% to the country's economic output.

images.alt_text: Central bank policymakers around the world have recently spotlighted climate change and energy transition amid volatile energy prices and more frequent extreme weather events. T
The write-off will benefit more than 610,000 land reform beneficiaries but will cost the government US$1.04 billion, Marcos said.
Last month’s inflation rate, which was below the 5.5 per cent forecast in a Reuters poll, brought the year-to-date average to 7.2 per cent.

site_title: ‘Oppenheimer’ sparks online outrage in India due to Hindu scripture scene
summary: A scene in the movie "Oppenheimer" featuring a Hindu scripture has sparked online outrage in India, with many users calling for a boycott due to a perceived "scathing attack on Hinduism." The scene depicts the protagonist reciting a verse from the Bhagwad Gita before sexual intercourse. The nationalist group "Save Culture Save India Foundation" has condemned the movie, while the film's producers have not responded to comments. The movie has grossed around $9.8 million in India despite receiving a U/A rating from the Central Board of Film Certification.

images.alt_text: Enter Barbie and Oppenheimer, two polar opposite movies that debuted simultaneously in a matchup dubbed “Barbenheimer”.

site_title: Norway government ministries hit by cyberattack
summary: Norway's government ministries have been hit by a cyberattack, with the attack identified on July 12 due to "unusual" traffic on a supplier's platform. The attack was uncovered before causing significant damage, and the platform's weakness has been shut down. The prime minister's office and other ministries were not affected as they use a different IT platform. This is the latest cyberattack to hit Norway's state sector, following a similar incident in June 2022. The extent of the impact and the identity of the perpetrators are still unknown.

images.alt_text: The EU Cyber Emergency Mechanism will test entities in highly critical sectors such as healthcare, transport and energy for potential vulnerabilities.

site_title: A better outlook for social bonds
summary: Social bond issuance slumped in 2022, falling 41% from 2021, but the market remains young and investors are keen to allocate capital to credible impact investments. Government-related issuers dominate the market, accounting for 77% of outstanding social bonds, while corporate issuers are entering the market. Despite challenges in standardizing metrics, the market is expected to grow as investors seek to demonstrate the social impact of their investments. Regulatory efforts to address "social washing" are underway, and the market is expected to rebound in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of greenery in city state Singapore. For stories regarding ESG, sustainabilty, sustainabilty investing, and business environmental governance
The sustainability-linked bond targets entity-level change, and could therefore be a key decarbonisation tool if the financial industry can address criticisms about the structure.

site_title: Bird has flown as Musk, Twitter CEO Yaccarino say 'X' logo is here
summary: Twitter has unveiled a new logo featuring a white "X" on a black background, replacing the blue bird symbol. The logo change was announced by CEO Linda Yaccarino and Elon Musk, who polled his followers on the idea. The new logo is visible on Twitter's handles, but the blue bird remains on the platform. The change comes as Twitter attempts to reverse a decline in advertising revenue. The "interim X logo" was first posted by Musk on Sunday.

site_title: Vodafone reports better revenue growth, names new CFO
summary: Vodafone reported a 3.7% revenue growth in its first quarter, driven by strong demand in Britain and improvements in Germany, Italy, and Spain. The company's new CFO, Luka Mucic, began on September 1, replacing Margherita Della Valle, who took over permanently in April. Despite a decline in Germany, growth in Britain accelerated to 5.7% due to strong consumer growth and price increases. The company aims to simplify its operations and stem declines in European markets hit by fierce competition.

images.alt_text: Vodafone will own 51 per cent and Hutchison 49 per cent of the combined group, which will be led by current Vodafone UK boss Ahmed Essam, the companies say.

site_title: ClientEarth loses bid to revive UK lawsuit against Shell over climate strategy
summary: ClientEarth's bid to revive a lawsuit against Shell over its climate strategy was rejected by London's High Court. The charity, which holds 27 shares in Shell, alleged the company's current strategy would not achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, and its directors were therefore breaching their duties. The court ruled that the case "ignores competing considerations" and should not be interfered with. Shell's directors are said to have acted in the company's best interest, but ClientEarth plans to pursue an appeal.

images.alt_text: The gas will be transported from Spanish ports initially, using a gas pipeline that links the two countries, until Morocco builds its own LNG terminals, the ministry said.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's headline and core inflation eased further in June, with prices of non-cooked food and prepared meals rising at a slower pace, reaching 5.9% and 4.5% respectively. Ultra-luxury car registrations slowed down in June due to tax hikes. The Far East Shopping Centre is up for collective sale with a guide price of S$928 million. Higher deposit caps for digital lenders are unlikely to disrupt local banks. Executive condos in suburbs were among the top profit gainers in Q2.

site_title: British Airways parent IAG buys stake in UK maker of fuel from ethanol
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, is investing in Nova Pangaea Technologies, a UK firm that will produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from ethanol by 2025. The deal aims to help British Airways meet its goal of using 10% sustainable fuel by 2030. The company plans to use agricultural waste and wood residue as feedstock, with partner LanzaJet converting the bioethanol into sustainable fuel. IAG will become a minority shareholder in Nova Pangaea, but financial terms were not disclosed. This investment supports British Airways' decarbonisation efforts.

site_title: Executive condo sellers in suburbs among top profit gainers in Q2
summary: Executive condominium sellers in suburban areas achieved the highest percentage gains, with four EC sellers pocketing profits of 86% to 93% after holding their units for an average of 6.5 years. In contrast, the top five loss-making deals in the second quarter were all in prime areas, with losses ranging from S$300,000 to S$1.83 million.

images.alt_text: The Jalan Tembusu site, for private housing development, is near the future Tanjong Katong MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.
Developers sold less private homes in June 2023.
As state land tender for three 99-year leasehold sites closed on Tuesday (Jun 27), one developer, Kingsford Group, stood out with its bids.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip as China indices weigh; STI ends 0.4% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.4% lower on Monday, following China's key indices into the red. The decline was attributed to persistent challenges in China's fiscal conditions, including falling land sales revenue and local government financing issues. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC are expected to report weaker quarterly performance, contributing to the STI's decline. However, Aztech Global's share price surged 12.1% after announcing a record quarterly profit, with its trading value reaching S$765.4 million.

site_title: Byju’s, creditors aim to amend US$1.2 billion loan terms
summary: Byju's, India's once-valued startup, is working with creditors to amend the terms of a $1.2 billion loan after facing financial distress. The company, which topped 100 million users on its flagship app, has struggled with declining demand for online tutoring and increased spending on marketing. Its auditors quit, and the government ordered an inspection of its finances. A steering committee of creditors and Byju's agreed to work towards a signed agreement by August 3, which would be a positive development for the company. The talks are ongoing and the situation may change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Byju's logo is seen in this illustration taken, June 22, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: JPMorgan sees 35% downside for China’s top builder as woes mount
summary: JPMorgan downgraded Country Garden Holdings, China's top builder, to underweight due to liquidity concerns and a weakening sales outlook. The bank expects shares to drop 35% as default risks and refinancing support from authorities are unlikely to ease. Analysts warn that government measures won't stem the decline, and the sector's woes are unlikely to subside until more government support is confirmed.

images.alt_text: The property firm’s move last week to refinance part of a 2019 loan facility failed to assure investors of its ability to repay debt due in the coming months.

site_title: India blocks US$1 billion bid by China’s BYD to set up EV factory
summary: India has rejected a US$1 billion proposal by Chinese carmaker BYD to build an electric vehicle (EV) factory in partnership with a local company, citing national security concerns over the use of Chinese technology. The decision follows restrictions on Chinese investment in India amid strained relations between the two nations. BYD had aimed to capture 40% of India's domestic EV market by 2030, but the rejection deals a blow to its ambitious plans.

images.alt_text: Thailand has attracted a wave of investments by Chinese EV carmakers in local manufacturing.
Singapore electric scooter company Scorpio says it is in collaboration with Shenzhen BYD Electronics to produce pre-production prototypes of the X1.

“The sales volume of the company’s new energy vehicles has achieved strong growth from a high base in the same period last year, and continued to consolidate its leadership in new energy vehicle industry,” BYD says
BYD's Denza N7 electric sport utility vehicle at its launch in Beijing this month. The company's push into India is part of its rapid global expansion to challenge Tesla.

site_title: Julius Baer profit jumps as new money flows from Credit Suisse
summary: Julius Baer's profit surged 18% to 532 million Swiss francs in the first half of 2023, driven by 7.1 billion francs in new client funds amid the Credit Suisse crisis. The bank's CEO Philipp Rickenbacher has led efforts to recover from a difficult period, including an investigation and impairments. Julius Baer is poised to benefit from Credit Suisse's demise, with plans to expand into alternative assets and digital wealth management services, including crypto offerings.

site_title: Philips lifts outlook after profit beat, voices concern over China
summary: Philips, a Dutch health technology company, has lifted its full-year targets after beating quarterly earnings expectations. The company reported adjusted earnings of €453 million for the April to June period. However, Philips expressed concern over China's drive to become self-sufficient in health-related technologies, citing uncertainty in global market conditions. Despite this, the company's modest increase in targets suggests a cautious optimism about its future prospects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Dutch technology company Philips. logo is seen at company headquarters in Amsterdam, Netherlands, January 29, 2019. REUTERS/Eva Plevier/File Photo

site_title: OCBC’s Mike Ng to take on new group chief sustainability officer role
summary: OCBC has appointed Mike Ng, head of sustainability office for global wholesale banking, as its new chief sustainability officer, effective August 1. Ng, who has been with the bank since 2010, has advised corporate clients on net-zero transition and helped the bank finance renewable energy projects worldwide. The new role is a response to OCBC's established board sustainability committee, requiring strong business acumen and expertise in sustainability, climate change, and financial products. CEO Helen Wong praised Ng's experience and innovative approach to sustainable finance.

images.alt_text: OCBC is in a good position to capture wealth and trade flows given its strong links between the greater China and Asean regions, said CEO Helen Wong.

OCBC's chief executive officer Helen Wong (middle), head of global whole banking Tan Teck Long (left) and head of global wholesale banking sustainability office Mike Ng (right) announcing the bank's decarbonisation targets on May 16, 2023.

The uptake of loans that link borrowing costs to agreed sustainability targets shows that companies are growing more aware of the financial benefits of improving their sustainability practices over time, says Sustainable Fitch.  PHOTO:

site_title: China seeks private investors for 3.2 trillion yuan of projects
summary: China is seeking private investment in over 2,900 projects worth 3.2 trillion yuan, aiming to boost its faltering economy. The National Development and Reform Commission has compiled a list of projects in sectors such as transportation, clean energy, and advanced manufacturing, which will be supported by improved funding and infrastructure real estate investment trust (Reit) products. While the move is seen as a positive sign, economists expect effects to be felt next year and beyond, as business confidence takes time to recover.

images.alt_text: The rare meeting with global funds comes after Chinese President Xi Jinping’s administration voiced its strongest support in recent years for the country’s private tech enterprises just days earlier.

site_title: UK private-sector output grows at slowest pace in six months
summary: The UK private sector experienced its slowest growth in six months, with new orders stalled and inflationary pressures easing. The S&P Global Market Intelligence index fell to 50.7 in July, down from 52.8 in the previous month. Manufacturing also hit its lowest in 38 months, with respondents citing caution among clients. The slowdown suggests a potential economic slowdown later this year, following the Bank of England's interest rate increases to cool inflation.

images.alt_text: London remained the only part of the country without a bump in pay.

site_title: Ryanair quarterly profit soars, cautious about winter travel
summary: Ryanair reported a 663 million euro after-tax profit for the three months ending in June, surpassing pre-pandemic levels. The airline cited a 11% year-on-year increase in traffic and a 42% jump in average fares. However, it cut its passenger growth forecast due to Boeing delivery delays, now expecting 9% growth in the year to March 2024, down from 185 million passengers. Ryanair remains cautiously optimistic about full-year profit, with CEO Michael O'Leary warning of potential macroeconomic trends affecting consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Ryanair says it urged the government in February to cut UK visa costs.

site_title: Ultra-luxury car registrations slow down in June after tax hike
summary: Singapore registrations of ultra-luxury cars, such as Ferrari and Rolls-Royce, plummeted in June due to tax increases. The Additional Registration Fee (ARF) tax hike, announced in February, led buyers to rush and purchase cars before the tax increase took effect. Industry watchers expect sales for the rest of the year to slow down, as the initial surge in registrations was "front-loaded."

images.alt_text: Flowing lines make the electric Rolls a graceful, almost waifish thing.
Müller-Ötvös is adamant that you can put a blindfolded person into the Spectre and he would immediately be able to tell that he was in a Rolls-Royce, from the way it smells and feels.

site_title: OpenAI’s Sam Altman launches Worldcoin crypto project
summary: OpenAI's Sam Altman has launched Worldcoin, a cryptocurrency project that aims to address the economic implications of generative AI. The project, which has 2 million beta users, uses an in-person iris scan to verify users as real humans and issue a unique World ID. This ID can help combat income inequality and reduce fraud in social programs like universal basic income. Worldcoin's cryptocurrency token WLD saw a significant price increase in early trading, and the project plans to scale up operations to 35 cities in 20 countries.

images.alt_text: OpenAI, whose AI chatbot ChatGPT, has stormed the world, has said it depends on its trust and safety team to build “the processes and capabilities to prevent misuse and abuse of AI technologies”.
The arrangement involves OpenAI licensing part of AP’s text archive, while AP will leverage the ChatGPT-maker’s technology.
UK finance ministry “firmly disagrees” with the recommendation to regulate retail trading and investment activity in unbacked cryptoassets as gambling rather than as a financial service.
The SEC formally acknowledges applications from Bitwise, VanEck, WisdomTree, Fidelity and Invesco for similar spot bitcoin ETFs.
Many crypto fans argue that an approval would not only make it easier to invest in Bitcoin, but would also showcase the crypto industry’s move into the mainstream

site_title: Wall Street AI optimism gives Taiwan tech rally another boost
summary: Taiwan's technology stocks continue to rally as hardware firms are expected to benefit from booming demand for artificial intelligence (AI) servers. Analysts say companies like Wistron, Quanta Computer, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co will see a positive earnings trend due to the rise in AI server adoption by hyper-scalers like Google. The tech sector has been overlooked by investors until now, but recent upgrades by banks and increasing bullishness on these stocks due to the AI arms race are driving the rally. Some analysts caution that gains may be sentiment-driven and dependent on the strength of each company's AI story.

images.alt_text: TSMC is viewed as among the earliest beneficiaries of efforts from the US to China to develop AI platforms.

site_title: Roche signs US$2.8 billion Anylam deal for hypertension drug
summary: Roche Holding has signed a US$2.8 billion deal with Alnylam Pharmaceuticals to develop a potential treatment for hypertension, with Roche paying US$310 million upfront. The deal includes development, regulatory, and sales milestones, and Roche will sell the drug in the US while holding exclusive rights worldwide. This partnership aims to expand Roche's presence beyond cancer therapies, following high-profile failures in its pipeline last year. The experimental RNAi-based treatment, zilebesiran, is currently in mid-stage human trials after delivering promising results in an early study.

site_title: Adidas swamped with 508 million euros in orders for unsold Yeezy shoes: FT
summary: Adidas received orders worth 508 million euros (S$751.2 million) for 4 million unsold Yeezy shoes, exceeding its forecast. The strong demand could help the company avoid a significant write-down on its remaining stock. The orders come after Adidas stopped selling Yeezy shoes following Kanye West's anti-Semitic comments. The company had initially expected a loss this year, but the Yeezy sales may offset this, with some proceeds to be donated to organizations fighting anti-Semitism and racism.

images.alt_text: The German sportswear giant has been in a predicament over the Yeezy stock since it cut ties with West over his anti-Semitic comments late last year, with the controversy weighing on its stock and hitting its bottom line.

site_title: Billionaire family courts world’s rich on contrarian office bet
summary: Billionaire Reddy family, owners of Hyderabad-based GAR Corp, is selling a minority stake in their 3.5 million square foot Infobahn business park to raise up to $200 million. This move comes as India's commercial real estate market defies a global slowdown, with vacancies falling to the lowest level since 2020. The sale will likely diversify the Reddy family's wealth and fund further property development, with GAR owning over a dozen office blocks in the city.

images.alt_text: A woman is reflected on a glass as she works in a cubicle at Deloitte's office in Gurugram, India, June 13, 2023. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis

site_title: Pimco’s Clarida expects a ‘modest’ recession in the US
summary: US Federal Reserve global economic adviser Dr. Richard Clarida expects a "modest" recession in the US, despite the Fed likely hiking interest rates two more times this year. Clarida expects the Fed to begin cutting rates in the first half of 2024, after inflation slows to 3% in June from 4% in May. He favors a "soft-ish" landing, where GDP growth slows, unemployment rises, and inflation falls into the 2% range. Investment-grade fixed income assets are considered attractive, with yields at 15-year lows.

site_title: Big Food should be ESG’s next target
summary: Big food companies, such as those holding top ESG ratings, are being called to prioritize sustainability beyond environmental and social factors, and also consider the nutritional impact of their products. Ultra-processed foods are linked to various health issues, including obesity, cancer, and heart disease. ESG investors are urged to develop evidence-based metrics to measure the nutritional quality of food products, and companies are encouraged to adopt standardized mandatory disclosures to ensure transparency. This shift is necessary to address the growing health crisis caused by the production and consumption of ultra-processed foods.

images.alt_text: The taxes on junk food and sweetened beverages are forecast to generate 76 billion pesos in additional revenue during the first year, says Philippines’ Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno.
Throughout the carbonated-beverage business, from Diet Coke and Coke Zero Sugar, to Diet Pepsi and Diet Dr Pepper, aspartame is used to provide calorie-free sweetness.

site_title: More polling stations, counters for Presidential Election 2023
summary: The Elections Department (ELD) has announced plans to increase the number of polling stations to 1,264 for the 2023 presidential election, reducing waiting times. More registration and ballot paper counters will be provided in each station. A new X-stamp and online queue status checking system will also be introduced. Overseas voting will be available for the first time, with registration now open and a deadline of 10 days after polling day.

images.alt_text: Allegations of an affair between Mr Leon Perera and Ms Nicole Seah had made their rounds amongst WP members.
Clockwise from top left: Tan Chuan-Jin, Cheng Li Hui, David Ong, Yaw Shin Leong and Michael Palmer.
Ng Kok Song and his fiance Sybil Lau arrived at the Elections Department shortly past 10.30am on Wednesday to pick up an application form for the certificate of eligibility
Deputy PM Lawrence Wong, who is also Minister for Finance, will chair the International Advisory Council’s 21st meeting in November.

site_title: India's Reliance eases off record highs as Q1 profit disappoints
summary: Reliance Industries, India's largest company by market capitalization, posted a bigger-than-expected drop in profit, with its flagship oil-to-chemicals business experiencing a 6% decline in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) in the latest quarter. The company's shares fell nearly 3% on Monday, despite expanding into retail, green energy, and telecommunication. Analysts expect the unit's profitability to remain under pressure due to global economic factors.

images.alt_text: Reliance’s oil-to-chemicals business is still its main growth engine that powers both profit and revenue, despite the company’s aggressive expansion into retail, telecom and green energy.

site_title: Far East Shopping Centre up for collective sale with S$928 million guide price
summary: Far East Shopping Centre, a 999-year leasehold building on a 36,014 sq ft site in Singapore, is up for collective sale with a guide price of S$928 million. The site is zoned for commercial use and has an allowable gross plot ratio of 4.9. The sale comes as part of a joint integrated redevelopment scheme with adjacent sites, which could include hotel and retail components. The tender closes on September 20, with potential buyers expected to integrate different land uses, including retail, office, and lifestyle uses, to boost foot traffic in the area.

images.alt_text: While the Forum mall is sited on land zoned for commercial use, the voco Orchard Singapore site currently has only hotel use permitted.
HPL's Hilton Singapore along Orchard Road to be rebranded voco under IHG

site_title: UK job vacancies rise for fifth month, adding to pressure on pay
summary: UK job vacancies rose for a fifth consecutive month, with 1.06 million listings in June, a 0.78% increase from the previous month but 12% lower than a year ago. Advertised salaries rose 3.6% to £37,807, and the number of days to fill open positions fell to a record low. The tight labor market is expected to fuel inflation, with the Bank of England monitoring the situation closely.

images.alt_text: epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: China central bank issues draft rules on its data security management
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has issued draft rules on data security management for its own operations, aiming to tighten data usage and security amid geopolitical tensions and concerns about privacy. The rules propose a system of accountability and punitive measures for data security violations, requiring data collected within the country to be stored domestically and banning data processors from reducing data size for official security checks when exporting. Public opinions on the draft guidelines will be solicited until August 24.

site_title: Higher deposit caps for digibanks unlikely to dent earnings of DBS, UOB, OCBC: report
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, are unlikely to be impacted by the raised deposit caps for digital banks GXS and MariBank, according to Fitch Ratings. The increased caps, which are now at S$75,000, do not significantly affect the local banks' profitability, as they command 65% of all Singapore-dollar deposits and have a significant liquidity surplus. The move is seen as a step towards sustainable growth for digital banks, but challenges lie ahead for them to achieve long-term viability.

images.alt_text: The move indicates that MAS has raised the S$50 million deposit cap imposed on GXS and MariBank.
Grab’s digital bank, that’s also backed by Singapore Telecommunications, was set up just under a year ago.
Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO of Trust says that the bank is not targeting high net-worth individuals.

BT20220831_202283516324 : Gin Tay / bcgrab/ Benjamin Cher 

Generic photo of GXS Bank logo at Grab HQ@One North on Aug 31, 2022.
GXS CEO Charles Wong unveiling the digital bank's Flexiloan product, which is its first step to building a profitable bank.
MariBank is only offering a savings account for now, with an interest rate of 2.5 per cent credited daily.

site_title: Thai industrial sentiment rises in June, but political uncertainty a concern
summary: Thailand's industrial sentiment rose to 94.1 in June, driven by higher domestic demand, but sluggish exports and political uncertainty remain concerns. The Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) attributes the increase to a continued recovery in the tourism sector, but warns that soft global demand is impacting Thai exports. A new government has yet to be formed following the May national election, with the next parliamentary vote for a new prime minister set for Thursday. The FTI expects 29-30 million foreign tourists this year, down from 40 million in 2019.

images.alt_text: The central bank aims to reduce household debt to 80 per cent of gross domestic product from about 90.6 per cent – the highest among major Asian economies.

epa10751685 Pheu Thai Party's Prime Ministerial candidate Srettha Thavisin leaves party’s headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 17 July 2023. The Pheu Thai Party, which came in second place in the 14 May Thai general elections, is in talks to coalition parties and the progressive Move Forward Party ahead of the second round of Parliament's voting to elect next prime minister on 19 July.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Australia’s budget surplus set to be nearly five times higher than forecast
summary: Australia is expected to experience its first budget surplus in 15 years, with a surplus of over A$20 billion, exceeding initial forecasts of A$4.2 billion. However, this surplus is short-lived, as deficits are forecast for the current and next financial years due to rising interest bills and spending on disability care, health, and defense. Treasurer Jim Chalmers also warned of slowing economic growth and a focus on addressing global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Employment strength has been a key factor in the RBA’s confidence that Australia can avoid a recession

site_title: The great M&A slump is shaking up giants of investment banking
summary: A slump in mergers and acquisitions, combined with the collapse of Credit Suisse, has triggered a significant turnover of senior managers in the investment banking industry, including trading and advisory services. Top firms such as Goldman Sachs, Barclays, and smaller rivals like Jefferies Financial Group, Evercore, and PJT Partners are actively recruiting from these departing executives. This year, seven out of the top eight merger advisory firms have changed their investment bank chiefs or shuffled their M&A leadership, highlighting the industry's shift in response to the market downturn.

images.alt_text: BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, last month debuted its retail private credit fund.

site_title: China developer Country Garden shares extend losses on debt worries; others fall
summary: China property developer Country Garden shares and bonds fell on debt concerns, extending losses from the previous week. The company's move to refinance part of a 2019 loan facility failed to reassure investors, with Country Garden shares down 5% and bonds plummeting 20%. The decline is part of a broader downward trend in the property sector, which accounts for 25% of China's GDP. Home sales are slumping, and the government is moving to rein in unsustainable borrowing. Other developers, including Longfor Group and Sunac China Holdings, also saw their shares fall on Monday.

images.alt_text: Country Garden, which has thousands of projects across China, has moved to refinance part of a 2019 loan facility.

site_title: ‘Barbenheimer’ frenzy gives sluggish summer box office a major boost
summary: "Barbie" and "Oppenheimer" debuted simultaneously, dubbed "Barbenheimer," and boosted the summer box office, with domestic ticket sales topping $300 million for the fourth time in history. "Barbie" earned $155 million, while "Oppenheimer" collected $80.5 million. The films drew a wide audience, including fans dressed in pink, and helped revitalize the industry, which had been struggling due to disappointing box office numbers and strikes by writers and actors.

images.alt_text: Skincare brand mtm labo, headed by managing director Kelly Keak (left), collaborated with Barbie collector Jian Yang (right) to showcase Barbie at her most diverse.  The dolls include Barbie on wheelchairs, albino Barbie and pregnant Barbie.

site_title: Singapore’s ‘007’ who took the world by storm with his chips, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The 38th Singapore Business Awards honoured top business leaders in Singapore. The awards ceremony recognised outstanding contributions to the country's business landscape. The winners included prominent entrepreneurs, CEOs, and industry experts who demonstrated exceptional leadership, innovation, and impact. The awards aimed to celebrate the achievements of Singaporean businesses and individuals who have made significant contributions to the country's economic growth and development. The ceremony was attended by prominent business figures, government officials, and other stakeholders, highlighting the importance of the awards in promoting business excellence in Singapore.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly gain ahead of key rate decisions
summary: Asia's stock markets rose on Monday, July 24, ahead of key rate decisions from major central banks this week. Despite concern over China's economy, markets were boosted by recent data suggesting inflation is decreasing. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce another interest rate hike, but some analysts believe it may signal a pause in tightening cycles to avoid a recession. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan is expected to keep its monetary policy unchanged, and the European Central Bank is set to hike interest rates this week.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Manila and Jakarta edged up but Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Wellington dipped.

site_title: BlackRock names heads of wealth for Singapore, Greater China
summary: BlackRock has appointed Dennis Quah as the Singapore Wealth head, effective July 24, and Mandy Lui as the head of Greater China Wealth in Hong Kong, also starting in mid-August. Quah will focus on building partnerships with banks and insurers, while Lui will develop strategic relationships with distributors in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and offshore China. Both bring extensive experience in asset management and distribution in the region, with Quah having spent two decades in Asia markets and Lui previously leading wealth distribution efforts for several firms.

images.alt_text: BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, last month debuted its retail private credit fund.
CEO of Aramco Amin Nasser provides BlackRock with “a unique perspective” on key issues facing the company and its clients.
The budding trend underscores a growing belief that the country is too big and complicated to be lumped with others.

site_title: Singapore’s headline, core inflation ease further in June
summary: Singapore's headline and core inflation eased to multi-month lows in June, with headline inflation at 4.5% and core inflation at 4.2%. Food inflation also eased to 5.9%, while private transport inflation fell to 5.8%. Economists expect inflation to moderate further in the second half of the year, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore unlikely to change its monetary policy settings in October. The downward trend is attributed to energy disinflation, easing food and services inflation, and falling private road transport costs.

images.alt_text: Gig workers, including platform workers, were not earning enough to cover their spending as they had relatively less stable income flows, said DBS.
Lower inflation for xxx offset higher inflation for xxx.

site_title: One year after liftoff, ECB grapples with endgame for rate hikes
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to unveil another quarter-point increase in the deposit rate to 3.75% as part of its toughest-ever campaign of rate hikes. Policymakers are debating whether to offer guidance on the September meeting, with some seeking a final move and others preferring a pause. Investors and economists expect a 4% peak in rates, as the ECB continues to grapple with endgame for rate hikes, one year after lifting rates in December 2021.

images.alt_text: Core price growth – the focus of ECB even as headline inflation fades – is seen a touch lower this year than earlier.

site_title: China’s state planner unveils steps to spur private investment
summary: China's state planner, the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), has unveiled measures to promote private investment in infrastructure sectors, including transport, water, and clean energy. A special fund will be set up to provide annual support for 20 cities with high private investment growth and strong policy implementation. The NDRC aims to attract more private capital to participate in national major projects, with the goal of keeping the proportion of private fixed-asset investment at a "reasonable level". This move comes as China seeks to improve the private sector and address the country's flagging post-pandemic economic recovery.

images.alt_text: The rare meeting with global funds comes after Chinese President Xi Jinping’s administration voiced its strongest support in recent years for the country’s private tech enterprises just days earlier.

site_title: Stellantis, Samsung SDI set plan to build second US battery plant
summary: Stellantis and Samsung SDI plan to build a second US battery plant, with an initial production capacity of 34 gigawatt hours, targeting a start in 2027. The plant aims to support the production of 25 new battery electric vehicles for the North American market by the end of the decade. This move is part of Stellantis' goal to reach 50% electric car and light truck mix in the US by 2030 and 100% electric passenger car sales in Europe by the same year.

images.alt_text: Stellantis, Italy’s major automaker, produced fewer than 700,000 vehicles in the country last year and in 2021, as it was hit by a global shortage of microchips and other components.
Stellantis and LGES first announced their battery plant investment in March last year.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades Grab to ‘fully valued’ on structural challenges
summary: DBS Group Research has downgraded its call on Grab to "fully valued" from "hold" due to structural challenges affecting the company's future profitability. The research house views Grab's stock as expensive compared to peers, with a significant enterprise value-to-gross-profit premium that may be difficult to sustain. Despite this, DBS raised its target price to US$3.16, factoring in higher valuations based on projected margins of mature peers Uber and Dash. Analysts expect Grab's gross merchandise value to grow at 15% CAGR, but warn of a potential decline in GMV due to competition and rising inflation.

images.alt_text: Grab will acquire Singapore's third-largest taxi operator, Trans-cab, through its subsidiary Grab Rentals.
Grab’s digital bank, that’s also backed by Singapore Telecommunications, was set up just under a year ago.
Grab held a company-wide town hall on Wednesday for the survivors of the layoffs, where Tan fielded questions about the possibility of a second round of cuts.
Grab's latest round of retrenchment has cast a pall over those left behind, while those impacted have seen the community rally around them.
Grab is cutting more than 1,000 staff to streamline costs.

site_title: China central bank sells cash deposits at record low, more easing seen
summary: China's central bank sold 2% cash deposits at a record low, as commercial lenders lowered interest rates on yuan deposits in June. The People's Bank of China sold 60 billion yuan worth of finance ministry one-month deposits 75 basis points lower than the previous auction in May, driven by market expectations of further monetary easing. Economists expect the authorities to use tools such as lowering reserve requirement ratio and interest rates to loosen monetary policy and boost growth. This move provides relief for the financial sector and wider economy, which has been facing economic weakness.

images.alt_text: The steady LPR fixings come as the People’s Bank of China rolled over maturing medium-term policy loans and kept the interest rate unchanged earlier this week.
The central bank last adjusted the ratio in October 2022 by raising it to 1.25 from 1, to ease yuan depreciation pressure.

site_title: India’s economy to hold top spot for GDP but not so much for jobs growth: poll
summary: India's economy is expected to grow at 6.1% this fiscal year and 6.5% next year, but its job growth is expected to be limited, with only a slight improvement over the next year. The country needs to implement reforms in education, infrastructure, healthcare, and technology to reach its 8% growth potential, which is necessary to leapfrog to a developed nation status. The Production-Linked Incentive scheme is expected to have a modest impact on GDP growth, but its impact on employment remains uncertain.
