site_title: Asset-heavy property groups like HPL should have minimal key man risk
summary: Hotel Properties Limited (HPL), an asset-heavy property group, may not be significantly impacted by the corporate troubles of tycoon Ong Beng Seng, popularly known as OBS. OBS was recently arrested and required to provide information to the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) regarding his interactions with Minister for Transport S Iswaran. Despite OBS' involvement in high-profile events and corporate battles, HPL's operations are expected to remain unaffected. OBS' personal issues may not directly influence the company's financial performance or daily operations.

images.alt_text: The hotel and property tycoon is also known for being one of those responsible for first bringing the Formula 1 night race to Singapore in 2008.
While the Forum mall is sited on land zoned for commercial use, the voco Orchard Singapore site currently has only hotel use permitted.

site_title: FTX’s Bankman-Fried denies witness tampering, accepts gag order
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, founder of FTX, has denied witness tampering and accepted a gag order, according to his lawyers. Bankman-Fried spoke with a New York Times reporter and provided personal documents, including those from his former colleague Caroline Ellison, who has cooperated with the US government. Ellison's documents revealed her unhappiness and feelings of rejection from Bankman-Fried. Bankman-Fried's lawyer confirmed he did not violate any laws or rules governing his conduct. Bankman-Fried has pleaded not guilty to fraud and his case continues.

images.alt_text: The prosecutors argue that Bankman-Fried is trying to malign Caroline Ellison’s credibility.
Sam Bankman-Fried has pleaded not guilty to several criminal charges.

site_title: Why is America undercutting Japan?
summary: The US is undermining Japan's economy through protectionist policies, including the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) and the Chips and Science Act, which favor domestic US producers and discriminate against Japanese and other foreign companies. The IRA provides a $7,500 subsidy per US-made electric vehicle, while the Chips Act subsidizes construction of semiconductor "fabs" in the US, undercutting Japan in key sectors. This policy shift could lead to Japanese companies relocating investments or operations to the US, harming the global economy and undermining US allies in Asia.

site_title: Russia’s Putin: Black Sea grain deal became meaningless
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin stated that the Black Sea grain deal became meaningless, leading to its withdrawal due to ignored conditions. The deal, which allowed Ukraine to export grain despite the war, was quit after Russia's demands were not met. Putin expects a record harvest and plans to supply grain, food, and fertilizers to Africa, valuing economic ties with the continent. Russia has been pounding Ukrainian food-exporting ports, and an attack on Odesa killed one person and injured scores more.

images.alt_text: Russia has the upper hand in its embargo on Ukrainian wheat exports, as low wheat prices mean it faces little pressure from its allies in the Global South.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Monday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,281.14 points at Monday's open, with gainers outnumbering losers 83 to 47. The most active counters included Seatrium, Thai Beverage Public Company, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Globally, markets closed mostly positive on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rising, while the Nasdaq declined.

images.alt_text: Cromwell E-Reit, which has the Piazza Affari 2 as a trophy asset in Milan, saw its portfolio valuation for the half-year ended June 2023 fall a further 1.6 per cent to about 2.3 billion euros.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cromwell E-Reit, Aztech Global, Hong Leong Asia
summary: Cromwell E-Reit's portfolio valuation fell 1.6% to 2.3 billion euros for the half year ended June 2023, but manager described the decline as "modest." Aztech Global reported a 0.2% increase in net profit to S$42.9 million for the first half of 2023. Hong Leong Asia opened a 3.8-hectare facility in Punggol, boosting local production of building materials. CapAllianz called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Chevron posts US$6 billion quarterly earnings, beating estimates
summary: Chevron reported second-quarter earnings of $6.01 billion, beating analyst estimates of $5.5 billion. Despite a 48% decline from last year, the profit topped expectations. Chevron also produced a record 772,000 barrels of oil equivalent at the Permian Basin and issued record shareholder distributions of $7.2 billion. The company's chief financial officer, Pierre Breber, will retire in 2024 and be replaced by Eimear Bonner, who will take over as CFO on March 1, 2024.

site_title: Bain to buy 90% stake in Adani Capital and Adani Housing
summary: US-based investment firm Bain Capital has agreed to acquire 90% of Adani Capital and Adani Housing, buying out the Adani family's private investments. Gaurav Gupta will retain 10% stake and continue as managing director and CEO. Bain has committed $120 million and an additional $50 million in liquidity. The deal aims to position Adani Capital as a standalone company to expand lending, following international investments by companies like GQG after the Adani Group faced pressure due to US short seller Hindenburg Research's accusations.

images.alt_text: A reporter raises his hand to ask a question during a news conference by Bain Capital LP Managing Director Yuji Sugimoto (not in the picture) in Tokyo, Japan October 5, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Top Taiwan bank looks to South-east Asia in shift from China
summary: Taiwan's largest lender, Cathay United Bank, is shifting its focus to South-east Asia as corporate clients in high-tech and textile manufacturing diversify their supply chains away from China. The bank has boosted hiring in Vietnam and Singapore, with plans to expand into Vietnam, Indonesia, and Cambodia. This move follows a broader shift away from China by Taiwanese banks, which have cut their exposure to the world's second-largest economy to its lowest level in at least a decade.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins shakes hands with Malaysian Minister of Investment, Trade and Industry Tengku Abdul Aziz, as Britain signs the treaty to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, in Auckland, New Zealand July 16, 2023. REUTERS/Lucy Craymer
“I think about five to seven years... it depends on the business,” Joe Wu, president of PSMC Japan talks about the timing for a potential listing.

site_title: Indonesia set for record fundraising in 2023; large IPOs still expected in S-E Asia in H2
summary: Indonesia is poised to set a record for initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2023, with a total of $3.3 billion raised in the first half of the year, exceeding the previous record of $3.1 billion in 2022. The country's robust IPO market is driven by high interest rates and a weak macroeconomic outlook in other South-east Asian countries, with three sizeable IPOs in Indonesia raising over $1.2 billion each. Analysts expect Indonesia to continue its momentum, with more large IPOs in the pipeline, despite headwinds from uncertain interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: blur, chart, computer

site_title: Fund managers prefer using ESG bonds to reach net-zero: survey
summary: A survey by NatWest found that 70% of asset managers prefer sustainable bond structures to meet their net-zero targets. The most popular options were use-of-proceeds bonds (26%), green securitization (24%), and sustainability-linked bonds (23%). However, 28% of respondents preferred conventional bonds, citing concerns over greenwashing. The survey also highlighted the need for improved impact reporting and clearer guidelines from regulators to drive innovation in green bonds.

images.alt_text: Bankers pointed out that the downtrend comes amid an overall drop in bond and loan issuances, including non-ESG financing instruments, as global macroeconomic factors such as rising inflation and interest rate hikes have increased the costs of capital.
About 44 per cent of North American respondents say that their reasons for having an ESG strategy have become weaker over the past twelve months, according to the survey.
HSBC has stepped up expansion in China despite criticism from some lawmakers in the West of the bank’s conduct in the region.
Japanese companies such as Japan Airlines Co, which issued 20 billion yen of transition notes this year, have been the world's most active issuers of sustainable bonds in 2023 so far.

site_title: Evergrande seeks approval in courts for restructuring plan vote
summary: Evergrande Group is set to seek approval in a Hong Kong court to hold votes on its offshore-debt restructuring plan, which is crucial for the company's overhaul. Over 77% of Class A creditors have agreed to the plan, while around 30% of Class C creditors have shown support. The company aims to restructure its debt, with creditors receiving new notes or a combination of debt and equity in 10-12 years. A successful vote would be a key step towards the company's restructuring, which has been delayed due to concerns about China's property sector and the company's financial struggles.

images.alt_text: Evergrande’s financial woes even started to affect operations at the building, which sits in Hong Kong’s busy Wan Chai district.
Evergrande has asked to convene meetings for offshore creditors to approve its credit overhaul plan, after reporting long-delayed financial statements for 2021 and 2022.

site_title: Sunak renews UK housebuilding pledge, relaxes planning rules
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has renewed his pledge to build 1 million new homes over the course of this parliament, aiming to meet his 2019 election manifesto commitment. The plan includes relaxing planning rules, such as converting disused premises into new houses, to address the UK's housing shortage and rising rents. However, critics, including Labour, have expressed skepticism, citing the need for more substantial measures to address the crisis, which is exacerbating the UK's cost-of-living crisis ahead of a general election in 2025.

images.alt_text: A party completed home on a residential property construction site in Harlow, UK. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesian nickel mine takes green steps as environmental concerns mount
summary: Indonesia's Morowali industrial park, a major nickel production hub, is taking steps to address environmental concerns. The complex, backed by China's Tsingshan Holding Group and Indonesia's BintangDelapan Group, aims to reduce its carbon footprint by constructing 500 megawatts of solar panels and implementing more efficient waste management practices. The move follows scrutiny from industry consultants and environmental groups, who have raised concerns about the park's reliance on coal-fired power and waste-disposal plans. The park's managing director, Hamid Mina, says the company will focus on a "green" industry in the next five years, with plans to invest US$63 million in renewable energy.

images.alt_text: There were 85 IPOs across Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Philippines and Vietnam in the first half of the year, raising US$3.3 billion, according to a Deloitte report.
Indonesia has seen FDI rise sharply as the resource-rich country attracts investment in the manufacturing of stainless steel and battery materials.

site_title: MCL Land, at 60, presses on with restocking residential land and listening to customers
summary: MCL Land, a 60-year-old Hongkong Land subsidiary, plans to focus on developing Singapore residential projects despite thin profit margins. The company will prioritize teaming up with partners who share its values and vision to replenish its residential land stock. MCL will concentrate its new capital in Singapore, with the allocation of funds focused on government land sales (GLS) sites. The company aims to develop projects that cater to changing customer needs, including co-working spaces, and supports sustainability initiatives. With a strong reputation in Singapore, MCL will continue to develop projects, including four under development, and expand its presence in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: The Jalan Tembusu site, for private housing development, is near the future Tanjong Katong MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.
Contributions from the investment properties segment was “marginally” higher year on year with a stronger showing from the retail segment.
Eligible buyers bought 73 per cent of units at Copen Grand, the first Executive Condominium project at the upcoming Tengah Town, developers City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land said.
The 340 units, amounting to 53 per cent of the project’s available units, were sold at an average selling price of S$2,465 per square foot (psf).

site_title: Japan’s factory activity shrinks in July as orders weaken: PMI
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity declined in July, with the manufacturing PMI falling to 49.4 from 49.8 in June, while the service sector's growth slowed to 53.9 from 54.0. New orders and output fell at the fastest pace since March, while cost pressures eased with input prices growing at the slowest pace since February 2021. The decline in manufacturing activity is attributed to weak demand and souring confidence, with the country's core inflation exceeding the central bank's 2% target for the 15th month in a row.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A worker checks machinery at a factory in Higashiosaka, Japan June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Sakura Murakami/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Chinese chipmakers urge Beijing to do more amid escalating US export controls
summary: China's chip companies have urged Beijing to take more measures to address the impact of US export controls, which have resulted in significant uncertainty and harm to the supply chain. The companies, including over 700 Chinese chipmakers, have called for enhanced communication between Beijing and Washington to avoid escalating tensions. The US imposed export controls in October last year, affecting the entire supply chain from design to materials, and have also harmed the global semiconductor industry, including US players.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm gets more than 60 per cent of its revenue from the China region, where it supplies components to smartphone makers such as Xiaomi.
The chip industry is keen to protect its profits in China as the Biden administration considers another round of restrictions on chip exports to China.

site_title: Tourists flee wildfires on Greek island of Rhodes
summary: Thousands of tourists and residents fled the Greek island of Rhodes on Sunday as wildfires spread, forcing the evacuation of 19,000 people from homes and hotels. The fires, fueled by extreme heat, threatened resorts and coastal villages, leaving trees black and skeletal. Many tourists walked for miles in scorching heat to reach safety, while others were rescued by private boats and coastguard vessels. The Greek government has set up shelters and provided assistance to those affected, with some holidaymakers praising local generosity and kindness.

images.alt_text: The Hellenic Financial Stability Fund’s 1.4 per cent stake in Eurobank will be the first to be put up for sale.

site_title: Beyond Fed’s expected hike, worries remain over pay and Putin
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates on July 26, bringing rates to a near 20-year high of 5.5%, amid concerns over inflation and wage pressures. The Fed's rate-setting committee, led by Chairman Jerome Powell, will assess the economic data and may give a subtle hint that the hike is a "one and done". However, a new round of food inflation seems inevitable due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, which could impact the inflation story and the Fed's decision. Analysts predict the Fed will not reverse plans for a rate hike, but will continue to monitor wage growth to prevent a return to stagflation.

images.alt_text: The threat of a recession continues to linger as the US Federal Reserve could keep interest rates higher for longer.

The US Federal Reserve Building is seen in Washington, DC, May 3, 2023. - The US Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise its benchmark lending rate for a 10th -- and possibly final -- time, as it aims to bring down inflation while preventing fresh banking concerns from spreading. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: Workers select and pack items during Cyber Monday at the Amazon fulfilment centre in Robbinsville Township in New Jersey, U.S., November 28, 2022. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit’s portfolio valuation down 1.6% in H1
summary: Cromwell E-Reit reported a 1.6% decrease in its total portfolio value to €2.3 billion (S$3.4 billion) for the first half of 2023, mainly due to a 2.6% decline in its Dutch portfolio valuation. Despite this, the Reit's active leasing and renewals, high inflation indexation growth, and positive rent reversions contributed to its strong performance. The Reit's manager attributed the decline in Poland's office market to weakness in the Grade B office market and new supply.

site_title: Secret villas inside hotels are the ultimate in quiet luxury
summary: Luxury hotels are introducing secret villas that can be booked only by direct inquiry, evading public awareness and online presence. These exclusive accommodations feature private spas, infinity pools, and other high-end amenities, but are only accessible to those who know to look. The suites are often removed from hotel websites and search results, and pricing is only available through personal inquiries. The trend of quiet luxury has expanded to the travel industry, offering an exclusive and private experience for discerning guests.

images.alt_text: In Thailand, where tourism is an economic mainstay, the number of Indian tourists – though fewer than Chinese in absolute terms – is only about 14 per cent lower than it was in 2019.

site_title: WealthBT: Market impacts of scarcity and how to position yourself (Ep 28)
summary: Dong Chen from Pictet Wealth Management discusses the market impacts of scarcity, including resource, labor, and trust shortages, which will drive markets in the long run. Chen emphasizes the importance of understanding these trends to position a portfolio effectively. Key asset class expectations include labor shortages affecting wages, resource scarcity impacting commodities, and trust erosion affecting financial markets.

images.alt_text: Learn more about private debt as an asset class with Goh Hui Yang, Pictet’s head of alternative investments in Asia.
What is the first step towards a long-lasting legacy?

site_title: Law Society elects Jason Chan as new president following Adrian Tan’s death earlier this month
summary: The Law Society of Singapore has elected Jason Chan Tai-Hui as its new president, effective immediately, following the untimely death of Adrian Tan on July 8 at 57 due to a year-long battle with cancer. Chan's term will last until December 31 this year.

images.alt_text: Law Society of Singapore president Adrian Tan was diagnosed with cancer in March 2022.

site_title: Yen slides, US dollar gains as BOJ seen maintaining loose policy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its loose policy, leading to a 2.22% weekly gain for the US dollar against the yen. The yen dropped after Reuters reported that the BOJ will scrutinize more data to ensure wages and inflation rise before changing the policy. This decision comes as inflation exceeds the BOJ's 2% target, with core inflation rising to 3.3%. The US dollar gained 1.24% against the yen, while the euro and pound fell against the dollar.

images.alt_text: Trade in the yen has been broadly subdued earlier in the session after data shows Japan’s core inflation rises to 3.3 per cent

site_title: Private-hire car population up 11.3% as demand for services grows; taxi numbers shrink
summary: The number of private-hire cars in Singapore has increased by 11.3% to 76,686 in June, driven by rising demand for ride-hailing services from returning tourists. This growth comes despite fewer Certificate of Entitlement (COE) available for registration, with 28% of COEs used for private-hire cars in the first half of 2023. The taxi population has been shrinking, with 13,861 taxis in Singapore as of June 2023, down 3.47% from a year ago. Industry experts warn that high COE premiums may limit the growth of private-hire car fleets.

images.alt_text: Grab will acquire Singapore's third-largest taxi operator, Trans-cab, through its subsidiary Grab Rentals.
ComfortDelGro’s planned purchase of new hybrid taxis comes as its push towards fully electric vehicles has slowed.

site_title: China to be centre of Mercedes-Benz 2025 EV sales drive
summary: Mercedes-Benz plans to shift its focus to electric vehicles, with all new platforms set to produce only EVs starting in 2025. The German luxury carmaker's CEO, Ola Kaellenius, stated that mastering electric propulsion is crucial to meet customer expectations. The company is reviewing models for China, prioritizing space and digital content, as local brands dominate the Chinese EV market. China remains a key market for Mercedes-Benz, with significant stakes held by local shareholders, but Berlin is seeking to reduce its exposure to China's economy amid efforts to diversify the German economy.

images.alt_text: Sales grow in all Mercedes-Benz’s main regions – Europe, Asia and North America – with deliveries in Germany up 23 per cent, while China is up by 12 per cent and the US by 6 per cent.

site_title: Singapore’s bone marrow donor programme gifts S$3.6 million to medical school for clinical trials
summary: Singapore's Bone Marrow Donor Programme (BMDP) has donated S$3.6 million to the National University of Singapore's medical school for cellular therapy clinical trials. This funding will support patients with blood diseases who are at high risk of not responding to chemotherapy. The BMDP, which operates on a cost-recovery basis, aims to grow its registry to 350,000 potential donors and has already helped over 800 patients find bone marrow matches. The donation was announced at the BMDP's 30th anniversary dinner, which was attended by 300 people, including Minister of State Desmond Tan.

images.alt_text: The art auction features 12 resin geode artworks, created by children from The Salvation Army and volunteers from Peace of Art.

site_title: Distressed home sales fall in Q2 despite continued bankruptcy pressure
summary: Mortgagee listings in Singapore's second quarter of 2023 fell 35.7% to 18, down from 28 in the previous quarter, amidst a "robust" primary and secondary market. Bankruptcy applications increased in April and May, with 301 and 314 cases, respectively, compared to 300 and 297 last year. The rental market remains buoyant, with the overall rental index for private homes increasing 7.2% quarter-on-quarter. Experts attribute the drop in mortgagee listings to financially distressed owners selling properties themselves or obtaining rental income to buffer mortgage payments.

images.alt_text: Orchard’s prime retail rents have increased 5.9 per cent on the year, greater than the 5.4 per cent increase of the islandwide average.
The Jalan Tembusu site, for private housing development, is near the future Tanjong Katong MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.
Developers sold less private homes in June 2023.

site_title: Barclays banks on renewable power in S-E Asia: sustainable finance head
summary: Barclays' global head of sustainable finance, Daniel Hanna, predicts solar energy will drive growth in renewable capacity in South-east Asia, with a focus on financing the region's power sector. Hanna believes supportive policies, increased investment in grids, and innovation in blended finance can accelerate the rollout. The bank aims to mobilize $1 trillion of sustainable and transition finance globally by 2030, with a focus on growing its share in Asia. Hanna also emphasizes the importance of a "just transition" that addresses social impact, and notes that industry guidelines on incorporating just-transition criteria into deals are needed.

images.alt_text: Daniel Hanna, global head of sustainable finance at Barclays

site_title: G20 fails to reach agreement on cutting fossil fuels
summary: The G20 failed to reach an agreement on phasing down fossil fuels, despite efforts to triple renewable energy capacities by 2030. The meeting in India resulted in an outcome statement and chair summary instead of a joint communique, as disagreements over language and curbing "unabated" fossil fuel use persisted. Major fossil fuel producers such as Saudi Arabia and Russia opposed the goal, while some countries suggested using carbon capture instead of a phase-down. The failure to reach consensus highlights the international community's foot-dragging on climate action, with the G20 accounting for over three-quarters of global emissions.

images.alt_text: The UAE’s Sultan Al Jaber, president of the COP28 conference, is scheduled to address the India event.
Indonesian state utility Perusahaan Listrik Negara has set a target to phase out coal power plants by 2056, as part of the country’s goal to reach net zero carbon emission by 2060.

The statement, by Britain’s Energy Security and Net Zero Secretary Grant Shapps (left) and US Special Presidential Envoy on Climate John Kerry, followed a Climate Finance Mobilisation Forum held at Windsor Castle, England.

site_title: China addresses investor concerns in meeting with global funds
summary: China's regulators met with global investors on July 21 to address concerns about investment in the country, following Chinese President Xi Jinping's administration's support for private tech enterprises. The meeting, attended by venture capital firms and private equity groups, aimed to boost market confidence as China's economic recovery slows. Regulators discussed steps to expedite overseas initial public offerings, accelerate listings in mainland China, and relax merger and acquisition rules. The meeting comes amid escalating tensions between China and the US, as well as China's weakening economy and crackdown on its private sector.

images.alt_text: The new rules, signed by Premier Li Qiang and effective on Sep 1, create a chapter specifically for venture capital funds, as policymakers encourage investment into innovative technology startups.

site_title: Spot Bitcoin ETFs are coming. Beware the risk
summary: US regulators are expected to approve spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) soon, allowing investors to buy, sell, and hold the digital currency more easily and securely. A spot ETF would give investors confidence in the legitimacy of Bitcoin as a financial product. Despite its high growth rate, Bitcoin's Sharpe Ratio, a measure of risk-adjusted return, is not exceptional when compared to traditional investments like stocks and bonds. In fact, it has been less volatile than stocks and bonds, but its performance has been inconsistent, with a median Sharpe Ratio comparable to that of the S&P 500 and the Bloomberg US Aggregate Bond Index.

images.alt_text: UK finance ministry “firmly disagrees” with the recommendation to regulate retail trading and investment activity in unbacked cryptoassets as gambling rather than as a financial service.

site_title: Spain go to polls as conservatives eye ousting Sanchez
summary: Spain is holding its first summer election, with turnout reaching 40.5% despite the heat. Conservative opposition leader Alberto Nunez Feijoo is favored to win, potentially forming a coalition with far-right Vox party. Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez, who called the snap election, is betting on last-minute mobilization but faces a challenging outcome. A win for Feijoo would mark redemption for the People's Party, which was ousted from power in 2018, and would be the first time a far-right party enters government.

images.alt_text: Voters cast their ballot during Spain's general election, in Elgoibar on July 23, 2023. Spain votes today on whether to hand Socialist Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez a fresh four-year mandate or, as polls suggest, bring the right back to power with its far-right ally. (Photo by ANDER GILLENEA / AFP)

site_title: Students try a day in the life of a Thrive journalist at career fair
summary: Students from various tertiary schools attended a career fair event called World X 2023, organized by SkillsFuture Singapore's Lifelong Learning Institute and non-profit group The Astronauts Collective, to explore emerging growth areas in healthcare, sustainability, and digital sectors. Participants, including those from Thrive, the young audience initiative of The Business Times, engaged in workshops and activities such as creating social media clips, street interviews, and skits. The event drew over 1,000 participants and featured professionals from more than 100 different occupations, with a focus on skills in software testing, user experience, and green facilities management.

images.alt_text: From left: The Business Times young audience editor Vivien Shiao; screenwriter and director of Ajooma He Shunming; Sam Neo founder of People Mentality Inc, Stories of Asia and StoryBuddy; co-founder and chief executive officer of Calm Collective Asia Sabrina Ooi; and Apurv Suri, SC Ventures, Standard Chartered Bank.
BT
While posturing can help one in the short term to build up confidence, cracks will start to appear in the long run if one does not have the capability required.

site_title: Illycaffe, Hangzhou Onechance to partner in China
summary: Illycaffe, an Italian coffee roaster, has partnered with Hangzhou Onechance Tech Corp to grow its business in China. The partnership aims to strengthen Illycaffe's presence in home and online channels, with a goal to treble its turnover in China by 2026. Illycaffe is on track to meet its target of an initial public offering (IPO) by 2026, also planning to increase its presence in the US ahead of the IPO.

site_title: Outlook for cocoa continues to stay bullish
summary: Cocoa prices continue to rise, topping charts with a 30% upside swing year-to-date due to a 30% drop in harvest from key production regions, primarily West Africa and Latin America. The benchmark Cocoa contract reached a 12-year high of $3,438 per metric tonne, with prices up 31.46% year-to-date. This surge has significant implications for food and candy producers, and the retail industry, making chocolate an expensive indulgence.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cocoa pods are pictured at a farm in Sinfra, Ivory Coast April 29, 2023. REUTERS/Luc Gnago/File Photo

site_title: ‘Training my replacement’: Inside a call centre worker’s battle with AI
summary: Ylonda Sherrod, a 38-year-old customer service representative at an AT&T call center in Mississippi, is concerned about the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on her job. The AI tool has been generating transcripts of her calls and providing suggestions to customers, making her feel like she's "training her replacement." Sherrod, who is the vice-president of the call center's local union chapter, has begun questioning the company about its AI plans and fears job loss. A recent survey of US call center workers found that nearly two-thirds reported that they felt it was likely that increased use of bots would lead to layoffs within the next two years. Experts argue that AI will gradually eliminate the need for humans to do certain tasks, making the remaining work more challenging.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT reached 100 million users in less than two months, 15 times faster than Instagram, which took 30 months.
Companies relying on externally developed AI systems should conduct thorough due diligence to ensure system accuracy and robustness.
Jobs at highest risk were defined as those using more than 25 of the 100 skills and abilities that AI experts consider can be easily automated.

site_title: 17 S-Reits reporting earnings during the week
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit released its H1 2023 financial results, reporting a 23.2% year-over-year increase in gross revenue to S$55.3 million and a 0.5% year-over-year increase in net property income to S$27.2 million. The company's occupancy rate rose 2.6 percentage points to 93.9%, driven by strong leasing momentum. However, the Reit maintained a cautious outlook due to macro-economic challenges and a decline in Singapore's industrial property market occupancy rate.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit was the best performing S-Reit in the first half of 2023, driven by stronger growth in distributable income and distribution per unit.

site_title: China’s Wanda Commercial meets US$400m bond repayment deadline
summary: Dalian Wanda Commercial Management, a unit of China's largest commercial real estate developer Dalian Wanda Group, has met its US$400 million bond repayment deadline. The company has around 6.7 billion yuan of onshore bonds maturing and US$1 billion of offshore bonds due in the period, with its next deadline being a 3.5 billion yuan onshore bond due on July 29. Despite concerns from ratings agencies Moody's and S&P about the company's ability to meet debt repayment deadlines, Wanda Commercial's debt pile is relatively small compared to other Chinese residential property developers.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of July 21, 2023, highlights a sluggish Pacific capesize market with limited activity, leading to stagnant rates. In contrast, the Atlantic market has seen a slightly higher level of activity, primarily driven by South Brazil and West Africa routes to the Far East. Panamax and ultramax/supramax markets have experienced losses, with the Panamax market showing little signs of abatement. The Asian arena has led the way for ultramax/supramax, with the Asian arena leading the way. Handysize markets have been limited, with optimism that August may bring some positivity to the region.

images.alt_text: The Capesize market experienced a decline in rates as the week progressed, with a shift in sentiment due to a growing abundance of available vessels.

site_title: What congestion pricing’s arrival in NYC would mean
summary: New York City's Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) plans to implement congestion pricing, charging motorists a fee to drive into Manhattan's central business district, starting as early as April 2024. The aim is to reduce traffic and pollution while raising $15 billion for the city's subways, buses, and commuter rails. The toll could be up to $23 during peak hours, with discounts for residents earning less than $60,000 per year. Critics argue it penalizes drivers who already pay high tolls, while supporters see it as a demand-side solution to clear streets and cleaner air.

images.alt_text: Why emptier US streets meant an especially deadly year for traffic deaths
Hamptons boom creates a new world of luxury problems

site_title: As Paris Olympics looms, hotel industry has reservations
summary: The Paris Olympics, set to take place in 2024, is causing concerns for the hotel industry in the Ile de France region, which is already a popular tourist destination. With 45 million tourists visiting annually, hoteliers fear the Games could exacerbate existing issues, including a potential "bad buzz" if the event fails. However, hotel professionals expect the Olympics to drive up prices for years to come, with some hotels already renting rooms to agencies and partners rather than private individuals. The region's hotel network is growing, with 2,100 establishments and 124,000 rooms, and is expected to attract more investment.

images.alt_text: “We have full confidence in the organising committee and the French authorities to deliver successful Olympic and Paralympic Games and in the hospitality of the French people to welcome the world to these Games,” the IOC says.

site_title: China to resume 15-day visa-free entry for Singaporeans from Jul 26
summary: China will resume a 15-day visa-free entry for Singaporeans starting July 26, allowing them to travel to China for tourism, business, visiting relatives and friends, and transit purposes. The facility was suspended in March 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic and was previously reinstated in March this year. The resumption is expected to facilitate people-to-people exchanges and boost bilateral cooperation between Singapore and China, making it easier for tourists, enterprises, and youths to travel to China.

images.alt_text: A visa-free travel arrangement can could boost visitor numbers from China, which was Singapore's biggest pre-pandemic tourism market.

site_title: Crowded Singapore makes room for micro-gyms
summary: In Singapore, micro-gyms, or small, air-conditioned capsule gyms, are gaining popularity as an alternative to traditional gyms. The gyms, which can be booked via an app, offer private workouts with equipment like treadmills and weights, and are priced between $12 to $15 for a 60-minute session. This trend is capitalizing on record levels of Singapore residents exercising or playing sports, with 74% of residents reporting exercise at least once a week in 2022. Micro-gyms are also seen as a safe and hygienic environment, and are attracting consumers who prefer the convenience and affordability of these small, pop-up gyms.

images.alt_text: Using geolocation data near golf courses in the United States, a Stanford study found there was 278 per cent more people playing golf at 4pm on a Wednesday in August 2022 than in August 2019. And there were 83 per cent more golf games being played on a weekday in August 2022 than in August 2019.
Many of those wealthy Asian buyers are paying in cash or obtaining low-interest loans from foreign banks with local branches.
The new Technogym in Singapore, a two-storey building located at 55 Mohamed Sultan Road.

site_title: Europe: Shares end second week higher; tech records worst week of the year
summary: European shares rose for the second consecutive week, driven by a rally in British shares following evidence of slowing domestic inflation. The Stoxx 600 index edged 0.3% higher, while the UK's FTSE 100 posted 3% gains, its best in nearly four months. However, concerns about China's weak economic recovery and the tech sector's earnings season capped gains. The pan-European index rose 0.9% for the week, despite a decline in the mining sector. Investors are now focused on central bank policy meetings next week for clues on the global interest rate trajectory.

site_title: Singtel says A&G’s Christina Ong still qualifies as independent director due to transitional period
summary: Singtel announced that independent director Christina Ong remains eligible for her role despite exceeding the nine-year tenure limit due to a transitional period implemented by the Singapore Exchange. The company's board continues to consider Ong an independent director, and she will be retained in her position. Singtel also addressed shareholder queries on its business strategy, including its new infrastructure unit Digital InfraCo and its strategy for the data centre business, which is expected to surge with the rise of generative artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: Singtel is bringing its net-zero targets earlier to 2045.

site_title: Most expensive euro on record has traders braced for declines
summary: The euro has reached its most expensive level on record, posing a risk to the European economy and potentially forcing the European Central Bank (ECB) to turn dovish. The euro's nominal effective exchange rate is near its highest level against the yuan in three years, which could dim the appeal of the region's exports. Analysts predict the euro will drop to US$1.10 by September and possibly lower, as the ECB faces concerns over the euro area's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Japanese 10,000 yen banknotes and U.S. one-hundred dollar banknotes are arranged for a photograph in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, May 31, 2013. Japanese shares fell, with the Topix index deepening its correction, as Nomura Holdings Inc. paced declines among brokerages and a stronger yen weighed on exporters earnings outlook. Photographer: Yuriko Nakao/Bloomberg

site_title: CEOs of Israel's biggest banks warn of fallout from judicial changes
summary: Israel's two largest banks, Bank Leumi and Bank Hapoalim, warned the government to halt its judicial overhaul, citing economic fallout if the changes continue. CEOs Hanan Friedman and Dov Kotler expressed concerns about damage to the economy and potential loss of investments. The moves come as protests against the changes escalate, with a key vote in parliament scheduled for next week. Proponents of the changes say they would restore balance to the government, while critics argue it would remove vital checks and balances.

images.alt_text: jerusalem, israel, middle east

site_title: The pandemic’s labour market myths
summary: The US labor market has proven resilient in the face of the pandemic, defying predictions of permanent changes. Women lost jobs early in the pandemic but have returned to the workforce in record numbers, and early retirements did not materialize. The shift towards remote work for white-collar jobs is still reshaping the economy, but the overall labor market has not been permanently worsened. The US worker's ability to adapt and find new jobs has proven correct, with unemployment remaining low and high-skilled employees finding new opportunities.

images.alt_text: The shift in the balance of power is slowly starting to affect wages. Worker compensation grew 4.8 per cent in the first quarter from a year ago, down from a 5.1 per cent pace in the previous quarter, Labor Department data show.
One potential explanation for the gender disparity: Women continue to shoulder the burden of housework and childcare.
Half of US workers surveyed in new research say office politics have remained throughout the Covid pandemic.

site_title: Trailers, a growing trend in wealthy California's housing crisis
summary: A growing trend of people in wealthy California, particularly in Los Angeles County, are turning to trailers, RVs, and vans as makeshift homes due to the state's severe housing crisis. Over 75,000 people are homeless in the county, with many living in RVs and trailers that have formed makeshift camps. The average rent in Los Angeles is $2,950 a month, making it difficult for low-income individuals to afford housing. The situation is exacerbated by high inflation and unemployment, with some individuals needing to work three jobs to make ends meet.

images.alt_text: Country Garden, which has thousands of projects across China, has moved to refinance part of a 2019 loan facility.

site_title: Cambodia’s ruling party claims landslide win in one-sided election
summary: Cambodia's ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP) has declared a landslide victory in the general election, with Hun Sen's party expected to retain all 125 seats in the Lower House. The election was widely criticized as a sham, with opposition parties banned, challengers forced to flee, and freedom of expression stifled. Hun Sen's son, Hun Manet, is set to succeed him, potentially prolonging the family's grip on power. The election turnout was 84%, with many voters expressing disappointment and disillusionment with the outcome. Rights groups have condemned the election, calling it "profoundly concerning".

images.alt_text: Hun Manet, son of Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Sen, is a candidate for the election, making his debut.

site_title: Chinese chipmaker Hua Hong seeks up to  21.2 billion yuan in mainland listing
summary: Hua Hong Semiconductor, China's second-largest chip foundry, plans to raise up to 21.2 billion yuan (S$3.9 billion) through a Shanghai stock exchange listing. The company will sell 407.75 million shares at 52 yuan per share. This initial public offering is set to be the biggest mainland listing this year, as Chinese chipmakers seek self-sufficiency amid an escalating technology war with the US. Hua Hong's revenue jumped 52% in 2022 to a record $2.5 billion, and the company plans to increase production capacity and build new lines.

site_title: Tesla starts offering 84-month loans as interest rates rise
summary: Tesla has started offering 84-month car loans in response to rising interest rates, after CEO Elon Musk said the company would "have to do something" about the trend. The loans, previously up to 72 months, will allow consumers to lower monthly payments but face greater interest and risk of owing more than the vehicle's value. This move comes as the trend of longer car loans slowed in the first quarter, with 34% of new vehicle loans being over six years.

site_title: What’s stopping some Singapore companies from allowing employees to work from home?
summary: Singapore companies are hesitant to adopt flexible work-from-home (FWHA) arrangements due to concerns about fairness, communication, teamwork, productivity, and camaraderie. Some employers, such as Audit Alliance and BR Metals, mandate full-time office attendance for certain roles, citing the need for face-to-face interaction and teamwork. However, initiatives are underway to promote FWAs, with the government describing them as a "national imperative" to attract workers and reduce family stress. New guidelines will be released next year to require companies to evaluate FWA requests fairly.

images.alt_text: laptop, work, coffee

site_title: Pheu Thai to seek senate support while sticking with allies
summary: Thailand's Pheu Thai Party, the second-largest winner in the May general election, will seek the support of the military-appointed Senate to form a government, aiming to prevent parties aligned with the establishment from returning to power. Led by ousted former premier Thaksin Shinawatra, the party will prioritize talks with Senate members to secure the necessary votes. If unsuccessful, Pheu Thai will consider seeking support from conservative parties outside the coalition, which commands a majority in the lower house.

images.alt_text: epa10751685 Pheu Thai Party's Prime Ministerial candidate Srettha Thavisin leaves party’s headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 17 July 2023. The Pheu Thai Party, which came in second place in the 14 May Thai general elections, is in talks to coalition parties and the progressive Move Forward Party ahead of the second round of Parliament's voting to elect next prime minister on 19 July.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK
“I would like to say goodbye until we meet again,” Pita Limjaroenrat tells the chamber, raising his fist as he leaves the assembly floor to the cheers of fellow lawmakers.
With Pita Limjaroenrat out of the running, Thailand remains in political limbo as the country awaits the identity of its next prime minister.

site_title: A sweaty robot may help humans understand impact of soaring heat
summary: Researchers at Arizona State University have deployed a robot, Andi, to study the impact of soaring heat on the human body. The humanoid robot, costing over half a million dollars, can breathe, shiver, and sweat, simulating how humans respond to extreme climate conditions. With its network of sensors and internal cooling system, Andi provides a safer alternative to human experimentation, helping researchers better understand hyperthermia and develop tailored solutions for heat protection, such as heat-resistant clothing and adjusted working hours.

images.alt_text: Italy’s Environment Ministry has warned in a report this year that foreign tourists will in future travel more in the spring and autumn and choose cooler destinations.
The 27-country EU has one of the most ambitious climate targets among major economies – having agreed in law to cut its net greenhouse gas emissions by 55 per cent by 2030, compared with 1990 levels.
A man uses water bottles for flotation as he cools off in a canal in Beijing. Swathes of northern China sweltered in 40 deg C on June 22.
Searing temperatures across Europe have crippled agriculture in France, forced Spain to cut water supply in some regions and triggered a state of emergency in parts of Italy.

site_title: Trans-cab acquisition risks giving Grab monopolistic pricing power
summary: Grab's proposed acquisition of Trans-Cab, a taxi company, is expected to require approval from authorities, with critics warning it could grant the company monopolistic pricing power. The acquisition follows a trend of ride-hailing companies adopting predatory practices in Singapore, leading to higher fares for consumers. Despite Grab's losses, the company is investing billions, and its fares may need to increase further for it to make a reasonable return. Authorities must assess the implications of the acquisition to ensure taxi services remain reasonably affordable.

images.alt_text: Grab will acquire Singapore's third-largest taxi operator, Trans-cab, through its subsidiary Grab Rentals.
Grab has revised its adjusted Ebitda range upwards as it says it is on track to breakeven on an adjusted Ebitda basis in the fourth quarter of this year.

site_title: Booz Allen pays US$377.5 million to settle US civil probe
summary: Booz Allen Hamilton Holding agreed to pay $377.5 million to settle a US civil investigation related to its cost accounting practices from 2011-2021. The US Department of Justice alleged that the company improperly charged government contract costs to commercial and international contracts. The settlement, considered one of the largest procurement fraud settlements in history, does not admit liability and was agreed upon to avoid protracted litigation. The company had previously recorded a $350 million reserve for possible exposure from the probe.

images.alt_text: Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, said nothing as he entered the courtroom or when he left roughly an hour later.

site_title: Twitter to change logo, bid adieu to ‘all the birds’: Musk
summary: Elon Musk announced plans to change Twitter's logo, tweeting that the company will "bid adieu to the Twitter brand and, gradually, all the birds." The logo change comes after Musk's acquisition of the platform, during which Twitter has changed its business name to X Corp and laid off over half its workforce. Musk posted an image of a flickering "X" logo and replied "yes" to a question about the logo change, stating it "should have been done a long time ago." The change is expected to take effect worldwide tomorrow if a good "X" logo is posted tonight.

images.alt_text: Twitter has been criticized over lax content moderation, followed by an exodus of many advertisers who did not want their ads appearing next to inappropriate content.

site_title: Taking stock of institutional and retail fund flows
summary: SGX-listed stocks experienced a net institutional fund outflow of S$2.8 billion and a net retail inflow of S$1.4 billion in the year to Jul 18. Companies such as Sembcorp Industries and Seatrium saw the most net institutional fund inflows, driven by pivots to sustainable infrastructure and high trading volumes. These companies ranked among Singapore's most traded stocks, with Sembcorp Industries ranking among the 15 most traded and Seatrium ranking as the sixth most traded.

site_title: Ray-Ban maker accused in lawsuit of inflating prices 1,000%
summary: EssilorLuxottica, the French-Italian eyewear company behind Ray-Ban and Oakley, is being sued for allegedly inflating prices by up to 1,000% by forming anti-competitive agreements with thousands of eye care providers and its vision benefits subsidiary, EyeMed, to steer consumers towards overpriced eyewear. The complaint, filed in San Francisco federal court, claims EssilorLuxottica is the "instigator and primary enforcer" of the price-fixing scheme in the US market.

site_title: Chip CEOs urge US to study impact of China curbs and take pause
summary: US chip CEOs, including Intel's Pat Gelsinger, Nvidia's Jensen Huang, and Qualcomm's Cristiano Amon, urged the Biden administration to study the impact of export restrictions on China and pause before implementing new ones. The executives argued that such restrictions risk harming US leadership in the industry and could harm chip production plans in the US. They pointed out that Chinese customers have found alternative solutions, such as buying more chips to compensate for banned products, and that the US needs access to the Chinese market to fuel research and development.

images.alt_text: The chip industry is keen to protect its profits in China as the Biden administration considers another round of restrictions on chip exports to China.

The industry group says it wants “the Biden administration to refrain from further restrictions until it engages more extensively with industry and experts to assess the impact of current and potential restrictions.

site_title: Darkening gloom plagues China stocks as politburo hopes dim
summary: China's key indexes are down for the year, losing out on a global rally, amid low expectations for the upcoming politburo meeting. Investors anticipate limited policy support, with some describing it as "incremental" rather than "bazooka-like" stimulus. Despite officials' promises to boost consumption and the property sector, market scepticism persists, with many focusing on specific sectors that align with policy goals. The CSI 300 benchmark fell 2% this week, and the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index lost 2.2%, making it one of the year's worst performers.

images.alt_text: The slump in the property market has weighed on China’s economic recovery, putting Beijing’s official growth target of around 5 per cent at risk.
Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to treat foreign investors better and called for greater opening up in recent weeks.

The benchmark CSI 300 Index of mainland shares will likely climb about 3 per cent this quarter while Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index may advance less than 6 per cent, according to the median estimate of 18 analysts and money managers surveyed by Bloomberg News last week.

site_title: Drahi’s Telecom empire wrestles with corruption probe fallout
summary: Patrick Drahi's telecommunications empire, Altice, is facing a crisis after a corruption probe in Portugal detained co-founder Armando Pereira, who is accused of alleged corruption, tax fraud, and money laundering. The company has suspended contracts with 60 suppliers, launched internal audits, and put several executives on leave, including Yossi Benchetrit and Alexandre Fonseca. The fallout is expected to slow work on some networks and impact investor confidence, with Moody's analysts warning of material weaknesses in internal controls.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Patrick Drahi, Franco-Israeli businessman and founder of cable and mobile telecoms company Altice Group attends the inauguration of the Altice Campus in Paris, France, October 9, 2018.  REUTERS/Philippe Wojazer/File Photo

site_title: Oil rallies for fourth straight week on tightening supply
summary: Oil prices rose for a fourth consecutive week, with Brent crude futures up 1.8% to $81.07 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 1.9% to $77.07 a barrel. The increase is attributed to growing supply shortages and rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine, which could further impact supplies. US shale oil and gas production is forecast to decline in August for the first time this year, adding to concerns of supply tightness.

images.alt_text: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and the International Energy Agency have said China’s demand is expected to continue to rise in the second half of this year and remain the main driver of global growth.
A crude oil tanker at an oil terminal off Waidiao island in Zhoushan, Zhejiang province, China.

site_title: Three mindfulness and meditation techniques that could help you manage work stress
summary: Research supports the effectiveness of mindfulness, attention-based meditation, and compassion meditation in managing work stress. Mindfulness involves observing thoughts, emotions, and physical sensations without judgment, helping detect early signs of stress. An effective mindfulness-based technique is the body scan, where individuals focus on relaxing tight muscles. Attention-based meditation uses anchors such as the breath to maintain focus, reducing stress and anxiety. Cultivating compassion through meditation can also help disengage from a critical inner voice and promote self-love and understanding. Regular practice can lead to improved emotional regulation and reduced stress.

images.alt_text: Company well-being initiatives aren’t always making it out of the boardroom.
The tasks employees perform are often not what leads to their mental health degradation. Instead, an employer’s culture and the way its jobs are designed play big roles.
If you're stuck in a work rut, delve into how and why you got there in order to work out how best to get out of it.

site_title: US plans water heater standards, says they will save consumers US$11 billion
summary: The US Department of Energy proposed energy efficiency standards for water heaters, aiming to save consumers $11.4 billion annually. The standards, set to take effect in 2029, would require electric water heaters to use heat pump technology and gas-fired water heaters to use condensing technology. The proposal is expected to save nearly $200 billion and reduce over 500 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions over 30 years. Environmental groups and efficiency organizations welcomed the move, while a water heater manufacturer expressed concerns that the standards would be "technologically impossible" and reduce consumer choice.

site_title: Dollar heads for best week since February as hawks linger
summary: The US dollar is expected to continue its recovery, with a 1% gain in the past five days, as traders await central bank meetings next week. The Federal Reserve meets on Wednesday, while the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan convene on Thursday and Friday, respectively. Traders are looking for guidance on the Fed's rate hike cycle and the BOJ's yield curve control program. The dollar's recovery comes as eurozone developments have raised questions about the hawkish central bank outlooks in the eurozone, UK, and Japan.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of six currencies, has fallen as low as 99.587, languishing near last Friday’s trough of 99.574, its lowest since April 2022.

site_title: Toyota eyes lunar rover powered by regenerative fuel cell tech
summary: Toyota plans to develop a manned lunar rover powered by regenerative fuel cell technology, with the goal of landing on the Moon in 2029. The rover, dubbed the Lunar Cruiser, will use solar energy and water to produce hydrogen and oxygen through electrolysis, allowing it to operate for extended periods, even in lunar night. Toyota hopes to secure an order for the rover by autumn 2024 and plans to use the Moon's water ice as an energy source in the future, although it will likely rely on other companies or future developments for this capability.

images.alt_text: Toyota topped overall passenger car registration figures for Singapore with 2,867 units in the first six months of 2023.

The administration’s proposal “underestimates key challenges, including the scarcity of minerals to make batteries, the fact that these minerals are not mined or refined in the US, the inadequate infrastructure and the high cost of battery-electric vehicles,” Toyota says.
Toyota says US sales in June come to 195,448 vehicles, up 15 per cent from a year ago.
Global sales of hybrids grew 25.8 per cent year-on-year to 261,147 units, accounting for just under a third of the total number of vehicles sold worldwide last month.
In Toyota’s case the total amount of the project to be subsidised is seen reaching 330 billion yen.

site_title: G-20 energy ministers meet as extreme heat spurs climate focus
summary: G20 energy ministers met in India to discuss climate action and shift away from fossil fuels amid extreme heat impacting Europe, the US, and Asia. The talks, led by UAE's Sultan Al Jaber, president of COP28, aim to lay the groundwork for a leaders' summit in September. The meeting seeks to reinvigorate energy diplomacy ahead of key global meetings this year, with climate change and energy security on the agenda.

images.alt_text: Adnoc group chief executive Sultan al-Jaber, who is also incoming president of the COP28 climate summit, notes that hydrogen will be a critical fuel for energy transition.
The 27-country EU has one of the most ambitious climate targets among major economies – having agreed in law to cut its net greenhouse gas emissions by 55 per cent by 2030, compared with 1990 levels.

site_title: Tornado at Pfizer plant exposes fragility of drug supply chain
summary: A category EF-3 tornado struck a Pfizer facility in North Carolina, causing significant damage to the company's warehouse and production lines. The facility, which produces 25% of sterile injectables used in US hospitals, may have lost up to three to four months' worth of production. The impact on the healthcare system is unclear, but the incident highlights the fragility of the US drug supply chain. Experts suggest that creating a government-funded reserve of vital medicines could help address shortages, and a government-backed inventory for vulnerable products is also being proposed as a solution.

site_title: The bear market has nearly been erased, fewer than 20 months after it began
summary: The US bear market, which began nearly 20 months ago, is nearing its end, with the S&P 500 just 260 points from being completely erased. Despite recession fears, economic indicators such as job growth, consumer spending, and corporate earnings are defying doomsayers. The stock market is experiencing a cross-sector surge, with economically sensitive shares driving the latest leg up, and momentum-driven funds are snapping up global shares. While concerns about valuations, inflation, and interest rates remain, some experts believe the optimism could persist, potentially leading to a faster-than-average recovery.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average is  in its strongest rally in almost six years.

site_title: Leon Black headed off Epstein lawsuit in US Virgin Islands deal
summary: Leon Black, co-founder of Apollo Global Management, reached a $62.5 million settlement with the US Virgin Islands to avoid a public legal battle over his business ties with Jeffrey Epstein. The deal mirrors those reached by banks doing business with Epstein while maintaining no involvement in his crimes. A spokesperson for Black stated the agreement reflects the typical approach taken by banks and financial institutions in similar situations.

images.alt_text: Leon Black, chairman and senior founding partner of Apollo Management, pauses during a lunch meeting on day three of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 30, 2009. site_title: Pfizer to end licence deal with Syros for blood disorder therapies
summary: Pfizer is terminating its licence deal with Syros for developing novel therapies for sickle cell disease and beta thalassemia, ending a three-year collaboration. The partnership, which began after Pfizer's acquisition of Global Blood Therapeutics in a $5.4 billion deal, will conclude on October 16. Syros plans to seek a new licensing partner for its sickle cell disease program following the termination.

site_title: Mazda CX-60 review: Advancing from the rear
summary: The Mazda CX-60 is a new sport utility vehicle (SUV) that marks a reboot for Mazda, offering a balance of driving pleasure, refinement, and practicality. With a rear-wheel-drive layout, the CX-60 is more balanced than average SUVs, providing better traction and uncorrupted steering. The interior is luxurious, with a calm and understated design, and features a 12.3-inch screen display. Although not a direct competitor to BMW or Mercedes-Benz, the CX-60 hits a sweet spot in terms of cabin quality and driving experience, making it a desirable option in its class.

images.alt_text: Flowing lines make the electric Rolls a graceful, almost waifish thing.
The Nissan X-Trail e-Power doesn’t need hours of charging, but it exhibits all the smooth urgency of an electric car, with much of the quietness.

site_title: Finding bright spots in Asean amidst a global slowdown
summary: The global economy is experiencing a slowdown, with recession forecasts varying between a sharp US recession and a more synchronized global recession. However, the Asean region offers some long-term plays, with large-scale foreign direct investment projects relocating to the area, including nickel mining and smelting to Indonesia. Despite labor market cooling and demand slowing, inflationary pressures are expected to ebb, allowing central banks to potentially ease monetary policies. Four long-term investment plays in Asean include banks, industrial goods producers, industrial real estate, and consumer names.

site_title: G7, others ask China to stop North Korea sanctions evasion in its waters
summary: The G7, EU, and several other countries plan to appeal to China to stop North Korea from evading UN sanctions by using Chinese territorial waters. The letter, signed by 13 countries, accuses North Korea of continuing to import and export sanctioned petroleum products through Chinese waters. The countries provide satellite images showing the practices occurred in 2022 and 2023. They request China to inspect vessels, deny services, and expel them from its waters if discovered. China has repeatedly said it abides by UN sanctions resolutions, but the letter urges China to take action to prevent sanctions evasion.

images.alt_text: “Unfortunately, the grain terminals of an agricultural enterprise in Odesa region were hit. The enemy destroyed 100 tons of peas and 20 tons of barley,” regional governor Oleh Kiper says.

site_title: Peruvian court opens door to legally recognise same-sex couples
summary: A Peruvian high court has ordered the registration of same-sex unions in public records, marking a victory for the LGBTQ community in the country. The ruling, made on July 21, followed a case brought by a gay Peruvian citizen who sued the registration office for refusing to record her 2019 marriage overseas. The court declared an article of the Peruvian Civil Code of 1984 on the family, which refers to marriage as the union between man and woman, as "inapplicable". This decision is seen as a step forward for LGBTQ rights in Latin America, where same-sex marriage has not been widely recognized.

site_title: Venezuela explores US$1.5 billion project with EU to curb emissions
summary: Venezuela is exploring a US$1.5 billion project with the European Union to capture methane emissions from its idle oil wells and export them as natural gas to Europe. The plan, which is in its early stages, aims to reduce pollution and bolster EU's natural gas supplies amid Russia's war with Ukraine. The project, involving Italian energy giant Eni and Spanish company Repsol, would use EU's Global Gateway Initiative funds and take about two years to complete.

images.alt_text: Producing milk through fermentation uses less water and emits fewer greenhouse gases than conventional dairy production.

site_title: Gold slips as dollar firms, focus on US Fed meet next week
summary: Gold prices fell on Friday, moving further away from a two-month peak, due to a stronger US dollar and cautious investor sentiment ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting next week. Spot gold dropped 0.3% to $1,962.85 per ounce, while US gold futures settled 0.2% lower. Analysts expect the Fed to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, potentially weakening gold prices and pushing them back into the $1,900-$2,000 range.

images.alt_text: Russia’s gold reserves stood at 74.9 million troy ounces at the start of July, the central bank said on Thursday.

site_title: US House committees investigate Ford Chinese battery partnership
summary: US House committees are investigating Ford Motor's partnership with Chinese battery company CATL, citing concerns over the company's reliance on China for inputs to produce electric vehicle batteries. The committees, led by Republican chairs Jason Smith and Mike Gallagher, are seeking answers about the deal and warn that it may expose US taxpayers to the Chinese Communist Party's politics. Ford has responded, stating it will own and run the plant in the US, but the committees are also scrutinizing CATL's ownership stake in companies connected to forced labor practices in Xinjiang.

images.alt_text: Ford has also strengthened its sourcing options and unveiled new supply deals for battery-grade lithium earlier this year.

site_title: Cambodia’s long-serving leader says son can become PM in 3-4 weeks
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen has indicated that his son Hun Manet, 45, may become the new prime minister in 3-4 weeks, following the country's one-sided election. Hun Manet, a US-educated military general, makes his debut as a candidate, and many analysts believe the election was designed to ensure a smooth transition of power to his father. The Cambodian People's Party (CPP) is running virtually unopposed, and human rights groups have dismissed the election as a sham, accusing Hun Sen of controlling the media and threatening critics.

images.alt_text: Meta, in a written statement, agreed to take down the video but said it would respond to the recommendation to suspend Hun Sen after a review.

Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Sen orders the rubber-stamp parliament to revise the law so that anyone who does not vote in the general election on Jul 23 will be barred from contesting any future elections.

site_title: Amazon builds US$120 million satellite processing hub in Florida
summary: Amazon is building a US$120 million satellite processing hub at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida for its Kuiper internet satellites. The 100,000 sq-ft facility, part of a US$10 billion investment, will employ 50 staff and process satellites before launch. The hub aims to complement Amazon's web services and compete with SpaceX's Starlink. Construction began in January, with a target to ship first satellites for processing in 2025 and deploy half of the network into orbit by 2026, as required by US regulators.

site_title: Satellite R&D facilities could be the future of specialised car development
summary: Polestar, a Swedish electric vehicle brand owned by Chinese auto giant Geely, is developing its two newest cars in a satellite research and development facility in the UK, far from its headquarters in Sweden. The facility, owned by Geely through Volvo, is faster and cheaper than conventional car development, with a 500-person team having high-level facilities such as a test track and wind tunnel. Polestar aims to roll out four luxury models by 2025, including the Polestar 5 and 6, which will compete with high-end sports cars like the Porsche Taycan and 911 Turbo Cabriolet.

images.alt_text: A Polestar 5 EV development prototype shown at the Polestar UK MIRA development facility.

site_title: BMW sees European electric car demand holding up as China pulls back
summary: BMW sees European electric car demand holding up, driven by 55% surge in EV orders, outpacing diesel sales. This growth helps offset a decline in orders in China, where overall car sales declined due to economic recovery. BMW aims for 15% of deliveries to be electric this year and 50% by 2030. The company's "Neue Klasse" electric platform, set to arrive in 2025, is expected to accelerate sales and cut battery costs by half.

BMW has shifted resources towards the development and marketing of its most expensive models to help finance the shift to electric vehicles.

site_title: India's Reliance misses profit view as oil-to-chemicals business drags
summary: Reliance Industries, India's most valuable company, reported a wider-than-expected drop in first-quarter profit due to its oil-to-chemicals (O2C) business being hurt by weak demand and a steep fall in refining margins. The O2C business, which accounts for the company's main growth engine, saw refining margins fall 60-70% from last year's highs. Consolidated profit fell to 160.11 billion rupees (S$2.6 billion) in the quarter, missing analysts' expectations.

The RBI’s move will make onshore and offshore pricing more aligned and also provide better liquidity, price discovery, transparency and access to market participants, HSBC says.
ETFs that exclusively buy Chinese shares continued to fail to get new inflows last week.

site_title: Better geographic investing begins with an inclusive index
summary: Researchers have developed a new index, called the Expectation-Maximization (EM) index, to track geographic risks in investing more accurately than traditional indices. By analyzing data from over 50,000 firms worldwide, the EM index better captures a firm's operational risks as a function of its exposure to various countries. The index is more representative of each country's risks, less volatile, and less correlated across countries compared to traditional indices. This tool can help asset managers make more informed investment decisions and better manage risks, particularly in an era of globalization.

images.alt_text: A blistering rally in growth and technology stocks has lifted the Nasdaq 100 index by 37.5 per cent this year.
Stock of Taiwanese chip giant TSMC has rallied strongly.

site_title: Women’s World Cup roundup: Spain, Switzerland coast to wins
summary: Spain dominated Costa Rica in a 3-0 Women's World Cup win, outshooting 45-1 and scoring three goals in a six-minute stretch. Switzerland also secured a 2-0 win over the Philippines, with Ramona Bachmann and Seraina Piubel scoring in a dominant display. Spain and Switzerland advance in the group stage, while Costa Rica faces Japan and the Philippines meets New Zealand.

site_title: UK pension fund USS wins appeal over fossil fuel investments
summary: The UK's Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS), a £82 billion pension fund, has won an appeal against a lawsuit over its investments in coal, natural gas, and petroleum. The lawsuit, brought by two academics, claimed that the investments posed a significant financial risk to the scheme. The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, ruling that the lawsuit was an attempt to challenge the scheme's management decisions, which was "bound to fail." The USS has welcomed the judgment, rejecting "meritless claims" that its investments have caused losses.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed; Dow up for tenth straight day
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising for its 10th straight day, its longest rally in almost six years. The Dow rose 0.01% to 35,227.69 points, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.03% to 4,536.34 points. Gains were led by Procter & Gamble and Chevron, while Nvidia and Meta Platforms lost 2% each. Analysts attributed the volatility to the expiration of monthly options and a special rebalancing of the Nasdaq 100.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 09: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during afternoon trading on January 09, 2023 in New York City. The stock market closed with mixed results after opening on a high note with the Dow Jones and S & P 500 both closing on losses and Nasdaq closing with a second day of gains.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Prosecutors accuse FTX's Bankman-Fried of witness tampering
summary: US prosecutors have accused FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried of witness tampering, alleging he shared private documents with the press to malign Caroline Ellison's credibility. Ellison, a key witness in the case, had pleaded guilty to defrauding investors. Bankman-Fried's lawyers confirmed he met with an author of a New York Times article and shared confidential documents. Prosecutors argue this conduct could chill witnesses and taint the jury pool, seeking a court order to bar Bankman-Fried from making public statements.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried has pleaded not guilty to several criminal charges.
FTX filed for bankruptcy in November 2022 after a run on customer deposits.
FTX has also filed lawsuits over its pre-bankruptcy investment in the stock platform Embed and its payments to Genesis Global Capital, the bankrupt lending arm of crypto firm Genesis.

site_title: Life in plastic, it’s not fantastic: tackling single-use plastic consumption
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency reports that plastic waste accounts for roughly one billion kilograms discarded in 2022, with 44% of ocean plastic consisting of food packaging. The food industry's reliance on single-use plastics poses a significant environmental and health risk. Experts estimate that consumers may be consuming five grams of microplastics weekly. To address the issue, governments can ban or restrict single-use plastics, and businesses can adopt sustainable packaging alternatives, such as compostable materials. Reducing single-use plastics can also enhance a company's brand reputation and customer loyalty, and is essential for long-term business success.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - A man looks at garbage and plastic waste floating next to fishing boats at a port in Banda Aceh on June 5, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)

site_title: Three magical nights, one festival of football
summary: Singapore's National Stadium will host the Singapore Festival of Football Driven by CDG Zig, featuring four teams: Liverpool, Bayern Munich, Tottenham Hotspur, and Leicester City. The event, set to begin on August 2, marks the start of the European football season, with fans eager to watch world-class football action after a three-year hiatus due to the pandemic. The festival will consist of three matches at the 55,000-seater National Stadium, with the teams competing in a unique format.

images.alt_text: Liverpool (in red) defeated Leicester 3-0 in the English Premier League on May 16. The two teams will play each other again in Singapore on Jul 30 at the National Stadium.
Chrono 24 co-chief executive officer Tim Stracke (left) says the size of Christiano Ronaldo's stake is a significant amount for the company.
Liverpool will play both Leicester City and Bayern Munich in two pre-season friendlies.
Hannah Wilkinson's winner put New Zealand on the right track towards their goal of getting out of the opening stage of the Women’s World Cup campaign.

site_title: Thailand unveils measures to trim US$469 billion household debt
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, has unveiled measures to reduce the country's high household debt, aiming to bring it down to 80% of gross domestic product from 90.6%. The bank plans to implement some measures from next year, while more complicated steps will be introduced later. Deputy Governor Ronadol Numnonda emphasized the need for gradual and long-term efforts to adjust borrower and lender behavior, as strong measures could harm the economy. The goal is to curb the debt level and support economic growth amid rising interest rates and uneven recovery.
