site_title: Issue 58: Incentivising EV adoption; an ESG bond falls out of favour
summary: Singapore's incentives for electric vehicle (EV) adoption are set to expire, raising concerns about the country's goal of having an entirely clean vehicle fleet by 2040. The country's EV adoption rate remains low at 14%, with charging infrastructure being a major factor. The Singapore Ministry of Transport has yet to announce its plans for the incentives, which critics argue can have unintended consequences, such as dealerships increasing prices of EVs. Sustainability-linked bonds, which were once popular, have also seen a decline in issuance in South-east Asia, with critics citing questionable KPIs and lack of science-based targets.

images.alt_text: The EV population is at its highest level to date, but still makes up only 1.3 per cent of the passenger car population.
An illustration of the Keppel Sakra Cogen Plant, which is envisaged to be able to save up to 220,000 tons of carbon dioxide per year.

Bankers pointed out that the downtrend comes amid an overall drop in bond and loan issuances, including non-ESG financing instruments, as global macroeconomic factors such as rising inflation and interest rate hikes have increased the costs of capital.
The South-east Asian country has at times faced fuel supply crunches due to tight global supplies or malfunctions at its local oil refineries.
The challenge for Singapore is how to aggregate and scale the carbon credit market, while preserving quality and maintaining product differentiation.

site_title: SGX RegCo to review Kitchen Culture’s potential listing-rule breaches
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is investigating potential listing-rule breaches by Kitchen Culture, following an independent review by Deloitte. The review found potential payroll irregularities, including unauthorised transactions, and potential internal control lapses. Deloitte discovered that Kitchen Culture's executive director, Lim Wee Li, hired two former employees for employment passes in exchange for monetary benefits, which could constitute offences under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act. The regulator will refer any infringements to the relevant authorities and will follow up with Deloitte to investigate potential listing-rule breaches.

images.alt_text: Private investor Tan Gin Tat had loaned S$1 million and S$500,000 to Kitchen Culture in two separate loan agreements in August and December 2022.
Kitchen Culture said the redesignation is due to the need for the chairperson of the board to lead the company forward following the recent changes made to the board announced on Jun 26.
Kitchen Culture has also secured a S$4 million loan to pay its debts and for general working capital.

site_title: JPMorgan to expand online bank Chase to Germany, EU
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon announced the expansion of its online bank Chase to Germany and other European Union countries, marking the company's first foray outside the US. This move increases competition for European rivals in the crowded market. JPMorgan previously entered the UK market with a digital-only retail offering in 2021, with plans to expand to other countries. The expansion aims to capitalize on growing demand for digital banking services in the EU.

images.alt_text: The 30-storey, 865,000-square-foot building has struggled in the past year.

site_title: Taiwan probes alleged leak of classified reports, diplomatic cables
summary: Taiwan is investigating a possible leak of classified documents, including diplomatic cables and reports, related to its bid to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade pact. Initial findings suggest some parts of the documents are real, while others were forged, but the origin of the leaked documents remains unclear. The leak comes at a delicate time for Taiwan, which is set to hold elections early next year and faces opposition from China, which claims Taiwan as its own.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Vice President and Chairman of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) William Lai gestures during his speech at the DPP headquarters in Taipei on April 12, 2023. - Lai will represent the DPP running for presidential elections in 2024. (Photo by Sam Yeh / AFP)

site_title: World Bank's IFC considers US$1.5 billion in investments in Ukraine banking, farming and infrastructure
summary: The World Bank's International Finance Corporation (IFC) is considering $1.5 billion in investments in Ukraine's banking, agribusiness, and infrastructure sectors. The lender has provided nearly $400 million in support since Russia's invasion 17 months ago, with a focus on the agribusiness sector and plans to support the banking sector. The IFC aims to deliver the investments within 12-18 months, with potential for private investors to contribute $140 billion to Ukraine's reconstruction and recovery, estimated at $411 billion.

images.alt_text: Head of World Bank Ajay Banga told a summit on financing the fight against climate change that the multilateral lender would adopt a new approach that “significantly expands the World Bank’s toolkit”.

site_title: China to rate sponsor institutions’ performance in assisting listed firms
summary: China's Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges have introduced guidelines to rate the performance of sponsor institutions, such as brokerages, that assist listed firms. Assessments will focus on the quality of listed firms, including management competency, market performance, and governance. Scores will be given and sponsors categorized into A, B, or C, with those receiving C for three consecutive times subject to on-site supervision. The move aims to combat capital market fraud as part of the government's reforms.

site_title: Gig workers can tap existing investment and financial solutions
summary: Gig workers in Singapore can tap into existing investment and financial solutions ahead of upcoming legal protections. With about 257,000 own-account workers, or 9% of the resident labour force, these individuals face unique challenges, including access to suitable investment and financial products. To achieve their financial goals, tailored solutions are required, particularly addressing healthcare concerns and retirement adequacy. Proactive steps can be taken by gig workers to prepare for upcoming legal protections, which aim to provide better financial security for this demographic.

images.alt_text: Dr Koh also provided several updates on implementation details of the new legislation.
While Grab, Foodpanda and Deliveroo say “appetite for union support is seemingly low”, independent research shows a need for platform workers to have greater bargaining power.

site_title: OpenAI, Google, others pledge to watermark AI content for safety
summary: Seven major tech companies, including OpenAI, Google, and Meta Platforms, have pledged to implement measures to make AI-generated content safer. The companies will develop a system to watermark all forms of content, from text to videos, to inform users when AI technology was used. The move follows the Biden administration's efforts to regulate the technology, which has experienced significant investment and consumer popularity. The companies also commit to thoroughly testing systems before release and investing in cybersecurity to reduce risks.

images.alt_text: Apple has created a chatbot service that some engineers call Apple GPT.

site_title: Shanghai stops accepting new ride-hailing drivers in overcrowded market
summary: Shanghai, China, has stopped accepting new ride-hailing driver applications due to an overcrowded market, following similar moves in other cities. The city's fleet already numbers 126,000, and authorities have suspended capacity checks and will stop accepting new licenses from September. This decision aims to address market saturation, with many drivers facing a lack of orders, and average daily order volumes falling below ten in some cities. The move is part of efforts to regulate the ride-hailing industry and manage the surge in flexible working jobs.

images.alt_text: Baidu's fleet of robotaxis, under the brand Apollo Go, will be allowed to operate across an area of 188 square kilometres in China’s southern tech hub Shenzhen.
In January, Didi’s main apps returned to China’s biggest mobile stores, paving the way for the company to resume business as usual, and to eventually work towards a Hong Kong listing.

site_title: Russia’s weaponising of wheat won’t hurt the world
summary: Russia's wheat embargo on Ukraine, imposed in response to the invasion, has largely been ineffective due to low global wheat prices, which have fallen nearly 50% from their 2022 peak. Despite the West's denunciation of the move, Russia's own wheat exports have surged to an all-time high, limiting any extra gains from the embargo. The West has limited options to respond, and Ukraine is struggling with the loss of its main export route. Global food prices are down more than a fifth from their 2022 peak, and Russia's actions may even be contributing to keeping prices under control.

images.alt_text: Ukraine and Russia are among the world’s top grain exporters.

Mukesh Sahdev, senior vice president and head of downstream at Rystad Energy, said that over the past 35 years, geopolitical events in big oil producers have increased oil prices by an average of 8 per cent over the five days after the start of the triggering event.

site_title: AmEx beats profit estimates as card spending rises
summary: American Express (AmEx) reported a profit of $2.89 per share in the second quarter, beating analysts' expectations of $2.81 per share. The company's affluent customer base continued to spend, driven by double-digit growth in US Consumer and International Card Member spending. Total network volumes rose 8% to $426.6 billion, and total revenue increased 12% to $15.05 billion. The boost in consumer spending helped offset the creation of bigger rainy-day funds to guard against an economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Amex cardholders received erroneous text messages about temporary card suspensions on Thursday.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: American Express logo and trading symbol are displayed on a screen at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., December 6, 2017. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: China seeks to boost demand by pushing urban development
summary: China's cabinet approved guidelines to transform "urban villages" in megacities, aiming to boost demand and support the economy. The move comes as the country's post-Covid recovery falters due to weakening demand at home and abroad. The transformation of underdeveloped areas poses a threat to public safety and social governance, prompting the government to take action. This initiative is part of China's efforts to stimulate the economy and address growing pressures on policymakers.

site_title: Vietnam calls for domestic food security after India’s rice export ban
summary: Vietnam urges its rice traders to balance exports and domestic sales to stabilize domestic prices, following India's move to curb its rice exports. India, the world's largest rice exporter, has ordered a halt to its largest rice export category to reduce domestic prices. Vietnam's Ministry of Industry and Trade stated that India's move will affect the global rice market, highlighting the need for domestic food security. The call comes as Vietnam aims to ensure sufficient domestic rice supplies and stabilize prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Labourers unload rice bags from a supply truck at India's main rice port at Kakinada Anchorage in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, India, September 2, 2021. Picture taken September 2, 2021. REUTERS/Rajendra Jadhav/File Photo

site_title: Laguna National club owner Peter Kwee and daughter Karen embroiled in property lawsuit
summary: Peter Kwee, owner of Laguna National club, and his daughter Karen are embroiled in a property lawsuit over a three-storey semi-detached house in Bukit Timah. Businessman Low Kai Yang claims Karen agreed to grant him an option to purchase (OTP) for the property, securing an S$800,000 loan, but Karen disputes this, stating she was not informed of any loan agreement. The lawsuit, which began in 2022, is now pending in court with Low seeking S$800,000 plus interest. A mortgagee sale of the property was initiated in April 2023, resulting in a sale price of S$4.2 million.

images.alt_text: Karen Kwee's house

site_title: US: Wall St rises as megacaps rebound, Dow set for tenth day of gains
summary: Wall Street rose on Friday, with the Dow set for its tenth consecutive day of gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with the S&P 500 up 0.34% at 4,550.16 and the Nasdaq up 0.60% at 14,148.18. This rebound follows sharp losses in the previous session, as megacap growth and technology stocks recovered.

site_title: Sri Lanka consumer inflation slows to 10.8% y/y in June
summary: Sri Lanka's consumer price inflation slowed to 10.8% year-over-year in June, down from 22.1% in May, due to a moderation in food price rises and a stronger rupee. Food prices rose 2.5% in June, while non-food items rose 18.3%. The National Consumer Price Index (NCPI) is expected to hit single-digit levels by the end of July, with some analysts predicting 8.5% inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past the main entrance of the Sri Lanka's Central Bank in Colombo, Sri Lanka March 24, 2017. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo
Sri Lanka’s economy shrank at a slower pace last quarter as fresh funds eased widespread shortages.
The Colombo All-Share Index climbed as much as 4.7 per cent, its biggest gain in more than a year.
FILE PHOTO: A vendor sells vegetables to a customer amid the rampant food inflation, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, July 29 , 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Global investors tell Modi plans to pump in US$4 billion at risk due to gaming tax
summary: India's 28% gaming tax has sparked concerns among global investors, including Tiger Global, Peak XV, and Steadview Capital, who claim it will deter US$4 billion in prospective investments and harm the sector's growth. The tax, which targets funds collected from online gaming customers, has been criticized as a "social evil" by some government officials, despite pleas from the industry. The investors are urging Prime Minister Narendra Modi to review the tax, citing the risk it poses to the sector's growth and existing investments of over US$2.5 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Dream11 and MPL logos are displayed in front of the Indian flag in this Illustration taken September 14, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Tony Bennett dies at 96
summary: Tony Bennett, the American singer known for his smooth voice and enduring hits like "I Left My Heart in San Francisco," has died at 96. Born Anthony Dominick Benedetto in 1926, Bennett rose to fame in the 1950s with hits like "Because of You" and "Cold, Cold Heart." He continued to perform and record music well into his 90s, collaborating with artists like Lady Gaga and Paul McCartney. Bennett was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease in 2016 but continued to record music until his retirement in 2021.

images.alt_text: Many said her life story was an inspiration as she overcame abuse during her marriage to Ike Turner and emerged as a star on her own.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB expects faster order book executions from CSE Global, raises target
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for CSE Global to S$0.45 from S$0.37, citing faster order book executions due to easing global supply-chain pressures. The research team expects a 9-21% core EPS increase and 11-13% revenue growth for FY2023-2025. Analysts predict a yield of 6.7% for FY2023 and consider Q2 2023 as an "inflection point" for the company, leading to a clearer earnings recovery path.

images.alt_text: Lim Boon Kheng, CSE Global's group managing director, noted that the company's diversification strategy has turned its infrastructure segment into a key revenue growth driver for the group.
Lim Boon Kheng, chief executive of CSE Global, said the company's margins have been impacted by higher project execution costs due to ongoing supply chain disruptions, and project cost overruns.

site_title: Russia hits Ukraine’s grain for fourth day, practises seizing ships
summary: Russia has launched attacks on Ukraine's grain export facilities for the fourth consecutive day, targeting key infrastructure and threatening global food supplies. The attacks follow a vow by Ukraine to defy Russia's naval blockade on its grain export ports. Moscow claims the strikes are revenge for a Ukrainian strike on a Russian-built bridge to Crimea. The UN Security Council is set to meet over the humanitarian consequences of Russia's withdrawal from a safe sea corridor deal, which aid groups say is vital to stem growing hunger in poorer countries.

images.alt_text: A view shows a grain warehouse destroyed by a Russian missile strike, amid Russia's attack on Ukraine, at a compound of an agricultural company in Odesa region, Ukraine July 21, 2023. Press Service of the the Operational Command South of the Ukrainian Armed Forces/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY.

site_title: China briefs trade partners on new anti-espionage law
summary: China has briefed major trade partners, including the US, on its new anti-espionage law, which took effect this month. The law bans the transfer of information related to national security and interests without clear definitions, and expands the definition of spying to include cyberattacks. Chinese officials, led by Assistant Commerce Minister Chen Chunjiang, emphasized the country's commitment to creating a fair business environment. The law grants authorities access to data, electronic equipment, and personal property, and allows for exit bans. This comes amid growing uncertainty for foreign companies about the law's scope.

site_title: Chinese property giant Country Garden sinks in renewed storm
summary: Country Garden, a Chinese property giant with thousands of projects, has refinished part of a 2019 loan facility, sending its Hong Kong-listed shares down over 5% and its bonds to record lows. The move comes as the sector faces a crisis, with analysts warning that sales must improve for developers to avoid repayment issues. Country Garden has over $40 billion of debt, and its bondholder says the company is facing a further batch of bond payments in coming months, adding to concerns about the government's approach to the crisis and potential support for the sector.

images.alt_text: The warnings add to concerns that China could be about to suffer its biggest property developer default since Evergrande.
Evergrande’s financial woes even started to affect operations at the building, which sits in Hong Kong’s busy Wan Chai district.
China’s property sector, which accounts for about a quarter of the economy, remains firmly in a downtrend, with property sales and investment recording double-digit falls.
Shanghai-based Greenland has failed to make a payment for the 6.75 per cent June 2024 bond with an outstanding US$432 million.

site_title: Singapore shares end week slightly higher, STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,278.30 on Friday, driven by bargain hunting in the local capital market amid a slew of corporate earnings results and macroeconomic data releases. Top gainers included UOB, DBS, and Singapore Exchange, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was the top loser. Market strategist Charu Chanana noted that big tech companies must justify stretched valuations to support the equity rally, but any disappointment could lead to a rotation into cyclicals and quality stocks.

images.alt_text: Previous Chinese law requires company insiders such as board directors to return profits earned from short-term share trades to the company. The new rules would help clarify when those requirements apply.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Manila and Jakarta edged up but Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Wellington dipped.

site_title: OpenAI's head of trust and safety steps down
summary: Dave Willner, OpenAI's head of trust and safety, is stepping down due to the pressures of the job affecting his family life. Willner cited his decision in a LinkedIn post, stating he would prioritize his family over his job. The move comes as fears about AI misuse and abuse continue to rise, with OpenAI relying on its trust and safety team to prevent such misuse. Willner's departure leaves a void in the company's trust and safety department, which has taken on a high-profile role in limiting harmful content on platforms.

images.alt_text: Apple has created a chatbot service that some engineers call Apple GPT.
The government has had early access to some of the latest capabilities of OpenAI, the developer of ChatGPT, said Dr Janil Puthucheary (pictured).
Infosys launched a platform called Infosys Topaz for generative artificial intelligence in late May.

site_title: Global retailers cash in on Barbie film craze
summary: Global retailers are capitalizing on the release of the Barbie film by offering a wide range of products, including clothing, accessories, and home items, aimed at adults and children alike. Retailers such as Zara, H&M, and Gap have launched Barbie collections, while brands like Crocs and Beis have also gotten in on the trend. The craze is expected to boost revenues for retailers, despite concerns about over-saturation. The film's emphasis on diversity and inclusivity may help keep the brand's appeal fresh, with Mattel aiming to renew the doll's nostalgic appeal and embed it in the psyche of a new generation.

images.alt_text: The two A-listers do tremendous justice to Gerwig’s sparkling dialogue, and take full advantage of the opportunity to flex their physical comedy muscles with hilarious results.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Caution rules the trading week (Ep 52)
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a cautious week, with muted market movements. The main driver of the week's market movements was mixed economic data. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a slight decline in trading volume. The podcast also highlighted notable news, including the impact of global events on the markets. The week's cautious tone was attributed to uncertainty surrounding economic trends and geopolitical developments.

images.alt_text: A positive week for markets?
How did mixed economic data affect markets this week?

site_title: Ramsay, Sime Darby kick off US$1.5 billion hospital unit sale, sources say
summary: Ramsay Health and Sime Darby are selling their joint venture hospital unit, Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care, for up to $1.5 billion. The sale comes amid Malaysia's consideration of a capital gains tax on unlisted share disposals. The companies have invited healthcare firms and private equity groups to submit non-binding bids by August. This marks the second attempt to sell the hospital unit, following a failed discussion with IHH Healthcare in September. The sale process is ongoing, with no final decisions made.

images.alt_text: IHH Healthcare confirms offer to buy Ramsay-Sime Darby JV for RM5.67b

site_title: Glencore says trading unit may earn US$4 billion this year
summary: Glencore forecasts a profit of $3.5 billion to $4 billion from its commodity trading business this year, falling short of the record $6.4 billion in 2022 but still above its guidance range. The company expects to beat its long-term target for trading profit for a fourth consecutive year. A reduction in volatility has allowed Glencore to release working capital, and the industry's boom year in 2022 is normalizing. The company plans to return more than $7 billion to shareholders in dividends and buybacks.

images.alt_text: The deal comes as a mining M&A spree picks up, spurred in part by investors betting on rising demand for metals needed for the global green energy transition in coming years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Global private equity firms hold a record $2.49 trillion in dry powder, the highest level since 2000. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) health worsened in Q2, but business owners remain positive. Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong plans to nominate Seah Kian Peng as the new Speaker of Parliament. Meanwhile, Hong Leong Asia opens a precast facility in Punggol to diversify its supply chain. The Healthier SG initiative brings lower healthcare costs for patients but uncertain benefits for GPs. Local shares ended the week slightly higher, with the STI up 0.1%.

site_title: Private equity dry powder hits record US$2.49 trillion as dealmaking slows: S&P
summary: Global private equity firms hold a record $2.49 trillion in dry powder as of July 3, up 11.2% from the previous year. Sluggish dealmaking in 2023 has limited opportunities for deployment, attributed to an uncertain global economic outlook, rising transaction costs, and increased regulatory scrutiny. However, challenging conditions have created potential opportunities for investors to invest in undervalued companies. Experts expect a significant increase in deal activity in 2024 and 2025 as pricing returns to fair value and recession fears fade.

images.alt_text: The number of private equity deals fall 23.3 per cent to 46.
The Asia-Pacific witnessed the second-highest private equity deal values in June, with 258 transactions totalling US$7.1 billion.
Blackstone now oversees US$1.001 trillion, up from US$940.8 billion a year earlier.
Stock markets have been more or less closed to initial public offers of PE companies for 18 months now, according to Dealogic data.

site_title: PM Sunak avoids wipeout in key elections
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's governing Conservatives lost two parliamentary seats, but retained Boris Johnson's old constituency, giving him some breathing space before a national election next year. Labour leader Keir Starmer's party overtook the Conservatives in the safe seat of Selby and Ainsty, while the Conservatives retained Uxbridge and South Ruislip by fewer than 500 votes. Despite the losses, Labour's lead in polls remains, but the results suggest a hung parliament and a possible change in the dynamics of the election.

images.alt_text: Zac Goldsmith accused Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of abandoning his commitments to climate change, environmental protections and animal welfare.

site_title: China’s securities regulator issues draft of new short-swing trading rules
summary: China's securities regulator has issued a draft of new short-swing trading rules to limit insider trading. The new rules aim to clarify when company insiders, such as board directors, must return profits earned from short-term share trades to the company. The rules will not affect ordinary investors and are intended to standardize supervision, stabilize market expectations, and improve trading convenience. The regulator will solicit opinions until August 20, as the move aims to enhance the attractiveness of China's A-share market.

images.alt_text: China’s blue-chip CSI 300 Index edges down 0.11 per cent, while the Shanghai Composite Index ends flat.
China’s blue-chip CSI 300 Index ends 0.8 per cent lower, while the Shanghai Composite Index declines 0.9 per cent.

site_title: Philippines will not cooperate with ICC in drugs war probe, says Marcos
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. announced his government will not cooperate with the International Criminal Court's (ICC) probe into thousands of killings during his predecessor's 'war on drugs'. Marcos maintained the ICC has no jurisdiction, citing the country's withdrawal in 2019. The ICC rejected the Philippines' attempt to block the investigation, and Marcos stated the alleged crimes must be dealt with domestically. The justice ministry has promised a fair investigation into the drugs war, defending the Philippines' sovereignty and questioning the ICC's jurisdiction.

images.alt_text: epa10753381 Supporters and relatives of drug war victims hold a solidarity rally after watching a broadcast of the International Criminal Court (ICC) in Quezon City, Metro Manila, Philippines, 18 July 2023. The ICC on 18 July issued a decision to continue an investigation into alleged crimes and human rights violations during the drug war campaign of former President Rodrigo Duterte, a move that rejected an opposing appeal from the Philippine government.  EPA-EFE/ROLEX DELA PENA

site_title: Aztech Global H1 net profit up 0.2% to S$42.9 million on higher sales
summary: Aztech Global reported a 0.2% increase in net profit to S$42.9 million for its first half of 2023, driven by a 6.6% rise in revenue to S$388.6 million. The revenue growth was mainly attributed to an increase in sales of IoT devices and data communication products. Higher employee benefits and operating expenses offset the gains, resulting in a similar net profit to the previous year. Earnings per share rose to 5.56 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: On May 16, Aztech Global executive chairman and CEO Michael Mun Hong Yew acquired 500,000 shares at S$0.70 per share.
Tech manufacturing counters take a beating in Q1 on weak end-consumer demand
Michael Mun, executive chairman (right) and chief executive officer, as well as Jeremy Mun, executive director and chief operating officer for Aztech Global.

site_title: Yen slides after sources say BOJ leaning to holding key policy
summary: The yen slid against the US dollar after a Reuters report that the Bank of Japan (BOJ) is leaning towards keeping its key yield control policy unchanged next week, amid concerns over inflation. Core inflation in Japan rose to 3.3% in data released earlier in the session, matching market forecasts but remaining ahead of the BOJ's 2% target. The BOJ is set to review its policy at a meeting on July 27-28, with investors awaiting data to gauge the likely path of monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Thailand election winners make way for allies after PM bid fails
summary: Thailand's election-winning Move Forward party will form a government with its alliance partner Pheu Thai after its leader's bid was thwarted by a military-backed Senate. Despite a May 14 election victory, the two parties face an obstacle in the 249-member Senate, which has blocked previous attempts to form a government. Pheu Thai has announced plans to nominate 60-year-old Srettha Thavisin for prime minister on July 27, aiming to overcome the Senate's opposition to their anti-establishment agenda, including reforming the military and amending article 112 of the criminal code.

images.alt_text: “I would like to say goodbye until we meet again,” Pita Limjaroenrat tells the chamber, raising his fist as he leaves the assembly floor to the cheers of fellow lawmakers.

site_title: Startups are producing real dairy without a cow in sight
summary: Startup companies like Better Dairy and Perfect Day are producing synthetic dairy products through precision fermentation, eliminating the need for cows and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. These plant-based milk alternatives use yeast to convert sugar into milk proteins, similar to brewing. With rising concerns about food security and climate change, synthetic dairy has the potential to disrupt the $900 billion global dairy market, offering a more sustainable and allergen-friendly alternative to traditional dairy products.

images.alt_text: Singapore is among the top five countries globally for the availability of “meat substitutes” in restaurant menus, according to GlobalData.
The whey protein in Perfect Day's Very Dairy milk is made in a lab, using a bioengineered form of the fungus Trichoderma reesei.
Alternative proteins are those that do not involve the slaughter of animals; they may be plant-based, fermented using microbes, or cultivated from animal cells.

site_title: Builder Skanska profit falls as property market slump weighs
summary: Skanska, the Nordic region's largest builder, reported a 44% drop in second-quarter operating earnings to 1.33 billion Swedish kronor (S$170.3 million) due to a slump in its property development businesses. Despite robust construction performance, soaring inflation and interest rate hikes have hit the property market, weighing on the construction sector. Skanska forecasts weaker markets for both residential and commercial property over the coming months, while construction is expected to remain strong in the US.

images.alt_text: A Skanska building site stands in Jonkoping, Sweden, on Tuesday, Nov. 25, 2008. Skanska AB, Swedens biggest builder, will cut about 3,400 jobs in Nordic countries as a slump in the European housing market spreads to commercial and civil building. Photographer: Anna Hallams/Bloomberg News

site_title: A fan’s front-row view of Taylor Swift’s success
summary: Taylor Swift's Eras Tour has been a global phenomenon, with her devoted fan base, known as Swifties, driving travel to Singapore and fueling a cultural event. The 10-date tour in Southeast Asia has sparked a frenzy among fans, with over 300,000 tickets sold out in hours. Swift's interactions with fans, both online and offline, have redefined the fan-celebrity relationship, earning her a reputation for thoughtfulness and sincerity. The tour is expected to generate $5 billion in consumer spending in the US alone, cementing Swift's status as a cultural icon.

images.alt_text: On top of increased search activity for the duration of Swift's Singapore concerts, more actual bookings have also been made at hotels, and some flight prices are recording increases.
Klook packages including Category 1  Taylor Swift concert tickets sell out within two hours.

site_title: South Korea export recovery to be sluggish compared with past: central bank
summary: South Korea's exports are expected to recover at a sluggish pace due to structural changes in the Chinese economy, according to the Bank of Korea. Recent weakness in China-bound exports, 35% due to higher competitiveness of Chinese companies, will hinder the recovery. Exports are not expected to rebound as much as in the past, with a 15% drop in exports for the first 20 days of July. Automobile exports are expected to continue growing gradually, while semiconductor exports remain weak.

images.alt_text: Officials at the BOK remain cautious about whether the annual declines will continue.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia opens precast facility in Punggol to beef up supply chain
summary: Hong Leong Asia (HLA) has opened its 3.8-hectare precast facility in Punggol, Singapore, to strengthen its supply chain and increase local production of building materials. The facility, a joint venture with Sunway Construction Group, can produce 100,000 cubic meters of precast elements for 2,500 dwelling units annually. HLA aims to diversify and balance its supply chain, with plans to recoup investments over time. The facility is the largest of its kind in Singapore and will strengthen the company's supply chain resilience.

site_title: Indonesia Q2 FDI growth slowest in 1½ years
summary: Indonesia's foreign direct investment (FDI) growth slowed to 14.2% in the April-June quarter, the lowest pace in 1.5 years. FDI reached 186.3 trillion rupiah (S$16.48 billion), driven by investment in manufacturing and battery materials. Singapore was the largest source of FDI, followed by China, Hong Kong, Japan, and the US. Authorities warn of a potential slowdown in foreign investment due to uncertainty ahead of Indonesia's general elections in 2024.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's imports have fallen 18.35 per cent on a yearly basis to US$17.15 billion.

site_title: Infosys dives 10% after outlook cut renews tech spending fears
summary: Infosys fell 10% after cutting its annual sales forecast, sparking concerns about tech spending. The company now expects 1-3.5% revenue growth, down from 4-7%. Analysts had predicted 7% growth. CEO Salil Parekh cited clients slowing down transformation programs and discretionary work, particularly in financial services. Despite this, Parekh remains optimistic about long-term prospects as companies adopt new technologies like generative AI. Infosys's shares have fallen 4% this year, trailing the broader Mumbai market's 11% gain.

images.alt_text: Infosys launched a platform called Infosys Topaz for generative artificial intelligence in late May.
The partnership involves Infosys working with Danske to accelerate the bank’s technological transformation.

site_title: PM Lee to nominate Seah Kian Peng as Speaker of Parliament following Tan Chuan-Jin’s exit
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong plans to nominate Seah Kian Peng as the new Speaker of Parliament, succeeding Tan Chuan-Jin who stepped down due to an "inappropriate relationship." Seah, a 61-year-old MP from Marine Parade GRC, previously served as Deputy Speaker from 2011 to 2015. The nomination is set to take effect at the next Parliament sitting in August, with Seah assisted by two deputies, including Acting Speaker Jessica Tan.

images.alt_text: PM Lee says the resignations of Tan (left) and Cheng (right) are necessary to “maintain the high standards of propriety and personal conduct which the PAP has upheld all these years”.
For the first time in many years, Singapore finds itself confronting the possibility of corruption involving an active minister and a prominent member of the business community.
Ng Kok Song and his fiance Sybil Lau arrived at the Elections Department shortly past 10.30am on Wednesday to pick up an application form for the certificate of eligibility

site_title: Healthier SG a shot in the arm for patients, less so for GPs?
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG initiative aims to improve patient outcomes and reduce healthcare costs by encouraging residents to enroll with participating clinics. While patients benefit from lower costs and greater convenience, general practitioners (GPs) face increased administrative costs and potential losses in medication revenue. GPs must adapt to new digital systems and processes, which can be burdensome. Despite these challenges, many GPs remain optimistic about the initiative's long-term benefits, emphasizing the importance of clinical outcomes over financial gains.

images.alt_text: Bringing automation to clinics
The interest in preventive health technology has been rising globally.

By ensuring a productive economy, creating aged-friendly living environments, assuring retirement adequacy, reforming the healthcare system and continuing to practice good governance, Singapore can stay economically vibrant even as it ages, says Healthcare Minister Ong Ye Kung.

site_title: Fast fashion report cards show what’s really in your clothes
summary: Fast fashion brands like Shein, Inditex (Zara), and H&M are under scrutiny for their reliance on synthetic fabrics, particularly polyester, which contributes to the world's growing textile waste and carbon emissions. Polyester, made from petroleum and taking up to 200 years to decompose, makes up 64% of Shein's mix, while Inditex and H&M use 27% and 21%, respectively. Despite industry efforts to increase recycling, consumers still discard millions of garments, and cotton, a natural fabric, requires intensive inputs and water. The fashion industry's focus on quantity over quality has led to an almost doubling of global fibre production over the past two decades.

images.alt_text: China fast-fashion retailer Temu blasts rival Shein over ‘exclusionary tactics’
Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase are among the banks helping Shein with its IPO preparation, according to six of the sources.

site_title: China announces steps to boost sales of cars, electronics
summary: China has announced measures to boost car and electronics sales, amid weak domestic demand and a price war. The government will encourage regions to increase annual car purchase quotas and support second-hand vehicle sales. Authorities also plan to apply domestic AI technology to improve electronic products. The goal is to shore up the slowing economy, while warning against protectionist policies and competition that could fuel a vicious cycle. The measures aim to stimulate growth in the automobile sector, a key area of focus for policymakers.

images.alt_text: Seven of the 10 manufacturers showed worse progress towards their goals than in the first half of last year.

site_title: Blackstone taps strong Japanese demand with private credit fund
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, has tapped strong demand for a private credit fund in Japan, raising over 40 billion yen (S$379.24 million) in its first two months. The fund invests in US loans to speculative-grade companies, offering returns of around 12%, compared to 7.5% two years ago. This has made it appealing to Japan's wealthy investors, who have been affected by the Bank of Japan's monetary policy. Blackstone's chief of credit, Dwight Scott, expects the credit market to remain resilient in any downturn, despite rising defaults.

images.alt_text: Blackstone now oversees US$1.001 trillion, up from US$940.8 billion a year earlier.

site_title: Hong Kong's golfers battle housing policy that threatens famed course
summary: Hong Kong's government plans to repossess a fifth of the 172-hectare Fanling golf course land to build 12,000 public houses, sparking opposition from golfers and environmental experts. The move, scheduled for September 1, could harm the city's international image and threaten the exclusive club's financial future. Despite the government's determination to follow statutory procedures, prominent figures and non-profit organizations are mobilizing against the plan, citing financial, environmental, and cultural concerns. The Hong Kong Golf Club has applied for a UNESCO cultural heritage conservation award to preserve the course's historical and nature conservation value.

images.alt_text: The mortgage easing comes after Hong Kong lowered the stamp duty for first-time buyers of cheaper homes in February.

site_title: YouTube hikes prices for US premium subscribers for the first time
summary: YouTube has increased prices for its US premium subscribers for the first time since its launch in 2018. The YouTube Premium plan now costs $13.99 per month, up $2 from before, and the annual plan costs $139.99, up $20. Existing subscribers who signed up five years ago will receive three additional months of the old price. This move follows similar price hikes by other music streaming services, including YouTube Music, Amazon Music, Apple Music, and Tidal.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate as US jobs data knocks rate hopes
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Friday as US jobs data knocked hopes of two more Federal Reserve interest rate hikes, adding to concerns about China's economy. Despite a rally last week, investors remained cautious due to ongoing worries about the US labor market and China's economic recovery. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Manila, and Jakarta edged up, while Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, and Wellington dipped. Analysts expect further downward pressure on corporate earnings and a possible stimulus package from Beijing, which may be announced at the end of July.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Manila, Jakarta and Wellington rose. However, Tokyo and Singapore dropped.

site_title: SME health worsens in Q2, but business owners still upbeat: OCBC
summary: Singapore's SME health worsened in Q2, with the OCBC SME Index contracting to 49.0, down from 49.9 in Q1. Collections and payments fell by 11.3% and 9.5% year-on-year, respectively. Domestic-oriented sectors like building and construction, education, and business services performed well, but externally-oriented sectors like ICT, transport, and logistics were weak. The index is expected to ease further in Q3 due to economic uncertainties. Despite this, business sentiment remains positive, with about 49% of business owners expecting their business to improve for the rest of 2023.

images.alt_text: Technology companies can share their expertise by offering short online courses on in-demand tech and digital skills, at low to no cost.
The index was weighed down by weaknesses in externally-oriented industries, such as transport and logistics.
Linus Goh, OCBC's head of global commercial banking, believes there is a chance that SMEs will still remain in expansionary territory for the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Carmakers race to meet targets in China as price cuts backfire
summary: China's top automakers are struggling to meet their sales targets, with seven of 10 manufacturers showing worse progress in the first half of 2023 compared to the same period last year. Despite deep price cuts, sales growth is far below the 30% expansion recorded in 2021, with overall car sales increasing 2.7% to 9.52 million units. The price war, which was sparked by Tesla, appears to be petering out, and manufacturers are now racing to meet their goals, with some warning of potential unfulfilled demand in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The Category A COE-friendly 100 kW version of the BYD Atto 3 arrived in May 2023 after the car was launched with 150 kW initially.

site_title: Elon Musk’s wealth slumps US$20 billion as Tesla shares tumble
summary: Elon Musk's net worth dropped by $20.3 billion after Tesla's shares tumbled 9.7% due to warnings of potential price cuts for electric vehicles. Musk's fortune now stands at $234.4 billion, narrowing the wealth gap with Bernard Arnault. The decline also affects other tech billionaires, including Jeff Bezos, Larry Ellison, and Mark Zuckerberg. Musk attributes the drop to rising interest rates, which he believes will continue to impact Tesla's profitability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk gets in a Tesla car as he leaves a hotel in Beijing, China May 31, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: HK’s billionaire Cheng family takes over Vietnam casino resort
summary: The Cheng family, owners of Hong Kong-based Chow Tai Fook Enterprises, has taken over the management of the Hoiana casino resort in Vietnam from the former listed company of jailed Macau junket operator Alvin Chau. The resort features a casino, golf course, and luxury hotels, with a total investment of around $4 billion. Vietnam's relaxed rules and potential for sharing VIP revenue with casinos make it an attractive destination for Macau junket operators, who are increasingly looking to the country for business.

images.alt_text: The skyline of Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Mixue on the march: ice-cream serves soft power for China in Indonesia
summary: China's Mixue has dominated South-east Asia's ice-cream and tea businesses for five years, with 22,500 stores in China and 1,000 in Indonesia, surpassing Starbucks and McDonald's. Mixue's success in Indonesia can be attributed to supply chain efficiency, affordable product prices, and ease of franchise. The brand has the potential to promote a positive national image for China, similar to how food can act as a national ambassador in international relations. Mixue's presence has also helped Indonesia tackle unemployment by recruiting local workers, despite negative sentiments towards China.

images.alt_text: Butter-poached Maine lobster, American Osetra caviar, delicata squash raviolo, and tarragon sauce is presented during a media preview ahead of the state dinner in honour of French President Emmanuel Macron, in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on Nov 30, 2022.

The bubble tea market in China, estimated to have an annual turnover of US$20 billion, has already seen some of its popular Chinese brands like Mixue, Chagee and Heytea segue into Southeast Asia, joining earlier counterparts like Gong Cha and Koi.

site_title: As China embraces membership stores, Sam’s Club expansion gathers pace
summary: China's membership stores, including Sam's Club and Costco, are expanding rapidly, with sales more than doubling to $3.7 billion in 2022 from $1.8 billion four years earlier. Despite accounting for only 0.3% of sales in the grocery sector, warehouse clubs are gaining ground amid a decline in China's hypermarket sector. Sam's Club, the market leader, is focusing on curated and unique products, while Alibaba's Freshippo is targeting China's younger, digitally savvy urbanites with its exclusive and imported products. The membership store format is seen as a "bright spot" in the Chinese retail market.

images.alt_text: Beyond opening actual stores, the new division will explore innovative retail models, the JD.com says.

site_title: Growing climate risks fuel surge in US home insurance costs
summary: US home insurance costs have surged, with premiums rising by 9% on average last year and by more in some states. The main drivers of higher premiums are the rising cost of reinsurance, which has increased by 30-40% year-over-year, and the growing cost of rebuilding materials. Natural disasters, particularly Hurricane Ian, caused $140 billion in damage last year, with $90 billion insured. Climate change is exacerbating the issue, with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change stating that human activity is already affecting many weather and climate extremes globally.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Firefighters attempt to get control of the scene as dozens of homes burn during the Dixie in the Indian Falls neighborhood of unincorporated Plumas County, California on July 24, 2021. Natural disasters destroyed assets worth more than $140 billion in the United States last year, of which close to $90 billion was insured, according to data from Munich Re. In California, for example, insurance premiums are well below the national average at around $1,300, according to III, due in large part to state laws that give the government a greater say over any increases. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP)

site_title: Deglobalisation is not just for countries
summary: Multinational companies are rethinking their corporate structures due to global tensions, with many introducing "Chinese walls" between their Chinese operations and the rest of the world. This shift is driven by the need to protect Western technology from potential military rivals, as seen in companies like Rockwell Automation and Volkswagen. Some companies, like HSBC and Ping An Insurance, are already operating with separate power centers in the UK and Hong Kong, and China. The trend is expected to continue, with companies prioritizing local operations and protecting themselves from the risks of global supply chains.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of Todtnau in Germany's Black Forest. The real engine of the German economy is not the big corporations but its Mittelstand, the country's mid-sized "mighty minnows".
The Apple store in Beijing's Wangfujing shopping belt, Feb 2023. The store was Apple's biggest in Asia when it opened in Oct 2012.

site_title: China needs more than monetary stimulus to bolster flagging economy: analysts
summary: China's economy is not showing signs of improvement despite the People's Bank of China's rate cuts in June, with analysts stating that monetary stimulus alone is not enough to bolster the flagging economy. Poor data in the past two months, including a slowdown in consumption and fixed-asset investment, suggests that the rate cuts may have limited impact. Analysts point to constrained infrastructure and real estate investment, as well as the shrinking demand for financing from property developers and local government financing vehicles, as major factors contributing to the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Coins and banknotes of China's yuan are seen in this illustration picture taken February 24, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
The government will boost support for private companies in share listings, bond sales and overseas expansion, according to the statement.
The Asian Development Bank cut Vietnam's growth forecast for 2023 as weaker external demand weighs on manfuacturing output.
China’s private sector has been hit by Covid-19 curbs and a wide-ranging regulatory crackdown that targeted sectors from technology to property.

site_title: UK rents climb a third above pre-Covid levels as tenant demand remains firm
summary: UK rents rose 3.5% in the second quarter of 2023, outpacing the 1.5% increase in the first quarter, with average advertised rents reaching £1,231 per month outside London and £2,567 in London. This marks a 9.3% increase from a year ago and 33% higher than in 2019. Strong tenant demand and rapid interest rate increases are contributing to the housing market's challenges, with 16% of properties for sale previously on the rental market and 42% fewer properties available than in 2019.

images.alt_text: The rental figures emphasise the headwinds facing the UK housing market, as interest rates keep rising and add to mortgage costs.

site_title: Japan’s inflation re-accelerates in June, stays above BOJ target
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation rose 3.3% in June, staying above the Bank of Japan's 2% target for the 15th consecutive month. This data supports speculation that the BOJ may phase out its yield curve control policy, which has been criticized for distorting market pricing. The BOJ's policy meeting next week will determine whether conditions are ripe for the policy change. The yen has fallen and Japanese shares have risen following BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda's comments that Japan is still distant from achieving its 2% inflation target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks about his parent policy at a press conference at his official residence in Tokyo on March 17, 2023. YOSHIKAZU TSUNO/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% at 3,271.21 points. The STI was influenced by mixed US and European trading sessions, and the decline was led by Seatrium, which fell 0.7%. Despite this, local banks DBS and UOB had mixed performances, while OCBC remained flat. The market's tone was also influenced by global trends, including a mixed US stock market and a strong Stoxx 600 index in Europe.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Financial's maritime private equity fund has invested in two chemical and product tanker projects for US$32.1 million.

site_title: British consumer confidence falls for first time in six months
summary: UK consumer confidence has fallen for the first time in six months, dropping 6 points to minus 30 in July, according to market research firm GfK. This decline is attributed to soaring prices and rising interest rates, which are cutting into household spending power. Economists warn of a potential softening of the economy in the months ahead. Despite this, a separate survey from the REC shows an increase in job postings, with 2.2 million active job postings in the week ending July 9, a 53.3% rise compared to the same period last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk along a busy shopping street, during the traditional Boxing Day sales in London, Britain, December 26, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang Financial, SLB Development, Sabana Reit
summary: Yangzijiang Financial's maritime private equity fund has invested $32.1 million in two chemical and product tanker projects. SLB Development expects a loss for the second half of its fiscal year, leading to a lower full-year profit. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust will internalise its management function after removing its manager.

site_title: US leading indicators point to recession starting soon
summary: The Conference Board's Leading Economic Index (LEI) declined 0.7% in June to 106.1, marking the 15th straight month of decreases. This is the longest streak since the 2007-2009 recession. Economists expect economic activity to continue decelerating, with the US economy likely to enter a recession from the third quarter to the first quarter of 2024. The contraction in the LEI is accelerating, falling 4.2% over the last six months.

site_title: Gold prices set for third weekly gain on US Fed pause views
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,971.79 per ounce, poised for a third consecutive weekly gain, amid expectations that the US Federal Reserve will pause rate hikes after July. A weaker dollar made bullion cheaper for holders of other currencies. The metal slipped on Thursday due to stronger-than-expected US labour market data, but rebounded as new claims for unemployment benefits fell, defying Fed efforts to slow demand. The Fed is expected to raise rates by 25 basis points next week, but most economists expect this to be the last increase of the current tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: The dollar index wobbled near a more than one-year low, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies.

site_title: TikTok signs payment pact with Atome for Malaysia e-commerce
summary: TikTok has partnered with fintech platform Atome to expand its e-commerce presence in Malaysia, offering its "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) service as a payment option on TikTok Shop. The deal aims to drive e-commerce growth, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, and is part of ByteDance's plans to invest billions of dollars in South-east Asia over the next three to five years. Atome's BNPL service allows consumers to defer payments over three to six months, and the partnership is seen as a boost for the fintech startup and Malaysia's e-commerce market.

site_title: Johnny Depp self-portrait painted during ‘dark time’ goes on sale
summary: Johnny Depp's self-portrait, "Five," created in 2021, went on sale, priced at $1,950. The artwork, inspired by a 2015 photograph, depicts Depp during a tumultuous period in his life, including his divorce from Amber Heard. Depp stated that the piece was created during a "dark time" and was donated to non-profit Mental Health America, with $200 from each sale going to the organization. The artwork follows Depp's "Friends & Heroes" collection, which features portraits of celebrities like Elizabeth Taylor and Bob Dylan.

images.alt_text: In reaching this final sum, the painting Dame mit Facher also set a record for Klimt at auction.

site_title: Nasdaq ends 2.1% lower as Tesla, Netflix tumble
summary: The Nasdaq fell 2.1% on Thursday, July 20, due to selloffs in Netflix and Tesla following mixed earnings reports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.7%. Analysts warn of a potential market pullback after a strong second quarter. Tesla's shares dropped 10% despite beating earnings estimates, while Netflix fell 8.4% despite adding 6 million customers, missing revenue estimates.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 19, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: What if China and India became friends?
summary: India and China, two Asian giants, are reassessing their complex relationship amid growing economic ties and shifting geopolitics. Despite border disputes and military clashes, the two countries are exploring ways to stabilize their relationship, including a recent meeting between their foreign ministers and a push for more economic cooperation. China's economy is expected to surpass India's by 2075, according to Goldman Sachs, and the two nations have significant trade and investment ties. However, nationalism and historical grievances continue to fuel tensions, and the border dispute remains a major challenge to a more sustainable and mutually beneficial relationship between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping says China would “persist in the correct direction of economic globalisation, oppose protectionism, unilateral sanctions and extension of national security concepts”.
India and the global balance of power

site_title: South Korea annual economic growth likely slowed slightly in Q2: poll
summary: South Korea's economic growth likely slowed in Q2 due to declining exports and imports, particularly from China, its largest trade partner. According to a Reuters poll of economists, GDP growth is expected to have expanded 0.8% in the April-June period, slightly slower than the 0.9% growth in the January-March period. High interest rates also hurt private consumption, accounting for about half of the economy.

images.alt_text: Officials at the BOK remain cautious about whether the annual declines will continue.

site_title: Britain rejects call to regulate crypto as gambling
summary: Britain's Financial Services Minister Andrew Griffith firmly disagrees with the recommendation to regulate unbacked cryptocurrencies as gambling, citing risks to consumers and potential misalignment with global standards. The UK wants to become a global hub for crypto, and its current approach aims to address risks and provide clarity. Griffith argues that a system of gambling regulation would not address the risks highlighted by the collapse of FTX and would create unclear mandates between financial regulators and the Gambling Commission.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: Oil settles higher amid low crude stocks, cautious economic outlook
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, with September Brent futures climbing 18 US cents to $79.64 a barrel and August US West Texas Intermediate crude gaining 28 US cents to $75.63 a barrel. Lower US crude inventories and strong crude imports by China contributed to the increase, but a cautious economic outlook and a weaker demand outlook kept investors cautious. Strong economic data and low employment have supported US oil demand this year, but a potential 25 basis point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve next week may impact the market.

images.alt_text: An idled oil pumping unit in Cabimas, on the East coast of Lake Maracaibo, Venezuela, is illuminated by the morning light Friday January 3, 2002. A nationwide strike has cut shipments from the fourt-biggest source of U.S. imports. Photographer: Ana Maria Otero Borjas/Bloomberg News.

site_title: PM Lee, DPM Wong did not disclose Iswaran’s arrest as it is CPIB’s call to make: PMO
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong did not disclose Transport Minister S Iswaran's arrest due to CPIB's decision, not politics. The PMO clarified that ministers should not deviate from operational information released by the CPIB. The arrest was announced by the CPIB on Jul 12, and ministers kept to the agency's statement, which did not provide details on the investigation. A correction notice was issued to Political Sophistry for spreading false information, and the blog has since posted a correction notice.

images.alt_text: Ong Beng Seng returned on a private jet which landed in Seletar Airport at about 5.15pm on Monday, accompanied by his wife Christina Ong.
Presidential hopeful and former senior minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam made the comments while speaking to reporters during his campaign trail in Teck Whye.
From left to right: Minister for Transport S Iswaran; Formula One Group chief executive Stefano Domenicali; and HPL co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng.
The hotel and property tycoon is also known for being one of those responsible for first bringing the Formula 1 night race to Singapore in 2008.
DPM Lawrence Wong says that he and PM Lee Hsien Loong are “fully committed” to keeping and preserving the trust that the people have in the government.
Iswaran will take a leave of absence until the investigations are complete.

site_title: UK removes sanctions on businessman Tinkov after Branson plea
summary: The UK has removed sanctions on businessman Oleg Tinkov, who renounced his Russian citizenship after criticizing Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. Tinkov was sanctioned in February 2022, but an appeal by Richard Branson and others led to his designation being revoked. Tinkov had previously sold his stake in Tinkoff Bank and publicly opposed Russia's actions in Ukraine, citing his opposition to "fascism" and those who collaborate with "killers." The decision was made after a review of Tinkov's actions following his sanctions designation.

site_title: Single family offices unlikely to flock to Singapore equities until market returns pick up: industry watchers
summary: Singapore's tax incentives for single family offices (SFOs) may encourage them to invest in local equities, but market players expect fund flows to remain uncertain until market returns pick up. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has tweaked the tax incentive scheme, making SFOs entitled to a tax exemption on income from Singapore-listed equities. However, industry watchers believe SFOs are unlikely to flock to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) until the market's liquidity and depth improve, with many opting for private assets or non-listed businesses instead.

images.alt_text: While most family offices welcome the change, there were also calls to go beyond tax incentives in growing the family office space.
In the face of Hong Kong's friendly tax regime, Singapore may lose out if it is too choosy in attracting family offices.

Among the 1,400 locals employed by single family offices that receive tax incentives in Singapore, about 900 of these jobs were created in just the last three years, said Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, adding that these are “generally well-paying jobs”.
Further, MAS will also recognise grants that SFOs give to support blended finance structures, as two dollars for every dollar of grant given.
calculator, calculation, insurance

site_title: South Korea producer prices fall for first time in 31 months
summary: South Korea's producer prices fell 0.2% in June, marking the first annual decline in 31 months, due to lower petroleum and agricultural product prices. The Bank of Korea (BOK) remains cautious about the trend, citing rebounding global oil prices and potential upward pressure from agricultural products. Despite the decline, the index has shown annual increases every month since December 2020, when it reached a 14-year high of 10%. Monthly prices fell for the third consecutive month, with coal and petroleum products down 3.7% and agricultural products down 1.3%.

images.alt_text: Representatives from 11 foreign institutions including JPMorgan Chase Bank, HSBC Bank, MUFG Bank, Yuanta Securities, Goldman Sachs Securities, insurers, and investment companies attended.

site_title: Billionaire Cheng family takes over Vietnam casino resort
summary: The billionaire Cheng family has taken control of the Hoiana casino resort in Vietnam, which was previously managed by the former listed company of jailed Macau gambling kingpin Alvin Chau. The Cheng family's investment firm, Chow Tai Fook Enterprises, now oversees the resort's operations, featuring a casino, golf course, and luxury hotels. This move comes as many Macau junket operators seek opportunities in South-east Asia due to relaxed rules and higher VIP revenue sharing.

images.alt_text: Revenue from casinos continues to be the main driver, rising 29.8 per cent to US$649 million.

site_title: Malaysia telecoms firms complete talks to take up stakes in 5G agency
summary: Malaysia's telecommunications firms have agreed to take stakes in state 5G agency Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB), following negotiations with the government. The firms, including CelcomDigi, Maxis, and Telekom Malaysia, will have access to DNB's 5G infrastructure. The deal comes after concerns over pricing, transparency, and monopolistic practices were raised in 2021 when Malaysia announced that state-owned DNB would own the full 5G spectrum. The agreement marks a resolution to protracted negotiations over Malaysia's 5G rollout plans.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A salesperson at a telecommunications store uses a phone in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, January 6, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES/File Photo

site_title: FTX sues Bankman-Fried, others to recoup more than US$1 billion
summary: FTX has filed a lawsuit against founder Sam Bankman-Fried and other former executives, seeking to recoup over $1 billion they allegedly misappropriated before FTX's bankruptcy. The lawsuit names Caroline Ellison, Zixiao "Gary" Wang, and Nishad Singh as defendants, accusing them of misusing funds for luxury projects, political contributions, and speculative investments. FTX claims the alleged fraudulent transfers occurred between 2020 and 2022 and can be undone under the US bankruptcy code or Delaware law. This move comes as US prosecutors have charged Bankman-Fried with masterminding a massive financial fraud.

images.alt_text: FTX filed for bankruptcy in November 2022 after a run on customer deposits.
The company “has begun the process of soliciting interested parties to the reboot of the FTX.com exchange,” CEO John Ray says.

site_title: China’s sagging economy looms over quarterly results around the world
summary: China's economy, which has been experiencing sluggish growth, is expected to weigh on companies with exposure to the world's second-largest economy, including Apple, luxury retailers, and chipmakers, as they report quarterly results. US inflation and weaker spending are expected to hurt profit margins, with Wall Street bracing for a steep drop in second-quarter US earnings. Companies like Corning and Tesla are also expected to report weak results, with China accounting for a significant portion of their revenue. The uncertainty surrounding China's economic growth is also affecting trade disputes between Washington and Beijing, particularly in semiconductors.

images.alt_text: The central bank last adjusted the ratio in October 2022 by raising it to 1.25 from 1, to ease yuan depreciation pressure.
The steady LPR fixings come as the People’s Bank of China rolled over maturing medium-term policy loans and kept the interest rate unchanged earlier this week.

site_title: Restaurant Zen’s sister outlet Brasserie Astoria debuts at Victoria Concert Hall
summary: Brasserie Astoria, a sister restaurant to three-Michelin-starred Zen, opens on July 25 at Victoria Concert Hall in Singapore. The classic brasserie concept, modeled after the original in Stockholm, features a Nordic focus with Asian influences and a menu including steak frites and signature dish Toast Astoria. Chef Emil Cecil Ess heads the kitchen, with Bjorn Frantzen investing in local talents. The 132-seater restaurant includes a bar/lounge and private dining room, designed to evoke a rich and warm experience. Brasserie Astoria marks a move towards more casual and accessible dining for the Frantzen Group, with plans for future openings in Dubai and Singapore.

images.alt_text:
jeastoria20 - astoria

Credit: Brasserie Astoria

site_title: Sri Lanka adopts measures to boost central bank independence
summary: Sri Lanka's parliament approved a new law to boost the central bank's independence, part of a US$2.9 billion IMF bailout package. The law aims to control inflation, introduce an inflation target, and improve bank oversight. The move prioritizes controlling money printing and putting public finances in order, as the country seeks to finalize foreign debt talks with key creditors. The legislation is expected to help Sri Lanka stabilize its economy and prepare for its first IMF review in September.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka’s economy shrank at a slower pace last quarter as fresh funds eased widespread shortages.

site_title: Lian Beng warns of lower FY2023 profits on unit’s expected losses
summary: Construction and engineering company Lian Beng expects lower profits for FY2023 due to its subsidiary SLB Development's expected loss for the second half of the fiscal year. The loss is attributed to higher finance costs and lower revenue from property development projects. Lian Beng will disclose further details in SLB's unaudited financial results on Jul 29. Shares of Lian Beng have been suspended from trading since Jul 10.

images.alt_text: Ong Pang Aik is chairman and managing director of Lian Beng.

site_title: American Airlines Q2 profits rise on record revenues
summary: American Airlines reported a record-breaking second-quarter profit of $1.4 billion, nearly tripling the year-ago level, driven by strong consumer demand and lower jet fuel costs. Revenues rose 4.7% to $14.1 billion, also a record. The airline's full-year forecast was lifted following the robust spring quarter, and it highlighted a two-notch upgrade in its credit rating.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Easyjet Airbus aircraft takes off from the southern runway at Gatwick Airport in Crawley, Britain, August 25, 2021.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Wing Tai’s The LakeGarden Residences to start previews on Jul 22
summary: Wing Tai's The LakeGarden Residences in Jurong will start previews on July 22, marking the first condo launch in the area in seven years. The 306-unit 99-year leasehold condominium offers prices starting at S$2,000 per square foot, with units ranging from 484 sq ft to 2,260 sq ft. The development aims to provide a sustainable and contemporary home, with features like solar energy powering 30% of common areas. Pre-sales begin on August 5, with delivery expected in August 2027.

images.alt_text: The Jalan Tembusu site, for private housing development, is near the future Tanjong Katong MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.
Developers sold less private homes in June 2023.
An artist's impression of Newport Residences which will be built on the site of the former Fuji Xerox Towers on Anson Road.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial fund invests in 2 tankers, enters into co-chartering agreement
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding's maritime private equity fund has invested $32.1 million in two chemical and product tankers and entered into a co-chartering agreement for eight eco-medium-range tankers. The fund aims to develop as an alternative source of capital for the shipping industry, capitalizing on expected demand growth and tight supply. With $178.8 million in funding commitments, the fund hopes to achieve capital appreciation and steady income through maritime asset investments.

images.alt_text: The private credit market in Asia has experienced strong growth in recent years, supported by rising investor interest and increasing demand for alternative debt, said Vincent Toe, chief executive officer of Yangzijiang Financial.
Yangzijiang Financial chief executive Vincent Toe said that the MOU will broaden the group's reach and boost its total assets under management.

site_title: India bans some non-basmati rice exports to control prices
summary: India has banned the export of non-basmati white rice, affecting about 25% of its total rice shipments, to control domestic prices ahead of the 2024 general election. The ban will be lifted for countries meeting food-security needs or with government requests. The move aims to reduce domestic prices, but may lead to higher global costs due to the return of the El Niño weather pattern and escalating tensions in the Black Sea region.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager says ‘no assurance’ staff will stay if EGM resolutions passed
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit's manager, Sabana Real Estate Investment Management (SREIM), says there's no assurance that existing staff will stay if resolutions at an EGM on Aug 7 are passed, which would remove SREIM as manager. The EGM, requisitioned by activist investor Quarz Capital, aims to internalize the Reit's management function. If SREIM loses staff, the responsibility to manage the Reit could fall on the trustee or professional advisers appointed by the trustee. The EGM also includes a resolution to direct the trustee to internalize the Reit's management function, which could lead to cost savings for unitholders.

images.alt_text: Sabana Reit’s second major asset enhancement initiative (AEI) at its property at 1 Tuas Avenue 4 is 14 per cent complete as at end-June 2023.
Sabana Reit's manager has said Quarz's internalisation proposal may destroy value for unitholders
The trustee of Sabana Reit, HSBC Trustee, is urging unitholders to carefully consider the resolutions and note the uncertainty and risks associated before voting at an upcoming EGM.
Sabana Reit's manager ought to obtain clarity from UOB and other lenders on whether they plan to pull back their credit facilities in the event unitholders vote for internalisation.
External managers of Singapore-listed trusts need to act in the interest of unitholders and deliver value in order to keep their jobs.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. Quarz Capital had requisitioned the EGM, which was slated to take place on Aug 4, to vote on two resolutions.
Sabana' Reit's upcoming extraordinary general meeting involves two resolutions - one for the removal of its Reit manager and second on the internalisation of the Reit management function.
Investors could benefit from stricter rules around the formats of meetings. This is particularly true for EGMs that are convened to vote on contentious corporate issues.
At an upcoming extraordinary general meeting, unitholders will vote on whether to remove Sabana Reit’s current manager and replace it with an internal one.
Quarz believes the move to replace Sabana Reit’s manager – an external manager controlled by ESR – with an internal manager will net cost savings for unitholders.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at one-month high, tech stocks tumble
summary: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% to a one-month high, driven by gains in miners, banks, and healthcare sectors, while chip stocks declined after TSMC's poor sales forecast. The index extended its gains for the third consecutive session, reaching a day's high of 464.17 points. Upbeat corporate earnings and a slowdown in British consumer inflation fueled hopes of easing global price pressures.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended up 0.3 per cent, extending gains to the second straight session.

site_title: Struggling German property firms appeal to Berlin for multi-billion euro boost
summary: Germany's property industry is facing its worst crisis in decades, with a housing shortage and collapsing prices. Firms are appealing to Chancellor Olaf Scholz for multi-billion euro support, including dramatic tax cuts and low-interest rate credit programs, to boost new residential building. The industry is struggling due to war, inflation, and an energy crisis, and experts warn of insolvencies and stalled investment. The government is under pressure to address the crisis, which affects one in ten jobs and roughly a fifth of economic output.

images.alt_text: While rising rents are a problem for most residents, the main issue for Berlin’s tech sector is a lack of supply, which means higher salaries offer little respite.

site_title: ‘Must-have’ Japanese whisky turns 100 as demand soars
