summary: Japan's Yamazaki distillery, the country's oldest, marks its 100th anniversary with record-breaking demand for its aged whiskies. The distillery's unique water and copper stills contribute to its distinct flavor profile, which is well-suited to Japanese cuisine. Exorbitant prices, ranging from $28,415 to $600,000, are driven by growing demand and longstanding shortages. Despite the challenges, Suntory plans to invest 10 billion yen in its distilleries to meet the increasing demand, with exports surging to 56 billion yen last year.

site_title: Blackstone’s US$1 trillion triumph is muted by deal slowdown
summary: Blackstone has become the first private equity firm to manage over $1 trillion in assets, but its success is tempered by a dealmaking slump. The firm's distributable earnings fell 39% to $1.2 billion in the second quarter, the lowest in two years. Blackstone slowed its deal pace and cash-out of existing bets due to industry-wide dealmaking challenges. The slowdown weighed on the firm's second-quarter results, despite its record $1.001 trillion in assets.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Loan Financing Limited was incorporated in Jersey and has exposure to both CLOs and CLO warehouses.
Bellagio, one of the top-performing resorts on the city’s famous Strip, is operated under a long-term lease by MGM Resorts International, its original owner.

Blackstone own figures show it’s attracted 240 million euros (S$347 million) to its new private credit fund, dubbed ECRED, a fraction of the US$12 billion raised for BCRED, an equivalent US fund, at the half-year point of its fundraising about two years ago.

site_title: Ubisoft Q1 net bookings drop on lack of new games releases
summary: Ubisoft reported an 8.7% decline in net bookings in its first quarter, citing a lack of new game releases. The company attributed the decline to focusing on new versions of older games instead of launching new titles. Despite this, Ubisoft confirmed its targets for the 2023/24 finance year and expects second-quarter net bookings to increase. The company also announced its in-house AI tool, Ghostwriter, which aims to write first drafts of non-playable character dialogue. Ubisoft's finance chief assured that game releases scheduled for the current financial year, including Assassin's Creed Mirage, will not be delayed.

site_title: Well-designed, award-winning products you can use
summary: The 2023 Red Dot Award: Product Design has announced its winners, recognizing 2,150 products across 51 categories. International judges praised designs such as the Frenz Brainband for its slim, elegant profile and ergonomic design, the hó-lim Beverage Tumbler for its innovative straw-like structure, and the Stealth 16 Studio for its purist design with artistic touches. Other winners include the Maverick smart glasses, the Moment teapot, and the Rott Kron earring, which blur the boundaries between fashion and technology.

site_title: US existing home sales fall; annual house price decline slows
summary: US existing home sales fell 3.3% in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.16 million units, the lowest level since January. The decline was attributed to a chronic shortage of houses on the market, which slowed the pace of annual house price decline. Home resales plummeted 18.9% year-on-year, and the median existing house price fell 0.9% to $410,200. The persistent shortage of homes for sale may limit any rebound in the housing market.

images.alt_text: Initial claims for state unemployment benefits drop 9,000 to a seasonally adjusted 228,000 for the week ended Jul 15, US Labor Department says.

A home being built in Lemont, Illinois, in June. Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, dropped 7.0 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 935,000 units last month.
June’s solid rise and May’s upward revision to core retail sales in May suggest that consumer spending has continued to grow last quarter.

June has marked the second consecutive monthly decline, reversing some of the positive figures seen earlier this year and providing further evidence of slowing production as the Fed prepares to weigh another interest rate hike next week.

The single point increase in builder confidence marked a deceleration after two consecutive months of five-point increases, highlighting increasing concern over the availability of construction financing.
US consumer sentiment, while still well below pre-pandemic levels, has been improving against a backdrop of steady employment growth and wage gains.

site_title: Vietnam to waive tax for income from capital transfer for Ho Chi Minh City startups
summary: Vietnam has introduced a tax-exemption scheme for startups in Ho Chi Minh City, exempting individuals and organizations with income from capital transfer from both personal income tax and corporate income tax for five years. The scheme aims to boost domestic and foreign investment in the city's startup scene, which ranked third in South-east Asia in 2022. Observers note that the policy is similar to those in Thailand and Singapore, but implementation details are unclear, and some investors remain cautious due to complex administrative procedures.

images.alt_text: Da Nang is home to nearly 900 foreign-invested projects with a total investment capital of US$5.9 billion.

site_title: Ministry of Health in talks to lease office space at Labrador Tower
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) is in talks to lease office space at SP Group's Labrador Tower, a 34-storey building above a large underground electrical substation. The project, which will be directly connected to Labrador Park MRT station, will offer 700,000 sq ft of lettable office space. MOH Holdings, the holding company of Singapore's public healthcare clusters, earlier reported that it was not in talks to lease the space, but the MOH has clarified that it is planning to consolidate its HarbourFront area offices at the tower.

images.alt_text: The four-storey building at 51 Scotts Road where some of Prudential Singapore's agency offices are located.
What’s stopping some Singapore companies from allowing employees to work from home?
Artist's impression of Elementum project in Singapore

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fall
summary: US initial jobless claims unexpectedly fell to 228,000 for the week ended July 15, a seasonally adjusted drop of 9,000. Economists had forecast 242,000 claims, but the data may be skewed due to seasonal patterns. Despite this, the labour market remains tight, with claims below the 280,000 level that would signal a slowdown in job growth. The decline suggests persistent strength in the labour market, with some laid-off workers quickly finding new work.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Stacked containers are shown as ships unload their cargo at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California, U.S. November 22, 2021. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
Receipts slipped 11 per cent compared with last year, while outlays rose by 10 per cent.
The return to positive inflation after a contraction in May suggests wholesale prices remain buoyant in some areas.

The average rate paid on short-term loans for small businesses shot up to 9.2 per cent in June, up 1.4 percentage points from May’s reading – marking the largest increase in short-term borrowing costs since December 2006

MIAMI, FLORIDA - MAY 05: A 'Now Hiring' sign posted in the window of a restaurant looking to hire workers on May 05, 2023 in Miami, Florida. A report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed the US economy added 253,000 jobs in April.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: India's Adani to convert Mumbai slum into modern city despite challenges
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani plans to convert Dharavi, the country's largest slum in Mumbai, into a modern city hub despite challenges. The redevelopment project, valued at $619 million, will require rehousing around 1 million people. Adani aims to provide basic amenities such as gas, water, and healthcare to residents. The project, dubbed the "world's largest urban renewal scheme," has been in the works since the 1980s, and Adani's group has faced criticism and a significant stock plunge in recent months. The project's success will test Adani's capabilities and resilience.

images.alt_text: A representative of the Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority, which oversees the project, confirms it was given the go-ahead by the Maharashtra state government.

site_title: Semiconductor startup Silicon Box to create up to 1,200 jobs with manufacturing facility
summary: Singapore-based semiconductor startup Silicon Box plans to create up to 1,200 jobs at its $2 billion manufacturing facility, with the goal of solving unique challenges in chiplet adoption. The facility will support the production of advanced semiconductor chips, which combine multiple smaller chips into a single package, offering greater flexibility and efficiency. The company aims to reduce costs for chip designers by up to three-quarters when designing graphical processing units and high-performance computing chips using chiplet designs.

images.alt_text: TSMC is viewed as among the earliest beneficiaries of efforts from the US to China to develop AI platforms.
SMIC is China’s most advanced chip manufacturer, a national champion that competes with the likes of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing in fabricating silicon.

“We are in touch with multiple prospective investors, including Foxconn ... Gujarat is uniquely positioned to attract top chipmakers,” says Vijay Nehra, secretary of the science and technology department in Gujarat.

site_title: Asia’s private credit markets thrive as desperate borrowers find lenders
summary: Asia's private credit markets are thriving as desperate borrowers seek funding from private lenders, who are offering higher yields due to an "illiquidity premium." Long-term lenders like pension funds and wealth managers are investing in private debt, while borrowers include property developers, startups, and privately held companies. The boom is driven by factors such as global monetary tightening and US regional banking sector turmoil, which have led to caution in public debt markets. Private lenders are queuing up to capitalize on the trend, with investment firms like Muzinich and Co and BlackRock launching new private debt strategies.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ The headquarters of BlackRock, the investment manager from which the state treasurers of Arkansas, Louisiana and West Virginia have pulled more than $700 million over objections that the firm has become too focused on environmental issues, in New York, March 23, 2022. State treasurers from Arizona to West Virginia are using their authority to punish companies that are trying to reduce planet warming emissions. (Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times)

site_title: Fed launches long-awaited instant payments service, modernising system
summary: The US Federal Reserve has launched FedNow, a long-awaited instant payments service aimed at modernizing the country's payment system. Launched with 41 banks and 15 service providers, FedNow will allow everyday Americans to send and receive funds in seconds, 24/7. The service seeks to eliminate the several-day lag in cash transfers, bringing the US in line with countries like the UK, India, and Brazil. FedNow will compete with private sector real-time payments systems and will settle directly in central bank accounts, benefiting consumers and small businesses.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve Building is seen in Washington, DC, May 3, 2023. - The US Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise its benchmark lending rate for a 10th -- and possibly final -- time, as it aims to bring down inflation while preventing fresh banking concerns from spreading. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)
The Fed has raised rates aggressively since starting its tightening campaign in March 2022.
FILE PHOTO: Workers select and pack items during Cyber Monday at the Amazon fulfilment centre in Robbinsville Township in New Jersey, U.S., November 28, 2022. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz
FILE PHOTO: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Thomas Barkin poses during a break at a conference in Dallas, Texas, U.S., May 23, 2019. REUTERS/Ann Saphir/File Photo
The Fed has raised interest rates by 5 percentage points since March 2022 to bring down the highest US inflation in four decades.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 slide at open as Tesla, Netflix drag
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Thursday, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 sliding due to concerns over Tesla's price cut and Netflix's quarterly revenue miss. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 30.77 points, or 0.09%, at the open to 35,091.98. The Nasdaq Composite fell 84.72 points, or 0.59%, and the S&P 500 dropped 11.34 points, or 0.25%.

site_title: US dollar steadies after one-two punch from Aussie, Chinese yuan
summary: The US dollar held steady against major currencies, including the euro and yen, but dropped against the Australian dollar and Chinese yuan. The Aussie dollar rose 1.1% after employment data beat expectations, while the yuan strengthened after Chinese monetary authorities relaxed a rule allowing companies to raise funds overseas. The US dollar index traded roughly unchanged against a basket of currencies, and individual currency reactions to data are likely to be volatile. The dollar is heading for its first weekly gain in nearly a month.

site_title: Dubai invites pitches for IPOs of taxi, parking assets: sources
summary: Dubai's Roads and Transport Authority (RTA) has invited investment banks to pitch for roles in the planned initial public offerings (IPOs) of its taxi and parking businesses. The first IPO, in the Dubai Taxi Corporation, is expected to take place around December or January. The RTA has also appointed Rothschild & Co to advise on a strategic review of its assets, including its Nol card. This move follows the success of Dubai's previous IPOs, which raised nearly US$8.5 billion last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: General view of the Burj Khalifa and the downtown skyline in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, September 30, 2021. REUTERS/Mohammed Salem/File Photo

site_title: Pink ka-ching! Companies capitalise on Barbie frenzy
summary: Companies worldwide are capitalizing on the Barbie phenomenon, with thousands of products and events related to the iconic doll. Hot pink products, such as shoes and clothing, are selling out rapidly, with brands like Superga, Typo, and Zara experiencing high demand. The Barbie movie's release has also sparked renewed interest, with collaborations with companies like Di Martino Pasta and mtm labo. Mattel's efforts to diversify Barbie, including the introduction of dolls with disabilities, have contributed to the brand's resurgence, with sales rising from $954 million in 2017 to $1.49 billion in 2022.

images.alt_text: The two A-listers do tremendous justice to Gerwig’s sparkling dialogue, and take full advantage of the opportunity to flex their physical comedy muscles with hilarious results.
The toy was brought to market through work with the National Down Syndrome Society (NDSS), to ensure it accurately represents someone with the condition, the Mattel said.

site_title: Ringfencing of residential, commercial land from foreigners may drive investors to other asset types
summary: Singapore's amendment to the Residential Property Act restricts foreign buyers from purchasing land zoned as "commercial and residential" without government approval. This move may divert foreign investment to other asset types, such as shophouses, hotels, and strata-titled office units. Analysts predict uncertainty in the shophouse market, collective sales, and investment sales, and potential price increases due to reduced foreign demand. The change aims to safeguard residential land for locals and prevent over-concentration of ownership in developments by foreigners.

images.alt_text: The facade of four shophouses (2 to 5 Circular Road) that were among properties bought by a China buyer recently.
The Jalan Tembusu site, for private housing development, is near the future Tanjong Katong MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.
A black-and-white bungalow at Seletar.

site_title: Barbie plays on gender stereotypes with riotous Kenergy
summary: Greta Gerwig's live-action film "Barbie" is a humorous and thought-provoking take on the iconic doll, subverting traditional gender stereotypes and offering a nuanced exploration of identity, self-discovery, and societal expectations. The film follows Margot Robbie's Barbie as she navigates the real world, confronting existential concerns and pressures of modern womanhood. With a talented cast, including Ryan Gosling and America Ferrera, "Barbie" balances humor and heart, highlighting the commonalities between men and women in navigating life's complexities. Gerwig's direction proves herself capable of tackling the film's complex themes, resulting in a film that is both entertaining and impactful.

images.alt_text: Barbie-mania is everywhere as the hotly anticipated film starring Margot Robbie hits theatres worldwide.

site_title: Concern mounts over China's Wanda Commercial as rating agencies sound default warnings
summary: Rating agencies Moody's and S&P Global issued warnings about China's Dalian Wanda Group, citing high uncertainty over a $400 million debt payment due in three days. This raises concerns that China may be on the verge of its largest property developer default since Evergrande. Moody's slashed Wanda Commercial Management's rating by six notches, indicating a significant risk of default. The warnings add to growing concerns about the financial stability of China's property sector.

images.alt_text: Dalian Wanda Group in a statement says it “is confident it will defend its legitimate rights”.

site_title: Apollo to launch private fund in asset-based financing buildout
summary: Apollo Global Management is launching a private fund focused on asset-based financing, expanding its more-than-$100 billion platform. The fund, expected to reach $5 billion, will allow external investors to directly tap into the asset-based financing business. Eric Siegel, a former Goldman Sachs executive, joined Apollo as managing director of the asset-based financing platform. This move aims to build out Apollo's asset-based origination business, which was previously bolstered by the acquisition of Credit Suisse's platform Atlas.

images.alt_text: Apollo said proceeds from the investment into PanAsia will support HMI’s growth strategy as the company seeks to continue expanding in South-east Asia.

site_title: New condo prices in Tokyo surge 60% to a record in H1
summary: New condo prices in Tokyo surged 60% to a record 129.6 million yen (S$1.23 million) in the first six months of 2023, according to the Real Estate Economic Institute. The price increase is attributed to factors such as higher labor and raw material costs, luxury units, and high demand for properties in central Tokyo. The trend of growth is expected to continue, with supply falling 9% in central Tokyo, and the Tokyo metropolitan area seeing new condo prices rise to a historic high of 88.7 million yen.

images.alt_text: Globally, investors are also shying away from offices due to historically high vacancy rates in major cities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-based semiconductor startup Silicon Box plans to hire up to 1,200 jobs in areas like computer science, engineering, and design, with a US$2 billion manufacturing facility expected to be fully fitted out in the future. Malaysia's exports fell 14.1% year-on-year in June, driven by lower shipments of manufactured goods. Americans have surpassed Chinese buyers as the top foreign buyers of Singapore condominiums in Q2. The cut-off yield on Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill has fallen to 3.85%. Local shares ended flat on Thursday, with investor optimism remaining subdued.

site_title: China's Xi gets nostalgic with 'old friend' Kissinger
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, calling him an "old friend" who will never be forgotten. The meeting comes amid efforts to mend strained US-China relations, with tensions over Ukraine, Taiwan, and trade curbs. Xi expressed China's willingness to work with the US on issues like climate change, while Kissinger emphasized the importance of their relationship for world peace and human society progress. The meeting follows a visit by US presidential envoy John Kerry, and highlights the ongoing diplomatic efforts between the two superpowers.

images.alt_text: Wang Yi (right) described John  Kerry as “my old friend”, saying they have “worked together to solve a series of problems between both sides”.

site_title: Yellen worry about mid-sized lenders amid ‘solid’ big-bank results
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed optimism over the quarterly earnings of large US banks, citing a "solid" performance. However, she is closely monitoring mid-sized lenders, which were at the center of a near-crisis in March, to assess their resilience. The KBW Bank Index has risen 10% this month, outperforming the S&P 500, with major lenders like JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup reporting strong results. Yellen awaits further data on mid-sized lenders' performance before drawing conclusions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

site_title: China’s Citic cuts around 20 bankers from Hong Kong’s CLSA: sources
summary: China's Citic Securities cut around 20 bankers from its offshore platform CLSA in Hong Kong, a move aimed at reducing costs as the bank's parent firm adheres to Beijing's common prosperity drive. The move affects about 10% of CLSA's 200 Hong Kong-based investment banking staff, with some employees being offered relocation to the mainland with reduced pay. The unusual move is seen as a response to pressure from Beijing to lower costs and is part of Citic's efforts to adapt to the country's economic shift.

images.alt_text: The logo of CITIC Securities is seen at its branch in Beijing, China, March 22, 2016.REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Malaysia issues licence to Musk’s Starlink to bring Internet services to remote areas
summary: Malaysia has issued a license to SpaceX's Starlink to provide internet services, particularly in remote areas. The service will initially focus on schools and higher education institutions. The move aims to address the 3% of populated areas with internet access issues. This follows a call between Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and Elon Musk to discuss investments in the country. The government plans to work with satellite communications firms, including Starlink, to achieve 100% internet coverage in populated areas.

images.alt_text: The launch comes a week after Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim held a virtual meeting with Tesla founder Elon Musk on investments involving the EV giant and SpaceX’s satellite Internet service.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says Tesla’s operations in Malaysia will begin this year.
Trade Minister Zafrul Aziz has confirmed local media reports that Tesla will officially launch in Malaysia on Jul 20.

site_title: Singapore stocks close flat on Thursday as investor optimism wanes
summary: Singapore's stocks closed flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index losing 0.03% to 3,274.38, as investors maintained subdued optimism despite easing global inflation. Advancers outnumbered decliners 303 to 261, with thinly-traded Isetan and Keppel Corporation gaining 5.2% and 1.5% respectively. However, Jardine Cycle and Carriage and two local lenders fell 1.2% and 0.8% respectively.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Manila, Jakarta and Wellington rose. However, Tokyo and Singapore dropped.

site_title: Healthy appetite for new launches
summary: Singapore's private home market saw a 73% drop in sales in June, with 278 units sold, compared to 1,039 units in May. However, major launches in July have boosted sales, with 1,100 units sold across four projects. The market's resilience is being tested, with interest rates staying elevated and economic uncertainties persisting. The low volume of sales in June can be attributed to the lack of major launches, and buyers are predominantly Singapore citizens and Permanent Residents, unaffected by the latest property cooling measures.

images.alt_text: Despite the decline in sales volume after successive rounds of cooling measures, property prices stayed relatively firm and rents remain high, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In the latest edition of his column, The Level Ground, Leslie Yee argues the Jurong Lake District site is worth serious consideration by major developers.
Singapore’s office market is far from distressed, but pockets of weakness are opening up in prime Grade A CBD space, says BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Co-hosts New Zealand secure stunning upset over Norway to open World Cup
summary: New Zealand secured a stunning 1-0 upset win over Norway in their Women's World Cup opener at Eden Park, with Hannah Wilkinson scoring the winner in the second half. The underdogs, who had never won a World Cup match before, put themselves on track to get out of the opening stage of the tournament. They face the Philippines next, following Australia's co-hosted World Cup campaign later on Thursday.

site_title: The secret life of secondary forests
summary: Singapore artist Robert Zhao Renhui will represent the country at the Venice Biennale 2024 with a showcase exploring the intricate relationship between nature and culture, focusing on secondary forests that emerge on land previously cleared for human use. His collection, titled "Foreigners everywhere," delves into the theme of home, belonging, and indigeneity, reflecting on the resilience of these forests and their interconnectedness with the broader planetary context.

images.alt_text: Skincare brand mtm labo, headed by managing director Kelly Keak (left), collaborated with Barbie collector Jian Yang (right) to showcase Barbie at her most diverse.  The dolls include Barbie on wheelchairs, albino Barbie and pregnant Barbie.
Yeo Yann Yann in dress by Bottega Veneta and necklace, earrings and ring by Tiffany & Co.
Haryadi Suadi’s The Buraq (1986) (left) and A.D. Pirous’ Sura Isra II: Homage To My Mother (1983) (right) both feature the mythical buraq winged creature alongside Arabic calligraphy.

site_title: Philippines gaming regulator bets on online casinos
summary: The Philippine gaming regulator, Pagcor, plans to launch its own e-gambling operations next year, aiming to tap into the lucrative online gaming market and diversify its customer base. The move is expected to bring in significant revenue, with the global online gambling market valued at $63.53 billion and forecast to grow at a 11.7% compound annual rate from 2023-2030. This will contribute to the Philippine government's national budget and bolster the country's economy. Pagcor's chairman, Alejandro Tengco, sees online gaming as an opportunity to grow the industry and attract wealthy offshore gamblers.

images.alt_text: Philippine inter-agency panel chaired by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, says it prefers to invite bids for the airport modernisation project.
Central bank policymakers around the world have recently spotlighted climate change and energy transition amid volatile energy prices and more frequent extreme weather events. T
The Philippines is among Asia’s fastest-growing economies, beating growth expectations in the first quarter.
The write-off will benefit more than 610,000 land reform beneficiaries but will cost the government US$1.04 billion, Marcos said.
Last month’s inflation rate, which was below the 5.5 per cent forecast in a Reuters poll, brought the year-to-date average to 7.2 per cent.

site_title: Revised retail leasing code of conduct to include data transparency as ‘leasing principle’
summary: Singapore's revised retail leasing code of conduct is set to include data transparency as a mandatory "leasing principle". The updated code, expected to be implemented six months after the Lease Agreements for Retail Premises Bill passes Parliament, will require landlords to share sales data with tenants twice a year, with confidentiality clauses applied to both parties. The change aims to promote fairer and more balanced lease negotiations, with the bill's second and third readings scheduled for August.

images.alt_text: Tenant group Singapore Tenants United for Fairness (SGTuff) has proposed that landlords should have to provide tenants with data on the footfall and average rental per square foot (psf) in their retail premises.
The code of conduct contains 11 key leasing principles that aim to foster fairer and more balanced lease negotiations.

site_title: Housing prices in Paris fall to the lowest level in four years
summary: Paris housing prices have fallen to their lowest level in four years, with asking prices decreasing 4.1% from last year to 10,936 euros per square meter. This decline is attributed to rising interest rates and lending rule changes that have limited financing for prospective investors. In contrast, other European cities like Madrid, Berlin, and Vienna are experiencing price increases, with some cities facing housing shortages that are driving up prices. Despite this, Paris remains the most expensive housing market in Europe.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A photograph shows facades of Parisian buildings in Paris on April 27, 2023. Haussmann-era property prices fell by 0.2% in Q1, according to the benchmark Notaires-Insee index, the first quarter-on-quarter decline since June 2015, as announced on May 30, 2023. (Photo by JOEL SAGET / AFP)

site_title: Taiwan June export orders slump for 10th month, outlook may improve on AI
summary: Taiwan's export orders, a key indicator of global technology demand, fell 24.9% in June to $44.18 billion, marking the 10th consecutive month of decline. The drop was attributed to weak China demand, inflation, and high interest rates, which offset surging demand for artificial intelligence (AI) supply chains. This worsened from a 17.6% drop in May and a predicted 20% fall in a Reuters poll, raising concerns about the island's economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Authorities in Taiwan have pledged to fight high house prices.
Taiwan, which is export-dependant, has struggled with lacklustre overseas appetite for technological goods – including for semiconductors, a key product.
Tokyo-based SBI is eyeing the growing financing needs of chipmakers to create redundant production lines as manufacturers bow to political and investor pressure to diversify their suppliers.
Overseas orders to Taiwanese companies shrink 17.6 per cent last month from a year earlier to US$45.7 billion, says the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

site_title: Fed seen hiking final time to a 22-year peak in economist survey
summary: Most economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates a quarter point at its July 25-26 meeting to a range of 5.25-5.5%, the highest since 2001. The rate hike is seen as the final move in a 16-month hiking cycle to combat US inflation, which is expected to slow sharply. With price pressures diminishing, economists expect no change to rates at the September meeting, and just one-fifth predict another hike by the November meeting.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve Building is seen in Washington, DC, May 3, 2023. - The US Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise its benchmark lending rate for a 10th -- and possibly final -- time, as it aims to bring down inflation while preventing fresh banking concerns from spreading. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)

site_title: US announces first offshore wind rights sale in Gulf of Mexico
summary: The US has announced the first offshore wind rights sale in the Gulf of Mexico, attracting a record US$1.5 billion in bids. The sale, set for August 29, is part of the Biden administration's efforts to boost renewable energy. This marks the first offshore wind development rights sale off the Pacific coast in California, following successful auctions in the Atlantic. The Interior Department plans to expand offshore wind power into the Gulf of Mexico, introducing the industry to a major hub for oil and gas production.

images.alt_text: The two competitive grant programmes with US$20 billion in funding are the latest move by Biden administration to support projects that reduce planet warming emissions.
“This is an exciting and an historic day and continues an ongoing effort to ensure that rural America is a full participant in the clean energy economy,” Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack says.

site_title: Hotel deals, new condo launches, and tax takings
summary: Singapore's commercial market remains strong despite US and global market declines, driven by factors such as the city-state's unique business environment and tourism demand. A German asset manager's Singapore property is up for sale, while UOL Group sold its Parkroyal hotel for S$525 million. Meanwhile, the HDB resale market sees price resistance and slower sales, with transaction volumes falling 18% in June. New condo launches continue, with two projects opening for sale last week, and a plot of state land next to Pinetree Hill coming up for tender in August.

images.alt_text: In the latest edition of his column, The Level Ground, Leslie Yee argues the Jurong Lake District site is worth serious consideration by major developers.
Singapore’s office market is far from distressed, but pockets of weakness are opening up in prime Grade A CBD space, says BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: China says its 'priority' is to stop Taiwan VP visiting US next month
summary: China's ambassador to the US has stated that stopping Taiwan Vice President William Lai's visit to the US is a priority due to Beijing's view that Taiwan is its own territory. Lai is on a stopover in the US on his way to Paraguay for an inauguration, drawing anger from China. China has increased military and pressure on Taiwan over the past three years, with Taiwan rejecting Beijing's sovereignty claims. The US diplomat in Taipei has said there's no reason for China to take provocative action in response to Lai's visit.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 19, 2016, a Chinese soldier holds a Chinese flag during Peace Mission-2016 joint military exercises of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) in the Edelweiss training area in Balykchy, some 200 km from Bishkek. - During Xi Jinping's decade-long rule China has built the world's largest navy, revamped the world's largest standing army and amassed a nuclear and ballistic arsenal to trouble any foe. (Photo by Vyacheslav OSELEDKO / AFP)

site_title: Game studio Eyeball Games raises US$1.5 million in pre-seed round
summary: Eyeball Games, a Singapore-based game studio, has raised US$1.5 million in a pre-seed funding round led by White Star Capital's Ubisoft-backed Digital Asset Fund. The funding will support the development of Eyeball Games' first game, Eyeball Pool, a Web3-enabled mobile game launching on the Polygon x Immutable zkEVM chain in early 2024. The startup, founded in 2022, plans to release the game in phases, with holders of non-fungible tokens participating in a closed beta test.

images.alt_text: Google Play’s updated guidelines, which go into effect Dec. 7, say that games can support transactions involving tokenized assets under the platform’s existing Real-Money Gambling, Games, and Contests policy.

site_title: China professor says youth jobless rate might have hit 46.5%
summary: A Chinese professor, Zhang Dandan, estimates China's youth jobless rate may have hit 46.5% in March, including 16 million non-students relying on their parents. This contradicts the official youth jobless rate of 19.7% reported by the National Bureau of Statistics. Zhang's research highlights the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and recent regulations on the manufacturing sector, disproportionately affecting young employees. The discrepancy has sparked a debate about official data and the soft labor market, with some social media users sharing their struggles to find employment in China.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People attend a job fair in China's southwestern city of Chongqing on April 11, 2023. Unemployment among Chinese youths jumped to a record 21.3 percent in June, the National Bureau of Statistics said on July 17, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Australian BNPL firm Zip’s credit performance in local market weakens further
summary: Zip, Australia's largest BNPL provider, reported a 3.1% net bad debt rate in the June quarter, its highest since 2022, due to poor domestic consumer credit and third-party payment processor discrepancies. Despite this, the company posted a 21.1% revenue increase to A$193.8 million and a 6.4% jump in transaction volumes. Shares rose 13.2% following the announcement. The company attributed the improvement in bad debt rates to US business growth, partially offset by softness in the broader Australian credit market.

images.alt_text: In May, Australia said it would regulate BNPL services as a consumer credit product under new laws. The new law would require BNPL firms to run credit checks before lending, notifying customers when credit limits increase and following dispute resolution processes.
The new laws will impact consumer credit firms from Zip to Afterpay, which compete with banks to provide interest-free credit that is typically repaid in instalments.

site_title: Russia warns ships in Black Sea, Ukraine to create temporary grains export route
summary: Russia has warned ships sailing to Ukraine's Black Sea ports from Thursday that they will be considered potential military targets, amid Russia's withdrawal from a safe-passage deal that threatens to worsen global food supplies. Ukraine has established a temporary shipping route via Romania, while the International Monetary Fund warns that Russia's exit from the deal could increase food prices. The US has also accused Russia of laying additional sea mines in the approaches to Ukrainian ports, which could justify any attacks against civilian ships.

images.alt_text: An IMF spokesperson says the global lender would continue to carefully monitor ongoing developments in the region and their impact on global food insecurity.

site_title: Japan cuts growth forecast, sees inflation exceeding central bank target
summary: Japan's government has cut its economic growth forecast for the current fiscal year to 1.3% due to slowing global demand, but expects robust consumption and capital expenditure to drive growth. The government also projects a 2.6% overall consumer inflation rate this fiscal year, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida stated that Japan's economy is recovering moderately, with steady wage hikes and strong corporate spending appetite, but the central bank may reconsider its ultra-loose policy given the upgraded inflation forecasts.

images.alt_text: Imports fell 12.9 per cent year-on-year in June, versus the median estimate for a 11.2 per cent decrease.

site_title: Malaysia exports down 14.1% in June as orders for manufactured goods slip
summary: Malaysia's exports declined 14.1% year-on-year in June to RM124 billion, dragged down by lower shipments of manufactured goods. The country's total trade declined 16.3% to RM222.1 billion, with a trade surplus of RM25.8 billion. Economists expect the trade performance to continue on a weaker track due to a high base effect and slower global demand. Exports to key markets such as Singapore and China also fell, while imports declined 18.9% to RM98.2 billion.

images.alt_text: The Asian Development Bank cut Vietnam's growth forecast for 2023 as weaker external demand weighs on manfuacturing output.

site_title: Mizuho to set up 10 billion yen venture debt fund for Japan
summary: Mizuho Financial Group is launching a 10 billion yen (S$95 million) venture debt fund in Japan to support middle and late-stage startups without diluting shareholder equity. The fund aims to finance startups in deep tech fields such as biotech, space, and renewable energy, where large upfront investments are required. According to Mizuho's retail and business banking chief Kazutoshi Isogai, the fund will provide financing to help these startups overcome the scarcity of venture capital in Japan.

site_title: Record rent increases boost King Charles’ income
summary: King Charles received £26.2 million from his vast property empire, the Duchy of Lancaster, in 2023, a 2 million-pound increase from his mother Queen Elizabeth's income. The duchy's rent hikes accounted for an extra £8.2 million, contributing to a cost-of-living crisis in the UK. Despite the financial woes faced by the nation, King Charles' private income from the duchy has increased, and the monarch's business-driven strategy remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: Harry and Meghan were reportedly told to vacate Frogmore Cottage in January, just days after the publication of the prince’s tell-all memoir "Spare".

site_title: 🤸 Making side hustles work for you
summary: A recent Thrive newsletter discusses the importance of making side hustles work for individuals, providing a fresh perspective on finding meaning in mundane tasks. The newsletter also covers various topics, including the resurgence of vintage digicams among Gen Z, voter reflections on the 2025 General Election, and investing in oneself. The content aims to inspire readers to find purpose and meaning in their lives, whether through work, leisure, or personal growth.

site_title: EasyJet reports record Q3 results on back of summer travel demand
summary: EasyJet has reported a record pretax profit of $262.5 million for its third quarter, exceeding analysts' forecasts, driven by strong summer travel demand and limited disruptions despite ongoing strikes. The airline expects to report record pretax profit for its fourth quarter, with ticket yields soaring 22% year-on-year. CEO Johan Lundgren warned about potential impacts of limited airspace availability and air traffic control strikes, but stated that the strikes have not caused major disruptions so far. The airline's optimistic outlook is further driven by robust winter bookings and a planned 15% capacity increase in December.

images.alt_text: Easyjet has scrapped 1,700 flights that were due to operate in July, August and September, which will affect around 180,000 passengers.

site_title: Traffic at Changi Airport crosses 5m mark in June
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore reached a milestone of 5.12 million passengers in June, surpassing the 5 million mark for the first time since January 2020. The airport, ranked the best in the world, saw passenger traffic surge to 88% of pre-pandemic levels, indicating a strong recovery in international ties. The rebound is attributed to travelers' willingness to travel despite economic concerns, with key markets including Australia, India, and Indonesia. The airport aims to build ties to more points in China and South-east Asia in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Passengers queueing at the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 3 on Mar 31, 2023. Delays are expected across some land and air checkpoints due to a disruption in the immigration clearance system. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) announced the disruption on Facebook at 11.28am on Friday, adding that it “regrets the inconvenience caused to travellers and seeks their understanding and patience”. In an update at 12.03pm, it advised travellers to postpone all non-essential travel.

site_title: Swiss watch exports jump again in June as demand stays strong
summary: Swiss watch exports surged 14% in June to 2.4 billion Swiss francs ($2.8 billion), driven by strong demand from the US and China. This marks the second consecutive month of growth, despite concerns over economic growth and higher prices. The first half of the year saw a 12% increase in exports to 13.3 billion francs, with shipments to the US and China rising 8.8% and 9% respectively. Demand for lower-priced watches also improved, with exports in the 200-500 franc category rising 19%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Swiss watch maker Swatch Group is pictured on a store in Geneva, Switzerland, May 31, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo
Swiss watch exports have continued to increase in 2023 after reaching a record of more than 24 billion Swiss francs (S$36.9 billion) last year.
A Omega Speedmaster watch stands on display during the 2018 Baselworld luxury watch and jewelery fair in Basel, Switzerland, on Thursday, March 22, 2018.Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

site_title: Americans overtake Chinese as top foreign buyers of Singapore condos in Q2: OrangeTee
summary: US surpasses China as top foreign buyer of Singapore condos in Q2, with 56 non-landed homes purchased, marginally more than 51 units bought by non-PR mainland Chinese buyers. The US proportion rose to 27.3% in Q2, while mainland Chinese buyers' proportion fell to 24.9%. The Singapore government's doubling of the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for foreigners contributed to the decline in foreign purchases. Despite this, property experts expect buying activities to persist in the second half of the year, with overall property prices stabilizing at around 4-6% growth.

images.alt_text: Developers sold less private homes in June 2023.
Will the latest ABSD rate hike help lower new home prices?
URA's flash estimate has shown a 3.2 per cent quarter-on-quarter rise for its overall private home price index in Q1 2023.

site_title: South Korea financial watchdog gathers securities firms to manage real estate risks
summary: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Service gathered securities firms to assess real estate-related risks amid concerns of rising non-performing loans. The firms were urged to write off or restructure overdue loans to manage debt delinquency rates. A recent incident at a local credit union, where customer withdrawals were triggered by media reports on overdue real estate loans, highlighted the need for proactive measures. Authorities will intensify monitoring of securities firms' exposure to real estate projects and engage with those at high vulnerability to prevent liquidity risks.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands Q2 net revenue grows 36% on record mass gaming
summary: Marina Bay Sands' Q2 net revenue grew 36% on record mass gaming, driven by a 29.8% increase in casino revenue to US$649 million. Adjusted property earnings surpassed pre-Covid-19 levels, reaching US$432 million. Occupancy rates rose to 97% and average daily rates increased 80% year-over-year. The resort's mass gaming revenue reached a record US$580 million, while room revenue and food and beverage revenue also saw significant gains.

images.alt_text: Beneficiaries from APSN Centre for Adults with staff volunteers from MBS.
The Londoner Macao celebrated its grand opening in Macau in late May, complete with replicas of London landmarks such as the Big Ben.
Mass gaming revenue reaches a record US$549 million in Q1, parent company Las Vegas Sands says.

site_title: China mulls mortgage easing to spur home purchases in big cities
summary: China is considering easing homebuying restrictions in major cities by removing a rule that disqualifies people with a mortgage record from being considered first-time homebuyers. This move aims to boost demand in cities like Beijing and Shanghai, where curbed demand has been a hurdle for years. State banks have submitted relevant mortgage data to regulators, and the plans are currently under discussion. If approved, the change could lead to lower down payment requirements and more flexible borrowing limits for first-time homebuyers.

images.alt_text: Evergrande’s financial woes even started to affect operations at the building, which sits in Hong Kong’s busy Wan Chai district.

site_title:
EV startup Maka Motors bags 
US$37.6 million in seed funding
summary: Maka Motors, an Indonesian electric vehicle startup, has secured US$37.6 million in seed funding co-led by AC Ventures, East Ventures, and SV Investment. Founded by Raditya Wibowo and Arief Fadillah in 2021, the company aims to accelerate electric motorcycle adoption in Indonesia. The funds will be used to scale operations, expand R&D capabilities, and boost production. Maka Motors' first mass-market product is in development, with a factory set to be built in West Java later this year.

site_title: Latest 6-month Treasury bill offers 3.85% cut-off yield
summary: The latest six-month Treasury bill auction in Singapore received a total of S$12.2 billion in applications for the S$5.6 billion on offer, resulting in a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.18. The cut-off yield for the auction fell to 3.85%, marking a decrease from the previous six-month tenor of 3.99%.

images.alt_text: Taking on some risk by buying high quality dividend paying shares can be prudent.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS)‘s data published on Thursday (Jul 6) showed that a total of S$5.4 billion was allotted out of the S$10.3 billion received in applications.
Singapore dollar currency notes

site_title: Nokia profit falls as North American slowdown dents margins
summary: Nokia reported a decline in second-quarter profit due to a slowdown in North American demand, primarily from high-margin customers. The company expects second-half net sales to be broadly similar to the first half, with sequential improvement in the fourth quarter. Growth in 5G gear sales in low-margin markets like India failed to offset the decline. CEO Pekka Lundmark attributed the slowdown to operators in North America reducing their investments more than expected, after a strong 2021 and 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Nokia logo is seen on a smartphone in front of a displayed stock graph in this illustration taken February 5, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Tesla margins slip on price war, Musk warns of ‘turbulent times’
summary: Tesla reported a quarterly automotive gross margin of 18.1% in line with estimates, but lower than a year earlier. The company slashed prices several times, increasing discounts and incentives to reduce inventory, which pressured margins. CEO Elon Musk warned of "turbulent times" and said Tesla would sacrifice margin to drive volume growth. Despite this, the company beat profit estimates and reported record deliveries of 466,000 vehicles globally. Musk also discussed licensing its full self-driving software and the company's progress on yield improvement of its 4680 battery cell production lines.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s earnings may end up being a side-show if chief executive officer Elon Musk gives investors highly-anticipated updates on new products, refreshes of existing vehicles and AI.
The attendees’ main concern at Tuesday’s event is how Tesla will manage to expand the plant without using additional water.

site_title: Australia telco giant Telstra to cut nearly 500 jobs
summary: Australia's telecommunications giant Telstra plans to cut nearly 500 jobs due to digitization, automation, and exiting legacy products and services. The 1% workforce reduction affects approximately 472 jobs, excluding customer-facing units. This move comes as businesses worldwide seek cost-cutting measures amid inflation and rising interest rates. Telstra's efforts aim to gain efficiencies from new technology and reduce the impact of exiting legacy products.

images.alt_text: Telstra expects to be able to offer the new service options to both customers and businesses towards the end of the year.
Optus says it views the decision to block Telstra and TPG Telecom’s proposed network sharing agreement as a favourable one.

site_title: Australian employment rises further in June, currency gains
summary: Australian employment rose further in June, surpassing expectations, with the jobless rate holding at 3.5% and the economy adding 32,600 roles. The data suggests a tight labor market, with employment growth in line with population growth. The Australian dollar strengthened to 68.28 US cents, while three-year bond yields jumped 12 basis points. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to resume rate hikes next month, with traders betting on a 50% chance. The data supports the RBA's confidence that Australia can avoid a recession, but may require further rate rises to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: The RBA this month left interest rates unchanged at 4.1 per cent.

site_title: TSMC profit decline smaller than feared as AI boom offsets tech slump
summary: TSMC posted a smaller-than-expected profit decline, with net income of NT$181.8 billion for the June quarter, beating analysts' estimates. The company's AI-related business offset a slump in smartphone demand, with AI chip orders rising. Despite a 10% decline in second-quarter revenue, TSMC's earnings trajectory in H2 may still be impacted by a sluggish smartphone sector. The company is diversifying its manufacturing footprint to mitigate concerns over geopolitical uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Biren’s fundraising efforts come as the Chinese government accelerates its campaign to develop its domestic semiconductor industry, after a US-led effort that blocked Chinese companies’ ability to buy advanced chips

site_title: Netflix sales and forecast come up short
summary: Netflix reported a 2.7% increase in sales to $8.19 billion, short of Wall Street estimates, despite an 8% growth in subscribers. The company's stock fell 10% in extended trading, following a disappointing earnings report. Despite a solid quarter, Netflix's growth is still not meeting analysts' expectations, with revenue per customer declining. The company attributes the shortfall to foreign exchange rates and price cuts in some markets, but expects sales growth to accelerate in the coming months.

site_title: Grab acquires taxi company Trans-cab
summary: Grab, a NASDAQ-listed ride-hailing company, acquired Singapore's third-largest taxi operator Trans-cab through its subsidiary Grab Rentals. The acquisition was valued around S$100 million. Trans-cab was privately owned and was the Republic's third-largest taxi company. The deal marks Grab's expansion into the Singaporean taxi market.

images.alt_text: The exterior of of the Grab headquarters in Singapore, pictured on December 20, 2022. Can be used for stories on delivery, business, food and beverage, economy, jobs, population, and Singapore.
Grab’s digital bank, that’s also backed by Singapore Telecommunications, was set up just under a year ago.
The representative framework seeks to build “a society with stronger safety nets" for platform workers, like Grab drivers and riders.
Grab's latest round of retrenchment has cast a pall over those left behind, while those impacted have seen the community rally around them.
Grab held a company-wide town hall on Wednesday for the survivors of the layoffs, where Tan fielded questions about the possibility of a second round of cuts.

site_title: China central bank eases cross-border financing rule to temper yuan weakness
summary: China's central bank eased cross-border financing rules, raising the ratio to 1.5 from 1.25 to make it easier for domestic firms to raise funds from overseas markets. The move aims to ease yuan depreciation pressure and prevent excessive FX volatility. The onshore yuan strengthened by 0.8% to a high of 7.1620 following the announcement, which was seen as a sign of the PBOC's efforts to defend its currency.

images.alt_text: The steady LPR fixings come as the People’s Bank of China rolled over maturing medium-term policy loans and kept the interest rate unchanged earlier this week.

site_title: Our civilisation was built for a climate that’s vanishing
summary: Global temperatures are near record highs, with cities like Tokyo, Delhi, and Phoenix experiencing unprecedented heatwaves. Climate records are falling daily, and extreme weather events, such as floods, wildfires, and droughts, are becoming more frequent. The warming caused by two centuries of industrial civilization has already put human societies within the range of epoch-making events that shaped human history. The coming upheaval is expected to affect 3.4 billion people by 2050, with relatively wealthy regions being the most at risk. A switch to cleaner energy and food systems is seen as a small price to pay to avoid unpredictable and dire consequences.

images.alt_text: Italy’s Environment Ministry has warned in a report this year that foreign tourists will in future travel more in the spring and autumn and choose cooler destinations.
Prolonged high temperatures in China are threatening power grids and crops and raising concerns about a repeat of last year’s drought, the most severe in 60 years.
China has a four-tier, colour-coded weather warning system, with red the most severe, followed by orange, yellow and blue.

site_title: Made in Russia? Chinese cars drive a revival of Russia’s auto factories
summary: Russia's auto industry is experiencing a revival, driven by Chinese carmakers, which now account for 49% of the market. The Moskvich, a classic Soviet-era car, has been relaunched by a state-owned company, with engine parts and upholstery sourced from China's JAC Motors. Six factories in Russia, formerly owned by European, Japanese, and US carmakers, are now producing Chinese models or have plans to do so, with an annual capacity of around 600,000 cars. The industry's growth benefits Russia, enabling it to restart production and keep workers employed, but profits are increasingly dependent on the yuan exchange rate.

images.alt_text: Farizon, which started selling vehicles in 2016, sold roughly 37,800 light commercial vehicles in China in 2022, according to consultancy LMC Automotive.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says the plan was conveyed to him in a letter from Geely.

site_title: China keeps lending benchmarks unchanged; economic weakness tests policymakers
summary: China kept its lending benchmarks unchanged, with the one-year loan prime rate (LPR) at 3.55% and the five-year LPR at 4.20%, despite economic weakness. The decision came as the country's economy grew at a frail pace in the second quarter, prompting hopes for more stimulus. However, policymakers are cautious, as rate cuts could widen interest rate differentials with the US and pressure the weak yuan. The central bank will use policy tools to weather the challenges, and a poll of market watchers predicted no change to the rates.

images.alt_text: The drop in exports was the worst since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic more than three years ago.

site_title: With Pita out of PM race, Thailand braces for mass protests and tussle for power
summary: Thailand is bracing for mass protests and a power struggle after Pita Limjaroenrat, the leader of the party that won the May 14 general election, was barred by parliament from running for prime minister. The parliament will vote again on July 27, and Pita's coalition partners, including Pheu Thai, are likely to seek the top job. The move has sparked concerns about a delay in forming a government, which could hurt Thailand's economy, particularly tourism. The country's caretaker Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha will remain in charge, and investors are worried about the impact on borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: “I would like to say goodbye until we meet again,” Pita Limjaroenrat tells the chamber, raising his fist as he leaves the assembly floor to the cheers of fellow lawmakers.

TOPSHOT - Move Forward Party supporters and pro-democracy activists gather to protest the day after Move Forward Party Leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat failed to secure the parliamentary vote for the premiership in Bangkok on July 14, 2023. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
The government has prepared some 120 billion baht to shore up South-east Asia’s second-largest economy and will speed up investment and other spending.

site_title: Evergrande creditors seized a US$1.6 billion tower they can’t sell
summary: China Evergrande's creditors failed to sell a US$1.6 billion tower in Hong Kong's Wan Chai district after almost a year of efforts. The 26-floor building, renamed the YF Life Centre, was bought by Evergrande in 2015 for a record price. Despite refurbishments and a discount, potential buyers are hesitant due to Hong Kong's struggling commercial property market, with office values declining 35% from their peak in 2018. The sale's failure signals challenges for secured lenders of China's defaulted developers, who may struggle to recover debts from trophy assets in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Evergrande has asked to convene meetings for offshore creditors to approve its credit overhaul plan, after reporting long-delayed financial statements for 2021 and 2022.

site_title: Tesla launches Model Y in Malaysia for RM199,000 in South-east Asia push
summary: Tesla has launched its Model Y in Malaysia with a starting price of RM199,000 (S$57,840), aiming to boost sustainable mobility in the South-east Asian nation. The move comes a week after Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim held a virtual meeting with Tesla founder Elon Musk on investments involving the electric vehicle giant and SpaceX's satellite Internet service. Deliveries are set to begin early next year, marking Tesla's entry into the Malaysian market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla super chargers are shown in Mojave, California, U.S. July 10, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Geely truck unit, Farizon, raises US$600 million in funding round
summary: Chinese electric and hybrid truck maker Farizon has raised US$600 million in a Series-A funding round led by Boyu Capital and Yuexiu Industrial Fund. The funds will be used for technology and product development, as well as expansion outside of China. Farizon plans to establish a presence in Asia-Pacific, the Middle East, South America, and Europe, with a focus on Europe, where it will start selling its light electric cargo van, the Super Van, as early as 2024. The company expects sales of 150,000 vehicles this year, with a majority of its overall sales volume still coming from China.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says the plan was conveyed to him in a letter from Geely.

site_title: Alibaba injects US$845 million into South-east Asia unit Lazada
summary: Alibaba has invested US$845 million into Lazada, its South-east Asian online retail business, amid intensifying competition from Sea and Amazon. This capital infusion brings Alibaba's total investment in Lazada to several billion dollars since 2016. The move is part of Alibaba's plan to split its international online shopping unit into six parts to spur growth, including e-commerce, logistics, and the cloud. The company had previously explored splitting off Lazada and had discussed raising US$1 billion in funding in 2022 before mothballing the plans and injecting additional funds instead.

site_title: Japan exports underwhelm in June, global weakness drags on economy
summary: Japan's exports grew 1.5% year-on-year in June, below the 2.3% gain expected by economists, amid weak global demand. Imports fell 12.9% year-on-year, easing concerns about rising costs. The trade surplus narrowed to 43 billion yen, contrary to the median estimate of a 90.1 billion yen deficit. Weakening global economy and monetary policy tightening since last year are attributed to the underwhelming exports, casting a pall over Japan's post-Covid recovery.

images.alt_text: The service-sector index fared much better, with the non-manufacturers index slipping just one point to +23, though it was a second straight month of decline.

site_title: Keppel funds buy Seoul tower; S Korean portfolio now 2.6 trillion won
summary: Keppel Corporation announced the acquisition of the Bank of Korea's Sogong Annex Facility in Seoul's Central Business District, expanding its South Korean portfolio to 2.6 trillion won (S$2.6 billion). The 13-storey office tower, spanning 15,750 square meters, will be held by Keppel Asia Macro Trends Fund IV and a co-investment programme.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation has acquired 50 per cent of a 13-storey office tower at Seoul’s CBD, bringing its South Korean portfolio to S$2.6 billion.
An illustration of the Keppel Sakra Cogen Plant, which is envisaged to be able to save up to 220,000 tons of carbon dioxide per year.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise on rate hopes but China fears weigh
summary: Asia's stock markets mostly rose on Thursday, driven by hopes that interest rate hikes are subduing inflation, allowing central banks to take a softer approach to monetary policy. Despite this, China's economy weighed on sentiment, with weak data and concerns about deflation. The mood was generally positive, with US inflation slowing and a low UK inflation reading, which fueled expectations of a softer landing. Analysts remain cautious, warning the road ahead could still be bumpy, and investors are anxious for Beijing to set measures to reinvigorate growth.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was hit by a sharp drop in tech firms while Shanghai and Seoul were also down.

site_title: Singapore ringfences ‘commercial and residential’ land from foreign buyers
summary: Singapore has implemented changes to the Residential Property Act (RPA) to restrict foreign buyers from purchasing land zoned for "commercial and residential" use. Effective immediately, foreigners must obtain government approval to retain and redevelop existing properties in these zones. This move aims to "safeguard residential land for Singaporeans." Existing property owners will still need to seek approval under the RPA to retain and redevelop their properties.

images.alt_text: The Jalan Tembusu site, for private housing development, is near the future Tanjong Katong MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.

site_title: BHP posts record full-year iron ore output, flags rising costs
summary: BHP Group reported its highest-ever annual iron ore production, reaching 72.7 million metric tons in the three months to June 30, aided by improved rail performance at its Western Australia mines. The company expects fiscal 2024 iron ore production to be between 282-294 million metric tons, a 0.9% increase from the previous year. Despite rising costs, BHP forecasts copper production to rise 9% to 1,716.5 thousand metric tons in fiscal 2024, driven by higher grades at its top copper mine and integration of Oz Minerals into its business.

images.alt_text: BHP estimates the world needs to double the amount of copper produced over the next 30 years to keep pace with the development of decarbonisation technology.

site_title: Musk says Tesla to spend over US$1 billion on Dojo supercomputer
summary: Elon Musk announced that Tesla plans to invest over $1 billion in its in-house supercomputer, Project Dojo, by the end of 2024. The supercomputer is designed to handle massive amounts of data, including video from Tesla cars, for autonomous driving software development. The investment, which is part of Tesla's three-year expense outlook, has sparked a 4% postmarket slide in Tesla's share price. Musk stated that Tesla has a "staggering amount" of data, including over 300 million miles of data from its Autopilot and Full Self Driving Beta features.

site_title: UBS wealth arm looks for pullback in Japan stocks before buying
summary: UBS Global Wealth Management is waiting for a 5-8% correction in Japanese stocks before investing, citing "no longer depressed" valuations and muted share buybacks during the summer. Japanese shares have risen 19% this year, driven by a weak yen and overseas demand. If a correction occurs, UBS will consider adding to the market. The firm's head of chief investment office Asia Pacific, Min Lan Tan, notes that the summer months may see profit taking and a pause in the market due to a lack of share buyback catalysts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at the company's office at the Bahnhofstrasse in Zurich in this July 1, 2009 file photo.   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
The size of the contract will require EY to call in staff from other countries to work on the audit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Sabana Reit
summary: Keppel's private funds acquired a 13-storey office tower in Seoul's Central Business District, increasing its South Korean portfolio to 2.6 trillion won. The group also broke ground for Singapore's first hydrogen-ready co-generation plant. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) posted a distribution per unit of S$0.0161 for the first half of its fiscal year, up 1.3% year on year.

images.alt_text: A generic picture of the Keppel Corporation logo at the Central Business District, shot on December 23, 2022. Can be used for stories on offshore and marine, property, infrastructure and asset management businesses, money, banking, economy, recession, finance, investments, banks and Singapore.

site_title: myBT personalisation feature now available on the BT app
summary: BT has rolled out its myBT feature for registered users and subscribers, allowing them to personalize their reading experience by curating topics of interest. The feature is now available on both the web and the BT app, and users can set up myBT by selecting keywords on the onboarding page. Users can also change or add to their keywords by tapping the settings button or following keywords from article pages. The feature aims to provide users with a more tailored reading experience, with stories displayed based on their selected keywords.

images.alt_text: By following keywords, myBT users can personalise their BT reading experience.
By following keywords, myBT users can personalise their BT reading experience.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.2% to 3,280.56 on Thursday, driven by overnight gains in US and European markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) saw 44.8 million securities worth S$47.4 million trade, with advancers outnumbering decliners 56 to 48. Key performers included Seatrium, Genting Singapore, and DBS, while UOB and OCBC were mixed. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with Wall Street stocks ending slightly higher on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation has acquired 50 per cent of a 13-storey office tower at Seoul’s CBD, bringing its South Korean portfolio to S$2.6 billion.

site_title: Here is how you can catch the Liverpool pre-season friendlies against Leicester City and Bayern Munich
summary: Liverpool FC will play two pre-season friendlies in Singapore, against Leicester City on July 30 and FC Bayern Munich on August 2. The games are part of the inaugural Singapore Festival of Football, with The Business Times offering two pairs of tickets to subscribers. This will be Liverpool's second visit to Singapore in two years, following their 2-0 win over Crystal Palace in 2022.

images.alt_text: Lion City Sailors are the latest addition to the Singapore Festival of Football.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher as earnings season continues
summary: US stocks ended slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.3% to 35,061.21, extending an eight-day bullish run. Major banks including Morgan Stanley and Bank of America saw their share prices increase after beating earnings expectations. Despite Goldman Sachs' 62% drop in second-quarter profits, its shares ended 1% higher after executives hinted at an improvement. The S&P 500 advanced 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite Index remained flat, as investors await the release of Tesla and Netflix's earnings.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 39.28 points, or 0.11 per cent, at the open to 34,991.21.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sells US$6.75 billion of debt amid bond rush
summary: Morgan Stanley sold $6.75 billion of debt in a four-part deal, marking the latest in a wave of bank bond sales amid a reporting season surge. The sale, which saw $29 billion in orders, suggests investors are hungry for financial issuance, potentially signaling a rebound in the second half of 2023. The deluge of transactions comes as lenders emerge from earnings blackout periods and seek to meet new regulations requiring greater total loss absorbing capacity.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley’s remaining staff on the mainland have started to build a standalone China system to comply with local regulations.
Morgan Stanley has reported 82,006 employees at the end of June, down from 82,266 at March’s end.

site_title: Gold hovers near eight-week high on hopes of US Fed rate-hike pause
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,978.59 per ounce, nearing an eight-week peak, as investors anticipate a possible pause in the US Federal Reserve's interest rate-hiking cycle. The dollar index wobbled near a one-year low, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies. The Fed is expected to raise rates by 25 basis points next week, but investors are betting on a potential pause. Gold holdings rose at the SPDR Gold Trust, and China is set to keep lending benchmarks unchanged despite a faltering economy.

images.alt_text: The hallmark details on a one kilogram gold bar are seen at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: China vows to boost private economy, protect businesses
summary: China's Communist Party and government have pledged to boost support for private companies, treating them equally to state-owned enterprises, and protect businesses and entrepreneurs. The government will provide support for share listings, bond sales, and overseas expansion, and will prevent unjust lawsuits. While the move is seen as a positive signal, analysts note that it doesn't represent a dramatic shift in policy, and concrete measures are needed to enforce the changes. The announcement has led to a rally in Chinese company shares, with the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index rising 2.9% on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration is considering new rules that would restrict the flow of US investments in Chinese companies working on advanced semiconductors, AI and quantum computing.
China’s private sector has been hit by Covid-19 curbs and a wide-ranging regulatory crackdown that targeted sectors from technology to property.

site_title: What Taylor Swift tells us about Singapore vs Hong Kong
summary: Taylor Swift's upcoming tour plans have intensified the rivalry between Singapore and Hong Kong, with Swift opting to perform in Singapore over Hong Kong. This decision has sparked debate among expats in Singapore, with some expressing disappointment and others commending the city-state's ability to attract top international acts. The heightened competition has also led to soaring prices for hotels and flights to Singapore, further exacerbating the issue of affordability.

images.alt_text: On top of increased search activity for the duration of Swift's Singapore concerts, more actual bookings have also been made at hotels, and some flight prices are recording increases.
Agoda regional associate vice-president for South-east Asia Eenric Casals says that searches for Singapore during Taylor Swift's concert dates have already surged, ahead of ticket sales next week.
R

site_title: Bank Indonesia rates on hold for rest of year, cut in Q1 2024: poll
summary: Bank Indonesia (BI) will maintain its key interest rate at 5.75% for the rest of the year, according to a Reuters poll of economists. This decision comes as inflation is expected to average 3.8% this year and decline to 3.0% next year, staying within BI's 2-4% target range. This move aims to maintain the stability of the Indonesian rupiah, as inflation remains within the central bank's target range, contrary to expectations of further interest rate hikes in the US, Britain, and the eurozone.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's imports have fallen 18.35 per cent on a yearly basis to US$17.15 billion.
India’s Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman and her Indonesian counterpart Sri Mulyani Indrawati discussed the proposals ahead of meetings among the Group of Twenty countries in India

site_title: Europe: Shares gain as homebuilders surge; UK stocks shine
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% on Wednesday, extending gains for the second straight session, led by UK stocks after a slower-than-expected British inflation rate boosted hopes of peaking interest rates. London's FTSE 100 index advanced 1.8% as the pound slipped, while the broader real estate index rose 4.3%. Despite expectations of a 97% chance of a 25 basis point interest rate hike next week, markets focus on data and policymakers for signs of slowing inflation.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6 per cent lower, with luxury giants at the forefront of the selling pressure.

site_title: Chairman of Chinese aluminium giant Chalco resigns after two years
summary: Chairman of Chinese aluminum giant Chalco, Liu Jianping, has resigned after two years in office due to a "work adjustment". The departure comes amid a government-led investigation into deals in the market, with a unit of the company terminating some aluminum contracts. Liu's resignation has no connection to the reported suspension of contracts, according to the company. Zhu Runzhou will act as chairman of the board of directors until a new chairman is appointed.

site_title: When large companies provide free upskilling for SMEs, everyone gains
summary: Large companies can benefit by supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in digitalizing and upskilling, leading to increased insights into new markets, supplier base, and societal value. Initiatives such as low-barrier skilling programs and flexible training courses can create a digital upskilling "flywheel" for SMEs. Companies can share expertise through low-cost online courses, and public-private partnerships can provide solutions at scale. By supporting SMEs, businesses can also boost employee satisfaction, retention, and attract tech talent, ultimately driving growth.

images.alt_text: Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Ministry of Trade and Industry and Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, spoke at the event, encouraging SMEs to upskill themselves through digitalisation.
Minister for Transport Dr Tan See Leng encourages retailers to adapt to shifting consumer demands.

site_title: Congressional panel probes US firms’ investments in China
summary: A US House of Representatives committee has launched an investigation into investments by four US venture capital firms into Chinese AI and semiconductor companies, citing concerns over human rights abuses, military modernization, and technological competition. The probe, the first in a series, requests information from firms GGV Capital, GSR Ventures, Walden International, and Qualcomm Ventures by August 1.
