The Biden administration is also considering new rules to restrict US investments in Chinese companies working on advanced semiconductors, AI, and quantum computing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A central processing unit (CPU) semiconductor chip is displayed among flags of China and U.S., in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices dip on profit-taking despite tighter US supplies
summary: Oil prices declined on Wednesday, falling 17 cents to $79.46 a barrel for Brent futures and 40 cents to $75.35 a barrel for US WTI crude. Investors took profits after earlier gains due to tighter US supplies and China's pledge to boost economic growth. A stronger US dollar also weighed on prices, while US crude inventories fell 708,000 barrels to 457.4 million barrels. Market analysts believe the end of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve's releases will lead to more stable oil prices.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates increase borrowing costs and can slow economic growth and reduce oil demand.

site_title: Deep tech creates good vibes for plants and people
summary: Singapore-based company JAH Tech has developed a ceramic alloy technology that emits an electromagnetic field, improving agricultural yields and potentially benefiting plants and people. CEO Tan Chong Hui aims to build the company's reputation and become profitable within the next one to two years. The technology, which has shown positive impact in various areas, is being commercialized by JAH Tech, which is exploring multiple applications beyond agriculture.

images.alt_text: Redhill Communications aims to list on the New York Stock Exchange in 2024, says founder and chief executive Jacob Puthenparambil.
Despite the gloom, Singapore is still expected to produce a “steady pipeline” of emerging tech startups.

site_title: Gucci parent Kering taps defence advisers as activist Bluebell circles
summary: Kering, the French luxury group behind Gucci, is speaking to defense advisers amid activist investor Bluebell Capital Partners' push for improvements and organizational changes. Bluebell has taken a stake in Kering and met company officials, seeking better performance at Gucci and potential deals. The company has been preparing to boost shareholder engagement efforts, but faces challenges from the Pinault family's 42% stake and 59.3% voting rights. Gucci's sales disappointed in the first quarter, and the brand is expected to report weak second-quarter results.

images.alt_text: Kering last year saw sales rise nine per cent on a comparable basis, with Gucci’s sales edging up only one per cent.
CAA represents thousands of actors, directors and music artists.
The French luxury group made the acquisition since flagging intentions earlier in the year to create an in-house cosmetics business.

site_title: US single-family starts drop; building permits hit 12-month high
summary: US single-family homebuilding dropped 7.0% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 935,000 units in June, according to the Commerce Department. Despite this decline, permits for future construction rose to a 12-month high, with single-family building permits increasing 2.2% to 922,000 units. The housing market is expected to stabilize, but rising mortgage rates may mute the anticipated rebound, with the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate approaching 7%.

images.alt_text: With new construction activity at the highest level in more than a year, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta’s GDPNow tracker is projecting that residential investment added 0.1 per cent to growth in gross domestic product in the second quarter.

A worker nails a piece of lumber to a wall frame on the site of a home under construction at the M/I Homes Inc. Bougainvillea Place housing development in Ellenton, Florida, U.S., on Thursday, July 6, 2017. The U.S. Census Bureau is scheduled to release housing starts figures on July 19. Photographer: Ty Wright/Bloomberg
The increase in building costs comes as Canada grapples with high home prices and rents, an immigration-driven population boom, and shortages of workers and raw materials.

site_title: Nasdaq beats profit estimates on steady demand for investment products
summary: Nasdaq beat profit estimates for the second quarter, driven by consistent demand for investment-related products and capital markets solutions, such as anti-financial crime software. The company's diversified business model, shifting away from market-sensitive businesses like listing fees, helped mitigate the effects of a drought in the US market for IPOs. This strategy allowed Nasdaq to maintain steady growth despite rising interest rates and volatility.

images.alt_text: A blistering rally in growth and technology stocks has lifted the Nasdaq 100 index by 37.5 per cent this year.
The adjustment will be based on shares outstanding as of Jul 3, with changes announced on Jul 14 and taking effect before the market opens on Jul 24.

site_title: Apple tests ‘Apple GPT’, develops generative AI tools to catch OpenAI
summary: Apple is developing its own generative AI tools, dubbed "Apple GPT," to compete with OpenAI, Google, and Microsoft. The company has built a framework called Ajax to create large language models, and a chatbot service called Apple GPT. Apple employees are using the tool to assist with product prototyping and answer questions based on data. The company is still determining the consumer angle for generative AI, but is working on several related initiatives, including a health coaching service and an electric car. Apple's CEO Tim Cook has expressed cautious optimism about the technology, but acknowledges potential issues.

images.alt_text: Following the deal between the two tech giants, the prices of Apple devices sold online rose in Spain.
Wechat users can buy Apple products including iPhones, iPads and Macs from its store.

site_title: MBS gearing up for annual charity festival by partnering APSN
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) is partnering with the Association for Persons with Special Needs (APSN) Centre for Adults to host a charity festival on August 4. The event, called Sands for Singapore Charity Festival, aims to provide opportunities for APSN's beneficiaries to engage in vocational training and gain skills in areas such as hospitality and horticulture. The collaboration aims to challenge the misconception that APSN beneficiaries are solely reliant on charity, highlighting their potential to contribute to society with proper training and support.

images.alt_text: From left: Minister Edwin Tong, Keppel Infrastructure CEO Cindy Lim and Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua with one of the electric trucks paid for with Keppel's donation.

site_title: IBM misses Q2 revenue estimates as tech spending cools
summary: IBM reported a 14.6% decline in its mainframe computer business revenue in Q2, missing Wall Street estimates. This decline is attributed to a cooling tech spending trend, with businesses cutting costs in the face of rising inflation. This trend is also affecting other IT companies, with Accenture and Tata Consultancy Services warning of demand weakness. The decline in tech spending is a departure from the rapid growth seen during the Covid-19 pandemic, and is expected to continue, posing challenges for the industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Two women pass by an IBM logo at the company's headquarters at la Defense in Paris, May 6, 2005. REUTERS/Philippe Wojazer  ABP/TC/File Photo
IBM provides Rapidus key process technology that enables 2nm chip nodes and beyond, using a new type of transistor composition called nanosheet

site_title: IMF says Russia exit from Ukraine grain deal risks adding to global food inflation
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that Russia's exit from the Ukraine grain deal could increase global food insecurity and drive up food prices, especially in low-income countries. The deal, which allowed Ukrainian exports via the Black Sea, has been instrumental in facilitating food, grain, and fertilizer exports, helping to tame international food price pressures. The IMF will continue to monitor the situation, which could worsen food security and global food inflation, particularly in North Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia.

site_title: Activision, Microsoft extend deal deadline to secure UK approval
summary: Microsoft and Activision have extended the deadline for their $69 billion deal to October 18, allowing them to address UK regulatory concerns. The companies initially missed their July 18 deadline due to US regulatory efforts and Britain's push to restructure the deal. The extension will also increase the fee owed to Activision in case the deal falls through, to $3.5 billion. Microsoft aims to secure UK approval to bolster its gaming portfolio with titles like Call of Duty and Diablo, competing with Tencent and Sony.

images.alt_text: Over the weekend, Microsoft struck a deal with Sony Group to ensure Activision’s popular Call of Duty franchise remains on Sony’s PlayStation platform for a decade.
Microsoft has offered to sell the cloud-based market rights for games in the UK.
The appeals court decision removes one of the few remaining hurdles stopping Xbox maker Microsoft from expanding its gaming business by closing its deal to buy Activision.
The software giant is re-engaging in talks with the UK Competition and Markets Authority, which had vetoed the deal in May.
The FTC says that by buying video-game publisher Activision Blizzard, Microsoft would gain an unfair advantage in consoles and cloud-gaming.

“We’re grateful to the court in San Francisco for this quick and thorough decision and hope other jurisdictions will continue working towards a timely resolution,” Microsoft president Brad Smith says.

site_title: Broadcom’s US$61 billion VMware deal gets interim UK clearance
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has provisionally cleared Broadcom's $61 billion takeover of VMware, stating that the deal is unlikely to substantially reduce competition in the supply of key computer server products. The CMA found that the potential lost business to Broadcom would outweigh the risk of harm to rivals, and the deal is expected to be finalized by September 12. The decision comes after the EU approved the deal on July 12, with Broadcom agreeing to behavioral remedies to ensure interoperability standards.

images.alt_text: The merger would unite VMware’s cloud-computing software with Broadcom’s chipmaking empire.
“While we maintain that this deal does not present any competition issues, we have made a proposal to address fully the concerns expressed by the European Commission,” says Broadcom.
Cisco is a major supplier of networking equipment including ethernet switches, which connect devices such as computers, laptops, routers, servers and printers to a local area network.

Apple will tap Broadcom for what are known as film bulk acoustic resonator (FBAR) chips, which are part of a radio-frequency system that helps iPhones and other Apple devices connected to mobile data networks.

site_title: New standards guide sustainability disclosures, but the proof will be in adoption
summary: The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) has introduced new standards for sustainability disclosures, aiming to enhance transparency and comparability of sustainability reporting worldwide. Companies in sectors with high climate-related risks may need to conduct strategic reviews and adapt their business practices. The ISSB standards, IFRS S1 and S2, require companies to disclose their approach to managing sustainability-related risks and opportunities, and the resilience of their strategy and business model to those risks. While the standards have received support from governments and central banks, regional adoption is challenging due to diverse regulatory landscapes, with only 34% of Singapore-listed companies providing detailed climate-related disclosures.

images.alt_text: Singapore-mandated issuers demonstrate strong disclosure practices under the governance pillar but lag the global average for disclosures across other pillars of the TCFD's recommendations.
The Sustainability Reporting Advisory Committee has recommended that non-listed companies with an annual revenue of at least S$1 billion make mandatory climate-related disclosures from FY2027.
FILE PHOTO: A worker adjusts an ASEAN flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng

site_title: US SEC accepts six spot bitcoin ETF proposals for review
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has accepted applications from six firms, including BlackRock, to create spot bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) for review. The firms, which also include Bitwise, VanEck, WisdomTree, Fidelity, and Invesco, have proposed similar spot bitcoin ETFs. This is the first step in the SEC's process for deciding whether to approve the proposals, which come after the agency previously rejected dozens of similar applications due to concerns over anti-fraud and investor protection standards.

site_title: ChildAid searches for child talents to star in musical whodunit
summary: ChildAid 2023, a charity fundraiser organized by BT & ST, will feature a musical dinner theatre where guests solve a whodunit while dining. The event, titled "Mesra", is set in 1930s pre-independent Singapore and will showcase young performers aged 6-19. Candidates can submit videos of themselves performing and audition in person between Sep 2-8. Rehearsals will run from Oct 30-Dec 3, and the event will be held on Dec 4, raising funds for The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

images.alt_text: ChildAid 2022 promises a show of thrills and top-flight performances, on par with its pre-pandemic 2019 stage spectacle (pictured).
Portrait of Corey Koh

site_title: Microsoft offers free security feature after alleged China cyber hack
summary: Microsoft will provide free cloud security logs to all customers in the coming months, responding to increasing nation-state cyber threats. The move comes under pressure from US cybersecurity officials, who highlighted the importance of security logs in detecting and preventing breaches. Customers will receive detailed logs of email access and 30 other types of log data previously only available to premium service users. The decision is seen as a response to evolving nation-state cyber threats, with Microsoft citing the need to enhance customer security.

site_title: Donald Trump loses bid for new trial in E Jean Carroll case
summary: US District Judge Lewis Kaplan has dismissed Donald Trump's request for a new trial in the E. Jean Carroll defamation case, upholding the $5 million damages award against the former president. The judge ruled that Trump's arguments were "almost entirely in favor of Ms. Carroll" and that the jury's verdict was not a "seriously erroneous result" or a "miscarriage of justice." Trump had appealed the decision, but the judge's 59-page ruling rejected his claims, affirming the jury's unanimous verdict that Trump was liable for sexually abusing and defaming Carroll.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump’s legal woes have so far failed to dent his efforts to win the 2024 Republican nomination.
Trump’s wealth and celebrity – from his international real estate empire to his star turn on “The Apprentice” – have raised questions about the intersection of his presidency and business interests
State attorney general Letitia James accuses Donald Trump of lying to lenders and insurers from 2011 to 2021 about asset values at the Trump Organization, as well as his own net worth.

site_title: China to increase support for private companies to bolster economy
summary: China has pledged to support its private sector with new policy measures to bolster its economy, which has been hit by Covid-19 curbs and a regulatory crackdown. The government aims to create a market-oriented business environment, protect property rights, and ensure fair competition. Measures include a "traffic light" system for private investment, support for listing and refinancing, and encouragement of innovation bonds. The goal is to revive the private sector, a key driver of China's economy, and promote high-quality development.

images.alt_text: As long as machinery gets built, bought and shipped, industrial production figures will hum along.
The world’s second-biggest economy grew at a frail pace in the second quarter as demand weakened at home and abroad.
The drop in exports was the worst since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic more than three years ago.

Local authorities are encouraged to help residents refurbish their homes, and people should get better access to credit to buy household products, according to the plan released jointly by 13 government departments.

site_title: Is CPTPP a new dawn for UK trade?
summary: The UK has formally joined the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), the first European country to do so, with Japan as its second-largest economy. While the deal offers significant opportunities for UK businesses, particularly in sectors like dairy and machinery, the government estimates that economic gains will be relatively small, around 0.08% of GDP over 10 years. Concerns remain over worker rights, environmental impacts, and the need for ratification by CPTPP members, which could take at least a year. The long-term success of the deal depends on the UK's ability to redirect trade patterns towards the Asia-Pacific and the Americas.

images.alt_text: UK Secretary of State for Business and Trade Kemi Badenoch (in blue jacket) at a meeting of trade ministers in New Zealand on Jul 16, 2023. On her right are Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong and Vietnam's Minister of Trade and Industry Nguyen Hong Dien.
Rows of houses in front of the Canary Wharf skyline in London. The UK has concluded negotiations to join the 11-member Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership.

site_title: China, Hong Kong stocks wobble; focus on stimulus
summary: China's blue-chip CSI 300 Index and Shanghai Composite Index closed flat, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 0.33%. Economic data showed a 2.7% year-on-year decline in foreign direct investment and a 13.3% growth in fiscal revenue. Investors are waiting for meaningful stimulus, with 81% of fund managers surveyed calling for monetary easing. Despite this, some analysts remain positive, citing undervalued valuations and good earnings growth prospects for 2023.

site_title: Sterling slides after cooler inflation data, yen back under pressure
summary: The pound slid 0.78% against the US dollar after British inflation fell more than expected, at 7.9% in June, its slowest in over a year. This led to a decrease in interest rates expectations, causing a decline in the pound. Meanwhile, the yen softened due to dovish comments from the Bank of Japan. The US dollar index rose 0.27% after a cooler-than-expected US inflation reading. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to deliver a 25-basis-point rate hike at its upcoming meeting.

site_title: US: Wall St rises at open as investors assess bank earnings
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 39.28 points, or 0.11%, to 34,991.21. Investors assessed Goldman Sachs' second-quarter results and strong earnings from smaller banks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 8.89 points and 44.89 points, respectively. The market reaction suggests a positive outlook for the US economy, but the article does not provide further details on the earnings reports or market analysis.

site_title: Goldman profit slides to three-year low on consumer losses
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a quarterly profit of $1.07 billion, or $3.08 per share, for the second quarter of 2023, marking its lowest profit since 2020. The bank's earnings fell 60% due to a retreat from consumer businesses and declining investment values. Goldman took writedowns of $504 million for its GreenSky business and $485 million for consolidated real estate investments. This marks a significant decline from previous quarters, with the bank's profit taking a toll from consumer losses.

images.alt_text: A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. logo hangs on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, May 19, 2010. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. racked up trading profits for itself every day last quarter. Clients who followed the firmÕs investment advice fared far worse. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg
The moves are part of a deep cost-savings drive at Goldman Sachs.
FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly//File Photo
Globally, Goldman is working on its third round of staff cuts in under a year.

site_title: Private credit’s dancing in the streets gets wilder
summary: Private credit firms, including Apollo Global Management and Blackstone, are thriving due to the US government's lenient stance on regulations. With US$1.5 trillion in private credit assets, it has surpassed high-yield corporate bonds and leveraged loans. These firms are expanding into debt financing, with Apollo acquiring $40 billion of buy-now, pay-later loan receivables from PayPal. The sector's growth is expected to continue as new regulations tighten, forcing banks to increase capital requirements, allowing non-bank lenders to expand their operations.

images.alt_text: Demand for credit is growing as Asia’s economies mature; South-east Asia alone is estimated to need at least US$2.8 trillion of infrastructure investments to ensure sustainable economic growth.

Blackstone own figures show it’s attracted 240 million euros (S$347 million) to its new private credit fund, dubbed ECRED, a fraction of the US$12 billion raised for BCRED, an equivalent US fund, at the half-year point of its fundraising about two years ago.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Former GIC investment chief Ng Kok Song has picked up papers to run for president, citing concerns about the integrity of Singapore's institutions. WP members Leon Perera and Nicole Seah have resigned from the party after an affair, with Perera stepping down as MP. The Asian Development Bank has downgraded its 2023 growth forecast for Southeast Asia to 4.6%, citing weak manufacturing demand. COE prices for small-cars decreased, while other categories held steady. GXS Bank has raised its savings account limit to S$75,000.

site_title: Omega files criminal complaint over US$3 million faked Speedmaster
summary: Omega has filed a criminal complaint with Swiss prosecutors over the sale of a faked Speedmaster watch it bought at auction for over $3 million. The watch, sold by Phillips in 2021, was allegedly created by former Omega employees who conspired with others to produce a "Frankenstein" version. The complaint comes after online blogger raised questions about the watch's authenticity last month, and a Swiss newspaper reported that the ex-Omega employees had assisted others in Switzerland in constructing the watch. The investigation is ongoing, with Phillips cooperating fully with the authorities.

images.alt_text: The Omega Speedmaster with ‘Broad Arrow’ hands from 1957 featured on the Phillips website.

site_title: Japan’s Nissan to adopt Tesla EV-charging design from 2025 in US, Canada
summary: Nissan will adopt Tesla's North American Charging Standard (NACS) port in its US and Canadian EVs starting in 2025, aiming to reach 40% of US vehicle sales as fully electric by 2030. This move follows other major automakers, including Ford and General Motors, in expanding their fast-charger networks. Nissan will provide NACS charging adaptors for its Ariya EV models, allowing them to charge on Tesla's Supercharger network, which accounts for 60% of US fast chargers. The adoption of NACS is expected to boost EV adoption and make Nissan's vehicles more compatible with Tesla's charging infrastructure.

site_title: Thai reformist Pita’s PM bid crashes on establishment opposition
summary: Thai reformist leader Pita Limjaroenrat's bid to become prime minister ended after the military and pro-royalist establishment blocked his attempt, despite his party winning the most votes in May elections. Pita's suspension from parliament was due to a case alleging he owned shares in a media company, which he inherited from his father. Lawmakers voted to refuse considering him for a second ballot, effectively ending his bid for power. Pita has vowed to step aside to allow another party to form a government, with property tycoon Srettha Thavisin seen as a potential compromise candidate.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party's leader and its prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat (centre) shake hands with Pheu Thai Party leader Cholnan Srikaew as the eight coalition parties reaffirmed its backing for Pita to become prime minister.

TOPSHOT - Move Forward Party supporters and pro-democracy activists gather to protest the day after Move Forward Party Leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat failed to secure the parliamentary vote for the premiership in Bangkok on July 14, 2023. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Pita Limjaroenrat cannot be nominated again, according to some of senators in military-appointed Senate.
In Parliament on Thursday, he defended himself again, telling lawmakers: “I am fully qualified” despite attempts to suspend him over allegations he broke campaign rules.

site_title: China e-CNY in circulation hit 16.5 billion yuan as of Jun 30 this year, central bank governor says
summary: China's digital yuan, e-CNY, reached 16.5 billion yuan in circulation as of June 30, according to central bank governor Yi Gang. The transaction volume hit 1.8 trillion yuan, with 950 million total transactions. This marks a significant milestone in China's development of its central bank digital currency (CBDC).

site_title: Auditor-General flags lapses in public agencies, including improper money management practices
summary: Singapore's Auditor-General's Office has flagged several public agencies for lapses, including improper money management practices. The People's Association was found to have improper handling of money in awarding tenders and disbursing welfare assistance schemes. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore was also criticized for disbursing an excess of $1 million in grants due to inadequate checks. The Auditor-General's report also highlighted weaknesses in procurement and contract management at multiple agencies, including the Ministry of Communications and Information, Ministry of Defence, and Singapore Food Agency.

images.alt_text: Foreign workers queueing to collect their lunch at a dormitory in 2020.
Auditor-General flags lapses in operations management, possible record irregularities

site_title: South Africa says Putin agreed not to attend Brics summit
summary: South Africa announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin will not attend the upcoming Brics summit in August due to "mutual agreement". The decision came after the International Criminal Court (ICC) issued an arrest warrant for Putin in March, accusing him of war crimes related to the deportation of Ukrainian children. Russia will be represented by Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov instead. The ICC warrant raised concerns for South Africa, which is a member of the court and theoretically required to arrest Putin if he attended the summit.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a meeting with officials dedicated to an attack on the Crimean Bridge in Moscow, Russia July 17, 2023. Sputnik/Alexander Kazakov/Kremlin via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY.

site_title: Tesla faces profit test after US$540 billion rally
summary: Tesla's second-quarter earnings may be overshadowed by CEO Elon Musk's updates on new products and AI, after the company's market value has surged $540 billion this year. Analysts expect a 20% automotive gross margin, down from 28% last year, due to price cuts driving sales. Tesla faces scrutiny over its profitability, with the stock trading at 70 times forward earnings. The company's dramatic price cuts have boosted sales but weighed on profitability, and investors will be watching for signs of how Tesla can maintain its market lead.

images.alt_text: Tesla wants to double capacity to 1 million cars per year and 100 gigawatt hours of battery production at a plant that would make even more cars than produced by Volkswagen at its Wolfsburg headquarters

site_title: Merger rules get tougher in crackdown by US antitrust enforcers
summary: The US Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission have proposed 13 new guidelines to curb the rise of companies dominating their industries through mergers and acquisitions. The guidelines, which will be open for public comment for 60 days, aim to curb corporate concentration, limit consumer choices, and contribute to higher prices. The proposed rules will examine multiple mergers, impact on workers, and market share thresholds, potentially leading to more mergers being blocked. The move is part of the Biden administration's crackdown on mergers, following several recent court defeats for antitrust enforcers.

images.alt_text: The appeals court decision removes one of the few remaining hurdles stopping Xbox maker Microsoft from expanding its gaming business by closing its deal to buy Activision.
Any outstanding regulatory hurdle makes it more likely the agreement between Microsoft and Activision will expire on Jul 18 without the deal having been completed.

“We’re grateful to the court in San Francisco for this quick and thorough decision and hope other jurisdictions will continue working towards a timely resolution,” Microsoft president Brad Smith says.

site_title: Judge questions future viability of Violet Oon Inc if it is not bought over or wound up
summary: A Singapore court questioned the viability of Violet Oon Inc, a restaurant group, if its ownership remains divided between its owner, Violet Oon, and her business partner, Manoj Murjani. Justice Philip Jeyaretnam asked how both parties can continue to work together if the company's ownership remains divided. Murjani acknowledged making derogatory comments about Oon's son but apologized and expressed willingness to work with Oon. The court will now review the case and make a decision on whether to order a buyout or wind up the company.

images.alt_text: Violet Oon Inc runs three restaurants in Singapore serving local and Peranakan-inspired cuisine.

(seated) Restaurateur Violet Oon; (standing, left to right) her son Tay Yiming, business partner Manoj Murjani and her daughter Tay Su-Lyn. Murjani took the stand during a shareholder oppression case brought by Oon and her children, who are seeking a court order to be able to purchase outstanding shares they do not already own in Violet Oon Inc, or for the company to be wound up.
Violet Oon (seated) with her son Tay Yiming (left), business partner Manoj Murjani (middle) and daughter Tay Su-Lyn.

Violet Oon (seated) and her children (from left) Tay Yiming and Tay Su-Lyn. Tay Yiming alleged that business partner Manoj Murjani had verbally agreed when signing a 2014 shareholding agreement to match the family dollar for dollar whenever Violet Oon Singapore required more money.

(From left) Tay Yiming, Tay Su-lyn, Violet Oon and Manoj Murjani. Tay Su-Lyn was the second witness in a civil case she, her mother and her brother Tay Yiming brought against Murjani, alleging oppression.
Chef Violet Oon was cross-examined by her business partner Manoj Murjani’s lawyer on Tuesday, with Justice Philip Jeyaretnam presiding over the trial.

veviolet25 - Violet Oon Singapore outlet at Jewel Changi Airport. 

Credit: Violet Oon Singapore

site_title: Sweden home starts indicator hits 9-year low after price slump
summary: Sweden's residential construction indicator has hit a 9-year low due to a slump in housing prices, higher credit costs, and raw material prices. The dwelling subcomponent of the Byggfakta indicator fell for a 22nd consecutive month, the weakest point since August 2014. Despite this, the overall construction industry saw a rise in building starts for the second month. Analysts predict an annual rate of 25,000 housing starts by autumn, with home values expected to drop by around 20% from last year's peak.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,275.24. The market saw a positive handover from overnight US stock gains, driven by better-than-expected earnings results from major US banks. UOB was the largest gainer, rising 3.4%, while DFI Retail Group was the biggest loser, falling 2.1%. Market analysts attribute the rally to the potential bottoming-out of corporate earnings, supporting a worst-is-over stance for a recovery over the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumber losers 81 to 37, or about two securities up for every one down, as 46 million securities worth S$63.5 million change hands.

site_title: UAE’s Abu Dhabi sees strong industrial sector growth amid diversification push
summary: Abu Dhabi aims to double its industrial sector's contribution to GDP to 171 billion dirhams by 2031, driven by a diversification push amid regional competition to reduce dependence on oil. The emirate's industrial sector grew 9.7% year-on-year to 90.8 billion dirhams in 2022, exceeding its target. The UAE's economy is forecast to outperform the GCC bloc with a 2.8% growth rate in 2023, driven by a strong non-oil sector.

images.alt_text: OMV plans to transform itself from one of eastern Europe’s biggest fossil-fuel companies to an integrated green enterprise built around chemicals, recycling and electric-vehicle infrastructure.

Falcon 40B is a foundational large language model (LLM) with 40 billion parameters and trained on one trillion tokens which was developed by the Technology Innovation Institute (TII), a research centre within ATRC.
Abu Dhabi’s biggest sovereign wealth fund has been pushing deeper into the US and real estate investments, tapping into opportunities brought on by the pandemic.

(FILES) A file photo taken on July 27, 2022 shows the headquarters of UAE's state oil company ADNOC in Dubai. - Gas giants British Petroleum (BP) and Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) placed a $4 billion offer to purchase half of NewMed Energy, the Israeli company said on March 27, 2023. (Photo by Giuseppe CACACE / AFP)

site_title: UK property rental prices rise at the fastest pace since 2016
summary: UK rental prices rose 5.1% in the year to June, the largest increase since 2016, with London rents jumping 5.3% and house prices increasing by 1.9% to £286,000. This follows rising interest rates and mortgage costs, forcing landlords to raise rents and deterring buyers. Despite this, house prices are still £7,000 below the 2022 peak, and annual house price inflation slowed for the seventh consecutive month.

images.alt_text: Construction starts and completions were both just over 4,000 between April and June, compared with about 3,550 and 3,090, respectively, in the previous quarter but below the three-year average.
Prices nationwide are still 0.5 per cent above where they were a year ago and have risen steadily since December.
Britain’s housing market faces pressure from softer buyer demand and falling house prices against a backdrop of surging mortgage rates and the Bank of England’s battle to tame stubborn inflation.
UK fixed mortgage deal rates have risen rapidly in recent weeks amid stickier-than-expected consumer price inflation.

site_title: Singapore prosecutors close case against OK Lim
summary: Singapore prosecutors have closed their case against OK Lim, the former head of the failed Hin Leong group, after a 14-week trial involving 17 witnesses. Lim faces cheating and forgery charges. The defense will present its case on August 2, where it will indicate whether to submit a "no case to answer". The trial began on April 11 and was led by Deputy Public Prosecutor Christopher Ong. The outcome of the trial will determine whether Lim will face prosecution for the alleged crimes.

images.alt_text: Lim Oon Kuin, better known as OK Lim, of the failed Hin Leong group faces cheating and forgery charges. The hearing continues at the State Court

site_title: Sabana Reit H1 DPU up 1.3% to S$0.0161 on ‘strong operational performance’
summary: Sabana Reit posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0161 for the first half of its fiscal year, up 1.3% from the same period last year, driven by a 23.2% increase in gross revenue to S$55.3 million. The property's portfolio occupancy reached a multi-year high of 93.9%, largely due to strong leasing momentum from third-party logistics providers. This is a positive sign for the company's operational performance.

images.alt_text: Sabana Reit's manager has said Quarz's internalisation proposal may destroy value for unitholders
DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.

site_title: Volkswagen's efforts to boost valuation stifled by lack of succession plan
summary: Volkswagen's efforts to boost its stock market value are hindered by the lack of a clear succession plan for its supervisory board, with investors warning that the company's governance issues will continue to weigh on its performance unless addressed. The Porsche-Piech family clan's aging leaders, both above 80, have no clear successors, and analysts point to weaknesses in the board's neutrality and qualifications. The company's capital market days, aimed at boosting valuation, have failed to impress investors, and experts say that a long-term transition plan for the supervisory board is urgently needed.

images.alt_text: Including all fuel types, Volkswagen sells the most passenger cars in the region.

site_title: Amid rise in global temperatures, climate crisis gains urgency
summary: A record-breaking heatwave is hitting the world, with temperatures soaring to 52°C in China, 60°C in Spain, and 40-year highs in Singapore. The World Meteorological Organization has declared El Nino, expected to bring extreme heat and break temperature records. The climate crisis is worsening, with limited water availability threatening carbon sinks and ecosystems. Despite awareness and efforts to reduce carbon emissions, the world is not moving fast enough to meet the 1.5°C limit set by the Paris Agreement, with many countries struggling with debt and debt relief.

images.alt_text: The 27-country EU has one of the most ambitious climate targets among major economies – having agreed in law to cut its net greenhouse gas emissions by 55 per cent by 2030, compared with 1990 levels.
Prolonged high temperatures in China are threatening power grids and crops and raising concerns about a repeat of last year’s drought, the most severe in 60 years.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Q2 private equity investments fall 34.5% to US$6 billion: S&P
summary: Private equity and venture capital investments in the Asia-Pacific region, excluding Japan, declined 34.5% to US$6 billion in Q2 2023, with a 23.3% drop in the number of deals to 46. The region's transaction value also fell 40.3% to US$14.4 billion, while volumes decreased to 93 transactions. Private equity deals accounted for 6% of total merger and acquisition transactions in Q2, down from 5% in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk by office towers in the Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai, China October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
The Asia-Pacific witnessed the second-highest private equity deal values in June, with 258 transactions totalling US$7.1 billion.
Stock markets have been more or less closed to initial public offers of PE companies for 18 months now, according to Dealogic data.

site_title: Small-car COEs dip, other categories hold steady
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for July's second round of bidding remained largely stable, with the only notable decrease being a 1.9% drop in Category A COE prices to S$95,202. Category B, C, and D prices held steady, while Category E prices rose 0.9% to S$121,000. The larger COE quota announced by the Land Transport Authority (LTA) last Friday is expected to reduce bidding pressure and lower prices.

images.alt_text: Iswaran will take a leave of absence until the investigations are complete.
The Category A COE-friendly 100 kW version of the BYD Atto 3 arrived in May 2023 after the car was launched with 150 kW initially.
Certificate of Entitlement prices for most categories held stable for July's second round of bidding.

site_title: Europe car sales rise 19% with growth streak nearing a full year
summary: Europe's car sales surged 19% in June, with 1.27 million new registrations, driven by growing demand for electric vehicles and improved parts supply. Battery-electric vehicle sales rose 55%, while diesel car deliveries declined 10%. Volkswagen led the region with 325,612 deliveries, followed by Stellantis, which saw a 2.5% decline. Tesla's sales doubled from last year, and the company plans to expand production capacity at its German factory. The growth streak is nearing a full year, but supply-chain concerns and potential cost-cutting by consumers remain a cloud on the outlook.

site_title: China state-backed developers Greenland, Sino-Ocean in debt payment trouble
summary: China state-backed developers Greenland Holdings and Sino-Ocean Group are facing debt payment trouble. Greenland defaulted on a $432 million bond due to a missed amortization payment, while Sino-Ocean proposed extending a $367.2 million onshore bond payment by a year. The defaults add to the debt woes plaguing the Chinese property sector, which is now a significant drag on the cooling economy. This raises concerns of more defaults among private developers in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector, which accounts for about a quarter of the economy, remains firmly in a downtrend, with property sales and investment recording double-digit falls.
The slump in the property market has weighed on China’s economic recovery, putting Beijing’s official growth target of around 5 per cent at risk.
Many of China’s property developers have been battered over the last couple of years as a share fall in apartment sales and a rash of debt defaults.
Evergrande has come to embody a broader crisis in China’s property sector, which accounts for around a quarter of the country’s gross domestic product.

wanda17 - The newly built Wanda Mall, operated by Dalian Wanda Group Co., stands near residential buildings in this aerial photograph taken in the Wuxiang New District of Nanning, Guangxi province, China, on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2019.
FILE PHOTO: A woman walks near a construction site of apartment buildings in Beijing, China, July 15, 2022. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo
With about US$300 billion of total liabilities, Evergrande’s debt problem has rippled through China’s property sector.
New construction starts measured by floor area fell 24.3 per cent year-on-year, after a 22.6 per cent drop in the first five months.
The central and local governments and regulators have announced a slew of policies over the past year to prop up the sector.

site_title: China will release cotton from state reserves from late July
summary: China plans to release cotton from state reserves in late July, marking the first announcement this year. The base price of released cotton will be determined by a 50-50 weighted average of domestic and international market prices. The move comes as scorching temperatures affect major cotton-growing areas in Xinjiang, leading China's agriculture ministry to urge growers to irrigate and fertilize more.

site_title: The return of Barbie
summary: The iconic Barbie doll is making a comeback with a new movie and accompanying marketing frenzy. The film, starring Margot Robbie, has spawned a wave of Barbie-themed products and events, with brands in Singapore selling out their Barbie product lines. The doll's evolution, which began in 2016 with more diverse body shapes and skin colors, has cemented its status as a feminist icon, inspiring self-acceptance and empowerment. The Barbie phenomenon has grown into a commercial juggernaut, with the new movie set to capitalize on its enduring popularity.

site_title:
Eased restrictions on GXS, MariBank
indicate maturing digibank sector: observers
summary: GXS Bank and MariBank have eased restrictions on their services, allowing deposits of up to S$75,000 per account. This move indicates the Monetary Authority of Singapore's easing of the S$50 million deposit cap, suggesting a maturing digital banking sector. The changes reflect greater trust from the regulator and signal the growth of these upstart banks.

images.alt_text: Grab’s digital bank, that’s also backed by Singapore Telecommunications, was set up just under a year ago.
Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO of Trust says that the bank is not targeting high net-worth individuals.

site_title: Temasek seeks partnerships to deploy US$5 billion a year in India
summary: Temasek Holdings is seeking partnerships to deploy between $3 billion to $5 billion annually in India, aiming to become a top driver for growth. The state investor plans to hire more professionals and commit up to $10 billion to the country over three years, targeting sectors like finance, technology, and healthcare. Temasek has been ramping up investments in India over the past five years, attracted by the country's demographics, capital markets, and opportunities in decarbonisation and energy transition.

images.alt_text: Temasek's FY2023 performance was supported by Singapore companies like Keppel, Sembcorp and Seatrium
Some of the largest contributors to Temasek’s portfolio emissions are also companies that the Singapore state-owned investment firm cannot dispose of.

Unlike other carbon-intensive sectors, which may have various avenues to decarbonise, the only way SIA is able to reduce its carbon emissions is by switching its fuel, which are currently fossil fuel-based, to sustainable aviation fuel, said Dilhan Pillay, chief executive officer of Temasek.
Temasek Holdings said that persistent inflatoin, geopolitical tensions and rising nationalism and protectionism led to an increase in the firm's cost of capital.
Temasek developed its T2030 strategy in 2019 as its 10-year roadmap to guide strategic planning and capability building for the organisation.

Attendees at the Ant Group booth at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, July 6, 2023. The conference runs through July 8. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

Tata Group has started discussions with Temasek around a deal that would give the Singapore state investor an opportunity for a long-awaited exit from its investment in the platform, formerly known as Tata Sky.

site_title: Truck maker Volvo raises market outlook after Q2 profit jump
summary: Volvo, a Swedish truck maker, reported a higher-than-expected jump in second-quarter adjusted operating profit, reaching 21.7 billion krona. The company raised its market outlook for Europe and North America, expecting sales of 330,000 heavy trucks in each market this year. This represents a 10% increase in order intake for the quarter. Volvo attributed the success to improving margins and cost management despite supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Keppel and consortium break ground for Singapore’s first hydrogen-ready co-generation plant
summary: Keppel and a consortium of Mitsubishi Power Asia-Pacific and Jurong Engineering broke ground on Singapore's first hydrogen-ready co-generation plant. The project, valued at an undisclosed amount, aims to save up to 220,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per year. This marks the first power plant to be announced in Singapore in seven years, following the 2016 commissioning of the Tuaspring power station.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Retail podium at 183 Longhaus up for sale with S$35 million guide price
summary: The retail podium at 183 Longhaus in Singapore is on sale with a guide price of S$35.1 million, a decrease of S$3 million from its previous price tag. The freehold property, which spans 11,291 sq ft, features 10 shops and food-and-beverage units. Knight Frank notes a healthy demand for strata retail units, despite fewer transactions in the first half of 2023, and predicts long-term capital appreciation and rental upside. The purchaser will have majority veto rights to en bloc with 27.9% share value.

images.alt_text: The Reit’s aggregate leverage rises to 57 per cent.
Orchard’s prime retail rents have increased 5.9 per cent on the year, greater than the 5.4 per cent increase of the islandwide average.

Tenant group Singapore Tenants United for Fairness (SGTuff) has proposed that landlords should have to provide tenants with data on the footfall and average rental per square foot (psf) in their retail premises.
The facade of four shophouses (2 to 5 Circular Road) that were among properties bought by a China buyer recently.

site_title: The great ESG language divide
summary: The article highlights the disconnect between companies' sustainability reports and investors' ability to understand them. The 20 largest primary-listed companies on the Singapore Exchange average 45,939 words in their sustainability reports, three times the word count of their financial statements. This disconnect is due to companies' self-serving language and investors' lack of understanding of technical terms such as "materiality" and "Scope 3." The International Sustainability Standards Board's (ISSB) recently published sustainability disclosure standards aim to address this issue, but investors must still learn and understand these terms to hold companies accountable for their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) focuses.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said financial supervision is required if carbon taxes – the “most logical and rational” option – don’t rise to adequate levels globally without lots of free riders.
South-east Asian governments must help their small and medium-sized enterprises to meet the accounting profession's new sustainability reporting standards.
The Sustainability Reporting Advisory Committee has recommended that non-listed companies with an annual revenue of at least S$1 billion make mandatory climate-related disclosures from FY2027.
Singapore-mandated issuers demonstrate strong disclosure practices under the governance pillar but lag the global average for disclosures across other pillars of the TCFD's recommendations.

The new sustainability standards provide a structured framework for companies to assess and disclose their resilience to sustainability-related risks, allowing investors to understand the company’s long-term prospects better.

site_title: Philippines rejects private sector’s 267 billion pesos offer to upgrade ageing airport
summary: The Philippine government rejected a 267 billion pesos (S$6.5 billion) offer from a local consortium to upgrade the country's ageing main international airport, citing a preference to invite bids for the project. The airport, ranked among the world's worst, badly needs an upgrade to address congestion and improve facilities. The government-approved project aims to boost annual airport capacity to 62 million passengers and increase air traffic movement to 48 aircraft per hour. The consortium, comprising six of the Philippines' largest conglomerates, was welcome to join the bidding process.

site_title: Visitors to Japan top two million in June for the first time since Covid
summary: Japan's inbound visitors reached 2.07 million in June, the first time since February 2020, surpassing the 2 million mark. The surge is attributed to the weak yen, which has made holidays the cheapest in decades, and is fueling a tourism boom. Retail businesses, such as Tokyo's Kyubey sushi restaurant, are benefiting from the increase in consumer prices and hopes for a broader economic boost. The number of visitors is up from 1.9 million in May and 28% higher than in June 2019, with many tourists coming from the US, Europe, Australia, and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: The rise, which followed a 5.2 per cent gain in May, was the slowest annual pace since April 2021, data by the BOJ showed.
Wage growth is one of the key trends the Bank of Japan is closely watching as it considers if and when it should unwind its ultra-loose monetary stimulus.
The government has scrapped strict pandemic-related border controls and reclassified Covid-19 as the same level as the seasonal flu.
Manufacturing output and new orders contracted for a ninth consecutive month as customer and market demand remained weak.

Private consumption, which makes up more than half Japan's economy, grew 0.6 per cent in January-March from the previous quarter, as the country’s re-opening from the pandemic boosted service spending.

site_title: Tesla lays out steps to building Europe's biggest car plant
summary: Tesla has submitted plans to expand its factory in Germany, aiming to double production to 1 million cars per year and 100 gigawatt hours of battery production. The plant, which would surpass Volkswagen's Wolfsburg headquarters, will undergo modifications, including a battery cell testing lab and water recycling, with the goal of becoming Europe's largest car plant. Local citizens have until mid-September to file objections, following a series of changes that are expected to become operational in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: The attendees’ main concern at Tuesday’s event is how Tesla will manage to expand the plant without using additional water.
Tesla says the legal action comes in response to a lawsuit that Cap-XX originally filed against Tesla subsidiary Maxwell Technologies in 2019 for patent infringement.
Plans for the vehicle, with its silvery, tortoise-like shape and unusual angles, were first announced in November 2019.
The workers say they welcome the award after Tesla has cut bonuses for many staff in the previous quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong talent war means new bank hires get 30% jump in pay
summary: Hong Kong's financial industry is experiencing a talent war, driven by a surge in business from China and a shortage of workers. The border reopening has boosted the sector, with mainland customers flocking to open bank accounts and invest money. As a result, new hires are seeing a 30% jump in pay, with some positions commanding a 20-30% raise. The industry faces shortages in areas such as actuaries, finance, and IT staff, with over 4,000 unfilled jobs estimated. This has pushed salaries higher for finance and technology professionals in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Citic and its Chinese and global peers have also faced a challenging market environment that has weighed on dealmaking and trading revenues.

site_title: UK inflation slows sharply, offering some relief to Bank of England
summary: The UK's inflation rate slowed sharply to 7.9% in June, its lowest level since March 2022, offering some relief to the Bank of England. Despite staying above other major economies, the data eased pressure on the BOE to keep raising interest rates sharply. Sterling weakened against the US dollar and euro, and investors reduced bets on future rate hikes. Core inflation, excluding food and energy prices, also dropped by more than expected, coming in at 6.9%. The BOE is expected to raise interest rates for a 14th time on August 3.

images.alt_text: In the last year, around 18 per cent of UK-listed companies have issued a profit warning, the highest level since 2008,.
Recent jobs data provide some evidence that the labour market is easing, with job vacancies dropping and unemployment rising, but wages remain high.

The reduction will come as a relief for households struggling with their budgets, as rising interest rates bump up mortgage costs and inflation remains more than four times its target at 8.7 per cent.
Food prices have been driven up by increased costs for animal feed, fertiliser and fuel as well as energy and labour.

site_title: WP’s Leon Perera and Nicole Seah resign from party after affair; Perera steps down as MP
summary: Workers' Party members Leon Perera and Nicole Seah have resigned from the party after an affair was made public. Perera, a Member of Parliament, also stepped down as MP. The resignations follow a 15-second video clip of the pair being shared on social media, which initially denied their relationship but later confirmed by party leaders. WP chairman Pritam Singh stated that Perera's refusal to be honest about the affair led to his expulsion, citing the party's constitution requiring "frank and honest dealings."

images.alt_text: Allegations of an affair between Leon Perera and Nicole Seah had made their rounds amongst WP members.
In a statement, the WP said it is aware of a video clip circulating online today that suggests an inappropriate exchange between two senior Party members.

site_title: Asia: Most markets track Wall St rally but China weighs on optimism
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday following a Wall Street rally, driven by optimism over the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike end and a slowing US economy. However, China's growth outlook cast a shadow, with Hong Kong's tech sector experiencing a sharp drop. Data showing falling US inflation reinforced the positive sentiment. Despite this, concerns about China's economy persist, tempering investor optimism.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led losses in early trade Tuesday, shedding more than one per cent as it reopened a day after being shut because of a severe storm.

site_title: Russia readies pilot of digital rouble as war squeezes economy
summary: Russia is moving forward with plans to introduce a digital rouble, a digital currency that could ease cross-border payments and provide banking services to underserved groups. Legislation is set to be approved by the Federation Council, and tests may begin as early as next month. The digital rouble will be issued and regulated by the Bank of Russia, with individuals and companies able to open digital wallets and make transactions. However, international transactions will not be possible until the digital rouble is linked to other countries' currency platforms, a step that has not yet been taken.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman holds Russian Roubles in front of U.S. Dollar banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Australian office landlords face price reckoning amid buyer impasse
summary: Australian office landlords are facing a "price reckoning" amid a buyer impasse, with major Reits marking down office portfolios by roughly 10% or less over the past year. Despite a decline in public markets, valuations remain unchanged, creating a stalemate between landlords and buyers waiting for deeper discounts. The delay is partly due to workers' slow return to offices and higher rates hitting property values, making it harder for landlords to service debt. Investors expect a 20-30% discount in unlisted valuations, but owners are hesitant to sell, potentially breaking the deadlock.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sydney office buildings and commercial real estate appear behind Sydney waterfront properties in the suburb of Birchgrove, Australia, November 3, 2016. Picture taken November 3, 2016.  REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo
The RBA this month left interest rates unchanged at 4.1 per cent.
Lendlease has roughly 7,800 employees across Australia, Europe, the US and Asia.

site_title: Regulator cancels licence of FTX’s Australian business
summary: The Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) has cancelled the licence of FTX's Australian business, effective July 14. The licence was initially suspended in November until May, following FTX's US bankruptcy filing in November. FTX Australia can provide limited financial services until July 12, 2024, to terminate existing derivatives with clients. The cancellation comes after FTX's US$32 billion valuation in January 2023 and its inability to repay customers who deposited funds on its exchange.

site_title: Vietnam approves  750 trillion dong plan to expand fuel storage capacity by 2030
summary: Vietnam has approved a plan to expand its fuel storage capacity by 2030, with an estimated investment of up to 750 trillion dong (S$40 billion). The plan aims to raise the country's crude oil and refined fuel storage capacity to 75-80 days of net imports, addressing fuel supply crunches caused by tight global supplies or local oil refinery malfunctions. The majority of funds will be raised from businesses and the state budget, according to the plan signed by Deputy Prime Minister Tran Hong Ha.

site_title: Hot stock: Sakae Holdings hits five-year high following news of Douglas Foo’s proposed share sale
summary: Sakae Holdings' shares jumped 157.6% to a five-year high after executive chairman Douglas Foo agreed to sell 20% of the company to fund manager Makara Capital for S$26.5 million. The sale is nearly double the company's market capitalisation. Foo will retain a 46.2% stake. The company has struggled in recent years, reporting net losses in 2019 and 2020.

images.alt_text: If the proposed sale is completed, Foo will remain as executive chairman and controlling shareholder with about 46.15 per cent of the company’s total number of issued shares.
The transport operator's subsidiary has clinched a six-year contract to operate rail services in Paris, France.

site_title: Global power demand growth to rebound in 2024 after slowdown: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts global power demand growth will slow to slightly less than 2% in 2023 due to an ongoing energy crisis and economic downturn, but rebound to 3.3% in 2024. Renewable energy is expected to cover the growth and exceed one-third of the global power supply for the first time next year. The decline in hydropower is attributed to climate change, and the renewable growth is expected to cut global emissions, particularly in the European Union where emissions from power generation declined by 40% in the first half of 2023.

images.alt_text: China had a record number of days when the average temperature was 35C or above in the first half, highlighting the increasing pressure that global warming is putting on the grid.
EMA is looking for proposals that develop more land-efficient, cost-effective and safer ESS solutions suited for the Republic’s tropical and urbanised climate.

site_title: Thai recovery intact, interest rates to normalise gradually: central bank chief
summary: Thailand's central bank chief says the country's economic recovery is intact, with growth expected to reach 2.9% in the first half and 4.2% in the second half. The Bank of Thailand has raised interest rates by 150 basis points since August to curb inflation, which has dropped to 0.23% in June, the slowest pace in 22 months. The central bank plans to gradually normalise interest rates to support growth and keep inflation in check, despite expecting exports to remain flat for the year.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party's leader and its prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat (centre) shake hands with Pheu Thai Party leader Cholnan Srikaew as the eight coalition parties reaffirmed its backing for Pita to become prime minister.
Pita Limjaroenrat cannot be nominated again, according to some of senators in military-appointed Senate.

Tourists and locals browse goods and food at a walking street market in Phuket, Thailand, on Sunday, Oct. 2, 2022. Thailand will end a nationwide state of emergency declared in the wake of Covid outbreak after the Southeast Asian nation downgraded the virus from a “dangerous” communicable disease to one that only requires surveillance. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: Hot stock: Manulife US Reit falls as much as 33.7% following decline in portfolio valuations
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (Manulife US Reit) plummeted 33.7% as its units fell to a record low after a surprise decline in portfolio valuations. The Reit's manager expects a loss in the first half of 2023 due to a breach of loan covenants. The aggregate leverage has risen to 57%, exceeding the 50% limit set by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Research teams have downgraded the counter, citing near-term challenges and potential temporary halt in distributions, leading to a significant decline in the unit price.

images.alt_text: The Reit’s aggregate leverage rises to 57 per cent.
The divestment of Manulife US Reit's properties could allow gearing to fall to 45.2 per cent.
The Children's Place will vacate its 197,949 square feet of space on May 31, 2024.
The Reit’s manager says it aims to enter into a definitive agreement for Phipps Tower’s disposal by Jun 30, 2023. It will also waive the disposal fee.
Manulife US Reit's office properties have declined in value, and its gearing is bumping up against the statutory ceiling of 50 per cent
With the Reit’s portfolio having a weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of five years, its manager expects positive rental reversion for 2023.

site_title: China fast-fashion retailer Temu blasts rival Shein over ‘exclusionary tactics’
summary: Temu, a Chinese fast-fashion retailer, accused rival Shein of using "unlawful exclusionary tactics" after Shein filed a lawsuit against Temu in the US. Temu filed a counter-lawsuit, alleging Shein's actions violate US antitrust laws. This comes as the companies compete in the global fast-fashion market, with Temu launching in the US in 2022. The feud escalates tensions between the two Chinese companies vying for dominance in the market.

site_title: China’s fiscal revenue growth slows, signals broadening economic pressure
summary: China's fiscal revenue growth slowed to 13.3% in the first six months of 2023, down from 14.9% in the first five months, indicating broadening economic pressure. The country's GDP growth in the second quarter expanded 6.3%, below the forecast 7.3% growth, and demand weakened at home and abroad. Local governments' land sales revenue declined 24.26% year-on-year in June, highlighting strains in the property sector. Authorities are expected to roll out more stimulus steps, including fiscal spending and infrastructure projects, to shore up growth.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector, which accounts for about a quarter of the economy, remains firmly in a downtrend, with property sales and investment recording double-digit falls.

site_title: ‘Concerns about integrity’ prompt former GIC investment chief Ng Kok Song to seek presidential candidacy
summary: Former GIC investment chief Ng Kok Song has announced his candidacy for the Singapore presidency, citing concerns about the country's institutions and a desire to exercise Singaporeans' right to choose their president. Ng, 75, has 45 years of experience in building up Singapore's reserves and has never been affiliated with a political party. He faces competition from other candidates, including former senior minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and serial entrepreneur George Goh, who also announced their interest in the presidency. Ng's candidacy aims to set an example for younger Singaporeans and serve the country despite potential sacrifices.

images.alt_text: Ex-GIC CIO's low-key Singapore fund amasses US$10b for global foray
Ng Kok Song retired from GIC in 2013 after 27 years with the sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Putin could soon find himself with more friends in Europe
summary: A global upheaval is looming as far-right demagogues gain strength in Europe. In Spain, the far-right party Vox could gain power in a coalition government despite its election manifesto that calls for the repeal of laws on violence against women and denial of climate change. Similar trends are seen in other European countries, including Germany, Austria, Hungary, Poland, Greece, and Slovakia, where pro-Russian and anti-Semitic sentiments are on the rise. The normalization of prejudice is the most immediate consequence, and the health of democracy is threatened.

images.alt_text: Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez gestures as he speaks during a joint press conference with his Swedish counterpart at La Moncloa palace in Madrid on June 5, 2023. (Photo by PIERRE-PHILIPPE MARCOU / AFP)
Face of populism in Europe : 2022 saw the rise of Giorgia Meloni, a right-wing nationalist, as Italy's prime minister.

site_title: Vietnam EV maker VinFast to start construction of US factory next week
summary: Vietnam's automaker VinFast will start construction of its US electric vehicle factory in North Carolina next week, aiming to produce 150,000 units per year in the first phase. The US$4 billion factory, initially targeted for 2024, will be built on 1,800 acres of land and consists of two main areas for electric vehicle production and assembly. VinFast received environmental permits in February, and the project was delayed by a year. The factory is part of VinFast's plans to expand its global presence and meet growing demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Morgan Stanley moves 200 tech developers out of China on data law
summary: Morgan Stanley has relocated over 200 technology developers out of mainland China due to the country's tightened data law, which restricts the transmission of sensitive information. The employees are primarily moving to Hong Kong and Singapore, while Morgan Stanley's remaining staff on the mainland are building a standalone China system to comply with local regulations. This move is among the most significant by a Wall Street bank in response to the new law, which is forcing multinational companies to reassess their operations in China.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley has reported 82,006 employees at the end of June, down from 82,266 at March’s end.

site_title: Bitcoin ETF hype threatens another sell-the-news fizzle
summary: A US spot Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) approval is expected to bring significant investment, potentially worth over $50 billion, but its impact remains uncertain. Despite previous futures-based ETFs experiencing high turnover and a brief price surge, early momentum has been fleeting. Critics argue that the market has already seen the benefits of similar products in Canada and Europe, with little investor interest. Supporters believe that a US spot fund will attract more attention, offering easier access and potentially lower costs, but the blowback from the 2022 crypto market crash has cooled investor interest.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin’s price has leapt 80 per cent since the start of the year but its current level of just over US$30,200 is still less than half the US$69,000 peak back in November 2021.

site_title: Martial arts superstar Bruce Lee’s legacy endures 50 years on
summary: Bruce Lee, a renowned martial artist and actor, was born in San Francisco in 1940 and raised in Hong Kong. He achieved Hollywood superstardom at 32 before his death in 1973. Lee's films sparked a kung fu craze worldwide, making him a trailblazer for Asian men in Hollywood. 50 years after his death, fans in Hong Kong are celebrating his legacy with exhibitions and martial arts workshops, showcasing his enduring influence on the city and martial arts community.

images.alt_text: Coco Lee was born in Hong Kong in 1975 and was the youngest of three children of a Hong Kong Cantonese mother and Malaysian father.

site_title: Sakae chairman to sell 20% stake in company for S$26.5 million
summary: Sakae Holdings chairman Douglas Foo plans to sell a 20% stake in the restaurant operator for S$26.5 million. The sale, subject to conditions, will leave Foo as executive chairman and controlling shareholder with about 46.15% of the company's issued shares. The deal was facilitated by private equity firm Makara Capital. Following the sale, Sakae's counter jumped 90.9% to S$0.189.

site_title: New Zealand Q2 CPI rises 1.1%, slightly faster than expected
summary: New Zealand's consumer inflation rose 6.0% year-on-year in Q2, slightly above expectations, and 1.1% quarter-on-quarter. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) has responded by raising interest rates to 5.5%, aiming to dampen inflation. The RBNZ expects rates to remain "restrictive" despite the data suggesting the rate increases are having the desired impact. Non-tradeable inflation slowed to 6.6% on year, with food and housing prices driving the annual inflation.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ says it now expects inflation to decline from its peak.

site_title: Nissan, Renault ready to announce new alliance deal in days: sources
summary: Nissan and Renault are set to announce a restructured alliance deal in the coming days, finalizing a framework agreement reached in February. The deal involves Nissan taking a strategic investment in Renault's electric vehicle unit, Ampere, potentially below the 15% target. Nissan's stake in Ampere is expected to be less than 10%, while Renault will reduce its 43% stake in Nissan. The announcement comes after 10 months of negotiations and follows the departure of Nissan's former COO, Ashwani Gupta.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logos of car manufacturers Nissan and Renault are seen in front of dealerships of the companies in Saint-Nazaire, France, Feb. 6, 2023. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: China government land sales revenue downturn deepens in June
summary: China's government land sales revenue plummeted 24.26% year-on-year in June, exceeding the 13% drop in the previous month, as developers remain cautious about buying land amid economic stress. The downturn in the property sector, accounting for a quarter of China's economy, has seen double-digit falls in property sales and investment. The decline in land sales revenue for January to June fell 20.9% from the previous year, highlighting multiple economic challenges, including weak demand and high youth unemployment. A potential Politburo meeting later this month may bring policy support to shore up the stuttering economy.

site_title: Only 1% of US homes have changed hands so far this year: Redfin
summary: The US home turnover rate has fallen to its lowest in at least a decade, with 14 out of every 1,000 homes changing hands in the first half of 2023. High mortgage rates have led to a decrease in sales, with California experiencing the least housing availability, particularly in the San Francisco Bay Area. The highest turnover rate was in Newark, New Jersey, with 24 out of every 1,000 homes changing hands. This decline is attributed to the impact of high mortgage rates on homebuyers, making it difficult for them to afford homes.

site_title: Why China could become the luxury industry’s next sore spot
summary: China's luxury market is showing signs of slowing growth, with a disappointing sales update from Cartier owner Richemont and a faltering economy that prompted banks to trim their growth forecasts. Despite this, analysts predict a "multi-year consumption catch-up" in China, with the country's younger consumers driving demand for luxury goods. However, rising unemployment among the younger generation and over-reliance on the Chinese market by luxury companies pose concerns for the industry's future growth.

images.alt_text: Local authorities are encouraged to help residents refurbish their homes, and people should get better access to credit to buy household products, according to the plan released jointly by 13 government departments.
The drop in exports was the worst since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic more than three years ago.

site_title: UK profit warnings rise for seventh quarter as high rates bite
summary: The UK has seen a seventh consecutive quarter of rising profit warnings, with 66 issued in the April-June period, as companies struggle with "slow-rolling economic uncertainty" and high interest rates. This marks the longest streak since the 2008 global financial crisis. The warnings cited factors such as falling sales, contractual issues, and changing credit conditions, with industrials and construction and materials being the industries most affected. Around 18% of UK-listed companies have issued a profit warning in the past year, the highest level since 2008, raising concerns about Britain's economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Recent jobs data provide some evidence that the labour market is easing, with job vacancies dropping and unemployment rising, but wages remain high.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open after global markets rally; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, led by a global market rally, with the Straits Times Index (STI) adding 20.22 points to 3,274.48. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 81 to 37, with banking stocks rising and Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust falling 27.2% after breaching loan covenants. The rally follows strong banking results in the US, which boosted the market for the seventh day in a row.

images.alt_text: The transport operator's subsidiary has clinched a six-year contract to operate rail services in Paris, France.
The benchmark Straits Times Index ended the trading day with a paltry gain of just 0.17 point to close at 3,254.26.

site_title: Sabana Reit’s manager should state if it will work with the trustee on internalisation plan
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) manager Hock Lock Siew is under pressure to state its position on Quarz's internalisation proposal, which could potentially destroy unitholder value. The trustee of Sabana Reit has indicated that the current manager may serve as interim manager in the event unitholders vote for the plan, aiming to maintain stability. However, SREIM, the current manager, has warned that the proposal may trigger a mandatory prepayment of loans and destroy value for unitholders. A court hearing on the validity of Quarz's EGM requisition is set for July 19.

images.alt_text: Sabana' Reit's upcoming extraordinary general meeting involves two resolutions - one for the removal of its Reit manager and second on the internalisation of the Reit management function.
Investors could benefit from stricter rules around the formats of meetings. This is particularly true for EGMs that are convened to vote on contentious corporate issues.
At an upcoming extraordinary general meeting, unitholders will vote on whether to remove Sabana Reit’s current manager and replace it with an internal one.
The trustee of Sabana Reit, HSBC Trustee, is urging unitholders to carefully consider the resolutions and note the uncertainty and risks associated before voting at an upcoming EGM.

site_title: Tata to choose UK for new EV battery plant: source
summary: Tata, an Indian conglomerate, is expected to announce that it will build an electric vehicle battery plant in Britain, a move seen as a major win for the country's automotive industry. The plant, which will supply batteries for Jaguar and Land Rover vehicles, was chosen between sites in Somerset, England, and Spain.
