The decision is a boost for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's government, which has pledged to grow the economy and reduce carbon emissions. The UK government will provide subsidies worth hundreds of millions of pounds to Tata.

images.alt_text: A takeover of the Wistron factory in southern Karnataka state, potentially valued at more than US$600 million, would cap about a year of negotiations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ComfortDelGro, Manulife US Reit, Sakae
summary: ComfortDelGro's subsidiary clinched a six-year contract to operate rail services in Paris, marking the group's first foray into France's rail operations market. Manulife US Reit's manager announced a trading halt due to a sharp decline in portfolio valuations, potentially affecting distributions. Sakae's executive chairman entered into a sale and purchase agreement to sell a 20% stake for S$26.5 million. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust also called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: TikTok to perform ‘stress test’ ahead of EU Digital Services Act
summary: TikTok has agreed to undergo a "stress test" ahead of the EU's Digital Services Act (DSA), which requires companies to manage risk, conduct external auditing, and share data with authorities. The DSA, set to take effect in August, aims to control illegal content on large online platforms, with companies facing hefty fines for non-compliance. This move follows concerns about the impact of TikTok on democracies, as stated by EU industry chief Thierry Breton, who also met with TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew to discuss compliance.

site_title: US industrial output falls in June for second straight month
summary: US industrial output declined for the second consecutive month in June, reversing earlier positive figures, as the Federal Reserve prepares to consider another interest rate hike. The 0.5% drop was driven by a 2.7% contraction in consumer durables, including appliances and carpeting. This decline provides further evidence of slowing production, underscoring the Fed's decision to weigh another interest rate hike next week.

images.alt_text: A worker fits wheel hub badges on the Ford Focus automobile assembly line inside the Ford Motor Co. factory in Saarlouis, Germany, on Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2019. Ford recently announced it expects 'electrified' vehicles – which include mild hybrids, traditional hybrids, plug-in electric hybrids (PHEVs) and battery electric vehicles (BEVs) – to make up over 50% of its passenger vehicle sales by year-end 2022. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: US builder confidence hits highest level in over a year
summary: US home builder sentiment reached a 13-month high in July, driven by limited housing stock and resilient demand for new homes. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market index increased by one point to 56, the seventh consecutive monthly rise. Prospective buyer traffic reached its highest level since June 2022 at 40, despite high mortgage rates. However, builders remain cautiously optimistic, citing concerns over construction financing. Only 22% of builders reported cutting prices in July, down from 36% in November.

site_title: Kering shakes up underperforming Gucci
summary: Kering announced the departure of Gucci's long-time CEO, Marco Bizzarri, who will step down in September. Deputy CEO Jean-Francois Palus will take over temporarily to strengthen Gucci's teams and operations. The move comes after Kering saw sales rise nine percent last year, with Gucci's sales only edging up one percent. Kering's CEO Francois-Henri Pinault will oversee the changes, aiming to build a more robust organization to capture the growth of the global luxury market. Palus will resign from the Kering board and relocate to Milan to lead Gucci.

images.alt_text: CAA represents thousands of actors, directors and music artists.

site_title: Japan companies less confident about business conditions: survey
summary: Japan's large manufacturers saw their confidence decline in July for the first time in six months, with the service sector experiencing a second consecutive month of decline. The manufacturers' index fell to +3, down from +8 in the previous month, citing concerns over weakening overseas demand, US-China trade tensions, and elevated raw material costs. However, retailers and real estate firms reported increased confidence, while information and communications companies saw a slight drop in sentiment.

images.alt_text: The BOJ is scheduled to have a two-day policy meeting starting Jul 27.

site_title: Canada sees path forward on global digital services tax deal
summary: Canada has found a path forward in reaching an international consensus on a global digital services tax deal, with Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland stating the country supports international efforts and is implementing pillar two of the two-pillar deal. Canada initially opposed extending the global tax deal, citing a national interest, but has since had good conversations with other countries to find a path forward. The decision allows Canada to collect revenue from digital services taxes without delaying implementation.

images.alt_text: Canada's grocery prices rise 9.1 per cent year over year in June, a tick higher than the increase recorded in May.

site_title: Canada’s inflation rate drops to 27-month low; food prices still elevated
summary: Canada's inflation rate dropped to a 27-month low of 2.8% in June, beating expectations, according to Statistics Canada. Food prices remained elevated, rising 9.1% year-over-year, while petrol prices fell 21.6% compared to June 2022. The Bank of Canada's inflation rate is now within its 1-3% control range for the first time since March 2021, with the central bank expecting inflation to remain around 3% before dropping to 2% by mid-2025.

images.alt_text: People walk as some 90 wildfires are active in Alberta, with 23 out of control, according to the provincial government, in Calgary, Alberta, Canada May 16, 2023.  REUTERS/Leah Hennel
Home prices have also been pushed up by a population boom and a materials shortage that caused a gauge of residential construction prices to rise 51 per cent since the first quarter of 2020.

The preliminary growth estimate for May, which can change when final data is released next month, was led by increases in the manufacturing and wholesale trade sectors, as well as by offices of real estate agents and brokers, Statscan says.
The increase in building costs comes as Canada grapples with high home prices and rents, an immigration-driven population boom, and shortages of workers and raw materials.

site_title: IMF urges Pakistan to continue monetary policy tightening cycle
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Pakistan to continue its monetary policy tightening cycle to reduce inflation and facilitate external rebalancing. The country's central bank has raised its key policy rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022. The IMF recommends that the forward-looking real policy rate should return to positive territory to re-anchor expectations and achieve the central bank's inflation objective. Pakistan's government has forecast inflation at 21% for fiscal 2024, and the next monetary policy meeting is scheduled for July 31.

images.alt_text: Improving finances will ease Pakistan into elections later this year.

site_title: Microsoft’s new corporate AI products will come with a hefty price tag
summary: Microsoft's new corporate AI tool, Microsoft 365 Copilot, will cost US$30 per user per month, adding to existing subscription plans ranging from US$12.50 to US$57. The tool, based on OpenAI technology, has been tested with 600 customers, including General Motors and Goodyear, and is expected to become a US$10 billion business for Microsoft. The pricing reflects strong demand for corporate AI products, which require expensive computer chips and cloud-computing power. The tool will be offered for existing subscription plans, but a release date has not been announced.

site_title: US: Dow rises for seventh straight day after solid bank earnings
summary: US stocks rose for the seventh consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 1.1% to 34,951.93. Solid banking earnings, including Morgan Stanley and Bank of America, contributed to the rally. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with Morgan Stanley shares surging 6.5% and Bank of America climbing 4.4%. Despite weaker-than-expected US retail sales, the market remained in "a full-fledged rally mode", according to analyst Steve Sosnick.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 11.73 points, or 0.03 per cent, at the open to 34,597.08.

site_title: Trump says he is a target in US 2020 election probe
summary: Former US President Donald Trump stated he is a target in a grand jury investigation into efforts to overturn his 2020 presidential election defeat. The investigation, led by special counsel Jack Smith, is reportedly examining Trump's actions following his loss to Joe Biden. Trump's legal woes have not hindered his efforts to win the 2024 Republican nomination, with officials testifying about his pressure to dispute voter fraud claims and his supporters' attack on the US Capitol on January 6, 2021.

images.alt_text: Trump’s wealth and celebrity – from his international real estate empire to his star turn on “The Apprentice” – have raised questions about the intersection of his presidency and business interests

site_title: Gold retreats from 1½-month high even as traders bet on US Fed rate pause
summary: US gold prices retreated from a 1½-month high on Wednesday, falling 0.1% to $1,978.09 per ounce, despite investors betting on a pause in the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes due to recent economic readings. Gold futures remained flat at $1,981.60. The decline came after gold reached its highest since May 24 on Tuesday at $1,984.19.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates decrease the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit wins six-year contract to operate rail services in Paris
summary: ComfortDelGro has secured a six-year contract to operate rail services in Paris, France, through its subsidiary ORA. The contract covers the South sector of Line 15, a new automated line under the Grand Paris Express greenfield metro programme, serving 16 stations across 22 cities. This marks ComfortDelGro's first foray into France's rail operations market and its second overseas rail-operations contract, following a similar deal in Auckland, New Zealand.

images.alt_text: CDG and FairPrice will focus on loyalty benefits, with plans to jointly offer door-to-door experiences related to transport and daily essentials in the future.
The KYC Star V7 electric van will be available in both cargo carrying and passenger vehicle forms.

site_title: Banks’ new world: Depositors get a bigger share of rate rises
summary: US banks are passing on a larger share of interest rate hikes to depositors, with deposit beta increasing to over 70% in the current cycle. This trend is driven by sophisticated institutional clients seeking alternative investments, forcing banks to pay higher interest rates on deposits. As rates rise, banks are sharing more of the increase with customers, a shift from the previous cycle where banks retained most of the benefit. This trend is expected to continue, with experts warning that deposit beta will rise further, affecting banks' net interest income.

images.alt_text: Thin net interest margins are a key driver of lower profits, which in turn make banks less attractive to investors.
The fresh look at balance sheets shows it’s not just small- and medium-sized lenders that are having to compete harder to prevent depositors from pursuing higher returns elsewhere.

site_title: ASML to hire 100 researchers leaving Philips
summary: ASML, Europe's largest technology company, plans to hire 100 researchers leaving Philips, a former industrial conglomerate. The employees, from Philips' Engineering Solutions division, will join ASML's workforce, which is expected to slow its hiring pace this year. The move is part of ASML's expansion, following its net hiring of 7,000 employees in 2022. The company is set to report second-quarter earnings on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Dongfang, currently valued at about 8 billion yuan, is in the early stages of preparing for a potential listing.

site_title: Europe: Shares boosted by Novartis, telecom stocks slide
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Tuesday, driven by a forecast upgrade by Novartis and a 4.6% climb in the Swiss Market index. Telecom stocks, however, slid 0.9% to their lowest level in six months, led by a 10.6% plunge in Tele2. Analysts expect further monetary tightening in the eurozone and UK due to sticky price pressures. The focus shifts to central bank policy meetings next week, with the European Central Bank and Federal Reserve set to make decisions.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6 per cent lower, with luxury giants at the forefront of the selling pressure.

site_title: US: S&P 500 inches down as investors digest more big bank earnings
summary: US stocks edged lower on Tuesday as investors digested earnings reports from Morgan Stanley and Bank of America, after a week of market gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 11.73 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell. The decline follows signs of inflation cooling and anticipation of positive earnings reports.

site_title: Oil prices up on expected economic support in China, weaker US output
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Tuesday, driven by China's pledge to support economic growth and expectations that the US Federal Reserve will stop raising interest rates soon. Brent futures rose $1.13 to $79.63 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $1.60 to $75.75. The US shale oil production is expected to decline in August, and analysts forecast a 2.4-million barrel draw from US crude stocks. The oil market remains tight due to Russian shipments and China's support, but medium-term growth prospects remain weak.

images.alt_text: Oil briefly rose after a Reuters news alert on Saudi Arabia extending a voluntary output cut.

site_title: Tesla faces citizen grilling on impact of German plant expansion
summary: Tesla held a question-and-answer session with Brandenburg state residents to address concerns about its planned expansion of its local plant. The expansion aims to double production capacity to 1 million vehicles a year and add 50 gigawatt hours of battery production capacity. Residents are worried about the impact on water usage, as the plant is located in an area with limited water resources. Tesla has not provided a timeline for the expansion, which is crucial to surpassing Volkswagen's market share in the European market.

images.alt_text: Tesla says the legal action comes in response to a lawsuit that Cap-XX originally filed against Tesla subsidiary Maxwell Technologies in 2019 for patent infringement.
Plans for the vehicle, with its silvery, tortoise-like shape and unusual angles, were first announced in November 2019.
The workers say they welcome the award after Tesla has cut bonuses for many staff in the previous quarter.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says Tesla’s operations in Malaysia will begin this year.

site_title: Foxconn buys equipment from Apple for expansion in India
summary: Foxconn, a Taiwanese company, has acquired $33 million worth of equipment from Apple for its operations in India, signaling the company's accelerating expansion in the country. This purchase is part of Foxconn's plans to invest $700 million to build a new plant in Karnataka, which aims to ramp up local production of iPhone parts. Apple has been increasing its production in India, with the company assembling over $7 billion of iPhones in the country last fiscal year.

site_title: BOJ’s Ueda signals resolve to maintain ultra-easy policy
summary: BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda signaled his resolve to maintain ultra-easy monetary policy, citing that Japan still needs time to sustainably achieve its 2% inflation target. Ueda stated that the central bank will scrutinize progress at each policy meeting, with no changes to its overall narrative on monetary policy unless its inflation target assumption changes. This maintains the current yield curve control (YCC) policy, which guides short-term interest rates at -0.1% and buys government bonds to cap the 10-year bond yield around 0%.

images.alt_text: epa10590387 Pedestrians cross a street in Tokyo, Japan, 25 April 2023. The Japanese government's monthly economic report maintained a general assessment that the economy was recovering moderately, despite some weaknesses.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA
The BOJ is scheduled to have a two-day policy meeting starting Jul 27.

With inflation exceeding its 2 per cent target for more than a year, markets are speculating that the BOJ will phase out its massive stimulus that has drawn criticism for distorting market pricing and narrowing financial institutions’ margins.
The rise, which followed a 5.2 per cent gain in May, was the slowest annual pace since April 2021, data by the BOJ showed.

site_title: Laguna National Club owes creditors S$69.7 million; assets far short of sums owed
summary: Laguna National Golf and Country Club, Singapore's first proprietary golf club, is in liquidation due to S$69.7 million in debts owed to creditors. The club has only S$699,433.05 in estimated realisable assets, or 1% of its debts. A creditors' meeting was held to appoint a committee of inspection to represent the interests of creditors. The club's liquidators will investigate payments made over the past 20 years to determine if they were above board. A cash distribution to creditors has not been set.

images.alt_text: At the heart of the dispute is money – to the tune of tens of millions of dollars – that has not yet been paid back to debenture holders, even though the 30-year-old notes were due for redemption in June 2021.

site_title: Meta opens AI model to commercial use, throwing nascent market into flux
summary: Meta has released a commercial version of its open-source AI model Llama 2, which will be distributed by Microsoft through its Azure cloud service and run on the Windows operating system. The model, which has been pretrained on 40% more data than its predecessor, will be made available for free to businesses, potentially upending the market for generative AI software dominated by OpenAI and Google. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg believes open-source technology will drive innovation, while Microsoft sees the release as a way to extend its position as a cloud platform for AI work.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Facebook's new rebrand logo Meta is seen on smartphone in front of displayed logo of Facebook, Messenger, Instagram, Whatsapp and Oculus in this illustration picture taken October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Meta has left the door open for a Threads launch in Europe and few expect it to maintain its embargo indefinitely.
The game will arrive as a beta version, initially on Quest 2 and Quest Pro, in the coming weeks.
The branded content tools will help marketers collaborate with influencers on paid partnerships on the social media platform while advertising is unavailable.

site_title: AusGroup ordered to wind up; MOU to restructure company terminated
summary: AusGroup has been ordered by the Singapore High Court to wind up, discharging the company from judicial management and releasing joint and several judicial managers from liability. The court appointed Deloitte & Touche as joint and several liquidators. AusGroup had applied to be wound up in May after being unable to pay its debts, and its memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Arion Agrophotovoltaic was automatically terminated due to no definitive agreements being executed by the long-stop date. Shares have been suspended since November 2022, trading at S$0.009.

images.alt_text: It's been a rather unfortunate turn of events for AusGroup, which had held up over oil’s previous downturns
The notice was sent out to end AusGroup Thailand’s services for Esso Sriracha Refinery (pictured) following a failed bid to attract investments or get the company restructured.

site_title: As retail leasing guidelines become law, tenants want more data from landlords
summary: Tenant group Singapore Tenants United for Fairness is pushing for landlords to provide data on footfall and average rental per square foot in retail premises, despite existing guidelines. The group proposes collecting data "by mall and by floor" and publishing it monthly, similar to residential transactions. Retailers argue that current data is too broad and not granular enough to be useful, and that sharing footfall and rental data could give tenants more negotiating power. However, landlords are hesitant to share data due to concerns about competitors poaching tenants.

images.alt_text: The code of conduct contains 11 key leasing principles that aim to foster fairer and more balanced lease negotiations.
Landlords get creative with new ‘fees and charges’ as leasing code set to become law

While most major private landlords and government landlords have updated their lease agreements in line with the code of conduct, adoption is rarer among smaller landlords, businesses and Fair Tenancy Industry Committee (FTIC) members told The Business Times.

site_title: Warner Music, TikTok sign expanded licensing agreement
summary: Warner Music Group and TikTok have signed an expanded licensing agreement, giving TikTok access to Warner's repertoire and creating new revenue opportunities for artists and songwriters. The deal will harness TikTok's revenue generation and promotion capabilities, deepening artists' engagement with the social media company's massive audience. The partnership also includes a licensing deal for TikTok Music, a subscription streaming service launching in Indonesia and Brazil, with plans for expansion in other markets.

images.alt_text: Employees own 20 per cent of ByteDance, while 60 per cent is owned by global investors, and 20 per cent by its founders.
jlbrunch1

TikTok is the fastest growing social network in the report, used by 20 per cent of 18- to 24-year-olds for news, up five percentage points from last year. Fewer than half the survey respondents expressed much interest in news at all, down sharply from 6 out of 10 in 2017.

site_title: Singapore’s insolvency and restructuring regime, in the eyes of practitioners
summary: Singapore's insolvency and restructuring regime has not yet achieved its goal of becoming an international debt restructuring hub, according to insolvency practitioners. Introduced in 2017 and 2018, the changes aimed to attract foreign companies to use Singapore's schemes of arrangement, which are modeled after the US Chapter 11 "debtor in possession" model. While the regime has enhanced features, such as expanded jurisdiction and automatic stay, it still lags behind other leading debt restructuring hubs.

images.alt_text: A 2019 survey found that Singapore law was the second most widely adopted governing law in cross-border transactions in Asia after English law.
In the Zipmex restructuring case, the Singapore High Court had to consider whether the unregistered foreign Zipmex entities have a “substantial connection” to Singapore as a threshold issue.

site_title: Two cheers for multipolarism: a mediating role for China in Ukraine could benefit all
summary: China's diplomatic efforts in the Middle East and Ukraine could benefit all parties involved, rather than being a zero-sum game where one power gains at the expense of another. A recent deal between Saudi Arabia and Iran brokered by China reduced tensions in the region and helped prevent regional conflicts. Similarly, China's restraint in Ukraine, resisting US pressure to join sanctions on Russia, could pave the way for a ceasefire and diplomatic deal. By managing its relationships with multiple powers, China can promote international stability and benefit all parties, rather than simply gaining at the expense of others.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping says China would “persist in the correct direction of economic globalisation, oppose protectionism, unilateral sanctions and extension of national security concepts”.

Since President Xi Jinping’s landmark visit to the kingdom in December, however, Chinese executives have been emboldened to seek out Gulf investment and a potential role in Vision 2030, a plan to transform the economy.

site_title: BlackRock names CEO of world’s biggest oil producer to its board
summary: BlackRock has named Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser to its board, bringing his expertise on the global energy industry and the Middle East region. Nasser, who has led the world's biggest oil producer since 2015, will provide BlackRock with a unique perspective on key issues facing the company and its clients. The move comes amid a highly politicized debate about BlackRock's role in ESG investing, with environmental advocates criticizing the firm for investing in the fossil fuel industry. Nasser's leadership experience and knowledge of the energy industry will contribute to the BlackRock board dialogue.

images.alt_text: BlackRock has begun fundraising for the fourth vintage of its climate infrastructure franchise, investing in transition-enabling infrastructure including wind, solar and battery storage.
Nasdaq recently refiled BlackRock’s application, adding details about the proposal to indicate that Coinbase Global will provide market surveillance for the new product.
The institute, an arm of the world’s biggest asset manager, has an overweight allocation for AI-related shares in developed markets.
The world’s largest money manager began rolling out the BlackRock Private Credit Fund this month, targeting mom-and-pop investors while vowing to keep “an eye on risk”.

site_title: India court says Google cannot remove Disney app in tussle over in-app charges
summary: An Indian court ruled that Google cannot remove Disney's streaming service from its app store in the country, and ordered Disney to pay a 4% service fee for in-app purchases. This decision challenges Google's policy of imposing a 11-26% fee on in-app payments in India, following an antitrust directive that forced Google to allow third-party payments. The ruling also prevents Google from removing the Disney app from its store, despite Disney's threat to do so if it didn't comply with the new billing system.

images.alt_text: Disney’s India business comprises Disney+ Hotstar streaming service and Star India, which it took over when it acquired the entertainment assets of 21st Century Fox in 2019.
Disney also anticipates another US$400 million impairment charge related to film and TV content.

Chief financial officer Christine McCarthy said on an earnings call last week that Disney will write off as much as US$1.8 billion of programming in 2023 as it culls the number of films and TV shows on its services.
Google has now added new features to Bard, which apply worldwide.

Google Play’s updated guidelines, which go into effect Dec. 7, say that games can support transactions involving tokenized assets under the platform’s existing Real-Money Gambling, Games, and Contests policy.

site_title: Spain antitrust watchdog fines Amazon, Apple 194.1 million euros
summary: Spain's antitrust watchdog has fined Amazon and Apple a total of 194.1 million euros for colluding to limit the online sale of Apple devices in Spain. The two companies were fined 143.6 million euros and 50.5 million euros respectively for restricting online marketplaces, blocking retailers, and limiting advertising. The fines follow a two-year investigation and can be appealed within two months. The deal led to a rise in prices of Apple devices sold online in Spain, with over 90% of existing retailers blocked from selling Apple products.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A women uses an iPhone mobile device as she passes a lighted Apple logo at the Apple store at Grand Central Terminal in New York City, U.S., April 14, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo
Tuesday’s ruling is the latest decision in the legal battle between Apple and Optis, which began in 2019 and has prompted six separate trials and several appellate hearings in Britain alone.

site_title: Some S$1.5 million of reparations under contention based on Oon family’s total salaries: defendant
summary: Violet Oon Inc and her family are seeking S$1.55 million in reparations, calculated based on a total of S$1.1 million in salaries paid to Oon and her two children between 2015 and 2018. Business partner Manoj Murjani stated that this amount includes employers' Central Provident Fund contributions. The dispute revolves over Oon's family seeking a court order to purchase Group MMM's shares or for Violet Oon Inc to be wound up.

images.alt_text: (seated) Restaurateur Violet Oon; (standing, left to right) her son Tay Yiming, business partner Manoj Murjani and her daughter Tay Su-Lyn. Murjani took the stand during a shareholder oppression case brought by Oon and her children, who are seeking a court order to be able to purchase outstanding shares they do not already own in Violet Oon Inc, or for the company to be wound up.
Violet Oon (seated) with her son Tay Yiming (left), business partner Manoj Murjani (middle) and daughter Tay Su-Lyn.

Violet Oon (seated) and her children (from left) Tay Yiming and Tay Su-Lyn. Tay Yiming alleged that business partner Manoj Murjani had verbally agreed when signing a 2014 shareholding agreement to match the family dollar for dollar whenever Violet Oon Singapore required more money.

(From left) Tay Yiming, Tay Su-lyn, Violet Oon and Manoj Murjani. Tay Su-Lyn was the second witness in a civil case she, her mother and her brother Tay Yiming brought against Murjani, alleging oppression.
Chef Violet Oon was cross-examined by her business partner Manoj Murjani’s lawyer on Tuesday, with Justice Philip Jeyaretnam presiding over the trial.

veviolet25 - Violet Oon Singapore outlet at Jewel Changi Airport. 

Credit: Violet Oon Singapore

site_title: UK insolvencies jump as higher rates take their toll
summary: UK insolvencies increased by 27% in June, with 2,163 businesses going bust, exceeding pre-Covid levels. Higher interest rates and sluggish economic growth are taking their toll, with business services, construction, and hospitality sectors most affected. Small companies make up most of the closures, while larger businesses are starting to feel the pressure. Experts warn of a potential surge in insolvencies, with over 6,000 companies possibly going under in a quarter, similar to the aftermath of the 2009 financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Some 5,747 companies in England and Wales were declared insolvent in Q1 2023 compared with 5,969 in the final quarter of 2022, which was the highest number since mid 2009.

site_title: Awards of new data centre capacity signal search for fresh ideas to benefit Singapore economy: market watchers
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Economic Development Board (EDB) have awarded 80 megawatts (MW) of new data centre capacity to four operators: GDS, Equinix, a consortium of AirTrunk and ByteDance, and Microsoft. The awards signal a search for fresh ideas and unique capabilities to benefit the Singapore economy, particularly in artificial intelligence (AI) and high-performance computing. The selections exclude some large local players, but include new operators that can bring greater flexibility and support Singapore's goals in improving connectivity and supporting AI technologies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cables and computers are seen inside a data centre at an office in the heart of the financial district in London, Britain May 15, 2017. REUTERS/Dylan Martinez/File Photo

site_title: Morgan Stanley Q2 profit drops 18% as deal doldrums persist
summary: Morgan Stanley's Q2 profit dropped 18% to $2.05 billion, or $1.24 per diluted share, due to a decline in investment banking revenue amid a deal-making drought. Global M&A activity fell 36% in the second quarter compared to the same period last year. Despite this, shares rose 1.4% in premarket trading, sparking hopes of a nascent recovery.

site_title: Vietnam’s e-scooter makers ride on growing demand from delivery giants
summary: Vietnam's e-scooter makers are riding the growing demand from delivery giants, with several major companies, including Grab, Gojek, and Lazada Logistics, launching pilot projects with local EV makers. The companies aim to reduce emissions and lower operating costs, with Grab citing a quarter reduction in costs compared to petrol models. Several e-scooter makers, such as Selex Motors and VinFast, are expanding their fleets to meet the growing demand, with plans to reach 1,500 and 100 electric motorbikes respectively by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: GrabExpress partners with Hanoi-based EV maker Selex Motors

site_title: Ares Management to buy Singapore private equity firm Crescent Point Capital
summary: US-based alternative investment group Ares Management Corp agreed to fully acquire Singapore-headquartered private equity firm Crescent Point Capital (CPC), enhancing its footprint and capabilities in the Asia-Pacific region. CPC, founded in 2003, had $3.8 billion in assets under management and 50 staff across Singapore, China, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of this year, without disclosing the deal value. Ares believes the acquisition will capitalise on growth prospects for dedicated Asia-Pacific private equity strategies.

site_title: Evergrande pushes restructuring plan after US$81 billion loss
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese real estate giant, has asked to convene meetings for offshore creditors to approve its credit overhaul plan after reporting a US$81 billion loss over two years. The company is seeking to complete one of China's biggest debt restructurings amid the housing industry meltdown. Court hearings are scheduled for next week, and analysts expect a potential approval of its debt-restructuring plan to avoid offshore litigation for its defaults.

images.alt_text: Evergrande has come to embody a broader crisis in China’s property sector, which accounts for around a quarter of the country’s gross domestic product.

site_title: US retail sales rise slightly in June; core retail sales solid
summary: US retail sales rose 0.2% in June, slightly less than expected, but core retail sales remained solid, suggesting consumer spending continued to grow in the second quarter. This boost, combined with upward revisions to May's core retail sales, indicates consumer spending remained resilient despite interest-rate hikes. Core retail sales increased 0.6% excluding cars, petrol, building materials, and food services, supporting economic growth estimates of a 2.3% annualized rate for the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Shoppers on Powell Street in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, Nov, 29, 2022. US retailers eked out modest growth over Black Friday weekend with deep discounts that lured shoppers seeking a reprieve from stubborn inflation. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Morgan Stanley’s job cuts cost US$308 million
summary: Morgan Stanley reported 82,006 employees at the end of June, down from 82,266 at March's end, resulting in job cuts worth US$308 million. The investment bank took the brunt of the cuts, following earlier rounds in December and earlier this year. Despite efforts to reduce expenses, Morgan Stanley's compensation expenses rose to US$6.26 billion in the second quarter.

site_title: German real estate cash fears are overdone, Deutsche Bank says
summary: Deutsche Bank has expressed confidence in the German real estate sector, citing a stabilization of house prices in the second half of 2023 and a predicted 20% decline in German residential values. Analyst Thomas Rothaeusler believes residential firms will overcome refinancing challenges without raising capital, contrasting with peers' warnings of "potentially enormous" rights issues. The analyst upgraded Vonovia to buy and TAG Immobilien to hold, citing growth in the rental market and upgraded rental guidance from LEG Immobilien.

site_title: China AI chip startup targeting Nvidia seeks HK IPO in 2023
summary: Chinese chip startup Biren Intelligent Technology is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong as early as this year. The company aims to capitalize on local clients seeking alternative AI chips due to US-led restrictions on Chinese companies purchasing advanced chips. Biren is in talks with state-backed funds for a separate funding round, which could raise around $368 million. The company's fundraising efforts come as the Chinese government accelerates its domestic semiconductor industry development. Details of the IPO are still being deliberated, and the size and timeline may change.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is a long-time partner and client of Arm.
In September, Nvidia had said US officials asked the company to stop exporting two top computing chips for AI work to China.
The chip industry is keen to protect its profits in China as the Biden administration considers another round of restrictions on chip exports to China.

The industry group says it wants “the Biden administration to refrain from further restrictions until it engages more extensively with industry and experts to assess the impact of current and potential restrictions.
SMIC is China’s most advanced chip manufacturer, a national champion that competes with the likes of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing in fabricating silicon.

site_title: Bank of America profit jumps on boost from interest income, investment banking
summary: Bank of America reported a 20% increase in profit in the second quarter, driven by higher interest income and investment banking fees. The bank's net interest income rose 14% to $14.2 billion, while investment banking fees jumped 7% to $1.2 billion. Consumer banking revenue rose 15% to $10.5 billion, but provision for credit losses increased due to stress in commercial real estate lending. Despite this, Bank of America's shares rose nearly 1% in premarket trading.

images.alt_text: BofA had cited a dialogue with the Fed to understand differing results between the central bank’s stress test and the companies’ own under the Dodd-Frank Act.
FILE PHOTO: A person walks past a Bank of America sign in the Manhattan borough of New York City, New York, U.S., January 19, 2022. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Just 2 bids for Jalan Tembusu private housing site; EC plot in Tampines garners 7 bidders
summary: Two 99-year leasehold residential sites were tendered in Singapore, attracting varying bids. The private housing site in Jalan Tembusu garnered just two bids, while the executive condominium site in Tampines Street 62 drew seven bidders. Analysts attribute the difference in demand to supply dynamics and the impact of property cooling measures on ECs. The Jalan Tembusu site can yield approximately 840 residential units, while the Tampines EC site is near the future Tampines North MRT Station on the Cross Island Line.

images.alt_text: Both sites fall under the confirmed list in the first half 2023 government land sales programme. Together, they may yield around 1,540 residential units.
The 99-year leasehold Plantation Close EC site, which can yield an estimated 495 units, is located between the future Tengah Park MRT station and Bukit Batok West MRT station.
The Marina Gardens Lane site, zoned residential with commercial at first storey, can yield about 790  private housing units.

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi’s liquidated company to pay all GST arrears, and 60% of valid unsecured claims
summary: Ng Yu Zhi's liquidated company, Envy Strategic Holdings, will pay the Comptroller of Goods and Services Tax (GST) in full and 60% of admitted unsecured claims. The first and final payment to the preferential creditor, GST, will be made on July 25. This payment will also be the first interim payout to unsecured creditors. The proceeds will come from the liquidation of Envy Strategic Holdings, which is part of the Envy group of companies, including Envy Global Trading, Envy Asset Management, and Envy Management Holdings. Ng Yu Zhi is facing 105 charges related to a US$1.1 billion alleged nickel trading scam.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi was declared bankrupt last month on the application of the liquidators of his companies.

site_title: US dollar slips towards 15-month low, euro scales 17-month peak
summary: The US dollar has fallen to a 15-month low, reaching 99.587 against a basket of six currencies, while the euro has scaled a 17-month peak at US$1.1276. The decline is attributed to investors awaiting fresh catalysts to gauge the downside of the US inflation, which showed a cooler-than-expected increase last week. Money markets have largely priced a 25-basis-point rate hike from the Federal Reserve, but expect rates to come down as early as December.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index falls 0.07 per cent to 99.891.

site_title: Fitch Ratings says risks to Vietnam from real estate has eased
summary: Fitch Ratings says the risks to Vietnam's government from the property sector have eased due to measures taken to curb risks, including tightening lending control to high-end real estate projects. Interest rates have fallen, reducing stress on the sovereign balance sheet. However, Fitch warns that uncertainty persists, particularly due to delays in policy implementation following a corruption crackdown and weakened reserve buffers against external shocks.

site_title: AXA fund to invest US$49 million in Brazil reforestation projects
summary: AXA IM Alts, a French insurer-backed investment firm, is investing US$49 million in Brazilian startup Mombak's reforestation projects. Mombak aims to reforest 10,000 hectares of degraded land, generating up to 6 million carbon credits. The partnership will help scale up operations and technology, and AXA IM Alts will take a minority stake in the company. The investment is part of AXA's efforts to significantly scale up its deployment in Brazil and the Amazon basin, with the goal of building the largest carbon removal projects in the world.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of insurer and bank AXA Belgium S.A. is seen in Brussels, Belgium February 25, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
The accelerating loss comes a year after world leaders vowed to halt and reverse forest loss by 2030.
Allianz says in an emailed statement on Thursday it has decided to leave the NZIA, and says it would stick to its own climate goals.

site_title: SGX RegCo rejects No Signboard’s application for extension to hold AGM
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has rejected No Signboard's application for an extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) by Aug 18. The company must announce FY2022 and FY2023 unaudited financial results and hold its FY2022 AGM "as soon as possible". SGX RegCo also rejected applications for releasing Q1-3 FY2023 results by Aug 10-17 and FY2023 Q4 results by Aug 24. No Signboard's shares remain suspended from trading since January 2022, and the company plans to release unaudited quarterly results "as soon as possible".

site_title: China’s Citic to move dozens of Hong Kong bankers to mainland to cut costs: sources
summary: China's Citic Securities plans to relocate dozens of bankers from its Hong Kong-based CLSA platform to the mainland to cut costs, with pay reductions of 25-50% expected. This move comes weeks after Citic cut pay across its investment banking division and amid Beijing's efforts to bridge income inequality in the financial sector. Over 30% of CLSA's 200 Hong Kong-based investment bankers may be affected, with around a "single-digit" figure impacted initially. The relocation aims to reduce costs and align with Beijing's austerity measures.

images.alt_text: Citic Securities Co. Ltd, China's financial company.
Citic Securities' investment income surged 89.6 per cent year on year to 5.82 billion yuan in the first quarter this year.

site_title: Pretty in pink: ‘Barbie’ marketing blitz hits fever pitch
summary: The highly anticipated film "Barbie" starring Margot Robbie has sparked a marketing blitz, with companies such as The Gap, Burger King, and Microsoft partnering with Mattel to promote the film. The film's release has led to a surge in "Barbie"-themed products and collaborations, with some companies releasing limited-edition items in hot pink. Analysts predict a strong opening weekend for the film, with some expecting US$75 million in North American ticket sales. The film's release has also been accompanied by controversy, including a ban in Vietnam over a scene with a fictitious world map.

images.alt_text: 'Barbie' is the latest movie to be banned in Vietnam for depicting China’s nine-dash line, which was repudiated in an international arbitration ruling by a court in The Hague in 2016.
The latest movie from Studio Ghibli's Hayao Miyazaki will be a complete mystery to the audiences when it opens on Jul 14.
Vietnam authorities ban the upcoming Greta Gerwig film over a map in “Barbie” that they said shows a Chinese map of territory in the South China Sea, where the two neighbours have competing claims.

site_title: Singapore shares end Tuesday flat as investors move with caution
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index ended Tuesday flat, closing at 3,254.26 after a loss of 0.17 points. Investors approached the market with caution due to inflation, interest rates, and the upcoming corporate earnings season. Market analyst Olivier d'Assier noted that global market rallies may not be sustainable and risk-averse investors are waiting for clarity before re-entering equities. Top gainers included Novo Tellus and iFast Corp, while Venture Corporation was among the top decliners.

images.alt_text: Interior view of the Singapore Exchange (SGX), from an escalator passing by electronic ad boards, taken on 5 September 2019
Hong Kong led losses in early trade Tuesday, shedding more than one per cent as it reopened a day after being shut because of a severe storm.

site_title: Singapore bonds outlook: Stable rates and more debt issuance
summary: Singapore's interest rates remain stable, with yields on Treasury bills falling since their peak of 4.4% in late 2022. This divergence from the US fed funds rate trend indicates a shift in investor behavior. As a result, corporates are likely to return to the SGD debt market for issuance, particularly for shorter-duration bonds. This trend is expected to continue, making Singapore an attractive destination for investors seeking fixed-income assets.

images.alt_text: Generics of DBS building
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS)‘s data published on Thursday (Jul 6) showed that a total of S$5.4 billion was allotted out of the S$10.3 billion received in applications.

site_title: China rolls over US$600 million loan to Pakistan
summary: China has rolled over a $600 million loan to Pakistan, helping the country shore up its foreign exchange reserves following a long-awaited IMF bailout. The loan, part of a larger $5 billion rollover, was announced by Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif as negotiations with the IMF finally came to fruition. The IMF deal secured $3 billion in bailout funds, while additional support from Saudi Arabia and the UAE helped steady the Pakistani economy, with the country's trade deficit and current account deficit declining significantly.

images.alt_text: Improving finances will ease Pakistan into elections later this year.
Inflation has rocketed, the rupee has plummeted, and the country is struggling to afford imports, causing a severe decline in industrial output.
FILE PHOTO: Pakistan's Finance Minister Ishaq Dar is seen after a party meeting in Islamabad, Pakistan September 26, 2017. Picture taken September 26, 2017. REUTERS/Faisal Mahmood/File Photo

With sky-high inflation and foreign exchange reserves barely enough for a month of controlled imports, analysts say Pakistan’s economic crisis could have spiralled into a debt default in the absence of the IMF bailout.

site_title: Deutsche Bank draws fresh ECB scrutiny over FX swap sales
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has criticized Deutsche Bank over its foreign exchange (FX) sales, specifically FX derivatives such as swaps, to European companies. The ECB has instructed Deutsche Bank to improve oversight and checks, citing concerns that the lender has not adequately explained associated risks to clients. This comes months after Deutsche Bank completed an internal probe into past practices that led to initial changes. The criticism threatens to undermine CEO Christian Sewing's efforts to leave behind a history of scandals and regulatory run-ins.

images.alt_text: De Sanctis is merging the division’s two existing leadership teams into one in a broader reorganisation along regional lines.

site_title: China’s new consumption plan may do little to boost growth
summary: China releases a plan to boost household spending with measures such as local authorities helping residents refurbish their homes and improving access to credit for buying household products. The plan aims to address slowing economic growth, but economists say it is light on meaningful policies to boost the recovery. China's economic growth slowed in the second quarter, with retail sales cooling, the property market downturn deepening, and youth unemployment reaching a new high. Officials are expected to outline more details at a briefing later.

images.alt_text: Retail sales grew 3.1 per cent in June, slowing sharply from a 12.7 per cent jump in May.
The slump in the property market has weighed on China’s economic recovery, putting Beijing’s official growth target of around 5 per cent at risk.
Some members of the public feel that China's economy is doing even worse than the official figures suggest.
Demand in China remains lukewarm amid a bumpy post-Covid economic recovery.

site_title: Xi tells ex-Philippine president Duterte to promote ties with China
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has urged former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte to promote cooperation between the two countries, amid strained relations with the US. Duterte's successor, Ferdinand Marcos Jr, has strengthened ties with the US, following Duterte's pro-China stance. Xi expressed hope that Duterte would continue to play a key role in friendly cooperation between China and the Philippines. However, tensions between China and the Philippines have grown under Marcos, with the US reaffirming a decades-old security alliance with the Philippines.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) This file handout photo taken and released by the Presidential Photo Division (PPD) on March 1, 2018 shows President Rodrigo Duterte (R) firing a few rounds with a sniper rifle during the opening ceremony of the National Special Weapons and Tactics (SWAT) Challenge in Davao City on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao. - Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has been accused of rights abuses in a drug war that has killed thousands of people. But analysts say he is unlikely to face charges after he steps down on June 30, 2022. (Photo by ROBINSON NIÑAL / PRESIDENTIAL PHOTO DIVISION / AFP) / TO GO WITH Philippine-politics-crime-Duterte,FOCUS by Allison Jackson

site_title: How equity investors could dodge a recession
summary: US consumer spending has slowed, potentially mitigating rising prices, but a slowdown in household spending could have unintended consequences on private sector investments and international trade. Companies that can continually generate free cash under all conditions, such as pharmaceutical and healthcare companies, consumer goods makers, and food producers, are likely to survive an economic downturn. Investors should focus on cash flow and balance sheets rather than relying on easy monetary policy or Keynesian economics. The fittest companies will thrive, while those that struggle to generate cash may struggle to survive.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a discussion on "Perspectives on Monetary Policy" during the Thomas Laubach Research Conference at the Federal Reserve Board building in Washington, DC, May 19, 2023. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)
Inflation is falling in most places but at different speeds, leaving policymakers a variety of challenges.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government has early access to OpenAI's capabilities, including ChatGPT. The government is developing software for the public sector with similar features. Prime retail rents in Singapore are expected to rise 3-5% in 2023. A liquidated company belonging to Ng Yu Zhi will pay all GST arrears and 60% of unsecured claims. Manulife US Reit breached loan covenants due to declining valuations. Thunes raised $100 million in funding from EDBI and Visa, and Singapore shares ended flat on Tuesday.

site_title: India’s Vistara prepares to merge staff into Air India, CEO says
summary: India's Vistara airline is set to merge its staff into Air India, with the combined airline to be named Air India. The merger, announced in November, aims to rebuild the country's aviation empire. Vistara's staff integration process has begun, with regulatory clearances expected by April 2024. The deal is part of Tata Group's efforts to compete with market leader IndiGo. Singapore Airlines will receive a 25.1% stake in the combined entity and invest $250 million in exchange for its Vistara interest.

images.alt_text: Air India passenger aircraft are seen on the tarmac at Chhatrapati Shivaji International airport in Mumbai, India, February 14, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

With a total of almost 1,000 jet orders between them, IndiGo and Air India are betting an economic boom and growing middle class will spur demand for domestic air travel, and new jets will help them grab a bigger share of international traffic.

site_title: Regionalisation of supply chain networks benefits Asean and India
summary: Regionalisation of supply chain networks is gaining momentum in Asean and India due to the post-Covid-19 pandemic shift away from China. Strong foreign direct investment and growth in exports have driven this trend, with countries like Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand benefiting from labour-intensive industries and government incentives. India, with its vast domestic market and abundant labour force, is also poised to gain from supply-chain relocation. As companies diversify production capacities, emerging industrial hubs in Asean and India are expected to gain market share in global exports, while China remains a global manufacturing powerhouse.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Second Trade and Industry Minister Tan See Leng, who is on a three-day official visit to Vietnam, spoke at the opening of the Singapore Regional Business Forum in Hanoi.
An aerial view of Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam. To date, Vietnam has negotiated and participated in 18 bilateral and multilateral free trade agreements.

site_title: Risk and reward in stressed and distressed debt
summary: High interest rates have shifted the risk focus from rising costs to refinancing, particularly for debtors whose earnings grow slower than interest on debt. As central banks tightened credit conditions, nominal interest rates now outpace economic growth, leading to increased default rates and distressed exchanges. Investors are navigating this transition, with the public debt market offering a growing opportunity set despite higher volatility. Companies with solid growth profiles will continue to carry debt, and selective investors can exploit mispricing in stressed sectors, with the potential for 80% recovery over the next two years.

images.alt_text: Blackstone own figures show it’s attracted 240 million euros (S$347 million) to its new private credit fund, dubbed ECRED, a fraction of the US$12 billion raised for BCRED, an equivalent US fund, at the half-year point of its fundraising about two years ago.
Challenging times are ahead for borrowers, not least those in emerging markets, now that interest rates have risen.

In Europe, where a larger part of financing comes from banks, firms have started feeling the pinch from the fastest tightening cycle in a decade and the amount spent on finance costs rose by a sixth at constant exchange rates.

site_title: Indian tycoon Adani touts huge wind and solar project in Gujarat
summary: Indian tycoon Gautam Adani announced plans to build a 20-gigawatt hybrid renewable energy project in Gujarat's deserts, dubbed the "largest hybrid renewables park in the world." The project aims to generate 45 gigawatts of green electricity by the end of the decade. Adani dismissed allegations of corporate fraud from Hindenburg Research, calling them "malicious" and "false narratives." The project's details and completion timeline remain unclear, following a stalled $50 billion hydrogen venture with TotalEnergies.

site_title: Mandela goes from hero to scapegoat as South Africa struggles
summary: South Africa is reevaluating its relationship with Nelson Mandela, 10 years after his death. As the ruling African National Congress (ANC) faces a potential loss of majority power, Mandela's image has shifted from hero to scapegoat. Many South Africans, particularly young people, believe he did not address the country's structural issues, such as land inequality and unemployment. The country's economic struggles, including a 46% unemployment rate among 15-34-year-olds, have led to a decline in trust in the government and Mandela's legacy.

images.alt_text: The South African savannah produces beautiful dawn and dusk landscapes.

site_title: Workers’ Party leaders aware of affair between Leon Perera and Nicole Seah in early 2021: Sources
summary: Allegations of an affair between Leon Perera, an Aljunied GRC MP, and Nicole Seah, a senior Workers' Party (WP) member, had been circulating within party circles since mid-2020. The issue was brought up to the party's leaders around early 2021, with Perera mentoring Seah at the time. Sources claim the pair would frequently meet at hotels and engage in inappropriate behavior, sparking concerns among some WP members.

images.alt_text: In a statement, the WP said it is aware of a video clip circulating online today that suggests an inappropriate exchange between two senior Party members.
PM Lee says the resignations of Tan (left) and Cheng (right) are necessary to “maintain the high standards of propriety and personal conduct which the PAP has upheld all these years”.
Clockwise from top left: Tan Chuan-Jin, Cheng Li Hui, David Ong, Yaw Shin Leong and Michael Palmer.
Cheng was the only female MP serving in Tampines GRC.

site_title: China property recovery is short-lived as industry contracts
summary: China's property industry contracted 1.2% in the second quarter, reversing a short-lived expansion, and weighing on the country's economic recovery, which risks falling short of Beijing's 5% growth target. Despite this, officials remain confident in achieving the full-year target, citing new policies to boost consumption. Economists expect moderate monetary policy easing from the People's Bank of China, with a possible cut in reserve requirements in the third quarter, to support economic growth.

images.alt_text: Some members of the public feel that China's economy is doing even worse than the official figures suggest.
China’s annual growth averaged around 7 per cent last decade, and more than 10 per cent in the 2000s.

site_title: Novartis raises outlook, maps out Sandoz spinoff
summary: Novartis raised its full-year earnings guidance on strong drug sales and outlined a plan for the spinoff and stock market debut of its generic medicines division Sandoz, expected in early Q4. The Swiss pharma major also initiated a share buyback program worth up to $15 billion. Shareholders will vote on the Sandoz spinoff at an extraordinary general meeting on September 15. The separate listing was previously projected for the second half of the year.

site_title: Singapore developing software with ChatGPT-like features for public sector
summary: The Singapore government is developing a software suite called Pair, which offers features similar to ChatGPT, to enhance productivity for the public sector. Janil Puthucheary, Senior Minister of State for Communications and Information, announced the project, citing early access to OpenAI's capabilities. The goal is to improve digital services for citizens, leveraging AI technology.

images.alt_text: Larry Feinsmith (left), JP Morgan Chase’s head of global tech strategy, innovation and partnerships tells Databricks chief Ali Ghodsi about that the bank is working through the risks of AI.

site_title: Could ‘white hydrogen’ change everything for shipping – and everybody else?
summary: A new form of "white hydrogen" has been discovered, potentially offering a cheap, carbon-free alternative to traditional fuels. The fuel is created through fracking, a process that involves fracturing deep underground layers of sediments. While economically viable commercial extraction is not yet a reality, scientists predict that vast reserves of natural hydrogen lie under the earth's surface, and could supply the projected global hydrogen demand for thousands of years. The discovery has sparked an "exuberant rush" in the energy industry, with energy majors potentially exploring pilot projects to extract and store the fuel, which could change the future of the global energy system.

images.alt_text: Liner shipping, the global containerised shipping sector, has already come under great pressure to reduce its carbon footprint, and the sector is responding.
The dangerous work of ship demolition is often carried out by people wearing flip flops paddling around in puddles of oil and inhaling air full of asbestos dust.

site_title: Adnoc says high-speed hydrogen refuelling station to open this year
summary: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc) announced the completion of the region's first high-speed hydrogen refuelling station this year. The station, in partnership with Toyota and Al-Futtaim Motors, will test hydrogen-powered vehicles and support the UAE's National Hydrogen Strategy, aiming to make the country a large hydrogen producer by 2031. Adnoc's CEO, Sultan al-Jaber, sees hydrogen as a critical fuel for the energy transition, while the company invests in green technologies and expands oil production to 5 million barrels per day by 2027.

images.alt_text: Sultan al-Jaber, chief executive of the UAE's Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) and president of this year's COP28 climate gestures during the 7th Ministerial on Climate Action (MoCA) in Brussels on July 13, 2023. The Ministerial on Climate Action (MoCA) is an annual meeting attended by ministers and high-level representatives from over 30 countries, including ministers from the G20 and chairs of key party groupings in the UN climate negotiations. (Photo by François WALSCHAERTS / AFP)

(FILES) A file photo taken on July 27, 2022 shows the headquarters of UAE's state oil company ADNOC in Dubai. - Gas giants British Petroleum (BP) and Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) placed a $4 billion offer to purchase half of NewMed Energy, the Israeli company said on March 27, 2023. (Photo by Giuseppe CACACE / AFP)

site_title: Prime retail rents set to rise as global brands expand in Singapore: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's prime retail rents are expected to rise 3-5% in 2023, driven by global brands expanding and private wealth inflows. Orchard's prime retail rents increased 5.9% year-on-year, exceeding the islandwide average. The sector has benefited from international brand expansions, including luxury brands and F&B entrants, despite moderating growth and labor challenges. Knight Frank attributes the growth to Singapore's stable framework and growing private wealth, with special concept stores emerging as a key trend.

images.alt_text: The Paragon, a luxury shopping complex located in the Orchard Road area of Singapore on May 16, 2021 .
For all the battering that Hong Kong has taken, prices in its bellwether office sector have fallen only 7 per cent over the past two years.
DBS analysts expect most S-Reits to be able to keep earnings above three times interest expense. The exception would be office and US office S-Reits, which have higher leverage ratios.
Singapore narrowly avoids technical recession in Q2 as GDP grows 0.7% year on year, 0.3% quarterly

site_title: Japan chipmaker Rohm to invest 100 billion yen in Toshiba buyout fund
summary: Japanese chipmaker Rohm plans to invest 100 billion yen (S$956 million) in a fund backed by Japan Industrial Partners to participate in the privatization of Toshiba. Rohm aims to help resolve Toshiba's issues and notes the semiconductor business of both companies is highly compatible. There is no agreement to participate in Toshiba's management, but Rohm is open to future partnerships. The investment will be made through underwriting non-voting preferred stock issued by TBJ Holdings, which will be used for a tender offer for Toshiba, potentially putting the company in domestic hands.

site_title: Australia central bank hits pause as policy clearly restrictive, risking growth
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates unchanged at 4.1% for the second time since May last year, citing restrictive policy and a risk of a sharp downturn and higher unemployment. The bank warned that further tightening may still be needed to control inflation, which slowed to a 13-month low of 5.6% in May. The RBA will reassess the situation in August, awaiting additional data on inflation, the global economy, and household spending.

images.alt_text: Michele Bullock is currently deputy governor.

site_title: UK inflation data set to fuel pressure for more BOE rate hikes
summary: UK inflation figures are expected to show a slight drop to 8.2% in June, the lowest level since March last year, but core inflation remains at a 31-year high of 7.1%. The Bank of England is likely to raise interest rates again, with some economists predicting a half-point increase, fueling speculation about the fastest monetary-tightening cycle since the 1980s. The rate hike would add to the pressure on households and businesses, with mortgage costs expected to rise.

images.alt_text: The reduction will come as a relief for households struggling with their budgets, as rising interest rates bump up mortgage costs and inflation remains more than four times its target at 8.7 per cent.

site_title: Fast-fashion retailer Temu sues rival Shein over US antitrust law
summary: Temu, a Chinese fast-fashion retailer, has filed a lawsuit against rival Shein, accusing it of violating US antitrust law by coercing clothing manufacturers to sign loyalty oaths and discontinue business with Temu. Temu claims this practice has led to higher prices and fewer choices for consumers. Shein has responded that the lawsuit is "without merit" and will vigorously defend itself. This is the latest development in a feud between the two companies, which has already seen Shein sue Temu over social media allegations.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase are among the banks helping Shein with its IPO preparation, according to six of the sources.

site_title: Manulife US Reit’s manager ‘surprised’ by deep decline in valuations; breach of covenants may affect H1 distribution
summary: Manulife US Reit's portfolio valuation declined 14.6% to US$1.6 billion, breaching loan covenants due to higher discount rates and terminal capitalisation rates, as well as weakening US office market occupancy. The Reit's aggregate leverage rose to 57%, exceeding the 50% limit set by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The manager is addressing the breach with its legal and accounting team, and is exploring options to reduce debt, including selling assets or seeking sponsor support. Distributions for the first half of 2023 may be impacted, and the Reit's financial covenant breach could result in a cross-default on interest rate swaps.

images.alt_text: The Children's Place will vacate its 197,949 square feet of space on May 31, 2024.
The Reit’s manager says it aims to enter into a definitive agreement for Phipps Tower’s disposal by Jun 30, 2023. It will also waive the disposal fee.
Manulife US Reit's office properties have declined in value, and its gearing is bumping up against the statutory ceiling of 50 per cent
With the Reit’s portfolio having a weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of five years, its manager expects positive rental reversion for 2023.
MAS should set out its expectations of troubled Reits' managers and sponsor groups

site_title: Ralph Lauren will keep raising prices to boost brand prestige
summary: Ralph Lauren plans to continue raising the average price of its products to boost brand prestige, with a 80% increase since 2018. CEO Patrice Louvet aims to elevate product quality and storytelling to justify higher prices, despite industry-leading price increases and lower-than-expected gross margins. The company is focusing on expansion in India, with a goal of establishing a strong presence in the next five years, and aims to grow its women's business and open new dining and drinking locations.

images.alt_text: While overall US luxury spending has taken a hit, Ralph Lauren’s moves to double down on its outdoor wear and women’s clothing collections have drawn more shoppers.

site_title: MUFG, Morgan Stanley to collaborate on forex trading, Japan equity research
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Finance Group (MUFG) and Morgan Stanley have collaborated on foreign exchange trading and Japanese research and equity businesses for institutional clients. MUFG's main banking unit will use Morgan Stanley's global foreign exchange platform for scale and competitiveness. The duo will also combine their Japanese research and equity operations at their two brokerage joint ventures. This partnership deepens their collaboration, which began in 2008 with MUFG's $9 billion investment in Morgan Stanley, and expands their existing global investment banking and wealth management partnership.

site_title: Chinese EV giant BYD to assemble Singapore electric scooter
summary: Singapore electric scooter company Scorpio Electric has partnered with Chinese EV giant BYD to assemble its first product, the X1, in Shenzhen. The company will produce pre-production prototypes, which will undergo rigorous testing and certification before being exhibited at the Milan motorcycle show in November. BYD will assemble the X1, with Scorpio using a 5 kWh battery from Samsung, and the scooter is on track to hit the market by the end of 2023 with initial sales of 2,000 to 3,000 units.

images.alt_text: “The sales volume of the company’s new energy vehicles has achieved strong growth from a high base in the same period last year, and continued to consolidate its leadership in new energy vehicle industry,” BYD says

site_title: Australian developer Lendlease to cut about 740 jobs globally
summary: Australian developer Lendlease plans to cut approximately 740 jobs, about 10% of its global workforce, as part of a five-year turnaround plan. The majority of the cuts will be in international operations, with the company focusing on growing its fund-management business and development projects. Despite the layoffs, Lendlease's project delivery and targets remain unaffected. The move reflects the challenging times for the commercial real estate sector, which is battling lower occupancy and higher debt servicing costs. Lendlease shares closed down 4.9% on the news.

images.alt_text: Office buildings and commercial towers in the central business district of Sydney. The funds are facing increased regulatory scrutiny after ramping up their holdings of unlisted assets both locally and abroad in recent years.

site_title: Upholding the Singapore system against corruption’s threat
summary: Singapore is facing a corruption scandal involving Transport Minister S Iswaran and property tycoon Ong Beng Seng, the first time in years a government minister and business leader have been implicated. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) has arrested both individuals, with Iswaran on leave of absence. While the scandal has tarnished Singapore's reputation, the government's swift action and commitment to transparency have mitigated the damage, and the nation's business confidence remains intact. To prevent future scandals, Singapore must prioritize transparency, improve institutional integrity, and maintain a culture of accountability.

images.alt_text: Ong Beng Seng returned on a private jet which landed in Seletar Airport at about 5.15pm on Monday, accompanied by his wife Christina Ong.
From left to right: Minister for Transport S Iswaran; Formula One Group chief executive Stefano Domenicali; and HPL co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng.
DPM Lawrence Wong says that he and PM Lee Hsien Loong are “fully committed” to keeping and preserving the trust that the people have in the government.
The hotel and property tycoon is also known for being one of those responsible for first bringing the Formula 1 night race to Singapore in 2008.

site_title: Wastewater treatment startup Hydroleap raises US$4.4 million in Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based wastewater treatment startup Hydroleap has raised US$4.4 million in Series A funding led by Japanese venture firm Real Tech Holdings. The funding round also includes Mitsubishi Electric, Wavemaker Partners, and other investors. Founded in 2016, Hydroleap uses electrochemical techniques to treat industrial wastewater, reducing pollutants by up to 95%. The company plans to develop global best practices for cost-effective water-treatment technologies, with existing customers including PUB, CapitaLand, and Universal Robina.

images.alt_text: From top left, clockwise: Zenith's leadership team comprises Lim Zi Jian, Chester Mark, Bryan Tan, Joel Yap and Evan Heng.

site_title: India’s Infosys signs five-year AI deal with US$2 billion target spend
summary: Infosys, India's second-largest software services exporter, has signed a 5-year deal with an existing client to provide AI and automation services, valued at approximately US$2 billion. The agreement includes development, modernization, and maintenance services for the client, which was not disclosed. This move comes as companies worldwide invest heavily in AI, following rival Tata Consultancy Services' plan to train 25,000 engineers on Microsoft's Azure Open AI. Infosys launched its generative AI platform, Infosys Topaz, in May.

images.alt_text: The government has had early access to some of the latest capabilities of OpenAI, the developer of ChatGPT, said Dr Janil Puthucheary (pictured).
The partnership involves Infosys working with Danske to accelerate the bank’s technological transformation.

site_title: Is the EU’s green edge under threat?
summary: The European Union's green agenda is facing growing discontent both domestically and internationally. Despite its ambitious sustainability initiatives, including the European Green Deal and the EU Taxonomy for sustainable activities, there is criticism from countries like China and EU member states such as Germany and France. The EU's efforts to become climate neutral by 2050 are being challenged by concerns over the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, which could limit market access for developing countries. Domestic discontent has also been fueled by the cost of living crisis and concerns over the impact of EU environmental regulations on the economy.

images.alt_text: “Some are trying to draw climate policy into the culture wars, because then you create a tribal opposition,” EU climate chief Frans Timmermans says.
The EU law will require all new cars sold to have zero CO2 emissions from 2035, and 55 per cent lower CO2 emissions from 2030, versus 2021 levels.

site_title: Tan Chuan-Jin resigns as president of Singapore National Olympic Council
summary: Tan Chuan-Jin, Singapore's National Olympic Council (SNOC) president since 2014, has resigned from his post following his resignation as Speaker of Parliament and MP for Marine Parade GRC due to an extramarital affair. The SNOC executive committee accepted his resignation, and the vice-president will serve as acting president for the remainder of the term.

site_title: Europe’s sweltering summer could send tourists to cooler climes
summary: Europe's sweltering summer temperatures are prompting tourists to consider cooler destinations or travel in spring and autumn to avoid extreme heat. A 10% decline in Mediterranean travel plans for June to November has been reported, with destinations like the Czech Republic, Denmark, and Ireland seeing an increase in interest. Experts warn that unpredictable weather conditions will impact travelers' choices, with 7.6% of travelers now considering extreme weather events a major concern. Some tourists, like Anita Elshoy, are returning home earlier due to heat-related health issues, while others are considering alternative destinations like Norway.

images.alt_text: A man uses water bottles for flotation as he cools off in a canal in Beijing. Swathes of northern China sweltered in 40 deg C on June 22.

site_title: Ken Griffin purchases Palm Beach property for US$83 million
summary: Ken Griffin, a billionaire, purchased a Palm Beach property for US$83 million, adding to his existing office at 151 Worth Ave, which he also bought for US$78 million last year. Griffin has been expanding his Florida presence after moving Citadel's headquarters to the state. With an estimated fortune of nearly US$37 billion, Griffin plans to build an office tower in Miami's Brickell neighborhood, one of the city's tallest skyscrapers.

site_title: Thunes adds EDBI, Visa to extended Series C round
summary: Thunes, a Singapore-based global payment network, has raised US$72 million in its Series C funding round with new investors EDBI and Visa. The round, initially valued at US$60 million, was led by London-based hedge fund Marshall Wace and Bessemer Venture Partners. Thunes partners with 78 digital wallet providers globally and has clients such as Uber, PayPal, and Revolut. CEO Peter De Caluwe said the funding will help expand the network and offer unparalleled cross-border payments experiences.

images.alt_text: Insight Partners leads US$60m Series B extension round in cross-border payments startup Thunes, doubling its share price
Thunes partners Cambodia's Advanced Bank of Asia for instant cross-border transfers to bank accounts

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank initiates Lendlease Global Reit with ‘buy’ on retail rebound
summary: Maybank has initiated a "buy" on Lendlease Global Reit, citing its potential for a 17.6% upside due to resilient domestic consumption and steady tourism recovery. The Reit's 7% yield and 15% discount to book value also support its growth. Plans to develop Jurong as Singapore's second central business district and the redevelopment of Orchard Road are expected to benefit JEM and 313@somerset assets. The sponsor, Lendlease Group, has a significant development pipeline and right-of-first-refusal agreements, making it a supportive partner for the Reit.
