images.alt_text: Jem mall in Jurong East.

0620 Yy / Media Release: Keppel DC REIT strengthens portfolio with two data centres in Guangdong, China
/ 20 June 2022, Singapore – Keppel DC REIT has entered into agreements with Guangdong Bluesea Data Development Co. Ltd. (Bluesea) and its parent company, Guangdong Bluesea Mobile Development Co. Ltd., to acquire two data centre facilities, on a fully-fitted basis, in Jiangmen, Guangdong Province, for RMB 1,380.6 million (approximately S$297.1 million).
LReit volunteers bake and distribute muffins to beneficiaries.
Parkway Parade Partnership holds an indirect 100 per cent interest in Parkway Parade's 291 strata lots, which represent 77.09 per cent of the lots’ total share value.

site_title: How much trouble is China’s economy in?
summary: China's economy is faltering, with GDP growth slowing to 6.3% in the second quarter, down from the expected rate. The economy's nominal growth was weaker than inflation-adjusted figures, suggesting deflationary pressures. The property market is also struggling, with flat sales and a 27% decline in June. The government has cut interest rates and offered tax breaks, but has not released a detailed fiscal stimulus plan, sparking concerns that it may be losing confidence in the economy's recovery.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People attend a job fair in China's southwestern city of Chongqing on April 11, 2023. Unemployment among Chinese youths jumped to a record 21.3 percent in June, the National Bureau of Statistics said on July 17, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
Demand in China remains lukewarm amid a bumpy post-Covid economic recovery.

site_title: Malaysia PM says China’s Geely to invest US$10 billion in Malaysian auto city: report
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced that Chinese car manufacturer Geely plans to invest US$10 billion in the Malaysian state of Perak to turn Tanjung Malim into a major carmaking hub. The investment will create thousands of job opportunities for Malaysians, according to Anwar. Geely, which owns a 49.9% stake in Malaysian carmaker Proton, conveyed the plan to Anwar in a letter. The move aims to boost Malaysia's economy and provide employment for young people.

site_title: World Bank chief Banga unveils new plans to boost lending ‘firepower’
summary: World Bank president Ajay Banga unveiled new plans to boost lending by up to US$50 billion over the next decade, on top of initial steps approved in April. The plans include allowing shareholders to guarantee loans if countries cannot repay them, generating an estimated US$30 billion in new lending. Banga also proposed expanding very low or zero-interest lending, including a new US$6 billion crisis facility for the poorest countries. A capital increase will still be needed, but progress is being made, with Banga stating that the bank is "building a better bank."

images.alt_text: The WTO has a mandate to liberalise services but its member states have not collectively improved market access since 1997 when deals were struck on telecommunications, according to the joint report by World Bank and WTO.

site_title: Taylor Swift sets women’s record for most No 1 albums
summary: Taylor Swift has set a record for most No 1 albums by a female artist, surpassing Barbra Streisand with her 12th No 1 album, "Speak Now (Taylor's Version)". She has also become the first living artist in nearly 60 years to have four albums in the top 10 simultaneously, and the first living artist to have 11 albums in the top 200 at the same time.

images.alt_text: On top of increased search activity for the duration of Swift's Singapore concerts, more actual bookings have also been made at hotels, and some flight prices are recording increases.
Klook packages including Category 1  Taylor Swift concert tickets sell out within two hours.
American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift.
Fans wait in line outside Nissan Stadium ahead of artiste Taylor Swift's second night of performance on May 6, 2023 in Nashville, Tennessee.
(From left) Polytechnic student Nellie Titus and her friends Rebekah Loh, Megan Choy and Lynette Saw turned up at Lim Ah Pin Post Office in Kovan on Wednesday at 10.30 pm.

(FILES) US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performs onstage on the first night of her "Eras Tour" at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on March 31, 2023. Music megastars Taylor Swift and The Weeknd are among showbiz people invited to join the organization that votes on who gets Oscars, the body said on June 28.
Other invitees include Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, who directed "Everything Everywhere All at Once," which won seven Oscars this year including the prize for best picture.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its new crop of members of Tinseltown's most elite club numbers 398 people. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)
UOB's card applications have surged since Taylor Swift announced her stop in Singapore – the only one in South-east Asian for her Eras Tour.
US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performs onstage on the first night of her "Eras Tour" at AT&T Stadium on March 31, 2023, in Arlington, Texas. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

site_title: London new home sales tumble to lowest since 2012 as rates weigh
summary: London's newly-built home sales plummeted to their lowest in over a decade, with just over 3,000 homes sold between April and June, according to data compiled by Molior London. This is the lowest sales figure since 2012, and is attributed to surging borrowing costs weighing on the city's housing market. Construction starts and completions also fell below the three-year average, with a record 70 projects stalled in the capital. Developers are relying on incentives and marketing to the small pool of discretionary purchasers, as overseas sales, particularly from Hong Kong buyers, have also declined.

images.alt_text: Prices nationwide are still 0.5 per cent above where they were a year ago and have risen steadily since December.

site_title: UK support to rejoin the EU passes 50% for the first time
summary: A YouGov poll shows that 51% of Britons would vote to rejoin the European Union for the first time since the UK's 2016 Brexit referendum. This marks a 11-point increase since January 2021, reflecting growing disillusionment with Brexit. 57% of Britons now believe the UK was wrong to vote for Brexit, with 1 in 5 who initially supported leaving now saying it was the wrong decision. The UK government is seeking to renegotiate parts of the exit deal to mitigate costs and disruption.

images.alt_text: The reduction will come as a relief for households struggling with their budgets, as rising interest rates bump up mortgage costs and inflation remains more than four times its target at 8.7 per cent.
Prices nationwide are still 0.5 per cent above where they were a year ago and have risen steadily since December.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as China growth worries offset US Fed rate hopes
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as China's economy showed signs of weakness, outweighing optimism about the US Federal Reserve's ability to combat inflation. Hong Kong led losses, shedding over 1% as it reopened after a severe storm. Analysts warn that China's post-Covid recovery is facing challenges, and leaders' ability to implement stimulus measures is limited. The decline in Asian markets overshadowed expectations of the US Fed's potential rate hike, which had previously boosted investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: In the fight for supremacy, who emerges victorious? Singapore or Hong Kong?

site_title: Netflix plans documentary series on US Women’s World Cup team
summary: Netflix is producing a documentary series on the US Women's World Cup team, focusing on their quest for a third consecutive title in Australia and New Zealand. The series, featuring newcomers like 18-year-old Alyssa Thompson and veterans like Alex Morgan and Megan Rapinoe, is already in production and will be released later this year. Rapinoe announced that the 2023 tournament will be her last due to her retirement at the end of the National Women's Soccer League season.

site_title: China’s NDRC vows to roll out consumption support policies without delay
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has pledged to roll out consumption support policies without delay, citing weak consumer purchasing power and demand. The country's economy grew 6.3% in the second quarter, below forecast, and retail sales slowed to 3.1% in June. The NDRC aims to stabilize jobs, particularly youth employment, and improve the consumption environment through practical policies. Private business confidence remains weak, with fixed-asset investment shrinking 0.2% in the first six months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The skyline of the Beijing's Central Business District rises behind people crossing a street during evening rush hour as the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues in China, April 15, 2020. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: Lilly drug slows Alzheimer's by 60% for mildly impaired patients, Alzheimer's group says
summary: Lilly's experimental drug donanemab has slowed the progression of Alzheimer's by 60% for mildly impaired patients, according to the Alzheimer's Association. This is nearly twice the rate reported in May for the overall treatment group. Donanemab, an intravenous antibody, removes beta amyloid deposits from the brains of Alzheimer's patients. The 18-month trial showed continued treatment effect increase over placebo. The full study results are being presented at the Alzheimer's Association International Conference and published in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Eli Lilly and Company pharmaceutical manufacturing plant is pictured at 50 ImClone Drive in Branchburg, New Jersey, March 5, 2021. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares slip at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,251.48. Gainers outnumbered losers 54 to 43, with Seatrium rising 0.7% and Thai Beverage adding 1.7%. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS up 0.2% and UOB down 0.4%. The decline followed a mixed global market performance, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 closing higher, but European shares falling.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index ended Monday (Jul 17) with a gain of 0.2 per cent or 5.8 points at 3,254.43.

site_title: Australia’s Victoria pulls out of hosting 2026 Commonwealth Games
summary: Victoria, Australia, has withdrawn its bid to host the 2026 Commonwealth Games due to projected cost overruns, with estimated costs potentially exceeding A$7 billion. Premier Dan Andrews cited the expense as "three times the cost as estimated and budgeted for last year" and stated that funds would be redirected to hospitals and schools instead. The Commonwealth Games Federation has not commented on the decision, leaving the future of the event uncertain.

images.alt_text: The 36-year-old Djokovic is targeting an eighth Wimbledon title, which would draw him level with Federer’s men’s record.

site_title: Gold struggles for traction as traders await US Fed cues
summary: Gold prices struggled for momentum, remaining steady at $1,955.24 per ounce, as traders await the US Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting for clues on its monetary tightening path. Interest rate futures indicate another rate hike is likely, with markets pricing in rate cuts well into 2024. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Goldman Sachs' chief economist Jan Hatzius downplayed the risk of a US recession, citing lower interest rates decreasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: The US dollar edged up slightly above its April 2022 lows, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies.

site_title: China property giant Evergrande loses US$113 billion over two years
summary: China property giant Evergrande reported a net loss of over $113 billion in 2021 and 2022, and nearly $340 billion in liabilities. The company's financial struggles have contributed to a broader crisis in China's property sector, which accounts for around a quarter of the country's gross domestic product. Evergrande's Hong Kong-listed shares have been suspended since March 2022, and the company has announced a restructuring proposal to swap debt for new notes and equities. The company's longstop date for restructuring is December 15, 2023.

images.alt_text: With about US$300 billion of total liabilities, Evergrande’s debt problem has rippled through China’s property sector.
The case underscores the enduring conflict between creditors and homeowners as debt-laden Evergrande faces more than a thousand lawsuits.
Xia Haijun stepped down from the embattled Chinese property developer in July.

site_title: UK food and drink makers cut prices for first time since 2020
summary: UK food and drink manufacturers have cut prices for the first time in over three years, according to a survey by Lloyds Banking Group. The price reduction, driven by falling input costs, is a relief for households struggling with budget constraints. However, inflation remains high at 8.7%, and rising interest rates are expected to continue to impact mortgage costs. The move may ease concerns about "greedflation" but does not necessarily translate to lower prices for consumers immediately.

images.alt_text: Britain is suffering from acute labour shortages in some sectors, meaning employers are keen to recruit workers from abroad.
Food prices have been driven up by increased costs for animal feed, fertiliser and fuel as well as energy and labour.

site_title: Singapore needs both quality and quantity to win the carbon-trading race
summary: Singapore's carbon-trading hub is poised to become Asia's largest, but its success depends on aggregating and scaling high-quality credits while preserving product differentiation. The country's exchange, Climate Impact X, is already grouping similar credits and auctioning them collectively. However, ensuring the integrity of credits generated globally and addressing concerns around carbon offsetting remain significant challenges. To maintain its position, Singapore must balance the need for scale with the requirement for variety and high-quality credits, and buyers must conduct thorough due diligence to avoid greenwashing.

images.alt_text: Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: China property giant Wanda Commercial’s bonds suffer record slump
summary: China's Wanda Commercial bonds suffer record slump after a credit rating cut to "B+" from "BB-" by S&P Global and a downgrade warning by Bloomberg. The company, a services arm of China's largest commercial property firm, Dalian Wanda Group, reported it is still raising money for a $400 million bond payment due later this month. This comes amid a broader slump in China's property developers due to declining apartment sales and debt defaults. The rating cut and downgrade warning triggered a record decline in the unit's bonds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Men work at a construction site of apartment buildings in Beijing, China, July 15, 2022. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Chip companies, top US officials discuss China policy
summary: US chip company executives met with top Biden administration officials to discuss China policy, amid concerns over restricting chip exports to China. The chip industry, which generated $180 billion in US semiconductor purchases last year, urged the administration to refrain from further restrictions. Discussions centered on supply chains, the Chips Act subsidy program, and access to the Chinese market, with the US considering updating rules to restrict China's access to AI chips. The administration is weighing its options to balance national security concerns with the industry's interests.

images.alt_text: The industry group says it wants “the Biden administration to refrain from further restrictions until it engages more extensively with industry and experts to assess the impact of current and potential restrictions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Thomson Medical, SingPost, China Everbright Water, Penguin International
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced June operating results, carrying 2.9 million passengers, a 50.4% increase from last year. Cargo operations saw a 13% drop in load factor due to weaker demand. Thomson Medical Group issued S$30 million worth of notes, while Singapore Post appointed BofA Securities as its financial adviser for a strategic review. China Everbright Water issued S$276.8 million worth of five-year notes, and Penguin International's voluntary conditional cash offer was extended to Aug 3.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index ended Monday (Jul 17) with a gain of 0.2 per cent or 5.8 points at 3,254.43.

site_title: Ford slashes prices of F-150 Lightning trucks as EV wars heat up
summary: Ford has slashed prices of its F-150 Lightning electric trucks by 17% for the base model and 6.2% for the higher-end Platinum model, aiming to boost its share in the EV market dominated by Tesla. The price cuts follow improvements in scale and battery raw material costs. Ford's EV sales fell 2.8% in the quarter through June, and the company has strengthened its sourcing options for battery-grade lithium. The move is part of a price war started by Tesla, with Ford's shares closing down 6% at $14.09.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The all-electric Ford F-150 Lightning pickup truck is unveiled at the company's world headquarters in Dearborn, Michigan, U.S., May 19, 2021. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo

site_title: SIA’s net-zero path is not an easy one
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is under pressure to reduce its carbon emissions to meet Temasek's net-zero targets by 2050. The state investor notes that SIA's decarbonization path relies on switching to sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), but the cost of this fuel is a challenge. SIA's voluntary carbon offset program has seen modest take-up, and the airline's total emissions rose to 27 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent for the year ended March 31, 2023. Temasek's portfolio companies are expected to play a crucial role in achieving the state investor's ambitious climate goals.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines should disclose impact of sustainable fuel adoption

site_title: Tesla sues Australia’s Cap-XX over EV battery technology
summary: Tesla sued Australian company Cap-XX in Texas federal court, claiming its supercapacitors used in EV batteries infringe two US patents owned by Tesla subsidiary Maxwell Technologies. The lawsuit comes in response to a 2019 lawsuit filed by Cap-XX against Maxwell for patent infringement. Tesla says Maxwell's electrodes used in supercapacitors work in the same way as Cap-XX's technology, seeking unspecified damages. This marks a departure from Elon Musk's 2014 pledge not to initiate patent lawsuits against those using Tesla technology in good faith.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of car manufacturer Tesla is seen at a branch office in Bern, Switzerland October 28, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: US chip lobby presses Biden to refrain from further China curbs
summary: The US Semiconductor Industry Association has urged the Biden administration to refrain from further restrictions on chip sales to China, citing potential disruptions to supply chains and increased market uncertainty. Industry executives, including those from Intel and Qualcomm, plan to meet with government officials to discuss their views on China policy. The association also expressed concerns about China's recent restrictions on exports of raw materials used in chip production, warning of escalated retaliation.

site_title: Oil dips over 1.5% on demand fears after weak Chinese data
summary: Oil prices dropped over 1.5% on Monday after weaker-than-expected Chinese economic growth raised concerns over global demand. China's GDP grew 6.3% year-on-year in the second quarter, below analyst forecasts. Oil prices also fell due to the resumption of Libyan output and potential supply cuts from Russia and Saudi Arabia. US shale oil production is set to decline in August, adding to downward pressure on prices.

images.alt_text: On the supply side, output is climbing from the US to Brazil and Guyana. Even within Opec+, members such as Iran and Venezuela, exempted from making production cuts, are ramping up oil sales

site_title: US: Stocks rise, extending market rally
summary: US stocks rose Monday, extending a market rally ahead of major earnings reports and economic releases this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.4% and 0.9%, respectively. Shares of Tesla jumped 3.2% after announcing the production of its first Cybertruck, while Ford shares dropped 5.9% due to steep price cuts on its electric trucks. This week's calendar includes results from Bank of America, Tesla, and Netflix, which may influence market momentum.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 9.29 points, or 0.03 per cent, at the open to 34,499.74.

site_title: Harrods to open first private China club catering to ultra-rich
summary: Harrods is opening its first private members club in Shanghai, called The Residence, catering to ultra-rich Chinese customers. The club will offer exclusive services, including a British celebrity chef's restaurant, access to rare whisky, and global concierge services. Annual fees will start at 150,000 yuan (S$27,647), and the club will accept 250 members. The move aims to tap into China's growing luxury market, where Chinese consumers are increasingly shopping domestically amid economic uncertainty. The club's opening marks Harrods' bid to maintain its relationship with China's influential luxury market.

images.alt_text: Cha House in Shanghai. source: Harrods

site_title: Change of momentum in China-US relationship? Don’t bet on it
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration appears to be attempting to reduce tensions with China through high-level bilateral dialogue. Recent visits by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Special Presidential Envoy for Climate John Kerry suggest a softer tone in Sino-US relations. However, existing structural problems, including disagreements over Taiwan and trade restrictions, remain unresolved, and may create excessive expectations. The US's efforts to contain China through economic restrictions and military agreements are likely to be seen as counterproductive by Beijing, and may ultimately hinder the administration's goal of stabilizing the relationship.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's recent visit to China is evidence of efforts to restart dialogue with the US, but it remains to be seen if this will mean anything for businesses.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken met Wang Yi last month on the first visit to China by a US secretary of state in five years.

site_title: CPIB Iswaran probe: Ong Beng Seng back in S’pore after being allowed to travel to Bali while on bail
summary: Tycoon Ong Beng Seng returned to Singapore from Bali on a private jet after being allowed to travel overseas while on bail in a corruption probe. He was released on bail and had his passport impounded. Ong, 77, is the founder and managing director of Hotel Properties Limited, which has stated that no charges have been filed against him. Transport Minister S Iswaran, who was also arrested, is taking a leave of absence until the investigation is completed.

images.alt_text: Presidential hopeful and former senior minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam made the comments while speaking to reporters during his campaign trail in Teck Whye.
From left to right: Minister for Transport S Iswaran; Formula One Group chief executive Stefano Domenicali; and HPL co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng.
The hotel and property tycoon is also known for being one of those responsible for first bringing the Formula 1 night race to Singapore in 2008.
DPM Lawrence Wong says that he and PM Lee Hsien Loong are “fully committed” to keeping and preserving the trust that the people have in the government.
Iswaran will take a leave of absence until the investigations are complete.

site_title: US securities regulator ‘disappointed’ with defeat over Ripple’s XRP
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) expressed disappointment with a judge's ruling that Ripple Labs did not violate federal securities laws in a case involving the sale of its XRP tokens. SEC Chair Gary Gensler stated that the agency was still assessing the decision but welcomed a portion of the ruling that held Ripple should not have sold XRP directly to sophisticated investors. Gensler also emphasized the agency's ongoing efforts to develop climate disclosures and AI regulations.

images.alt_text: Customers Bank, ranked the 81st-largest US bank by assets, is now at the forefront of crypto industry that battered by blowups, scrutinised by regulators and shunned by mainstream lenders.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as Richemont, China data drag
summary: European shares declined 0.6% on Monday, led by luxury firms like Richemont and LVMH, due to weaker-than-expected organic sales growth and concerns about demand from China's economy. China's second-quarter growth slowed, raising pressure on policymakers to deliver more stimulus. The mining sector also declined, down 2.1%, as concerns about demand from top consumer China weighed on metal prices.

images.alt_text: The index has gained nearly 3 per cent this week, marking its best week since the end of March, recouping almost all of last week’s losses.

site_title: Will China ever get rich? A new era of much slower growth dawns
summary: China's annual economic growth is expected to slow to 3-4% annually, marking an era of much slower growth. This slower growth may lead to the country never becoming as rich as the US, disappointing its leaders and young population. Policymakers had hoped to narrow the development gap with the US, but current trends suggest it may not happen. The country's reliance on commodities exports to Africa and Latin America also relies on continued growth, which may not materialize. China's economic slowdown poses significant challenges for its economy and global influence.

images.alt_text: A worker sweeps a street in the Central Business District on a rainy day in Beijing, China, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: Greece to begin selling bank stakes this autumn: sources
summary: Greece will begin selling stakes in its four largest banks this autumn, marking the country's recovery from its financial meltdown in the previous decade. The Hellenic Financial Stability Fund will sell its 1.4% stake in Eurobank, followed by the remaining stakes in National Bank of Greece, Piraeus Bank, and Alpha Bank. The funds were injected to recapitalize the lenders during the crisis, with a total of about 50 billion euros (S$74.3 billion) invested. This move is seen as a key step towards Greece's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Greece’s debt ratio still remains the highest of any in the euro region, while the nation has a way to go to make up for the lost era of its debt crisis.

site_title: Protecting company directors and officers against litigation risks
summary: Singapore presents a relatively benign legal environment for directors, with limited claims against them. However, companies can face significant risks, particularly when expanding internationally or undergoing financial difficulties. Directors may be exposed to wider legal environments, stronger employee rights, and more favourable laws for third parties. To mitigate these risks, directors can understand their company's risk profile, review their articles of association and employment contracts, and consider directors and officers (D&O) insurance. Protecting their balance sheet and personal assets is crucial to minimize potential costs and fines.

images.alt_text: Hyflux independent director Lee Joo Hai has been further charged under the Securities and Futures Act.
Companies should ensure they have a robust and effective governance structure and compliance system, as well as clear guidelines when making statements open for public scrutiny.

site_title: TA Corp unit unable to pay debts; appoints provisional liquidators
summary: TA Corp's subsidiary, Tiong Aik Construction, has been placed under provisional liquidation due to its inability to pay debts. The company cited acute cash flow difficulties, including slow property sales and increasing borrowing costs, as reasons for its financial struggles. Provisional liquidators have been appointed, and TA Corporation has suspended trading of its shares to engage with stakeholders and address its financial position. The group's board plans to review its financial situation and seek advice from financial and legal experts.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based Zilingo provides digital services for e-commerce merchants.

site_title: UK relaxes visa rules to attract foreign construction workers
summary: Britain has relaxed visa rules for foreign construction workers to address acute labour shortages in the industry. The government has added 8 roles, including bricklayers, carpenters, and roofers, to its "shortage occupation list". This change allows these workers to obtain cheaper visas and more relaxed employment criteria, making it easier for employers to recruit staff from abroad. The move aims to alleviate labour shortages in key sectors, particularly in the construction industry.

images.alt_text: Striking teachers march during joint strike action by train drivers, teachers, university staff and civil servants, in Leeds, UK, on Wednesday, Feb. 1, 2023. The day of coordinated industrial action is expected to be Britain’s most severe day of strikes for over a decade, piling pressure on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Conservative administration to resolve disputes with public sector workers by making more generous offers on pay. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai alliance reaffirms backing for Pita's second PM bid
summary: Thai Prime Ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat, leader of the Move Forward Party, has reaffirmed backing from an eight-party coalition to become Thailand's prime minister despite his initial defeat in a parliamentary vote. Pita, who secured 324 votes, will face another vote on Wednesday, and said his candidacy cannot be blocked by the Senate. If he fails again, he will step aside and let the Pheu Thai party, his ally, take action, potentially paving the way for a Pheu Thai leader.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Move Forward Party supporters and pro-democracy activists gather to protest the day after Move Forward Party Leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat failed to secure the parliamentary vote for the premiership in Bangkok on July 14, 2023. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Pita Limjaroenrat cannot be nominated again, according to some of senators in military-appointed Senate.
In Parliament on Thursday, he defended himself again, telling lawmakers: “I am fully qualified” despite attempts to suspend him over allegations he broke campaign rules.

site_title: Danone reviews legal options after Russia seizes local business
summary: Danone, a French dairy group, is reviewing its legal options after Russia seized its local business. The Russian state took control of Danone Russia under a decree signed by President Vladimir Putin, citing foreign ownership stakes. Danone had been near to an agreement to sell its Russian subsidiary, but news of the decree broke, surprising the company. The company will write to the Kremlin and is in contact with French authorities, including President Emmanuel Macron's office, but is finding it challenging to exercise its rights in the country.

images.alt_text: Carlsberg called the decision “unexpected” and indicated it’s assessing legal and operational consequences as well as any financial impact.
French food group Danone, which makes Activia yoghurt, Aptamil infant formula and Evian water, has largely relied on Europe for raw materials.
Danone has increased prices to cope with surging costs but faces a challenge when it comes to the extent of price hikes before even affluent shoppers decide enough is enough.

site_title: Agri commodities risk long-term supply, price pressures amid climate change, food insecurity
summary: Climate change poses significant risks to agri commodities such as soybeans, corn, rice, and wheat, leading to potential supply and price volatility. Rising temperatures, droughts, and extreme weather events could impact crop yields, while increasing greenhouse gas emissions require suppliers to adopt more sustainable practices. Global food security is threatened, with analysts predicting "considerable challenges" for agriculture through 2050. The industry must shift to more sustainable practices to mitigate the impact of climate change, or face increased food insecurity and protectionist measures.

images.alt_text: PepsiCo’s results show resilience even as consumers pull back amid high levels of inflation.
Purchases of chocolate confectioneries are expected to climb 5.8 per cent this year to reach almost US$26 billion.
This comes in light of an anticipated improvement of crude palm oil prices in 2024 as a result of reduced CPO volumes due to El Niño.

site_title: Being inquisitive will help steer bankers in the most exciting age of mankind: Citi’s Jan Metzger
summary: Jan Metzger, Citi's Asia-Pacific head of banking, capital markets and advisory, emphasizes the importance of intellectual curiosity for bankers in an ever-changing finance industry. Having a real understanding of businesses and technology allows bankers to connect with clients more effectively. Metzger, who has a background in computer science and economics, notes that technology trends often emerge in Asia 8-12 years before they occur in the West. He sees the current era as the most exciting age of mankind, with new companies and business models forming at a rapid pace, and predicts that sustainability and technology adoption will drive revenue and cost reduction for businesses.

images.alt_text: Industry watchers noted that demand for investment bankers continues to remain strong, amid a tight talent market.
Citi’s markets revenue falls 13 per cent to US$4.6 billion on more subdued activity in fixed income and equities.
Kelvin Tan, head of sustainable finance and investments for Asean at HSBC, believes environmental, social and governance issues are unlikely to go away anytime soon.

Chew Mun Yew, UOB's managing director and head of private wealth, said: “Experience, especially if you make mistakes, really forces your instinct… There are some challenges in business and in management that you cannot simply think your way out of.”

site_title: Why it’s dangerous to assume banks are profiteering
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt criticized banks for profiteering, saying they haven't passed on interest rate hikes to savers. However, a report found that banks' net interest margins are at the long-term average, and thin margins lead to lower profits, making them less attractive to investors. Despite this, regulators have deemed the banking system solid, with robust capital, and banks' valuations are lower than those of US peers. The author argues that a minimally profitable banking system, especially with low valuations, may not be robust in times of crisis.

images.alt_text: Despite the rise in mortgage rates, Andrew Bailey said that for now both borrowers and lenders are in better condition to shoulder difficulty than they were in previous rate cycles.
The test checks if banks were holding enough capital to cope with theoretical shocks under a scenario which BoE said was more severe than the global financial crisis of 2008.

site_title: Virgin Galactic's next spaceflight to include sweepstakes winners
summary: Virgin Galactic's next spaceflight, Galactic 02, is set for August 10 from Spaceport America, New Mexico. The mission will include a mother-daughter duo, Keisha Schahaff and Anastatia Mayers, who won their tickets in a sweepstakes contest, and 80-year-old adventurer Jon Goodwin, a former Olympic athlete with Parkinson's disease. This marks a milestone for the company, which flew its first paying customers, members of the Italian Air Force, last month. Virgin Galactic competes with Blue Origin in the suborbital space tourism sector, with Galactic 02 being its 11th commercial flight.

images.alt_text: Virgin Galactic uses a piloted “mothership” aircraft that takes off from a runway, gains high altitude, and drops a rocket-powered plane that soars into space at nearly Mach 3 before gliding back to Earth.

site_title: EU may update climate pledge to show faster progress on CO2 goals
summary: The 27-country EU is considering updating its climate pledge to show faster progress on reducing CO2 emissions, aiming for a 57% cut by 2030, exceeding its current goal of a 55% reduction. This move is expected ahead of the COP28 summit.

images.alt_text: EU and UAE will work to “ensure maximum support on global 2030 targets for the tripling of renewable energy and doubling of energy efficiency,” a statement says.

site_title: Weary Thailand Inc awaits a functional government
summary: Thailand's Move Forward Party leader Pita Limjaroenrat failed to secure a majority in the parliamentary vote for the premiership, sparking protests in Bangkok. Despite winning 324 out of 749 votes, he fell short of the 375 needed. Pita will try again at the second vote on July 19, but analysts doubt the outcome will improve. The setback dashes hopes of swift political stability in Thailand, leaving the country's "Weary Thailand Inc" awaiting a functional government.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s benchmark SET Index had slid about 11 per cent this year, making it Asia’s worst performing market and near the bottom globally, as foreigners pulled some US$3.3 billion from domestic equities.

Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat (C) waves as he arrives to address a press conference with potential coalition partners in Bangkok on May 18, 2023, after his party secured the most seats in Thailand's general election. (Photo by Manan VATSYAYANA / AFP)
The government has prepared some 120 billion baht to shore up South-east Asia’s second-largest economy and will speed up investment and other spending.
Thailand has long been a popular destination for foreign tourists, receiving nearly 40 million visitors in pre-pandemic 2019.

site_title: Princess Diana’s ‘black sheep’ jumper to be auctioned
summary: Princess Diana's iconic black sheep sweater, designed by Warm & Wonderful, is set to be auctioned at Sotheby's Fashion Icons sale on Aug 31-Sep 14. The jumper, worn by Diana to a polo game in 1981, was rediscovered in an attic by the brand's founder and is expected to fetch a price of up to $80,000. The sweater holds sentimental value, with Diana requesting a replacement after it was damaged, and later wearing the new one two years later. The jumper is being sold with Oliver Everett's letters to the brand's co-founder.

site_title: Kitchen Culture receives letter of demand, asked to repay S$1.5 million loan due to event of default
summary: Kitchen Culture, a Singapore-based kitchen solutions provider, received a letter of demand from private investor Tan Gin Tat, demanding repayment of S$1.5 million due to an event of default related to the change in its board of directors. Tan lent S$1 million and S$500,000 to the company under two separate loan agreements in August and December 2022. The company must repay the loan within 30 days or face legal proceedings. Kitchen Culture will seek legal advice in response to the demand.

images.alt_text: Kitchen Culture said the redesignation is due to the need for the chairperson of the board to lead the company forward following the recent changes made to the board announced on Jun 26.
Kitchen Culture has also secured a S$4 million loan to pay its debts and for general working capital.
Kitchen Culture receives letter of demand from CDL unit for S$250,970 in unpaid rent

site_title: BridgeBio's heart disease drug meets late-stage study goal
summary: BridgeBio's experimental heart disease drug, acoramidis, met its late-stage study goal, showing a 1.8 times better effect than placebo in preventing death, hospitalization, and improvement in six minutes' walking distance. The drug improved survival by 81% in patients, reduced heart disease-related hospitalization by 50%, and had no safety concerns. BridgeBio plans to submit the data to the US FDA by the end of 2023 and expects to file in additional markets next year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at the new cell and gene therapy factory of Swiss drugmaker Novartis in Stein, Switzerland, November 28, 2019. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Global temperatures near record highs as US, China meet on climate
summary: Global temperatures reached historic highs, with China's Sanbao town recording a national record of 52.2°C (126°F), as the US and China met to discuss climate change. Scientists warn that the 1.5°C target to limit global warming is moving beyond reach. Wildfires in Europe raged ahead of a second heat wave, while nearly a quarter of the US population was under extreme heat advisories. The World Health Organization described the crisis as "not a warning, it's happening," urging world leaders to act.

images.alt_text: The United Nations Development Programme says in a 2020 report that “beekeeping has existed in Iraq... for an estimated 8,000 years”, with “recipes that use honey for medicinal purposes” inscribed on ancient Sumerian tablets.
The two competitive grant programmes with US$20 billion in funding are the latest move by Biden administration to support projects that reduce planet warming emissions.
China had a record number of days when the average temperature was 35C or above in the first half, highlighting the increasing pressure that global warming is putting on the grid.
A 30 MW coal-fired power plant in Taixing city, Jiangsu, China. Beijing has approved a major surge in coal power so far this year.

site_title: China Everbright Water issues 1.5 billion yuan worth of five-year notes at 2.97% interest
summary: China Everbright Water issued 1.5 billion yuan (S$276.8 million) worth of five-year notes at a 2.97% interest rate, fully subscribed by institutional investors in mainland China's national interbank bond market. The proceeds will be used to replenish working capital and repay interest-bearing debts. The notes have a subscription rate of 2.25 times and offer an interest rate adjustment option and resale option.

images.alt_text: The subsidiary of environmental services company China Everbright Water has secured the fourth phase of a waste water treatment project in Jiangyin City, Jiangsu province.

China Everbright's waste water treatment project in Qingdao. A consortium led by China Everbright secured a project that involves the design, procurement, construction and operation of the Jiangsu Huai’an Lianshui Konggang Industrial Park’s industrial waste water treatment plant.

site_title: TomTom lifts 2023 forecasts after new maps help beat Q2 expectations
summary: TomTom raised its full-year revenue and free cash flow forecasts after the successful rollout of its new maps, which offered wider geographical coverage and faster updates. The company's shares jumped 11.2% to a three-month high. Revenue at its automotive unit grew 52% to 91 million euros, contributing to the group's revenue of 157 million euros. TomTom now targets revenue of 570-600 million euros this year and free cash flow of 5% of revenue.

images.alt_text: TomTom, which counts Volkswagen, Renault and Microsoft among its clients, had been hit by soaring inflation and the global chip shortage that disrupted the automotive and electronics industries.

site_title: Penguin privatisation offer extended for the third time, to Aug 3
summary: The closing date for Penguin International's privatization offer has been extended for the third time to August 3, at 5:30 pm. The offer, priced at S$0.83 a share, has garnered 88.57% of the total shares, with the offeror and its associates controlling the majority. This is the consortium's second attempt to take the company private, following an unsuccessful bid in 2021.

site_title: Microsoft and Activision watch hurdles to US$69 billion deal fall
summary: Microsoft and Activision are nearing completion of a $69 billion deal after securing a deal with Sony to keep the popular Call of Duty franchise on the PlayStation platform for a decade. A US court denied an FTC request to halt the acquisition, and the UK's Competition and Markets Authority has given Microsoft a second chance to offer a remedy. The companies are working to address concerns about the merger's impact on rivals.

site_title: Why China’s reopening isn’t providing enough jobs for its young
summary: China's youth unemployment rate has hit new highs, with 21.3% of 16-24-year-olds out of work, four times the national level. The rate is expected to worsen as 12 million college graduates enter the job market this year. The problem is attributed to a combination of cyclical and structural factors, including the slowdown in the economy and a mismatch between jobseekers' skills and businesses' requirements. The government is trying to address the issue by encouraging hiring, boosting vocational education, and providing subsidies to businesses. However, job creation will depend on stronger economic growth, which is still uncertain due to global slowdown and rising tensions.

images.alt_text: The jobless rate for people aged between 16 and 24 in China has been above 20 per cent for three consecutive months.

site_title: US dollar hovers around 15-month low ahead of Fed, ECB meetings
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.07% to 99.891 on Monday, hovering near a 15-month low ahead of the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank meetings. The euro rose 0.1% to a fresh 16-month high, while the yen reached a two-month low against the US dollar. Investors are waiting for economic data and policy decisions before selling the US dollar further, with some analysts predicting a correction in the euro/US dollar exchange rate. The US dollar index had its biggest weekly decline since November 2022 last week, driven by US inflation data showing a disinflation shock.

site_title: Crypto’s new favourite bank is reluctant to accept the title
summary: Customers Bancorp, a US bank ranked 81st by assets, has emerged as a key partner for the crypto industry, despite its reluctance to accept the title. The bank partners with hundreds of digital-asset firms and has attracted new clients after the collapse of Silvergate Capital and Signature Bank. Customers has limited deposits on its crypto-related platform to 15% and has no loans to crypto clients. The bank's crypto business is a small part of its broader payments business, and its CEO has downplayed its connections to the industry.

images.alt_text: The FSB publishes final recommendations requested by the G20 on supervising firms that trade cryptoassets such as bitcoin.
Figuring out what does or doesn’t make a coin a security is a complicated question.
The layoffs at the world’s biggest crypto exchange come at a time when the industry’s future in the US market is uncertain.
Bitcoin has traded at its highest price since June 2022 overnight, touching US$31,818 on the Bitstamp exchange.

site_title: Violet Oon’s business partner takes stand, says family knew control would be diluted
summary: Business partner Manoj Murjani testifies in the Supreme Court that Violet Oon's family had agreed to terms limiting their control over Violet Oon Inc. He claims Tay Yiming verbally agreed to convert loans to shareholder equity, increasing his stake to 60% and the Oon family's to 40%. However, his lawyer argues that there is no evidence of explicit agreement, and the Oon family seeks a court order to purchase outstanding shares or have the company wound up.

images.alt_text: Violet Oon (seated) with her son Tay Yiming (left), business partner Manoj Murjani (middle) and daughter Tay Su-Lyn.

Violet Oon (seated) and her children (from left) Tay Yiming and Tay Su-Lyn. Tay Yiming alleged that business partner Manoj Murjani had verbally agreed when signing a 2014 shareholding agreement to match the family dollar for dollar whenever Violet Oon Singapore required more money.

(From left) Tay Yiming, Tay Su-lyn, Violet Oon and Manoj Murjani. Tay Su-Lyn was the second witness in a civil case she, her mother and her brother Tay Yiming brought against Murjani, alleging oppression.
Chef Violet Oon was cross-examined by her business partner Manoj Murjani’s lawyer on Tuesday, with Justice Philip Jeyaretnam presiding over the trial.

veviolet25 - Violet Oon Singapore outlet at Jewel Changi Airport. 

Credit: Violet Oon Singapore

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's EV population reached its highest level yet, but still accounts for only 1.3% of passenger cars. Industry analysts urge the government to extend or improve EV incentives to meet clean-transport goals. Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin and MP Cheng Li Hui resigned due to an "inappropriate relationship". Singapore's exports fell 15.5% in June, marking the ninth straight month of decline. Private home sales slumped in June, but are expected to rise in July. Former JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong was sentenced to 19 years in prison for cheating and breach of trust.

site_title: India planning $1.5 bln industrial water transport corridor in east: sources
summary: India is planning a $1.9 billion industrial water transport corridor in the east, connecting two ports in Odisha via the Brahmi River. The corridor, expected to carry 12-15 million tonnes of cargo by 2030, aims to decongest rail and road infrastructure, particularly in regions dotted with mines and industrial plants. The project will primarily transport finished products such as steel, aluminum, sponge iron, and fertilizers, reducing transportation costs via waterways to two-thirds of railways and half of road transportation costs.

images.alt_text: CVDs are additional taxes imposed on imported goods or products that are subsidised in their home country thus hurting the industries in the country importing them.

site_title: Vietnam central bank goes slow on rate-cut calls amid risks
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV), is going slow on rate cuts despite calls from Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh for an easier policy. The bank has reduced rates four times since the start of 2023 due to concerns over currency weakness and low deposit rates. Analysts attribute the cautious approach to the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and limited options for the central bank. The SBV may consider alternative measures, such as asking banks to cut operational costs, to address economic challenges, including a downturn in global demand and domestic growth.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) “adjusted the credit growth target to provide more capital to meet the needs of the economy in a timely manner, but at the same time remained cautious about inflation risks,” it says.

site_title: AI can write, but is it any good at picking stocks?
summary: AI has shown promise in deciphering market implications of "Fedspeak" and corporate news, rivaling human experts' abilities in some studies. Generative AI, like ChatGPT, can analyze financial data, while predictive AI uses math-trained analysts to find trading strategies. However, creating an AI that can accurately predict stock prices remains a significant challenge, as it requires more than just data analysis. Researchers continue to explore ways to improve AI's predictive capabilities in finance, but the holy grail of AI in investing remains elusive.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT reached 100 million users in less than two months, 15 times faster than Instagram, which took 30 months.

site_title: Workers’ Party looking into video that suggests ‘inappropriate exchange’ between Leon Perera and Nicole Seah
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) is investigating a video showing MP Leon Perera sharing an intimate moment with fellow senior party member Nicole Seah, who is also married. The 15-second clip, which has circulated online, appears to show Perera stroking Seah's hand while they had a glass of wine together. The party has stated that it is looking into the matter and expects all members to fully own and account for their behavior. Both Perera and Seah are married and on the party's Central Executive Committee.

images.alt_text: Cheng was the only female MP serving in Tampines GRC.
Clockwise from top left: Tan Chuan-Jin, Cheng Li Hui, David Ong, Yaw Shin Leong and Michael Palmer.
PM Lee says the resignations of Tan (left) and Cheng (right) are necessary to “maintain the high standards of propriety and personal conduct which the PAP has upheld all these years”.

site_title: WHO concerned at rise in Poland bird flu cases in cats
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is concerned about a rise in bird flu cases in cats in Poland, where 29 cats have tested positive for H5N1 bird flu since June. The infected cats showed severe symptoms, including difficulty breathing and neurological signs, and 14 were euthanized. The source of the exposure is currently unknown, and epizootic investigations are ongoing. The WHO notes that the risk of human infection remains low, but cat owners and veterinarians may be at risk if they are not using personal protective equipment.

images.alt_text: Throughout the carbonated-beverage business, from Diet Coke and Coke Zero Sugar, to Diet Pepsi and Diet Dr Pepper, aspartame is used to provide calorie-free sweetness.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq start week higher as investors await more results
summary: US stocks began the week higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising, while the Dow Jones fell 9.29 points, or 0.03%, to 34,499.74. Investors awaited quarterly results from major companies, showing cautious optimism ahead of industry reports. The S&P 500 opened 3.44 points higher, or 0.08%, at 4,508.86, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 36.21 points, or 0.26%, to 14,149.92.

site_title: German economy may contract slightly in 2023: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has predicted that Germany's economy may contract slightly in 2023 due to accelerating headwinds from population aging and a lack of productivity growth. Despite this, the economy is expected to regain momentum gradually in 2024 and 2025. Average GDP growth is expected to fall below 1% over the medium term, with inflation expected to keep falling amid softening energy prices and tightening fiscal policy. Uncertainty is high, with risks tilted downward for growth, particularly around core inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk through the Mall of Berlin shopping centre during its opening night in Berlin, Germany, September 24, 2014. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: China’s top chipmaker loses chairman in latest executive exit
summary: China's top chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), has lost its chairman, Gao Yonggang, who resigned due to a "job adjustment" about a year after taking the role. Gao's departure follows a series of high-profile exits at the company, which has been impacted by US chip sanctions. Liu Xunfeng, a 58-year-old chemist-turned-executive, will succeed Gao as chairman. SMIC, a national champion in China, is developing local alternatives to combat US technology export curbs and has achieved breakthroughs in making chips using 7-nanometre nodes.

site_title: Thomson Medical issues S$30 million worth of notes at 5.5% interest
summary: Thomson Medical Group issued S$30 million worth of notes at 5.5% interest, maturing in 2028. The notes will be consolidated with existing S$120 million notes, part of the group's S$1 billion multi-currency debt-issuance programme. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing borrowings and financing strategic expansions. UOB has been appointed as the sole dealer for the issue, which is expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on July 21.

site_title: Barclays picks industrials banker Grabos to co-lead Americas M&A
summary: Barclays has promoted senior industrials banker Dan Grabos as co-head of its mergers and acquisitions (M&A) group in the Americas, alongside incumbent head Larry Hamdan. Grabos will continue to lead industrials M&A, and Jonathan Gerst, a managing director, will also join him as co-head. The move is part of the bank's efforts to improve its market share and comes after a reshuffling of top leaders in its investment bank. Barclays has hired over 20 bankers this year, focusing on growth and improving its share of the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian walks past a Barclays Bank branch, in central London August 3, 2009.   REUTERS/Stefan Wermuth/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Fisker to sell limited edition electric SUVs in India by Q4
summary: Fisker plans to sell limited edition electric SUVs in India by Q4, with the Fisker Ocean Extreme Vigyan expected to complete final checks by the end of September. Pricing will align with the European market, with the vehicle costing around 6.5 million Indian rupees. The company had initially planned to begin selling its Ocean electric SUVs in India by July 2023, but has revised its timeline. Fisker will produce 100 limited edition SUVs for the Indian market.

images.alt_text: Fisker Ocean Extreme.

site_title: Credit Suisse announces management changes
summary: Credit Suisse announced management changes, including Daniel Hunziker taking over corporate clients business and Andreas Gerber leaving the bank after 34 years. Hunziker will also head institutional clients. The moves come after UBS's takeover of Credit Suisse. Gerber will take a break from banking.

site_title: Debt restructuring talks at G20 meet hurt by differences, low attendance
summary: Finance ministers from 13 G20 countries attended a two-day meeting in India, failing to make significant progress on debt restructuring for vulnerable nations, global minimum taxation, and reforms on multilateral development banks. The talks were hindered by key differences and low attendance due to domestic issues, with some countries skipping the event altogether. The US led the largest delegation, but nations remained unwilling to discuss fresh lending to vulnerable countries, despite the success of Zambia's debt restructuring deal last month. The meeting's slow progress may impact the G20 leaders' summit in September.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers work near the venue of G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting at Gandhinagar in Gujarat, India July 13, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave

site_title: Thai PM hopeful Pita can’t be nominated twice, senator says
summary: Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat, who fell short in his bid to become prime minister, cannot be nominated again for the top job, according to some senators. A parliament regulation bars a motion that fails from being raised again in the same session, citing obstacles to Pita's re-vote on Wednesday. Despite this, Pita is willing to step aside and let his coalition partner Pheu Thai Party take the lead in government formation, and a constitutional court case may also disqualify him as a lawmaker.

images.alt_text: In Parliament on Thursday, he defended himself again, telling lawmakers: “I am fully qualified” despite attempts to suspend him over allegations he broke campaign rules.

Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat (C) waves as he arrives to address a press conference with potential coalition partners in Bangkok on May 18, 2023, after his party secured the most seats in Thailand's general election. (Photo by Manan VATSYAYANA / AFP)
A source from the election commission says it would  request Pita be suspended as a parliamentarian pending the court’s ruling.

site_title: Saudi Arabia’s Neom seeks 10 billion riyal loan to build futuristic city
summary: Saudi Arabia's Neom, a $500 billion megaproject spearheaded by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, is seeking a 10 billion riyal (S$3.5 billion) loan to fund its early stages. The project aims to diversify the country's oil-dependent economy and serve as a test bed for technologies to revolutionize daily life. Neom has also planned to raise up to 3 billion riyals from local banks to develop Shushah Island, a luxury tourism development. The loan and investment deals are part of Neom's efforts to bring in investment and move forward with the project.

site_title: India, Indonesia plan local currency trade, payments links
summary: India and Indonesia are planning to settle bilateral transactions in local currencies and link their fast payments systems to spur cross-border fund transfers. The proposals were discussed by India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman and her Indonesian counterpart Sri Mulyani Indrawati ahead of G20 meetings in India. This move aims to reduce India's reliance on the US dollar and internationalize the rupee. Similar agreements have been inked with the UAE, and India has already linked its fast payments system with Singapore and is in talks with Japan and France.

site_title: Kremlin says Black Sea grain deal has 'de facto ended'
summary: The Kremlin announced that the Ukraine grain deal has "de facto ended" just hours before its expiration, citing unfulfilled Russian conditions. The landmark agreement, brokered by the UN and Turkey, allows Ukraine to export grain via the Black Sea. Moscow will return to the deal if its conditions are met, amid weeks of threats to leave the agreement. The deal officially expired at the end of Monday, but the Kremlin's statement implies it has effectively ended.

images.alt_text: The conflict between Russia and Ukraine – both major grain exporters – triggered fears of a global food crisis when major Ukrainian ports were blocked by Moscow’s warships.
Carlsberg called the decision “unexpected” and indicated it’s assessing legal and operational consequences as well as any financial impact.

site_title: BT Explains: Who is ex-PAP MP Cheng Li Hui, and why did she resign?
summary: Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin and MP Cheng Li Hui of the People's Action Party (PAP) have resigned due to an "inappropriate relationship" between the two. The relationship was discovered by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong after the last general election in 2020, and an investigation was launched. Tan admitted his wrongdoing and offered his resignation, which was accepted by PM Lee. Cheng, who was the only female MP in Tampines GRC, apologized for her resignation and will step down from her position.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from top left: Tan Chuan-Jin, Cheng Li Hui, David Ong, Yaw Shin Leong and Michael Palmer.
PM Lee says the resignations of Tan (left) and Cheng (right) are necessary to “maintain the high standards of propriety and personal conduct which the PAP has upheld all these years”.

site_title: Multi-asset income funds in a world of high interest rates
summary: Multi-asset income funds, popular among Asian investors, are adapting to the return of higher interest rates. While they can offer attractive yields, investors must weigh the trade-offs between growth and defensive assets. The funds' distribution yields have increased, but they also come with higher levels of risk. To achieve consistent income and capital growth, investors should be selective and choose funds that match their objectives and risk tolerance, and managers who are prudent in their payouts.

images.alt_text: Bond funds as safe haven for 4% return? Morningstar study flags hidden risks

site_title: UBS is sole successor to Credit Suisse’s CDS, swaps panel rules
summary: UBS Group has been designated as the sole successor to Credit Suisse's credit default swaps (CDS) and swaps panel, according to a ruling by the Credit Derivatives Determinations Committees. This decision comes after UBS took over Credit Suisse's debt obligations in April. The ruling effectively ends speculation that Credit Suisse's CDS contracts could have triggered a payout, and prices of Credit Suisse and UBS contracts are expected to converge.

images.alt_text: The swaps this week had their biggest increase since UBS Group agreed to buy Credit Suisse in an emergency weekend deal in March.

site_title: Singapore politicians who stepped down over affairs
summary: Singaporean politicians Tan Chuan-Jin and Cheng Li Hui, both from the People's Action Party (PAP), have resigned due to an "inappropriate relationship" between the Speaker of Parliament and an MP. This is the latest in a series of resignations, following similar cases involving Michael Palmer and Yaw Shin Leong. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced no immediate general election plans, citing the government's term has just entered its second half. The PAP has faced scrutiny over its handling of similar cases in the past.

images.alt_text: Cheng was the only female MP serving in Tampines GRC.
PM Lee says the resignations of Tan (left) and Cheng (right) are necessary to “maintain the high standards of propriety and personal conduct which the PAP has upheld all these years”.
Former WP MP Yaw Shin Leong disputes Pritam Singh's account of his sacking

Economic pessimism could be a reason for Singapore’s low total fertility rate (TFR), he said, adding that studies have shown a causal link in Singapore between high home prices and low TFR, which fell to a record low of 1.05 last year.

site_title: JPMorgan cuts China's 2023 growth forecast after sluggish Q2 GDP growth
summary: JPMorgan has lowered its forecast for China's 2023 economic growth to 5% from 5.5%, citing slower-than-expected Q2 GDP growth. The country's economy grew 6.3% year-on-year in the second quarter, below expectations of 7.3%. The downgrade reflects a loss of post-Covid momentum and demand weakening domestically and internationally. JPMorgan economists expect the government to step up policy easing measures, including a potential 10-basis-point policy rate cut and nationwide housing policy easing, to boost economic growth and address unemployment.

site_title: SIA Group flies 2.9 million passengers in June; passenger load factor at monthly record
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) carried 2.9 million passengers in June, a 50.4% increase from the previous year, with a record monthly passenger load factor of 90.6%. SIA and its subsidiary Scoot also posted record passenger load factors of 89.7% and 93.6%, respectively, marking significant growth and high demand for air travel.

images.alt_text: Unlike other carbon-intensive sectors, which may have various avenues to decarbonise, the only way SIA is able to reduce its carbon emissions is by switching its fuel, which are currently fossil fuel-based, to sustainable aviation fuel, said Dilhan Pillay, chief executive officer of Temasek.

site_title: Norway regulator to fine Meta over privacy breaches
summary: Norway's data protection authority, Datatilsynet, has fined Meta Platforms one million kroner (S$131,365) per day until Nov 3 over alleged privacy breaches. Meta is accused of harvesting user data in Norway, such as physical locations, to target advertising. The fine, which will be charged daily unless Meta takes remedial action, has wider European implications. The decision comes after the European Union's top court ruled against Meta's practice of harvesting user data for behavioral advertising, and a separate ruling in Ireland. Meta has stated it will review the decision.

images.alt_text: Meta has left the door open for a Threads launch in Europe and few expect it to maintain its embargo indefinitely.

site_title: Markets are propelled by what hasn’t happened
summary: Markets are being driven by what hasn't happened, including a recession, significant job losses, and financial instability, despite 10 consecutive interest-rate increases. The US labor market, inflation, and financial system have remained robust, and traders and investors have not been caught off guard by market volatility. The soft-landing narrative, which suggests a gradual decline in inflation and interest rates, has become more entrenched, potentially leading to broader and deeper rallies in stocks and government bonds. However, the outlook depends on several factors, including inflation, the Fed's confidence, and the economy's resilience.

images.alt_text: Unlike in the 1980s, the US Federal Reserve's recent rate hikes have failed to produce a recession. Unemployment has not meaningfully risen.

After a 37 per cent surge in the Nasdaq 100 Index this year, some strategists have revised their stock-market targets just to account for the equity rally – even if they see modest gains, or declines, for the rest of the year.

site_title: Wanda warns of US$200 Million shortfall on bond, surprising market
summary: Dalian Wanda Commercial Management Group, a key unit of Chinese conglomerate Dalian Wanda Group, warned of a US$200 million shortfall on a US$400 million bond payment, due July 23. The firm is seeking alternative plans, with no grace period for principal repayment. This comes as China's economy shows signs of cooling, with property investment declines steepening in June. The Wanda unit's bond price plummeted 21 cents to 72 cents, joining fellow high-yield property firms in distressed territory, amidst a surge in delinquencies by Chinese issuers since 2022.

images.alt_text: Shares in Dalian Wanda Commercial Management Group will be frozen for three years from Jul 4, 2023, to Jul 3, 2026.

site_title: Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin, MP Cheng Li Hui resign due to ‘inappropriate relationship’
summary: Singaporean Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin and MP Cheng Li Hui have resigned due to an "inappropriate relationship". Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the resignations are necessary to maintain the PAP's high standards of propriety and personal conduct. The move comes after Tan apologized for using "unparliamentary language" in April and a "hot mic" incident. Political observers expect little impact on Singapore's international reputation, but acknowledge that the PAP must address transparency and accountability issues.

images.alt_text: Cheng was the only female MP serving in Tampines GRC.
Clockwise from top left: Tan Chuan-Jin, Cheng Li Hui, David Ong, Yaw Shin Leong and Michael Palmer.
In a statement, the WP said it is aware of a video clip circulating online today that suggests an inappropriate exchange between two senior Party members.
The GRC system was implemented in 1988 to enshrine minority representation in Parliament.
The public service will reference the Ridout Road case as an additional example to reinforce the importance for public officers to act with integrity.
COP report objective, attempts to politicise matter regrettable: Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin

site_title: ECB to bring rates to 4% peak in September, economists say
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates to 4% in September, according to economists, as inflation remains stubborn. This would be two more quarter-point hikes, surpassing the previously predicted maximum of 3.75%. Inflation projections for 2024 and 2025 have increased to 2.8% and 2.4%, respectively, exceeding the ECB's own projections. The bank is becoming more hawkish as it struggles to bring inflation under control, with some officials warning of a potential extension of rate hikes beyond the summer.

images.alt_text: Adjusted for seasonal swings, the May trade deficit is a modest 0.9 billion euros from 8.0 billion euros in April.
While a survey of analysts suggested the ECB will deliver exactly the right dose of tightening, the final stages of the cycle may yet be the toughest.
While the ECB has hiked interest rates rapidly to make up ground in its fight against resurgent inflation, it is having a harder time reversing years of massive asset purchases.
The ECB’s most recent forecasts put it at 2.2 per cent in 2025.

site_title: Keppel donates S$315,000 to Willing Hearts
summary: Keppel Corporation donated S$315,000 to Willing Hearts, a charity organization that provides 7,000 daily meals to 70 locations island-wide. The donation funded two electric trucks and two electric-vehicle charging points for the organization. Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua and other officials unveiled the new fleet and charging points, highlighting the company's commitment to sustainability and community service. This marks the second significant donation from Keppel, following a S$120,000 contribution in 2021.

images.alt_text: Step Up volunteers Rishi Hindocha (left) and Piya Sawhney (right) from law firm Allen & Overy with mentee Azahari Harrison, who is now a team manager at a global automobile company.

site_title: Singapore should maintain or improve EV incentives to meet clean-transport goals: analysts
summary: Singapore's electric vehicle (EV) population is at a record high of 8,390 cars, but EVs still make up only 1.3% of the total car population. Analysts say the government must maintain or improve EV incentives to meet its clean-transport goals, which include switching entirely to cleaner-energy vehicles by 2040. The current EV incentives, including rebates and penalties, are set to expire at the end of 2023, and some analysts expect them to be reduced or phased out, while others suggest the government should offer more incentives to drive sales.

images.alt_text: A CCS2 charging plug on an electric vehicle.
The Category A COE-friendly 100 kW version of the BYD Atto 3 arrived in May 2023 after the car was launched with 150 kW initially.

Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD and its Dolphin compact hatchback on display at Waterway Point. BYD's most compact car to date, the Dolphin is one of the cheapest EV on the Singapore market.

site_title: Chinese developer Zhongliang’s restructuring pact gets initial support of bondholders
summary: Chinese property developer Zhongliang Holdings has received initial support from 38.5% of its bondholders for its offshore debt restructuring proposal, worth US$930 million. The proposal, announced in June, aims to alleviate the company's pressure of offshore indebtedness and provide financial flexibility. To pass, the restructuring requires approval from more than 75% of creditor value. Zhongliang is offering a 1% upfront principal payment in cash and new senior notes and convertible bonds. The company is urging other creditors to sign the agreement by August 11 to receive a 0.25% incentive fee.

site_title: New Zealand election too close to call three months from vote
summary: New Zealand's general election remains too close to call three months before the vote, with Labour and National parties almost neck and neck in the latest opinion poll. Labour's support has declined for a third straight poll, while National's leader Christopher Luxon's support has narrowed the gap with Prime Minister Chris Hipkins. If the results were replicated at the election, National and ACT would likely command a slim majority, while Labour and the Greens would struggle to form a government.

site_title: Local shares begin the week slightly higher as traders focus on earnings season
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by gains from DBS, OCBC, and UOB, despite a decline in the ASX 200 and other regional indices. The Straits Times Index ended at 3,254.43, with DBS and OCBC being the top advancers by value. Meanwhile, Jardine Cycle and Carriage and Venture Corporation were the top decliners. Investors are keeping an eye on the upcoming earnings season in the US market, with some analysts predicting a "muted rally" due to potential economic slowdowns.

images.alt_text: If the soft-landing narrative becomes more entrenched in the market psyche, rallies would broaden and deepen.
A man looks at an electric monitor displaying a stock quotation board outside a bank in Tokyo, Japan, June 5, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Consider tax changes for shophouses as Singapore businesses face being priced out
summary: Singaporean businesses and locals face being priced out of shophouses due to high property prices. Top-of-the-range shophouses can command record-breaking prices of up to S$8,000 per square foot. This makes it difficult for locals to afford shophouses, particularly for those who want to use them for business operations. The government is urged to consider tax changes to make owning a shophouse more accessible to locals, including lower taxes and more equitable treatment of commercial shophouse investors. This could help raise revenue and combat inequality in the property market.

images.alt_text: The star attraction at  11 New Bridge Road is the Song Fa Bak Kut Teh outlet which occupies the ground floor.
The row of six shophouses are part of the Boat Quay Conservation Area

site_title: Indian tourists flock to South-east Asia as China’s reopening falters
summary: Indian tourists are increasingly flocking to South-east Asia as China's reopening falters. Despite being 14% lower than 2019 levels, India's tourism numbers remain strong, with Indians visiting Thailand and other countries in the region. This shift is driven by India's growing middle-class and spending power, as well as the ease of obtaining visas. As a result, airlines, hospitality chains, and tourism operators are adapting to the new market, with some predicting a long-term increase in Indian tourists, potentially rivaling China's outbound tourism growth over the next decade.

images.alt_text: Some banks in Hong Kong have extended the hours of certain branches to accommodate mainland customers, who tend to show up on weekends.

site_title: China warns youth unemployment to worsen after hitting record high
summary: China's youth unemployment rate has hit a record high of 21.3% in June, marking the third consecutive month above 20%. The National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) attributes the increase to young people finishing their studies and looking for jobs, with nearly 12 million students expected to graduate this year. The government warns that the situation may worsen as new graduates start searching for employment.

site_title: Macro hedge funds lead gains in Asia; Japan shines
summary: Macro hedge funds in Asia have outperformed other strategies this year, with average gains of 6.1% by June, compared to 1.1% for all Asian hedge funds. Japan-focused funds, which thrived on a domestic stocks rally, saw a 5.5% gain. Analysts expect policy and inflation divergence between Asia and Western economies to continue creating profitable opportunities for macro funds. This is attributed to a domestic stocks rally in Japan, with macro hedge funds trading on economic trends.

images.alt_text: In the first half of the year, hedge funds added 3.45 per cent to their investors.

site_title: Joint task force for Iskandar could boost shares of Malaysian developers: Maybank
summary: A joint task force between Singapore and Malaysia to develop a special economic zone (SEZ) in Iskandar Malaysia is expected to boost shares of Malaysian developers, particularly those with high-rise residential segments.
