The SEZ is expected to create job opportunities and commercial activities, driving demand for properties and reducing unsold inventory. Malaysian developers UEM Sunrise, Sunway Group, Eco World Development, and AME Elite Consortium are expected to benefit from the development. Maybank maintains a neutral stance on the Malaysian real estate market while expecting further details.

images.alt_text: The Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex in Johor, in part given its proximity to Singapore, is hoped will spur Malaysia's green energy transition, Malaysia's Minister of Economy Rafizi Ramli reportedly said.

From left: Johor’s Menteri Besar Onn Hafiz Ghazi, Singapore’s Minister for National Development Desmond Lee, Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli, and Singapore’s Acting Minister for Transport Chee Hong Tat at a doorstop interview for the 16th JMCIM.
Increasing demand has pushed home rentals in Johor Bahru higher, with some even rising more than 50 per cent from 2021 levels.

site_title: Global rules leave crypto firms with no place to hide, says G20 watchdog
summary: The Financial Stability Board (FSB) has published final recommendations for supervising firms that trade cryptocurrencies, emphasizing the need for robust governance, risk management, and disclosures to prevent blow-ups like FTX. The G20's global baseline minimum standards aim to prevent spillovers from cryptoasset markets into the broader financial system. The recommendations are expected to be made more granular by additional measures from global banking and securities watchdogs, with review of implementation by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: Figuring out what does or doesn’t make a coin a security is a complicated question.
The layoffs at the world’s biggest crypto exchange come at a time when the industry’s future in the US market is uncertain.
Bitcoin has traded at its highest price since June 2022 overnight, touching US$31,818 on the Bitstamp exchange.

The case has been closely watched in the cryptocurrency industry, which disputes the SEC’s assertion that the vast majority of crypto tokens are securities and subject to its strict investor protection rules.
Volume on so-called centralised exchanges rose 16.4 per cent to US$575 billion in June.

site_title: The futility of the active versus passive debate
summary: Investors who prioritize non-negotiable life events, such as retirement, over short-term goals can benefit from a passive investment approach. Globally-diversified portfolios using low-cost index funds and systematic investments can provide reliable returns when combined with evidence-based wealth planning, investment management, and investor psychology strategies. Unlike traditional active management, this approach is not about outguessing the market, but rather about working with the evidence to create a tailored investment plan that meets clients' specific needs and goals. By taking a passive approach in areas where evidence supports it, and being active in areas where it does not, investors can achieve sufficient returns while minimizing unnecessary risk.

images.alt_text: Planning your legacy involves not just financial provision for your heirs, but also the ensuring family harmony and cohesion last for generations.
Understanding how advisers and their firms are remunerated is important because the compensation structure can pose a potential conflict of interest.

site_title: India’s HDFC Bank posts bigger-than-expected jump in Q1 profit
summary: HDFC Bank, India's largest private lender, reported a 30% jump in Q1 profit, exceeding analyst expectations, with a standalone net profit of 119.52 billion rupees. The bank's interest earned rose 38% to 485.87 billion rupees, driven by higher net interest income and strong loan growth. The results come after the bank completed a merger with parent Housing Development Finance Corp in a $40 billion deal, aiming to tap rising demand for home loans.

images.alt_text: Once the merger is effective, a cut-off date will be announced to determine HDFC shareholders eligible to receive HDFC Bank shares.

site_title: JLC Advisors’ ex-managing partner Jeffrey Ong jailed 19 years
summary: Former JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong Su Aun was sentenced to 19 years in prison for misappropriating nearly S$76 million of clients' money. He pleaded guilty to 10 charges, including cheating and criminal breach of trust as an attorney, resulting in S$64.1 million in losses for the victims and S$7.2 million in gains for Ong. He used the money to repay loans and issue loans to others without clients' consent.

images.alt_text: JLC Advisors Jeffrey Ong implicates Allied Tech executive director and investor in misappropriation case
Allied Tech applies for more time to hold AGM while seeking new auditor

site_title: China to boost Brazil oil imports in Q3, replacing some Saudi supply: sources
summary: China is set to boost Brazilian oil imports in the third quarter, replacing some Saudi supply, amid higher prices. China has booked nearly 1 million bpd of Brazilian crude for August and September delivery, with Unipec purchasing 20 million barrels. This marks a significant increase from the average first five months of the year, as Chinese refiners cut volumes from Saudi Arabia, the kingdom's second-largest supplier, which has hiked most of its crude prices.

site_title: Swatch sues Malaysia over seized Pride watches, says local media
summary: Swatch Group has filed a lawsuit against the Malaysian government, challenging the seizure of 172 Pride-themed rainbow watches worth RM64,795. The watches were confiscated by the home ministry citing the Printing Presses and Publications Act 1984, claiming they promoted LGBT elements. Swatch claims the seizures are illegal as the watches are not a publication. The case is set to be heard in the High Court on July 20, with Swatch seeking the cancellation of seizure notices and the return of the confiscated pieces within five days.

site_title: Fashion retailer H&M to launch in Brazil
summary: Fashion retailer H&M plans to launch stores and online trade in Brazil in 2025, following its expansion in Latin America since opening its first store in Mexico in 2012. The company is partnering with Dorben Group to support its entry into the Brazilian market, which has a population of over 210 million. H&M aims to accelerate its expansion in the North and South America region, focusing on Latin America. This move is seen as a strategic step to tap into the region's growing fashion market.

site_title: Hot stock: Centurion up 10% after CGS-CIMB initiates coverage with ‘add’ call
summary: Centurion Corporation's shares surged 10% on Monday after CGS-CIMB initiated coverage with an "add" call, citing strong demand recovery and undersupply of beds across its operating geographies. The stock reached a three-year high of S$0.44 and closed at S$0.43, up 7.5%. Analysts expect Centurion to benefit from regulatory reforms and growing awareness for migrant worker welfare, with a target price of S$0.58.

images.alt_text: In a bourse filing announcing this on Monday (Jun 5), the company that is listed on the Singapore Exchange’s mainboard said the volume of trading since its share offer on the HKEX in 2017 has been “very limited”.

site_title: SingPost picks BofA Securities as financial adviser for strategic review
summary: SingPost has appointed BofA Securities as its exclusive financial adviser for a strategic review of its portfolio, focusing on transitioning the group to a logistics business over time. The review aims to identify non-core businesses or assets to divest and recycle capital for further investments in logistics. The goal is to optimise the balance sheet and ensure the underlying businesses are valued appropriately, creating optionality for the future. The review may lead to possible divestments and capital recycling.

images.alt_text: SingPost shares rise as much as 7.7 per cent in early morning trade.
(From left) Polytechnic student Nellie Titus and her friends Rebekah Loh, Megan Choy and Lynette Saw turned up at Lim Ah Pin Post Office in Kovan on Wednesday at 10.30 pm.

The board recommends a final dividend of S$0.40 per share, subject to approval from shareholders at its next annual general meeting.

site_title: Evergrande's overdue results to show steep losses, market eyes liquidity update
summary: Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted property developer, is expected to post significant losses in its overdue 2021 and 2022 results, revealing steep losses and updates on its liquidity and liabilities. The company has been struggling to complete projects and repay creditors after defaulting in 2021. Analysts expect a clearer picture from Evergrande's first-half 2023 performance, which will be published by the end of August. The company's offshore debt restructuring plan is also being closely watched.

images.alt_text: The sector has been hit by many company defaults amid a debt crisis since mid-2021.
The case underscores the enduring conflict between creditors and homeowners as debt-laden Evergrande faces more than a thousand lawsuits.

site_title: Searchlight Capital to buy UK's Gresham House for about £470 million
summary: US-based investment firm Searchlight Capital Partners is set to acquire UK-based alternative asset manager Gresham House for approximately £469.8 million. The deal, valued at 62.5% premium to the stock's last closing price, will see Gresham's shareholders receive 1,105 pence in cash per share. Gresham House directors intend to recommend the deal to shareholders for approval.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker arrives at his office in the Canary Wharf business district in London Feb. 26, 2014.//File Photo

site_title: South Korea home prices stabilise in June as buying in Seoul improves
summary: South Korea's home prices remained stable in June, with a 0.05% decrease nationwide and a 0.05% increase in the capital Seoul city for the first time in a year. The nationwide house transaction price index has eased this year, following a record 1.98% drop in December, as authorities implement measures to engineer a soft landing of the market. Market sentiment is also stabilizing, with an index of South Koreans' expectations on house prices at 100, indicating optimism.

images.alt_text: The BOK has kept monetary policy unchanged since its last interest rate hike in January and its tightening campaign, which began in August 2021, is widely expected to be over.

site_title: Toyota, Mercedes-Benz, BMW lead Singapore car sales in H1; two EV brands in top 10
summary: Toyota topped overall passenger car registration figures in Singapore for the first half of 2023 with 2,867 units, accounting for 21.7% of total registrations. Mercedes-Benz and BMW took second and third place, respectively, with 2,229 and 1,690 units. The top 10 list included two electric vehicle (EV) brands, marking a growing presence of EVs in the market.

images.alt_text: A CCS2 charging plug on an electric vehicle.

site_title: Indonesia president names new communications minister after graft scandal
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced a minor Cabinet reshuffle, naming Budi Arie Setiadi as the new communications minister. Setiadi replaces Johnny G Plate, who is on trial for accepting US$1.14 million in kickbacks related to a telecommunications project. The move comes after Plate faces life imprisonment if found guilty of corruption. Widodo emphasized the need to prioritize resolving the corruption case and tasked Setiadi with investigating artificial intelligence and data protection.

images.alt_text: The latest survey signals that Prabowo Subianto, 71, is gaining ground ahead of the Feb 14 Indonesia presidential race.

site_title: China stocks ends lower as GDP growth disappoints; typhoon halts HK trading
summary: China's blue-chip CSI 300 Index and Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.8% and 0.9% respectively on Monday, amid disappointing GDP growth data that showed China's economy grew 6.3% in the second quarter, below the forecast of 7.3%. The Hong Kong market was closed due to Typhoon Talim. The country's property sales and investment slumped, prompting Goldman Sachs to expect more targeted easing measures in the coming months to counteract growth headwinds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Investors stand in front of an electronic board showing stock information on the first trading day after the week-long Lunar New Year holiday at a brokerage house in Shanghai, China, February 15, 2016. China stocks opened more than 2 percent lower on Monday, as they played catch-up with bearish global markets after the week-long Lunar New Year holiday. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Cinema XXI owner to raise 2.25t rupiah in IPO priced at bottom
summary: PT Nusantara Sejahtera Raya, Indonesia's largest cinema chain operator, raised approximately 2.25 trillion rupiah (S$198 million) in its initial public offering (IPO) priced at the bottom of the marketed range. The majority of the proceeds will be used to expand Cinema XXI's network, with 20% allocated for early debt repayment. This is the largest IPO from Indonesia's consumer sector this year, contributing to the country's banner year in the IPO market, which has seen companies raise over $2.92 billion.

images.alt_text: Most of the proceeds to be used to expand Cinema XXI’s network while 20 per cent for early repayment of debt to Bank Rakyat Indonesia.

site_title: South Korea central bank warns of financial stability risk as debts rise
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has warned of a financial stability risk due to rising household debts, which reached a record high in June. The bank stated that while there is limited risk, high household debt could negatively impact growth and inequality. The bank has kept monetary policy unchanged since January and is expected to end its tightening campaign. Policymakers are advised to be cautious in communicating interest rate changes to avoid underestimating risks. The bank's governor has left room for further rate hikes, but the tightening campaign is widely expected to be over.

images.alt_text: Mortgage loans jumped by 7.0 trillion won compared with 4.2 trillion won the previous month.

site_title: Tesla rolls out its first electric pickup, the Cybertruck
summary: Tesla has rolled out its first electric pickup, the Cybertruck, at its plant near Austin, Texas. The vehicle, with its silvery shape and unusual angles, was first announced in November 2019 and had promised to be delivered by the end of the year. Despite an initial mishap when Elon Musk broke a prototype's window, nearly 150,000 advance orders were received. The Cybertruck will be available in three models, with prices starting at $39,900 and reaching $69,900, and will have a range of 400-800 kilometers between charges.

images.alt_text: The workers say they welcome the award after Tesla has cut bonuses for many staff in the previous quarter.

site_title: Chinese banks face another blow from mortgage refinancing push
summary: Chinese banks' profits may be impacted as the People's Bank of China (PBOC) urges lenders to lower mortgage refinancing costs on $5.4 trillion of US home loans. The move, aimed at reviving the nation's flagging economy, could lead to lower lending rates and a decrease in banks' margin and earnings. According to JPMorgan analysts, a 60 basis point rate reduction could result in a -7 basis point and -8% impact on 2024 net interest margin and earnings, respectively.

images.alt_text: New construction starts measured by floor area fell 24.3 per cent year-on-year, after a 22.6 per cent drop in the first five months.

site_title: Indonesia sticking with domestic palm oil sale rules ahead of B35 implementation
summary: Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil producer, will not change its rules requiring exporters to sell a portion of their output to the domestic market. The current ratio is 1:4, meaning exporters can only ship four times the amount they sell domestically. This rule will remain in place as the country prepares for the full nationwide implementation of its B35 programme. A senior official from the coordinating ministry of maritime affairs stated that there was no plan to alter the ratio, indicating that the policy will continue unchanged.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trucks are seen near a palm oil plantation at a village in Sepaku, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, March 8 2023. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: China June property sales fall at fastest clip this year
summary: China's property sales by floor area declined 28.1% year-on-year in June, the largest monthly drop this year, and investment slumped 20.6% from a year earlier. The sector remains in a downtrend, with new home prices stalling after meagre gains in May. The decline is attributed to cash-squeezed developers and would-be homebuyers keeping cash in deposits rather than making fresh investments. Authorities have provided support measures, but demand remains sluggish, and developers struggle to finish presold housing projects.

images.alt_text: Many Hong Kong-listed Chinese developers have faced winding-up petitions since the sector slipped into a debt crisis in mid-2021.

site_title: France to cut government spending by 4.2 billion euros next year: minister
summary: France's government plans to cut spending by 4.2 billion euros in 2024, resulting in a 3.5% year-on-year decrease when adjusted for inflation. The reduction comes as the government phases out massive subsidies on fuel and electricity, which were introduced to shield consumers from soaring energy bills. The move aims to balance the government's finances and finance the green transition. The budget cuts follow pressure from Fitch cutting France's rating to AA- due to concerns about potential political paralysis and social unrest.

images.alt_text: This aerial view shows the La Defense business district, north-west of Paris on July 11, 2023. (Photo by Emmanuel DUNAND / AFP)

site_title: New private home sales slump in June amid few launches, but sales set to rise strongly in July
summary: Private residential home sales plummeted 73.2% in June, with 278 units sold, compared to 1,039 in May and 488 in the same period last year. This marks the lowest number of private homes sold this year. Despite a few launches, developers' sales are expected to rise strongly in July. The drop is attributed to fewer new launches, while low mortgage rates may also play a role.

images.alt_text: Singapore's housing market has seen a buoyant run, after an influx of capital and a pandemic-induced supply shortage pushed prices and rents to record highs.
Knight Frank says despite the fall in total sales volume, average price for properties gain 4.7 per cent in H1 2023.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as rally fades, China growth misses forecasts
summary: Asian markets struggled on Monday as China's economy grew less than expected in the second quarter, with gross domestic product expanding 6.3% on-year in April-June. This fell short of forecasts and further highlighted weakness in the world's number-two economy. Despite pledges from Beijing to introduce stimulus measures, investors remained cautious ahead of the upcoming Politburo meeting, which may influence policy decisions. The Shanghai stock market fell over 1% in early trade, while other markets in the region also declined.

images.alt_text: The upbeat mood on Wall Street filtered through to Asia, where Hong Kong rose for a fifth successive day thanks to a bounce in Chinese tech giants, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Jakarta also gained.

site_title: Indonesia surprises with large trade surplus; rate cuts expected before year-end
summary: Indonesia recorded a trade surplus of US$3.46 billion in June, exceeding expectations, driven by a 18.35% decline in imports to US$17.15 billion and a 21.18% decline in exports to US$20.61 billion. This suggests the central bank, Bank Indonesia, may cut interest rates before year-end to support economic growth. A 50-basis-point rate cut is predicted by economists, following a 225-basis-point hike in 2022-2023 to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Indonesia President Joko Widodo on Monday announced new deputy ministers for foreign affairs, village affairs, religious affairs, communications and state-owned enterprises.
Exporters in Indonesia, the world’s biggest palm oil producer, currently can only ship palm oil four times the amount that they sell domestically.

Nets payments to go digital and contactless. Photo shows Nets payment using a mobile phone. Consumers with phones that have near-field communications (NFC) technology will be able to pay with a tap on terminals with a payment reader. Those whose phones do not have NFC can pay by scanning a QR code on terminals with the camera.

site_title: Cartier owner Richemont sales rise as China demand holds while US softens
summary: Richemont, the owner of Cartier, reported higher first-quarter sales, with a 19% increase in constant-currency sales to €5.3 billion. The rebound in China sales offset a decline in the Americas, with revenue rising 40% in the Asia-Pacific region. The US luxury market is showing signs of weakness, with Chairman Johann Rupert warning of a potential downturn. This contrasts with Burberry Group's recent decline in revenue from the Americas, highlighting the industry's reliance on a China bounceback to counter a US slowdown.

images.alt_text: China has been a main driver of an explosion in demand for Swiss watches, jewellery and accessories in recent years.
“Richemont is very well positioned with Cartier, Van Cleef & Arpels or Vacheron Constantin. The company has everything in place for further market share gains.” chairman Johann Rupert says.

site_title: Microsoft agrees to keep ‘Call of Duty’ on Sony Playstation
summary: Microsoft has reached a deal with Sony to keep the popular gaming franchise "Call of Duty" on the PlayStation platform, addressing regulators' concerns about the merger with Activision Blizzard. The 10-year agreement, announced on July 16, aims to alleviate concerns that the deal would make Activision games exclusive to Xbox. This move follows a recent offer by Microsoft to sell cloud-based market rights for games in the UK, which has been agreed upon by the UK Competition and Markets Authority. The deal is seen as a significant step towards the completion of Microsoft's acquisition of Activision Blizzard.

images.alt_text: Microsoft won’t exclude the popular shooter game from consoles offered by its top competitor Sony.
CMA suggested that structural remedies could be needed to allay its concerns, including divesting the business associated with Call of Duty.

site_title: China’s 6.3% GDP growth in Q2 puts pressure for more policy support
summary: China's economy grew 6.3% in Q2, driven by base effects, but momentum faltered due to weakening demand at home and abroad. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, GDP expanded 0.8%, down from 2.2% in Q1. Analysts expect policymakers to roll out more stimulus steps, including fiscal spending and support for consumers and private firms, to shore up the economy, which is seen as on track to meet its 5% growth target. However, a deeper slowdown could lead to job losses and deflationary risks.

images.alt_text: China’s central bank lowered key policy rates in June to prop up the cooling economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks began Monday down 0.2% at 3,240.71, following a muted global market finish on Friday. Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 57, with Seatrium and Genting Singapore experiencing losses. Local banks DBS and UOB traded mixed, while OCBC slipped 0.2%. The decline mirrored European shares, which closed 0.1% lower on Friday, and US indices, which finished up 2.4% for the week.

images.alt_text: ESR Logos Reit's manager said its proposed divestment of seven non-core assets is in line with its strategy.

site_title: Softer earnings expected for S-reits in first half, with funding cost among headwinds
summary: DBS analysts expect Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) to report soft earnings for the first half of 2023, driven by high interest rates and a strong Singapore dollar. Most S-Reits are expected to maintain earnings above three times interest expense, but office and US office S-Reits with higher leverage ratios may struggle. Analysts recommend a "conservative stance" and prefer resilient sub-sectors like industrial and hotel S-Reits, citing potential for better distributions per unit (DPUs) in these sectors.

images.alt_text: Daiwa House Logistics Trust is among the five trusts with the highest ICR.

site_title: China central bank rolls over medium-term policy loans, rate unchanged
summary: China's central bank rolled over maturing medium-term policy loans worth 103 billion yuan (S$19 billion) at an unchanged 2.65% interest rate on July 17. This move resulted in a net 3 billion yuan fresh fund injection into the banking system. The People's Bank of China kept borrowing costs unchanged at 1.90% through seven-day reverse repos. The decision aligns with market expectations, following the central bank's rate cut in June to prop up the cooling economy.

site_title: Gold edges lower on slight US dollar uptick
summary: Gold prices edged lower on Monday, down 0.1% to $1,952.58 per ounce, as the US dollar strengthened, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. Despite a 1.6% weekly gain, investors largely expect the US Federal Reserve to hit the brakes on interest rate hikes, leading to a decrease in the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. The Fed is set to meet on July 25-26, with markets mostly pricing in another rate hike, but some expect rate cuts in 2024.

images.alt_text: Bullion hit its highest since Jun 16 earlier this week after data showed US consumer prices in June registered their smallest annual increase in over two years.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR Logos Reit, Ho Bee Land, IReit Global, UOL Group, Singapore Land, Sabana Reit
summary: Key developments in the Singapore stock market include ESR Logos Reit's proposed divestment of non-core assets, Ho Bee Land's expected net loss for the first half, and IReit Global's lease extension with a 45% rent increase. UOL Group and Singapore Land reported strong sales for their Pinetree Hill project, while Sabana Reit's trustee clarified the Reit's stance on replacing its manager. Trading was halted for TA Corporation pending an announcement.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: ‘Mission: Impossible’ returns, topping North American box office
summary: Paramount's 'Mission: Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part One' topped the North American box office, earning US$52.6 million over the weekend. The film, starring Tom Cruise, initially took the top spot, replacing horror flick 'Insidious: The Red Door'. Industry experts consider the opening "roughly average" for an action thriller at this point in the series, with strong foreign market performances except for China.

images.alt_text: Disney still laid on a red carpet at the theme park’s Haunted Mansion ride, but none of the movie’s stars were in attendance.

site_title: Hang Seng Index expected to continue trading down
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) has been trading down, with a 15% decline since its January peak, amid weak economic data from China, including a lower-than-expected Caixin Services Purchasing Managers' Index and deflation pressure. The index is currently in a downtrend channel with multiple bearish signals, including a bearish flag breakdown and a failed Relative Strength Index above 60. The HSI Volatility Index also broke out of a mid-term downtrend resistance, suggesting further volatility in the near-term.

site_title: Russia takes ‘temporary’ control of Danone, Carlsberg assets
summary: Russia has taken "temporary" control of the Russian subsidiaries of Danone and Carlsberg under a decree by President Vladimir Putin. The decree allows for state control over assets from "unfriendly" countries, including the US and its allies. This is the second time the Kremlin has used the decree to seize assets, following similar moves against Finnish utility Fortum and German utility Uniper. Danone and Carlsberg have expressed uncertainty and concern over the decision, with Carlsberg assessing legal and operational consequences.

images.alt_text: The sales agreement will not impact Carlsberg’s 2023 earnings expectations, the company says in a statement.
French food group Danone, which makes Activia yoghurt, Aptamil infant formula and Evian water, has largely relied on Europe for raw materials.

site_title: Hong Kong delays morning trading because of typhoon Talim
summary: Hong Kong delayed morning trading due to Typhoon Talim, which will skirt within 300 kilometers of the city. The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearings (HKEX) canceled the pre-opening session and delayed the morning session. The city's observatory hoisted the No 8 signal, its third-highest warning, and schools, businesses, and public transportation may be affected. This is the third time HKEX has canceled morning trading due to severe weather.

images.alt_text: The mortgage easing comes after Hong Kong lowered the stamp duty for first-time buyers of cheaper homes in February.

site_title: Heritage black-and-whites: The cost versus value of their conservation
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has been upgrading 26 black-and-white bungalows in the Ridout estate, spending a total of S$1.085 million, to restore them to basic habitable condition. However, experts say the cost is not justified, as the properties lack modern amenities and may not be a first choice of home for many. The SLA's efforts aim to balance redevelopment and conservation, but critics argue that the costs outweigh the benefits, and alternative uses, such as tourism or adaptive reuse, could be more cost-effective.

images.alt_text: A black-and-white bungalow at Seletar.

site_title: UN Security Council to hold first talks on AI risks
summary: The UN Security Council will hold its first formal discussion on artificial intelligence (AI) risks on July 18, with Britain calling for an international dialogue on AI's impact on global peace and security. This comes as governments worldwide consider how to mitigate the dangers of emerging AI technology, which could reshape the global economy and change the international security landscape. The discussion is seen as a step towards creating an international AI watchdog body, as proposed by some artificial intelligence executives and backed by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres in June.

site_title: UK property sellers cut asking prices for first time this year
summary: UK property sellers have cut their asking prices for the first time this year, with Rightmove reporting a 0.2% decrease in prices. This marks a shift towards lower prices, as mortgage lenders have also reported a trend of lower prices. The Bank of England's benchmark lending rate increase has contributed to the fall in prices, with mortgage rates rising to 5.69% for a 5-year fixed-rate loan. Despite this, buyer demand remains resilient, with prices still 0.5% above pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Food prices have been driven up by increased costs for animal feed, fertiliser and fuel as well as energy and labour.

site_title: Vietnam’s big bet on LNG may not ease its power crisis
summary: Vietnam aims to generate 22.4 gigawatts of power from liquefied natural gas (LNG) by 2030, but faces challenges in meeting its target due to disagreements over pricing, plant construction delays, and lack of supply contracts. The country's urgent need to boost electricity supply, highlighted by recent rolling blackouts, has raised concerns among foreign investors about Vietnam's reliability as a manufacturing hub. The country's reliance on imported gas may not ease its power crisis, and its ambitions to diversify manufacturing away from China are uncertain.

images.alt_text: The cargo is aimed at test-running PetroVietnam Gas’ Thi Vai LNG terminal in the south of the country, which is expected to supply gas to industrial clients and two nearby power plants being developed.

site_title: An essay on not investing
summary: FSSA Investment Managers director Vinay Agarwal advises against investing in companies that lack strong corporate governance, citing the importance of aligning interests and avoiding founder-led cultural turnarounds. Despite a turnaround in one company, the investment team err on the side of caution due to lingering suspicions about governance. This approach is rooted in decades of experience, as seen in past cases where companies with poor governance practices reverted to their previous behavior after initial attempts at change. The team prioritizes long-term investment success over short-term gains, maintaining a disciplined approach to avoid subtle drift from their principles and philosophy.

images.alt_text: Our engagement strategy involves conducting assessments to identify potential material thematic ESG issues that can affect our investee companies in the long run, says Wong

B Lab Global's Eleanor Allen says the controversy surrounding Nespresso's B Corp certification has taught her and her team the importance of having both big and small companies on board, and getting them to accept each other into the community.
Adani’s commentary is part of a wider effort to rebuild investor trust after Hindenburg accused his eponymous conglomerate of widespread corporate malfeasance in January.
Stewardship Asia Centre launches updated practices for responsible investing with nods from MAS, SGX

site_title: UK consumer group calls for government action on grocery prices
summary: UK consumer group Which? is urging the government to take action on grocery prices, citing a 25.8% rise in supermarket prices between June 2021 and June 2023. The price increases are driven by increased costs for animal feed, fertiliser, fuel, energy, and labour, as well as poor harvests and a weaker pound. Which? is calling for the government to address the issue, with the Competition and Markets Authority set to review competition and pricing in the grocery sector.

images.alt_text: All sectors of the UK economy contracted in May except for services, which showed no growth.

site_title: Singapore key exports down 15.5% in June in ninth straight month of decline
summary: Singapore's export growth is expected to remain weak after nine consecutive months of decline, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) falling 15.5% year-on-year in June. Electronic exports contracted 15.9% and non-electronic shipments declined 15.4%. The decline was driven by a 61.8% drop in primary chemicals exports. Economists expect a couple more months of year-on-year contraction, but some see tentative signs of stabilization in seasonally adjusted terms.

images.alt_text: Key exports’ value fell to S$13.8 billion in May, from S$16.1 billion in April. It also remained lower than the year-ago period’s S$17.1 billion and 2022’s average of S$16.6 billion.

site_title: BT’s new ‘Lens On’ podcasts take a deep dive into the big issues
summary: BT launches "Lens On" podcast series, focusing on current affairs in Singapore and the region. The first series, "Lens on Singapore," features monthly episodes exploring global developments, societal changes, and government policies. Hosted by Claressa Monteiro and Howie Lim, the series aims to provide a big-picture perspective on issues affecting Singapore and the broader Asean community. The series' first episode discusses Singapore versus Hong Kong, and future episodes will cover topics such as climate change and food security.

images.alt_text: In the fight for supremacy, who emerges victorious? Singapore or Hong Kong?

(FILES) A picture taken on February 8, 2019 in Paris shows a smartphone and its earphones as an audio podcast is being played. As people brace for the disruptive impact of artificial intelligence on jobs and everyday living, those in the world of audio books say their field is already being transformed.
AI has the ability to create human-sounding recordings -- at assembly-line speed -- while bypassing at least part of the services of the human professionals who for years have made a living with their voices. (Photo by Thomas SAMSON / AFP)
How podcasts’ unrealised potential is limitless.
Claressa Monteiro, BT's podcast editor.

site_title: Indonesians shun cash as QR code payments now the norm
summary: Indonesia has seen a significant shift towards QR code payments, with the rate of QR payments tripling nearly every year since its launch in 2019. By the end of 2023, Indonesian consumers will be able to make QR payments from their Nets-linked bank accounts while traveling to Singapore, and Singaporean travelers will be able to use their smartphones to make QR payments in Indonesia. The QRIS system has gained over 30.9 million users, with the value of QR transactions reaching $8.7 billion in 2022. The move is part of Indonesia's efforts to reduce its reliance on the US dollar and promote digital payments.

images.alt_text: SMS messages, which are not encrypted, can be intercepted and read by fraudsters in a number of ways.
GlobalTix co-founders Chan Chee Kong (left), who is chief operating officer, and Chan Chee Chong, who is chief executive officer, aim to work with more payment gateways so more e-wallets can be used.
On average, each Malaysian made 291 e-payments in 2022, with two-thirds of the transactions made through contactless payment such as mobile e-wallets.
A customer scans a QR code to pay a food at a food stall in Jakarta. Indonesia's internet penetration stands at 77 per cent, up from just 13 per cent in 2009.

site_title: More than half of Grand Dunman’s 1,008 units sold on launch weekend at average price of S$2,500 psf
summary: Grand Dunman, a 1,008-unit 99-year leasehold development, sold over half its units on its launch weekend, with 550 units sold at an average price of S$2,500 psf. The majority of buyers are Singaporean (90%), with 61% of three-bedroom units and 77% of two-bedroom units sold. The development's location near the Dakota MRT station and popular schools and eateries likely appealed to buyers, with analysts noting that the pricing is seen as acceptable given the project's city fringe location and easy access to public transportation.

images.alt_text: A total of 298 units in the 99-year leasehold project were sold during its launch weekend.
27 per cent of The Myst's 408 units were sold at an average price of S$2,057 per square foot (psf) over its launch weekend.

site_title: Elon Musk says Twitter’s cash flow still negative as ad revenue drops 50%
summary: Elon Musk stated that Twitter's cash flow remains negative due to a nearly 50% drop in advertising revenue and a heavy debt load. The company's non-debt expenditures decreased to $1.5 billion from a projected $4.5 billion in 2023. Musk's expectation to reach cash flow positive by June was not met, and July's ad revenue is seen as more promising. Twitter faces annual interest payments of $1.5 billion from its $44 billion debt deal.

images.alt_text: The company will use public tweets to train its AI models and may also work with Tesla on AI software.
Twitter is trying to draw more content creators to the platform.

site_title: S-E Asia ESG debt issuance lags global pace to fall for second straight quarter
summary: S-E Asia ESG debt issuance declined 37.8% year-over-year to US$3.2 billion in Q2 2023, lagging the global pace. The downturn was attributed to high interest rates and economic uncertainty, as well as lower funding needs by traditional issuers. ESG loan proceeds also fell 22.5% to US$3.7 billion, with sustainability-linked loans making up 80% of all ESG loans in the region. Despite the decline, bankers expect the volume of labelled bond issuances in Asean to increase in the latter half of 2023, driven by expectations of a US interest rate hike cycle ending.

images.alt_text: Singapore Budget 2021 generic pictures: Singapore Green Plan 2030

site_title: ‘Haunted Mansion’, a premiere without stars as strike bites
summary: The world premiere of Disney's 'Haunted Mansion' was held without its stars due to the ongoing Hollywood actors' strike. The Screen Actors Guild (SAG-AFTRA) and writers have been on strike for weeks, triggering the first industry-wide walkout in 63 years. Director Justin Simien expressed support for the actors and stated he missed them "terribly." The strike, which began on Thursday, has shut down all US productions except for reality and game shows, with dwindling pay and the threat of artificial intelligence being major demands.

images.alt_text: The SAG-AFTRA, which represents 160,000 performers including A-list stars, said negotiations had ended without a deal on their demands over dwindling pay and the threat posed by artificial intelligence.

site_title: London workers more gloomy about prospects of finding a new job
summary: A survey by Deltapoll commissioned by Bloomberg found that 38% of London workers are "not confident" about finding another job in three months if they lost their current one, significantly higher than those in other regions of England. This gloom may reflect the impact of the soaring cost of living and remote working on the city's job market, with concerns about job security in industries such as hospitality and retail. The UK's national unemployment rate has also risen unexpectedly to 4%, with London and the West Midlands having the highest levels of joblessness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk through the Canary Wharf financial district of London, Britain, December 7, 2018. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo

epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Catch Lion City Sailors take on Tottenham Hotspur and more in the Singapore Festival of Football
summary: The Singapore Festival of Football is set to feature a pre-season friendly match between Tottenham Hotspur and Lion City Sailors on July 26. After AS Roma dropped out, Spurs will face the Singapore Premier League club for the Tiger Cup trophy, with Lion City Sailors seeking to prepare for the AFC Champions League. The festival, which includes open training sessions by Liverpool and Bayern Munich, will kick off on July 25 and conclude with a match between the two German teams on August 2.

images.alt_text: Liverpool (in red) defeated Leicester 3-0 in the English Premier League on May 16. The two teams will play each other again in Singapore on Jul 30 at the National Stadium.

site_title: Alcaraz seizes the throne as Djokovic finally meets his match
summary: Carlos Alcaraz has become the youngest Wimbledon champion since 1986, defeating Novak Djokovic in the final with a 1-6 7-6(6) 6-1 3-6 6-4 victory. Alcaraz, 18, won his first Grand Slam title, just 16 years after Djokovic won his first, and only the third Spanish man to claim the title. Djokovic, 36, was at the peak of his powers but could not resist Alcaraz's attacking play, which sealed the win and marked a seismic moment in men's tennis.

images.alt_text: The 36-year-old Djokovic is targeting an eighth Wimbledon title, which would draw him level with Federer’s men’s record.

site_title: Singapore semiconductor stocks poised to ride AI boom as key links in supply chain: analysts
summary: Singapore-listed semiconductor companies, such as UMS Holdings, Frencken Group, and AEM Holdings, are expected to benefit from the artificial intelligence (AI) boom, despite not directly producing AI chips. These companies, which supply components and services to key clients in the semiconductor industry, could see a recovery in the second half of 2023 and beyond due to increased demand for AI chips. Analysts predict that the AI trend could lead to a normalization of inventory levels, driving new customer contracts and revenue growth for these companies.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor equipment is displayed at the American Tec (AMT) booth during Semicon China, a trade fair for the semiconductor industry, in Shanghai, China June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Nicoco Chan

site_title: Riyadh, Tokyo to cooperate on energy security, hydrogen and ammonia
summary: Saudi Arabia and Japan agreed to cooperate on energy security, hydrogen, ammonia, and recycled carbon fuels. The two countries signed 26 agreements during a visit by Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to Saudi Arabia, including rare earth resources cooperation and development projects. Saudi Arabia will continue to supply oil to Japan and maintain its position as the largest oil exporter, fulfilling 40% of Japan's total needs. The agreement also marks the resumption of talks on a free trade agreement between Japan and the Gulf Cooperation Council.

images.alt_text: The PIF has been on a global acquisition spree since 2016.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: And the winner is...Singapore or Hong Kong? (Ep 1)
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are in a heated competition for business and investment supremacy. A podcast discussion with experts reveals that Singapore's unique blend of business-friendly policies, high standard of living, and strategic location make it an attractive destination. Hong Kong's recent policy shifts and current appeal are also discussed, with some experts arguing that it is still a competitive financial hub. Ultimately, no clear winner is declared, with both cities vying for the top spot in the eyes of multinational corporations.

images.alt_text: While rents in Singapore's central business district remains cheaper than Hong Kong's, the latter offers more cost-effective decentralised nodes.
Michael Spiegel, global head, Transaction Banking at Standard Chartered Bank
Hong Kong is now seeking to revive the industry, in part by opening up for crypto firms and seeking to lure more family offices with tax breaks.
The surge in market heavyweight tech firms lifted the Hang Seng Index more than one per cent, while there were also gains in Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: Actress, singer Jane Birkin dies aged 76
summary: British-born actress and singer Jane Birkin, known for her roles in films like 'Blow-Up' and her hit song 'Je t'aime...moi non plus' with Serge Gainsbourg, has died in Paris at 76. She had suffered a mild stroke in 2021 and was a beloved figure in France for her warm nature and fight for women's and LGBT rights. Birkin had lived in France since the 1960s and was married to composer John Barry before her relationship with Gainsbourg.

images.alt_text: Coco Lee was born in Hong Kong in 1975 and was the youngest of three children of a Hong Kong Cantonese mother and Malaysian father.

site_title: China economic data likely to show recovery is fading quickly
summary: China's economic data is expected to show a post-pandemic bounce is quickly fizzling out, with likely 0.5% growth in the second quarter and a sharp loss of economic momentum. Weak demand, a protracted property market slump, and "scarring effects" from strict Covid measures are blamed for the slowdown. Authorities are likely to unveil more stimulus measures, including fiscal spending and property policy easing, to shore up activity and consumer confidence. However, analysts expect a quick turnaround is unlikely, and the central bank may cut banks' reserve requirement ratio to free up funds for lending.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says: “China is a very substantial importer from many countries around the world, so when Chinese growth slows, it has a impact on many countries – and we are seeing that.”
The central and local governments and regulators have announced a slew of policies over the past year to prop up the sector.

site_title: US dollar perks up after sharp losses, but downtrend still intact
summary: The US dollar experienced its biggest weekly decline since November, falling 2.3% against a basket of six major currencies. Despite a modest recovery on Friday, the dollar index remains down for the week. The Federal Reserve is near the end of its rate hike cycle amid softening inflation, and investors are waiting for its July meeting to see if officials will abandon their tightening bias. The euro touched a fresh 16-month peak against the dollar, while the Swedish krona is set for its biggest weekly gain since 2009.

images.alt_text: As traders price in an end to US rate rises, the narrowing gap between US borrowing rates and those elsewhere drive other currencies, particularly the euro, sterling and the yen higher against the US dollar.

site_title: China’s Xiaomi bets bigger on India retail stores amid Samsung rivalry
summary: Xiaomi, China's smartphone giant, plans to boost India sales through retail stores, aiming to revive its market position after losing leadership to Samsung. Currently, 34% of Xiaomi's India sales come from retail stores, with the rest from online platforms. The company aims to expand its store network to 18,000 and partner with phone vendors to sell other products. Xiaomi's India head, Muralikrishnan B, stated that offline sales are crucial in India's premiumization trend, where consumers prefer the look and feel of premium products.

images.alt_text: Court documents show Xiaomi’s frozen assets are spread across accounts at various banks including Deutsche, Citi and HSBC.
Xiaomi was once an unrivalled leader in India’s smartphone market, but lost steam after facing heightened regulatory scrutiny and stiff competition.

site_title: Pinetree Hill sells 29% of units during launch weekend, initial average price at S$2,460 psf
summary: Pinetree Hill, a 99-year leasehold development in Ulu Pandan, sold nearly 29% of its 520 units during its launch weekend, with 400 units launched and 150 sold at an average price of S$2,460 per square feet (psf). The majority of buyers were owner-occupiers, mostly Singaporeans and permanent residents, attracted by the project's proximity to popular schools and lifestyle offerings. The highest transacted unit was a five-bedroom unit above S$2,700 psf.

images.alt_text: Analysts said the Grand Dunman's location likely appealed to buyers. The development is a two-minute walk from Dakota MRT station and is near several popular schools and eateries.
A total of 298 units in the 99-year leasehold project were sold during its launch weekend.
27 per cent of The Myst's 408 units were sold at an average price of S$2,057 per square foot (psf) over its launch weekend.

site_title: Workers hate office noise – but is using headphones to shut out colleagues the solution?
summary: Wearing headphones in the office has become a common practice to block out distracting noise, but it may also indicate ineffective team dynamics. Research shows that open-plan office noise can lead to a 25% increase in negative mood and 34% increase in physiological stress. Using headphones can signal that the office environment is too noisy or distracting, and it can also indicate a lack of effective team communication. Organizations can address this by providing acoustic treatments, designing spaces for focused work, and establishing effective team communication strategies.

images.alt_text: Sleep is particularly important for higher-level cognitive skills that we use to control and coordinate our thoughts and behaviour.

site_title: The AI bubble will eventually burst, but investors are enjoying the ride while it lasts
summary: A tech bubble is forming in the artificial intelligence (AI) sector, with shares of major companies like Google, Microsoft, and Alphabet rising by 50% or more in recent months. Strategists warn that this "baby bubble" is likely to burst, citing the 1999 dotcom bubble as a precedent. Despite the hype, some experts believe AI has the potential to drive significant growth and productivity gains, but also acknowledge the risks of regulatory intervention and social dangers. As investors continue to capitalize on AI's profits, many are eager to enjoy the ride while it lasts.

images.alt_text: The arrangement involves OpenAI licensing part of AP’s text archive, while AP will leverage the ChatGPT-maker’s technology.
The finalised guidelines stipulate that offshore providers of generative AI tools – if they are aimed at Chinese residents – must also comply with the set of rules.
Semiconductor companies could ride the AI boom, even if they do not directly produce chips that are used in AI applications.
The assistant can also help entrepreneurs update their stores on Shopify.

site_title: Yellen eyes China de-escalation, but lifting tariffs ‘premature’
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the US should aim to "de-escalate" tensions with China, but lifting tariffs imposed by the Trump administration would be premature. Yellen discussed the issue with Chinese officials during her recent visit to Beijing, noting that China's economic slowdown has an impact on many countries. The US is nearing completion of a four-year review of the tariffs, which were imposed due to concerns over unfair trade practices. China has called for concrete actions to improve ties, including cancelling additional tariffs.

images.alt_text: Kerry’s trip to China, where he will meet with his counterpart Xie Zhenhua, follows weeks of record-setting summer heat that scientists say is being exacerbated by climate change.

site_title: Jacky Cheung’s 60+ Concert Tour is a visual treat
summary: Jacky Cheung kicked off his 60+ Concert Tour in Singapore with a sold-out show at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, performing to a crowd of 8,000 fans. The 62-year-old Cantopop legend showcased his vocals and stamina, delivering an impressive 140-minute-long show with complex choreography. While the set list omitted some classic hits, the show's over-the-top stage design and production value kept fans engaged, with many praising Cheung's vocals and performances. The tour marks the 11th consecutive sold-out show for Cheung in Singapore, solidifying his record as the most number of gigs by a solo artiste in the city-state.

images.alt_text: Shares in Unusual have steadily risen since April, with a jump of over 10 per cent in May. The company cited the overwhelming response for Jacky Cheung’s concerts as a reason for the rise.

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee urges unitholders to vote carefully in EGM, highlights ‘risks and uncertainties’
summary: HSBC Trustee, the trustee of Sabana Reit, is urging unitholders to carefully consider the resolutions at an upcoming EGM, which include removing the current manager and internalizing the management function. The trustee warns that replacing the manager or internalizing the management structure could take at least 12 months and will require significant time and cost. If the resolutions are passed, the trustee will implement them without a replacement manager being identified or an internalized management structure in place, and will assess all options in the best interests of unitholders, including an orderly winding-up of the Reit.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.
A six-storey industrial building with a ground level carpark. 151 Lorong Chuan, New Tech Park, Singapore 556741.
The EGM requisitioned by activist investor Quarz Capital is set to take place on Aug 4.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. Quarz Capital had requisitioned the EGM, which was slated to take place on Aug 4, to vote on two resolutions.
Sabana' Reit's upcoming extraordinary general meeting involves two resolutions - one for the removal of its Reit manager and second on the internalisation of the Reit management function.
At an upcoming extraordinary general meeting, unitholders will vote on whether to remove Sabana Reit’s current manager and replace it with an internal one.
Sabana Reit's manager ought to obtain clarity from UOB and other lenders on whether they plan to pull back their credit facilities in the event unitholders vote for internalisation.

site_title: Once-bitten investors unconvinced China tech rebound can last
summary: China's tech stocks have surged, with the Hang Seng Tech Index jumping 8.4% last week, driven by fines on Ant Group and Tencent Holdings signaling an end to the official crackdown. However, investors remain skeptical, citing lingering challenges and doubts over earnings growth. Analysts warn that more concrete support is needed for a sustainable recovery, and that the sector's outlook remains murky due to difficulties in raising offshore capital and the government's focus on creating common prosperity.

images.alt_text: People cross a street near office towers in the Lujiazui financial district, ahead of the National People's Congress (NPC), in Shanghai, China, February 28, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Biggest DeFi lender Aave set to launch decentralised stablecoin
summary: Aave, the largest DeFi lender, is set to launch a decentralized stablecoin called GHO, backed by assets on its platform. The stablecoin will be pegged to US$1 and managed by AaveDAO, a decentralized autonomous organization. GHO aims to provide a more convenient payment method for users, as stablecoins are less volatile than cryptocurrencies. Despite struggles in the DeFi sector following scandals like the collapse of TerraUSD, Aave's new stablecoin may help diversify the market and speed up mainstream adoption of the industry.

images.alt_text: Figuring out what does or doesn’t make a coin a security is a complicated question.

site_title: Oil surge to US$80 shows long-awaited market tightening is here
summary: Oil prices surged above $80 a barrel in London, driven by a tightening market as OPEC+ production cuts begin to take effect. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies have reduced output, draining storage tanks worldwide. Analysts expect a sharp tightening of the market, with Brent crude potentially reaching $90 a barrel. However, demand remains uncertain due to economic concerns, and some forecasters predict a surplus next year. Despite this, Saudi Arabia has committed to maintaining its production cuts, potentially fueling a price rally.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pump jack drills oil crude from the Yates Oilfield in West Texas’s Permian Basin near Iraan, Texas, U.S., March 17, 2023. Picture taken through glass. REUTERS/Bing Guan/File Photo
Brent crude futures settle at US$79.87 per barrel, down US$1.49, or 1.8 per cent.

site_title: Big players, top-down regulation could unlock value in Singapore stocks: industry watchers
summary: Singapore's stock market may require a large investor to inject liquidity to regain investor interest. Industry experts suggest that a fund focusing on small-cap or mid-cap stocks, as well as top-down regulation, could unlock the value of deeply discounted counters. Experts also recommend investors position their portfolios with a mix of defensive stocks, Reits, and fixed-income investments. To boost liquidity, Singapore could emulate Japan's approach of requiring companies trading below book value to address undervaluation. A large-scale investment could provide confidence and potentially reverse the market's downtrend.

images.alt_text: A growing cohort of investors today are looking for convenience, and appear to take a light-touch approach to portfolio management.
The PBOC is grappling with several challenges, including the looming prospect of deflation, subdued economic growth and a faltering property market.
SGX RegCo has set out guidelines for IFAs in the context of its listing rules.
The Business Times Mark to Market Live, a subscriber only webinar. Ben Paul, Senior Correspondent, The Business Times and  Helen Wong, Group CEO, OCBC Bank.

site_title: Defending the moat around the generative AI castle
summary: ChatGPT reached 100 million users in less than two months, 15 times faster than Instagram, which took 30 months. Generative AI companies face challenges in building defensible technology, proprietary data, and ecosystem moats. While technological lead is important, it may be transient, and companies should leverage their technological advantage as a first-mover benefit to build more sustainable moats. Proprietary data is a key moat, but publicly available data can also unlock hidden value. Strong ecosystems powered by developers and software integrations are also crucial for success. Companies should focus on identifying necessary moats and executing well to deepen them.

images.alt_text: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt (left, with Databricks co-founder Arsalan Tavakoli) warns that AI could be used by bad actors to "accelerate at scale".
Databricks chief executive Ali Ghodsi believes that MosaicML can get to US$50 to US$100 million in annual recurring revenue in 12 months.
Larry Feinsmith (left), JP Morgan Chase’s head of global tech strategy, innovation and partnerships tells Databricks chief Ali Ghodsi about that the bank is working through the risks of AI.
FILE PHOTO: Google, Microsoft and Alphabet logos and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

The FTC’s investigation into the wildly popular ChatGPT comes as artificial intelligence leaders have called for developers to hit the pause button on releasing AI tools to the public, warning the powerful technology could harm humanity.

site_title: Indonesia stays upbeat on 5% growth despite gloomy China outlook
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati expressed optimism about the country's 5% economic growth target for 2023, despite a gloomy global outlook, particularly from China. Indonesia's household consumption is expected to drive growth, while elections next year will boost the economy through government and party spending. The country aims to strengthen ties with India, which is seeking to diversify its imports from Indonesia due to China's economic slowdown.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Access to best performing asset class - privates (Ep 147)
summary: Private equities, real estate, and digital assets are alternative assets missing in investment portfolios. To achieve a balanced portfolio, investors can consider diversifying and allocating these assets, according to Kelvin Lee, Co-founder and CEO of Alta. Alternative investments can serve as a hedge against inflation, and their potential opportunities are on the rise, according to Lee.

images.alt_text: BT Money Hacks: One drunken party away from poverty - alternative investments (Ep 116)
hourglass, money, time
Alternative investments in portfolios: Their time has come
Is it possible to achieve salary independence?

site_title: Samudera eyes rising bulk shipping demand from Indonesia’s value-added mining policy
summary: Samudera Shipping Line, a Singapore-incorporated company, is considering re-entering the dry bulk vessel market to meet Indonesia's rising bulk shipping demand fueled by the country's value-added mining policy. The company, led by CEO Bani Mulia, plans to restore its bulk vessel chartering service as soon as possible. Samudera will adopt an asset-light approach, leasing some vessels and owning others, to provide flexibility in adjusting to market conditions. The move aims to mitigate the impact of freight-rate fluctuations on its mainstay container ship business.

images.alt_text: The vessels each have a capacity of 1,500 twenty-foot equivalent units.
The group’s performance in Q1 2023 is better than Q1 2021, Samudera said.

site_title: Temasek should offer more information on its activities, investments in emerging tech fields
summary: Temasek's FY2023 performance was marked by a 5.07% total shareholder return, the lowest in 7 years, due to global market turmoil and the collapse of cryptocurrency exchange FTX. However, the Singapore portfolio companies, such as Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Industries, and Seatrium, delivered relatively resilient performances. Temasek continues to invest in emerging tech fields, including quantum computing, artificial intelligence, and lithium-ion batteries, and has set up ventures to "enable innovation and growth across its ecosystem".

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Temasek logo is seen at the annual Temasek Review in Singapore July 7, 2016. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
“We are committed to the long-term success of SIA and continue to maintain a majority stake in it,” Juliet Teo, Temasek’s head of Transportation & Logistics, said in an emailed statement.
The closure of one of Singapore’s most promising biotech companies raises larger implications for the city-state’s emerging ecosystem.

Attendees at the Ant Group booth at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, July 6, 2023. The conference runs through July 8. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Temasek Holdings said that persistent inflatoin, geopolitical tensions and rising nationalism and protectionism led to an increase in the firm's cost of capital.
Temasek developed its T2030 strategy in 2019 as its 10-year roadmap to guide strategic planning and capability building for the organisation.

site_title: UBS to retain EY as auditor after Credit Suisse takeover
summary: UBS will retain Ernst & Young (EY) as its external auditor, expanding its role to include Credit Suisse's accounts from 2024. This decision comes after UBS acquired Credit Suisse for $3.48 billion in March. The audit will require EY to call in staff from other countries, and PwC will continue to audit Credit Suisse's accounts for 2023.

site_title: US envoy Kerry arrives in China to restart climate talks
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry arrived in China on July 16 to restart stalled climate talks with Chinese counterpart Xie Zhenhua, following record-breaking summer heat exacerbated by climate change. Kerry's trip comes after weeks of record heat globally and follows US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's previous visits to stabilize US-China ties. Kerry aims to engage with Chinese officials on increasing implementation and ambition on climate change, ahead of the UN climate talks in November.

images.alt_text: US Special Presidential Envoy for Climate John Kerry speaks during an event on the sidelines of  the COP27 climate conference at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, on November 8, 2022. (Photo by Joseph EID / AFP)

site_title: Oil capital of Canada sees home prices jump as newcomers rush in
summary: Calgary, the oil-rich city in Alberta, Canada, saw its benchmark home price rise 1.5% in June, driven by a surge in international and domestic newcomers. This marks the largest increase among over 50 Canadian markets, with prices rising 4.2% in a year. The influx of new residents is attributed to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's push for immigration and a shortage of affordable housing in other Canadian cities. Despite a decline in oil prices, Calgary's benchmark price of C$538,000 remains less than half that of Vancouver and Toronto.

images.alt_text: Britain’s housing market faces pressure from softer buyer demand and falling house prices against a backdrop of surging mortgage rates and the Bank of England’s battle to tame stubborn inflation.

site_title: Several carmakers shipping EVs here that are almost uniquely Singapore
summary: Several car manufacturers are producing electric vehicles (EVs) specifically designed for Singapore's unique Certificate of Entitlement (COE) system, which favors lower-power EVs. Examples include the Category A COE-friendly 100 kW version of the BYD Atto 3, the 99 kW version of the MG ZS, and two upcoming Hyundai EVs with less than 110 kW output. These models are not commonly available in other markets, and manufacturers are adapting their power output to meet the COE requirement, which can take months to develop and test. The move aims to lower the cost of buying a new mass market EV in Singapore.

images.alt_text: A CCS2 charging plug on an electric vehicle.

site_title: 10 S-Reits which outperformed in H1
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) outperformed the market in the first half of 2023, with the iEdge S-Reit Index generating 2.1% in total returns. The top 10 best-performing S-Reits, including Keppel DC Reit and Cromwell E-Reit, generated over 9.3% in total returns, driven by growth in distributable income and distribution per unit. The outperformance was driven by specialised, healthcare, and hospitality sub-sectors, while office, retail, and industrial sub-sectors underperformed.

images.alt_text:
0620 Yy / Media Release: Keppel DC REIT strengthens portfolio with two data centres in Guangdong, China
/ 20 June 2022, Singapore – Keppel DC REIT has entered into agreements with Guangdong Bluesea Data Development Co. Ltd. (Bluesea) and its parent company, Guangdong Bluesea Mobile Development Co. Ltd., to acquire two data centre facilities, on a fully-fitted basis, in Jiangmen, Guangdong Province, for RMB 1,380.6 million (approximately S$297.1 million).

site_title: Hybrids and EVs outsell petrol cars in H1, but EV adoption appears to be flatlining
summary: In the first half of 2023, electrified cars made up 56.9% of new passenger car registrations in Singapore, with hybrids and EVs outselling petrol cars. However, the adoption of EVs appears to be flatlining, with 14% of new car registrations being EVs, down from 14.3% in 2022. Petrol-electric hybrids dominated the market, accounting for 41.5% of new car registrations, followed by petrol cars, which still comprise 84.8% of the car population.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen Group Singapore managing director Kurt Wagner next to the Volkswagen ID.4 GTX electric SUV.

Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD and its Dolphin compact hatchback on display at Waterway Point. BYD's most compact car to date, the Dolphin is one of the cheapest EV on the Singapore market.

site_title: New book claims to reveal identity of Jack the Ripper
summary: A new book claims to reveal the identity of Jack the Ripper as Hyam Hyams, a 35-year-old cigar-maker who was in and out of mental asylums due to epilepsy and alcoholism. The author, Sarah Bax Horton, found similarities in Hyams' physical appearance, medical records, and a history of violent behavior with witness descriptions of the suspect. Hyams had an injury that left him unable to bend or extend his left arm, and was permanently committed to a mental asylum in 1889.

images.alt_text: The new 25-kilometre “super sewer”, which is 7.2 metres in diameter, snakes from west to east following the curves of the river; the large concrete shaft that is part of the Thames Tideway tunnel in west London.

site_title:
Shopify fuels meeting purge by shaming employees 
with cost calculator
summary: Shopify has introduced a cost calculator that estimates the cost of meetings with three or more people, aiming to reduce unnecessary gatherings. The tool, part of a year-long effort to cut out 322,000 hours and 474,000 discrete events in 2023, uses average compensation data and meeting length to put a price tag on events. Executives and employees say they spend hours in meetings that could disappear without consequence, and the company aims to change the default answer from yes to no.

images.alt_text: The assistant can also help entrepreneurs update their stores on Shopify.
“I don’t want to bury the lede: after today Shopify will be smaller by about 20 per cent,” chief executive officer Tobi Lütke said in a memo to staff.
When meetings run back-to-back, employees have little time to prepare or to follow up; the value of getting together is wasted.

site_title: Pound bulls face reckoning after currency’s best week this year
summary: Speculative traders are trimming bullish bets on the pound after it reached its strongest level in over five years ahead of the inflation report. Traders are concerned that high interest rates may eventually break down the economy, causing investors to sell and positioning to look stretched. The pound rose to nearly US$1.30 this week, its best week of the year, but faces a test in the inflation report, where even a faster-than-expected rate could work against it.

images.alt_text: The greenback is on track for its biggest weekly decline since November against a basket of six major currencies.

site_title: Britain inks treaty to formally join trans-Pacific free trade pact
summary: The UK has officially joined the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a free trade pact with 11 other countries. The UK's membership, signed in Auckland on July 16, 2023, brings the agreement to 12 members and accounts for about 15% of global GDP. The pact is expected to boost UK businesses and trade, with over 400,000 jobs and £182 billion in investment already linked to CPTPP countries. The agreement will also reduce tariffs on UK exports and imports, benefiting industries such as whisky and dairy farming.

images.alt_text: The signing will take place at a ministerial meeting of members of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, hosted by New Zealand.
Universities such as Cambridge (pictured) and Oxford are expected to support the new investment zones with research, data and knowhow.
Rows of houses in front of the Canary Wharf skyline in London. The UK has concluded negotiations to join the 11-member Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership.

site_title: Why Amazon put services in the spotlight for Prime Day
summary: Amazon's 2-day Prime Day event drew 200 million US Prime members, resulting in $12.7 billion in merchandise sales, a 6.1% year-over-year increase. The event also featured deals on services such as food delivery, travel, and healthcare, with partnerships with companies like Grubhub and Priceline. Amazon aims to move up the value chain and generate more revenue from services, which could bolster its advertising services and increase its market share.

images.alt_text: Amazon has also offered for the first time Prime Day travel discount, partnering with travel booking site Priceline.
An Amazon worker prepares to deliver orders on Amazon Prime Day in New York City. Consumers spent US$6.4 billion online in the first 24 hours of the event.
Amazon’s competition has likewise focused on reducing costs and has marketed free previews of such technology, though final pricing remained unclear.

site_title:
Think better education brings more jobs?
Not for Chinese women
summary: China's education system and job market perpetuate gender-based discrimination against women, hindering their career advancement and participation in the workforce. Women with higher education face a 21% lower job offer rate compared to men, and are often asked about their family plans during interviews, with 61% of women reporting invasive questions. This discriminatory practice discourages women from having children and staying in the labor market, contributing to China's widening gender gap and weakening economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A parents pushes a stroller with a baby in a park in Shanghai, China, April 2, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Many Chinese women are reluctant to have more than one or even any children due to the high costs of child-rearing and as the lack of childcare.

China dug itself into a demographic hole largely through its one-child policy imposed between 1980 and 2015. Authorities raised the limit to three in 2021, but even during the stay at home Covid-19 times couples have been reluctant to have babies.

site_title: Billionaire Adani gets final nod to revamp famous Mumbai slum
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani's real estate unit has received final approval to start the redevelopment of Dharavi, one of Asia's largest slums in Mumbai. Adani won the project with a bid of 50.7 billion rupees, transforming the slum into modern apartments, offices, and malls. The project has been met with protests from local inhabitants, who are concerned about relocation and poor amenities. Adani's plans are still opaque, but the project is expected to extend his foothold in India's financial capital.

images.alt_text: By selling shares through qualified institutional placement, or QIP, Adani Green is looking to bring on board more institutional investors and attract more research analysts to cover the firm.
Adani’s commentary is part of a wider effort to rebuild investor trust after Hindenburg accused his eponymous conglomerate of widespread corporate malfeasance in January.
The JV, called AdaniConneX, will seek to build a 1 GW clean energy data centre platform by 2030, with investments planned across India, the company added.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the facade of its Corporate House on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

Signage of Adani Group in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, on Feb. 15, 2023. Adani Group said it has adequate cash reserves and its listed companies are able to refinance their debts, in a credit report aimed at reassuring investors after a critical investigation by US short-seller Hindenburg Research last month.. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

site_title: London's new 'super sewer' to end Thames pollution blight
summary: London's new 25-kilometer "super sewer" is nearing completion, aiming to end the city's pollution blight by carrying 95% of sewage away from the Thames. The £4.3 billion project, 7.2 meters in diameter, snakes along the river's curves and will divert untreated sewage into the new tunnel during heavy rainfall. Once operational, it's expected to significantly reduce the 40 million tonnes of sewage spilling into the Thames each year, improving the river's health and environment. The project is a major upgrade to London's 19th-century sewers, which have been inadequate due to the city's population growth.

images.alt_text: A photograph taken on June 14, 2023 shows a large concrete shaft part of the Thames Tideway tunnel in west London. London's existing sewerage network dates back to the second half of the 1800s. With the size of the population set to continue to swell, the need for the £4.3-billion ($5.6-billion) upgrade has become critical. The new 25-kilometre (15-mile) "super sewer" is 7.2 metres in diameter and snakes from west to east following the curves of the river. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: Iraq honey production at the mercy of heat and drought
summary: Iraq's honey production is severely impacted by the current heatwave and drought, with beekeepers reporting a significant decline in honey yields due to bees traveling longer distances to find food and being exposed to extreme temperatures. The situation is exacerbated by climate change, which has led to a fourth consecutive year of drought in the country. Despite efforts to relocate bee hives to cooler regions, honey production remains a concern, with yields plummeting to 5 kg per year from 20-25 kg previously.
