images.alt_text: The two competitive grant programmes with US$20 billion in funding are the latest move by Biden administration to support projects that reduce planet warming emissions.

site_title: Why it matters whether crypto coins like Ripple’s are considered securities
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) considers a range of widely-traded digital assets to be securities, potentially imposing regulatory requirements that could be crippling for the crypto industry. Chair Gary Gensler has taken a hard line, suing Coinbase and Binance for listing unregistered securities. The SEC's Howey test applies to determine if an asset is a security, involving investors' intention to profit from an organization's efforts. The crypto community wants the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to oversee crypto assets, which would be less onerous. Globally, regulators have taken varying positions on treating cryptocurrencies as securities.

images.alt_text: The layoffs at the world’s biggest crypto exchange come at a time when the industry’s future in the US market is uncertain.

The case has been closely watched in the cryptocurrency industry, which disputes the SEC’s assertion that the vast majority of crypto tokens are securities and subject to its strict investor protection rules.
The crypto industry has been on even shakier ground since the US SEC sued crypto exchanges Binance and Coinbase Global last month raised risks of further regulatory challenges for the sector.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore has given in-principle approval to Ripple for a major payments institution licence.

site_title: Former BNY Mellon executive says he was fired for aiding friend’s complaint
summary: BNY Mellon was sued by former executive Jonathan Spirgel, who claims the bank fired him after 32 years due to his age and gender, as well as his aid in a male colleague's complaint against a female coworker. Spirgel alleges the bank took no action against the female salesperson despite a "sham investigation." The bank fired Spirgel and a male colleague in June 2020, but took no action against the female salesperson, who had made "egregious misconduct" allegations. BNY Mellon has stated it looks forward to defending itself in the case.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrency markets plunged in 2022, as rising interest rates and a series of high-profile collapses at crypto firms made investors cautious.

site_title: US homeowners are tapping US$9 trillion in real estate wealth
summary: US homeowners are tapping into their real estate wealth, borrowing $9 trillion through home equity lines of credit (Helocs) as mortgage rates surge. With interest rates nearly doubling, lenders have become more open to Helocs, which can be costly, especially with variable rates. Despite this, Americans are increasingly using Helocs to access cash, with 1.41 million individual loans originating in 2022, a 34% increase from the prior year. Homeowners are using the funds for repairs, tuition, and emergency expenses, citing the need for liquidity and flexibility.

images.alt_text: A person jogs past a row of residential housing in south London, Britain, August 6, 2021. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: Union Gas Holdings’ Teo Hark Piang ups stake to 8.05%
summary: Union Gas Holdings' CEO Teo Hark Piang increased his stake to 8.05% after acquiring 97,500 shares between Jul 11 and 12 for S$35,253. The Straits Times Index rose 2.8% over the five trading sessions, with institutions net buying S$67 million in Singapore stocks. Meanwhile, Airports of Thailand and CP All SDR attracted net buying interest from individual investors. PTT Exploration & Production saw the strongest gains among the SDR trio, with a 3.6% gain over the five sessions.

images.alt_text: On Jul 5, JEP Holdings executive chairman Andy Luong acquired 150,000 shares at an average price of S$0.305 per share.

site_title: Shell to supply Morocco with LNG in 12-year deal
summary: Shell has agreed to supply Morocco with 0.5 billion cubic meters of liquefied natural gas (LNG) per year under a 12-year deal. The gas will be transported from Spanish ports via a pipeline to Morocco until the country builds its own LNG terminals. The deal aims to help Morocco increase its share of gas in electricity production to meet low-carbon goals, with renewables currently accounting for 18% of total electricity production.

site_title: MOH Holdings says not in discussions to lease space at Labrador Tower
summary: MOH Holdings has denied being in discussions to lease space at Labrador Tower, a development by SP Group. The clarification comes after The Business Times reported that MOH Holdings was nearing an office lease deal for approximately 140,000 sq ft. Industry sources had expected MOH Holdings to join insurer Prudential in leasing space at the new development, set to be completed next year.

site_title: Roblox business chief to depart
summary: Roblox's Chief Business Officer Craig Donato is leaving the company at the end of the summer after nearly seven years. Donato will be replaced by Christina Wootton, who has been promoted to Chief Partnerships Officer, overseeing business relationships with major brands. Wootton has worked with brands like Gucci and Disney to develop a presence in the Roblox metaverse. Arvind KC will take over the recruiting division of human resources. The company is available to 66 million daily users across mobile devices, desktops, and Microsoft's Xbox.

images.alt_text: Roblox revives plans to go public
The game will arrive as a beta version, initially on Quest 2 and Quest Pro, in the coming weeks.

Roblox, which is among the world’s most popular gaming sites for children, has been constantly racing to expand its user base by doubling down on collaborations with NFL, Fifa and artists such as Elton John and Mariah Carey.
Roblox plans to go public through direct listing, not IPO: sources

site_title: JPMorgan eyes sale of US$350 million loan on Manhattan’s HSBC Tower
summary: JPMorgan is seeking to sell a $350 million loan backing Manhattan's HSBC Tower, a 30-storey building that has struggled in the past year. The bank is offering financing with cheaper-than-market rates to potential buyers. This move comes as banks face pressure to reduce exposure to office real estate due to rising borrowing costs and declining demand. The loan, which matures in 2024, is the latest in a series of failed attempts to sell the building, which has seen its value fall to $720 million.

images.alt_text: Lenders’ exposure to commercial real estate has come under growing scrutiny this year.
JPMorgan’s profit climbs to US$14.47 billion, or US$4.75 per share, for the quarter ended Jun 30.

site_title: Pofma orders issued to Kenneth Jeyaretnam, FB user and online site over Ridout Road rentals
summary: The Ministry of Law issued correction orders to opposition politician Kenneth Jeyaretnam and Facebook user Thamil Selvan over false statements about the Ridout Road rentals. The orders relate to an article and social media post claiming the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) awarded contracts to renovate two colonial-era bungalows to a home interior company owned by Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam's son. However, SLA denied the claims, stating the contracts were awarded through open tenders to separate contractors. Jeyaretnam and Thamil are required to carry correction notices on their website and social media accounts.

site_title: High-yield bond ETF exodus gathers pace as 10% drains from funds
summary: Investors have pulled $1 billion from the iShares iBoxx High Yield Corporate Bond ETF, a high-yield bond fund, amid recession concerns. This is part of a broader exodus from US junk-bond funds, which have lost nearly 10% of their assets under management year-to-date. However, the best-performing asset classes in US fixed income are the riskiest, CCC high-yield bonds and leveraged loans, delivering double-digit returns. Investors are instead favoring high-quality debt, adding 2% to assets under management, as they seek safe returns amidst economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JULY 06: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on July 06, 2023 in New York City. The stock market opened up low amid the release of minutes from the June meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) by the Federal Reserve and an expected upcoming rate hike.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: How Netflix plans total global domination, one Korean drama at a time
summary: Netflix aims to dominate the entertainment world by focusing on content that resonates with a single market's audience, rather than creating globally appealing content. The company is allocating more of its $17 billion annual content budget to expanding its foreign language programming and attracting customers abroad, particularly in Asia and Latin America. With shows like "The Glory" and "Extraordinary Attorney Woo" gaining popularity, Netflix is betting on locally produced content to succeed globally. The company's efforts have led to a significant increase in subscribers watching Korean-language shows and movies, with 60% of Netflix subscribers watching a Korean-language show or movie last year.

images.alt_text: South Korea has already become one of Netflix’s biggest suppliers of TV shows and films, helping fuel a surge in global subscriptions as more consumers tune in to Korean dramas and reality shows.
Crunchyroll expects the anime industry will have more than 800 million fans globally by 2025 outside markets in China and Japan.

The SAG-AFTRA, which represents 160,000 performers including A-list stars, said negotiations had ended without a deal on their demands over dwindling pay and the threat posed by artificial intelligence.

site_title: Gold poised for best week in 3 months on Fed pause bets
summary: Gold prices rose to their highest since June 16, gaining about 1.8% for the week, amid expectations of a pause in Federal Reserve interest rate hikes due to slowing US inflation. The benchmark US yield edged up, making non-yielding bullion less attractive to investors, but the dollar was on track for its biggest weekly decline since November.

images.alt_text: Gold is used as a safe investment during times of political and financial uncertainty, but higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.
India levies a 15 per cent tax on gold imports.
Gold is used as a safe investment during times of political and financial uncertainty, but higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Drawing lessons from history to make a case for Chinese equities
summary: Chinese equities are undervalued, both in absolute terms and relative to historical valuation and global peers, despite concerns over geopolitical challenges, regulatory uncertainty, and a property bust. A quarter century ago, Asian markets bottomed out during the Asian Financial Crisis, laying the groundwork for future growth. Today, Chinese equities face similar discomfort, but history suggests that undervaluation and overlooked positive trends can create fertile ground for long-term investments, particularly in the energy transition and industrial transformation.

images.alt_text: As China eased Covid curbs to revitalise the economy, the increase in risk appetite prompted rapid declines in corporate bonds, triggering investor redemptions in bond-focused wealth management products and funds.

The benchmark CSI 300 Index of mainland shares will likely climb about 3 per cent this quarter while Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index may advance less than 6 per cent, according to the median estimate of 18 analysts and money managers surveyed by Bloomberg News last week.

site_title: Kering boss Pinault in talks to buy majority of Hollywood agency CAA
summary: Francois-Henri Pinault, CEO of Gucci-owner Kering, is in advanced talks to buy a majority stake in Hollywood talent agency CAA, potentially valuing the agency at over $7 billion. CAA represents thousands of actors, directors, and music artists, including Tom Hanks and Beyonce. The deal could end without agreement and is seen as a big win for private equity firm TPG, which first invested in CAA in 2010. The sale comes amidst a strike by Hollywood actors and writers, deepening the disruption of film and television production.

images.alt_text: The SAG-AFTRA, which represents 160,000 performers including A-list stars, said negotiations had ended without a deal on their demands over dwindling pay and the threat posed by artificial intelligence.
“The acquisition clearly marks a major step for Kering Beaute, allowing it to reach critical mass in this category,” said Raffaella Cornaggia, CEO of Kering’s beauty division.

The walkout by 11,500 writers has shut down a wide swath of television production and delayed the filming of movies including Marvel’s “Thunderbolts” and “Blade.” Any ongoing filming would have to halt if actors also strike.

site_title: S’pore has never had a PM who prevented CPIB from doing its work: Tharman on Iswaran probe
summary: Former senior minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, a presidential hopeful, stated that Singapore has never had a Prime Minister who prevented the Corrupt Practices Investigations Bureau (CPIB) from doing its work. He emphasized the importance of transparency and integrity in the country's system, saying that the CPIB is given full rein to investigate cases. Tharman expressed confidence in Transport Minister S. Iswaran, who is currently under CPIB probe, and urged the investigation to take its course without making judgments.

DPM Lawrence Wong says that he and PM Lee Hsien Loong are “fully committed” to keeping and preserving the trust that the people have in the government.
Iswaran will take a leave of absence until the investigations are complete.

site_title: US Virgin Islands demands US$190 million from JPMorgan in Epstein case
summary: The US Virgin Islands is seeking a total of $190 million from JPMorgan Chase in a lawsuit accusing the bank of ignoring Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking. The territory wants $150 million in civil fines and $40 million from JPMorgan's 15-year relationship with Epstein, as well as damages for Epstein's victims and conduct changes to ensure the bank prioritizes public safety. A trial is scheduled for October 23, and this is the largest unresolved Epstein-related case.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit filed by the victims charged that JPMorgan ignored repeated warnings that Epstein had been trafficking teenage girls and young women for sex, even after he registered as a sex offender and pleaded guilty in a 2008 Florida case to soliciting prostitution from a teenage girl.
JPMorgan’s profit climbs to US$14.47 billion, or US$4.75 per share, for the quarter ended Jun 30.
The city’s cash-rich property tycoons may take advantage of the cheap valuations to buy assets, conduct share buybacks or take out minority shareholders at a time.

site_title: Modi and Macron agree on 25-year plan to deepen cooperation
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and French President Emmanuel Macron agreed on a 25-year plan to deepen cooperation in defense, nuclear energy, and space, with a focus on countering China's growing assertiveness in the Indo-Pacific region. The two leaders discussed joint production of defense equipment and cooperation on small modular nuclear reactors. They also coordinated their policies in the region, with Macron planning to visit India in September. The agreement comes as India seeks to position itself as a bulwark against China, and France aims to strengthen ties with emerging powers.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi (left) with French President Emmanuel Macron. Modi will be the guest of honour at Bastille Day celebrations in Paris on Jul 14.

India Health Minister Mansukh Mandaviya says the country’s national and state drug regulators have taken action against 105 pharmaceutical companies after risk-based inspections and audits found their products did not meet quality standards.

A cashier counts Indian one hundred-rupee banknotes at an Oriental Bank of Commerce branch in New Delhi, India, on Monday, May 7, 2012. site_title: Former GIC investment chief Ng Kok Song ‘deliberating’ bid for Singapore presidency
summary: Former GIC investment chief Ng Kok Song, 75, is "deliberating" a run for Singapore's presidency. Ng retired from GIC in 2013 after 27 years, and the decision to run is seen as a "great national importance" with "immense personal implications." An online report previously suggested he could be a candidate in the upcoming presidential election, but Ng has not made any official announcement yet.

images.alt_text: Presidential hopeful and former senior minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam made the comments while speaking to reporters during his campaign trail in Teck Whye.
Goh said he would not publicly disclose any further details of his case for candidature.

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Jurong GRC MPs (from left) Shawn Huang, Rahayu Mahzam and Xie Yao Quan at the opening of ActiveSG Sport Village @ Jurong Town on Sunday; Tharman says: "Having a contest is important for me. I much rather win or lose with the contest. My whole approach is not to shy away from competition, it has always been that way. It’s how I prove myself."

site_title: China's BYD says H1 net profit could more than triple
summary: Chinese electric vehicle giant BYD forecasts a 225.4% increase in its six-month net profit to 11.7 billion yuan (S$2.2 billion), driven by strong car sales and increased market share. The company's new energy vehicle sales have achieved significant growth, solidifying its leadership in the industry. BYD's forecast is buoyed by record deliveries of China-made vehicles by itself and US rival Tesla.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Members of the press and the general public check out the Atto 3 electric SUV made by Chinese carmaker BYD, at the Fully Charged Live electric vehicle trade show in Farnborough, Britain, April 28, 2023. REUTERS/Nick Carey/File Photo

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending July 14, 2023, reveals a mixed market with fluctuations in rates and shifting sentiment. The Capesize market declined due to an abundance of available vessels, while the North Atlantic market experienced heightened activity, leading to increased volume and scarcity of tonnage. In contrast, the Panamax market gained positive gains, with the Atlantic market absorbing tonnage worldwide. The Ultramax/Supramax sector had a mixed week, with the US Gulf region bucking the trend. Handysize vessels saw systematic erosion of levels due to limited enquiry. Clean freight rates were subdued, with LR2s and MRs experiencing limited enquiry. The Suezmax market had a busier week, with West Africa seeing increased activity. Aframax rates improved in the US, while LNG and LPG spot rates remained flat.

site_title: South Korea hit with landslides, flooding, hundreds evacuated
summary: South Korea experienced landslides and flooding on July 15, forcing hundreds of people to evacuate. Over 882 people were evacuated nationwide, with the number expected to rise as a dam in North Chungcheong province overtopped with water. Two deaths, one missing, and six injured were reported, and multiple landslides threatened safety on the railroad. The government ordered the evacuation of over 7,000 people and called for military assistance in rescue activities. Prime Minister Han Duck-soo urged the military to join in rescue efforts.

images.alt_text: Yoo Ha-jin, 27, looks at a building where she lives in Seoul, South Korea, February 21, 2023.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji
Mortgage loans jumped by 7.0 trillion won compared with 4.2 trillion won the previous month.
Representatives from 11 foreign institutions including JPMorgan Chase Bank, HSBC Bank, MUFG Bank, Yuanta Securities, Goldman Sachs Securities, insurers, and investment companies attended.

site_title: Alibaba-backed Trendyol hit by Turkey e-commerce ruling
summary: Turkey's Constitutional Court upheld a law regulating e-commerce companies, which restricts advertising spending and customer data use for companies with high sales volumes. The law, set to take effect in January 2024, aims to help smaller e-commerce firms compete with market leader Trendyol, 70% owned by Alibaba. The ruling is seen as a blow to Trendyol, which has rapid growth since the pandemic. Turkey's total e-commerce volume rose 109% last year to over $40.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Alibaba, which spun off Ant 11 years ago and has a 33 per cent stake, said on Sunday it was considering whether to participate in the buyback.

On Saturday, Ant proposed to buy back as much as 7.6 per cent of shares in an effort to provide a chance to cut stakes for investors ensnared by a years-long regulatory crackdown at the fintech powerhouse.
Alibaba's AI image generator, Tongyi Wanxiang, will compete with OpenAI’s DALL-E and Midjourney’s Midjourney

site_title: US FTC seeks additional info on Pfizer's proposed takeover of Seagen
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has requested additional information and documentary material related to Pfizer's proposed $43 billion acquisition of Seagen Inc. The deal, which aims to counter falling Covid-related sales and generic competition, is expected to complete in late 2023 or 2024. The FTC's scrutiny comes after the recent blockage of Amgen's $27.8 billion deal to buy Horizon Therapeutics, making investors cautious about the Pfizer-Seagen deal.

site_title: US appeals court refuses FTC request to pause Microsoft deal for Activision
summary: A US appeals court has rejected the Federal Trade Commission's (FTC) request to pause Microsoft's $69 billion purchase of Activision Blizzard, clearing the way for the Xbox maker to expand its gaming business. The FTC had asked a judge to temporarily halt the deal, but the request was denied. The decision removes one of the few remaining hurdles for Microsoft to close the deal.

images.alt_text: The software giant is re-engaging in talks with the UK Competition and Markets Authority, which had vetoed the deal in May.
Any outstanding regulatory hurdle makes it more likely the agreement between Microsoft and Activision will expire on Jul 18 without the deal having been completed.
The FTC says that by buying video-game publisher Activision Blizzard, Microsoft would gain an unfair advantage in consoles and cloud-gaming.

“We’re grateful to the court in San Francisco for this quick and thorough decision and hope other jurisdictions will continue working towards a timely resolution,” Microsoft president Brad Smith says.

site_title: US chip CEOs plan Washington trip to talk China policy: sources
summary: Intel Corp and Qualcomm executives plan to visit Washington next week to discuss China policy with US officials, focusing on market conditions, export controls, and other business matters. The trip comes amid US officials considering tightening export rules affecting high-performance computing chips and shipments to Huawei Technologies. The possible rule tightening would impact Intel, which is preparing a new artificial intelligence chip for China, and Qualcomm, which has a license to sell chips to Huawei. Other semiconductor CEOs may also attend meetings in Washington.

images.alt_text: Singapore semiconductor firms said they source their materials from a multiple countries and do not expect to see an impact from China's export curbs.
Governments are doling out enormous subsidies to manufacturers, especially chipmakers and those behind green technologies.
In the long run, if Micron is unable to eliminate the concerns of Chinese regulators, it will essentially lose the entire China market, said a semiconductor industry expert in Beijing.
Around the turn of the century, manufactured goods accounted for more than 80 per cent of US merchandise exports. By 2022, this share had shrunk to below 60 per cent.
Nvidia is a long-time partner and client of Arm.
Huawei shipped 240.6 million smartphones worldwide in 2019, its peak year, according to Canalys, before selling its Honor unit that accounted for nearly a fifth of shipments that year.

site_title: US lawmakers are wary of Threads but about half have signed up
summary: US lawmakers have joined Meta's new social media platform Threads at a rate of almost half of Congress, with 194 House members and 48 senators signing up since its launch on July 6. Despite concerns over data privacy and content practices, Democrats and Republicans alike see Threads as a way to reach constituents and promote their messaging. The platform has gained 100 million users in five days, with Democrats outnumbering Republicans on the platform, but some lawmakers, including Elizabeth Warren, remain skeptical about the need for another social media platform.

images.alt_text: Threads’ current momentum will quickly lose steam if the “town square” is sanitised into nothing more than a picture-less Instagram, a network known first and foremost as a place that puts an unrealistic sheen on reality.
Meta has left the door open for a Threads launch in Europe and few expect it to maintain its embargo indefinitely.
The branded content tools will help marketers collaborate with influencers on paid partnerships on the social media platform while advertising is unavailable.

Several rivals to Twitter have emerged but most do not have the capacity to grow at the necessary scale to dethrone Twitter. Threads is finding it easier because it is linked to Instagram, which has more than one billion regular users.

site_title: Binance lays off employees days after executive exodus
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, has laid off over 1,000 employees, just days after a wave of executive exits. The layoffs come as the industry's future in the US market is uncertain, with regulators cracking down on alleged illegal activities. CEO Changpeng Zhao denied the reports, stating the exchange is "still hiring." The job cuts follow a recent SEC lawsuit against Binance and its CEO, and a US judge's decision in favor of crypto firm Ripple Labs, which suggests regulators are facing an uphill battle.

images.alt_text: Binance faces a web of probes around the world.
Beijing clamped down on crypto over concerns about money laundering, the environmental impact of Bitcoin mining and currency outflows.
Binance typically accesses Sepa via payment intermediaries.
On Tuesday, Binance.US and the SEC agreed to work on a deal that avoids a total asset freeze at the cryptocurrency trading platform.

site_title: Nokia misses Q2 expectations, lowers full-year guidance
summary: Nokia reported 2Q sales of €5.7 billion, lower than expected, and lowered its full-year sales guidance to €23.2-24.6 billion, down from previous estimates. The company also narrowed its comparable operating margin range to 11.5-13% from 11.5-14%. Shares fell 9.4% on the news. The decline is attributed to Nokia's Network Infrastructure and Mobile Networks business groups.

site_title: Citigroup says it ‘significantly’ curbed lending to buyout firms
summary: Citigroup has significantly reduced its lending to buyout firms as part of its efforts to improve its ratio of revenue to risk-weighted assets. The bank cut back on its subscription credit facilities, which allow private equity funds to borrow short-term, after finding low returns and unfruitful prospects. Citigroup aims to boost returns and has successfully reduced risk-weighted assets by $120 billion in the past two years. The bank is also preparing for increased capital requirements under Basel III and the Federal Reserve's supervision efforts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Jamie Dimon, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of JPMorgan Chase & Co., gestures as he speaks during an interview with Reuters in Miami, Florida, U.S., February 8, 2023. REUTERS/Marco Bello/File Photo
Citi’s markets revenue falls 13 per cent to US$4.6 billion on more subdued activity in fixed income and equities.
Morgan Stanley’s EPS is anticipated to drop 9 per cent, although revenue from wealth management will likely cushion the blow from lacklustre dealmaking.

site_title: Microsoft says Chinese hackers used code flaw to steal emails from US agencies
summary: Chinese state-linked hackers secretly accessed email accounts at around 25 US organisations since May, including at least two government agencies, using a flaw in Microsoft's code. Microsoft said hackers misappropriated a digital key and exploited a validation error to steal emails. Beijing denies involvement, but US officials say the action is "deeply concerning" and they will hold those responsible accountable. Microsoft is reviewing its security practices and considering making its top-level digital auditing available to all customers free of charge.

images.alt_text: The software giant is re-engaging in talks with the UK Competition and Markets Authority, which had vetoed the deal in May.
Any outstanding regulatory hurdle makes it more likely the agreement between Microsoft and Activision will expire on Jul 18 without the deal having been completed.
The FTC says that by buying video-game publisher Activision Blizzard, Microsoft would gain an unfair advantage in consoles and cloud-gaming.

site_title: 'Artificially high' growth predicted for China in Q2: survey
summary: China's economy is expected to have expanded 7.1% in the second quarter, according to a survey of 13 experts, but this figure is considered "artificially high" due to the low base of comparison with the pandemic-wracked 2022. Experts predict a slowdown in growth, citing a sluggish job market, low consumer confidence, and a crisis in the real estate sector. This could lead to deflation and further economic woes, with exports declining 12.4% in June. The government has set a growth target of 5% for 2023, which experts expect to be met at 5.3%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An electronic board shows Shanghai and Shenzhen stock indices at the Lujiazui financial district in Shanghai, China, March 17, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Coinbase limiting staking service for retail customers in four states
summary: Coinbase is limiting its staking service for retail customers in California, New Jersey, South Carolina, and Wisconsin, pending proceedings initiated by the states last month. The staking program, which allows users to lock up cryptocurrency assets for yield, has been challenged by 10 states accusing Coinbase of violating state securities laws. Users who staked cryptocurrencies before June 6 are unaffected, but new pledges will be restricted until the issue is resolved.

site_title: Government awards 80 MW of new capacity to 4 data centre operators in pilot exercise
summary: The Singapore government has awarded around 80 MW of new data centre capacity to four operators, Equinix, GDS, Microsoft, and an AirTrunk-ByteDance consortium, through a pilot exercise called DC-CFA. The pilot aims to facilitate sustainable data centre growth and received over 20 proposals. The selected operators met desired outcomes by delivering energy-efficient performance and expanding international connectivity. The government plans to allocate more capacity in the next 12-18 months and engage industry stakeholders on future data centres, including building a competitive AI ecosystem.

images.alt_text: As we demand more of data centre infrastructure, they will need further cooling improvements to keep temperatures under control.

site_title: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo prepare for losses on office loans
summary: JPMorgan and Wells Fargo have set aside more funds for expected losses from commercial real estate loans, amid growing scrutiny of the sector due to high interest rates and remote work. Wells Fargo reported a $949 million increase in its allowance for credit losses, primarily due to its office loan portfolio. This move indicates stress building in the commercial real estate market, which has been pressured by these factors.

images.alt_text: For all the battering that Hong Kong has taken, prices in its bellwether office sector have fallen only 7 per cent over the past two years.
Wells Fargo reports profit of US$1.25 per share for the three months ended Jun 30.

epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: A ‘trade policy for the middle class’ will not save US manufacturing
summary: US trade policy is shifting towards a "fairer, more durable global economic order" to address the decline of American manufacturing. Despite free trade's benefits, US workers got a raw deal as the country's industrial base was hollowed out. Energy production, particularly oil and natural gas, drove the decline, rather than globalization. The US is an outlier in manufacturing exports compared to other developed economies. The Biden administration's "Buy American" policies and trade tariffs are unlikely to revive US manufacturing, as the sector's contribution to exports is largely driven by macroeconomic forces and other factors, such as the state of education and apprenticeship programs.

images.alt_text: Pinning US distributional woes, such as inequality or stagnant middle-class wages, on trade is mistaken, even if it is easier to blame foreigners rather than take responsibility.
While the Biden administration push, described by economists as an industrial policy, has opened opportunities for some companies, significant hurdles remain.

site_title: US: Stocks finish buoyant week on muted note
summary: US stocks ended a winning week on a muted note, with the S&P 500 down 0.1% and the Nasdaq 0.2% lower, despite strong earnings from large banks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3%. The week's gains followed consumer price data that raised hopes the Federal Reserve may end interest rate hikes soon. Stocks were affected by a strike in the entertainment industry, with Disney, Netflix, Warner Bros. Discovery, and Paramount dropping 2.0%, 1.9%, 5.3%, and 5.1%, respectively.

site_title: US banks point to resilient but slowing economy, flag risks ahead
summary: US banks reported mixed earnings, with JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo experiencing sharp increases in net interest income, driving up profits. However, Citigroup's profit tumbled 36% due to weakness in its trading business. Despite this, banks noted that US consumers still have a healthy balance sheet, but warned of slowing spending and a modest deterioration in consumer debt. Economists expect the economy to continue slowing, with Wells Fargo CEO Charlie Scharf stating that the range of scenarios for the economy should narrow over the next few quarters.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan’s profit climbs to US$14.47 billion, or US$4.75 per share, for the quarter ended Jun 30.
Citi’s markets revenue falls 13 per cent to US$4.6 billion on more subdued activity in fixed income and equities.
Wells Fargo reports profit of US$1.25 per share for the three months ended Jun 30.

site_title: Oil prices fall on profit-taking, still record weekly gain
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, with Brent crude futures settling at US$79.87 per barrel, down US$1.49, or 1.8%, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settling at US$75.42 a barrel, down US$1.47, or 1.9%. The decline was attributed to profit-taking and a strengthening US dollar, which reduces oil demand. Despite the short-term drop, analysts predict the market may resume its rally next week due to easing inflation, supply cuts, and disruptions. Oil prices gained nearly 2% on a weekly basis.

images.alt_text: High temperatures with dry conditions for a prolonged period of time could wipe out crop harvests of agri commodities like sugar and palm oil, while cold temperatures or frost could stall harvests as well.
Markets expect just one more rate rise.

Russian crude oil tanker ship Clyde Noble is seen berthed at the Karachi Port, Pakistan, June 28, 2023. Pakistan received its second cargo of discounted Russian crude oil as part of a new deal between Islamabad and Moscow.

site_title: US import prices decline further in June
summary: US import prices dropped 0.2% in June, the largest year-on-year decline since May 2020, according to the Labor Department. This marks the fifth consecutive month of decline, indicating easing inflationary pressures. The decline was largely due to a decrease in fuel costs, offsetting increases in other categories. Despite inflation remaining above the Federal Reserve's 2% target, economists expect an interest rate hike this month to be the last in the Fed's tightening cycle.

site_title: Singapore equities stand a chance to shine in H2 2023
summary: Singapore's equities are poised to shine in the second half of 2023, driven by a strong tourism sector and well-established companies that have bucked the global downtrend in corporate earnings. Despite elevated inflation, high interest rates, and geopolitical uncertainties, safe haven markets and stocks are expected to help investors ride out mounting economic uncertainties. Key factors supporting the Singapore market include government plans to grow key industries, low market valuations, and a strong focus on sustainable investments. The Straits Times Index has seen 1.8% earnings growth, and its stocks offer an average dividend yield of 5.1%.

images.alt_text: Taking on some risk by buying high quality dividend paying shares can be prudent.
Singapore's electronics exports are expected to rebound in coming months, helping to lift the manufactoring sector.

site_title: Ho Bee Land expects to report H1 net loss on fair-value losses in London portfolio
summary: Ho Bee Land, a mainboard-listed property developer and investor, expects to report a net loss for the first half of 2023 due to fair-value losses in its London portfolio. The losses are attributed to higher capitalization rates, and further details will be disclosed when the company announces its H1 2023 results on or before August 10. The company's shares fell 1% to close at S$2.01 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: US: Strong big bank earnings lift Wall Street at open
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Friday, July 14, 2023, after three major US banks, including JPMorgan and Wells Fargo, reported strong second-quarter earnings. The S&P 500 rose 0.10%, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.20%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also increased 0.09%. The positive start to the day follows a weaker open on Thursday, after US President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada.

site_title: Subsidies and protection for manufacturing will harm the world economy
summary: Governments worldwide are providing massive subsidies to manufacturers, particularly chipmakers and green technology companies, to combat climate change, enhance national security, and boost economic growth. However, this approach is expected to harm the world economy, as duplicating production reduces specialization, raises costs, and hinders economic growth. The estimated 10-year cost of America's green subsidies has risen by at least two-thirds and is likely to exceed $1 trillion. Experts warn that this industrial arms race will only lead to a "fenced-in yard" where countries become increasingly isolated and less competitive, ultimately harming their economies.

images.alt_text: Around the turn of the century, manufactured goods accounted for more than 80 per cent of US merchandise exports. By 2022, this share had shrunk to below 60 per cent.
To reach its ambitious goal in chip production, the EU will have to mobilise more than 43 billion euros (S$63.4 billion) in public and private investments.

Two employees of German semiconductor manufacturer Infineon Technologies AG work in a clean room on the production line of 300-millimeter wafers at the company's plant in Dresden, eastern Germany, on April 26, 2023. - German chipmaker Infineon will launch the groundbreaking of a new factory, the Smart Power Fab, in Dresden on May 2, 2023. Supply chain snarls during the Coronavirus pandemic have exposed how over-reliant Europe has become on chip imports from abroad in recent years, disrupting numerous industries that depend on the components. The European Union in 2022 launched a plan known as the "Chips Act", which aims to double Europe's market share in semiconductors by 2030. (Photo by JENS SCHLUETER / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Shares close best week in over three months on US disinflation hopes
summary: European stocks closed at their best week in over three months, gaining nearly 3% this week, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's decision on rate hikes amid hopes of disinflation. The Stoxx 600 index recouped losses from the previous week, with tech stocks leading the gains, while miners and telecom firms also performed well. Analysts expect the European Central Bank to pause rate hikes, and some predict one or two more hikes this year, with bond yields falling in response.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit was the best performing S-Reit in the first half of 2023, driven by stronger growth in distributable income and distribution per unit.
The Stoxx 600 falls 3.1 per cent for the week, its worst performance since mid-March.

site_title: Taking tea seriously as mixologists
summary: Mixology Salon Singapore, a Tokyo-based outpost, offers a unique experience blending traditional Japanese tea culture with modern mixology. The tea room features a selection of Japanese tea-based cocktails, including the signature Four Seams No 2, and a menu that explains the history and concept of Japanese tea. Manager Kaoru Takii aims to preserve and share Japanese tea culture, with plans to update the menu with local ingredients and potentially expand to other countries, incorporating local representation.

site_title: US consumer sentiment jumps to near two-year high on job market
summary: US consumer sentiment surged to a near two-year high in early July, reaching 72.6, driven by steady employment growth and wage gains. This marks the largest increase since 2006 and tops economists' forecasts. Short-term inflation expectations rose to 3.4%, still below last year's peak of 5.4%. The improvement is attributed to easing inflation and a strong labor market, despite consumer sentiment remaining below pre-pandemic levels.

The return to positive inflation after a contraction in May suggests wholesale prices remain buoyant in some areas.

site_title: Investors in VinFast’s Spac cash out most shares
summary: VinFast's special purpose acquisition company (Spac) partner, Black Spade Acquisition (BSA), has seen over 80% of its shares redeemed by investors, amounting to approximately $147 million. The redemption comes as the Spac's shareholders exercise their right to redeem shares before voting on the proposed merger with VinFast. The Spac's remaining shareholders have also voted to extend its lifespan by one year, which is inline with recent trends of other Spacs seeking extension. This development is a setback for VinFast, which had initially planned a US listing on its own and has struggled to start production and ramp up sales outside Vietnam.

images.alt_text: BSA shareholders have not yet voted on the merger with VinFast.
VinFast had said in May that it will list in the US by merging with SPAC company Black Spade in the second half of this year.

site_title: Citigroup profit drops 36% as trading slump casts cloud over earnings
summary: Citi's net income dropped 36% to $2.92 billion in the second quarter, largely due to a 13% decline in markets revenue and a 24% decrease in investment banking fees. The bank's personal banking and wealth management unit, however, saw a 6% increase in revenue. Despite this, the results were overshadowed by weaker trading activity on Wall Street, with other major banks like JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo reporting significant jumps in profits.

images.alt_text: The cuts are necessary for the bank to reduce its cost base because of adverse market conditions, according to a person within the bank, who isn’t authorised to speak publicly.
All jobs within the CitiFX global FX strategy team are affected, although some people may continue to work with Citi in other capacities.
Raymond Lim and Shawn Khong Hsiu-Mun join Citigroup as head of corporate finance for Asean and the head of Citi Commercial Bank Malaysia, respectively.

site_title: Buyers could have last laugh if Apac commercial real estate standoff drags on
summary: Commercial real estate activity in the Asia-Pacific (Apac) region has been lacklustre, with deal counts remaining low. Only Hong Kong and Singapore showed higher transaction volumes in the first quarter of 2023, according to MSCI's Apac Capital Trends report. If excluding the effects of a massive US$830 million sale in Hong Kong, the rest of the market appears stagnant, with prices in the bellwether office sector falling only 7% over the past two years.

site_title: JPMorgan profit jumps on higher interest income as First Republic lifts earnings
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a 67% jump in profit for the second quarter, driven by higher interest income and the purchase of First Republic Bank's assets. The bank's net interest income jumped $21.9 billion, up 44%, and its CEO, Jamie Dimon, reassured investors that the economy remains resilient. Dimon cautioned against premature optimism on inflation, citing risks such as consumers using up cash buffers and high inflation. The bank's shares rose 2.4% in premarket trading, and its full-year net interest income is expected to be higher than Wall Street estimates.

images.alt_text: The total workforce of JPMorgan, the largest US lender, stood at 296,877 at the end of the first quarter, up 8 per cent from a year earlier, according to a filing.
Morgan Stanley’s EPS is anticipated to drop 9 per cent, although revenue from wealth management will likely cushion the blow from lacklustre dealmaking.
JPMorgan Chase is overweight on Indonesia and Vietnam as those two markets have been at the forefront of attracting foreign direct investment flows from supply-chain shifts.

A man exits the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters building in New York, U.S. in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 8, 2011. LivingSocial, the second-largest daily-coupon site, is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase & Co. as one of the banks to manage its initial public offering, a person with knowledge of the talks said. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg
JPMorgan’s international operations serve American companies that do business overseas, as well as foreign companies that operate in the US.

site_title: Carsome waiting for ‘right timing’ for IPO; will launch sales of new EVs: CEO
summary: Carsome, Malaysia's tech unicorn startup, is waiting for the right market timing to revive its IPO plans on the Nasdaq and Singapore Exchange. Despite shelving its IPO indefinitely, the company is exploring new growth areas, including the sales of new electric vehicles and expanding its service centre business in Indonesia and Thailand. Carsome CEO Eric Cheng stated that the company is confident in achieving its goal of breaking even next year, with revenue growing 250% to $1.5 billion in 2022.

images.alt_text: Carsome Automall in Selangor has a capacity to showcase over 200 cars.
Carsome CEO Eric Cheng: “We will go listing when the market condition improves, making sure we look attractive to the market.”

site_title: Biden forgives US$39 billion in US student debt using programme tweak
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration has forgiven $39 billion in student debt for over 804,000 borrowers through a tweak to income-driven repayment (IDR) plans. Borrowers who made 20 or 25 years of monthly IDR payments are eligible for forgiveness. The relief addresses "historical inaccuracies" in payment counts and is part of a separate program. This move follows the Supreme Court blocking Biden's plan to cancel hundreds of billions of dollars in debt, and the administration will continue to pursue new measures for student loan relief.

site_title: Instead of pausing AI development, aim to mitigate risks
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) development poses significant risks, but a complete halt may be irresponsible and counterproductive. Companies relying on externally developed AI systems should conduct thorough due diligence to ensure accuracy and robustness. The human perspective is crucial in balancing AI innovation with risks, as AI can combat malicious codes and expose false content. Existing frameworks, such as the EU AI Act and Singapore's Model AI Governance Framework, provide principles for responsible AI development, including human-centric design, explainability, and transparency. Adequate human oversight and mitigation of safety risks are essential to ensure AI benefits humankind.

images.alt_text: While financial technology and generative AI hold great promise, they can be exploited to cause widespread disruption, said Heng Swee Keat.
The watchdog has already observed how volatility during the trading day has doubled and amplified compared to during the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: ‘Almost impossible’ for Oon family to make decisions; defence questions lack of protest when signing deal
summary: The Violet Oon group's family, led by Tay Yiming, testified in the High Court that they found it "almost impossible" to make commercial decisions due to fear of being threatened or evicted from the board. The family, which holds 75% of the company, is seeking a court order to purchase outstanding shares or for the company to be wound up. In contrast, business partner Manoj Murjani, who holds the remaining 25%, did not make any personal contributions, leading to a significant imbalance in the company's financial situation.

site_title: Rivalries on show as South-east Asia hosts annual security talks
summary: Top diplomats from 24 countries, including US, China, Russia, and South Korea, gathered in Indonesia for the Asean Regional Forum, where the US-China rivalry, war in Ukraine, and North Korean missiles are expected to dominate talks. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken called for peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific, Taiwan Strait, and Ukraine, while Chinese diplomat Wang Yi expressed a desire for a rational and pragmatic attitude to improve relations. The forum also addressed Myanmar's military junta and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Asean, which includes Myanmar among its 10 members, has pushed, without success, for the implementation of a five-point peace plan agreed with the junta shortly after a coup in early 2021.

site_title: New homes set to be built in two sites in Simei; one near Upper Changi MRT station
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has proposed rezoning two land parcels in Simei, Singapore, to residential use, marking the first new public housing in the area in over a decade. The smaller plot near Simei Lane may be developed into HDB flats, while the larger site near Upper Changi MRT station could accommodate up to 450-500 units. The move aims to achieve a better mix of private and public housing, and is seen as a response to the area's high demand for housing, with many young people seeking to move to the area due to its proximity to Changi Airport and existing amenities.

images.alt_text: The 13-storey building has retail and food and beverage outlets on the first floor, along with office and commercial units from the second to 13th floors.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit not in financial distress; divestment of assets in line with strategy: manager
summary: The manager of ESR-Logos Reit has stated that the divestment of seven non-core assets for around S$337 million is in line with the company's strategy to rejuvenate its portfolio by divesting underperforming assets and pivoting to higher-quality new economy assets. The move is aimed at reducing leverage and capitalising on the sale of assets below valuation, as the land lease tenure runs down and interest rates rise. The manager dismisses speculation of financial distress, citing a reduced aggregate leverage and unencumbered portfolio that will provide flexibility to optimise its capital structure.

images.alt_text: External managers of Singapore-listed trusts need to act in the interest of unitholders and deliver value in order to keep their jobs.

site_title: Thailand sees limited impact from delayed fiscal budget: official
summary: Thailand's fiscal budget, expected to be worth 3.35 trillion baht, has been delayed due to the country's ongoing government formation process. The delay is projected to have a minimal economic impact of 0.05 percentage point on growth. To mitigate the effects, the government has prepared 120 billion baht to shore up the economy and speed up investment and spending. The budget will need approval from the new government, parliament, and the king before taking effect, which could be delayed up to six months.

images.alt_text: Thailand has long been a popular destination for foreign tourists, receiving nearly 40 million visitors in pre-pandemic 2019.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia set up task force to study special economic zone
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have established a task force to study the establishment of a Johor-Singapore special economic zone (JS-SEZ). The task force, led by Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry and Malaysia's Ministry of Economy, aims to draft the terms of reference and areas of collaboration. The JS-SEZ is expected to build on the growth of Johor and significant investments by Singapore, with a focus on industrial cooperation, environment, innovation, tourism, immigration, and transportation links. The initiative is expected to create jobs and drive growth in a sustainable manner.

site_title: Nissan to recall 2.5 million cars in US, Europe, Japan
summary: Nissan is recalling approximately 2.47 million cars globally due to several issues, including sudden acceleration after exiting cruise control and short circuits that cause motors to stop while driving. The affected models include the Note, Kicks, Serena, and Leaf, and the recall affects vehicles in the US, Europe, and Japan. No accidents have been reported at this time, according to the company.

site_title: India launches rocket to land spacecraft on moon's South Pole
summary: India's space agency launched a rocket on July 14 to land a spacecraft at the lunar South Pole, as part of the Chandrayaan-3 mission. The mission aims to deploy a lander and rover near the moon's South Pole around August 23, marking an unprecedented feat for India. Only three other space agencies have successfully landed a lander on the moon's surface, and none have done so near the lunar South Pole. The mission includes a 2m tall lander designed to deploy a rover and conduct experiments for two weeks.

site_title: Mazda says needs China strategy overhaul to catch up with market
summary: Mazda Motor, Japan's second-largest automaker, plans to overhaul its strategy in China to catch up with the country's competitive market. CEO Masahiro Moro stated that the company faces increasing pressure to reduce profits, but will not scale back operations. Mazda aims to introduce electric vehicles one by one, with production output expected to be low for the next 18 months. The company's sales in China dropped 41% in 2022, and it trails EV startups like NIO and Xpeng.

images.alt_text: Car sales in June have totalled 1.91 million units. In the first half of the year, sales were up 2.5 per cent to 9.65 million units.

site_title: Wells Fargo raises outlook for interest income after profit surges 57% on higher rates
summary: Wells Fargo's profit surged 57% to $1.25 per share in the second quarter, driven by higher interest rates. The bank raised its annual forecast for net interest income by 4% to $13.16 billion, citing a stronger-than-expected US economy. However, Wells Fargo set aside $1.71 billion in provisions for credit losses, including a $949 million increase in allowance for potential losses in commercial real estate loans. The bank's CEO, Charlie Scharf, expressed optimism that economic uncertainty will narrow over the next few quarters.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A U.S. flag flies above Wells Fargo & Co headquarters in San Francisco, California, April 22, 2009. REUTERS/Robert Galbraith  (UNITED STATES BUSINESS)/File Photo

site_title: Chinese court rejects creditors’ application to wind up Guangzhou R&F
summary: A Chinese court has rejected applications by two creditors to wind up Guangzhou R&F Properties due to insufficient evidence of insolvency. The developer had over 110 billion yuan in assets, according to its financial reports, and the court found its operations normal. The dispute was over 20 million yuan in commercial paper, which R&F plans to oppose through legal measures. The rejection is seen as a rare instance of a mid-sized firm facing bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Thailand's Move Forward seeks to curb Senate powers after loss in PM vote
summary: Thailand's Move Forward party, led by Pita Limjaroenrat, announced a plan to amend the constitution to curb the power of the military-appointed Senate, following the party leader's loss in the premiership vote. The Senate, which has the power to elect the prime minister along with the elected lower house, closed ranks to deny Pita the top job, with only 13 senators backing him. The move aims to address concerns over the Senate's role in protecting the interests of the military and conservative establishment, and could take a month to implement.

images.alt_text: In Parliament on Thursday, he defended himself again, telling lawmakers: “I am fully qualified” despite attempts to suspend him over allegations he broke campaign rules.

site_title: Artificial sweetener aspartame is ‘possibly’ carcinogenic, yet safe at common use levels, WHO says
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has classified aspartame, an artificial sweetener commonly used in diet drinks, as a "possible cause of cancer" based on limited evidence. However, the WHO's International Agency for Research on Cancer has also determined that the safety of aspartame is not a major concern at current levels of recommended consumption. The US Food and Drug Administration has publicly disagreed with the WHO's classification, sparking confusion among consumers. Despite the conflicting statements, aspartame remains widely used in various products.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy narrowly avoided a technical recession in Q2 with a 0.7% year-on-year growth, despite a manufacturing sector downturn. Minister for Transport S Iswaran is under investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) over his interactions with HPL co-founder Ong Beng Seng. Meanwhile, Singapore's international visitor arrivals reached 1.13 million in June, exceeding the one-million mark for the fourth consecutive month. The Singapore stock market rose 0.3% as risk appetite surged due to easing US inflation data.

site_title: Indonesia to launch much awaited IPOs for PalmCo, PHE in coming months
summary: Indonesia plans to launch initial public offerings (IPOs) for state-owned palm oil estate PalmCo and upstream oil and gas company Pertamina Hulu Energi (PHE) in the coming months. PalmCo is expected to register for an IPO in September or October, while PHE is set to launch a share sale in August or September. This marks the latest in Indonesia's hot IPO market, which has seen listings from geothermal power firms and resource-rich companies. The move is seen as a significant step in the country's efforts to tap into the capital markets and raise funds for development projects.

images.alt_text: Most of the proceeds to be used to expand Cinema XXI’s network while 20 per cent for early repayment of debt to Bank Rakyat Indonesia.

site_title: More COEs available in next three months
summary: The Land Transport Authority has announced an increase of 5.6% in the August-October quota for certificates of entitlement (COEs), with a total of 11,019 COEs available. This is due to an extraordinary adjustment made in May, where 1,025 COEs were brought forward from projected peak-supply years, all for cars. The move aims to cool the overheated market, providing more options for buyers.

images.alt_text: A photo of a car showroom in Singapore.

site_title: No buffets needed: Today’s investor is more savvy, more challenging for companies to engage
summary: Investors today prioritize convenience and take a light-touch approach to portfolio management, leading to changing expectations for shareholder engagement. Companies are adapting to this shift by reverting to physical meetings as the default option and incorporating more interactive elements. However, differing perspectives among investors may make it challenging for companies to please shareholders. The rise of digitalization and self-serve mentality is also transforming the industry, with robo-advisors and online platforms automating investment decisions and reducing the need for human intermediaries. As a result, remisiers and financial advisors are adapting by upskilling and evolving to provide value-added services, while companies must prioritize sustainability, corporate governance, and shareholder engagement.

images.alt_text: Investors could benefit from stricter rules around the formats of meetings. This is particularly true for EGMs that are convened to vote on contentious corporate issues.

site_title: Major Australian Reit limits withdrawals from unlisted office fund
summary: Australian real estate investment trust Charter Hall has limited withdrawals from its $2.5 billion office fund, citing "challenging property conditions." Investors received only a quarter of their requested withdrawals, with the remaining 75% being funded by selling properties at a 17% discount. This move exposes the bind faced by Reits with unlisted funds, which need cash to pay investors and fund projects but are reluctant to sell properties or tap equity markets during a commercial real estate downturn.

site_title: Messi’s new league is considering taking sovereign wealth money
summary: Major League Soccer (MLS) is considering allowing sovereign wealth funds to invest in its teams, following other US sports leagues such as the NHL and NBA. The MLS commissioner, Don Garber, said the league's board will discuss the topic at a meeting next week. This move comes as sovereign wealth funds, including the Saudi Public Investment Fund, have been investing in professional sports globally. The influx of Middle Eastern capital has also led to the recent investment by the Qatar Investment Authority in the NBA.

images.alt_text: Messi has won two league titles and a French Super Cup with PSG.
Argentina's Messi reacting during last week's friendly  match against Australia at the Workers' Stadium in Beijing.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Markets feeling the cheer this week (Ep 51)
summary: Markets experienced a positive week, driven by easing inflation data. Claressa Monteiro, host of the podcast "BT Market Focus," explores the factors behind the market cheer. Insights from SGX and The Business Times' newsdesk, as well as corporate news for investors, were discussed. The week's notable news included mixed economic data, which was a main driver. The podcast provides analysis and insights into market movements in Singapore and beyond.

images.alt_text: How did mixed economic data affect markets this week?
Broad markets consolidate in this shorter trading week.

site_title: Eurozone almost eliminates trade deficit in May
summary: The eurozone trade deficit nearly eliminated in May, with a 0.9 billion euro deficit from 8.0 billion euros in April. Exports of chemicals and machinery increased, while imported energy products from Russia declined. The EU's trade surplus in manufacturing goods rose to 142.3 billion euros in Jan-May, with a narrowing trade deficit with Russia and China, but an expanded deficit with Britain. The EU's trade gap with the US also dipped.

images.alt_text: The yield on Germany’s 10-year Bund traded as much as 7.4 basis points (bps) lower after the data, extending an earlier small decline.

The Galeries Lafayette shopping mall on Friedrichstrasse in Berlin, Germany, Germany, on Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2022. National numbers this week from across the 20-member euro area showed Spanish inflation below the ECB’s 2 per cent target, while France, Italy and the Netherlands all saw a retreat, albeit well above the goal.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades ComfortDelGro to ‘buy’ on transportation rebound
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) upgraded ComfortDelGro to 'buy' and raised its target price to S$1.41, expecting the land transport operator's earnings to benefit from industry tailwinds. The brokerage forecasts the taxi segment to register more positive profit margins due to reduced taxi rental rebates and increased commission rates. UOBKH also expects public transport core operating profit to improve by 28% in Q2, driven by improved rail ridership and higher rail fares.

images.alt_text: CDG and FairPrice will focus on loyalty benefits, with plans to jointly offer door-to-door experiences related to transport and daily essentials in the future.
Taking on some risk by buying high quality dividend paying shares can be prudent.
The KYC Star V7 electric van will be available in both cargo carrying and passenger vehicle forms.

site_title: Credit Suisse offers rare example of bank disclosing emerging market debt
summary: Credit Suisse is one of a handful of global banks that publicly disclose loans to poor countries, according to research by UK nonprofit Debt Justice. The Swiss bank stands out for its relative transparency, with only Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group providing similar disclosures. In contrast, global banks have withheld information on $37 billion of loans to sovereigns in developing countries since 2021, despite guidelines on debt transparency. Debt Justice calls for improved transparency and regulation to prevent new debt crises and deliver lower interest rates for governments.

images.alt_text: The government’s and UBS’s priority was to “minimise potential losses and risks so that recourse to the federal guarantee is avoided to the greatest extent possible”, the government said.

site_title: BOJ likely to keep next year’s price forecast around 2%
summary: The Bank of Japan is likely to raise its inflation forecast for this fiscal year to above 2% due to stronger-than-expected price growth, but keep the forecast at 2% for the following year. The move reflects a stronger-than-expected momentum of businesses passing costs onto consumers this year, but inflation is expected to slow in the year starting April 2024. The BOJ's new quarterly outlook report will be released on July 28, and economists predict an average inflation of 2.6% for this fiscal year.

images.alt_text: With inflation exceeding its 2 per cent target for more than a year, markets are speculating that the BOJ will phase out its massive stimulus that has drawn criticism for distorting market pricing and narrowing financial institutions’ margins.

site_title: World’s biggest pension fund GPIF boosts its treasuries holdings
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) increased its holdings of US Treasuries to a three-year high, boosting its treasuries holdings to 43.3% of its foreign debt holdings. This move comes despite elevated yields and a weak yen, offsetting losses on the securities. The fund's decision suggests that Japanese appetite for Treasuries may remain strong, driven by income and capital gains, as long as the yen doesn't strengthen. This has implications for Japanese portfolio flows and the nation's economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The sign of Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) is seen at its reception in Tokyo, Japan, November 16, 2018.   REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: Issue 57: Temasek’s emissions problem is Singapore’s emissions problem; Asia’s protein transition
summary: Temasek, Singapore's state-owned investment firm, reported a slight increase in its portfolio emissions to 27 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent for the year ended March 2023. The main contributor is Singapore Airlines, which saw a 64% jump in Scope 1 and 2 emissions due to air travel resuming. Temasek aims to halve its greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and achieve net zero emissions by 2050. However, divestment of carbon-intensive companies is not an option for Temasek, and the firm is working with companies like SIA to decarbonize. A recent study suggests that Asia must shift away from meat towards alternative proteins to reach climate safety by 2050.

images.alt_text: Unlike other carbon-intensive sectors, which may have various avenues to decarbonise, the only way SIA is able to reduce its carbon emissions is by switching its fuel, which are currently fossil fuel-based, to sustainable aviation fuel, said Dilhan Pillay, chief executive officer of Temasek.

Analysis by LeapFrog suggests technologies including electric scooters in India and rooftop solar in Nigeria could cost 30-40 per cent less than traditional, carbon-intensive alternatives.

site_title: STI rises 0.3% as upbeat mood over cool inflation continues
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,248.63, driven by a risk-appetite surge and easing US inflation data. The local bourse saw 317 gainers and 223 losers, with 1.6 billion securities worth S$1 billion traded. The Singapore economy narrowly avoided a technical recession, according to the latest GDP data. Analysts attribute the market's optimism to the US Federal Reserve's tightening trajectory potentially nearing its end, leading to hopes for reduced interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Tumbling US dollar a boon to risk assets across the globe
summary: The US dollar has fallen nearly 13% against a basket of currencies since last year's two-decade high, reaching its lowest level in 15 months. This decline is attributed to cooling US inflation and the Federal Reserve's potential end to interest rate hikes. As a result, risk assets globally are expected to benefit, including a wide range of assets tied to the US dollar. The decline could have far-reaching implications for the global financial system.

images.alt_text: As traders price in an end to US rate rises, the narrowing gap between US borrowing rates and those elsewhere drive other currencies, particularly the euro, sterling and the yen higher against the US dollar.

site_title: China invites global investors for rare meeting as economy sputters: sources
summary: China has invited global investors to a rare symposium in Beijing next week, seeking to boost confidence in the country's economy amid waning global investor confidence. The gathering, organized by China's fund regulator, will focus on the challenges facing US dollar-denominated investment firms in China and discuss ways to address them. The meeting comes as China's economy sputters, with the country's post-pandemic recovery losing steam and Sino-US relations strained due to national security issues.

images.alt_text: People cross a street near office towers in the Lujiazui financial district, ahead of the National People's Congress (NPC), in Shanghai, China, February 28, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: US launches US$20 billion in ‘green bank’ programs to curb climate change
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has launched two competitive grant programs with $20 billion in funding to support projects reducing planet-warming emissions. The programs, part of the $27 billion Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund, will provide grants to national clean financial institutions and nonprofit groups to deliver funding and technical assistance to local lenders in low-income communities. The initiatives aim to create a clean energy economy and expand economic opportunities for disadvantaged communities, with Vice President Kamala Harris stating that the projects will "become reality" and create a "clean energy economy that works for all."

images.alt_text: The United Nations’ global shipping regulator agrees to cut total annual emissions of greenhouse gases “by at least 20 per cent.

site_title: Burberry sales rise 18% as China rebounds for luxury brand
summary: Burberry's sales rose 18% in the 13 weeks ended July 1, driven by a 46% rebound in China. The recovery in China partially offset weakness in the US market, where sales fell 8% in the Americas region. Burberry's heritage rainwear and leather goods, particularly women's bags, were particularly popular. The company reiterated its guidance for low double-digit sales growth this year and plans to upgrade over 50% of its stores by the end of the year. Burberry's new designer, Daniel Lee, is set to unveil his debut collection in September.
