site_title: World’s top anime site Crunchyroll is Sony’s new money maker
summary: Crunchyroll, a leading anime streaming platform, expects the global anime industry to have over 800 million fans by 2025 outside of China and Japan. Owned by Sony, the company is focusing on India as a major growth market, with plans to acquire more content and localize anime series using dubbing and subtitles in local languages. Crunchyroll aims to convince fans to switch to the official site by offering competitive pricing and unique features, while also collaborating with partners to address anti-piracy issues. The company's growth is seen as a key area for Sony's entertainment business.

images.alt_text: While traditional anime franchises tend to showcase heroes navigating hostile worlds, isekai focuses instead on a chance at a do-over of life.

site_title: India June wholesale prices fall for third straight month
summary: India's annual wholesale prices fell 4.12% in June for the third consecutive month, mainly due to lower fuel and power prices. This is the lowest level since September 2015. Food prices fell 1.24% year-on-year, while manufactured product prices declined 2.71%. However, retail inflation quickened to 4.81% in June, higher than expected, due to surging food prices. Deflationary pressures are expected to ease as food prices rise due to extreme weather events and uneven rainfall.

images.alt_text: Prices of tomato, onion and potato – key ingredients in an Indian meal – are major contributors to volatility in retail inflation.
FILE PHOTO: Dream11 and MPL logos are displayed in front of the Indian flag in this Illustration taken September 14, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Easing inflation, a brightening growth outlook and a stable rupee are all helping to burnish the appeal of Indian bonds.

site_title: Rolls-Royce Spectre review: A S$2.1m slice of heaven
summary: The Rolls-Royce Spectre, priced at S$2.1 million, is the first electric car from the luxury brand, aiming to usher in the electric age by 2030. Despite its massive size, the car is aerodynamically slippery, with a drag coefficient of 0.25 Cd, and features a 700-kilowatt-hour battery pack. The Spectre boasts 584 horsepower, accelerating to 100 kmh in 4.5 seconds, and offers effortless acceleration, silence, and advanced technology, including four-wheel steering and active anti-roll bars. The car's design and controls aim to evoke a sense of traditional Rolls-Royce luxury, making it a slice of heaven for its owners.

images.alt_text: Müller-Ötvös is adamant that you can put a blindfolded person into the Spectre and he would immediately be able to tell that he was in a Rolls-Royce, from the way it smells and feels.

site_title: Cathay Pacific expects up to HK$4.5 billion first-half profit as demand rebounds
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects a profit of up to HK$4.5 billion in the first half of the year, driven by a rebound in travel demand following border reopenings. The airline carried 7.8 million passengers in the first half, compared to 335,462 last year, with a passenger load factor of 87.2%. Cathay Pacific also plans to offer a special appreciation award to employees who remained with the airline during the pandemic. The airline's shares rose 6.3% as the news boosted the airline's recovery from record losses in the previous years.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways is also recruiting more crew from mainland China as it struggles to fill roles locally.
Cathay will be the sole airline offering in-town check-in services, and only from 6 am to 3 pm, Hong Kong train operator MTR says.

site_title: Swedish landlord SBB enters into talks with bondholders; net loss widens
summary: SBB, a Swedish commercial landlord, enters talks with bondholders to strengthen liquidity amid a net loss of 9.9 billion kronor (S$1.27 billion) in the second quarter. The company aims to obtain capital from the stock market to address its debt pile of US$8 billion, which has become unsustainable due to rising interest rates and falling property valuations. SBB's shares rose 4.9% after the announcement, and the company has started parallel processes to find buyers for properties and raise fresh capital.

images.alt_text: The SBB headquarters in Stockholm. Photographer: Jonas Ekblom/Bloomberg

site_title: Debt worries rise as China property developer Sino-Ocean’s bondholders flag missed payment
summary: China property developer Sino-Ocean has faced debt worries as two bondholders have yet to receive a coupon payment of $7.02 million, due on July 13. The payment has a 14-day grace period before an event of default could occur. Sino-Ocean has been at the center of the nation's junk-note market concerns, but has so far avoided repayment issues. The developer faces nearly $380 million of bond obligations in the third quarter, including a $9.5 million coupon payment. Analysts predict the developer may suspend servicing offshore debt and pursue restructuring.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China aims to increase financial support to ensure home delivery.

site_title: IMF loan helps Pakistan unlock another US$5.6 billion in funding
summary: Pakistan has secured a US$5.6 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, including US$3.7 billion from bilateral partners, to ease its financial struggles ahead of elections later this year. The loan programme, approved by the IMF executive board, boosts Pakistan's financial stability and foreign-exchange reserves. The move is seen as helping the nation avoid a default, and Fitch Ratings has upgraded Pakistan's sovereign rating to CCC. The loan reflects additional funding beyond the previous programme, with inflows from multilateral development partners expected in the coming weeks and months.

images.alt_text: Inflation has rocketed, the rupee has plummeted, and the country is struggling to afford imports, causing a severe decline in industrial output.
The nine-month short-term lifeline for Pakistan’s ailing economy, which has been on the cusp of default, came after eight months of tough negotiations over fiscal discipline.
FILE PHOTO: Pakistan's Finance Minister Ishaq Dar is seen after a party meeting in Islamabad, Pakistan September 26, 2017. Picture taken September 26, 2017. REUTERS/Faisal Mahmood/File Photo

With sky-high inflation and foreign exchange reserves barely enough for a month of controlled imports, analysts say Pakistan’s economic crisis could have spiralled into a debt default in the absence of the IMF bailout.
Transport prices climb 20.30 per cent while food inflation rises 39.5 per cent in June from a year earlier, according to data released by the Pakistan Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: Singapore semiconductor manufacturers unaffected by China’s metal export curbs
summary: China plans to impose export restrictions on gallium and germanium, key materials for chip production, from August 1. However, Singapore's semiconductor manufacturers, including STMicroelectronics and Infineon, say they do not expect the curbs to have a major impact due to their multi-sourcing strategy. The companies will continue to monitor the situation as it develops, but do not anticipate disruptions to their operations or testing capabilities in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Gallium is currently used in a wide variety of applications, from LEDs to smaller mobile phone adaptors.
Some larger chip manufacturers view China’s export controls on gallium as more of a warning shot about what economic pain the country could inflict.
“After evaluation, we do not expect the export restrictions on raw materials gallium and germanium will have any direct impact on TSMC’s production,” the company says.
Taiwan is a major producer of chips used in everything from smartphones and cars to fighter jets, supplying companies like Apple and Nvidia.

site_title: Industrial hub facing power crunch that may ripple across China
summary: China's industrial hub, Sichuan, is facing a power crunch due to extreme heat and water level drops, which may lead to shortages in other parts of the country. The province, reliant on hydropower, has had to ration electricity and cut exports, affecting industries such as steel and electronics. If the heat persists, the shortages may rival last year's curbs on power supply, potentially impacting Toyota's factory and Tesla's suppliers. The National Energy Administration warns of tight electricity supply in southern, central, and eastern China.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to treat foreign investors better and called for greater opening up in recent weeks.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend rally on hopes US Fed near end of rate hike cycle
summary: Asia markets extended their rally on Friday, driven by hopes the US Federal Reserve is nearing the end of its interest rate hike cycle. Falling US inflation data fueled optimism, with Hong Kong, Sydney, and other Asian cities rising for the fifth day in a row. However, Tokyo struggled due to a strong yen against the dollar. Analysts believe the Fed may be topping out its rate hikes, giving investors confidence in the economy avoiding a recession.

images.alt_text: Asia happily picked up the baton, with Hong Kong up more than two per cent while Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Manila were all up more than one per cent.

site_title: Who is Ong Beng Seng, the F1 supremo involved in Iswaran’s case?
summary: Ong Beng Seng, a Malaysian hotel and property tycoon, is involved in the corruption case of former Singapore transport minister S Iswaran, who was charged on January 18 with corruptly obtaining gratification from Ong. Ong earned millions from accurately predicting oil prices during his time at Kuo International, allegedly financing his later investments and property development. He is also known for bringing the Formula 1 night race to Singapore in 2008.

images.alt_text: Iswaran leaves the State Courts with his defence lawyer, senior counsel Davinder Singh, on Thursday, January 18 2024.
Hotel Properties to book S$29m gain from disposal of stake in 2 JV companies
While the Forum mall is sited on land zoned for commercial use, the voco Orchard Singapore site currently has only hotel use permitted.

site_title: BYD proposes investing US$1 billion in India to build EVs, batteries: sources
summary: China's BYD proposes a US$1 billion investment to build electric cars and batteries in India, in partnership with a local company, Megha Engineering and Infrastructures. The plan, if approved, would allow BYD to establish a full line-up of EVs in India, including hatchbacks to luxury models. This investment would give BYD a presence in all major global car markets, except the US, and would challenge Tesla's dominance in the EV market. BYD has already invested US$200 million in India and plans to scale up production to 100,000 EVs annually.

images.alt_text: The KYC Star V7 electric van will be available in both cargo carrying and passenger vehicle forms.
Xpeng has received a “significant” amount of orders for its newly launched G6 pure electric crossover, president Brain Gu says.
Competitive pricing, faster rollouts of new models and the rise of domestic electric carmakers like BYD, Nio and Xpeng Motors have changed the dynamic for made-in-China auto brands.
Of the nearly 850,000 new cars registered in Thailand last year, only around 1 per cent were EVs.

site_title: Signs of end of ‘crypto winter’ as regulatory fog begins to lift
summary: Cryptocurrency markets have seen a significant boost, with Bitcoin trading at its highest price since June 2022 at $31,818 and Ether reaching a year-high. The positive momentum is attributed to favorable regulatory moves, including a US judge's ruling that Ripple can be legally sold on public crypto exchanges, and the entry of traditional finance firms like BlackRock and Fidelity into the market. This shift in regulatory environment has driven a mood shift among investors, with smaller cryptocurrencies, known as "altcoins," seeing significant gains, and shares in exchange Coinbase reaching a year-high.

images.alt_text: The case has been closely watched in the cryptocurrency industry, which disputes the SEC’s assertion that the vast majority of crypto tokens are securities and subject to its strict investor protection rules.
The crypto industry has been on even shakier ground since the US SEC sued crypto exchanges Binance and Coinbase Global last month raised risks of further regulatory challenges for the sector.

site_title: In Sao Paulo, boom of apartments the size of hotel rooms
summary: In Sao Paulo, Brazil, a boom of micro-apartments the size of hotel rooms has gained popularity, with available units up to 30 square meters increasing from 461 to 16,261 between 2016 and 2022. Young professionals, mostly single and middle-class, are attracted to modern and well-located properties close to jobs or public transport. Despite some units being as small as 16 square meters, demand remains high, with many residents embracing the compact space and learning to prioritize what they need. The trend is attributed to factors such as low interest rates and reduced tariff fees for small apartment construction.

images.alt_text: Since 2020, Mexicans have spent more than 700 million euros in Spanish real estate and construction, buying second or third homes and parking their savings.

site_title: Jabeur and Vondrousova finesse their way to Wimbledon final
summary: Tunisia's Ons Jabeur and Czech player Marketa Vondrousova will face off in the Wimbledon women's singles final on Saturday night. Jabeur, a 28-year-old mother from Ukraine, defeated Aryna Sabalenka of Belarus in a three-set victory, while Vondrousova ended Elina Svitolina's tournament run in straight sets. Jabeur, who is seeking her first Grand Slam title, has a reputation for her crafty and athletic play, while Vondrousova has a history of upsetting top opponents. The match will be Jabeur's first Wimbledon final appearance since 2022.

images.alt_text: The 36-year-old Djokovic is targeting an eighth Wimbledon title, which would draw him level with Federer’s men’s record.
Olympic Esports Week will mark several firsts – not just for Singapore, but also for the esports world. The event bears similarities with the Olympic Games, but players will compete virtually.
Ten highlights from the 2023 French Open

site_title: Wang tells Blinken to ‘work with China’ on improving US ties
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken met with Chinese diplomat Wang Yi, urging "work with China" to improve ties during a South-east Asian talks meeting in Jakarta. The discussion comes after Blinken raised concerns about alleged Chinese cybersecurity threats. This is the second meeting between the two in less than a month, as both sides try to ease trade and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to treat foreign investors better and called for greater opening up in recent weeks.

site_title: With offices vacant, London’s Canary Wharf seeks growth beyond banking
summary: London's Canary Wharf, a 128-acre financial services hub, is pivoting to reenergise itself after a shift to remote work sent office markets plummeting. The area is adding residences, labs for life-sciences groups, and cultural shows to lure new businesses. Despite HSBC's departure, Canary Wharf is seeing signs of growth, with increased foot traffic and new residents. Analysts believe that companies from other sectors will eventually replace departing firms, citing the district's iconic status and potential for growth beyond banking. The area's owners are prioritizing making it a liveable space.

images.alt_text: epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Malaysian PM Anwar discusses Tesla investment, Starlink with Musk
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced that Tesla's operations in Malaysia will begin this year, following the approval of electric vehicle maker Tesla's application to import battery-run EVs. Anwar also discussed Tesla's investment with billionaire Elon Musk, including the company's satellite communications service, Starlink. The two leaders agreed on the company's plans to establish an office, showrooms, and service centers, as well as a network of charging stations for its cars.

site_title: Hot stock: HPL falls 2.6% on news of CPIB probe into Ong Beng Seng
summary: Hotel Properties Limited's (HPL) share price fell 2.6% on Friday after co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng was issued a notice of arrest by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) over interactions with Minister for Transport S Iswaran. HPL's bond prices are expected to experience a short-term downward pressure, but analysts from DBS Credit Research consider this a "knee-jerk effect" due to investor uncertainty. Despite the negative news, HPL's bond prices remain "attractive" according to DBS.

images.alt_text: The hotel and property tycoon is also known for being one of those responsible for first bringing the Formula 1 night race to Singapore in 2008.
From left to right: Minister for Transport S Iswaran; Formula One Group chief executive Stefano Domenicali; and HPL co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng.

site_title: NTUC launches ‘starter’ membership with perks aimed at young people
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has launched the NTUC Starter membership, a new programme aimed at young people aged 18-25. The membership, priced at S$36 a year, offers career programmes, mentorship, and discounts on NTUC Club and movie tickets. The initiative follows the release of NTUC's "The New Gen Worker 2023" report, which recommended increasing career mentorship and mental health programmes. The goal is to draw 2,500 young members and address their concerns, helping them prepare for the workplace.

site_title: Panama seizes six tonnes of illegally traded shark fins bound for Asia
summary: Panama authorities seized over six tonnes of shark fins worth an estimated US$500 million annually, bound for Asia, in a major crackdown on the black-market trade. Five people were arrested in connection with the seizure, with most of the fins already dehydrated and ready for export. The move is part of Panama's efforts to protect endangered shark species, led by the country's Attorney General Javier Caraballo.

images.alt_text: Members of a team of researchers from the Galapagos National Park measure a hammerhead shark, after discovering a shark nursery off Isabela Island in the Galapagos, Ecuador, in this photo delivered by Galapagos National Park newsletter on December 16, 2022. Galapagos National Park/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES
The shark initiative has been one of the most discussed at this year’s CITES summit in Panama, with the proposal co-sponsored by the European Union and 15 countries.

site_title: Tesla starts selling Chinese-made Model Y in South Korea for 56.99 million won
summary: Tesla has started selling Chinese-made Model Y SUVs in South Korea, priced at 56.99 million won (S$59,483) for the rear-wheel drive model. With government subsidies, the price drops to around US$30,000 in some cities. This marks a significant reduction from the previous prices of US$80,000 and US$62,000 for dual-motor performance and long range versions, respectively. Sales began on July 14 with deliveries for August or September, according to an advertisement from Tesla Korea.

site_title: Japan’s 10-year yield at over four-month high on hawkish BOJ bets
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield reached a four-month high of 0.485% on July 14, driven by speculation that the Bank of Japan will tweak its ultra-loose monetary policy. The yield is up 1.5 basis points from the previous session, amid strong wage growth and sticky inflation. The Bank of Japan is scheduled to meet on July 27, where it may raise its price projection for this fiscal year to between 2% and 2.9%.

images.alt_text: Globally, investors are also shying away from offices due to historically high vacancy rates in major cities.

site_title: Why the Rolls-Royce Spectre isn’t a funky electric car
summary: Rolls-Royce's CEO Torsten Muller-Otvos defends the company's decision not to create a "funky" electric car, instead prioritizing the brand's heritage and luxury image. Under his leadership, Rolls-Royce has seen record sales of 6,000 cars last year, and its Bespoke customization service has become increasingly lucrative. The company's new electric car, the Spectre, was delayed for six years, but Muller-Otvos emphasizes that it was designed to maintain the brand's high standards, with a focus on quality and exclusivity.

images.alt_text: Flowing lines make the electric Rolls a graceful, almost waifish thing.

site_title: China central bank pledges to use policy tools to spur recovery
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has pledged to use its policy tools to support economic growth amid challenges including deflation, subdued growth, and a faltering property market. Deputy governor Liu Guoqiang announced the plan, which includes targeted monetary policy and counter-cyclical adjustments, to ensure ample liquidity in the economy. The PBOC expects the economy to take one year to recover from the pandemic and inflation to pick up in August, avoiding deflation in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The PBOC may still show its support to the market on Monday while keeping the MLF rate unchanged.
Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to treat foreign investors better and called for greater opening up in recent weeks.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals up in June, surpass one million for fourth straight month
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals reached 1.13 million in June, surpassing the one-million mark for the fourth consecutive month. This marks a 1.5% increase from May, with Indonesia remaining the top source of visitors at 217,051. China jumped to third place with 113,290 tourists, a 42.6% increase from pre-pandemic levels. Visitor arrivals moderated to 72.8% of 2019 levels, with market watchers expecting a stronger increase in July and August.

images.alt_text: China is the fourth-largest source of tourist arrivals to Singapore in May, with 95,613 visitors.
Average room rates generally inch up across hotel categories in May, with the exception of the luxury segment.

site_title: China’s underlying strength, growth sectors can trump weak sentiment: OCBC head of wholesale banking
summary: OCBC's head of global wholesale banking, Tan Teck Long, believes China's economy can recover despite slower-than-expected growth due to its underlying strength and the ability of specific sectors to outperform. Tan aims to increase revenue from Greater China corporates and SME customers, grow transactional banking capabilities, and double investment banking revenue by 2025. He identifies sectors such as transition and renewable energy, technology, and electric vehicles as growth areas. Despite global economic slowdown and US-China tensions, Tan is optimistic about OCBC's growth plans, citing China's large manufacturing capacity and ability to restructure and adapt to changes.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector is a key growth driver, accounting for about 30 per cent of its economic output. The sector is facing strong headwinds.

Japan Foods Holding founder, chairman and CEO Takahashi Kenichi at Tokyo Shokudo in VivoCity. Kenichi said its best-performing restaurants were located in the heartland malls, even before the pandemic.
A view of the city skyline and Huangpu river in Shanghai. The boost from China's reopening to exports has been limited, says Maybank senior economist Chua Hak Bin.
Economists flag risk of technical recession for Singapore as manufacturing contracts further in May

site_title: IReit Global’s Berlin Campus main tenant extends lease at 45% higher rent
summary: IReit Global's Berlin Campus main tenant, Deutsche Rentenversicherung Bund, has extended its lease by six months until December 31, 2024, with a rent increase of about 45% effective July 1, 2024. The tenant will also pay an additional 18.5 months of rent and a lump sum of 15.5 million euros (S$23 million) for dilapidation costs. The lease extension is expected to improve the property's weighted average lease expiry (Wale) to 1.8 years, boosting IReit Global's portfolio Wale to 4.9 years.

images.alt_text: Louis d'Estienne d'Orves, CEO of IReit Global's manager. The preferential offering is expected to raise the real estate investment trust's market capitalisation by 13.7 per cent.
Louis d'Estienne d'Orves, CEO of IReit Global's manager, said the preferential offering is expected to raise the real estate investment trust's market value by 14.4 per cent.

Louis d'Estienne d'Orves, chief executive officer of IReit Global's manager, expects the continued success of the Reit’s retail parks properties due to their “attractive yields for investors” and “lower rental costs for tenants”, compared with other asset classes.
IReit Global's new tenant will be occupying about 25 per cent of Darmstadt Campus in the 15-year lease.

site_title: PBOC seen holding key borrowing rate after slew of support steps
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is likely to keep its key borrowing rate unchanged at 2.65% next week as it assesses the impact of its recent rate cuts and support measures for the property sector. The urgency for a rate cut has abated due to stronger credit data and banks' increased lending to clients. Analysts expect the PBOC to maintain its wait-and-see strategy, and some predict a possible net injection to show easing bias, with long-term rates expected to remain elevated.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to treat foreign investors better and called for greater opening up in recent weeks.
The drop in exports was the worst since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic more than three years ago.

site_title: Animation genius Miyazaki is bringing back cinematic mystery
summary: Hayao Miyazaki's new Studio Ghibli film, "How Do You Live?", will premiere on July 14 with minimal promotion, no trailers, and no voice actor announcements. The title is based on a 1937 book by Miyazaki, and the poster features a bird-like creature. Unlike typical blockbuster movies, Ghibli is deliberately keeping the plot and genre under wraps. This strategy is meant to recreate the sense of wonder of going to the movies as a child, and is an unusual approach for a major studio. The film's success will be a test of the brand's strength, which has been built over nearly four decades.

images.alt_text: A huge grinning Totoro and other whimsical Studio Ghibli exhibits welcomes visitors to the park, less than a month after Japan fully reopened its borders to foreign tourists.
Netflix to launch 40 new anime shows this year after 'Blood of Zeus' win

site_title: Gold poised for weekly gain as dollar hits over one-year low
summary: Gold prices are set for their biggest weekly gain since April as the US dollar hits a one-year low, sparking bets the Federal Reserve will soon slow interest rate hikes. The US dollar index has fallen to its lowest level since April 2022, making gold less expensive for overseas investors. The US producer prices barely rose in June, and the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell, indicating a tight labor market.

site_title: Philippines plans debut US$1 billion sukuk bond deal this year
summary: The Philippines plans to issue its debut US$1 billion sukuk bond deal this year to fund its budget deficit. Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno announced the plan, stating the country aims to penetrate the Middle East market. Treasurer Rosalia de Leon added that banks do not yet have a mandate for the transaction, but are working on the structure of the notes. This move is part of the government's efforts to diversify its funding sources and tap into the growing Islamic bond market.

images.alt_text: Central bank policymakers around the world have recently spotlighted climate change and energy transition amid volatile energy prices and more frequent extreme weather events. T

site_title: IReit Global preferential offering closes with valid acceptances of 77.3%; total applications at 134.7%
summary: IReit Global's preferential offering has closed with 77.3% valid acceptances, exceeding the 134.7% total applications. The offering raised S$75.9 million, with 186.1 million units issued, and is expected to increase the real estate investment trust's market capitalisation by 13.7%. The proceeds will mainly be used to fund the acquisition of 17 retail properties in France.

images.alt_text: Daiwa House Logistics Trust is among the five trusts with the highest ICR.
Louis d'Estienne d'Orves, CEO of IReit Global's manager, said the preferential offering is expected to raise the real estate investment trust's market value by 14.4 per cent.

site_title: Xi gets serious on boosting private sector as economy slumps
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to boost the private sector, treating foreign investors better and calling for greater opening up, amid the nation's post-pandemic recovery losing steam. The government has rolled out red-carpet gestures, including meeting with executives and visiting foreign companies, to reassure investors. However, critics argue that recent moves to insert Communist Party officials on boards and reduce market shares will hinder the efforts. The Chinese leader's efforts come as the nation's economy faces deflationary risks, shrinking exports, and a weak property market, making it challenging to attract Western business.

images.alt_text: US treasury secretary Janet Yellen with Chinese vice premier He Lifeng during a meeting at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing on July 8, 2023.
China’s attempts to encourage foreign investors have ramped up in recent weeks, as it has become clear that the economy’s recovery following the end of its zero-Covid policies is starting to flag.

site_title: Lisa Marie Presley died of small bowel obstruction: report
summary: Lisa Marie Presley, daughter of Elvis Presley, died six months after her passing due to a small bowel obstruction as a delayed consequence of bariatric weight loss surgery. The Los Angeles County Medical Examiner reported that the obstruction was caused by adhesions from the surgery, a known long-term complication. Presley had also taken excessive amounts of prescription medication, but toxicology reports showed "therapeutic levels" of the medication in her blood. She was 54 years old and survived by her four children.

images.alt_text: (From left to right) Harper Vivienne Ann Lockwood, Lisa Marie Presley, Priscilla Presley, Riley Keough and Finley Aaron Love Lockwood attend a ceremony honouring Priscilla Presley, Lisa Marie Presley and Riley Keough at TCL Chinese Theatre, Hollywood, California,  June 21, 2022.
Lisa Marie Presley, 54, suffered cardiac arrest in her home in the Los Angeles suburb of Calabasas.

site_title: Delayed metro projects hamper Vietnam’s push to ease congestion, reduce motorbike use
summary: Vietnam aims to reduce motorbike use in its major cities by 2030, but delayed metro projects may hinder efforts. The country's first metro line in Hanoi began service in 2021, but subsequent projects are facing lengthy delays. For example, the second metro line in Hanoi is now set to open in 2027, six years later than planned, and the first metro line in Ho Chi Minh City won't start operations until 2024, eight years later than initially planned. Despite these delays, the metro system is expected to play a key role in shifting commuters to public transport, reducing traffic congestion, and mitigating environmental impacts.

images.alt_text: The Wuling HongGuang MiniEV, touted as the best-selling mini EV model in the world with starting price expected to be at around 100 million Vietnamese dong (about S$5,667), will make an entrance into Vietnam in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: US: Stocks rise for fourth straight day
summary: US stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, reaching a 15-month peak, driven by benign inflation data and good corporate earnings. Wholesale prices increased 0.1% last month, slightly less than expected, while Treasury bond yields retreated. The S&P 500 ended at 4,510.04, up 0.9%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.1%. Earnings season continues with releases from JPMorgan Chase and two other major US banks on Friday.

site_title: US FTC asks court to halt Microsoft’s acquisition of Activision
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has asked a federal court to halt Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, citing concerns that the deal would harm competition in the videogame industry. The FTC appealed a previous ruling that allowed the deal to proceed, and Microsoft has vowed to fight the appeal. The FTC is seeking a preliminary injunction to temporarily stop the deal until an internal FTC judge can assess it, with a possible extension deadline of July 18.

images.alt_text: The FTC says that by buying video-game publisher Activision Blizzard, Microsoft would gain an unfair advantage in consoles and cloud-gaming.

site_title: Microsoft, Activision weigh sale of some UK cloud-gaming rights
summary: Microsoft and Activision Blizzard are reconsidering the sale of some UK cloud-gaming rights to appease UK regulators, who vetoed their $69 billion merger in May due to concerns over competition. The companies are exploring options, including selling rights to a telecommunications or gaming company, to meet regulatory requirements. Despite the setback, both companies still believe they can close the deal by the July 18 deadline. A US judge recently declined the Federal Trade Commission's request to pause the deal, and the UK Competition and Markets Authority is preparing to evaluate proposals from Microsoft.

images.alt_text: Any outstanding regulatory hurdle makes it more likely the agreement between Microsoft and Activision will expire on Jul 18 without the deal having been completed.

site_title: Nasa rover reveals new evidence about organic molecules on Mars
summary: NASA's Perseverance rover has discovered evidence of organic molecules on Mars, suggesting a potential indicator of life. The rover's SHERLOC instrument detected the molecules in rocks at a site where a lake existed long ago in Jezero crater. While the findings are intriguing, researchers caution that non-biological processes may be responsible for the signals, and more study is needed to determine if the molecules are a sign of life. The discovery adds to a growing body of evidence that organic molecules may be relatively common on Mars.

images.alt_text: The agency is looking to quantify potential resources, including energy, water and lunar soil, as a goal to attract commercial investment, says Gerald Sanders, a rocket scientist at Nasa’s Johnston Space Centre for 35 years.

“More intense rainfall and increased coastal flooding are devastating livelihoods and taking lives, demonstrating the importance of Nasa’s cutting-edge science to help answer questions that nobody else can.” Nasa says.

site_title: Twitter to offer ad revenue share to select content creators
summary: Twitter announced that select content creators will receive a share of the advertising revenue earned by the platform. Eligible creators must be verified users with at least 5 million impressions on their posts in the last 3 months and have a Stripe payment account. This move aims to draw more content creators to the platform, following the introduction of paid subscription options earlier this year.

site_title: Singapore shares advance after GDP estimates; STI up 0.3% at Friday’s open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,247.71 at 9:03 am, following a 0.7% year-on-year GDP growth estimate for the second quarter of 2023. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 85 to 27, with key gainers including Seatrium, Thai Beverage, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC trading up 0.3% each.

images.alt_text: Hotel Properties' co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng has been asked by the CPIB to provide information on his interactions with Transport Minister S Iswaran.

site_title: Sparks fly in Violet Oon trial over obligations to fund joint business
summary: Violet Oon's trial continues over obligations to fund joint business with business partner Manoj Murjani. Tay Yiming, Violet Oon's son and head of operations, claims Murjani verbally agreed to match the family dollar for dollar when the business needed money, but no written evidence supports this claim. Murjani's lawyer argues that the alleged promise was not included in the 2014 shareholding agreement. The trial also centers on pay raises for the family members, with Tay alleging that Murjani threatened to "wind up the company" and sue the family due to increased salaries.

images.alt_text: (From left) Tay Yiming, Tay Su-lyn, Violet Oon and Manoj Murjani. Tay Su-Lyn was the second witness in a civil case she, her mother and her brother Tay Yiming brought against Murjani, alleging oppression.
Chef Violet Oon was cross-examined by her business partner Manoj Murjani’s lawyer on Tuesday, with Justice Philip Jeyaretnam presiding over the trial.

veviolet25 - Violet Oon Singapore outlet at Jewel Changi Airport. 

Credit: Violet Oon Singapore

site_title: US Fed’s Waller eyes July rate rise, and another hike before year ends
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller expressed support for another interest rate hike in July, favoring two additional quarter percentage point increases this year. Waller cited the robust labor market and solid US economy as reasons for further tightening policy, despite recent inflation data showing a slowdown. The Fed is set to meet on July 25-26, with markets expecting a rate hike. Waller also noted that September's meeting may bring another rate increase if inflation doesn't cool down fast enough.

images.alt_text: Receipts slipped 11 per cent compared with last year, while outlays rose by 10 per cent.
The return to positive inflation after a contraction in May suggests wholesale prices remain buoyant in some areas.

site_title: Hollywood set for first shutdown strike since 1960
summary: Hollywood actors are poised to go on strike, joining writers in the first industry-wide shutdown in 63 years, after negotiations with studios over dwindling pay and the threat of artificial intelligence (AI) failed. The Screen Actors Guild (SAG-AFTRA), representing 160,000 members, including A-list stars, has unanimously recommended a strike, which could trigger a "double strike" with writers. The strike would halt nearly all film and television production, causing delays for popular series and major films.

images.alt_text: A sign is pictured at SAG-AFTRA offices after negotiations ended with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP), the entity that represents major studios and streamers, including Amazon, Apple, Disney, NBCUniversal, Netflix, Paramount, Sony, and Warner Bros Discovery, triggering an actors’ strike, in Los Angeles, California, U.S., July 13, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake

site_title: Trump NFTs, hotel sale: new report details US$1 billion in income
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has provided more details on his financial empire, including income from his crypto wallet, speaking fees, and the sale of his Washington, DC hotel. The revised financial disclosure form shows Trump earned over $1 billion in income from various endeavors, including managing his Dubai golf course ($1,166,357) and Trump Old Post Office ($284.5 million). Trump also listed $5.8 million in royalties and $12.6 million in speaking fees, including a $1.4 million payment for a live tour with Bill O'Reilly. Trump's wealth and celebrity have raised questions about the intersection of his presidency and business interests, with Democrats attacking him for failing to separate himself from his business dealings.

images.alt_text: State attorney general Letitia James accuses Donald Trump of lying to lenders and insurers from 2011 to 2021 about asset values at the Trump Organization, as well as his own net worth.

site_title: Ripple Labs notches landmark win in US SEC case over XRP cryptocurrency
summary: A US judge ruled that Ripple Labs did not violate federal securities law by selling its XRP token on public exchanges, a landmark victory for the cryptocurrency industry. The decision, made by Judge Analisa Torres, found that XRP sales on public cryptocurrency exchanges were not offers of securities under the law, as purchasers did not have a reasonable expectation of profit tied to Ripple's efforts. The ruling was a partial win for the SEC, which claimed that XRP sales to sophisticated investors were unregistered sales of securities. The decision is likely to provide ammunition for other crypto firms battling the SEC over jurisdiction.

images.alt_text: The crypto industry has been on even shakier ground since the US SEC sued crypto exchanges Binance and Coinbase Global last month raised risks of further regulatory challenges for the sector.

site_title: Disney wants to keep ESPN, could offload some traditional TV assets
summary: Disney CEO Robert Iger plans to keep ESPN, exploring strategic partnerships to help distribute and produce content. He also hinted at selling traditional TV assets due to the rise of streaming services. Iger aims to stay in the sports business, but acknowledges the decline in linear TV and the need for cost-cutting measures. The company is facing challenges from cord-cutting and the ongoing Hollywood writers' strike, which Iger believes will have a damaging effect on the business.

images.alt_text: Disney’s India business comprises Disney+ Hotstar streaming service and Star India, which it took over when it acquired the entertainment assets of 21st Century Fox in 2019.
Director Ali Selim revealed in a recent interview that the Disney+ show used AI as well as human illustrators to generate its opening credits.
Ryan Murphy would likewise continue to make shows for Netflix after a move to Disney.
The delays are unwelcome news for theatre chains desperate for more films from studios to draw movie-goers back to their screens.

site_title: Australia appoints first female head for central bank
summary: Australia appointed Michele Bullock as its first female head of the central bank, Reserve Bank of Australia, on July 14. Bullock, who is currently deputy governor, replaces Philip Lowe, who is leaving after a 43-year career due to a public backlash over rising interest rates. The appointment is seen as a history-making move, and Bullock is widely respected by economists and financial markets. The change comes as the central bank undertakes a sweeping reorganisation and faces a cost of living crisis, with interest rates at a decade-high of 4.1%.

images.alt_text: Office buildings and commercial towers in the central business district of Sydney. The funds are facing increased regulatory scrutiny after ramping up their holdings of unlisted assets both locally and abroad in recent years.
Labour costs jumped to 2.6 per cent in quarterly terms, possibly reflecting firms factoring in minimum and award wage increases, while input cost growth remained at 2.3 per cent.

site_title: US small business lending holding up despite higher cost of credit
summary: US small businesses continue to borrow at a relatively stable rate despite a significant increase in short-term loan costs, reaching 9.2% in June, the highest in 16 years. The Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes have tightened credit conditions, but the anticipated credit crunch has not materialized. Loan approval rates have stabilized or improved slightly, with small banks approving 18.8% of loans in June, up from a decline in May. However, annual credit growth from US banks is at a decade low, and economists warn of potential lags in the effects of rate hikes on credit availability.

images.alt_text: The return to positive inflation after a contraction in May suggests wholesale prices remain buoyant in some areas.

MIAMI, FLORIDA - MAY 05: A 'Now Hiring' sign posted in the window of a restaurant looking to hire workers on May 05, 2023 in Miami, Florida. A report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed the US economy added 253,000 jobs in April.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The CPI gained 0.2 per cent last month after edging up 0.1 per cent in May.

site_title: Both Iswaran and HPL’s Ong Beng Seng arrested on Jul 11, out on bail in CPIB probe
summary: Transport Minister S Iswaran and Hotel Properties Ltd managing director Ong Beng Seng were arrested on July 11 in a CPIB probe. They were released on bail, with Ong posting S$100,000. No charges have been filed against Ong, but he is required to provide information on his interactions with Iswaran. Iswaran is currently on leave assisting in the investigation, while Ong will travel from July 14 and surrender his passport to CPIB upon his return. HPL announced that Ong is cooperating fully with the CPIB.

images.alt_text: The hotel and property tycoon is also known for being one of those responsible for first bringing the Formula 1 night race to Singapore in 2008.
Iswaran will take a leave of absence until the investigations are complete.
While the Forum mall is sited on land zoned for commercial use, the voco Orchard Singapore site currently has only hotel use permitted.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HPL, IReit Global, Sabana Reit, ICP
summary: HPL's co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng has been asked by the CPIB to provide information on his interactions with Transport Minister S Iswaran, who is on leave. IReit Global received 134.7% valid acceptances for its offering, Sabana Reit's EGM has been fixed for Jul 19, and ICP will not proceed with its proposed placement. HPL's shares ended at S$3.86, down 0.3%, while IReit Global's units closed flat at S$0.425 and Sabana Reit's units fell 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow

site_title: US budget deficit nearly triples through June 2023
summary: The US budget deficit nearly tripled to $1.39 trillion from October 2022 to June 2023, driven by lower receipts and higher spending. Receipts declined 11% compared to the same period last year, while outlays rose 10%. Higher interest expenses and Social Security Administration outlays contributed to the increase. Federal Reserve earnings fell $93 billion, while interest on public debt rose $131 billion to $652 billion. This reflects slower economic growth and higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: The average rate paid on short-term loans for small businesses shot up to 9.2 per cent in June, up 1.4 percentage points from May’s reading – marking the largest increase in short-term borrowing costs since December 2006
The return to positive inflation after a contraction in May suggests wholesale prices remain buoyant in some areas.

site_title: UK's Sunak seeks to end strikes with new pay deals
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has offered pay increases of 6% and above to public sector workers, including teachers, doctors, and police officers, in an attempt to end months of crippling strikes. The pay rises, although below the current 8.7% inflation rate, aim to bridge the gap following the country's worst industrial unrest in over 30 years. However, the government warns that the increases will cost billions of pounds, potentially leading to cuts elsewhere, and has ruled out further negotiations.

images.alt_text: The bitter row between junior doctors and the government has seen them call for their 2008-9 pay levels to be restored – something the government says would mean an average pay award of about 35 per cent.

site_title: ICP terminates proposed share placement after Aw Cheok Huat’s cash offer
summary: ICP Ltd, a CATALIST-listed company, has terminated its proposed share placement of approximately 570.8 million shares after a mandatory conditional cash offer by controlling shareholder Aw Cheok Huat to acquire all shares at S$0.007 per share. The placement was deemed impracticable due to the material adverse change caused by Aw's offer, which was made just hours after ICP announced the placement.

images.alt_text: ICP, which has Travelodge Hotels (Asia) as one of its main operating subsidiaries, has received a requisition notice in part due to related party transactions between itself and Datapulse Technology, for which Aw Cheok Huat is Chairman.
ICP, which has Travelodge Hotels (Asia) as one of its main operating subsidiaries, will also vote at the EGM on the appointment of two new directors.

site_title: Founder of crypto lender Celsius Network pleads not guilty to fraud charges
summary: Alex Mashinsky, founder of bankrupt cryptocurrency lender Celsius Network, pleaded not guilty to US fraud charges for misleading customers and artificially inflating the value of his company's propriety crypto token, Cel. He faces seven criminal counts, including securities fraud and wire fraud. Three federal regulatory agencies also sued Mashinsky and Celsius, alleging the company raised billions of dollars through unregistered crypto securities and misled investors about its financial state. Mashinsky was released on a $40 million bond secured by his Manhattan residence.

images.alt_text: Fahrenheit will provide the capital, management team and technology to establish and operate the new company (NewCo), Celsius says.
Crypto lenders such as Celsius boomed during the Covid-19 pandemic, drawing depositors with high interest rates and easy access to loans rarely offered by traditional banks.

site_title: Oil prices up, hit nearly 3-month high as US inflation eases
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% to nearly a 3-month high on Thursday, driven by easing US inflation data. US consumer prices rose modestly in June, the smallest annual increase in over two years, causing the US dollar index to drop and boosting oil prices. Markets expect just one more interest rate rise, which could slow economic growth and reduce oil demand. Oil demand is expected to hit a record high this year, with OPEC maintaining an upbeat world oil demand outlook.

images.alt_text: Top producer Saudi Arabia pledged last week to extend a production cut of 1 million bpd in August, while Russia will cut exports by 500,000 bpd.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on signs of disinflation
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by producer price data showing signs of disinflation, which boosted hopes for an end to the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 64.88 points, or 0.19%, to 34,412.31, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The positive start comes after a five-day rally in Singapore stocks, ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: India to reject call for anti-subsidy tax on some Chinese steel products
summary: India will not impose a countervailing duty (CVD) on select Chinese steel products, despite a recommendation from trade officials and lobbying from local steel manufacturers. The decision, made by the finance ministry, aims to protect steel consuming firms from higher prices, but may hurt local steel manufacturers. The move comes as China is poised to export a record amount of steel this year, with imports from India rising 62% in April-May. The decision is seen as a rare move to protect consumers, but also benefits Chinese shipments at a time of economic recovery in India.

images.alt_text: India levies a 15 per cent tax on gold imports.

site_title: Associated Press, OpenAI partner to explore generative AI use in news
summary: Associated Press (AP) has partnered with OpenAI to explore the use of generative AI in news products. AP will license part of its text archive to OpenAI, while leveraging the technology from the makers of ChatGPT. The arrangement aims to benefit journalism, with AP's senior vice-president stating that news organizations should have a seat at the table to utilize this technology.

site_title: Singapore narrowly avoids technical recession in Q2 as GDP grows 0.7% year on year, 0.3% quarterly
summary: Singapore's economy narrowly avoided a technical recession in Q2, growing 0.7% year-on-year and 0.3% quarterly, driven by a strong services sector and a 6.6% year-on-year growth in the construction sector. The manufacturing sector shrank 7.5% year-on-year, but the decline slowed to 1.3% sequentially. The government's official forecast range is 0.5% to 2.5% for the full year, and analysts expect growth to come in around the mid-point, with some downgrading their forecasts due to a sluggish manufacturing sector and regional trade activity.

images.alt_text: Singapore GDP grew 0.4% in Q1; full-year growth expected at mid-point of 0.5 to 2.5% range

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as tech leads gains on US Fed rate optimism
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Thursday, extending a five-day winning streak, driven by technology stocks and a weaker dollar. The Stoxx 600 index gained 1.7% as rate-sensitive stocks like Softcat and miners rose. A faster-than-expected US inflation slowdown reinforced bets that the Federal Reserve may end rate hikes soon. Despite falling eurozone bond yields, investors remain cautious, awaiting the Fed's interest rate decision later this month.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 1.5 per cent higher, extending gains to the fourth straight day.

site_title: Celebrate Mid-Autumn Festival with Raffles Hotel Singapore
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore is celebrating the Mid-Autumn Festival with its annual collection of classic and new mooncake treats, available for purchase from Aug 1 to Sep 29. The selection includes traditional and contemporary mooncakes, such as the new Sakura & Raspberry Truffle Snow-Skin Mooncake and Yam & Coconut Rum Truffle Snow-Skin Mooncake, as well as the best-selling Champagne Truffle Snow-Skin Mooncake. The mooncakes are handcrafted by Raffles master chefs and beautifully presented in elegant boxes, making them ideal gifts or treats for family and friends.

images.alt_text: The entrance to 2-star Ynyshir. You don't get more rural than this.

site_title: Syngenta seeks to lure Mideast sovereign funds to 65 billion yuan IPO
summary: Syngenta, a Chinese-owned seed giant, has approached Middle Eastern sovereign funds, including the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, to invest in its 65 billion yuan (US$9 billion) Shanghai IPO. The move aims to attract cornerstone investors as rising interest rates and risk aversion deter other major investors. Closer ties between China and the Middle East are expected to boost capital flow into Asia's largest economy. Deliberations are still in the early stage, with representatives for the funds and Syngenta declining to comment.

site_title: Amazon’s ‘biggest ever’ Prime Day boosts US online sales to US$12.7 billion
summary: Amazon's Prime Day shopping event saw a 6.1% increase in US online sales to $12.7 billion, surpassing last year's figure. Over 375 million items were bought worldwide, with Prime members saving over $2.5 billion on deals. Average order size rose to $54.05, driven by discounts on electronics, apparel, and back-to-school items. The event marked Amazon's largest Prime Day ever, with rival retailers also offering discounts, and Amazon workers in Britain striking over a pay dispute.

images.alt_text: An Amazon worker prepares to deliver orders on Amazon Prime Day in New York City. Consumers spent US$6.4 billion online in the first 24 hours of the event.

site_title: VinFast’s Spac partner for US listing extends its lifespan by one year
summary: BSA shareholders, a special purpose acquisition company (Spac) partnering with Vietnam's VinFast, voted to extend its lifespan by a year. The Spac will now be valid until July 20, 2024, allowing VinFast to pursue a US listing. The initial merger deadline was this month, but the vote postpones the deal. BSA's shareholders had not yet voted on the merger with VinFast, which is expected to occur in the second half of this year.

images.alt_text: VinFast had said in May that it will list in the US by merging with SPAC company Black Spade in the second half of this year.
VinFast will release an over-the-air software update on May 25.
VinFast’s SPAC deal is expected to close in the second half of 2023.

site_title: OpenAI’s ChatGPT bot probed by FTC over consumer harms
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has sent a request for information to OpenAI regarding its ChatGPT conversational AI bot, as part of an investigation into potential consumer harms. The probe comes amid concerns from artificial intelligence leaders about the technology's potential to harm humanity. FTC Chair Lina Khan has emphasized the need for vigilance in regulating transformative tools like AI. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has called for robust safety standards for advanced AI systems, warning that the technology could "go quite wrong" if not properly regulated.

images.alt_text: The finalised guidelines stipulate that offshore providers of generative AI tools – if they are aimed at Chinese residents – must also comply with the set of rules.
Google has now added new features to Bard, which apply worldwide.
The lawsuit against OpenAI alleges that summaries of the plaintiffs’ work generated by ChatGPT indicate the bot was trained on their copyrighted content.
FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed ChatGPT logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
OpenAI says that means they will train AI systems using human feedback, train AI systems to assistant human evaluation, and then finally train AI systems to actually do the alignment research.
ChatGPT set off a frenzied use of generative AI in daily tasks from writing to coding and reached 100 million monthly active users in January, two months after its launch.

site_title: Singapore is being too picky about its billionaires
summary: Singapore's efforts to attract family offices may be hindered by its strict rules and tax breaks. Despite a 22-fold increase in family offices since 2018, they manage only 2% of Singapore's $4 trillion assets and have no local economic linkages. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has introduced incentives, but rules have been tightened, requiring new entrants to notify the central bank and maintain a relationship with a regulated financial institution. Singapore may lose out to Hong Kong, which has a more lenient approach to attracting wealthy individuals and families.

images.alt_text: Further, MAS will also recognise grants that SFOs give to support blended finance structures, as two dollars for every dollar of grant given.

Among the 1,400 locals employed by single family offices that receive tax incentives in Singapore, about 900 of these jobs were created in just the last three years, said Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, adding that these are “generally well-paying jobs”.

site_title: PepsiCo raises outlook, sees resilience after strong quarter
summary: PepsiCo raised its sales and earnings estimates for the year, citing resilience in the face of high inflation. Organic revenue is expected to grow 10% and earnings per share to increase by 12% at constant currencies. The company attributes this to improved productivity and digital enhancements, as well as consumers still willing to pay higher prices for its products. CEO Ramon Laguarta noted that lower-income shoppers are searching for deals, but the majority of consumers remain loyal to their brands.

images.alt_text: PepsiCo’s revenue rose 16 per cent in Russia and profits quadrupled, and the soda maker said operations in Russia accounted for 5 per cent of consolidated net revenue for 2022, up from 4 per cent a year earlier.

site_title: Patek Philippe’s most original travel timepiece
summary: Patek Philippe has released a two-time zone travel watch, the Calatrava Ref 5224R, which offers an original display of local and home time. The watch features two centre hands, one for home time and the other for local time, and is powered by a micro rotor movement visible through the sapphire-crystal caseback. The 24-hour dial features a double railway-track scale and 44 rose-gold appliqués, ensuring excellent legibility throughout the day. The watch is priced at S$76,400 and is part of Patek Philippe's extensive collection of travel timepieces.

site_title: Sensodyne toothpaste-maker Haleon planning job cuts
summary: Haleon, the world's largest standalone consumer health business, is planning to cut hundreds of jobs in the UK and potentially thousands worldwide. The company, behind Sensodyne toothpaste and Advil painkillers, has more than 24,000 staff globally. The redundancies were announced in a series of meetings and a consultation process, with those affected expected to leave in September. The company had previously announced £300 million in cost savings and £150 million in restructuring costs for 2023 and 2024.

site_title: MAS tax exemption tweaks may not move the needle for most single family offices: industry watchers
summary: Singapore's tax incentive tweaks for single family offices (SFOs) have been welcomed by most, but may not significantly impact the bulk of players. New requirements are being implemented, but some SFOs are finding it challenging to keep track of the changes. Industry watchers view the tweaks as a "good nudge" for investments, but calls for going beyond tax incentives to grow the SFO space in Singapore have also been made.

images.alt_text: Further, MAS will also recognise grants that SFOs give to support blended finance structures, as two dollars for every dollar of grant given.

Among the 1,400 locals employed by single family offices that receive tax incentives in Singapore, about 900 of these jobs were created in just the last three years, said Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, adding that these are “generally well-paying jobs”.

site_title: US economic activity rises but growth seen slowing, says Fed Beige book
summary: The US economy showed a slight increase in activity since late May, with most regions expecting slow growth in the coming months. Employment rose modestly, with difficulty in finding workers, and inflation rates increased at a modest pace, but at a slower rate in some districts. Price expectations remained stable or lower, offering relief to policymakers who are considering pausing or halting rate hikes. This report may give the Federal Reserve flexibility to adjust its policy after this month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Thomas Barkin poses during a break at a conference in Dallas, Texas, U.S., May 23, 2019. REUTERS/Ann Saphir/File Photo

site_title: CK Asset says Hong Kong luxury home project sale falls through
summary: CK Asset Holdings, a Hong Kong property developer, said its HK$20.8 billion luxury residential development deal to a Singapore fund has lapsed after the buyer failed to pay the first part payment of HK$1.04 billion. The deal, signed in September, was terminated and the HK$2.1 billion deposit paid by the buyer forfeited. The collapse of the deal is attributed to market and interest rate changes, and CK Asset will put the development on the market again. The company stated that the deal's collapse will not have a material adverse impact on its business.

images.alt_text: Generally, demand for industrial real estate including warehouses is more resilient than offices in Hong Kong.

site_title: US wholesale prices return to growth in June
summary: US wholesale prices increased modestly in June, rising 0.1% due to an increase in the cost of services. This rebound from a contraction in May suggests wholesale prices remain buoyant in some areas. The producer price index (PPI) ticked up, indicating a return to positive inflation.

images.alt_text: Imports have fallen 2.7 per cent to about US$254 billion, also the lowest since November; the decline was led by a drop in consumer goods.

site_title: Walk on the wild side of South Africa
summary: A writer recently took a trip to the South African savannah for an African safari experience, discovering the majesty of wildlife up close. The author notes that while safaris may seem inaccessible, Johannesburg's OR Tambo International Airport is only a 10-hour flight away. Despite the inconvenience of early morning calls, multiple drives, and limited free time, the author found the experience to be unforgettable, with encounters with giraffes, elephants, lions, and leopards. However, the author also highlights the contrast between the natural beauty of the savannah and the country's energy crisis, which has been ongoing since 2007.

images.alt_text: Anchovies at Table by Bruno Verjus, the No 10 ranked restaurant.

site_title: FDA approves first over-the-counter birth control pill in US
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved the first over-the-counter birth control pill, Opill, allowing millions of women to purchase it without a prescription. The daily contraceptive, sold by Perrigo, was first approved for prescription use in 1973 and uses progestin instead of estrogen. The approval is expected to increase access to contraceptives, cutting barriers of cost and time, and is seen as a step towards meaningful access to healthcare for Americans. The pill will be available in stores and online in the first quarter of next year, with Perrigo sharing its pricing plan next week.

images.alt_text: Abortion rights protesters at a Pro Choice rally at the Tucson Federal Courthouse in Tucson, Arizona on July 4, 2022. President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris will address a gathering of major abortion-rights groups including Emily’s List, Planned Parenthood and Naral Pro-choice America.

site_title: Supply squeeze forces co-working operators to get creative
summary: Singapore's co-working industry is facing a supply squeeze, with limited new office space completion in the Central Business District (CBD) and rising rents. Co-working operators are looking to Grade B offices and heartlands for expansion, with some opting for retail spaces with higher footfall. The industry's growth has been subdued, with demand increasing by 25% in 2022 but supply only rising by 3%. Operators are adopting a more conservative approach, opting for management contracts instead of conventional leases, and are considering locations outside the CBD.

images.alt_text: Co-working operators are having to prove their worth to landlords as their deals with landlords evolve.

site_title: Hearing over contended Sabana Reit EGM set for Jul 19
summary: A hearing for Sabana Reit's contested extraordinary general meeting (EGM) has been set for July 19. The EGM was requisitioned by activist investor Quarz Capital to remove Sabana Real Estate Investment Management as manager in favor of an internal manager. ESR Group, the sponsor of Sabana Reit, had sought to block the EGM but lost in the Singapore High Court, which dismissed its application for an interim injunction. The hearing will provide clarity on how to proceed with the requisition and prevent uncertainty among unitholders.

images.alt_text: The EGM requisitioned by activist investor Quarz Capital is set to take place on Aug 4.
Sabana Reit's manager ought to obtain clarity from UOB and other lenders on whether they plan to pull back their credit facilities in the event unitholders vote for internalisation.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. Quarz Capital had requisitioned the EGM, which was slated to take place on Aug 4, to vote on two resolutions.
Should Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust be managed externally or internally?

site_title: A glorious changing of the seasons
summary: Gucci's Allegoria High Jewellery collection celebrates the four seasons with vibrant hues and maximalist designs. The collection features intricate pieces with precious stones, antique stones, and eclectic cuts. Each chapter represents a season, with Spring showcasing fresh blooms, Summer featuring cool blues and greens, Autumn highlighting warm, muted colors, and Winter embracing crystalline ice and festive joy. The collection's unique approach to jewellery design showcases Gucci's savoir-faire, with one-of-a-kind pieces that evoke a sense of joy and life.

images.alt_text: Chanel's regal Tweed Royal necklace.
Under a cabochon-inspired dome, Bulgari's Divas’ Dream Acquarium watch recreated a miniaturised living aquarium.
Tiffany Lock bangles re-envision the padlock – a key motif from The Tiffany Archives.
White opals are put to great effect in a pair of Les Jardins de la Couture pink gold and diamond dangle earrings from Dior.
Bois de Rose bracelet in pink gold and diamonds.
Tweed Mademoiselle ring in white gold and diamonds.
For Tiffany, it is important that consumers are aware of where its diamonds come from.

site_title: Sound and fury: China and the US talking
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's recent visit to China signals efforts to restart dialogue with the US, but its impact on businesses remains uncertain. Yellen's visit with Vice-Premier He Lifeng highlighted significant disagreements, and the US is not committed to a policy of confrontation. However, the Biden administration's actions, such as restricting access to high-tech chips and imposing export controls, suggest a more hardline stance. The renewed economic dialogue may discourage further measures, but it is unlikely to unwind existing policies. The US and China's deep economic interdependence and shared growth concerns should be prioritized, as security issues are not the only consideration.

images.alt_text: US treasury secretary Janet Yellen with Chinese vice premier He Lifeng during a meeting at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing on July 8, 2023.
China’s attempts to encourage foreign investors have ramped up in recent weeks, as it has become clear that the economy’s recovery following the end of its zero-Covid policies is starting to flag.

site_title: Yeo Yann Yann: Iron Lady makes it to Hollywood
summary: Singaporean actress Yeo Yann Yann, known for her roles in "Ilo Ilo" and "Wet Season," has achieved mainstream success in Hollywood with her recent TV show "American Born Chinese" on Disney+. At 46, Yeo is defying ageism in the entertainment industry, which has historically pressured actors to retire in their 40s and 50s. Despite facing postpartum depression and struggling with negative comments about her appearance, Yeo persevered and continues to take on challenging roles. She aspires to follow in the footsteps of her acting idols, including Michelle Yeoh, and is open to playing meaty roles in her 50s and beyond.

site_title: Tudor’s Black Bay line curves and sparkles
summary: Tudor's latest Black Bay 31/36/39/41 collection presents a softer, sophisticated look with curved cases, domed sides, and a fixed bezel. The watches aim for a "versatile, unisex" feel, despite still being robust enough for diving up to 100 meters deep. The collection features sun-ray dials in blue, anthracite, and light champagne, and new in-house self-winding movements certified by the Official Swiss Chronometer Testing Institute (COSC) with a power reserve of 70 hours. Prices range from S$6,220 to S$11,650.

site_title: US dollar tumbles after inflation data upends rate outlook
summary: The US dollar plummeted to its lowest level since April, down 0.4% against the euro and 0.4% against the Swiss franc, after inflation data showed a slower-than-expected rate of 0.2% in June. This led to a shift in market expectations, with interest rate futures pricing in a potential end to US rate hikes and a narrowing gap between US and foreign borrowing rates. The euro and sterling rose against the US dollar, while the yen held steady, as traders anticipated a dovish stance from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: NTUC to beef up career mentorship programmes for youths and push for quality internships
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has announced plans to expand its career mentorship and mental health programs for young workers, following a year-long engagement with over 10,000 youths aged 17-25. The findings highlighted the importance of career mentorship, job preparation sessions, and extra funding support for trainings and upskilling. NTUC is also launching a new hub for career mentorships and a "quality internship" initiative to address the need for better work arrangements and mental well-being support.

images.alt_text: Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Mar 02, 2023.
