images.alt_text: Chef Violet Oon along with her children are seeking to buyout the 50 per cent shareholding of Group MMM in Violet Oon Singapore through legal proceedings.
(From left) Violet Oon's children Yiming Tay, Ms Su-lyn Tay, Ms Violet Oon and investor Manoj Murjani, chairman of Group MMM.

veviolet25 - Violet Oon Singapore outlet at Jewel Changi Airport. 

Credit: Violet Oon Singapore

site_title: Beyond decoupling and de-risking: Yellen’s visit puts a more positive spin on Sino-American ties
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's recent visit to China aimed to stabilize and promote the US-China economic relationship, contrary to calls for "de-coupling." Yellen emphasized the importance of maintaining open trade and investment ties between the two economies, citing the need for a non-zero-sum game and the interconnectedness of their global output. She downplayed the US's restrictive measures, such as controls on outbound investment, stating they should not significantly impact the investment climate. Yellen's softer tone may not change Beijing's perception, but it signals a shift towards a more positive spin on Sino-American ties.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and US Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns meet with representatives of the US business community in China. She said a decoupling of the US and Chinese economies would be “virtually impossible” and would destabilise global markets.
Yellen’s comments were delivered on Friday (Jul 7) during a meeting with Chinese Premier Li Qiang.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s overall message was for both sides to manage their rivalry with a fair set of rules. “President Biden and I do not see the relationship between the US and China through the frame of great power conflict,” she says. “We believe the world is big enough for both of our countries to thrive.”

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen met with officials including Premier Li Qiang, Vice Premier He Lifeng, Finance Minister Liu Kun and Pan Gongsheng, whom US officials described as the head of China’s central bank.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise, Irish stocks lead
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.7% on Tuesday, marking the third straight session of gains. Irish stocks led the advance, jumping 2.1%, driven by Kingspan's 15.7% gain after forecasting record profits for the first half. China extended some policy measures to support its real estate sector, boosting shares of luxury firms and industrial stocks. Investors await US data on consumer prices due on Wednesday for clarity on the US interest rate hiking cycle.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 0.2 per cent higher after recording its worst weekly performance in almost four months on Friday.

site_title: JPMorgan plans to lay off 63 employees in Jersey City
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to lay off 63 employees in Jersey City, New Jersey, as part of a larger restructuring effort. The bank has 560 positions open in the state and is working to redeploy affected employees. This move comes as the bank continues to review its operations and invest in the long-term. The job cuts are part of JPMorgan's regular review and do not reflect a change in its strategy.

images.alt_text: A man exits the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters building in New York, U.S. in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 8, 2011. LivingSocial, the second-largest daily-coupon site, is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase & Co. as one of the banks to manage its initial public offering, a person with knowledge of the talks said. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil settles up 2% at 10-week high on weaker US dollar, rising demand forecasts
summary: Oil prices surged 2% on Tuesday, reaching a 10-week high, driven by a weaker US dollar, hopes for higher demand in developing countries, and supply cuts by top exporters. Brent futures rose $1.71 to $79.40 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $1.84 to $74.83. The US dollar's drop to a two-month low against other currencies made crude cheaper for holders of other currencies. Analysts expect higher demand and supply cuts to maintain tight oil market conditions.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia will extend its 1 million barrels per day output cut into August and Russia will cut crude exports by 500,000 bpd.

site_title: Unlocking the power of generative AI
summary: Generative AI has made significant strides in various applications and sectors, offering immense benefits for businesses, including cybersecurity, task automation, and personal assistants. However, its limitations and potential issues must be addressed to avoid "gold-rush frenzy" and "development inertia." To unlock the full potential of generative AI, organisations must combine Large Language Models with up-to-date data and establish an ethical framework, prioritising user privacy and data protection. By doing so, they can bridge the gap between AI technology and human understanding, ultimately deriving maximum value from this transformative technology.

images.alt_text: Whether the world is ready for it or not, AI has become a democratic force for leaders to seek ways to extend the benefits of its capabilities across enterprises.
Alibaba's AI image generator, Tongyi Wanxiang, will compete with OpenAI’s DALL-E and Midjourney’s Midjourney

site_title: ‘Meta loses more’: Zuckerberg takes Threads fight to EU
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has withheld Meta's Threads app from European users due to "regulatory uncertainty" around the Digital Markets Act (DMA), an antitrust regulation that won't take effect until next year. Analysts predict Meta will struggle to maintain the embargo, and some believe the move may ultimately harm the company by missing out on 450 million potential customers. The DMA's rules, which include banning data transfers across platforms without consent, could prove "fatal" to Threads' rollout.

images.alt_text: The branded content tools will help marketers collaborate with influencers on paid partnerships on the social media platform while advertising is unavailable.

Several rivals to Twitter have emerged but most do not have the capacity to grow at the necessary scale to dethrone Twitter. Threads is finding it easier because it is linked to Instagram, which has more than one billion regular users.

site_title: India hits online gaming industry with 28% tax
summary: India's government has imposed a 28% tax on funds collected by online gaming companies from customers, affecting the $1.5 billion industry. The tax is expected to lead to higher ticket prices for games. Industry executives, including the CEO of The All India Gaming Federation, have criticized the decision as "unconstitutional and irrational". The move is seen as a setback for the industry, which has attracted international investors such as Tiger Global. The tax is expected to impact companies' cash flows and could lead to increased costs for gaming apps.

site_title: Temasek seeks talks with Ant on buyback valuation
summary: Temasek, a major shareholder of Ant Group, is set to discuss a planned share buyback with the company. The buyback, which would value Ant at about $105.6 billion, is part of the company's efforts to recover from a regulatory crackdown. Each investor, including Temasek, would be allowed to sell up to 7.6% of their equity rather than cashing out completely. The move comes as investors weigh the risks and opportunities in China's struggling economy.

images.alt_text: On Saturday, Ant proposed to buy back as much as 7.6 per cent of shares in an effort to provide a chance to cut stakes for investors ensnared by a years-long regulatory crackdown at the fintech powerhouse.

site_title: Microsoft wins US court nod to buy Activision in FTC loss
summary: Microsoft has won a US court's approval to proceed with its $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, defeating a challenge from the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to block the deal. The decision allows Microsoft to close the merger ahead of its July 18 deadline, except in the UK, where the deal was vetoed in May. The combined company will vault Microsoft to the No. 3 slot among global video-game companies, with Activision's mobile games, including Candy Crush, set to boost Microsoft's presence in the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft logo is seen on a smartphone placed on displayed Activision Blizzard's games characters in this illustration taken January 18, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: BofA to pay US$250 million over extra fees, unauthorised cards
summary: Bank of America has agreed to pay $250 million, including $150 million in fines and $100 million to customers, for improperly charging extra fees, withholding rewards, and opening unauthorized credit-card accounts. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau alleges that the bank systematically double-dipped on fees imposed on customers with insufficient funds and failed to pay promised credit-card reward bonuses. The bank will also change its business practices, including halting the practice of opening unauthorised accounts and disclosing limits on credit-card rewards and bonuses.

images.alt_text: BofA had cited a dialogue with the Fed to understand differing results between the central bank’s stress test and the companies’ own under the Dodd-Frank Act.

site_title: Rio Tinto, Japan’s Sumitomo to build hydrogen plant in Queensland
summary: Rio Tinto and Sumitomo Corporation plan to build a hydrogen plant in Gladstone, Queensland, to minimize carbon emissions at the Yarwun alumina refinery. The plant, expected to be operational by 2025, will produce 6,000 tonnes of alumina annually and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 3,000 tonnes per year. Construction will start in 2024 and will include a 2.5-megawatt on-site electrolyser to supply hydrogen to the refinery. The project aims to test the feasibility of using hydrogen as a replacement for natural gas in Queensland alumina refineries.

site_title: Disney explores strategic options for India business: WSJ
summary: Disney is exploring strategic options for its Star India business, including a joint venture or sale, amid macroeconomic headwinds affecting advertising revenue and subscriber growth. The company has discussed costs-sharing arrangements with a bank to help the India business grow. Disney's Star India business is expected to see a 20% revenue drop and a 50% earnings decline for the fiscal year ending September 2023. The company has already cut 7,000 jobs as part of a cost-saving effort. Talks are in the early stages, and it's unclear which options Disney might pursue.

images.alt_text: Director Ali Selim revealed in a recent interview that the Disney+ show used AI as well as human illustrators to generate its opening credits.

site_title: Israel protests flare over Netanyahu’s new Supreme Court Bill
summary: Thousands of protesters blocked Israel's main airport and highways on July 11, opposing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's judicial overhaul bill. The bill aims to curb the Supreme Court's power, sparking unprecedented protests and concern over Israel's democratic health. Protests have disrupted traffic, bruised the economy, and alarmed investors, with the shekel dropping nearly 8% since January. Netanyahu's nationalist-religious coalition presses ahead with the bill, despite opposition from Western allies and critics, who argue it will undermine democracy and checks and balances.

images.alt_text: Proposals by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s (top) hard-right coalition to give the government greater say in the selection of judges while limiting the Supreme Court’s power to strike down legislation have worried current and potential investors.

Intel, which has been operating in Israel since 1974, says its intention to expand “is driven by our commitment to meeting future manufacturing needs and supporting Intel’s IDM 2.0 strategy, and we appreciate the continued support of the Israeli government”.

site_title: Nato welcomes Ukraine’s membership but stops short of invitation
summary: NATO leaders stated that Ukraine should be able to join the military alliance in the future, but stopped short of offering an immediate invitation. They dropped the requirement for Ukraine to fulfill a Membership Action Plan, removing a hurdle for Kyiv's entry. The leaders also declared "Ukraine's future is in NATO," but offered no timeline for the process. This decision was met with anger from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

images.alt_text: Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg had convened Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan and Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson for several hours of talks on the eve of the summit as he sought to finally break the deadlock.

site_title: Canada probes Nike, Dynasty Gold over alleged use of forced labour in China
summary: Canada's corporate ethics watchdog has launched separate investigations into Nike Canada and Dynasty Gold over alleged use of forced Uyghur labour in China. The investigations follow complaints filed by a coalition of 28 civil society organizations in 2022. The UN human rights chief has previously reported that China's treatment of Uyghurs may constitute crimes against humanity. Nike Canada and Dynasty Gold deny the allegations, with Dynasty Gold calling them "totally unfounded." The watchdog will publish final reports with recommendations, which could lead to further action if companies are found guilty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a store of the sporting goods retailer Nike Inc at a shopping complex in Beijing, China March 25, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: 27% of jobs at high risk from AI revolution: OECD
summary: According to the OECD, 27% of jobs are at high risk of being automated by AI, defined as jobs using more than 25 of 100 skills and abilities that can be easily automated. The organization notes that while AI has not yet had a significant impact on jobs, the revolution is in its early stages. The report comes as workers fear job losses to AI, highlighting the need for policymakers to address the potential consequences of automation.

images.alt_text: Organisations looking to establish generative AI as an integral part of everyday business will need to exercise caution, and address its potential issues and limitations.

site_title: Conserved black-and-white bungalow on Lady Hill Road put on market with S$110 million price tag
summary: A conserved black-and-white bungalow on Lady Hill Road in Singapore's Nassim Road Good Class Bungalow Area has been put on the market with a guide price of at least S$4,000 per square foot, totaling S$109.9 million. The property, with a 27,465 sq ft freehold site, features four levels, a built-up area of 7,000 sq ft, and a wide frontage. The sale is part of a consolidation phase in the GCB market, which has seen a decline in transactions since 2021.

images.alt_text: This bungalow in the Nassim Road GCB Area was completed about a decade ago. It changed hands earlier this year for S$88 million or S$3,917 psf on land area.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit’s manager must justify decision to sell assets below valuation
summary: ESR-Logos Reit's manager is facing scrutiny over selling seven industrial properties for S$337 million, a 5.1% discount to their valuation. The trust will incur a net loss of S$30.7 million, and investors question the decision, given the trust's financial health and gearing ratio. The manager claims the sale will enable recapitalization and improve portfolio quality, but critics argue that selling assets below valuation may not be in the best interest of unitholders. The sale is part of a larger trend in the listed property trust sector, where external managers may prioritize fees over unitholder interests.

images.alt_text: The debt headroom would allow ESR-Logos Reit to recapitalise for growth in a very timely environment, says Adrian Chui, chief executive officer and executive director of the manager.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. Quarz Capital had requisitioned the EGM, which was slated to take place on Aug 4, to vote on two resolutions.

site_title: US banking giants to report higher profits even as dealmaking drags
summary: US banking giants are expected to report higher profits for the second quarter, with EPS jumping over 40% at JPMorgan and Wells Fargo, and rising 7% at Bank of America. However, investment banking behemoths like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are expected to experience a decline in EPS, with Goldman's dropping almost 59% and Morgan's down 9%. Despite this, revenue from wealth management is expected to cushion the blow for Morgan Stanley. The increase in profits is attributed to rising interest payments offsetting a downturn in dealmaking.

site_title: US investigates 346,000 Ford Escape SUVs over door issues
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating 346,000 Ford Escape SUVs due to a potential issue with the door assembly, where a weld may fail, causing the door to open while driving. There have been 25 reports of minor injuries and one report of minor property damage linked to this issue. The investigation follows 118 questionnaire submissions from 2020-21 model year Ford Escape vehicles.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Ford logo is pictured at the 2019 Frankfurt Motor Show (IAA) in Frankfurt, Germany September 10, 2019. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Greener pastures: Getting Asia closer to net-zero
summary: Asia is making progress towards reaching its net-zero goals, with issuances in the region increasing by nearly 10% in 2022 to $391 billion, mostly comprising green bonds and sustainability-linked loans. The Asia-Pacific region is home to the world's largest emitters, offering significant opportunities for sustainable finance. However, challenges remain, including a financing gap, lack of standard-setting, and limited voluntary carbon markets. To overcome these issues, companies must set targets, track and measure their progress, and access data and reporting resources. Partnerships with experts like Standard Chartered can provide crucial support in achieving net-zero goals.

images.alt_text: Michael Spiegel, global head, Transaction Banking at Standard Chartered Bank

site_title: Foxconn targets India’s chip scheme after pulling plug on US$19.5 billion JV
summary: Foxconn is exploring opportunities to partner with local and international companies to manufacture semiconductors in India, following its withdrawal from a US$19.5 billion joint venture with Vedanta. The Taiwanese firm aims to apply for incentives under India's semiconductor production plan, which offers up to 50% of capital costs for eligible projects. Foxconn's decision comes after the Vedanta breakup, a setback for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's chipmaking plans for India, and amid concerns over Vedanta's financial stability.

images.alt_text: “Foxconn is working to remove the Foxconn name from what now is a fully-owned entity of Vedanta,” the electronics manufacturer says.

site_title: Bank of England may need to keep rates higher for longer, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that the Bank of England (BOE) may need to keep interest rates high for an extended period to combat inflation pressures, which reached 8.7% in May. The IMF's directors have stated that if inflationary pressures persist, the policy rate may need to be raised further and remain higher for longer to durably lower inflation and anchor inflation expectations. This suggests a more aggressive tightening than expected for the US Federal Reserve or the European Central Bank.

images.alt_text: epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Saudi Arabia’s oil production cuts are quietly starting to bite
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil production cuts are starting to impact the global market, with prices rising to around $78 a barrel. The cuts are affecting lighter, sweeter oil varieties, leading to a surge in prices for heavier, sour grades. Refineries are clamoring for alternatives to Saudi oil, and some are looking to other markets, such as the US and West Africa. The market is shifting towards heavier grades, driven by strong demand for gasoline and fuel oil, and a halt in Iraqi oil exports.

images.alt_text: A crude oil tanker at an oil terminal off Waidiao island in Zhoushan, Zhejiang province, China.

site_title: US: US stocks open higher ahead of inflation numbers
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday ahead of inflation data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 112.54 points, or 0.33%, to 34,056.94. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 6.02 points, or 0.14%, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 24.33 points, or 0.18%. Investors are hopeful that a slowdown in inflation could lead to a sooner end to the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening policy.

site_title: India’s government orders inspection of Byju’s finances
summary: India's Ministry of Corporate Affairs has ordered an inspection of Byju's finances and accounting practices, following the resignation of its auditor and three board members. The inspection, due in six weeks, aims to assess the company's state of affairs and determine if the matter needs to be escalated to the Serious Fraud Investigation Office. Byju's, valued at $22 billion, has been struggling financially, cutting thousands of jobs and seeking to raise over $1 billion to tide over difficulties. The company has not received any communication from the MCA and will cooperate with any routine inspection.

site_title: US dollar falls to 2-month low, sterling hits 15-month high after jobs data
summary: The US dollar fell to a 2-month low of 101.66 against a basket of currencies after Federal Reserve officials signaled the end of its monetary policy tightening cycle. Meanwhile, the British pound hit a 15-month high of US$1.2933 after UK wage growth reached a joint record high. The pound's rally was driven by expectations of tighter Bank of England policy to control inflation. Other European currencies, such as the Norwegian krone and Swedish krona, also strengthened against the greenback.

site_title: Steady long-term return expected for gold: World Gold Council strategist
summary: Gold is expected to generate real returns of 2-3% per year, net of inflation, according to World Gold Council strategist John Reade. The near-term outlook depends on the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut, with Reade predicting nominal returns of 6-7% over the next few years. Central bank purchases, particularly from emerging markets, have been supportive of gold prices, with 24% of central banks planning to raise their reserves in the next 12 months. Gold's price is expected to trade between $1,800 and $2,000 per ounce in the near term, with a long-term goal of breaking the all-time high of $2,074.

images.alt_text: The gold price peaked at US$2,039 on March 8 this year after the US announced an import ban on Russian oil followed by the escalation of Russia-Ukraine tension, but the uptrend did not lasted long after a series of interest rate hike by Fed.

site_title: China rare earths body offers cash rewards for illegal mining tip-offs
summary: China's China Rare Earth Industry Association is offering cash rewards for information on illegal rare earths mining, processing, and smuggling. The move aims to curb longstanding issues amid mounting global demand. China dominates the rare earths market, accounting for 70% of global production in 2022. The association will review submitted information and pass it on to relevant authorities. This measure follows a range of measures, including annual mining quotas, to address the problem.

site_title: World's biggest gallium buyer says clients stockpiling
summary: Freiberger Compound Materials, the world's largest gallium buyer, is stockpiling the metal due to China's planned export controls, which will take effect on August 1. The company, which relies on Chinese suppliers for 90% of its gallium needs, is experiencing a surge in orders to increase inventory levels. China's move is seen as "sabre rattling" by the CEO, who believes it will not disrupt global trade flows in the short term. The controls will affect deliveries, but are expected to resume about a month later.

images.alt_text: Chinese authorities have instituted a range of measures to try to curb longstanding problems with illegal rare earths mining in recent years, including a system of annual mining quotas, amid mounting global demand for the minerals.
Gallium is currently used in a wide variety of applications, from LEDs to smaller mobile phone adaptors.
Earlier this week, China put export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables.
Some larger chip manufacturers view China’s export controls on gallium as more of a warning shot about what economic pain the country could inflict.

“The (Defense) Department is proactively taking steps using Defense Production Act Title III authorities to increase domestic mining and processing of critical materials for the microelectronics and space supply chain, including gallium and germanium,” the Pentagon spokesperson says.

site_title: Controlling shareholder Aw Cheok Huat makes conditional cash offer for ICP after S$5.4 million married deal
summary: Controlling shareholder Aw Cheok Huat has made a mandatory conditional cash offer for shares of Catalist-listed company ICP at S$0.007 apiece, following a 23.2% stake acquisition in a S$5.4 million married deal. The offer is solely to comply with the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers and does not aim to introduce major changes to the group's businesses. The offer is conditional on receiving valid acceptances and will result in the offeror and concert parties holding more than 50% of ICP at the close of the offer.

images.alt_text: ICP, which has Travelodge Hotels (Asia) as one of its main operating subsidiaries, will also vote at the EGM on the appointment of two new directors.
The resolutions seek to remove four fellow board members and appoint two others to the board.

site_title: EU lawmakers back chip-production plan
summary: EU lawmakers have approved the EU Chips Act, a plan to quadruple the EU's chip production by 2030 to 20% of global share. The plan requires over 43 billion euros in public and private investments. The goal aims to reduce the EU's dependency on Asian chip manufacturers and address supply chain shortages, particularly affecting the European car industry. The EU Chips Act also includes a monitoring system to detect potential supply shortfalls and reinforced research and development.

images.alt_text: Gallium is currently used in a wide variety of applications, from LEDs to smaller mobile phone adaptors.
Foxconn is in talks with several local and international partners to make semiconductors in India using mature chip manufacturing technology for products including EVs.
“Foxconn is working to remove the Foxconn name from what now is a fully-owned entity of Vedanta,” the electronics manufacturer says.

site_title: Tie-up between UOL-SingLand and CapitaLand bag Tampines mixed-use site at S$1.21 billion
summary: A joint venture between UOL-Singapore Land and CapitaLand Development won a tender for a 99-year leasehold land parcel in Tampines Avenue 11 at S$1.21 billion. The site will be integrated with a bus interchange, community club, and hawker centre, hosting 1,190 housing units. The development will span 126,700 sq m, with a maximum building height of 64 m. The project is expected to yield a maximum gross floor area of 126,700 sq m.

images.alt_text: generic photos of property landscape in singapore, featuring Ubin Thai Buddhist Temple in the foreground

site_title: Global private equity deal volume, value continue slide in June: S&P
summary: Global private equity and venture capital deals declined 59.3% year-over-year in June, with total deal value falling to $27 billion. The number of deals also dropped 44.9% to 847, following a similar trend in the first half of the year. The Asia-Pacific region had the second-highest deal values, totaling $7.1 billion, while technology, media, and telecommunications secured the most capital, raising $9.5 billion. The largest deal was a take-private transaction valued at $2.3 billion by Bain Capital Investors for China-based Chindata Group Holdings.

images.alt_text: Private equity deal volumes and values have fallen year on year in March and in the first quarter of 2023.
DBS will continue to retain a minority stake of 9.9 per cent in AXS.

site_title:
World job market on brink 
of ‘AI revolution’: OECD
summary: The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) warns that the world is on the brink of an "AI revolution" that will significantly impact the job market. While AI adoption is relatively low, rapid progress, falling costs, and increasing AI skills indicate a potential for widespread automation, potentially replacing jobs and creating new ones. The OECD urges the world's wealthiest nations to prepare for this change, focusing on training, social dialogue, and addressing the significant risks and benefits of AI, including data protection and job displacement concerns.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor companies could ride the AI boom, even if they do not directly produce chips that are used in AI applications.

site_title: Deep sea mining threatens US$5.5 billion tuna industry, study finds
summary: A study published in Nature npj Ocean Sustainability predicts that deep sea mining in the Clarion-Clipperton Zone, a region in the Pacific Ocean targeted for mining, could harm the US$5.5 billion Pacific tuna industry. The mining process could damage tuna health through toxic metal releases and disrupt their breeding and migration patterns due to noise and light from extraction operations. The study's findings coincide with the International Seabed Authority's meeting, where nations are calling for a moratorium on seabed mining.

images.alt_text: There is now a growing chorus for a moratorium on deep sea mining. Greenpeace activists protesting in front of the Ministry of Industry in Prague, Czech Republic, June 1, 2023.

Greenpeace activists from New Zealand and Mexico confront the deep sea mining vessel Hidden Gem, commissioned by Canadian miner The Metals Company, as it returned to port from eight weeks of test mining in the Clarion-Clipperton Zone between Mexico and Hawaii, November 16, 2022.

site_title: Amazon launches first Big Tech challenge to EU online content rules
summary: Amazon has launched a legal challenge against EU online content rules, citing unfair singling out as a "Very Large Online Platform" (VLOP) under the Digital Services Act. The US company claims it doesn't fit the VLOP description, despite having more than 45 million users in the EU, as its rivals in these countries have not been designated as such. Amazon's challenge at the Luxembourg-based General Court is the first by a Big Tech company, potentially prompting others to follow suit and challenge the EU's online content regulations.

images.alt_text: Amazon several years ago attempted to build a hotel booking service called Amazon Destinations but it closed a few months after launching.
A TikTok Shop livestreaming session at Flame Media’s studio in Jakarta. Flame Media manages a cast of around 50 live-streaming hosts at a bustling Jakarta shophouse.

site_title: Investment bankers’ pay unlikely to be hit by market slowdown, momentum holds for junior hires
summary: Demand for investment bankers remains strong in Singapore, despite a market slowdown, due to a tight talent market and firms setting up shop in the city-state. Average annual salaries for fresh investment bankers range from S$120,000 to S$150,000. Industry watchers attribute the demand to asset managers and family offices entering the market, with more firms planning to raise salaries. This suggests that investment bankers' pay is unlikely to be hit by the market slowdown.

images.alt_text: Generic photo on growing our economy and equipping our workers

site_title: Indonesia’s parliament approves changes to healthcare laws amid protests
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved revised healthcare laws aimed at attracting foreign talent and improving services. The laws make it easier for foreign doctors to practice, enable patients to file complaints against medical workers, and remove a 5% budget allocation for the health sector. Medical workers protested, citing concerns the reforms could weaken their protections and strain public health centers. The government aims to transform Indonesia's healthcare system, but critics say the changes will destabilize the health sector.

site_title: German investor mood sours in July
summary: German investor confidence declined in July, falling to minus 14.7 points, a worse-than-expected reading. The ZEW institute's economic expectations index dropped 6.2 points, with experts expecting the German economy to shrink by 0.2 to 0.4% in 2023. The decline is attributed to inflation and interest rate hikes, as well as a struggling manufacturing sector, particularly the chemicals industry. This marks a continuation of the gloomy trend, with industry facing a prolonged downturn.

images.alt_text: A worker moves equipment and materials on a cart at the factory of Schuko H. Schulte-Sdhoff GmbH, a manufacturer of extraction systems for the the craft and industrial sectors, in Bad Laer, Germany, on Friday, May 26, 2023. Without a major shift, Germany’s labor force will shrink dramatically in the coming years, undermining economic growth, boosting inflation pressures and posing especially tough challenges to the manufacturing firms like Schuko that are the backbone of Europe's biggest economy. Photographer: Ben Kilb/Bloomberg

A container ship docking at the Port of Hamburg in Hamburg, Germany, on Wednesday, Aug. 24, 2022. Germany's logistics problems are worsening an economic slowdown, with shallow rivers exposing fragile inland supply routes, an under-invested railway system that can't take on the extra capacity, and seaports that are still heaving with cargo. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

Shoppers walk along Friedrichstarsse in Berlin, Germany, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. Germany's economy appears to have held up better through the winter than initially feared. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
The report gives an initial hint of weakness in a pivotal week for data showing the health of manufacturing in Germany after it suffered a recession earlier this year.

site_title: China's yuan strengthens past key level on property support steps
summary: China's yuan strengthened to a two-week high past the 7.2 per US dollar level, breaching a key threshold, after the central bank set a firmer-than-expected midpoint fixing and extended policy support for the struggling property sector. The onshore yuan rose to 7.1934 per dollar, its strongest level since June 21, while the offshore counterpart strengthened to 7.1950, the strongest level since June 26. Analysts expect more easing measures, such as lowering down-payment ratios and easing purchase restrictions, as the central bank aims to shore up the real estate sector and boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: China’s real estate crisis is stifling a recovery in the world’s second-largest economy, fuelling expectations for the government to take more steps to revive demand.

site_title: China June new bank loans jump more than expected on policy support
summary: China's banks extended 3.05 trillion yuan in new yuan loans in June, more than double May's tally and beating analysts' forecasts. Household loans rose to 963.9 billion yuan, while corporate loans soared to 2.28 trillion yuan. The central bank cut its benchmark lending rates by 10 basis points in June to shore up the economy, which is experiencing a post-pandemic recovery fade. Economists predict more stimulus steps are expected, with some analysts expecting another rate cut to come before long.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Headquarters of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Thailand PM Prayuth retires from politics, 9 years after his coup
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-o-cha has announced his retirement from politics, nine years after taking power in a military coup. He will remain caretaker premier until a new government is formed. Prayuth, 69, cited his "many successes" and said he has worked hard to protect the nation and monarchy. His announcement comes after his military-backed party lost a May 14 election, and a new government is expected to be formed soon, potentially leading to market-friendly reforms and a relief rally.

images.alt_text: epa10675351 Move Forward Party leader Pita Limjaroenrat (C) speaks to the media after a meeting with the working group of seven party allies to form a coalition government, at Pheu Thai Party headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 06 June 2023. An eight-party coalition, spearheaded by the Move Forward party, agreed to form a government with Limjaroenrat as prime minister, after winning the most seats in the 14 May general election.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Gary Lineker retains top spot in BBC pay list, with £1.35 million
summary: BBC presenter Gary Lineker retained his top spot in pay, earning £1.35 million in the 2022-23 financial year. He was taken off air in March after criticizing the government's immigration policy on Twitter but was reinstated after a public backlash and staff near-mutiny. The BBC's annual report, published Tuesday, reveals Lineker's salary, drawing criticism about high pay.

images.alt_text: BBC chairman Richard Sharp said he had agreed to a request to stay on until the end of June to give the government time to find his successor.

Cars move past a hoarding of broadcaster BBC, installed along the roadside in Mumbai on February 15, 2023. - Indian tax authorities raided the BBC's New Delhi and Mumbai offices on February 14, weeks after the broadcaster aired a documentary on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's actions during deadly sectarian riots in 2002. (Photo by Indranil MUKHERJEE / AFP)

site_title:
A stock market gift 
right under your nose
summary: The US stock market has experienced a significant rally, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising nearly 33% for the first half of the year. However, investors are uncertain about the long-term prospects of the market. A key ingredient for long-term returns is time and selecting the right stocks. Companies that thrive during difficult economic conditions, such as Booking Holdings and Apple, are likely to outperform in the long run. These companies have demonstrated resilience and growth in both good and bad times, making them attractive investment options.

images.alt_text: Wechat users can buy Apple products including iPhones, iPads and Macs from its store.
The next big player in the artificial intelligence space could be among nascent, private entities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek to allocate 30-40% of portfolio in dynamic investments. Private residential rents in Singapore declined 2.2% in May, according to Savills. The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro) cut its 2023 inflation forecast due to easing global commodity prices and normalising supply chains. Temasek reported a 5.1% decline in its total shareholder return for FY23, its worst performance in 7 years. DBS agreed to sell a majority stake in AXS to private equity firm Tower Capital Asia.

site_title: Temasek to allocate 30%-40% of portfolio in dynamic investments with higher expected returns
summary: Temasek, a state investor, plans to allocate 30-40% of its portfolio to dynamic investments with higher expected returns, as part of its T2030 strategy. The allocation aims to deliver returns exceeding its risk-adjusted cost of capital of around 9%. The "dynamic" component will focus on growth-oriented investments, while the "resilient" component will prioritize long-term value-oriented assets. Temasek's T2030 strategy also emphasizes sustainability and talent development, amid a more volatile and uncertain world.

images.alt_text: Temasek joins four other global investors, all of whom scored full marks based on the GSR scoreboard.
The closure of one of Singapore’s most promising biotech companies raises larger implications for the city-state’s emerging ecosystem.

site_title: First owners of executive condominiums make average gains of S$322,220 when selling: Huttons Asia
summary: First owners of executive condominiums (ECs) in Singapore tend to make higher average gross profits when selling, with an average gain of S$322,220, according to Huttons Asia. This surpasses the S$261,948 average gain for second owners. First owners tend to sell their EC units within one year of fulfilling the minimum occupation period (MOP), with average gross gains ranging from S$317,731 to S$327,982. The study analyzed 5,033 EC transactions for projects launched from 2010, concluding that new EC units are a superior option for those considering between a new and resale EC unit.

images.alt_text: Executive condominiums like The Vales in Sengkang, are favoured for their affordability and size.

site_title: Malaysia seeks proposals to revive high-speed rail project with Singapore
summary: Malaysia has called for proposals to revive the high-speed rail project with Singapore, estimated to cost around $17 billion. The project was cancelled two years ago due to disagreements between the two countries. The Malaysian government-owned entity, MyHSR Corp, is seeking private sector companies to develop and operate the 350 km rail line via a public-private partnership model. Companies from China, Japan, and Europe had expressed interest in the project before it was cancelled. Malaysia is seeking fresh proposals after Singapore indicated it is open to new proposals last year.

images.alt_text: Market observers said Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim’s recent visit to China has opened up opportunities to attract the interested parties to participate in Malaysia’s infrastructure projects, such as HSR.

site_title: Meta’s Instagram to bring branded content tools to Threads
summary: Meta's Instagram is set to bring its branded content tools to Threads, a platform where advertising is currently unavailable. The tools will enable marketers to collaborate with influencers on paid partnerships. A source familiar with the matter revealed the plan to Axios. Meta has not commented on the matter. This move aims to facilitate partnerships between marketers and influencers on Threads while advertising is not available.

images.alt_text: Meta’s newest offering Threads also experienced an outage, with about 470 users reporting problems accessing the app.

Several rivals to Twitter have emerged but most do not have the capacity to grow at the necessary scale to dethrone Twitter. Threads is finding it easier because it is linked to Instagram, which has more than one billion regular users.
Meta, which launched Threads on Wednesday and has logged more than 30 million sign ups, looks to take on Elon Musk’s Twitter by taking advantage of Instagram’s billions of users.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance with focus on key US inflation data; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 3,163.84 on Tuesday, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street and China's efforts to support its ailing property sector. The move aims to boost liquidity through financial institutions rolling outstanding loans by end-2024. Ahead of key US inflation data, investors are watching for signs of easing inflationary pressures, which could end the Federal Reserve's rate-hike cycle. Local stocks, including Nanofilm Technologies and DBS, were among the gainers, while Keppel Corp secured contracts worth US$70 million.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.6 per cent at 33,944.40.
The counter hits its lowest since Nanofilm’s listing in October 2020.
China’s real estate crisis is stifling a recovery in the world’s second-largest economy, fuelling expectations for the government to take more steps to revive demand.
Smart analysts can translate broad economic or political trends into clever trades, point investors to companies that are rising stars or hold management to account for financial promises.

site_title: Copper is unexpectedly getting cheaper
summary: Copper prices have dropped by around 10% since January to US$8,300 a tonne, contrary to predictions of a potential boom due to the energy transition. The decline is attributed to rising interest rates making investors prefer cash-generating assets, and supply disruptions easing, with smelters charging higher fees. Despite concerns about the economy, copper demand is expected to nearly double by 2040 due to the growing demand for electric vehicles and renewable energy infrastructure, but supply is expected to struggle to keep up, forcing prices to stay subdued.

images.alt_text: Materials such as lithium, used in EV batteries, can be found in raw state aross the world, but extracting and refining them can be costly. China dominates the entire value chain in many critical minerals.
Australian trade data shows exports worth A$60.5 million (S$50.3 million) of copper ore and concentrate to China in January.
FILE PHOTO: A sign adorns the building where mining company Rio Tinto has their office in Perth, Western Australia, November 19, 2015. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo
Gallium and germanium are used in a wide range of products such as solar panels, lasers, night-vision goggles and computer chips.

site_title: Helping former inmates stay the course through partnerships with professionals
summary: A partnership between HCSA Community Services and corporate mentors is helping former inmates reintegrate into society through the Step Up mentoring program. The program, now in its second year, pairs former inmates with professionals from various sectors, providing a supportive network to aid in their rehabilitation. The initiative aims to reduce recidivism rates, with 10 mentees achieving career-oriented goals and fostering cross and reverse mentorships among beneficiaries and corporates. The program's success is attributed to intentional lifestyle shifts and the provision of a new network of friends, sparking personal growth and improvement.

images.alt_text: The art auction features 12 resin geode artworks, created by children from The Salvation Army and volunteers from Peace of Art.

site_title: Dubai property prices surge at fastest pace since 2014
summary: Dubai's residential property prices surged 16.9% in the year to June 30, the fastest pace since 2014, with average apartment prices reaching 1,294 dirhams per square foot and villas averaging 1,525 dirhams per sq ft. Average rents jumped 22.8% in the same period, driven by a post-pandemic economic rebound and relaxed residency rules. 9,876 residential units were sold in June, up 18.8% from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: A general view shows the city of Dubai, with the Burj Khalifa, the world’s tallest building at an elevation of 828 metres (2717 feet), on January 18, 2023. (Photo by Karim SAHIB / AFP)

site_title: Indonesia’s Prabowo increases lead in latest pre-election survey
summary: Indonesia's Defense Minister Prabowo Subianto has increased his lead in the latest pre-election survey, topping the survey with a 34.3% approval rating, surpassing Central Java governor Ganjar Pranowo and ex-Jakarta governor Anies Baswedan. The survey signals Prabowo's momentum ahead of the February presidential election, seven months away. Analysts attribute Prabowo's gain to a rebranding exercise targeting millennials and a strategy of capitalizing on incumbent Joko Widodo's popularity.

site_title: Toilet limits for transgender woman 'unacceptable', says Japan's top court
summary: Japan's Supreme Court ruled that restricting a transgender woman's use of toilets at her workplace was "unacceptable". The decision comes after a series of regional court rulings on same-sex marriage and a law promoting LGBT community understanding. The ruling may help promote LGBT rights in Japan, where transgender people can only change their gender on their family register with surgery. The court's decision may also pave the way for same-sex unions in Japan, the only G7 nation without legal protection.

images.alt_text: Japan court backs right to same-sex marriage for first time

site_title: French inflation pressures ease as more firms cut prices
summary: French inflation pressures ease as fewer firms raise prices, with 8% of industrial companies imposing increases in June, the lowest proportion in over two years. Some firms even cut prices, reaching a near three-year high of 6%. Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau expects the slowing pace of consumer price increases to be noticeable next year, while the European Central Bank debates interest rate hikes. The survey also shows economic activity holding up in France, with growth in industry, services, and construction in June.

site_title: UBS shelves plan for new China fund unit, takes over Credit Suisse joint venture: sources
summary: UBS has suspended plans to set up a new fund unit in China, citing the country's regulation limiting foreign ownership to two firms. The bank will maintain ownership in a joint venture with ICBC Credit Suisse, a move that will impact around 60 staff members. UBS had formed the plan in 2021 to tap China's $3.9 trillion fund market, but decided to keep the joint venture due to the lucrative income it generates, estimated at 2.7 billion yuan in net profit last year.

images.alt_text: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at the company's office at the Bahnhofstrasse in Zurich in this July 1, 2009 file photo.   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann

site_title: IMO’s decarbonisation strategy is vague, but move to net-zero is already underway
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has agreed on a revised strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from international shipping, aiming to reach net-zero emissions by 2050. The strategy includes a commitment to use alternative zero and near-zero fuels by 2030 and indicative checkpoints for 2030 and 2040. However, environmental campaign groups are dissatisfied with the targets, calling for a 50% reduction by 2030 and carbon neutrality by 2040. Industry representatives, such as the International Chamber of Shipping, welcome the agreement but emphasize the need for a global levy on ships' GHG emissions to support a "fund and reward" mechanism.

images.alt_text: The dangerous work of ship demolition is often carried out by people wearing flip flops paddling around in puddles of oil and inhaling air full of asbestos dust.
Second officer Nirmalesh Chandra Nirmal stars in a new recruitment film from the shipping industry.

site_title: Succession and strikes: what to expect from Emmy nominations
summary: The 75th Emmy Awards ceremony is set to announce nominations on Wednesday, amid a writers' strike that has already jeopardized the event. The strike, now in its 11th week, may impact the honor of television's finest. Succession is expected to top the nominations, but Amazon's Lord of the Rings prequel could also be a contender. The ceremony will be live-streamed, and final-round voting will begin after the nominations are announced. The outcome is uncertain due to the ongoing strike, which may affect the ceremony's success.

images.alt_text: Katie Boehly, US businessman Todd Boehly, Helen Hoehne, and a guest arrive for the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on Jan 10, 2023. The scandal-hit association of foreign journalists that created the Golden Globes will be wound down as the Hollywood award show is formally purchased by private investors including US billionaire Todd Boehly.

site_title:
China gallium curbs raise chip questions 
for future EV models
summary: China's imposition of export controls on gallium, a key material used in semiconductors for electric vehicles, has raised concerns among carmakers and chipmakers about the potential impact on future EV models. Gallium Nitride, a compound used in EVs for efficient power management, is in high demand due to its ability to handle high power without generating heat. China produces around 80% of gallium, but the export controls could force manufacturers to seek alternative suppliers, potentially leading to supply chain disruptions and higher costs.

images.alt_text: Some larger chip manufacturers view China’s export controls on gallium as more of a warning shot about what economic pain the country could inflict.

“The (Defense) Department is proactively taking steps using Defense Production Act Title III authorities to increase domestic mining and processing of critical materials for the microelectronics and space supply chain, including gallium and germanium,” the Pentagon spokesperson says.

FILE PHOTO: Worker miniatures are placed among the flag of China and printed circuit boards with semiconductor chips, in this illustration picture taken July 5, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.

site_title: Hmlet rebrands as Habyt, new Apac CEO eyes expansion
summary: Hmlet, a co-living operator, has rebranded as Habyt and appointed Jonathan Wong as its new Asia-Pacific CEO. Wong, previously CEO of Uber's ride-sharing business in Singapore and Malaysia, aims to double the size of Habyt's portfolio over the next 12 months. With an average occupancy rate of over 90%, Wong plans to expand into new markets, including Seoul and South-east Asian capitals, capitalizing on the growing demand for flexible living spaces.

images.alt_text: Co-living operators, such as LHN's Coliwoo (above), have seen their tenant profile skew towards younger people, who enjoy having shared spaces for a community lifestyle.
Coliving operators like lyf have seen an increase in interest from tenants looking to move out of their private rentals into a coliving space.
Hmlet merges with European co-living player Habyt

site_title: Eurozone bonds hold steady as traders await US inflation data
summary: Eurozone government bond yields held steady on Tuesday, remaining at elevated levels after a sharp rise last week. Investors are awaiting US inflation data on Wednesday, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Traders expect the Fed to raise interest rates by 25 basis points to 5.25-5.5% on July 26. Eurozone inflation rates are currently at 3.5%, but pricing in derivatives markets suggests they may rise to 4% or more by early next year.

images.alt_text: Sentix managing director Manfred Huebner singles out Germany in particular for having “dramatically bad” values:  The overall index falls 7.3 points to land at -28.4.

site_title: The corporate bankruptcy wave will get even uglier
summary: Business bankruptcies are surging globally, with volumes not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. US bankruptcies in the first six months of 2023 reached the highest level since 2010, while England, Sweden, and Germany also reported record-high insolvencies. The surge is attributed to weakening demand, surging inflation, and higher borrowing costs, which are proving too much for weaker borrowers. A decade of cheap money has created a false sense of invincibility, leading to a wave of corporate defaults expected to continue.

images.alt_text: Bed Bath & Beyond filed for bankruptcy in a District of New Jersey court, listing both its estimated assets and liabilities in the range of US$1 billion and US$10 billion, according to a court filing.

Repricing of credit risk followed the collapse of US tech lender Silicon Valley Bank and a crisis of confidence in Credit Suisse Group that tipped the Swiss lender’s investment-grade bonds into distress.

site_title: More than US$2 billion committed at UK-US climate finance forum
summary: The UK and US have committed over $2 billion to climate finance efforts in Africa, Asia, and Latin America, according to a joint statement by Energy Security and Net Zero Secretary Grant Shapps and US Special Presidential Envoy on Climate John Kerry. This commitment aims to bolster private capital flows to emerging economies through initiatives like nature-based solutions and technology to reduce environmental impacts. Companies like Builders Vision, Mitsui & Co, and Renewable Resources Group Partnership have pledged to invest at least $1 billion in emerging markets.

site_title: Sterling hits 15-month high as high wage growth heaps pressure on BOE
summary: The British pound has reached a 15-month high against the US dollar, rising 0.3% to US$1.2899, following strong pay growth data. Wages excluding bonuses were 7.3% higher in the three months to May than a year earlier, exceeding expectations. This adds pressure on the Bank of England to continue raising interest rates, despite the economic impact on the UK economy, which contracted for the second month in a row.

site_title: UK mortgage rates hit 15-year high after surpassing ‘mini-budget’ peak
summary: UK mortgage rates have reached a 15-year high, surpassing the levels seen after the "mini-budget" crisis in 2022. The average two-year fixed residential mortgage rate rose to 6.66%, exceeding the previous peak of 6.65% in October 2022. The surge is attributed to stickier-than-expected consumer price inflation and increased market bets on the Bank of England's benchmark rate peaking at 6.5%. This has prompted lenders to reprice home loan offerings, although most households remain locked in to previous deals.

images.alt_text: The decline is driven by a far steeper slump in the house building component, which slid to 39.6 from 42.7.
JPMorgan’s comments come after a FTSE index tracking UK homebuilder stocks fell about 10 per cent in the second quarter.
Values for London office buildings with a BREEAM certification are on average 20.6 per cent higher than those without that accreditation, says Jones Lang LaSalle.

A housing crisis is brewing in Britain as millions of people are forced to re-negotiate expiring fixed-rate mortgages at significantly higher costs as the Bank of England raises interest rates in its battle to tame inflation.

epa10307958 British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt departs his home in London, Britain, 16 November 2022. Hunt is set to announce his Autumn Statement to parliament on 17 November, with tax rises and government cuts expected.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: SIA is key to Temasek reaching its net-zero targets: Temasek CEO
summary: Temasek CEO Dilhan Pillay states that Singapore Airlines' (SIA) ability to decarbonize its operations is crucial for the state investment company to hit its net-zero targets. SIA's carbon emissions are expected to be cut to 11 million tonnes by 2030 from 27 million tonnes currently, with the airline relying solely on sustainable aviation fuel to reduce its emissions. This aligns with Temasek's goal of being net-zero by 2050.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings said that persistent inflatoin, geopolitical tensions and rising nationalism and protectionism led to an increase in the firm's cost of capital.
Temasek developed its T2030 strategy in 2019 as its 10-year roadmap to guide strategic planning and capability building for the organisation.
Temasek joins four other global investors, all of whom scored full marks based on the GSR scoreboard.
Philanthropy should be conducted sustainably to continue generating value for the environment and society in the long run, says an industry stakeholder.
Temasek Trust joins the Series A round of impact verification provider BlueMark as a new investor.

site_title: Singapore-based medical firm Genesis MedTech weighs up to US$500 million HK IPO: sources
summary: Genesis MedTech, a Singapore-based medical firm, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, potentially raising up to US$500 million. The company, founded in 2019, focuses on value-segment medical device products for emerging markets. Genesis had initially planned to launch the IPO this year but decided to wait due to market conditions. The IPO could take place as early as next year, pending further developments.

images.alt_text: stethoscope, listen, care

site_title: Asean chair urges unity as top diplomats meet amid Myanmar discord
summary: Indonesia's Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi urged unity among ASEAN nations as top diplomats met in Jakarta amid discord over Myanmar's ruling generals. Marsudi emphasized the bloc's need to demonstrate its ability to navigate regional and global dynamics. The meeting comes as ASEAN faces doubts over its effectiveness, particularly in addressing the ongoing conflict in Myanmar and the junta's failure to implement a peace plan. ASEAN has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, with Malaysia saying it is not a key issue.

images.alt_text: Thomas Andrews, UN Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights in Myanmar  said the meeting in Thailand “can have the dangerous effect of legitimising the junta and undermining Asean unity”.

site_title: UK wage growth matches record high, keeping BOE under pressure
summary: The UK's basic earnings increased by 7.3% in the three months to May, matching its highest growth rate on record, but also showing signs of labor market tightening easing. The unemployment rate rose to 4.0% and vacancies fell to their lowest since mid-2021. Sterling rose to a 15-month high against the dollar, but interest rate expectations remained under pressure as the Bank of England assesses inflationary pressure. Economists suggest wage growth may slow, but inflation remains a concern, with the BOE expected to continue monitoring pay growth closely.

images.alt_text: Last week, the BOE raised rates by half a point to a 15-year high of 5 per cent, its most aggressive move in months, following the fourth inflation shock in a row.

site_title: Pakistan receives US$2 billion in Saudi financial support
summary: Pakistan has received $2 billion in financial support from Saudi Arabia, boosting its foreign exchange reserves. The funds were deposited with the central bank, helping Pakistan cover a month of controlled imports. The move comes ahead of the International Monetary Fund's expected approval of a $3 billion bailout. Finance Minister Ishaq Dar described the support as a "great gesture" from longtime ally Saudi Arabia.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pakistan's Finance Minister Ishaq Dar is seen after a party meeting in Islamabad, Pakistan September 26, 2017. Picture taken September 26, 2017. REUTERS/Faisal Mahmood/File Photo

With sky-high inflation and foreign exchange reserves barely enough for a month of controlled imports, analysts say Pakistan’s economic crisis could have spiralled into a debt default in the absence of the IMF bailout.

site_title:
Choose stocks with dividend yield of 4% or less 
over fixed deposits and T-bills
summary: Singapore's stock market may re-rate as retail participation, liquidity, and confidence rise. Investors can consider dividend-paying shares with yields of 4% or less, such as GuocoLand and Vicom, which offer consistent dividend payments and good business operations. Higher interest rates in instruments like fixed deposits and T-bills make them attractive, but equities may be riskier. A lower interest rate environment could boost economic growth, leading to higher stock prices. Despite market fluctuations, there are reasons for optimism, including the potential for privatisation and capital upside from corporate action, making it a good time to invest in Singapore-listed equities.

images.alt_text: Singapore's electronics exports are expected to rebound in coming months, helping to lift the manufactoring sector.
There are opportunities in stocks which offer high and growing dividends.

site_title: Hot stock: Nanofilm hits new low after warning of H1 loss
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a mainboard-listed company specializing in advanced materials and coatings, saw its shares hit a new low after warning of a net loss of S$8 million for the first half of the year. The company attributed the loss to a 34% fall in revenue to S$73 million, due to factors such as inflation, high interest rates, and geopolitical tensions. Despite the warning, analysts have kept their forecasts and recommendations unchanged, with some predicting the company will become profitable in FY2023.

images.alt_text: Nanofilm expects to report a 34 per cent fall in revenue to S$73 million for the half year ended Jun 30, 2023.
Nanofilm specialises in advanced materials and coatings.
Ian Howe was the former chief executive officer of Dutch machining manufacturer Additive Industries, where he served between 2021 and 2022.
The first quarter is typically cyclical in line with production cycles, while revenue was also hit by China’s slow and soft recovery since its re-opening, Nanofilm said.

site_title: Tata Group closes in on deal to become first Indian iPhone maker
summary: Tata Group, India's largest conglomerate, is close to acquiring Apple's supplier Wistron factory in southern Karnataka state, valued at over $600 million. The deal, potentially worth $1.8 billion, would enable Tata to assemble iPhones, marking the first time a local company would manufacture the device. This move aims to diversify Apple's production base beyond China and boost India's domestic manufacturing efforts, potentially challenging China's status as the "factory of the world."

images.alt_text: Wechat users can buy Apple products including iPhones, iPads and Macs from its store.

site_title: Meituan faces battle with ByteDance to revive shares
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food-delivery firm, is facing a battle with ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, to maintain its market share. Meituan's shares have slumped 30% this year, with the company struggling to compete with ByteDance's Douyin platform, which has built-in e-commerce features. ByteDance is also expanding into Meituan's key food-delivery sector. Despite Meituan's efforts to hire 10,000 staff, analysts warn that the company's loss-making business model and commitment to its community group buying platform may hinder its ability to compete.

site_title: Madonna officially postpones celebration tour
summary: Madonna has officially postponed her North American Celebration Tour due to health concerns. The 64-year-old singer was admitted to a hospital with a serious bacterial infection, prompting speculation about her well-being and the fate of the tour. The entire North American leg of the tour, comprising 41 shows, has been rescheduled to open in Europe in October. Fans are advised to hold onto their tickets as they will be valid for the new dates once announced. Madonna has stated that her focus is on recovery and getting stronger, assuring fans she will return as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: Organisers said Madonna: The Celebration Tour will take fans on her “artistic journey through four decades and pays respect to the city of New York where her career in music began”.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as China pledges fresh property support
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, driven by China's pledge to support its struggling property sector and further economic aid. Hong Kong and Shanghai led the gains, while traders await key US inflation data this week. Despite concerns over high valuations and a potential economic slowdown, investors remain optimistic. The release of earnings season data and interest rate plans from the Federal Reserve are also expected to influence market trends.

images.alt_text: The surge in market heavyweight tech firms lifted the Hang Seng Index more than one per cent, while there were also gains in Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: Mercedes sales rise in Q2 on top-end, electric vehicles
summary: Mercedes-Benz Group reported a 6% year-on-year increase in Q2 sales, reaching 515,700 vehicles. Sales grew in all main regions, with deliveries in Germany up 23%, China up 12%, and the US up 6%. Electric vehicles drove the growth, with passenger car sales increasing 123% to 56,300 units, and the top-end segment also posting a 12% increase. The company's second-quarter sales outperformed expectations.

site_title: Singapore’s private residential rents fall 2.2% in May: Savills
summary: Singapore's private residential rents fell 2.2% in May 2023, according to Savills. Analysts attribute the decline to the increase in new housing supply in 2023, as more projects near completion and construction delays are resolved. The challenging macroeconomic situation also led to cost-cutting measures, including smaller budgets for expatriates' rentals and staff layoffs.

images.alt_text: Condo and HDB rents appear mixed.
Singapore's housing market has seen a buoyant run, after an influx of capital and a pandemic-induced supply shortage pushed prices and rents to record highs.

site_title: Australia June business conditions steady in sign of resilience
summary: Australian business conditions remained above average in June, holding steady at +9, despite rising labour costs to 2.6% and input costs at 2.3%. Sales and employment remained strong, with the employment index at +5 and profits rising two points to +9. Capacity constraints eased, and forward orders rose to -2, indicating ongoing resilience. The Reserve Bank of Australia skipped a rate hike, awaiting signs of inflation restraint.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank Australia held rates steady at 4.1 per cent last week, in the middle of the survey period.
Data brokers generally gather information like personal details of customers including their browsing and purchasing behaviour.

site_title:
Tortoise versus hare – which portfolio 
gets you to the finish line?
summary: A foundation portfolio based on asset allocation is often considered a slow and steady approach to investing, less likely to panic during sharp market sell-offs. This method, like a tortoise, tends to get investors to their destination. In contrast, an opportunistic approach, like a hare, is highly dynamic but faces challenges, including difficulty in timing markets and picking outperforming stocks. Historically, market timing has proven difficult, with less than 27% of US S&P index constituents outperforming the overall index this year. A balanced approach may be suitable for investors with a genuine interest in financial markets, but a tortoise-like approach often yields better results.

images.alt_text: Acknowledging that there are several potential outcomes in markets benefits investors. It prevents you from investing on the expectation of just one oucome, and helps to prepare you for market fluctuations.
Expected returns of assets are higher across the board., and equities are expected to outperform bonds.

site_title: Meta’s social media apps back up after brief outage: Downdetector.com
summary: Meta's social media apps, including Instagram, Facebook, WhatsApp, and Threads, experienced a brief outage affecting thousands of users on July 10. At the peak, 14,000 users reported issues with Instagram, while 7,000 and 2,700 users faced issues with Facebook and WhatsApp, respectively. Downdetector.com reported the outages, which were resolved after an hour. Meta did not immediately respond to inquiries about the outage.

site_title: Chinese embrace summer holiday flying for first time in years
summary: Chinese travelers are embracing summer holiday flying for the first time in years, with passenger traffic reaching almost 9 million in the first five days of July, a 14% increase from 2019. Domestic air passenger traffic is expected to be 7% higher this summer than in 2019, while international routes saw a 22% increase in average ticket prices. Airlines, including Air China, China Southern Airlines, and China Eastern Airlines, have seen significant gains in stock markets, with some rising over 10%.

images.alt_text: Passengers at the Hangzhou East train station in China. Around 270 domestic trips were made during the five-day Labor Day holiday that ran from Apr 29 to May 3 this year.

site_title: Facebook says China trolls ‘evolving’ in push for influence
summary: Meta reported that China-based networks waging a coordinated disinformation campaign in Europe have "evolved" and adopted new tactics. The social media platform removed dozens of Facebook accounts from these networks, which have shifted their focus to influencing public opinion by targeting journalists, charities, and public relations firms. This marks a noticeable change in tactics over the past seven months, with Meta officials stating that these networks are increasingly sophisticated in their efforts to sow discord overseas.

images.alt_text: Meta and Facebook logos are seen in this illustration taken February 15, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration##########meta3##########

site_title: The days of the rock star research analyst are long gone
summary: The days of rock star research analysts are fading as the industry faces significant changes. The EU and UK are moving to undo 2018 reforms that aimed to ensure value for money in research, sparking concerns about the impact on investors. Research providers have seen spending drop 50% since 2018, while banks and brokers argue that unbundling has led to fewer analyst reports, smaller brokers, and reduced listings. However, innovative providers are thriving, and some experts believe that bringing back bundling could improve market liquidity and capital markets, but may not necessarily lead to more value for investors.

images.alt_text: Contrary to the predictions of most economists, it's possible that the US will get through this disinflationary period and make the proverbial “soft landing”.
Airbnb and DoorDash set for flurry of analyst coverage next week

After a 37 per cent surge in the Nasdaq 100 Index this year, some strategists have revised their stock-market targets just to account for the equity rally – even if they see modest gains, or declines, for the rest of the year.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust mulls selling retail malls among options in debt restructuring
summary: Dasin Retail Trust is considering selling its retail malls as part of a debt restructuring plan, with a 24-month timeframe for disposal. The trustee-manager is also exploring engaging a financial adviser to search for strategic investors. The move comes after talks with a "reputable Chinese entity" for a potential memorandum of understanding (MOU) fell through, prompting lenders to flag concerns over the trust's management, including CEO Wang Qiu. The board has clarified that Wang acted in the interest of all stakeholders, and the trust will engage lenders to address their concerns.

images.alt_text: Dasin Retail Trust’s board said it will continue to explore available options related to its restructuring exercise with its lenders.
Ocean Metro Mall is one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio. The trust's net loss for the second half ended December 2022 stands at S$221.5 million.
Dasin Retail Trust’s trustee-manager’s hearing of the winding-up petition in the Hong Kong court is now postponed to Aug 17.
Substantial unitholder Zhang Zhencheng is suing to remove lead independent director Tan Huay Lim from the manager's board, alleging breaches of fiduciary duties.
The Carrefour lease in Ocean Metro Mall was originally for a term of 20 years, commencing from Dec 28, 2014, for a total leased area of 17,770 square metres (sq m).
Ocean Metro Mall, one of seven malls in Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio.

site_title: Apple opens store on China’s WeChat platform
summary: Apple has opened a store on China's WeChat platform, allowing users to buy Apple products including iPhones, iPads, and Macs. This marks the US company's expansion of retail channels in China, the world's second-largest economy. The move comes as Chinese consumers increasingly turn to social media platforms for shopping, and follows Apple's existing online store on Alibaba's Tmall marketplace. Despite a 5% decline in Chinese smartphone sales in the first quarter, Apple recorded a 19.9% share of the market, its highest since 2014.

images.alt_text: US district judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers’ decision clears the way for shareholders led by a British pension fund to sue over a one-day plunge that wiped out US$74 billion of Apple’s market value.

site_title: Nuclear stocks jump as South Korea considers adding new plant
summary: South Korea's government has confirmed plans to consider constructing a new nuclear power plant, leading to a surge in nuclear-linked stocks. President Yoon Suk-yeol supports nuclear power expansion, aiming for it to account for nearly one-third of generation capacity by 2030. This move follows a broader revival of nuclear power globally, with Japan, China, the UK, and France also planning to add more nuclear capacity. The review of the new plant is expected to examine the potential addition of a further nuclear facility, sparking gains in stocks such as Korea Electronic Power Industrial Development.

site_title: JPMorgan says Hong Kong property market has pool of undervalued assets
summary: JPMorgan analysts predict a "large pool of undervalued assets" in Hong Kong's property market due to valuations hitting a 30-year low. The city's cash-rich property tycoons may take advantage of these cheap valuations to buy assets, conduct share buybacks, or acquire minority shareholders. This could lead to increased buying activity among majority shareholders, taking advantage of the market downturn. The Hong Kong property and conglomerates sector is valued at a 63% net asset value discount to the aggregate market capitalization.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view shows residential apartment blocks in Hong Kong, China, June 29, 2019. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Britain’s Waitrose joins forces with Uber Eats for rapid delivery
summary: Waitrose, a British upmarket supermarket group, has teamed up with Uber Eats to deliver groceries to customers' homes in as little as 20 minutes. The partnership, launching in five London stores and expanding to over 200 stores by August, builds on Waitrose's existing partnership with Deliveroo and its own online shopping business. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for online grocery shopping in Britain, where online's share of the market has increased to 10.4% since the pandemic.

site_title: Temasek posts total shareholder return of -5.1% for FY23, worst performance in 7 years
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a one-year total shareholder return (TSR) of -5.07% for FY2023, the worst performance in seven years.
