images.alt_text: "As much as we want to think about nearshoring for resilience... no country, no region, is entirely self-sufficient," says Jacqueline Poh, managing director of the Singapore Economic Development Board.

In line with the new Jobs Transformation Map (JTM) for food services, trade associations and chambers in the sector have committed to work with over 800 member companies, employing around 80,000 workers, to transform their jobs.
Minister for Transport Dr Tan See Leng encourages retailers to adapt to shifting consumer demands.

site_title: UK assets are world’s cheapest: Morgan Stanley strategists
summary: UK equities are the worst performers among major European and developed-market stocks this year due to high inflation and hawkish monetary policies from the Bank of England. Despite investor pessimism, Morgan Stanley strategists believe UK assets are the cheapest globally, offering relatively attractive valuations. If inflation subsides, this sentiment could shift, creating investment opportunities. UK equities and corporate bonds have been the cheapest global assets over the last 20 years, according to Morgan Stanley.

images.alt_text: The Office for National Statistics (ONS) says it now estimated that Britain’s economy shrinks by 10.9 per cent rather than 11.0 per cent in 2020.

site_title: Twitter rival Threads signs up 100 million users in five days
summary: Threads, Instagram's rival to Twitter, has signed up over 100 million users in five days, surpassing AI tool ChatGPT's record for fastest-growing consumer app. The app's success is attributed to its link to Instagram, which has over 1 billion regular users. Twitter, with around 200 million regular users, has struggled with technical failures and user alienation since Elon Musk's acquisition. Threads' rapid growth poses a threat to Twitter's dominance, with Meta, Instagram's parent company, navigating data privacy legislation in Europe to make the app available in the region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Meta's Threads app logo is seen in this illustration taken July 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: From baseball to banking, companies race to invest in new wave of AI
summary: Companies across various industries, including baseball, banking, healthcare, and education, are racing to invest in artificial intelligence (AI) tools to boost productivity and performance. Generative AI models can create text, images, and videos, while predictive models can anticipate future trends. However, concerns over regulation and the potential risks of AI, such as "hallucinations" and biological threats, are also growing. Major companies, including JP Morgan Chase, Amazon, and Databricks, are investing heavily in AI, with some announcing significant acquisitions, such as Databricks' $1.3 billion purchase of MosaicML.

images.alt_text: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt (left, with Databricks co-founder Arsalan Tavakoli) warns that AI could be used by bad actors to "accelerate at scale".
Databricks chief executive Ali Ghodsi believes that MosaicML can get to US$50 to US$100 million in annual recurring revenue in 12 months.

site_title: China’s car sales shrink 2.9% in June as big-ticket spending falters
summary: China's car sales declined 2.9% in June to 1.91 million units, driven by cautious spending amid a stumbling economic recovery. However, the first half of the year saw a 2.5% increase in sales to 9.65 million units. New energy vehicle (NEV) sales surged 25% in June, accounting for 35% of total car sales, and increased 37% to 3.09 million units in the first six months.

images.alt_text: After Tesla kicks off a price war that quickly enveloped other manufacturers earlier this year, now some two-thirds of auto brands in the world’s largest car market are offering discounts.

site_title: Sluggish loan growth, economic uncertainties cloud Singapore’s banking prospects: RHB
summary: Singapore's banking sector is expected to remain range-bound in the near future due to sluggish loan growth, economic uncertainties, and low demand for credit. Despite healthy net interest margins, RHB Research has downgraded its weighting for the sector to "neutral" from "overweight". The research house recommends buying UOB due to its smallest exposure to China, while maintaining a "neutral" stance on DBS and OCBC. Net interest income growth is forecasted to drive sector earnings growth, but at a slower pace in FY2024.

images.alt_text: RHB has dropped its target price to S$13.20 for OCBC, downgrades to "neutral' for its stocks.
Piyush Gupta is in many ways the Jamie Dimon of Singapore, the highest-profile banker leading the country’s largest lender and surrounded by succession speculation.
FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billow from Belchatow Power Station, Europe's largest coal-fired power plant powered by lignite, in Zlobnica, Poland October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Kuba Stezycki/File Photo
SMS messages, which are not encrypted, can be intercepted and read by fraudsters in a number of ways.

site_title: Indonesia wants more doctors, but reforms are facing resistance
summary: Indonesia is pushing to improve its healthcare system, but reforms are facing opposition from local nurses and doctors. The proposed legislation would allow foreign doctors to work in the country and exempt Indonesians from paying tuition fees for hospital residency. The measure also seeks to shift the burden of funding hospitals to the private sector and clarify abortion criteria. Despite efforts to address the country's shortage of doctors, particularly in rural areas, healthcare workers have staged protests, citing a lack of transparency in Parliament discussions.

images.alt_text: Inflation in South-east Asia’s largest economy has gradually eased since peaking last September at 6 per cent.

site_title: India’s Go First airline seeks investor interest as part of insolvency process
summary: Go Airlines, an Indian carrier, has invited investor interest as part of its insolvency process. The airline, which operates Go First, filed for bankruptcy protection in May citing "faulty" Pratt & Whitney engines for grounding about half its Airbus A320neos. As part of the process, a court-appointed administrator has issued a newspaper advertisement seeking buyers or investors. The move is seen as a step towards finding a potential buyer or investor for the carrier, with the final resolution subject to the crystallization of rights of lessors.

site_title: China’s factory gate prices fall at fastest pace in 7 years
summary: China's factory-gate prices fell 5.4% in June, the fastest pace in over seven years, while consumer inflation remained unchanged year-on-year. The producer price index (PPI) marked its ninth consecutive month of decline, while the consumer price index (CPI) was at its slowest pace since 2021. Economists expect headline inflation to rise to around 1% by the end of the year, but credit demand remains weak, with fiscal policy expected to provide the main support.

images.alt_text: The China Securities Regulatory Commission said it had drafted reform plans after listening to opinions from market participants.
The new rules, signed by Premier Li Qiang and effective on Sep 1, create a chapter specifically for venture capital funds, as policymakers encourage investment into innovative technology startups.

site_title: Post-pandemic, connectivity and compact homes ensure quality offices and malls maintain relevance
summary: Post-pandemic, many knowledge workers are spending more time in physical offices, benefiting office landlords. However, this trend has led to a decline in demand for office space, with Singapore-listed Manulife US Reit experiencing a 10.9% drop in portfolio valuation and a 33.1% decline in valuation for one of its Los Angeles properties. Rising vacancy rates and high interest rates are feared to lead to office landlords collapsing, potentially sparking a financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Although Central Business District supply is expected to remain tight, shadow space levels are beginning to creep up.

site_title: Ocado launches first robotic warehouse in Asia with Aeon
summary: Ocado, a British online supermarket, has launched its first robotic warehouse in Asia with Japanese partner Aeon, serving the Kanto region. The customer fulfilment centre (CFC) is taking orders for Aeon's "Green Beans" brand and is part of a 2019 deal that anticipates 600-1 trillion yen in online grocery sales by 2030 and 2035. Ocado CEO Tim Steiner said grocery spend in Asia is set to outstrip other regions, with online growth expected to continue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Ocado grocery delivery van is driven along a street in London, Britain, March 25, 2023. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: SVB Financial sues US FDIC to recover US$1.93 billion
summary: SVB Financial Group has filed a lawsuit against the US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) to recover US$1.93 billion, claiming the regulator seized Silicon Valley Bank without identifying specific claims. SVB Financial alleges the FDIC violated bankruptcy rules by transferring funds and refusing to pay, despite numerous opportunities. The company is attempting to sell its remaining assets in bankruptcy.

site_title: GM cuts Lyriq EV price in China by 14% after VW discounts
summary: General Motors has cut the starting price of its luxury electric vehicle, the Cadillac Lyriq, in China by 14% to 379,700 yuan (approximately $70,785), following Volkswagen's recent price reductions. The move aims to stay competitive in the market, where global automakers are under pressure. The Lyriq's new price is equivalent to a US$2,500 deposit discount for buyers who make a deposit before August. This is part of a growing trend of price cuts by automakers in China, where the market share of made-in-China EV brands is rising, and the market faces intense price competition.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Cadillac all-electric 2023 Lyriq is displayed during a media day of the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Michigan, U.S. September 14, 2022..   REUTERS/Rebecca Cook

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Great Eastern’s great potential (Ep 33)
summary: OCBC's recent purchase of more Great Eastern shares has narrowed the insurer's public spread, increasing the risk of suspension from trading. Despite this, undervalued shares still hold potential due to embedded value soaring and increasing dividend payouts under consideration. However, minority shareholders lack protection, and the AGM's comments on compensation and share price have sparked concerns.

images.alt_text: What will it take to resurrect this owner of US office properties?
Sias lamented in a March commentary the "ridiculous lowball" offers that foment investor resentment and mistrust in the local market
OCBC affirmed Great Eastern’s as a capability within the banking group.
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 December 2019.

site_title: Gold firms as US jobs data raises doubts on aggressive rate hikes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,925.49 per ounce after US jobs data raised doubts about the Federal Reserve's rate hike trajectory, potentially dampening the appeal of gold due to its lack of interest payments. The Labor Department's employment report showed the US added the smallest jobs in 2-1/2 years in June, indicating that higher borrowing costs are starting to impact businesses. Meanwhile, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's meetings with senior Chinese officials were deemed "direct" and "productive", stabilizing the US-China relationship.

images.alt_text: US gold futures settle 0.9 per cent higher at US$1,932.50.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, EC World Reit, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Sabana Reit resumes trading on Monday after a trading halt, amid a court application by its sponsor ESR Group to prevent an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) where Quarz Capital seeks to remove the Reit manager. EC World Reit has entered into a supplementary agreement to amend the terms of the divestment of two properties in China. Dasin Retail Trust reported a net loss of S$221.5 million for the second half of 2022, widening from the previous year's H2 net loss.

site_title: Japan logs current account surplus for fourth month as trade gap narrows
summary: Japan's current account surplus exceeded $17.6 billion in May, its fourth consecutive month of gains, driven by a narrowing trade deficit and increased income from overseas investments. The primary income surplus rose to 3.6 trillion yen, while the trade deficit narrowed to 1.2 trillion yen from 1.8 trillion yen in the same month last year. The data suggests the Japanese economy is recovering from the impact of high energy costs and a weak yen, with overseas investment playing a key role in the country's earning power.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks about his parent policy at a press conference at his official residence in Tokyo on March 17, 2023. YOSHIKAZU TSUNO/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong mortgage easing is cold comfort to buyers with high rates
summary: Hong Kong's mortgage easing measures, announced on July 7, are unlikely to boost demand from homebuyers deterred by high interest rates, analysts say. The government increased the loan-to-value ratio for some homes, allowing buyers to snap up properties with smaller down payments. However, experts believe borrowing costs remain elevated, and interest rates won't decrease until the Federal Reserve eases monetary policy. The initial market reaction was muted, with shares of major developers climbing slightly, but some analysts predict a 5% gain in residential prices this year.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has been the world’s least affordable housing market for 13 consecutive years, according to research firm Demographia, and housing woes are widely blamed for most of the city’s social problems.

site_title: Property stamp duty collection dips 12% to S$5.95 billion in FY2022 on lower sales
summary: Singapore's property stamp duty collections fell 12% to S$5.95 billion in FY2022 due to lower transaction volumes amid tight housing supply. Despite this, property tax takings rose 9.1% to S$5.1 billion, driven by higher rents and low vacancy rates. Overall, the government's tax revenue for FY2022 increased 10.6% to S$82.71 billion. Analysts attribute the decline in stamp duty collections to a slowdown in the property market, with sales of private homes and public housing down 32.9% and 8% respectively in FY2022.

images.alt_text: The second-quarter decline, based on the flash estimate, is the first drop in the price index since Q1 2020 as price momentum eased across all market segments, URA says.
Despite the hefty price tag, leading developers should seriously consider participating in the tender for the Master Developer site at Jurong Lake District.
HDB resale prices continue to rise 0.6 per cent in June, but volumes were down.

site_title: North Korea warns it may shoot down US spy planes violating its airspace
summary: North Korea has warned it may shoot down US spy planes violating its airspace, amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula. The warning comes after the US sent a nuclear-powered cruise missile submarine near the peninsula and conducted air and navy drills with South Korea. North Korea's Ministry of National Defence accused the US of escalating tensions and said the use of US reconnaissance planes and drones is a "shocking accident waiting to happen". The US has denied the claim, stating that air surveillance assets conduct routine reconnaissance flights around the peninsula.

images.alt_text: The enlarged plenary meeting of the Central Committee of the ruling Workers’ Party of Korea opened on Friday and plans to also review the country’s economic projects during the first half of this year, says KCNA.

site_title: Insidious whips past Indy 5 to top North America box office
summary: Insidious: The Red Door, directed by Patrick Wilson, took the top spot at the North American box office with an estimated US$32.7 million, beating out Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny. The fifth installment of the horror franchise had weak reviews, but its opening was considered excellent. Other films in the top 10 included Sound of Freedom, a Christian action thriller, and Disney's Elemental, a family-friendly animation.

images.alt_text: Vietnam authorities ban the upcoming Greta Gerwig film over a map in “Barbie” that they said shows a Chinese map of territory in the South China Sea, where the two neighbours have competing claims.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust reports H2 net loss of S$221.5 million; Sias queries board on financials
summary: Dasin Retail Trust reported a net loss of S$221.5 million for the second half of 2022, compared to a loss of S$51.8 million in the same period last year. The loss was mainly due to changes in the fair value of investment properties, resulting in a wider S$297.9 million loss. Revenue declined 24.7% to S$37.6 million, and net property income fell 33.6% to S$20.6 million. The trust has defaulted on loans worth approximately S$910 million and has not declared a distribution for the period. Minority investor group Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has queried the trust's financials and loan defaults.

images.alt_text: Dasin Retail Trust’s board said it will continue to explore available options related to its restructuring exercise with its lenders.
Dasin Retail Trust’s trustee-manager’s hearing of the winding-up petition in the Hong Kong court is now postponed to Aug 17.
Substantial unitholder Zhang Zhencheng is suing to remove lead independent director Tan Huay Lim from the manager's board, alleging breaches of fiduciary duties.
The Carrefour lease in Ocean Metro Mall was originally for a term of 20 years, commencing from Dec 28, 2014, for a total leased area of 17,770 square metres (sq m).

site_title: EC World Reit to extend deadline for divestment of two China logistics assets
summary: EC World Reit has entered a supplementary agreement to amend the terms of its divestment of two logistics assets in Zhejiang, China. The agreement extends the deadline to Oct 31, allowing more time to complete the divestment and reducing the likelihood of default on financing obligations. The revised agreement also includes a two-stage completion process and changes to the mandatory prepayment amount, providing flexibility for the purchasers to secure financing.

images.alt_text: accountant, accounting, adviser
EC World Reit is seeking to divest its indirect interests in Bei Gang Logistics (above).
Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of the largest e-commerce developments in the Yangtze River Delta in Shanghai, China. This is one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio.

site_title: China mutual funds cut fees as regulator targets US$3.7 trillion sector
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission has drafted reform plans to lower mutual fund fees in the US$3.7 trillion industry. Major mutual fund companies, including China Asset Management, cut fees in 1,500 fund products, reducing management fees to 1.2% and custodian fees to 0.2%. The move aims to reduce investors' costs and follows the regulator's vow to guide fees lower. The reform is part of a broader "common prosperity" drive to reduce wealth gaps, and regulators also plan to limit executive pay at fund management companies and banks.

images.alt_text: The new rules, signed by Premier Li Qiang and effective on Sep 1, create a chapter specifically for venture capital funds, as policymakers encourage investment into innovative technology startups.

site_title: China property developer Kaisa faces Hong Kong lawsuit seeking to wind it up
summary: Chinese property developer Kaisa Group has faced a winding-up petition in a Hong Kong court over 170 million yuan (S$31.7 million) non-payments on onshore bonds. The company's shares dropped 13.5% to an all-time low of HK$0.18. This is the latest move in the sector, which has faced winding-up petitions since the debt crisis in mid-2021. Many Hong Kong-listed Chinese developers have defaulted and are undergoing debt restructuring.

site_title: Proof humans reshaped the world? Chickens
summary: Scientists conclude that the rapid expansion of human appetites and activity led to a significant shift in Earth's natural systems, marking the beginning of the Anthropocene era. The biomass of domesticated chickens is over three times that of all wild bird species combined, indicating a profound impact on ecosystems. Other telltale signs of this change include rising greenhouse gases, nuclear waste, microplastics, and invasive species, which will be visible in future sediment layers. These findings suggest that human activity has had a profound and lasting impact on the planet.

images.alt_text: It might be too early to invest in cultured meat with no good way to tell winners from losers, says PGIM chief operating officer Taimur Hyat.
Startups face the challenge of achieving price parity, as the cost of producing alternative proteins exceeds that of traditional meat products.

site_title: China should shift stimulus to consumption, ease residency curbs: PBOC adviser
summary: China's central bank policy adviser, Cai Fang, recommends shifting stimulus focus from investment to consumption and easing residency curbs to boost migrant workers' spending power. This could lift migrant workers' spending by over $372 billion. Reforms to China's residence permit system, or "hukou", would benefit 180 million rural migrant workers, addressing economic bottlenecks and weaknesses. The move aims to support urbanization and consumption recovery, with the government prioritizing this aspect this year.

images.alt_text: Beijing has set a target for average consumer inflation in 2023 of about 3 per cent. Prices rose 2 per cent year-on-year in 2022.
The new rules, signed by Premier Li Qiang and effective on Sep 1, create a chapter specifically for venture capital funds, as policymakers encourage investment into innovative technology startups.

site_title: Gucci-owner Kering paid  3.5 billion euros for French fragrance label Creed: FT
summary: Kering, the owner of Gucci, has acquired French fragrance label Creed for 3.5 billion euros. The all-cash deal, expected to close in the second half of the year, marks Kering's move to create an in-house cosmetics business. Funds controlled by BlackRock and Creed's current chairman, Javier Ferran, will be involved in the acquisition.

site_title: Alibaba, Tencent shares rise as investors bet China’s tech crackdown is over
summary: Alibaba and Tencent shares rose in Hong Kong on Monday following China's $984 million fine against Ant Group, signaling the end of a regulatory crackdown on the country's technology sector. The fine, announced on Friday, was a significant penalty for Ant Group, which had been fined for violating laws and regulations in areas such as corporate governance and anti-money laundering. The announcement has led investors to believe that regulatory pressure will ease, with Alibaba and Tencent shares rebounding strongly.

images.alt_text: Pedestrian walk past the Alibaba logo which is displayed on the wall of the Alibaba Group Holding Ltd exhibition space at the CeBit tech show in Hanover, Germany, on Monday, March 16, 2015. European Commission and EIB plan to accelerate upgrades to telecommunications networks by subsidizing construction in rural areas, Guenther Oettinger, commissioner for the digital economy, says at CeBIT conference in Hanover. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

On Saturday, Ant proposed to buy back as much as 7.6 per cent of shares in an effort to provide a chance to cut stakes for investors ensnared by a years-long regulatory crackdown at the fintech powerhouse.
Founded by billionaire Jack Ma, Ant operates China’s ubiquitous mobile payment app Alipay as well as consumer lending and insurance products distribution businesses among others.
Ant’s fine would be the largest regulatory penalty imposed on a Chinese Internet company since ride-hailing major Didi Global was fined US$1.2 billion by China’s cybersecurity regulator last year.

site_title: Vietnam orders Netflix to remove Chinese TV drama over disputed map
summary: Vietnam's culture ministry ordered Netflix to remove the Chinese TV drama "Flight to You" from its platforms due to a disputed map of the South China Sea, which shows islands as non-Vietnamese territory. The move follows the country's ban on the movie "Barbie" and the film "Uncharted" last year and week, respectively. FPT Telecom stopped offering the drama after receiving a 24-hour notice, and Netflix has declined to comment. This marks the second time in a week Hanoi has sought to restrict foreign entertainment over the map issue.

images.alt_text: Vietnam authorities ban the upcoming Greta Gerwig film over a map in “Barbie” that they said shows a Chinese map of territory in the South China Sea, where the two neighbours have competing claims.
'Barbie' is the latest movie to be banned in Vietnam for depicting China’s nine-dash line, which was repudiated in an international arbitration ruling by a court in The Hague in 2016.
The world-famous Blackpink is due to perform in Vietnam for the first time ever on Jul 29-30.

site_title: Axiata eyes unit stake sales as debt swells after overseas push
summary: Axiata Group, Malaysia's largest wireless carrier, plans to sell stakes in some of its businesses and list its technology units to reduce debt, which has swelled to 36.7 billion ringgit after its overseas expansion. The company's CEO, Vivek Sood, mentioned stake sales in its wireless tower unit Edotco Group and revamping its Indonesian operations as options to slash debt. Axiata also plans to bring in new investors in its digital fintech arm Boost and AI firm ADA, with listings expected in two to three years.

images.alt_text: Asean telecom tower owners draw investors on structural growth, stable cash flows

site_title: UK jobs market cools again, pay growth weakest since April 2021: REC
summary: The UK jobs market cooled again in June, with vacancies ticking up further but at the weakest pace since records began in March 2021. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) reported a 57.6 availability of staff, the steepest month-on-month increase since 2009, driven by people reacting to high inflation. Pay growth weakened, with increases in starting salaries for permanent and temporary staff at their weakest since April 2021. This could ease concerns about inflation pressure for the Bank of England, which has raised interest rates 13 times since late 2021.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England is worried about long-term price pressures in the labour market and it is widely expected to continue raising interest rates.

site_title: Brics summit to be ‘physical’ despite Putin warrant: South Africa
summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa confirmed that the upcoming Brics summit, scheduled for August, will be held in-person despite an arrest warrant for Russian President Vladimir Putin. Ramaphosa stated that the summit will be a "physical" meeting, with all participants committed to having a face-to-face discussion. The move comes amid speculation that Pretoria might have considered moving the talks to China to avoid arresting Putin. Ramaphosa defended South Africa's neutral position on the Ukraine conflict, saying the country will not be deterred in its efforts to promote dialogue and negotiation.

images.alt_text: Brics countries have to resolve a perennial problem – how to move from bilateral to multilateral clearing and to a common currency.

site_title: M&A worth US$800 billion leaked in last year’s deals slump
summary: A report from H/Advisors found that in 2023, around 33% of deals worth $2 billion or more were leaked to the media, totaling approximately $800 billion. Asia-Pacific was the most porous region, with over half of deals being detailed before announcement. Western Europe followed closely, with 48% of deals being leaked. The leakiest sectors included aerospace and defense, retail, and food and tobacco. The decline in M&A activity, which began in 2021, continued into 2023 due to inflationary pressures and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: A 200 billion yuan wave of selling pressure threatens China stocks
summary: China's stock market is facing a wave of selling pressure as over 200 billion yuan ($37.3 billion) of cash locked up in mutual funds is set to mature, prompting investor redemptions. The funds, which have averaged a 0.4% loss since inception, are expected to trigger further selling, adding to concerns about the market's momentum. Investors are becoming wary, with many holding for less than six months, and selling quickly, posing a challenge to fund managers already facing a confidence crisis.

images.alt_text: Newly registered active equity funds can’t charge more than 1.2 per cent for the management fee or a 0.2 per cent for a custodian fee, the official China Securities Journal reports, citing a work plan by the China Securities Regulatory Commission

site_title: Asia: Tech rally helps Hong Kong lead most markets higher
summary: Hong Kong led gains in most Asian markets as tech firms rebounded after China's crackdown on the sector. The Hang Seng Index rose over 1% on hopes that the firms could focus on their businesses again. Alibaba and Tencent were fined huge amounts for "illegal acts", but analysts see the prospect of a return to normalcy. The gains were seen in Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Manila, and Jakarta, with other markets also rising.

site_title: Oil eases ahead of China, US data, but Opec+ cuts support market
summary: Oil prices eased ahead of fresh economic data from the US and China, with Brent crude falling 0.3% to $78.25 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude down 0.4% to $73.57 a barrel. Saudi Arabia will extend its 1 million barrels per day output cut into August, and Russia will cut crude exports by 500,000 barrels per day. Despite cautious investor sentiment, Opec+ plans to further reduce supply, which could support prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The sun is seen behind a crude oil pump jack in the Permian Basin in Loving County, Texas, U.S., November 22, 2019. REUTERS/Angus Mordant//File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Annual bonus rates hold steady for most par funds despite 2022 losses
summary: Insurers have held steady annual bonus rates for most par funds despite 2022 losses, which caused double-digit losses for some insurance participating funds. The poor equity and bond markets led to the reduction of terminal bonus rates for some par funds to ensure long-term sustainability.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of a customer being served at the CPF Bishan Service Centre, 16 February 2023.
Lower-risk options are now more attractive due to higher interest rates, but inflation remains a risk.

site_title: China-led EV boom in Thailand threatens Japan’s grip on key market
summary: China is gaining ground in Thailand's electric vehicle (EV) market, threatening Japan's dominance. Chinese automaker BYD has become the market leader, with Siam Motors, a Thai family-owned group, in talks with Chinese companies for potential partnerships. Thailand aims to convert 30% of its vehicle production to EVs by 2030, and has offered incentives to attract Chinese investment. This shift reflects a broader trend in Asia, where Chinese automakers are expanding their presence and building overseas production hubs in response to a competitive home market.

images.alt_text: Bali saw demand for luxury hotels drop in the January-May period amid a substantial decline in tourists from China.

site_title: For Hong Kong’s youth, government-backed hostels offer a smidgen of housing hope
summary: Hong Kong's youth hostel program, launched in response to the city's chronic housing shortage, offers subsidized rooms for young adults. The program aims to provide 3,000 beds in five years through hotel-to-hostel conversions. Despite initial enthusiasm, the program faces challenges, including high demand and limited financing models. Applicants are required to complete community service and have limited financial resources. Experts say the program will only provide a limited solution to the city's housing woes, which are rooted in broader social and economic issues.

images.alt_text: Self-use homebuyers will be able to borrow as much as 70 per cent on residential properties worth up to HK$15 million, and 60 per cent for properties worth between HK$15 million to HK$30 million.

site_title: Millions of Chinese staying home shackle South-east Asian growth
summary: South-east Asian nations are experiencing a decline in Chinese tourist arrivals, with numbers varying between 14% and 39% lower than pre-pandemic levels in May. This slowdown is attributed to China's slower-than-expected economic recovery and a decrease in spending by the Chinese population. Despite Thailand's rebound in post-pandemic travel demand, Chinese visitor arrivals are expected to miss the original target of seven million for 2023 by at least two million. Countries are now diversifying their target markets to reduce reliance on Chinese tourists.

images.alt_text: Japan Foods Holding founder, chairman and CEO Takahashi Kenichi at Tokyo Shokudo in VivoCity. Kenichi said its best-performing restaurants were located in the heartland malls, even before the pandemic.
The 6.8 hectare site is adjacent to the new Science Centre and Jurong Lake Gardens.

site_title: Alibaba mulls selling shares to Ant for buyback as probe ends
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is considering selling up to 7.6% of shares to Ant Group, a fintech powerhouse, as part of a buyback program. This move comes after a nearly three-year regulatory probe. Ant proposed the buyback program at a valuation of 567.1 billion yuan (S$106 billion), which would value the company at almost 70% less than its 2020 market capitalization. The planned share repurchase aims to cut stakes for investors affected by a years-long regulatory crackdown.

site_title: How to land a good job in a world where CVs and degrees don’t matter as much
summary:
LinkedIn Apac boss Feon Ang shares her insights on finding opportunities in the job market, where traditional CVs and degrees no longer guarantee success. Key takeaways include: 

* Job seekers need to go beyond a good CV by focusing on skills and building quality connections. 
* A degree or diploma does not guarantee a job; companies now prioritize skills over pedigree. 
* Personal growth and self-improvement are essential for career advancement, and the future of work is more fluid and non-linear, with flexibility and culture being top priorities for employees.

images.alt_text: A LinkedIn office in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, May 3, 2023.

Last year, more than 161,000 people were laid off from technology companies and startups, according to Layoffs.fyi, a site that tracks job cuts. So far this year, more than 148,000 people have been laid off.
The war for talent is real: LinkedIn Asia-Pac MD
Breaking glass ceilings start from different sectors of society

site_title: The super rich are snapping up Tokyo’s new ultra-luxury homes
summary: Wealthy Asian buyers are snapping up ultra-luxury homes in Tokyo, taking advantage of a weaker yen and low interest rates. The Kita complex and Mita Garden Hills have seen strong demand, with prices doubling and tripling year-over-year. Foreign investors, including those from Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan, are also drawn to the city, with many paying in cash or securing low-interest loans. The trend is driven by Japan's stable economy and attractive real estate market, which offers more affordable luxury options compared to other global cities.

images.alt_text: The strong base pay growth boosted worker’s total cash earnings, or nominal wages, by 2.5 per cent in May, after a revised 0.8 per cent increase logged in April.

site_title: The Myst sells 27% of units on launch weekend at average of S$2,057 psf
summary: CDL's The Myst in Upper Bukit Timah sold 110 units, or 27% of its 408 units, at an average price of S$2,057 psf over its launch weekend. The majority of buyers, 99%, were Singaporeans, while 1% were permanent residents from China. The most popular unit types were one-bedroom plus study and two-bedroom plus study. Despite lower take-up rates compared to other recent launches, analysts believe The Myst's sales will rebound as the project's advantages, such as its proximity to nature and schools, remain attractive to buyers.

images.alt_text: CDL says that around a third of the units at The Myst will be priced at "a sweet spot" of S$1.5 million and below.

site_title: Sarah Silverman sues Meta, OpenAI for copyright infringement
summary: Comedian Sarah Silverman and two authors have filed copyright infringement lawsuits against Meta Platforms and OpenAI, alleging that their content was used to train AI language models without permission. The lawsuits claim that summaries generated by ChatGPT indicate the bot was trained on their copyrighted material. Meta and OpenAI have not commented on the allegations. The proposed class action lawsuits were filed in San Francisco federal court on Friday.

images.alt_text: As a chatbot on Character.AI, Einstein has responded to 1.6 million messages, expounding on everything from theories of relativity to pet recommendations.
FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed ChatGPT logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: In call with Turkey’s Erdogan, Biden expresses support for Sweden’s Nato bid
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed support for Sweden's NATO bid, saying he wants to see Stockholm join the alliance "as soon as possible." During a phone call with Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan, Biden also discussed the delivery of F-16 fighter jets to Turkey and Ukraine's bid to join NATO. Turkey, along with Hungary, has been blocking Sweden's NATO membership, citing concerns over terrorism. The two leaders agreed to meet in person at an upcoming NATO summit in Lithuania to discuss bilateral relations and regional issues.

images.alt_text: By leveraging Turkey’s geopolitical position, Erdogan was able to sustain his spending spree until Turks cast their ballots. But now that he has won another term, an economic reckoning looms.

site_title: New Zealand, EU ink trade deal that likely goes into effect in 2024
summary: New Zealand and the European Union (EU) signed a free trade agreement (FTA) on July 9, 2023, with the deal expected to come into force in the first half of 2024. The agreement aims to cut costs and support exporters to grow and diversify their trade, particularly in the regions affected by Cyclone Gabrielle. New Zealand's Minister for Trade and Export Growth Damien O'Connor stated that the new access will accelerate the country's post-Covid recovery and boost its regions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, June 5, 2020. REUTERS/Yves Herman//File Photo

site_title: Failure is an enabler of success: one founder’s personal story
summary: Qumata CEO Luca Schnettler shares his personal story of how embracing failure helped him achieve success. Schnettler, who turned down a spot at a top university, recognized his weaknesses and switched to entrepreneurship, eventually building a scalable tech business with a team of 50 professionals and raising over $30 million in funding. He emphasizes the importance of learning from failure and using it as a stepping stone to growth and positive impact. Schnettler's story highlights the need to reframe failure as an essential part of success, rather than something to be feared or hidden.

images.alt_text: Multiple tales of breakthrough have echoed through the startup ecosystem, making any decision to shutter a tough one for founders to make.

site_title: Yellen says still too early to rule out risk of US recession
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said it's "not completely off the table" that the US may experience a recession, citing high inflation and slowing job growth. Despite President Joe Biden's optimism, a baseline scenario suggests a recession could begin in late 2023. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again this month to combat inflation, which remains above the target. Yellen's visit to Beijing focused on strengthening US-China ties and addressing trade concerns.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s overall message was for both sides to manage their rivalry with a fair set of rules. “President Biden and I do not see the relationship between the US and China through the frame of great power conflict,” she says. “We believe the world is big enough for both of our countries to thrive.”

The US Treasury has referred to Pan Gongsheng as “head” of the People's Bank of China, adding to expectations he would soon be the first person to concurrently hold the titles of party chief and governor since 2018.

site_title: A glut of made-in-China plastic will dent oil’s growth machine
summary: China's rapid expansion in the petrochemical industry is set to lead to a glut of made-in-China plastic, denting oil's growth and squeezing profits. The construction of over 20 petrochemical projects in China this year will increase the country's capacity to nearly a quarter of the world's total, leading to oversupply and thin margins. This is expected to impact traditional manufacturing giants in the region, such as South Korea and Japan, and may prompt countries like India and Vietnam to build their own production facilities to reduce dependence on imports.

images.alt_text: The profit crunch is being driven by China’s refiners boosting output of olefins such as ethylene to offset an expected decline in sales of petrol and diesel as electric vehicle take-up accelerates.

site_title: Australia’s competition watchdog puts data brokers on radar
summary: Australia's competition watchdog, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), is investigating data brokers, including Oracle, Equifax, and Experian, for their business practices. The ACCC is seeking feedback on data brokers' transparency and awareness of their operations, which gather personal details of customers and their browsing behavior. The regulator aims to explore potential competition and consumer issues. The report will be handed over to the treasurer in March 2024, following a five-year inquiry into digital services.

images.alt_text: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison concedes defeat in the national elections in Sydney on May 21, 2022. (Photo by Saeed KHAN / AFP)

site_title: UK firms most upbeat in 10 months despite economic headwinds: survey
summary: UK businesses reported their highest level of optimism in 10 months in June, despite economic headwinds, according to a survey. The survey found that hiring plans increased, while inflation pressure dropped to its lowest in nearly two years. However, rising interest rates may prompt consumers to cut spending, and the Bank of England is expected to continue raising rates to curb inflation. The UK economy is also shrinking for the second month, posing a challenge to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Rising costs may dampen appetite for restaurants, even if weak tourist numbers don’t: analysts
summary: Singapore's restaurants are adapting to the post-pandemic market, driven by domestic consumers rather than tourists. Analysts say that while tourist numbers are still below pre-Covid levels, companies like Jumbo Group and Japan Foods are benefiting from domestic spend and recovery in non-China tourist footfall. Restaurant sales volumes have recovered to 91% of 2019 levels, with some outlets seeing a "well-balanced number of locals and tourists." However, rising costs and inflation may lead to muted demand growth, with customers opting for cheaper options.

images.alt_text: Economists expect tourism to support retail sales, after on-year growth eases to 1.8% in May
A queue for Coldplay concert tickets at the SingPost outlet in June.

site_title: Half of Lentor Hills Residences units sold on launch weekend at average of S$2,080 psf
summary: Half of Lentor Hills Residences' 598 units were sold on its launch weekend, with 298 units sold at an average price of S$2,080 psf. Buyers were predominantly Singaporeans, with units selling at a starting price of S$1,834 psf. The two-bedroom and two-bedroom-plus-study units were the most popular, while dual-key units also registered "healthy take-up". The project's take-up rate came within expectations, with developers attributing it to the location, pricing, and resilient demand for new private homes among homeowners.

images.alt_text: Lentor Hills Residences has 598 residential units across five towers and parking lots for all units.

site_title: Nasdaq 100 in consolidation phase
summary: The Nasdaq 100 index had its best performance since 1983 in the first half of 2023, rising 31.7% due to a focus on artificial intelligence and expectations of the end of the rate hike cycle. The index's outperformance was spread evenly across the months, with only February marking a marginal loss. A double-top formation at 15,285 serves as a critical resistance point, but a potential reversal could occur if the index fails to break above it.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electric monitor displaying Japan's Nikkei share average and recent movements, outside a bank in Tokyo, Japan, June 5, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: How the food system is changing and what it means for investors
summary: Global shifts in income, populations, geopolitics, and climate change are altering the world's food supply. Taimur Hyat, PGIM's COO, warns that it's too early to invest in cultured meat due to lack of clear winners and losers. His research paper, "Food for Thought: Investment Opportunities Across a Changing Food System," explores investment opportunities in a changing food system.

images.alt_text: China will reduce its emissions by some 3.8 gigatonnes of CO2e if it can switch half of its protein consumption to alternative proteins by 2050.
Startups face the challenge of achieving price parity, as the cost of producing alternative proteins exceeds that of traditional meat products.

Enthusiasm for alternatives to beef and pork surged in the aftermath of Beyond Meat’s 2019 initial public offering, and venture capitalists were willing to invest in companies that offered little more than a recipe book.

site_title: London is falling down and it's because of climate change
summary: London's centuries-old historical homes are being damaged due to subsidence, a phenomenon caused by the city's unique London clay soil shrinking and swelling with extreme weather. Prolonged droughts and heatwaves, exacerbated by climate change, have triggered the highest insurance payout in nearly two decades. Experts warn that the issue could worsen, with one in six homes built before 1900 being particularly vulnerable. The UK's insurance industry expects to pay £219 million for subsidence claims in 2022, with a 26% increase in overall claim volumes reported last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: High-rise apartments under construction can be seen in the distance behind a row of residential housing in south London, Britain, August 6, 2021. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Thai PM frontrunner rallies supporters ahead of parliamentary vote
summary: Thai Prime Minister frontrunner Pita Limjaroenrat rallied supporters ahead of a parliamentary vote this week, which will determine if he will lead the country. His pro-democracy Move Forward Party (MFP) secured the most seats at the May 14 election with 312 Lower House seats, but falls short of the 376 votes needed to endorse him for the top job. Despite the uncertainty, Limjaroenrat vowed not to step back, emphasizing his determination to become Thailand's prime minister.

images.alt_text: Pita Limjaroenra says: “Enough to make me become PM.” when he is asked how many senators would endorse him.

site_title: Law Society president Adrian Tan dies at 57 after battle with cancer
summary: Law Society of Singapore president Adrian Tan, 57, has died after a year-long battle with cancer. Tan, who was diagnosed in March 2022, continued to carry out his duties with courage and humor despite his illness. The Law Society announced his death on Saturday evening, with tributes pouring in from colleagues, including Minister for Law K. Shanmugam and TSMP Law Corporation partner Stefanie Yuen Thio. Tan was remembered as a distinguished leader, cherished friend, and tireless advocate for the legal profession.

images.alt_text: New Law Society president to help lawyers feel inspired again, prevent exodus of talent
Culture not main reason for attrition: LawSoc president

site_title: Editors Talk: Lessons from the world’s biggest newsrooms (Ep 4)
summary: The International News Media Association held its annual world congress in May, attracting leaders from 50+ countries. Christopher Lim, associate editor (product) of The Business Times, shared insights from the event on the podcast "Editors Talk." Lim discussed lessons from the world's biggest newsrooms, including the impact of AI, audio, and newsroom transformation. He highlighted the importance of adapting to changing industry trends and the need for continuous learning and innovation.

images.alt_text: Editors Talk: Journalism is no longer just writing (Ep 3)
How podcasts’ unrealised potential is limitless.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Monday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% or 1.7 points to 3,141.17 at the Monday open, following mixed global markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 58 to 53, with Seatrium rising 1.6% and Golden Agri-Resources gaining 2.1%. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also increased, while Healthway Medical lost 2.1%. This follows mixed US employment data and rate-hike fears, with the Nasdaq Composite Index slipping 0.1% on Friday.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.

site_title: China sets wide-ranging rules for US$2.9 trillion private investment funds
summary: China has introduced wide-ranging rules for its US$2.9 trillion private investment fund sector, effective September 1. The new regulations create a chapter specifically for venture capital funds and aim to promote innovation by encouraging investment in technology startups. The rules cover obligations of fund managers and custodians, fundraising, risk identification, and supervision. The regulations have 62 items in seven chapters and apply to private investment funds with different organisational forms, including contract, company, and partnership. The move aims to better protect investors and promote innovation in the sector.

images.alt_text: The budding trend underscores a growing belief that the country is too big and complicated to be lumped with others.

site_title: ESR Group files court application to prevent Quarz Capital from convening EGM
summary: ESR Group, the sponsor of Sabana Industrial Reit, has filed a court application to prevent Quarz Capital, an activist investor, from convening an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on August 4 to vote on two resolutions. The EGM would have voted on removing the Reit manager and internalizing the management function of Sabana Reit. ESR Group claims the requisition contains false and misleading statements and that the resolutions breach the trust deed of Sabana Reit. The court application seeks to declare the EGM requisition invalid and restrain Quarz Capital from taking further steps.

images.alt_text: Sabana' Reit's upcoming extraordinary general meeting involves two resolutions - one for the removal of its Reit manager and second on the internalisation of the Reit management function.
At an upcoming extraordinary general meeting, unitholders will vote on whether to remove Sabana Reit’s current manager and replace it with an internal one.

In response to a query from The Business Times, Quarz Capital said on Friday (Jun 23) said that an internal manager model for Sabana Reit would help transfer “significant value” from ESR Group to the Reit’s unitholders.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of July 7, 2023, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The Panamax market started the week in a slow state, with owners prioritizing quick cover over rate revival. In contrast, the Capesize market showed a notable level of enquiry, with majors from West Australia to China securing fixed vessels. The Pacific market found a floor, while the Atlantic market experienced a lack of activity, with downward pressure on rates. The week ended on a slightly more positive note for the Atlantic market.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Jun 30, 2023).

site_title: Grand Banks Yachts pushes full steam ahead to capture wave of demand
summary: Grand Banks Yachts, a luxury recreational motor yachts manufacturer, has seen significant growth after retooling its processes during the pandemic. Revenue rose 42.1% to S$78 million in the 9 months ended March 31, with earnings surging to S$5.7 million. The company secured 5 new boat orders and a trade-in boat order in the third quarter, with a net order book of S$178 million. Grand Banks plans to expand its Pasir Gudang yard, increasing production capacity by 10-15% and improving efficiency. The company is also introducing stock boats to cater to customers seeking instant gratification, and exploring sustainable fuels and engines for future products.

images.alt_text: Grand Banks' cruising through crisis

site_title: Asia must shift to alternative proteins to reach climate safety: report
summary: A report by Asia Research and Engagement (ARE) warns that Asia's protein supply chain cannot reach its climate goals without a significant shift towards alternative proteins. Current business-as-usual conditions will lead to a 78% increase in meat and seafood consumption in Asia by 2050, resulting in a 90% rise in greenhouse gas emissions. To mitigate this, China can reduce emissions by 3.8 gigatonnes of CO2e by 2050 if it switches half of its protein consumption to alternative proteins. The region's protein companies are slow to decarbonize, and banks are also hesitant to commit to net-zero targets for the food and agribusiness segment.

images.alt_text: Startups face the challenge of achieving price parity, as the cost of producing alternative proteins exceeds that of traditional meat products.

Enthusiasm for alternatives to beef and pork surged in the aftermath of Beyond Meat’s 2019 initial public offering, and venture capitalists were willing to invest in companies that offered little more than a recipe book.
Impossible Foods wins ruling to continue use of key additive

site_title: SGX RegCo’s IFA guidelines commendable, but it’s time to look at other protections for minorities
summary: SGX RegCo has set out guidelines for independent financial advisers (IFAs) in Singapore, emphasizing the need for them to be independent, diligent, and transparent in their analyses. However, regulators are flagging concerns over IFAs' opinions in cases where offer prices are below a company's net asset value (NAV) or revalued net asset value (RNAV). Examples include Chip Eng Seng and Golden Energy and Resources, where IFAs' opinions were deemed fair and reasonable despite lowball offers. To strengthen protections for minority investors, regulators may consider requiring real estate companies to be valued at a minimum of their NAV when taken private.

images.alt_text: The issuance of new guidelines follow some controversial independent financial advisor opinions in the past year.
SGX RegCo is issuing the Guide on Independent Financial Advisers as a starting point to improve the standards, clarity and consistency of advice that IFAs render in their opinions.
Minority shareholders have voiced displeasure in recent months over perceived lowball offers that still receive “fair and reasonable” opinions from their IFAs.

site_title: Privatised Britain’s debt load is now a major government problem
summary: The UK's privatized debt load is becoming a major government problem, as borrowing costs surge to a 16-year high. Many public service providers, including water companies, have issued inflation-linked bonds, which are now becoming increasingly difficult to service. The UK's biggest water company, Thames Water, is in talks to raise over £1 billion to service its debts, while other companies like Network Rail and Southern Water are also struggling. The government is at risk of being put on the hook to clean up the mess, with the national debt exceeding 100% of GDP for the first time since 1961.

images.alt_text: The entrance to the headquarters of Thames Water in Reading, UK, on Monday, July 3, 2023. The bonds of the UK's biggest water provider climbed on Monday as investors bet a selloff driven by fears the utility would be nationalized had gone too far. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Thieves stole US$20 million via Revolut US payment flaw
summary: Criminal gangs exploited a flaw in Revolut's payment systems, resulting in the theft of over $20 million. The issue arose due to differences between the US and European systems, causing some transactions to be declined and then erroneously refunded. Thieves would encourage individuals to make large transactions, which would be declined, then withdraw the refunded sums via ATMs. Revolut has not commented on the incident. A total of $23 million was stolen, with $3 million recovered, resulting in a net loss of approximately $20 million.

site_title: Corporate scandals spark crisis of confidence in Thai market
summary: Thailand's benchmark SET Index has plummeted 11% this year, becoming Asia's worst performing market, amid a crisis of confidence sparked by corporate scandals and accounting irregularities. A recent default by Stark Corp, a US$2 billion wire maker, has left investors facing losses, and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is under fire for its handling of the situation. Investors are calling for tighter oversight of Thailand's capital markets, and the government faces challenges in addressing the crisis, including a transition period following the surprise win of a new party leader.

images.alt_text: The Bangkok-based Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) files charges of financial misconduct against 10 entities and individuals in the management of Stark Corp.

site_title: As Macau roars back to life, Sands China plots next stage of reinvestment
summary: Macau's gaming industry is experiencing a resurgence, with Sands China's Londoner Macao integrated resort opening in late May. The resort, which cost $2 billion, features replicas of London landmarks and has seen a return of crowds, gaming tables, and convention bookings. Sands China has committed to investing $5.1 billion over the next decade, with 93% going towards non-gaming segments. The company's COO, Grant Chum, announced plans to double the size of The Venetian's meeting space and develop a conservatory garden-themed attraction. Macau's recovery is expected to continue, with Chum citing higher-spending customers and the city's existing world-class integrated resorts as advantages over competitors.

images.alt_text: Bellagio, one of the top-performing resorts on the city’s famous Strip, is operated under a long-term lease by MGM Resorts International, its original owner.
Prior to the recent developments, Singapore had earned a name for itself as one of the region’s top gambling spots, with two casinos – one at MBS and the other at  RWS.
Macau’s tourism has started ramping up since China's reopening, returning to 66 per cent of the pre-Covid level in April as the mainland resumed international flights.
Casinos along the Cotai strip in Macau, China. Photographer: Eduardo Leal/Bloomberg

site_title: BOE’s Bailey rejects calls to raise inflation target above 2%
summary: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey rejected calls to raise the inflation target above 2%, citing the need to maintain expectations and flexibility in the central bank's remit. Despite grappling with 8.7% inflation, Bailey assured that the BOE will bring inflation back to target, while also acknowledging the flexibility to lengthen the horizon to achieve this goal. Markets expect a potential rate hike to 6.5% to prevent a wage-price spiral, with some economists warning of a recession if the benchmark is not lifted.

images.alt_text: IMF official Alfred Kammer says the BOE's surprise move last week to ramp up its pace of tightening was "important".

site_title: Startup bets on kitesurfing to blow away shipping pollution
summary: A French startup, Beyond The Sea, is testing a blue inflatable kite sail to propel a catamaran across the water, aiming to reduce shipping industry carbon emissions. Inspired by kitesurfing, the technology uses an automated traction system with artificial intelligence to adapt the sail's position to wind conditions. The goal is to design larger kite sails for yachts, trawlers, and container ships, potentially reducing fuel consumption by 20% and achieving a net-zero emissions target by 2050.

images.alt_text: The United Nations’ global shipping regulator agrees to cut total annual emissions of greenhouse gases “by at least 20 per cent.

site_title: Yellen says US-China ties on ‘surer footing’ after critical trip
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen completed a four-day visit to China, aiming to revive engagement between the two largest economies. She emphasized the benefits of trade with China and stressed that diversifying supply chains isn't decoupling. Yellen's comments were seen as a positive step, with the US and China managing their rivalry with a fair set of rules. The US and China have been in a trade war, with both sides restricting exports critical to advanced technologies, but Yellen's message suggests a shift towards a more collaborative approach.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen's comments come as the United States seeks to cool tensions and stress areas of collaboration between the world’s two biggest economies.

site_title: UK to sign Pacific trade deal, shifting focus to China
summary: The UK is set to sign a Pacific trade deal, known as the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), in Auckland on July 15-16, marking its first new membership since the agreement's inception. The signing shifts the UK's focus to China, which is next on the list of applicants. The CPTPP, currently comprising 11 members, is valued at 15% of global GDP, and its inclusion of the UK is expected to boost its economic influence. The move is seen as a way to balance China's growing influence in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: After riots, France bans Bastille Day fireworks sales
summary: France has banned the sale, possession, and transport of fireworks until July 15 due to riots sparked by the police killing of a 17-year-old during a traffic stop on June 27. The ban comes amid long-standing frustrations and accusations of systemic racism among France's security forces.

images.alt_text: More than two hundred police were injured and 875 people arrested overnight, authorities said, as rioters clashed with officers in towns and cities across France, with buildings as well as buses and other vehicles torched, and stores looted.

site_title: Asia’s co-firing ambitions may produce more carbon emissions
summary: A new study by the Breakthrough Institute suggests that co-firing technology, which uses ammonia and hydrogen alongside coal, may generate more emissions than just coal or gas. Asian countries such as Japan and South Korea are investing in this technology, but critics argue it is costly and inefficient, with minimal climate benefits. The study found that co-firing can leave up to 80% of fossil-fuel emissions, and that producing ammonia and hydrogen using fossil fuels can result in "considerably more carbon emissions" than burning coal or gas alone.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on September 21, 2021 shows smoke from coal combustion rising from the chimneys at the Suralaya coal power plant in Cilegon. - Smokestacks belch noxious fumes into the air from a massive coal-fired power plant on the Indonesian coast, a stark illustration of Asia's addiction to the fossil fuel which is threatening climate targets. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP) / TO GO WITH Climate-UN-COP26-Asia-coal,FEATURE by Haeril Halim and Sam Reeves

site_title: Yellen’s China trip leaves little doubt Pan’s in charge of PBOC
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's visit to Beijing left little doubt that Pan Gongsheng, the newly appointed party chief of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), will soon become the central bank's governor. Despite initial uncertainty, the Treasury referred to Pan as "head" of the PBOC, and his elevation to party chief has sparked expectations of an unannounced promotion. Pan's appointment is expected to be approved by China's legislature, with the potential for his official appointment to be announced in August.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s overall message was for both sides to manage their rivalry with a fair set of rules. “President Biden and I do not see the relationship between the US and China through the frame of great power conflict,” she says. “We believe the world is big enough for both of our countries to thrive.”

site_title: Why Tesla’s EV charging plugs are becoming industry standard
summary: Tesla's electric vehicle (EV) charging plugs are becoming the industry standard, with major rivals Ford Motor, General Motors, Rivian, Volvo, and Mercedes-Benz announcing plans to use Tesla's charging gear. This move is driven by access to Tesla's US network of 20,000 Superchargers, which offer faster and more reliable charging. Tesla stands to gain $3-5.2 billion in annual charging revenue by 2030. While the shift may limit competition, it's unlikely to be fatal, and other charging networks will need to adapt to include Tesla's plug.

images.alt_text: The programme is rolled out in Tesla’s largest markets, including the US, China, Germany, France, Canada, Mexico, Hong Kong and Singapore, according to regional websites.
Mercedes-Benz will be the first German automaker to sign up for Tesla’s charging design for its North American customers.
Deliveries from Tesla’s Shanghai plant rise almost 20 per cent from a year earlier in June to 93,680 vehicles
Tesla’s sales of cars produced in Shanghai in the second quarter accounted for over half of its global deliveries.
Around 20,000 staff are employed at Tesla’s Shanghai factory, which has the capacity to churn out about 1 million cars a year.

site_title: China cuts stock funds’ management fees to bolster market
summary: China's securities regulator has cut stock mutual funds' management fees to 1.2% and custodian fees to 0.2%, aiming to boost the market and increase institutional investors' equity allocations. The move is part of efforts to reduce costs and improve investor sentiment, which has been eroded by high fees and poor returns. The regulator also plans to cut trading commissions and coordinate with ministries to direct more funding to investment institutions.

images.alt_text: The budding trend underscores a growing belief that the country is too big and complicated to be lumped with others.

site_title: Retail investors net buy S$390 million of S-Reits in H1 2023
summary: Retail investors in Singapore net bought S$390 million of S-Reits in the first half of 2023, with Keppel DC Reit being the best performer with 25% total returns. Institutional investors saw net outflows of S$485 million, with data centre S-Reits receiving the most institutional net inflows. Diversified S-Reits saw the most institutional net outflows, while retail investors showed net inflows to Suntec Reit, Lendlease Global Commercial Reit, and Keppel Reit.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve last Thursday (Jun 29) signalled that more rate hikes may come in a bid to curb inflation.

site_title: Elton John hails fans at emotional final farewell show
summary: Elton John brought his 50-year live performance career to a close with an emotional farewell concert in Stockholm, Sweden. The 76-year-old pop superstar performed to a sold-out crowd of 30,000 fans, thanking them as his "lifeblood" and dedicating songs to his band and crew. The concert, part of his "Farewell Yellow Brick Road" tour, marked the end of his live performances, which have seen him play in front of 6.25 million fans worldwide.

images.alt_text: Elton John, 76, known for his glittery outfits and iconic glasses, is nearing the end of his final tour, of which Glastonbury will represent the last British show.

site_title: Barclays hires new chairman of healthcare investment banking
summary: Barclays has hired Jim Birchenough, formerly of Wells Fargo & Co, as its chairman of global healthcare investment banking. Birchenough will be based in San Francisco and joins the bank alongside Alexis de Rosnay, who is taking on an expanded role. The move is seen as a boost to the bank's healthcare investment banking unit, which was impacted by the departure of its vice chairman earlier this year. Birchenough brings a "real track record" to the role, according to Barclays' global head of healthcare and real estate investment banking.

images.alt_text: The British hedge fund has grappled with redemptions since the FT and Tortoise Media on Jun 8 jointly reported allegations by 13 women that Crispin Odey had sexually assaulted or harassed them over a 25-year period.
Barclays is tapping an increasing appetite from Asia quantitative and multi-strategy hedge funds for its prime financing business.
CEO CS Venkatakrishnan in recent weeks has been trying to stem a bevy of departures in the firm’s investment bank.
The Italian loans are one of the final remaining parts of its retail business in the country.

site_title: New minimum wage rule for NYC food delivery workers temporarily halted by judge
summary: A New York state judge has temporarily halted a new law requiring minimum wage payments for app-based food delivery workers, set to go into effect on July 12. The law, which applies to Uber, DoorDash, Grubhub Holdings, and Relay Delivery, was halted after the companies argued they could be irreparably harmed by the law. A hearing is scheduled for July 31 to determine the law's implementation.

site_title: Wall Street soothsayers have rarely been so bewildered about what’s next
summary: Wall Street analysts are divided on the stock market's future, with some predicting a 10% gain to 4,825 for the S&P 500 and others expecting a decline of 27% to 3,225. After a 37% surge in the Nasdaq 100 Index this year, forecasters are reassessing their targets due to the Federal Reserve's continued rate hikes. A 50% difference in year-end forecasts highlights the uncertainty, with some calling for a recession and others seeing a mild economic contraction. The market's resilience has led to a shift towards more bullish predictions.

images.alt_text: The world’s biggest economy adds 209,000 jobs last month, fewer than expected, but the unemployment rate edges close to historic lows.

site_title: US-China cooperation in climate finance 'critical': Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen emphasized the importance of US-China cooperation in climate finance, calling it "critical" to address the global threat of climate change. She urged China to support multilateral institutions like the Green Climate Fund and to include the private sector in transitioning towards net zero emissions. Yellen's comments come as the US seeks to cool tensions with China and stress areas of collaboration, including climate finance and global economic affairs. She plans to meet with Chinese officials and experts to discuss these issues during her four-day trip to Beijing.

images.alt_text: Yellen’s comments were delivered on Friday (Jul 7) during a meeting with Chinese Premier Li Qiang.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and US Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns meet with representatives of the US business community in China. She said a decoupling of the US and Chinese economies would be “virtually impossible” and would destabilise global markets.

site_title: China angst drives boom in funds excluding Asia’s biggest market
summary: China's large and complex market is driving a trend of excluding the country from emerging-market portfolios, with nearly 12 funds launched in the past year. This strategy aims to reduce risk due to China's policy and geopolitical headwinds. China's stocks now account for nearly 30% of MSCI's emerging market gauge, which has underperformed globally for a third consecutive year. As investors seek alternatives, funds focusing on other emerging markets in Asia have gained popularity, with assets held in iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ex-China ETF swelling to $4.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Ant’s fine would be the largest regulatory penalty imposed on a Chinese Internet company since ride-hailing major Didi Global was fined US$1.2 billion by China’s cybersecurity regulator last year.

Economic woes are adding to concern over some US$9 trillion of debt at local-government financing vehicles (LGFVs), entities controlled by authorities but not officially part of the Chinese government.
A view of the city skyline and Huangpu river in Shanghai. The boost from China's reopening to exports has been limited, says Maybank senior economist Chua Hak Bin.

site_title: How do ‘Barbie’ and Blackpink figure in a dangerous territorial dispute?
summary: Vietnam authorities have banned the upcoming Greta Gerwig film "Barbie" over a map in the movie that shows a Chinese map of territory in the South China Sea, where Vietnam and China have competing claims. The ban is part of a pattern of Vietnamese censors rejecting movies that depict disputed areas as under Beijing's control. The Philippines is also reviewing the film's release, with authorities citing concerns that it would denigrate Philippine sovereignty. The controversy highlights the complex relationship between Vietnam and China, with Vietnam seeking to counterbalance its relationship with China by strengthening ties with the US and other countries.

images.alt_text: 'Barbie' is the latest movie to be banned in Vietnam for depicting China’s nine-dash line, which was repudiated in an international arbitration ruling by a court in The Hague in 2016.
The world-famous Blackpink is due to perform in Vietnam for the first time ever on Jul 29-30.
Actor Margot Robbie, who plays the title role in the movie Barbie, during a photocall for the upcoming Warner Bros film  in Los Angeles last month.
Worldwide gross billings for Barbie, which represents amounts invoiced to customers, fell 41 per cent.

site_title: Innovation in EVs seen denting copper demand growth potential
summary: Industry analysts say innovation in electric vehicles (EVs) is reducing copper content, limiting demand growth for the metal. EVs typically use 80 kgs of copper, but new designs are cutting that amount by 20-30 kgs. Goldman Sachs and consultancy CRU Group lowered their copper usage estimates for EVs to 65-56 kgs per vehicle by 2030. This could slow copper demand growth, contrary to previous forecasts that relied on EVs driving copper demand.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz will be the first German automaker to sign up for Tesla’s charging design for its North American customers.
The Maxus T90 electric pickup truck will be launched in Singapore in Q4 2023, says authorised Maxus distributor Cycle & Carriage.
Goldman said its analysts were optimistic about EVs, anticipating “strong sales in China, driven by lower prices and a high demand for EVs that has been building up over the rest of 2023”.

site_title: When there’s wayang in the workplace
summary: A "fake-it-till-you-make-it" attitude, where individuals pretend to be confident and capable in the workplace, is common, especially during project work. This posturing can lead to success in the short term, but can also create a disconnect between an employee's actual capabilities and their desired perception. Experts, such as Samuel Chng and Jaya Dass, note that while a bit of posturing can be beneficial, excessive it can lead to a toxic work environment. To succeed, it's recommended that individuals focus on delivering results and building a solid reputation as a problem-solver, rather than relying solely on creating a desirable image.

images.alt_text: Being that springboard for your staff to move on to bigger and better things is certainly laudable.

site_title: Uncensored chatbots provoke a fracas over free speech
summary: A new wave of uncensored chatbots has emerged, sparking a debate over free speech and moderation. These unmoderated chatbots, developed by independent programmers, can produce misinformation, hate speech, and even suicidal advice. Companies like Google and OpenAI have added controls to limit what their tools can say, but the new chatbots lack these safeguards. Experts warn of the dangers, but proponents argue that the benefits of unmoderated AI outweigh the risks, citing the potential for customization and the printing press analogy. The debate raises questions about ownership and control, with some developers pushing for moderation and others rejecting it.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed ChatGPT logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
ChatGPT set off a frenzied use of generative AI in daily tasks from writing to coding and reached 100 million monthly active users in January, two months after its launch.
Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt (left, with Databricks co-founder Arsalan Tavakoli) warns that AI could be used by bad actors to "accelerate at scale".
US President Joe Biden meets a group of civil society leaders and advocates, who have previously criticised the influence of major tech companies, to discuss artificial intelligence.

site_title: XMH chairman Tan Tin Yeow builds direct stake
summary: Singapore stocks declined 1.8% over the past five trading sessions, while the Hang Seng Index fell 2.0% and the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI gained 0.2%. Institutions sold S$130 million of Singapore stocks, while Keppel Reit, Seatrium, and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit led the institutional inflow. XMH Holdings chairman Tan Tin Yeow acquired 600,000 shares, increasing his direct interest to 43.93%. The company reported a 29.2% increase in profit after tax and a 79% increase in revenue for FY23.

images.alt_text: Andy Luong, founder of UMS Holdings.

site_title: K-pop megastars BTS release memoir
summary: BTS, the K-pop megastars, released their memoir, "Beyond the Story: 10-Year Record of BTS", in South Korea on July 9, marking their 10th anniversary as a group. The book shot to the top of Amazon and Barnes and Noble bestseller lists in May on pre-orders. It contains a chronological summary of their musical career and hints at their future endeavors.
