The release was met with excitement from diehard fans, despite heavy rain, and marks a milestone in the group's history.

images.alt_text: Vietnam authorities ban the upcoming Greta Gerwig film over a map in “Barbie” that they said shows a Chinese map of territory in the South China Sea, where the two neighbours have competing claims.

site_title: PGA Tour commissioner Monahan will return on Jul 17
summary: PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan will return to work on July 17 after being sidelined nearly a month due to a medical issue. His return comes six days after he missed a hearing by US lawmakers regarding the PGA-LIV deal. Monahan, who negotiated a merger deal with Saudi backers of LIV Golf, will address questions and concerns about the tour's future. He stated his focus will be on securing a stable path forward for the tour in light of the merger deal framework with the Public Investment Fund of Saudi Arabia and DP World Tour.

images.alt_text: Chinese golfer Yin Ruoning kisses the trophy after winning the KPMG Women's PGA Championship in New Jersey on June 25, 2023.
The 20-year-old Yin, who collected her maiden LPGA Tour title at the DIO Implant LA Open earlier this year, is only the second Chinese woman to win a golf major.

The news came 10 days after PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan (pictured) appeared with PIF governor Yasir Al-Rumayyan for a CNBC interview explaining the parties’ decision to pursue a new, for-profit entity controlling the world of professional golf.

site_title: Nato allies agree to spend 'at least 2%' of their GDP on defence: diplomats
summary: NATO allies agree to spend at least 2% of their GDP on defense, surpassing the current target of 2% of national GDP. The 31 allies made the commitment as part of a two-day summit in Vilnius. The agreement aims to ensure a minimum level of military spending, rather than a goal to be achieved. Currently, only 11 of the 31 members meet the 2% target, with some countries spending under 1.4% of GDP on defense.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg holds a news conference at the alliance's headquarters in Brussels, Belgium November 16, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
A Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson says Japan should be “extra cautious on the issue of military security” given its “history of aggression”.

site_title: 2023 Nissan X-Trail review: On the right trail
summary: The 2023 Nissan X-Trail e-Power is a family-friendly SUV that delivers comfort, practicality, and safety. Its e-Power drivetrain combines the benefits of electric and petrol cars, offering smooth acceleration and quiet operation. The car's interior features a neat dashboard, solid build quality, and ample space for passengers and cargo. While its rear seats may be limited for adults, the X-Trail excels in terms of refinement, polish, and efficiency, making it a standout in its class. With a price tag of S$249,800, it competes with luxury cars like the BMW X1, but its roominess, practicality, and driving experience make it a compelling choice.

images.alt_text: The Hyundai Ioniq 6 is a relentlessly streamlined sedan that has a habit of picking up accolades, among them the prestigious World Car Of The Year Award.

site_title: Einstein and Musk chatbots are driving millions to download Character.AI
summary: Character.AI, a chatbot platform valued at $1 billion, has seen widespread adoption, with over 16 million custom chatbots created and 200 million monthly visits. The platform, which allows users to create their own chatbots impersonating anyone or anything, has become a popular conversation partner, with some chatbots receiving millions of messages. However, the company faces thorny questions about the future of AI tools, including potential legal issues surrounding the use of copyrighted characters and impersonators. Despite these concerns, Character.AI remains committed to its mission of providing personalized AI assistance to users, with plans to expand its services and revenue streams in the future.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed ChatGPT logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Alibaba's AI image generator, Tongyi Wanxiang, will compete with OpenAI’s DALL-E and Midjourney’s Midjourney
Larry Feinsmith (left), JP Morgan Chase’s head of global tech strategy, innovation and partnerships tells Databricks chief Ali Ghodsi about that the bank is working through the risks of AI.
ChatGPT set off a frenzied use of generative AI in daily tasks from writing to coding and reached 100 million monthly active users in January, two months after its launch.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on March 15, 2023 this photo illustration shows the ChatGPT logo at an office in Washington, DC. - Shares in companies that specialize in publishing school textbooks and offering online classes took a big hit on May 2, 2023 after signs emerged that AI-bots such as ChatGPT were eating into their business. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: Elon Musk sues Wachtell law firm to recoup fees from Twitter buyout
summary: Elon Musk has sued law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz to recoup $90 million in fees received from Twitter for its buyout. Musk claims Wachtell accepted "success" fees from departing Twitter executives, which he calls "unconscionable" given the firm's lower billing for its work on the Delaware lawsuit. Musk wants to recoup "excess" fees, citing an agreement signed by a Wachtell partner and Twitter's chief legal officer Vijaya Gadde on the day of the buyout's closing.

images.alt_text: Meta, which launched Threads on Wednesday and has logged more than 30 million sign ups, looks to take on Elon Musk’s Twitter by taking advantage of Instagram’s billions of users.
Threads’ arrival comes after Zuckerberg and Musk have traded barbs for months and even threatened to fight each other in a real-life mixed martial arts cage match in Las Vegas.
The limit took effect soon after Twitter began requiring users to log into an account on the social media platform to view tweets.

site_title: Hedge fund Dymon hires Yu from Goldman, aims to raise US$1 billion
summary: Singapore hedge fund Dymon Asia Capital has hired 24 portfolio managers, including Goldman Sachs' Jaewon Yu, to boost its US$1 billion fundraising goal. The company aims to increase its assets to US$3 billion and expand its operations in Asia. Dymon's flagship multi-strategy fund has returned 3.3% this year, outperforming the Eurekahedge Asian Hedge Fund Index. The new hires are part of Dymon's diversification strategy, which focuses on Asia and includes investments in Japan and India.

images.alt_text: The closing date for Penguin's privatisation offer has been extended by another two weeks to Jul 20.
Allen House, one of Hwa Hong's properties in London; Hwa Hong on Feb 1 filed a legal action against Evercore and four former Hwa Hong directors.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz picks Tesla’s charging standard for North America EVs from 2025
summary: Mercedes-Benz has agreed to adopt Tesla's North American Charging Standard (NACS) for its electric vehicles in North America starting from 2025. This makes the German automaker the first German brand to join American rivals Ford and General Motors in adopting the charging standard. Mercedes-Benz will also gain access to over 12,000 Tesla Superchargers and initially offer an adaptor for its existing EVs to charge on the NACS network. The move aims to expand the network of fast-chargers and make owning EVs easier for customers.

images.alt_text: Mercedes says ChatGPT would make its car system’s answers sound more natural and would let drivers ask for destination information or address other queries, like what to cook for dinner.
The luxury-car maker, which has been focusing on selling more of its higher-end cars, expects automaking margins at the upper end of its forecast range, it said on Friday (Apr 28).
Kentucky is the first state to mandate Tesla’s charging technology.
Ford, General Motors and ChargePoint are among the companies that have signed up for Tesla’s charging design in the past few weeks.
Customers of Rivian, which has its own small network of fast chargers, will be able to access 12,000 Tesla Superchargers with adaptors in the US and Canada as early as spring 2024.
Shares of Tesla were up 4 per cent at the close of regular trading in New York on Friday.

site_title: US: Stocks dip after mixed jobs data
summary: US stocks declined on Friday following mixed jobs data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.3% lower. The US economy added 209,000 jobs last month, fewer than expected, but the unemployment rate edged closer to historic lows at 3.6%. Strong wage growth kept the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates to combat inflation, despite the less-than-stellar jobs figures.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 29, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Ant's share repurchase plan values firm around US$79 billion, down sharply before crackdown
summary: Ant Group, a fintech giant founded by billionaire Jack Ma, announced a share repurchase plan valued at approximately $106 billion, down sharply from its peak of over $300 billion. The plan aims to replenish staff incentives and provide liquidity for investors following a regulatory overhaul. China's central bank fined Ant and its subsidiaries 7.1 billion yuan, paving the way for the company to secure a financial holding company license and revive its plans for a stock market listing.

images.alt_text: Ant’s fine would be the largest regulatory penalty imposed on a Chinese Internet company since ride-hailing major Didi Global was fined US$1.2 billion by China’s cybersecurity regulator last year.
Ant is waiting for a financial holding company licence, more than two years after authorities torpedoed its planned initial public offering.
Ant is racing against companies including its affiliate Alibaba Group Holding, Baidu and SenseTime Group.
Tencent, operator of the popular chat app WeChat and payment network WeChat Pay, says that WeChat users overseas can link credit cards issued by Visa to their WeChat app from next month.

site_title: Prominent economist Lim Chong Yah dies, aged 91
summary: Prominent economist Lim Chong Yah, 91, died on Saturday morning. He led a body forging wage consensus for Singaporean workers for nearly three decades. Born in Malacca, Lim studied economics at the University of Malaya and later joined the Singapore administrative service. His work had a significant impact on the country's labor market.

images.alt_text: Professor Lim Chong Yah was an eminent economist who led a body forging wage consensus for Singaporean workers for nearly three decades.

site_title: SBF’s new chief on a mission to make sure companies are future-ready
summary: Kok Ping Soon, the new CEO of the Singapore Business Federation (SBF), emphasizes the need for businesses to transform quickly to capitalize on opportunities in digitalization and the green economy. Despite uncertainty in the near term, there is quiet confidence about optimism for the future, driven by strong economic fundamentals and growth potential in Southeast Asia, particularly in countries like Vietnam, Malaysia, and Indonesia. SBF aims to scale its impact to benefit more members, positioning itself as a key player in shaping policies and fostering capabilities for companies to be future-ready.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cars and motorbikes ride in an avenue decorated to welcome the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam in Hanoi, Vietnam, January 25, 2021. REUTERS/Thanh Hue/File Photo

Kok Ping Soon will take on the role of SBF CEO-designate from Apr 1 and concurrently serve as the chief executive of the Government Technology Agency (GovTech). Come Jun 1, he will become SBF’s new CEO and step down from GovTech.
Singapore's Second Trade and Industry Minister Tan See Leng, who is on a three-day official visit to Vietnam, spoke at the opening of the Singapore Regional Business Forum in Hanoi.

site_title: Circles.Life co-founder steps back after months of tumult
summary: Circles.Life co-founder Abhishek Gupta is stepping down from the company's management team and taking on a non-executive role. Gupta, who helped build the digital telecom provider over seven years, will remain a co-founder but no longer oversee the business-facing arm Circles X. The move is part of a staffing overhaul aimed at reducing costs, following years of attempts to disrupt Singapore's incumbent services. A new project, "Brave New World," aims to turn the company around in 180 days under new CEO Rameez Ansar.

images.alt_text: Circles.Life ramps up hiring in Singapore as it expands its B2B offering for telcos

site_title: UK set to ease stock market listing rules
summary: The UK is set to ease stock market listing rules, with Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt announcing new measures to heighten the appeal of British markets to firms seeking to float. The "Mansion House Reforms" will simplify rules, improve research facilities, and deliver higher returns for investors. The reforms also aim to roll back a European Union-era securities law and introduce a new "Research Platform" for firms. The plans are expected to be approved, paving the way for potentially removing unbundling rules.

images.alt_text: The FCA has says it will report back on whether it thinks the savings market is functioning by the end of this month.

The entrance to the headquarters of Thames Water in Reading, UK, on Monday, July 3, 2023. The bonds of the UK's biggest water provider climbed on Monday as investors bet a selloff driven by fears the utility would be nationalized had gone too far. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
Inflation in the UK has defied the BOE’s efforts to rein in prices, prompting the central bank to unexpectedly raise interest rates by half a percentage point last week.

site_title: Gold rises as dollar, yields slip after US jobs data
summary: US gold futures rose 0.9% to US$1,932.50 after weaker-than-expected US nonfarm payrolls numbers raised doubts over interest rate hikes, causing the dollar and bond yields to fall. This led to a 0.8% gain in spot gold to US$1,926.54 per ounce. The first weekly gain in four months was on track.

images.alt_text: The dollar index was steady near a two-week high hit on Friday, making gold expensive for holders of other currencies.
Gold is highly sensitive to rising US interest rates, as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: US SEC to vote on 'swing pricing,' liquidity fund reporting
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) will vote on two proposals to enhance the resiliency of money market funds and large liquidity funds. The proposals include a "swing pricing" rule to discourage hasty withdrawals during times of stress and increased disclosures from large liquidity fund advisors. The SEC will also consider a change to reserve deposit requirements for broker-dealers, potentially requiring daily calculations rather than weekly ones. These measures aim to control systemic risk in the money market and large liquidity fund sectors, which together hold trillions of dollars in investor assets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission logo and representations of cryptocurrency are seen in this illustration taken June 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Petrobras expects to fall short of government gas-price target
summary: Brazil's state oil giant Petrobras is expected to fall short of the government's goal to slash natural-gas prices by 40% due to high extraction costs in ultra-deep waters. Petrobras faces higher production costs compared to onshore shale gas drillers abroad, making a price cut of that magnitude unfeasible. The company argues that using gas to increase well pressure boosts oil production, but this approach could lower the price to $7-8 per MMBtu from the current $12. The government is under pressure to tame energy prices as President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva steers the economy in a more populist direction.

site_title: US to give Ukraine cluster munitions in US$800 million aid package
summary: The US announced an $800 million aid package to Ukraine, which includes cluster munitions prohibited by over 100 countries. The decision was made to boost Ukraine's counteroffensive to reclaim seized territory, with US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan citing the risk of civilian harm if Russian troops roll over Ukrainian positions. Ukraine has provided assurances to use the cluster munitions carefully, and the package also includes additional artillery, air defenses, and anti-tank weapons. The move has been met with opposition from human rights groups and some US allies, including Germany.

images.alt_text: The American and Ukrainian flags wave next to each during an Independence Day parade in Washington D.C., U.S., July 4, 2023.  REUTERS/Kevin Wurm

site_title: Fans from Philippines are top buyers of Klook’s sold-out Taylor Swift concert packages
summary: Fans from the Philippines topped the list of buyers for Klook's sold-out Taylor Swift concert packages, with the most expensive tickets and hotel stays selling out in just two hours. The packages, released on Friday, featured over 40 hotels and 12 ticket categories, with prices ranging from S$542 to S$4,977. Singapore, Indonesia, and China followed as top-buying countries, with Malaysia rounding out the top five. Klook sold over 600,000 experience packages, with fans willing to spend more than S$1,700.

images.alt_text: Fans wait in line outside Nissan Stadium ahead of artiste Taylor Swift's second night of performance on May 6, 2023 in Nashville, Tennessee.
American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift.

(FILES) US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performs onstage on the first night of her "Eras Tour" at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on March 31, 2023. Music megastars Taylor Swift and The Weeknd are among showbiz people invited to join the organization that votes on who gets Oscars, the body said on June 28.
Other invitees include Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, who directed "Everything Everywhere All at Once," which won seven Oscars this year including the prize for best picture.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its new crop of members of Tinseltown's most elite club numbers 398 people. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

site_title: US has destroyed all its chemical weapons: Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden announced that the country has fully destroyed its decades-old stockpiles of chemical weapons, fulfilling a commitment under the Chemical Weapons Convention. The US was the last signatory to complete this task, which involved eliminating 500 tonnes of lethal chemical agents. The destruction marks the first time an international body has verified the elimination of an entire category of declared weapons of mass destruction. The US had held stores of artillery projectiles and rockets containing mustard gases, VX, sarin nerve agents, and blister agents, which were condemned after their use in World War I.

images.alt_text: “The (Defense) Department is proactively taking steps using Defense Production Act Title III authorities to increase domestic mining and processing of critical materials for the microelectronics and space supply chain, including gallium and germanium,” the Pentagon spokesperson says.
The upcoming Nato summit on July 11-12 takes place against a backdrop of a redrawn security landscape across Europe.

site_title: Winklevoss twins’ Gemini sues crypto conglomerate DCG, citing fraud
summary: Gemini Trust Co, founded by Winklevoss twins, filed a lawsuit against Digital Currency Group (DCG) and CEO Barry Silbert, alleging "fraud and deception" over a failed lending venture. The lawsuit stems from a months-long public dispute over hundreds of millions of dollars in frozen funds related to Genesis Global Holdco, a now-bankrupt DCG subsidiary. Gemini claims DCG deceived them, trapping Earn users' funds after Genesis froze withdrawals following FTX's collapse.

images.alt_text: The Winklevoss twins shot to fame after they sued Meta Platforms founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg, alleging he had stolen their idea for Facebook.
Beijing clamped down on crypto over concerns about money laundering, the environmental impact of Bitcoin mining and currency outflows.
The Securities and Exchange Commission is suing Gemini as regulators crack down on the industry.

site_title: Oil prices up 3% to nine-week high on supply concerns
summary: Oil prices surged 3% to a nine-week high on Friday, reaching $78.47 a barrel for Brent and $73.86 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude. Supply concerns and technical buying outweighed fears of slowing economic growth and reduced demand, driven by fresh output cuts from Saudi Arabia and Russia. Analysts expect tighter market conditions and supply deficits in the second half of 2023, supporting higher oil prices.

images.alt_text: Top oil exporters Saudi Arabia and Russia announced a fresh round of output cuts for August.

Russian crude oil tanker ship Clyde Noble is seen berthed at the Karachi Port, Pakistan, June 28, 2023. Pakistan received its second cargo of discounted Russian crude oil as part of a new deal between Islamabad and Moscow.
US crude stocks fell by about 4.4 million barrels last week, while petrol and distillate inventories rose, according to market sources citing American Petroleum Institute figures.

site_title: Apex court finds WP’s Sylvia Lim, Low Thia Khiang liable for control failures in AHTC, but not Pritam
summary: The Singapore Court of Appeal has found Workers' Party (WP) chairman Sylvia Lim and former party chief Low Thia Khiang liable for control failures in the Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) payments process that led to S$33.7 million improper payments between 2011 and 2015. However, WP leader Pritam Singh cannot be held liable as he was not given the chance to defend himself against this claim. The court ruled that Lim and Low allowed control failures in the payments process, but the three WP leaders were found not liable for damages in the setting up of payment processes.

site_title: Quant screening: 3 questions for investment managers
summary: Investment managers can be evaluated using a simple filter of three questions. Asset owners should ask: 1) What are the drivers of their investment process, and can they be defended on conceptual grounds? 2) What evidence is there that their process will be effective, and have they published their research in peer-reviewed journals? 3) What risk controls are part of their investment process, and can they ensure focused exposure to their intended factors? If a manager cannot provide satisfactory answers, their process may have fundamental flaws, making them unsuitable for further vetting.

images.alt_text: In today's AI-fuelled world, human financial advisers and analysts can still prevail in investment analysis or portfolio construction, if they offer authenticity, originality, and more than the conventional wisdom.
CFA Institute requires fund managers and investment professionals to exercise diligence, independence and thoroughness in analysing and recommending investments, and taking investment actions.
Can fund managers spot winners in the digital age?

site_title: US job growth slows in June; unemployment rate falls to 3.6%
summary: US job growth slowed in June, with 209,000 new jobs added, below expectations. The unemployment rate fell to 3.6% from 3.7% in May. Average hourly earnings rose 0.4% for the second consecutive month, with annual wage growth at 4.4%. Despite slowing job growth, the labor market remains tight, and the Federal Reserve's rate hikes since March 2022 are helping the economy defy recession predictions.

images.alt_text: The US labour market has remained resilient despite 500 basis points worth of interest rate hikes from the Fed since March 2022.

site_title: Restaurant chain Cava faces Wall Street review after hot debut
summary: Cava Group, a fast-casual restaurant chain, delivered a strong trading debut with a 99% surge in its first day of trading, raising $318 million. The company's valuation stands at $4.6 billion, but sell-side analysts, including New Constructs' David Trainer, question its valuation, citing "terribly overpriced" stock and lower-than-expected restaurant-level margins. Analysts also note the crowded restaurant space and intense competition, leading to concerns about the company's long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: Cava sold about 14.4 million shares in the offering, raising US$318 million.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher after worst week in nearly four months
summary: European shares ended higher on Friday, July 7, after data showed the US economy added the fewest jobs in 2-1/2 years in June, easing concerns about interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. However, persistently strong US wage growth pointed to a tight labor market, leading traders to bet on a 5.25-5.5% interest rate hike this month. The Stoxx 600 index fell 3.1% for the week, its worst performance since mid-March, with the chemicals sector leading gains and defensive real estate being the sole gainer.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index deepened losses by the close to fall 2.3 per cent to its lowest level since late March, while the EURO Stoxx 50 index plunged 2.9 per cent.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after payrolls report
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday after data showed US job growth slowed more than expected in June, but labor market conditions remain tight. The S&P 500 fell 0.16% to 4,404.54, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.08% to 13,668.07. Despite this, the labor market conditions remain strong, with the unemployment rate retreating from a seven-month high and wage gains continuing.

site_title: Uefa relax multi-club ownership rules, allow Milan and Villa to compete in Europe
summary: UEFA has relaxed its rules on multi-club ownership, allowing teams such as AC Milan and Aston Villa to compete in European competitions for the 2023-24 season. The clubs had faced proceedings due to potential conflicts with the rule, which prohibits a club from holding shares in or dealing in securities of another club in UEFA competitions. UEFA's Club Financial Control Body (CFCB) found significant changes implemented by the clubs and their investors brought them into compliance with the rule, allowing them to compete in next season's competitions.

site_title: From Ronaldo to Benzema, Saudi Arabia’s megabucks lure football’s superstars
summary: Saudi Arabia's professional league is attracting top football players with lucrative contracts, with several high-profile stars, including Cristiano Ronaldo, Karim Benzema, and Roberto Firmino, signing with clubs Al-Nassr, Al-Ittihad, and Al-Ahli. The league's plans to privatize its largest clubs aim to boost revenue and attract the best players, with more superstars expected to join the league ahead of the new season in August. The influx of top talent has raised hopes for Saudi Arabia's national team, which shocked Argentina in the World Cup last November.

images.alt_text: Chinese golfer Yin Ruoning kisses the trophy after winning the KPMG Women's PGA Championship in New Jersey on June 25, 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong raises maximum mortgage available for homes valued up to HK$30 million
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has raised the maximum mortgage available for homes valued up to HK$30 million, allowing self-use homebuyers to borrow up to 70% on properties worth HK$15 million and 60% on those worth HK$15-30 million. This is the first relaxation of tightening measures since 2009, aiming to help residents buy or upgrade homes as prices have corrected 13% since their peak in 2021.

images.alt_text: Steep discounts offered by property developers on new launches have also added pressure on prices, especially in the secondhand market.
The sleek, modern building is the work of German architect Ulrich Kirchhoff, 52, who told AFP he tried to blend elements of nature into a high-density space to create a “neighbourhood village feel”.
Beijing is considering a broad package of stimulus measures as pressure builds on the government to boost the economy.

The government is working with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and will carefully deliberate between balancing financial stability and interests of first-time homeowners, says Financial Secretary Paul Chan.

site_title: Tesla rolls out global customer referral incentive as EV price war heats up
summary: Tesla rolled out a global customer referral incentive program, dubbed "Refer and Earn," in its largest markets, including the US, China, Germany, France, Canada, Mexico, Hong Kong, and Singapore. The program offers cashback incentives equivalent to about $500 for buyers purchasing Model 3 and Model Y, plus three months of Full Self-Driving feature in the US. This move is part of the company's strategy to boost sales amid an electric-vehicle price war.

images.alt_text: “Next week, Elon Musk asked to discuss with me the possibility and his commitment to increase his investments in Malaysia,” Anwar said in a speech during an event with civil servants.
Deliveries from Tesla’s Shanghai plant rise almost 20 per cent from a year earlier in June to 93,680 vehicles
Tesla’s sales of cars produced in Shanghai in the second quarter accounted for over half of its global deliveries.
Around 20,000 staff are employed at Tesla’s Shanghai factory, which has the capacity to churn out about 1 million cars a year.

site_title: Does it take empty shelves to get us to care about supply chains?
summary: Singapore's supply chain is finally back in full swing, with the recent Covid-19 cases not causing disruptions to mask supplies. However, the pandemic highlighted the vulnerability of supply chains to unprecedented events. To future-proof supply chains, concerted action from both the public and private sectors is needed. The Singapore government is investing in infrastructure and policies to support more resilient supply chains, while businesses are developing digital tools to introduce new solutions and leverage emerging technologies. Consumers are also driving change, with nearly half of Singaporean consumers willing to choose not to repurchase from a brand with unethical suppliers, forcing businesses to re-evaluate their supply chain strategies.

images.alt_text: Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong (centre) attended the IPEF ministerial meeting in Detroit on May 26 and May 27, 2023.

South Korea has pledged cooperation with other key regional players including Japan, India, France, Canada and the Netherlands to facilitate a stable supply chain.

site_title: AI4Bharat researchers to raise US$12 million from Peak XV, Lightspeed for own firm, sources say
summary: Researchers from India's AI4Bharat, backed by the Indian government, are raising US$12 million from venture capital firms Peak XV and Lightspeed Venture to launch a new venture called Sarvam, which will develop custom-made large language models for India-centric use-cases. This larger-than-usual seed funding round underscores the growing interest in generative AI, following the success of OpenAI's ChatGPT. The investment will support the development of custom-made language models for India, highlighting the increasing demand for AI solutions in the country.

images.alt_text: A market frenzy for all things AI-related has supercharged Microsoft shares this year.
FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed ChatGPT logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China weighs more local bond sales to help pay risky hidden debt
summary: China is considering plans to allow local bond issuance to help pay down hidden debt at local-government financing vehicles (LGFVs), which control US$9 trillion of debt. Provincial governments would tap unused bond quotas to support cash-strapped cities and counties. The proposal, subject to change, aims to address financial concerns and could utilize over 1 trillion yuan (S$187 billion) of unused quotas. Authorities have begun inspections to press local officials to disclose hidden debts, amid economic woes and plans to unveil financing policies for needed projects.

site_title: Ultra-wealthy continue to prop up Dubai’s luxury property market
summary: Dubai's luxury residential market continued its strong performance in the first half of the year, with 176 homes worth at least $10 million sold, according to Knight Frank. The city surpassed Hong Kong and New York as the world's busiest market for properties over $10 million, with transactions worth $3.1 billion recorded. The luxury market remains attractive to global high-net-worth individuals, with Dubai emerging as the top destination for second-home purchases.

images.alt_text: Dubai’s market has surged amid an influx of foreign wealth.

site_title: India’s Vedanta to take over Foxconn chip JV from holding company
summary: Vedanta, India's metals-to-oil conglomerate, will take over a joint venture with Taiwan's Foxconn to make semiconductors, previously set up with a US$19.5 billion investment. Vedanta also will acquire a display glass manufacturing venture from Volcan Investments, its holding company. The project, initially set to be led by Volcan, has been delayed due to stalled talks with STMicroelectronics. Vedanta faces penalties from India's marker regulator for initially making it appear it partnered with Foxconn, despite later clarifying Volcan would lead the project.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bird flies by the Vedanta office building in Mumbai August 16, 2010. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam eyes new free trade agreements to spur economic growth: deputy minister
summary: Vietnam aims to pursue and sign more free trade agreements (FTAs) to spur economic growth, with Deputy Minister of Industry and Trade Nguyen Sinh Nhat Tan stating that the country has established FTAs with most of the world's largest economies. Vietnam currently has 18 bilateral and multilateral FTAs, with 15 in force, and has sought opportunities to establish more FTAs with countries like Singapore, which has 27 FTAs. The country's goal is to deepen trade and investment, and strengthen economic integration with the region and globally.

images.alt_text: epa10723850 A general view of the city of Hanoi, Vietnam, 03 July 2023. Vietnam manufacturing sector PMI rose to 46.2 points in June, up from 45.3 points in May 2023, according to latest survey from S&P Global.  EPA-EFE/LUONG THAI LINH
"We are looking to scale the impact of our work, so that more of our members can benefit from the things we do," says SBF's new CEO Kok Ping Soon.
Singapore's Second Trade and Industry Minister Tan See Leng, who is on a three-day official visit to Vietnam, spoke at the opening of the Singapore Regional Business Forum in Hanoi.
VinFast had said in May that it will list in the US by merging with SPAC company Black Spade in the second half of this year.

site_title: US dollar slips after job growth slows in June
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.64% to 102.410 after data showed the US economy added the fewest jobs in 2-1/2 years in June, with 110,000 fewer jobs created in April and May than initially reported. Despite strong wage growth, the job market remains resilient, suggesting the Federal Reserve will likely resume hiking interest rates later this month.

images.alt_text: NOVATO, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 07: A customer walks by a now hiring sign posted in front of a Ross Dress For Less store on April 07, 2023 in Novato, California. The U.S. labor market added 236,000 jobs in March bringing the national unemployment rate down to 3.5 percent. (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Singapore, regional equities follow Wall Street lower; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 3,139.47 on Friday, tracking lower US stock market performance after stronger-than-expected economic data, including US jobs and services purchasing managers' index. Regional markets also declined, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi down 1.2%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.9%. DFI Retail Group was the largest gainer, while CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and the trio of banks fell.

images.alt_text: LEMONT, ILLINOIS - JUNE 21: A home is constructed at a housing development on June 21, 2023 in Lemont, Illinois. US housing starts climbed more than 20% last month which has helped lumber futures climb nearly 9% over the same period. According to the National Association of Home Builders, volatile prices of lumber products in recent years have caused the average price of a new single-family home to increase by more than $14,000.   Scott Olson/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SCOTT OLSON / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Christopher Nolan returns with latest blockbuster Oppenheimer
summary: Christopher Nolan's latest blockbuster film "Oppenheimer" is based on the 2005 biography "American Prometheus" by Kai Bird and Martin J Sherwin. The film, starring Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr, Emily Blunt, and Cillian Murphy, tells the story of J Robert Oppenheimer, the American theoretical physicist who oversaw the creation of the atomic bomb during World War II. Nolan's film aims to capture the dramatic and complex aspects of Oppenheimer's story, focusing on the humanity and emotion behind the character.

site_title: Collapse of Putin’s regime would cause commodity price spike, hampering inflation control efforts
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's regime collapse could lead to a commodity price spike, hindering inflation control efforts. The collapse, potentially triggered by a peaceful transition or an ousted Putin, could result in a civil war, paralyzing oil production and driving up prices. Oil futures may reach $150 a barrel, exacerbating inflation expectations. A peaceful transition, however, could lead to a short-lived oil price spike and a more stable global economy. The outcome depends on the manner of Putin's fall, with a 50-50 chance of an abrupt collapse, according to strategist Kent Engelke.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Russian President Vladimir Putin and Belarus' President Alexander Lukashenko at the Victory Day military parade in Moscow on May 9, 2023. The weekend mutiny in Russia ended after Lukashenko negotiated a truce with Yevgeny Prigozhin; the Wagner leader stood down his troops and left in exile to Belarus.
State TV showed Putin meeting top security officials and military officers in the Kremlin, sternly thanking them for their support.

FILE PHOTO: Founder of Wagner private mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin leaves a cemetery before the funeral of a Russian military blogger who was killed in a bomb attack in a St Petersburg cafe, in Moscow, Russia, April 8, 2023. REUTERS/Yulia Morozova//File Photo

site_title: Omega raises luxury watch prices as other swatch brands struggle
summary: Omega, a Swiss luxury watch brand, raised prices by 2% in Switzerland and China, and 8% in the US, its largest export market. The price hikes, attributed to weakness rather than strength, may hurt sales volumes and weigh on top brand Omega's sales. The Swatch Group, which owns Omega, relies heavily on the brand's cash flow, with Omega accounting for 60% of its operating profit. The move could pressure Omega's sales growth, especially with recent demand showing signs of weakness in the US market.

The real Rolex Submariner (right) compared to a  counterfeit (left).

The Omega Speedmaster with ‘Broad Arrow’ hands from 1957 featured on the Phillips website.

site_title: Japanese PM heads to Nato to warn of East Asia risks
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is set to attend the NATO summit in Lithuania on July 11, where he will warn of East Asian risks and remind the alliance of Chinese and Russian activity in the region. Japan is seeking new security partners amid a growing reliance on the US, doubling defense spending to deter Chinese and Russian forces. Kishida aims to deepen cooperation on cyber security, space, and information sharing with NATO, but a Tokyo office is unlikely due to French President Emmanuel Macron's opposition.

images.alt_text: There is an increased opportunity for the EU and Japan to make a much bigger global impact, across wide-ranging issues, amid a fast-changing global geopolitical and economic landscape.

site_title: Yellen says US-China rivalry not ‘winner-take-all’ situation
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that competition between the US and China is not a "winner-take-all" situation, urging both countries to manage their rivalry with fair rules. During a meeting with Chinese Premier Li Qiang, Yellen emphasized the need for targeted national security actions and encouraged dialogue on global challenges. The visit aims to find common ground between the two superpowers, amid a trade war and tensions over Taiwan's security. Yellen reiterated that the US seeks to diversify, not decouple, from China, and that a decoupling would be destabilizing for the global economy.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and US Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns meet with representatives of the US business community in China. She said a decoupling of the US and Chinese economies would be “virtually impossible” and would destabilise global markets.

site_title: Singapore’s first electric pickup truck to debut in Q4 2023
summary: Singapore's first fully-electric pickup truck, the Maxus T90, will debut in Q4 2023 through authorized dealer Jardine Cycle & Carriage. The truck has a claimed range of around 330 km, powered by a 150 kW electric motor and 88.5 kWh battery pack. Pricing has not been officially announced, but it may qualify for the maximum S$15,000 Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme rebate. The T90 will be offered as a double-cab version with seating for five people and a maximum payload of a tonne.

images.alt_text: Kim Hock Corporation has trialled wheel loaders for a month and received good responses from its operators.

Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD and its Dolphin compact hatchback on display at Waterway Point. BYD's most compact car to date, the Dolphin is one of the cheapest EV on the Singapore market.

site_title: China's Alibaba unveils AI image generator to take on Midjourney and DALL-E
summary: Alibaba has unveiled an AI image generator, Tongyi Wanxiang, to compete with OpenAI's DALL-E and Midjourney. The image generator, available in beta form to enterprise customers, aims to tap into the fast-growing AI sector. This move follows similar efforts by Chinese tech companies Baidu and SenseTime Group, and comes as generative AI is expected to add $7.3 trillion in value to the world economy each year, according to McKinsey estimates.

images.alt_text: Sea will offer the highest growth of 27%, as compared to Amazon’s 21% and Alibaba’s 8%.
Alibaba’s digital media and entertainment business narrows its losses in the first quarter, thanks to Youku’s investment in content and production capability.
Joseph Tsai, 59, will replace Daniel Zhang as chairman of the board.

“What we will focus more for the future is to build local businesses, so you will see something called TMall which we have in China become TMall in Europe, which means we will serve local brands and local customers in local markets,” says J Michael Evans, president of Alibaba Group.

site_title: Talent gaps, market hurdles blot Singapore’s move up startup ecosystems ranking
summary: Singapore has jumped 10 spots to rank eighth globally in startup ecosystems, driven by large exits and strong investor activity. The country has had four startup exits valued at over US$1 billion, including Grab's US$40 billion IPO. However, Singapore faces challenges, including a shortage of life-sciences talent and a limited market reach. The city-state's small population of 5.6 million people hinders its ability to commercialize deep technologies, and it relies on its robust regulatory landscape and venture firms to support startups.

images.alt_text: Grab, Sea and more: How Singapore forged a startup ecosystem
South-east Asia could benefit from investor's caution towards China, driving more funds to the region.
Grab's hyper localised approach inspired Benjamin Lee, co-founder of Sealed Network to start a South-east Asia focused expert network.
The closure of one of Singapore’s most promising biotech companies raises larger implications for the city-state’s emerging ecosystem.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB initiates Astra International with ‘add’
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Astra International with an "add" call and a target price of 7,925 rupiah, citing expected higher market share and net profit growth for the automotive conglomerate in Indonesia. The analysts estimate Astra's car market share to rise to 57% in FY2023, driven by aggressive sales from Toyota and Daihatsu, and strong motorcycle sales growth of 25%. The group's overall bottom line is projected to be boosted by the automotive and financing businesses, driving Astra's return to net profit growth by FY2025.

Carro CEO Aaron Tan (left) will join the board of Republic Auto, while Jardine C&C managing director of direct motor interests Wilfrid Foo (right) will join the board of Carro.

site_title: Philippines writes off US$1 billion in farmer debt to boost food production
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos has signed a law writing off $1.04 billion in land-related debt owed by over 610,000 farmers. The debt, issued by government banks, was accumulated by farmers who received land on 30-year payment terms under a 1988 land reform program but were unable to pay. The write-off aims to boost food production and alleviate economic pressure on the country, which has struggled with shortages and soaring prices of farm commodities. The move will cost the government $1.04 billion, but Marcos says it is necessary to "feed our people."

images.alt_text: The cost of onions in the Philippines surged from around pesos 70 pesos (S$1.69) per kg in April last year to as much as 700 pesos in December, making them more expensive than meat.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar to meet Elon Musk to discuss investments
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced plans to meet with Elon Musk to discuss Tesla's investments in the country. Musk had previously expressed interest in increasing his investments in Malaysia, following the country's approval of Tesla's application to import battery-run electric vehicles. The meeting, set to take place next week, comes after Anwar also met with Saudi Aramco to discuss increased investments in the state of Johor. Details of the meeting with Musk were not provided.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is focusing on the development of an electric vehicle ecosystem and aims to provide at least 10,000 public charging facilities by 2025.

site_title: Evergrande homeowners find delivered project seized: report
summary: A court in Guangdong's Zhuhai city seized a China Evergrande Group residential project's land nine months after it was completed, according to the National Business Daily. The seizure was made after a local bank sued the developer over a loan conflict. The land was later lifted on July 4. The case highlights the ongoing conflict between creditors and homeowners as debt-laden Evergrande faces over 1,000 lawsuits, with local governments and financial institutions rushing to seize assets following the developer's default in 2021.

site_title: Taiwan exports plunge at fastest pace in 14 years on demand woes
summary: Taiwan's exports plummeted 23.4% in June, the largest decline in 14 years, due to weak overseas demand for technological goods, including semiconductors. The country's trade balance was nearly $6 billion, and imports dropped 29.9% from the previous year. The decline is attributed to a stagnant global economy, inflation, and interest-rate hikes. This marks a significant concern for Taiwan's export-dependent economy, which is struggling to maintain growth amidst the slump in global demand.

images.alt_text: Authorities in Taiwan have pledged to fight high house prices.
Overseas orders to Taiwanese companies shrink 17.6 per cent last month from a year earlier to US$45.7 billion, says the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

site_title: Global maritime sector agrees deal on carbon-reduction target
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has agreed to cut greenhouse gas emissions from shipping by at least 20% by 2030 and 70% by 2040, aiming for 30% and 80% reductions respectively. This deal, described as "historic" by the IMO, falls short of the 50% reduction by 2030 and carbon neutrality by 2040 advocated by green campaigners. The agreement comes after a five-day meeting at the IMO's headquarters in London, attended by representatives from 100 countries, and is seen as a step towards reducing the shipping industry's significant impact on global emissions, which contribute to around 3% of global greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: There is significant value in calculating avoided emissions for as many companies as we can – not just to better understand the impact of our investments, but also to make meaningful decisions about how the energy transition will unfold.
Geoengineering techniques include directly removing CO2 emissions from the atmosphere.
Fossil fuels remain dominant at 82 per cent of consumption, despite a strong showing from renewables.
Currently, most large companies report how many tonnes of carbon they emit into the atmosphere each year, but the data is often not reliable.

site_title: Issue 56: MAS, GIC contemplate too-little-too-late future; S-E Asia’s vulnerable workers
summary: A "Too Little Too Late" (TLTL) climate scenario, characterized by ineffective policies and high transition and physical risks, is now considered the most plausible by GIC, based on its assessment. This scenario, which includes a delay in implementing climate policies, could lead to global warming reaching 2-3°C by 2100. The likelihood of TLTL has increased due to a "widening gap" between countries' words and deeds, with countries accelerating their commitments but lagging behind in actual policymaking. This scenario poses significant risks to Singapore's official foreign reserves and could impact investment and business decisions.

images.alt_text: The facade of the Monetary Authority of Singapore Building on May 30, 2023.
The Sustainability Reporting Advisory Committee has recommended that non-listed companies with an annual revenue of at least S$1 billion make mandatory climate-related disclosures from FY2027.
Most current workers will likely need to upskill, rather than completely retrain, to find a new job or remain in their current one.
Companies should ensure they have a robust and effective governance structure and compliance system, as well as clear guidelines when making statements open for public scrutiny.
The EU's plan aims to reduce the unnecessary use of water, fertilisers and energy to produce, process and preserve food that ends up in the trash.

site_title: Digital money needs to be bound to the real world
summary: Policymakers and regulators are concerned about linking digital assets to real economic value. The collapse of major crypto firms and notable scams have shown that cryptocurrencies are not reliable stores of value. To address this, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed a concept called "purpose-bound money" (PBM), which involves wrapping digital money with a protocol that specifies contractual arrangements before releasing it to a recipient. In contrast, "soulbound" tokens are non-transferable and create value only for their buyers. Both concepts aim to ensure preservation of economic value, but a broader perspective is needed to ensure digital assets contribute to national economic goals and protect citizens' interests.

images.alt_text: Some financial institutions and fintech firms in Singapore are launching purpose-bound money trials in online commerce and programmable rewards

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Second Trade and Industry Minister Tan See Leng emphasized the need for deeper bilateral cooperation between Singapore and Vietnam in areas like innovation, energy connectivity, and sustainability. During his three-day official visit to Vietnam, he highlighted opportunities for the two countries to work together to seize advantages of the next decade. This cooperation aims to strengthen economic ties between Singapore and Vietnam, promoting mutual growth and development.

site_title: Nikkei slumps for fourth straight session on Fed tightening concerns
summary: The Nikkei index fell 1.17% to 32,388.42 on Friday, marking its fourth consecutive decline, amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's tightening policies and strong US labor market data. Every sector in the Nikkei fell, with real estate leading the way down 1.97%. The broader Topix index also dropped 0.97%. Despite this, a strategist at Daiwa Securities expressed optimism for a "soft landing" and predicted the Nikkei could rebound to 35,000 by year-end.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei lost 0.47 per cent to 32,618.88 by the midday break. The index had fallen as much as 1.36 per cent early in the session.

site_title: China’s central bank boosts gold reserves for eighth month
summary: China's central bank, People's Bank of China (PBOC), has boosted its gold reserves for the eighth consecutive month, adding 680,000 troy ounces in June. The total stockpiles now stand at 2,330 tons, driven by economic and geopolitical risks, as well as a desire to move away from the US dollar. This is the eighth consecutive month of gold purchases, and around 183 tons have been added since November. The move is seen as a strategic effort to diversify its currency reserves and reduce dependence on the US dollar.

site_title: Tuition centre Zenith Learning Group raises US$1.4 million in seed round
summary: Zenith Learning Group, a tuition centre chain, has secured US$1.4 million in seed funding to expand into education technology. The funds will be used for research and development of edtech products and team growth. The investment was led by Trihill Capital, with participation from East Ventures and other investors. The startup aims to launch a hybrid learning programme for primary school children, including a gamified online education platform, and plans to become a more data-driven, hybrid learning service provider.

images.alt_text: NodeFlair is founded by Ethan Ang (left) and Adrian Goh.
From left: Kiyan Foroughi, Serene Gan, Rachelle Yee, Jeannie Nguyen

site_title: Australia inquiry says ex-PM Morrison misled Cabinet on debt recovery scheme
summary: A Royal Commission inquiry in Australia has found former Prime Minister Scott Morrison misled the Cabinet about a welfare debt recovery scheme, known as "robodebt." The program, which ran from 2015 to 2019, wrongly calculated debt for hundreds of thousands of Australians and recovered A$1.76 billion. The inquiry recommended unnamed individuals be referred for prosecution or civil action. Morrison rejected the findings, claiming they were "untrue" and contradicted by documentary evidence, but the report's findings were welcomed by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who described the scheme as a "gross betrayal and a human tragedy."

images.alt_text: Australia to spend US$920m to expand wage subsidy scheme for apprentices

site_title: Underlying price pressures finally easing in the eurozone
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) says underlying inflation pressures in the eurozone are easing, with most indicators showing signs of softening. ECB Vice President Luis de Guindos stated that while underlying price pressures remain strong, they are narrowing. The ECB has raised interest rates at every meeting over the past year, and while some policy makers advocate for a pause in rate hikes, hawks remain in favor of further tightening. The ECB's job is not yet done, and inflation remains high, with services inflation and labor costs to be closely monitored.

images.alt_text: The Galeries Lafayette shopping mall on Friedrichstrasse in Berlin, Germany, Germany, on Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2022. Germany has put together a 200 billion emergency aid package -- which has not yet been implemented -- with about half the money earmarked for energy-bill subsidies, according a proposal from the Independent Commission for Natural Gas and Heating last month. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
The downturn was broad-based, with surveys published on Monday (Jul 3) showing that factory activity in all four of the eurozone’s biggest economies contracted last month.

site_title: Shutting startups down: When to pull the plug?
summary: A significant number of startups are shutting down due to funding issues, with 90% of startups failing and 10% dropping out in the first year. Tessa Therapeutics, a biotech startup, ceased operations after failing to raise funding, citing high interest rates and decreased investor appetite. Founders like Dayana Yermolayeva of JiPay and Karl Mak of Televate struggled with making the decision to shut down, citing factors such as market timing, regulatory issues, and dwindling energy levels. Investors emphasize the importance of being communicative and open with founders, and acknowledge that accepting failure is a significant challenge in Asian culture. Ultimately, the decision to shut down a startup is the founder's, but it's essential to engage with the board and investors before making a public announcement.

images.alt_text: Stem cell biologists Ling Ka Yi (left) and Sandhya Sriram founded Shiok Meats in 2018 to develop lab-grown crustacean meat. The company is facing challenges in scaling up for commercialisation.
The closure of one of Singapore’s most promising biotech companies raises larger implications for the city-state’s emerging ecosystem.

site_title: Modi’s push to take Indian rupee global gets off to a slow start
summary: India's efforts to boost the global role of its rupee currency have made little progress, with total local currency trade volumes totaling around 10 billion rupees since the project began. Despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's aspirations for a bigger global heft for India, the country's capital controls and current account deficit hinder its ability to become a significant international currency. India's efforts to internationalize the rupee have drawn comparisons to China's attempts to do the same, but the rupee still lags behind in terms of global payments and forex turnover.

images.alt_text: india indian rupee Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: UK tells banks to do more to help savers access best rates
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has urged banks to accelerate efforts to make savings rates more accessible to customers. The FCA will report back by the end of this month on whether the savings market is functioning. The Consumer Duty, coming into force by the end of the month, requires lenders to treat customers fairly and meet competitive standards. Banks and building societies have made some improvements, but need to step up their efforts to meet the new regulations.

images.alt_text: Policymakers have delivered 13 successive rate increases since late 2021.
The decline is driven by a far steeper slump in the house building component, which slid to 39.6 from 42.7.

site_title: Apple plans a slow, appointment-only rollout of its US$3,500 Vision Pro
summary: Apple plans a slow, appointment-only rollout of its $3,500 Vision Pro headset in the US, initially in select major markets like New York and Los Angeles, before expanding nationwide. The company will set up special areas in its stores with seating, demo units, and tools to size accessories. The rollout will occur early next year, with international markets like the UK, Canada, and Asia to follow in 2024. The device will be sold at all 270 US locations, but the rollout will be phased to manage demand and ensure a smooth customer experience.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Apple's Vision Pro headset is on display at Apple's annual Worldwide Developers Conference at the company's headquarters in Cupertino, California, U.S. June 5, 2023. REUTERS/Loren Elliott/File Photo

site_title: China tightens scrutiny of Japanese food, citing safety reasons
summary: China will tighten its scrutiny of Japanese food imports, citing safety reasons, amid Tokyo's plan to discharge treated radioactive water from the Fukushima nuclear power plant into the sea. China will strengthen supervision and rigorously examine certificates for food imports, especially aquatic products, from non-banned prefectures. The move comes after China voiced strong opposition to the Japanese plan, citing threats to the environment and human health. Some Japanese officials worry that China may halt purchases of seafood exports.

images.alt_text: Despite existing curbs on some food products related to the 2011 Fukushima meltdown, Japan’s agricultural and seafood exports have risen, hitting a record high last year.

site_title: Uber, Facebook linked to PwC Australia tax schemes based on leaked government plans
summary: Uber and Facebook are linked to PwC Australia tax schemes based on leaked government plans, according to leaked emails. PwC advised both companies on restructuring to comply with Australia's Multinational Anti-Avoidance Law (Maal), which was set to start on January 1, 2016. Both companies expressed surprise over the firm's breaches of government confidentiality. Uber dropped PwC as a tax adviser in 2016 and restructured its tax affairs, while Facebook was one of the first multinationals to comply with the tax avoidance law.

images.alt_text: PwC has not publicly identified any client in relation to the scandal.
Three of the partners were singled out for actions that “failed to meet their professional responsibilities”.

site_title: On falling home prices and black-and-white houses
summary: The Singapore private home price index has eased 0.4% quarter-on-quarter in Q2 2023, driven by a 2.6% slide in non-landed private home prices in the city fringe. HDB resale flat volumes fell 4.6% year-on-year, while resale prices rose 1.4%. Developers are cautious about big sites due to high construction costs and interest rates. However, Leslie Yee argues that the Jurong Lake District site is worth consideration for major developers, potentially yielding rich rewards with its transport connectivity.

site_title: UK house prices post biggest annual drop since 2011: Halifax
summary: UK house prices dropped 2.6% in June, the largest annual decline since 2011, according to Halifax. This follows a 1.1% fall in May. Mortgage costs are expected to remain high, with forecasts predicting a peak in Bank of England interest rates of over 6%, leading to continued downward pressure on house prices over the coming year.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Mixed economic data the week’s main driver (Ep 50)
summary: Mixed economic data was the main driver of market movements this week. The data included a decline in inflation, a slowdown in economic growth, and a decrease in interest rates. These mixed signals affected various markets, including the US dollar, leading to a decline in its value. The US dollar's tumble was attributed to Trump's comments on tariffs.

images.alt_text: Broad markets consolidate in this shorter trading week.
Did the skittish week for markets extend to Singapore?

site_title: China ends Ant Group’s regulatory revamp with US$984 million fine
summary: China has fined Ant Group, a fintech firm, a total of $1.4 billion ($984 million for Ant Group and $416 million for Alipay) for regulatory breaches. The penalties are seen as a step towards Ant Group obtaining a financial holding company license, allowing it to secure growth and potentially revive its plans for a stock market debut. The move follows China's appointment of Pan Gongsheng as the central bank's party secretary, a precursor to his potential appointment as governor, and comes as Ant Group's CEO Ma returns to China after spending months overseas.

images.alt_text: There’s a slim chance an Ant listing would make it onto this year’s slate — global economic uncertainty and continuing US-China tensions shouldn’t be discounted.

site_title: Sweden housing prices edge higher amid signs of stabilisation
summary: Sweden's housing market has shown signs of stabilization, with private home prices rising 1% in June for a fifth consecutive month, according to realtor data. This marks a surprise as prices have withstood rising mortgage costs and inflation. Experts expect prices to decline by 20% from their peak in early 2022, but some, including the Riksbank, are more optimistic. Low transaction volumes and high housing costs have made it difficult for people to move, and the commercial property market is also facing challenges, with landlords struggling to refinance maturing debt.

images.alt_text: The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: US starts new round of audit inspections on China firms: source
summary: US inspectors have begun a new round of routine checks on Wall Street-listed Chinese companies' audits in Hong Kong, part of an agreement signed between the US and China last year. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) will inspect around a dozen Chinese firms, including Tencent Music Entertainment Group, Didi Global, and NetEase. The move follows a long-running dispute over auditing compliance of US-listed Chinese firms, with the US seeking full access to audits in mainland China and Hong Kong. The PCAOB had previously said it would demand complete access in 2023.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s four-day trip is her first to China as Treasury chief, and she is the second high-ranking US official to visit the country after Secretary of State Antony Blinken last month.
Earlier this week, China put export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables.

site_title: EMA to issue grants for energy storage system proposals
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) in Singapore is seeking proposals for energy storage system (ESS) solutions that are land-efficient, cost-effective, and safe for the country's tropical and urbanized climate. Successful applicants will receive a grant under the statutory board's second ESS grant call. EMA anticipates a 80% growth in the clean-energy workforce by 2032, with a focus on developing local capabilities, and projects a 13% increase in the power sector workforce over the same period.

images.alt_text: Night view of HDB flats, private houses and condominiums at Toa Payoh, 24 March 2023.

Back in the ‘heyday’ of Singapore’s OEM in 2019/20, residential consumers were spoilt for choice as frenzied competition among retailers eager to grow market share resulted in super competitive rates (BT File photo)
Starting from Jul 1, the island’s Energy Market Authority has imposed temporary caps on wholesale power prices to tamp down exceptional volatility.
The Specktronic Cruiser hydrogen fuel cell light commercial vehicle (LCV) will be trialed at the Jurong Innovation District from Q4 2023.
The renewables penetration in Asean has been driven by supportive regulation and tariff policies

site_title: After Spac merger, Vietnam’s VinFast plans third-quarter Nasdaq listing
summary: Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast plans to list its shares on the Nasdaq Global Select Market in the third quarter after merging with Spac Black Spade. The deal, expected to be completed by July 20, would give VinFast an equity value of approximately $23 billion. VinFast had previously considered a traditional initial public offering but opted for the merger due to challenging capital markets. The company's CEO stated that this decision was made to secure a listing in the US before the capital markets became "very challenging."

site_title: Amman Mineral makes firm debut in Indonesia’s biggest IPO this year
summary: Amman Mineral Internasional, Indonesia's second-largest copper and gold producer, made a successful debut in the country's biggest IPO this year, raising 10.7 trillion rupiah (S$957.5 million). The company's stock opened at 1,745 rupiah, 3.5% higher than its IPO price, before settling at 1,755 rupiah. Amman Mineral plans to use the funds to repay debt and fund projects, including a US$980 million copper smelter. The IPO was the largest since GoTo's US$1.1 billion listing in April 2022, and is seen as a positive sign for Indonesia's IPO market.

images.alt_text: Most of the proceeds to be used to expand Cinema XXI’s network while 20 per cent for early repayment of debt to Bank Rakyat Indonesia.
Tokyo’s debutants in 2023 are up an average of 75 per cent since their listings.

site_title: PepsiCo, Mars see business boom in Russia after staying behind
summary: PepsiCo, Mars, and Mondelez saw significant business growth in Russia, with sales rising 16%, 38%, and 14% respectively, and profits quadrupling and more than doubling. Despite restrictions on fund transfers and a windfall tax on profits, the companies reported strong sales, with Mondelez's sales reaching 92 billion roubles. The growth is attributed to the strength of the Russian consumer and the suspension of advertising, with companies citing a tight labor market and moderating inflation as supporting consumer demand.

images.alt_text: “China is getting better, but slowly,” PepsiCo chief financial officer Hugh Johnston says

site_title: Singapore, Vietnam can deepen ties in innovation, energy connectivity, sustainability: Tan See Leng
summary: Singaporean Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng emphasized the potential for deeper bilateral cooperation with Vietnam in innovation, energy connectivity, and sustainability. During a three-day visit, he highlighted the two countries' shared goals of driving economic growth through technology and innovation, as well as their common vision to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Tan also announced plans for joint implementation of carbon credit generating projects and the signing of 12 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) between Singaporean and Vietnamese businesses. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's official visit to Vietnam in August will celebrate 50 years of bilateral relations.

images.alt_text: “The State Bank of Vietnam has already adjusted the monetary policies but needs to make more effort,” Chinh said in a statement released after a government meeting.
The renewables penetration in Asean has been driven by supportive regulation and tariff policies
Vietnam’s exports in the second quarter fell 14.2 per cent from a year earlier due to weak global demand.
Samsung centre building is seen in Hanoi Vietnam May 29, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio

site_title: Yellen says 'impossible' to decouple China, US economies
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that a decoupling of the US and Chinese economies is "virtually impossible" and would destabilize global markets. During her four-day visit to Beijing, she emphasized the importance of maintaining economic ties between the two nations. Yellen's comments come as the US seeks to "de-risk" from China by limiting its access to advanced technology deemed crucial to national security. The visit highlights the ongoing efforts to strengthen economic cooperation between the two countries.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s four-day trip is her first to China as Treasury chief, and she is the second high-ranking US official to visit the country after Secretary of State Antony Blinken last month.

site_title: Goldman-backed ClinChoice considers Hong Kong IPO
summary: ClinChoice, a clinical trial services provider backed by Goldman Sachs, is considering a Hong Kong IPO, potentially valuing the business at $1 billion. The company, founded in 2007, provides research services to pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies globally. ClinChoice has recently grown through acquisitions, including the purchase of Cromsource, to boost its network and services in Europe and the US. The IPO preparations are being handled by China International Capital and Morgan Stanley, with a first-time share sale expected to raise a few hundred million dollars.

site_title: Lawrence Wong to replace Tharman as chairman of EDB’s International Advisory Council
summary: Deputy PM Lawrence Wong will replace Tharman Shanmugaratnam as chairman of the International Advisory Council of the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB), effective from July 8. Wong, also Minister for Finance, will chair the IAC's 21st meeting in November. This change comes as Wong takes on additional responsibilities, marking a shift in leadership for the council.

images.alt_text: In his big-picture speech, Mr Lawrence Wong said that it is not a given that the “Asian Century” will come to pass.

site_title: Tesla starts to lay off some battery workers at China factory
summary: Tesla is laying off some battery production workers at its Shanghai factory, with around 20,000 staff employed at the facility. The layoffs are reportedly due to a price war in China, with the company notifying employees on the cell assembly lines and offering them the option to transfer to other workshops. It's unclear how many battery workers will be let go, but some automation equipment is in the design and construction phase to potentially replace human labor. The move comes as Tesla delivers a record number of cars globally in the second quarter, despite a shrinking operating margin.

images.alt_text: Deliveries from Tesla’s Shanghai plant rise almost 20 per cent from a year earlier in June to 93,680 vehicles
Elon Musk has missed his own deadlines for a fully autonomous vehicle – and Tesla’s driver-assistance technology has provoked regulatory probes in the United States.

site_title: Tesla offers cash rebate on top models in China
summary: Tesla is offering a cash rebate of 3,500 yuan (S$654) to new buyers of its top-selling Model Y and Model 3 vehicles in China if they have a referral from an existing owner. The rebate is part of a price war in China's EV market, where Tesla has cut prices by 14% for the Model 3 and 10% for the Model Y since the start of the year. The move aims to deepen a truce with other EV makers, following a pledge by 15 companies, including Nio and Xpeng, to avoid "abnormal pricing".

images.alt_text: Around 20,000 staff are employed at Tesla’s Shanghai factory, which has the capacity to churn out about 1 million cars a year.
Deliveries from Tesla’s Shanghai plant rise almost 20 per cent from a year earlier in June to 93,680 vehicles

site_title: Bain to acquire Rainmaking Apac; doubles down on venture-building
summary: Bain & Company is acquiring Rainmaking Apac, the Asia-Pacific arm of venture-building studio Rainmaking, for an undisclosed amount. Rainmaking Apac will retain its brand and operate independently under Bain's innovation and design unit. The acquisition is part of Bain's efforts to ramp up venture-building, with the goal of growing the team in the coming years. Current clients will not be affected, and there will be no redundancies from the acquisition.

images.alt_text: Venture studios have built some notable companies, such as payment startup Ovo, which as since achieved unicorn status.

Representatives from the appointed venture studios – BCG Digital Ventures; FutureLabs Ventures; Leap by McKinsey; Next by Bain & Company; Rainmaking; and Wright Partners (in partnership with Ming Labs), along with EDB managing director  Jacqueline Poh and executive vice-president Choo Heng Tong at the MOU signing of the Corporate Venture Launchpad 2.0 programme on July 26, 2022.

site_title: UBS wealth chief Khan pushes ‘net new money’ mantra in Asia tour
summary: UBS wealth chief Iqbal Khan is on an Asia tour, rallying staff to focus on "net new money" as the company targets the region for growth following its takeover of Credit Suisse. The message was clear in both Hong Kong and Singapore events, where Khan emphasized the importance of attracting new assets. UBS plans to retain hundreds of Credit Suisse private bankers, bringing its total to over 1,200 in the Asia-Pacific region. The company aims to generate lucrative fees despite Credit Suisse's asset outflows in other regions.

images.alt_text: Switzerland’s biggest bank will return to India, with Puneet Matta, another former Credit Suisse executive, being tapped to leading its wealth management business there.

UBS is focused on the transfer of wealth between baby boomers to their heirs in the coming years. About US$18 trillion will be passed to younger generations in the US over the next seven years, and as much as US$84 trillion over the next two decades.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall further as US data fans rate fears
summary: Asian markets fell further on Friday, July 7, as the US data reinforced expectations of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes amid stubbornly high inflation. Minutes from the Fed's last meeting showed officials plan to increase borrowing costs again this month, while Chinese figures confirmed the world's second-largest economy had run out of steam. US private firms created twice as many jobs as expected in June, solidifying bets on a July hike. Treasuries yields spiked, with two-year notes below 5% and 10-year bonds passing 4%, signaling a looming recession.

images.alt_text: While growth remains healthy for now, the prospect of even more rate hikes has stoked worries that the Fed could tip the economy into recession, weighing on risk sentiment.

site_title: Toronto home sales slow, but prices continue to climb
summary: Toronto's housing market slowed in June with a 6.9% decrease in home sales from May, according to the Toronto Regional Real Estate Board. Despite this, home prices rose 2.5% to C$1.16 million, driven by a population boom and materials shortage. The Bank of Canada's rate hike in June appeared to deter some buyers, but monthly price growth decelerated. Experts expect further rate hikes and a potential impact on mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: The preliminary growth estimate for May, which can change when final data is released next month, was led by increases in the manufacturing and wholesale trade sectors, as well as by offices of real estate agents and brokers, Statscan says.

site_title: Indonesia’s biggest cinema chain seeks up to 2.4 trillion rupiah in IPO
summary: Indonesia's largest cinema chain, Cinema XXI, is seeking up to 2.4 trillion rupiah (S$214.5 million) in an initial public offering (IPO) to expand its operations. The company operates 1,216 screens across Indonesia and plans to use most of the proceeds to expand its network. A 10% stake will be sold via private placement on the listing date, with underwriters including JP Morgan and UBS. The IPO is scheduled for August 2.
