site_title: Levi Strauss to cut prices as weak consumer spending hits outlook
summary: Levi Strauss & Co. cut its annual profit forecast due to weak consumer spending and falling sales at its wholesale channels in North America. The company reported a net loss of US$1.6 million for the second quarter, a significant decline from a net income of US$49.7 million in the same period last year. The decline in net revenues was 9%, the steepest quarterly drop since 2021, and shares fell 6% in extended trading. This move joins peer American Eagle Outfitters in predicting a weak outlook for consumer spending.

images.alt_text: For the 2023 fiscal year, Levi sees net revenue of US$6.3 billion to US$6.4 billion, reflecting growth of 1.5 per cent to 3 per cent from the prior year.

site_title: Traders bet UK rates are heading to the highest since 1998
summary: Traders are betting on the Bank of England's key interest rate reaching 6.5% by February, the highest since 1998, as policymakers face pressure to tame inflation without harming the economy. This surge in bets follows 13 successive rate increases since late 2021, despite UK inflation remaining above the BOE's 2% target at 8.7%. Higher rates could lead to a sharp blow to the economy, adding to difficulties for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's government ahead of an expected election next year.

images.alt_text: The finance ministry and Bank of England have launched a public consultation on whether to issue a so-called central bank digital currency or CBDC, mirroring moves by many central banks across the world.

site_title: Taiwan hikes taxes on vacant homes by up to 33% to cool hot market
summary: Taiwan's government plans to raise taxes on vacant homes by up to 33% to cool the country's overheated property market. The annual tax on unoccupied homes will increase to 4.8% from 3.6%, generating an estimated NT$2.6 billion in extra tax revenue. The move aims to encourage the release of houses and reduce vacant properties, as the country's housing market continues to face high prices and speculation.

images.alt_text: Overseas orders to Taiwanese companies shrink 17.6 per cent last month from a year earlier to US$45.7 billion, says the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

site_title: Using avoided emissions to build the case for investing in climate change mitigation
summary: Investors can benefit from investing in companies that contribute to climate change mitigation and adaptation by calculating "avoided emissions," which measure the CO2 reduction impact of a business's solutions. Avoided emissions represent emissions that would have been released if a particular action or intervention did not take place. By investing in companies offering low-carbon products or services, investors can align their portfolios with efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Calculating avoided emissions can help investors identify attractive opportunities in sectors such as renewable energy and sustainable packaging.

images.alt_text: Climate change is arguably the greatest global challenge facing the world, and it calls for urgent action.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.2% at 3,144.26. Decliners outnumbered advancers 60 to 35, and 27.4 million securities worth S$52.3 million changed hands. The decline mirrored global market slump, with US stocks dropping on Thursday due to strong economic data that may lead to more interest rate hikes. The Singapore market also saw declines in local banks OCBC and UOB, while DBS and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding remained flat.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX
SingPost will be working with IMDA to review its costs and operating model.

site_title: Yellen to discuss US-China ties, global economic outlook in Beijing
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen begins a four-day visit to Beijing, marking her first trip to China as Treasury chief. The visit aims to steady tense US-China relations and address issues such as export controls, human rights, and national security. Yellen will meet with Chinese Premier Li Qiang and former Vice Premier Liu He to discuss economic relations and collaboration opportunities. Despite no expected policy breakthroughs, the visit is seen as a chance for frank and productive conversations that can pave the way for future talks.

images.alt_text: Earlier this week, China put export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrives at Beijing Capital International Airport in Beijing, China on July 6, 2023. She will expand lines of correspondence, avoid miscommunications and widen collaboration on the global economy, climate change, debt distress and other issues.

site_title: Saudi Arabia hikes most August oil prices to Asia after supply cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia raised its July official selling prices (OSP) for crude oil to Asia by 20 US cents a barrel in August, marking a second consecutive month of price hikes. The price increase is attributed to the de facto leader of the Opec+ group's decision to prolong an extra output cut. This move is expected to further weigh on thin refining margins in Asia, prompting refiners to seek alternatives from other suppliers or regions.

images.alt_text: Saudi Minister of Energy Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman al-Saud speaks during a panel discussion at the 10th Arab-China Business Conference in Riyadh, on June 11, 2023. (Photo by Fayez NURELDINE / AFP)
Any influx into Asia of oil from the Atlantic Basin could be a mixed blessing for Middle East producers.

site_title: Google delays release of fully custom phone chip until 2025: The Information
summary: Google has delayed the release of its fully custom phone chip, internally called Redondo, until 2025, according to a report by The Information. The tech giant will switch from Samsung to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) for making the chips, called Tensors. The Laguna chip, based on TSMC's 3-nanometer manufacturing process, will be released in 2025, replacing the current semicustom chips designed with Samsung.

images.alt_text: Google’s latest Supreme Court filing shows its deepening disagreement with how the CCI conducted its Android investigation.
In 2021, Google was hit with a 220 million euro (S$324.6 million) fine by France’s antitrust watchdog for favouring its AdX sales platform.

Visitors cast their shadows past a Google logo at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France, June 15, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes

site_title: China’s sinking markets heap pressure on Xi to deliver stimulus
summary: China's stock market is experiencing its third consecutive week of losses, with the yuan trading near an eight-month low. Premier Li Qiang has pledged to implement targeted stimulus measures, but no specifics have been provided. The government faces pressure to deliver more substantial action amid growing concerns over the economy, including a weak property market and sluggish household confidence. The Politburo is set to discuss stimulus later this month, and economists expect limited scope for stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: A view of the city skyline and Huangpu river in Shanghai. The boost from China's reopening to exports has been limited, says Maybank senior economist Chua Hak Bin.

site_title: Japan’s Nikkei tracks Wall Street lower on US Fed rate hike bets
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 0.47% to 32,618.88 on Friday, tracking declines in US stocks after strong labor market data fueled bets on additional US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The Nikkei has fallen 1.72% this week, after closing at a 33-year high on Monday. Financials sector led the decline, with real estate falling over 1%. Experts predict investors are selling to take profits, with one strategist predicting the Nikkei could fall to 31,500 this summer before resuming its climb to reach 35,000 by year-end.

images.alt_text: The strong base pay growth boosted worker’s total cash earnings, or nominal wages, by 2.5 per cent in May, after a revised 0.8 per cent increase logged in April.

site_title: Gold faces weekly loss on bets US interest rates will be higher for longer
summary: Gold prices are on track for a fourth consecutive weekly loss as investors bet the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates higher for longer, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Spot gold held steady at $1,911.85 per ounce, but was down 0.4% for the week. This follows US private payrolls increasing more than expected in June, indicating strength in the labor market despite growing risks of a recession from higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising US interest rates, as they increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Japan’s base salaries jump most since 1995, puts BOJ policy into view
summary: Japan's base salaries rose 1.8% in May, the largest gain since 1995, boosting total cash earnings by 2.5% and nominal wages by 0.8% in April. This growth is being closely watched by the Bank of Japan, which may consider unwinding its ultra-loose monetary stimulus. Analysts expect real wages to remain in contraction for the rest of 2023, while household spending fell 4% in May, down for a third month. The BOJ's deputy governor emphasized the need for continued support with easy policy.

images.alt_text: Wage growth is one of the key trends the Bank of Japan is closely watching as it considers if and when it should unwind its ultra-loose monetary stimulus.

site_title: Samsung Electronics flags 96% drop in Q2 profit as chip glut drags on
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a likely 96% drop in second-quarter operating profit to 600 billion won (S$620.4 million) due to a chip glut, its lowest profit for any quarter since 2009. The company's memory chip business likely saw losses shrink in the second quarter, but analysts expect the downturn to hit bottom in the third quarter. Revenue likely fell 22% from the same period last year to 60 trillion won. The company is set to release detailed earnings on July 27, with investors focusing on third-quarter signals and potential demand recovery.

images.alt_text: Samsung is expected to unveil its latest foldable smartphones later this month in Seoul.
The latest orders bring this year’s combined tally of orders from Pfizer to US$1.08 billion.

site_title: Crypto trading volume dropped in second quarter to lowest since 2019
summary: Crypto trading volume dropped to its lowest since 2019 in the second quarter, with a 40% decline to $1.7 trillion in June. Centralized exchanges saw a 16.4% increase in volume to $575 billion, while Binance's market share declined for the fourth consecutive month to 42%. Binance's CEO, Changpeng "CZ" Zhao, faces a lawsuit from the US SEC over securities laws, and the company's US subsidiary also saw a decline in market share. Coinbase's market share was the least affected, with a 0.08% decline.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Sabana Reit, Singapore Paincare
summary: SingPost shares hit a seven-week high after the government considers adjusting postage rates. The company will review costs and operating model with the Infocomm Media Development Authority. Sabana Reit's sponsor ESR Group responds to an investor's open letter regarding an upcoming EGM. SPCH partners with Puxiang Healthcare to expand its specialist pain-care treatments in China.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as strong data boosts odds of more Fed actions
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as strong economic data boosted the chances for more Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 dropped 0.8% to 4,411.59 and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.8% to 13,679.04. The data showed the US economy added 497,000 jobs in June, more than double expectations, and a survey pointed to solid growth in the services sector. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note pushed above 4%, predicting another rate increase at the July 26 meeting.

site_title: US wants coalition of nations to engage China in curbing synthetic drugs
summary: The US is seeking a global coalition to curb the flow of synthetic drugs, particularly fentanyl, with a virtual meeting of over 80 countries on the agenda. Assistant Secretary of State Todd Robinson stated that China needs to do more to disrupt illicit synthetic drug supply chains, but it's unclear if China will participate. The US has previously filed criminal charges against Chinese companies and individuals accused of trafficking fentanyl precursor chemicals. The meeting aims to engage other countries in combating the supply chain, with China's cooperation seen as crucial in addressing the opioid crisis.

images.alt_text: Earlier this week, China put export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables.
China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.

site_title: Taxi segment could rev up ComfortDelGro’s shares, but rising costs and competition are potential speed bumps
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation is expected to benefit from its taxi segment, driven by a new platform fee for its booking app CDG Zig. The move is similar to those of other ride-hailing platforms, and a massive downsizing by Grab suggests less competition. However, rising costs and competition remain potential speed bumps for the company. This development is expected to drive profits for ComfortDelGro, despite the challenges in the industry.

images.alt_text: Grab held a company-wide town hall on Wednesday for the survivors of the layoffs, where Tan fielded questions about the possibility of a second round of cuts.
Analysts remain positive on ComfortDelGro despite the announcement that two of its competitors will be merging.
Analysts from DBS Research and RHB Securities are positive on ComfortDelGro's decision to implement a S$0.70 platform fee charge for rides booked via its app.

Geographically, ComfortDelGro said Singapore is showing “signs of slowing economic growth”. Over in Australia, there are driver shortages but also new terms from successful re-tenders, the company said.

site_title: Swifties and shifting fandom dynamics
summary: Taylor Swift's Eras world tour has sparked a frenzy among fans, with many traveling across countries to attend the concerts. The tour has seen a surge in engagement with Swift's entire catalogue, with a 79% increase in interest after the first 10 weeks. Fans are also purchasing and wearing merchandise, with 53% of Gen Z-ers willing to do so. The tour has highlighted the evolving nature of fandom, with fans forming community-centric groups and using digital spaces to secure tickets. Swift's ability to connect with fans on a personal level has solidified her status as a modern-day pop star with a hyper-dedicated fan base.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performs onstage on the first night of her "Eras Tour" at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on March 31, 2023. Music megastars Taylor Swift and The Weeknd are among showbiz people invited to join the organization that votes on who gets Oscars, the body said on June 28.
Other invitees include Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, who directed "Everything Everywhere All at Once," which won seven Oscars this year including the prize for best picture.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its new crop of members of Tinseltown's most elite club numbers 398 people. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)
UOB's card applications have surged since Taylor Swift announced her stop in Singapore – the only one in South-east Asian for her Eras Tour.

site_title: Binance key executives, many US employees leave crypto exchange amid crackdown
summary: Binance is facing a regulatory crackdown, with key executives and US employees leaving the company amid allegations of fraud. Chief Strategy Officer Patrick Hillmann, Senior Vice-President for Compliance Steven Christie, and General Counsel Hon Ng are among those departing. Eleanor Hughes, current head of legal for the Asia-Pacific region, will take over as General Counsel. The departures come as regulatory pressures from Australia, Europe, and the US continue to impact the company's business.

images.alt_text: Binance typically accesses Sepa via payment intermediaries.
On Tuesday, Binance.US and the SEC agreed to work on a deal that avoids a total asset freeze at the cryptocurrency trading platform.

site_title: Rome’s historic bakery to the popes closes
summary: Rome's historic bakery to the popes, "Panificio Arrigoni," has closed after being sold, marking the end of a nearly century-long tradition of catering to the Catholic Church's leaders. The 79-year-old owner, Angelo Arrigoni, said mass tourism and rising energy costs forced him to shut down, despite the bakery's reputation for serving the popes, including John Paul II and Benedict XVI. The sale has saddened regular customers, who lamented the loss of a unique, locally-owned business.

images.alt_text: Affirmative action supporters walk through a gate at Harvard University on July 1, 2023, the day after the US Supreme Court ruled that race-conscious admissions programmes at Harvard and the University of North Carolina were unconstitutional.

site_title: Senior US Fed official backs more monetary tightening
summary: A senior US Federal Reserve official, Dallas Fed president Lorie Logan, expressed support for additional monetary tightening to combat stubborn inflation, which remains above the 2% target. Despite the Fed's decision to pause interest rate hikes last month, Logan believes two more quarter-point increases may be necessary this year to bring inflation back in check. Her backing for the additional hikes is contingent on no significant unexpected events.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms has slashed jobs in May, part of a plan announced in March to eliminate 10,000 roles.

Cars lined up outside the Tesla car manufacturing plant in California. The US purchasing managers' index has stayed below the 50 threshold for eight straight months indicating a contraction in manufacturing.

site_title: Warner Bros defends ‘Barbie’ film’s world map as ‘child-like’
summary: Warner Bros. defended the "child-like" drawing of a map in its upcoming Barbie film, which shows China's nine-dash line in the South China Sea, as having no intended significance. Vietnam banned the film due to the map, citing its depiction of disputed territories. The map, according to Warner Bros., is a "whimsical, child-like crayon drawing" meant to show Barbie's journey. The studio claimed the map was harmless, while Vietnam's authorities deemed it a "serious" issue. The film's release in Vietnam was previously scheduled for July 21.

images.alt_text: Actor Margot Robbie, who plays the title role in the movie Barbie, during a photocall for the upcoming Warner Bros film  in Los Angeles last month.

site_title: ESR Group hits back at Quarz, asks if push for internalisation vote is in unitholders’ best interests
summary: ESR Group responds to Quarz Capital's push for an internalisation vote at Sabana Reit's upcoming EGM, questioning whether it's in unitholders' best interests. ESR Group claims Quarz's approach is "irresponsible and reckless" and lacks operational knowledge of the Singapore Reit market. The sponsor urges the Sabana manager to exercise discretion judiciously and resolve the dispute in a conclusive manner without further delay.

images.alt_text: At an upcoming extraordinary general meeting, unitholders will vote on whether to remove Sabana Reit’s current manager and replace it with an internal one.

site_title: Titanic sub operator suspends expeditions after deadly implosion
summary: OCEANGATE, a US-based company, has suspended all exploration and commercial operations following the deadly implosion of its tourist submersible, the Titan, during a dive to the Titanic wreck on June 18. The incident killed all five people on board and is under investigation by US and Canadian authorities. Examination of debris recovered by the US Coast Guard is expected to shed more light on the cause of the implosion, which raised questions about the unregulated nature of such expeditions. The company had planned two more expeditions to the Titanic ruins for June 2024.

site_title: Meta’s Threads swiftly signs up 30 million users, in clear threat to Musk-owned Twitter
summary: Meta's Threads app has signed up over 30 million users within 18 hours of its launch, emerging as a significant threat to Elon Musk-owned Twitter. The app leveraged its connection to Instagram's 2 billion monthly active users and its similar look to Twitter. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg has traded barbs with Musk, even suggesting a mixed martial arts cage match. Analysts view Threads' swift success as a major blow to Twitter, with one describing it as "stellar execution and an easy-to-navigate user interface."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Meta's Threads app logo is seen in this illustration taken July 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Oil near flat as tighter supplies offset US rate hike risk
summary: Oil prices remained near flat on Thursday as tighter US crude supplies offset concerns about a potential US interest rate hike. Brent crude futures settled 13 US cents lower at $76.52 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 1 cent to $71.80 a barrel. Top oil exporters Saudi Arabia and Russia announced fresh output cuts for August, totaling over 5 million barrels per day. The cuts, combined with a drop in US crude stocks, provided some support for prices, but fears of further rate increases continue to dominate the market.

images.alt_text: US crude stocks fell by about 4.4 million barrels last week, while petrol and distillate inventories rose, according to market sources citing American Petroleum Institute figures.

site_title: ChatGPT and AI disruption: Is consulting next in line?
summary: AI-powered algorithms can generate business intelligence reports in a manner analogous to human consultants, providing affordable and timely strategic advice. Companies can hire these algorithms to conduct due diligence on obscure products or markets, reducing costs and time. Generative AI has been successfully deployed in various industries, including Ocean Spray Cranberries and Fortune 500 companies. However, some experts raise concerns about the death of human authorship and metaphysical implications of automated writing. Consulting firms must adapt to the rise of AI-generated reports, focusing on non-formulaic tasks and people skills to maintain value.

images.alt_text: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman initially said his company could quit Europe over new AI rules but later backtracked.
Note the buzzwords : All AI methodologies can and/or have already been used for generative purposes (eg a robot splashing paint on a canvas).

site_title: Twitter threatens to sue Meta over Threads: Semafor
summary: Twitter has threatened to sue Meta Platforms over its new Threads platform, citing the hiring of former Twitter employees who allegedly have access to trade secrets. Meta launched Threads with over 30 million sign-ups, aiming to compete with Elon Musk's Twitter. Twitter's lawyer Alex Spiro accused Meta of using stolen information, while Meta denies this, stating no former Twitter employees are on its engineering team. The dispute raises concerns about intellectual property rights and the competition between the two social media platforms.

images.alt_text: While Threads is a standalone app, users can log in using their Instagram credentials, which makes it an easy addition for Instagram’s more than 2 billion monthly active users.
FILE PHOTO: Meta's Threads app logo is seen in this illustration taken July 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Tech tools sold online to jump queue for Taylor Swift tickets come with risks
summary: Tech tools sold online to bypass queues for Taylor Swift tickets can pose risks, experts warn. These "bypass links" were sold on platforms like Carousell and Telegram for between SGD 30 and SGD 100 during pre-sales for her Eras Tour concerts at the National Stadium in Singapore. The general sales start on July 7. Using such tools can lead to issues with ticket providers or scams, and fans are advised to be cautious when using them.

images.alt_text: (From left) Polytechnic student Nellie Titus and her friends Rebekah Loh, Megan Choy and Lynette Saw turned up at Lim Ah Pin Post Office in Kovan on Wednesday at 10.30 pm.

site_title: VW ready to deal with China metal curbs; chipmakers play down fallout
summary: Volkswagen (VW) is monitoring metal markets due to China's export restrictions on gallium and germanium, effective August 1, which may impact semiconductors and electric vehicles. Larger chip manufacturers view these controls as a warning shot about potential economic pain, but some are playing down fears of shortages. The move comes after a top Chinese trade adviser hinted at further curbs on strategic exports, including rare earths. Companies are scrambling to secure supplies and prices have risen as a result of the controls.

images.alt_text: “The (Defense) Department is proactively taking steps using Defense Production Act Title III authorities to increase domestic mining and processing of critical materials for the microelectronics and space supply chain, including gallium and germanium,” the Pentagon spokesperson says.
“After evaluation, we do not expect the export restrictions on raw materials gallium and germanium will have any direct impact on TSMC’s production,” the company says.
Earlier this week, China put export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables.

site_title: Chinese banks told to be vigilant of free trade zone bond risks: sources
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has instructed commercial lenders to be vigilant of risks linked to bonds issued in Shanghai's free trade zone, known as "pearl bonds." The guidance aims to tighten rules on local government borrowing and curb the market's growth. The PBOC has asked banks to be aware of purchasing these foreign debt bonds, which have seen a record sales surge to 72 billion yuan (S$13.5 billion) in the first five months of the year. Authorities have also introduced new requirements for LGFVs to issue such bonds and plan to shut a private funding route for them.

images.alt_text: The PBOC pledged to curb speculation last month and used its daily reference rate to push back this week.

Pan Gongsheng’s appointment as party chief of the People’s Bank of China indicates the bank will stay the course, consistent with its recent approach of only modestly cutting interest rates and encouraging banks to lend more to targeted areas.
Pan Gongsheng is likely to first be appointed as the bank’s Communist Party chief before he is installed as governor, which requires appointment by the government, the report says.
PBOC’s move will reduce financing costs, promote and expand employment and support economic recovery.
The central bank set its so-called fixing for the managed currency at a stronger-than-expected level on Friday, after the offshore yuan extended a seven-month low.

site_title: Can anything pop the ‘everything bubble’?
summary: The "everything bubble" in risky assets, which emerged in the wake of low interest rates and central bank money printing, has surprisingly survived despite recent challenges such as inflation, rising interest rates, and war in Europe. Despite a looming liquidity crisis and dwindling Treasury cash buffers, asset prices have remained resilient, with indices of high-yield bonds, housing, and even speculative assets like Bitcoin and non-fungible tokens showing remarkable recovery. Analysts warn that valuations have become increasingly difficult to justify, but the bubble may be able to survive for an extended period.

images.alt_text: The labelling of recessions – and of bull and bear markets – is critical in understanding what has already happened, but these labels aren’t all that helpful for acting now or preparing for the future.
Those sceptical about Wall Street's recent strength may well have a strong case, given the chance that the US economy could slide into recession.

site_title: UBS overhauls leadership at wealth management division
summary: UBS announces a series of management changes, affecting around 180 executives, following its takeover of Credit Suisse. Former Credit Suisse executives Puneet Matta will lead UBS's wealth management business in India, and Michael Marr will head Global Wealth Management Australia. Lisa Golia will become chief operating officer for wealth management in the US. The changes aim to promote "fairness and meritocracy," according to UBS Global Wealth Management President Iqbal Khan. The moves follow a larger overhaul of UBS's third layer of management and come as the bank prepares for major job cuts, potentially affecting 30% of its workforce.

images.alt_text: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at the company's office at the Bahnhofstrasse in Zurich in this July 1, 2009 file photo.   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann

UBS is focused on the transfer of wealth between baby boomers to their heirs in the coming years. About US$18 trillion will be passed to younger generations in the US over the next seven years, and as much as US$84 trillion over the next two decades.
The government’s and UBS’s priority was to “minimise potential losses and risks so that recourse to the federal guarantee is avoided to the greatest extent possible”, the government said.

site_title: China’s Li says recovery at critical stage, vows speedy measures
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang says the country is at a critical stage of economic recovery and vows to implement targeted policies to stabilize growth and employment. He pledged to "spare no time" in implementing measures to prevent risks, without detailing specifics. This aligns with expectations from private-sector economists who predict China will avoid all-out stimulus measures due to debt concerns. Li also aims to enhance communication between the government and private sector, including foreign companies.

site_title: Startup e-commerce platform Temu expands to Japan
summary: Temu, a low-cost e-commerce platform owned by PDD Holdings, has expanded to Japan, marking its first entry into the Asian market. The platform ships a wide range of products, including clothing, electronics, and home goods, from Chinese merchants at discounted prices. Temu has previously expanded to 22 countries, including the US, and has proven popular in the West amid inflation and cost-of-living crises. Japan is considered an "attractive, affluent" market for Temu, but its effectiveness in adapting to local nuances remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: PDD posts revenue of 37.64 billion yuan (S$7.2 billion), compared with analysts’ estimates of 31.98 billion yuan, according to Refinitiv data.
PDD reported revenue of 39.82 billion yuan in the fourth quarter, falling short of estimates for 41.01 billion yuan.
Temu has made a big splash since launching in the US last September, selling shoes, jewelry, beauty accessories and home goods directly from Chinese merchants for very low prices.
Temu topped US app download rankings in early April, a spot it held since January.

site_title: ByteDance launches new music streaming service in Brazil, Indonesia
summary: ByteDance, the Chinese company behind TikTok, is launching a new music streaming service in Brazil and Indonesia, expanding its presence in the market led by Spotify. The service, TikTok Music, will offer three monthly plans in Brazil, priced between $2.34 and $26.90. The existing music streaming service Resso will be discontinued in Brazil and Indonesia, while maintaining operations in India. This move follows previous reports of ByteDance's plans to expand its music streaming service into more countries.

images.alt_text: The ByteDance logo is seen at the company's office building in Shanghai, China July 4, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Crypto firm Gemini sues DCG after conflict over unit’s restructuring deal
summary: Gemini, a major cryptocurrency firm, has sued Digital Currency Group (DCG) and its CEO Barry Silbert, accusing them of "fraud" and "deception" over a restructuring deal for Genesis, a troubled crypto lending firm. The dispute arises from DCG's failure to reach an agreement on a restructuring plan with creditors, who are owed over $3 billion. Gemini had set a deadline for a deal by Thursday, threatening litigation if no agreement was reached. The lawsuit is the latest in a series of conflicts between Gemini and DCG following the collapse of Genesis in January.

site_title: The challenge of corporate culture
summary: Corporate culture is a shared set of values, beliefs, and practices that guide an organization's behavior and decision-making. Despite its importance, prioritizing organizational culture is challenging due to its intangible nature. Boards should understand the factors that impact culture, such as organization size, industry sector, employee demographics, and sociopolitical factors. To shape the right corporate culture, boards should set the tone, encourage open dialogue, equip leaders to lead, and hold themselves accountable for upholding ethical and cultural standards. By focusing on the three "T"s – Tone, Tune, and Tempo – boards can empower and enable management teams to implement a desired corporate culture.

images.alt_text: The recent cases of independent directors being hauled to court for disclosure-related offences have sent shockwaves to many independent directors.
Analytics firm Social Sprout found in its 2022 survey that 63 per cent of people say CEOs who have online social profiles are better representatives for their companies than those who do not.
Under pressure in a dynamic environment, management may, however, seek to portray a different financial image of the company beyond what strict accounting rules might allow.

site_title: ISM survey shows US service sector up in June; inflation gradually slowing
summary: The US services sector grew faster than expected in June, with a non-manufacturing PMI of 53.9, indicating growth in the industry. New orders increased to 55.5, while services inflation moderated, falling to a three-year low. The slowdown in services inflation suggests the Federal Reserve's efforts to bring inflation down to 2% may be on track. Despite the positive indicator, the manufacturing sector remains stagnant, and the Fed is expected to raise interest rates this month to combat elevated inflation and a tight labor market.

images.alt_text: epa10182552 Containers are stacked at the Los Angeles and Long Beach Ports in Long Beach, California, USA, 13 September 2022.  EPA-EFE/CAROLINE BREHMAN

site_title: Goldman Sachs says rising EV usage to power higher copper demand
summary: Goldman Sachs forecasts copper demand from electric vehicles (EVs) to reach 1 million tonnes by 2025, driven by strong sales in China and increasing adoption of EVs globally. The bank attributes copper's high conductivity and ductility as ideal properties for EV applications. Copper usage in EVs is expected to decrease over time, with a projected 65 kg per unit by 2030, compared to 73 kg in 2022. This growth in EV demand is seen as a key driver of copper's bullish story, with the sector accounting for 27% of additional copper consumption over the next decade.

site_title: New Tudor Pelagos FXD makes a splash at Alinghi Red Bull Racing’s Barcelona base
summary: Tudor has unveiled two new Pelagos FXD watches, the Alinghi Red Bull Racing Edition, in partnership with two-time America's Cup winner Alinghi Red Bull Racing. The watches draw inspiration from the team's yacht, AC75, and feature a carbon fibre case and bezel insert, as well as a titanium bi-directional rotatable bezel. The watches are available in time-only and chronograph versions, both COSC-certified and weekend-proof, and retail for S$5,130 and S$7,080, respectively. The design showcases the partnership's spirit, with the team colors blue and red featured on the dials and fabric straps.

images.alt_text: The Tudor Prince Chronograph One is a unique piece that will be auctioned at Only Watch 2023.

site_title: US: Wall St slides as labour data stokes rate hike concerns
summary: Wall Street's main indexes fell on Thursday as data showing a resilient US labor market and hawkish Federal Reserve minutes fueled concerns that interest rates could remain higher for longer. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.34% to 34,171.39, while the S&P 500 fell 0.54% to 4,422.62 and the Nasdaq Composite declined 1.00% to 13,653.17. The declines were attributed to the strong labor data and the Fed's interest rate hike expectations.

site_title: AI robots could play future role as companions in care homes
summary: A social robot named Nadine, powered by AI, could be more effective than human carers in care homes, according to Professor Nadia Magnenat Thalmann. Nadine has 24/7 availability, allowing it to provide constant care, whereas human carers are limited by their time. Thalmann, who served as the model for Nadine's design, believes robots like Nadine could revolutionize care home services, providing better care and attention to the sick and elderly.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SoftBank Corp's logo is pictured at a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, February 4, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Eunice Ng with Miss Ugene, the company's first robot that was introduced in 2014.
The seven-year-old startup’s robotic arms and rovers can remotely perform routine construction work.
Big tech companies and startups like Figure are racing to develop the next commercially viable humanoid robot.

site_title: Ford auto sales rise on robust demand, improved supply
summary: Ford's quarterly US auto sales rose about 10% to 531,662 vehicles, driven by easing supply chain snags and pent-up demand for personal transportation. The company's truck sales jumped 26% and electric F-150 sales more than doubled. However, overall EV sales fell 2.8% due to supply snags. Industry-wide US new vehicle sales in June were 1.37 million units, with annual sales projected at 15.7 million. Ford's sales increase comes as automakers rush to make up for lost production during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The company has said it will lose US$3 billion in 2023 on its nascent EV.
Ford defends its efforts, saying the plants being funded by the government loan will create 7,500 “good-paying” jobs.
Ford Motor executive chairman Bill Ford Jr, great-grandson of founder Henry Ford, said he sees an opportunity for Ford engineers to understand the technology.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Ford logo is pictured at the 2019 Frankfurt Motor Show (IAA) in Frankfurt, Germany September 10, 2019. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise moderately; layoffs drop in June
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 12,000 to 248,000 for the week ended Jul 1, exceeding economists' forecast of 245,000. Despite a moderate increase, claims remain below the 280,000 level that signals significant job growth slowdown. Employment growth averaged 314,000 jobs per month this year, and the labour market remains resilient despite 500 basis points of interest rate hikes. Continuing claims fell by 13,000 to 1.72 million, indicating shorter spells of unemployment.

images.alt_text: Job seekers speak with representatives at the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg

site_title: US private payrolls beat expectations in June: ADP
summary: US private payrolls increased by 497,000 jobs in June, beating expectations of 228,000 jobs added. The labour market remains resilient despite 500 basis points of interest rate hikes from the Fed since March 2022. Economists forecast total nonfarm payrolls to have risen by 225,000 jobs in June, following a surge of 339,000 in May. The strong labour market suggests the economy is holding up despite growing recession risks.

site_title: Berlusconi’s will leaves 100 million euros to his last girlfriend
summary: Former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi left 100 million euros to his partner Marta Fascina and 100 million euros to his brother Paolo in his will, as revealed on July 6. Fascina, a lawmaker for Berlusconi's Forza Italia party, was in a three-year relationship with the ex-premier and remained by his side during his final months. The will also includes the ex-premier's plan to pass his business empire to his oldest heirs.

images.alt_text: Former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi was in many ways a forerunner of many of the populist politicians of today in Europe and beyond.

site_title: Thai regulator files fraud charges against debt-ridden Stark
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission of Thailand has filed charges of financial misconduct against 10 entities and individuals, including Stark Corp's largest holder Vonnarat Tangkaravakoon, for concealing details and making false statements about the company's accounts. The charges follow Stark's accounting scandal and debt default, which led to a 99% stock crash and a class-action lawsuit. The regulator also found the company had diverted money raised from a bond sale for a planned investment in a German firm.

images.alt_text: Stark's incident has heightened scrutiny of hidden financial risks in Thailand at a time of investor uncertainty over a political impasse in the wake of last month’s general election.

site_title: AI seen fuelling Microsoft to US$3 trillion value in Morgan Stanley model
summary: Microsoft's market value is expected to reach US$3.1 trillion, according to Morgan Stanley analysts, who have raised their price target to US$415. The software giant is poised to benefit from the growth of AI, with analysts citing Microsoft's position as the best placed to monetize AI expansion. Despite a 41% share-price rally this year, the valuation is considered "still reasonable" by analysts. This would propel Microsoft to join Apple as a stock with a market capitalization of over US$3 trillion.

images.alt_text: The FTC says the transaction would give Microsoft exclusive access to Activision games, leaving Nintendo and Sony Group out in the cold.

FILE PHOTO: A Microsoft logo is seen a day after Microsoft Corp's $26.2 billion purchase of LinkedIn Corp, in Los Angeles, California, U.S. June 14, 2016. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo
From 2015 to 2020, Microsoft retained the data that it collected from children during the Xbox account creation process, even when a parent failed to complete the process, according to the complaint.
“We’re investigating an issue with accessing Outlook on the web,” Microsoft tweets.

site_title: A sky-high perspective of Osaka
summary: The Conrad Osaka hotel offers a unique experience with its 40th-floor lobby featuring a stunning view of the city skyline. The hotel's design incorporates Japanese contemporary art, including a shimmery crystal installation in the Sky Bar Lounge. Guests can enjoy teppanyaki at Kura, with the city skyline as a backdrop. The hotel's design also includes imposing "Fu/Rai" gods of wind and thunder, adding to the luxurious atmosphere. With its sky-high perspective and sophisticated design, Conrad Osaka is an ideal choice for travelers seeking a high-end experience in Osaka.

images.alt_text: Tsuromi Ryokuchi Park is mesmerising during sakura season.

site_title: Pentagon has strategic germanium stockpile but no gallium reserves
summary: The US Pentagon holds a strategic stockpile of germanium, a rare earth metal used in semiconductors and military applications, but has no inventory reserves for gallium, another critical metal used in radar and satellite technology. China's export restrictions on the two metals, effective August 1, have sent companies scrambling to secure supplies and raised prices, potentially slowing down the production of defense systems and increasing costs. The Pentagon plans to increase domestic mining and processing of critical materials, including gallium and germanium, through the Defense Production Act.

images.alt_text: The elements of Gallium and Germanium are seen on a periodic table, in this illustration picture taken on July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
Taiwan is a major producer of chips used in everything from smartphones and cars to fighter jets, supplying companies like Apple and Nvidia.
Earlier this week, China put export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables.

FILE PHOTO: Worker miniatures are placed among the flag of China and printed circuit boards with semiconductor chips, in this illustration picture taken July 5, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.
China did not control an absolute amount of germanium in the world as it did with rare earths.
Gallium and germanium are used in a wide range of products such as solar panels, lasers, night-vision goggles and computer chips.
Gallium and germanium are used in a wide range of products such as solar panels, lasers, night-vision goggles and computer chips.

site_title: US agency seeks updated responses from Tesla in Autopilot probe
summary: US auto safety regulators are seeking updated responses and data from Tesla regarding its Autopilot system, following 830,000 vehicles and over a dozen crashes involving stopped emergency vehicles. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating whether Tesla vehicles adequately ensure drivers are paying attention when using the driver assistance system, and is also looking into the effectiveness of the company's alert strategy. The agency has previously raised questions about driver engagement and attentiveness in prior crashes, and is now seeking information on Tesla's cabin camera system and "Tesla Vision" equipped vehicles.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has missed his own deadlines for a fully autonomous vehicle – and Tesla’s driver-assistance technology has provoked regulatory probes in the United States.
Deliveries from Tesla’s Shanghai plant rise almost 20 per cent from a year earlier in June to 93,680 vehicles
Kentucky is the first state to mandate Tesla’s charging technology.
The Tesla Model 3. In addition to cutting prices across the lineup this year, Tesla has introduced perks such as three months of free fast-charging in the US to entice buyers.
Tesla is expected to hit record sales in China, its second-largest market after North America, despite stiff competition from market leader BYD.

site_title: Goodpack sues supplier CIMC Transpack in spat over intellectual property
summary: Goodpack, a logistics company owned by KKR, is suing supplier CIMC Transpack in the Singapore High Court over alleged breaches of contract and intellectual property theft. Goodpack claims CIMC's newer container models feature similar designs to Goodpack's, causing confusion in the international market for bulk-shipping containers. The company seeks damages of US$9.9 million and a court order to recall CIMC containers made with confidential information. The lawsuit follows failed talks between the two companies in 2021 to form a joint venture for leasing IBCs.

images.alt_text: Goodyear to buy Cooper Tire for US$2.8b, doubling China presence

site_title: ECB backs draft EU rules for winding down smaller banks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) backs proposed EU rules to wind down smaller banks when they fail, aiming to avoid taxpayer bailouts. The rules, proposed by the EU, establish industry-funded deposit guarantee schemes (DGS) to take losses earlier, reducing the need for taxpayer bailouts. However, the ECB urges the EU to make the rules more ambitious, allowing for easier takeover of failing banks and harmonizing national practices. The ECB also calls for an EU-wide deposit guarantee scheme and increased funding for banks coming out of resolution.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) is pictured outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, April 26, 2018. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: In sherry country, wines of the future that look to the past
summary: In sherry country of southwestern Spain, a small group of winemakers have rediscovered lost grapes and unfortified styles, producing some of the world's most exciting wines. After decades of focusing on mass-market bottles, producers like Alberto Orte and Ramiro Ibáñez are reexamining terroirs, reviving old grape varieties, and showcasing the region's unique vineyard expressions. These wines demonstrate that sherry is not only capable of aging but also dependent on the skill of the winemaker and the terroir, challenging traditional myths about the palomino grape and the industry's decline.

images.alt_text: Napa has long been the US’s primo wine destination, noted for high-end accommodations and pricey dining rooms.

site_title: Latest T-bill offers 3.99% cut-off yield
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released data showing the latest six-month Treasury bills, or T-bills, offered a cut-off yield of 3.99% compared to 3.89% last month. A total of S$5.4 billion was allotted out of S$10.3 billion received in applications, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 1.91. Demand for T-bills appears to be weakening, as only 2% of competitive bids were allotted, down from 74% last month. The median yield was 3.5% and the average yield was 2.87% per annum.

images.alt_text: Applications for the risk-free, government-backed fixed income product totalled S$9.9 billion for the S$5 billion on offer, resulting in a bid-to-cover ratio of 1.98.
MAS believes the prevailing monetary policy stance was sufficiently tight and appropriate for securing medium-term price stability.

site_title: French commercial property woes mount as investment plunges
summary: French commercial property investment plummeted 61% in the second quarter to 2.5 billion euros, the lowest level in at least three years, due to concerns over soaring interest rates. This marks the third consecutive quarterly decline, with previous contractions of 35% and 52%. The data, compiled from four brokers, reflects a significant downturn in investor deals for offices, retail space, and warehouses.

images.alt_text: A view shows skyscraper office properties at La Defense business and financial district near Paris, France, June 26, 2023. REUTERS/Stephanie Lecocq

site_title: US layoffs halve in June as tech job cuts ease: report
summary: US layoffs nearly halved in June, with technology sector job cuts easing, according to a report from employment firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. Corporate America laid off a higher number of workers in June compared to the same month last year, despite a drop in tech sector layoffs. Technology companies led job cut announcements with 141,516 layoffs in the first half of the year, up from 6,000 in the same period last year. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes may have slowed job losses, with experts predicting further tightening could impact other sectors of the US economy.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk fired about half of Twitter’s 7,500 workers in November, following his US$44 billion purchase of the company.
The cuts are part of an effort to burnish ESPN’s finances.
Job growth is being driven by the services sector, including the leisure and hospitality category, which is still catching up after businesses struggled to find workers over the last two years.
The trading platform played a crucial role in the retail-trading frenzy during the pandemic but has struggled with a contracting customer base spooked by higher cost of commodities.

site_title: Blackpink Vietnam concert organiser apologises over South China Sea map
summary: The organizer of a Blackpink concert in Hanoi, iME, has apologized after its website featured a map showing China's territorial claims in the South China Sea, prompting backlash on social media. The map, known as the "nine-dash line," was criticized for being used to illustrate China's expansive claims over the resource-rich waterway. iME has committed to replacing the image and sent a written explanation to relevant authorities. The incident has sparked concern about China's growing influence in the region and has led to calls for a boycott of the concerts.

images.alt_text: Actor Margot Robbie, who plays the title role in the movie Barbie, during a photocall for the upcoming Warner Bros film  in Los Angeles last month.

site_title: Chef David Thompson aims to revive traditional Thai customs
summary: Chef David Thompson and his partner Tanongsak Yordwai are reviving the ancient wai khru ceremony, a traditional Thai customs, to recreate a festival of culture and food. The ceremony, known as wai khru, is a gesture of deep respect and is still an integral part of Thai life today. The event, held in the market town of Amphawa, was attended by scholars, history buffs, and food lovers, featuring a panel discussion, lakorn performance, and a rice offering ceremony. The duo aims to restore wai khru to its nobler intentions, highlighting the importance of knowledge and tradition in Thai culture.

images.alt_text: Tsuromi Ryokuchi Park is mesmerising during sakura season.

site_title: Maybank turns ‘neutral’ on Malaysia’s renewable energy sector, says valuations fair
summary: Maybank has downgraded Malaysia's renewable energy sector to "neutral" but believes valuations are fair. The brokerage expects earnings growth to peak in the second half of 2023, driven by remaining Large Scale Solar 4 projects and a lifting of the renewable energy export ban. Cheaper solar-related materials and higher revenue are also expected to contribute to the sector's growth. Maybank has maintained "hold" calls on Solarvest and Cypark Resources, with target prices of RM1.22 and RM0.77, respectively.

images.alt_text: Sarawak Energy exports about 80-100 MW of electricity to Indonesia’s West Kalimantan and is building a 1,375 MW hydropower plant with its partner in North Kalimantan which may come online by 2030, CEO Sharbini Suhail says.
The renewables penetration in Asean has been driven by supportive regulation and tariff policies
Solar energy likely the main booster for Malaysia's renewable energy sector: Maybank
Gentari chief renewables officer Low Kian Min and Sembcorp Singapore and SEA chief Koh Chiap Khiong ink the MOU.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Sustainability Reporting Advisory Committee has recommended that non-listed companies in Singapore with annual revenue of at least S$1 billion make mandatory climate-related disclosures starting from FY2027. Additionally, listed companies will be required to make such disclosures from FY2025. The government has also announced it will step in and terminate funding for SPH Media Trust if misconduct or mismanagement is found. Meanwhile, the overnight policy rate in Malaysia remained at 3% amid easing inflation and growth.

site_title: SoftBank backs robot startup as Masayoshi Son goes on the offensive
summary: SoftBank has backed robot startup Telexistence with a $170 million funding round, following its previous investments in robotics, including the failed robot pizza startup Zume. Telexistence, which already works with tech firms Microsoft and Nvidia, will expand to the US and increase headcount with the funding. The company will also enter a strategic partnership with SoftBank Robotics Group to commercialize its robots in North America, and will receive board seats from SoftBank and Globis Capital Partners.

site_title: Norwegian Air to buy regional peer Wideroe for US$106 million
summary: Norwegian Air has agreed to purchase regional airline Wideroe for $106 million, aiming to strengthen its position in Norway. The deal comes two years after Norwegian Air emerged from bankruptcy protection, having raised cash and increased its fleet from 51 aircraft to 81 Boeing 737-800s. The combined airline expects annual synergies of $18.8-$28.2 million and plans to close the deal by the end of the fourth quarter, financing it through available funds. The companies will continue to operate under separate brands.

images.alt_text: Norwegian Air to end transatlantic flights, seeks state help

site_title: Instagram unveils Threads app, a threat to Musk’s Twitter
summary: Meta's Instagram has launched Threads, a direct rival to Twitter, allowing users to post text and links, reply, and repost messages. The app garnered over 10 million sign-ups in its first seven hours, with users able to port over existing follower lists and account names. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that Threads aims to provide a public conversations app with 1 billion-plus people, a goal Twitter has yet to achieve. The app will have the same content rules as Instagram and will be interoperable with competing products, marking the first Meta app to do so.

images.alt_text: Zuckerberg’s tweet was his first since 2012 and comes days after Musk challenged the Meta founder to a cage fight.

site_title: Single family offices with tax perks employ 1,400 Singaporeans, PRs: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam revealed that single family offices (SFOs) in Singapore, which receive tax incentives, employ approximately 1,400 locals and permanent residents, with about 900 jobs created in the last three years. These jobs are generally well-paying, with two-thirds earning more than S$5,000 per month. Tharman also stated that SFOs contribute to the economy through job creation and revenue generation, but MAS lacks data on these contributions, which will be reviewed.

images.alt_text: All investments in non-listed Singapore operating companies including private credit will be recognised
Further, MAS will also recognise grants that SFOs give to support blended finance structures, as two dollars for every dollar of grant given.

site_title: UK house building slumps as interest rates rise
summary: The UK house building sector experienced its largest decline in 14 years, with the S&P Global/CIPS construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 48.9 in June from 51.6 in May. The decline was driven by a sharp fall in the house building component, which slid to 39.6 from 42.7, due to rising interest rates and higher borrowing costs. The Bank of England's interest rate hike to 5% has led to typical mortgage rates rising above 6.5%, causing builders to slow down their pipeline of work and act cautiously to protect margins.

images.alt_text: HSBC recently announced that it will relocate its Canary Wharf headquarters to the City of London. Among the other major employers that are planning to leave are law firm Clifford Chance and fintech giant Revolut.

Britain’s housing shortage is a contentious political issue ahead of a general election expected in 2024, with the Conservatives under fire after backing away from a manifesto pledge to build 300,000 homes a year.
Values for London office buildings with a BREEAM certification are on average 20.6 per cent higher than those without that accreditation, says Jones Lang LaSalle.

ivdrop - Commuters make their way over London Bridge towards the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, Sept. 30, 2021. Officials have flagged concerns about the labor market after the end of the government’s furlough plan, while households are also facing looming increases in their tax and energy bills that economists say could hurt confidence and reduce the opportunity for hikes. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
JPMorgan’s comments come after a FTSE index tracking UK homebuilder stocks fell about 10 per cent in the second quarter.

Terraced residential housing in Sheffield, UK, on Friday, May 19, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK CPI Inflation data on Wednesday. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

Mortgagors today borrow much greater sums against their income – a ratio that has risen from 2.0 in the late 80s to around 3.5 today – while changes to taxes and mortgage products have also altered the equation.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losses as geopolitics, growth worries weigh; STI down 1.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% to 3,150.43 on July 6, amid geopolitical concerns and interest rate expectations. Investors weakened sentiment, with losers beating gainers 338 to 196. Major Asian bourses also declined, including Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. The cut-off yield of Singapore's six-month Treasury bill rose to 3.99%, pricing in expectations of higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s planned Jul 6-9 trip comes just weeks after Secretary of State Antony Blinken met China’s top leader President Xi Jinping and Foreign Minister Qin Gang in Beijing in June.

site_title: Revealing debut for first Saudi in Paris Fashion Week
summary: Saudi designer Mohammed Ashi made his debut at Paris Fashion Week, showcasing a collection of highly revealing and transparent designs that challenge traditional Saudi dress. Ashi, founder of Ashi Studio, has been dressing celebrities and has been welcomed back to mentor young Saudi designers as part of the kingdom's efforts to develop its fashion industry. The show was seen as a significant milestone in Ashi's career, marking "the peak of his career," and comes ahead of Riyadh's planned fashion week in October.

images.alt_text: Fashion designer Mohammed Ashi poses after his show for the Women's Haute-Couture Fall/Winter 2023/2024 Fashion Week in Paris on July 6, 2023. (Photo by Geoffroy Van der Hasselt / AFP)
Models strode across the cobblestones lining the river, parading tweed suits lined with tufts of tulle or embellished with flower motifs in autumn tones

site_title: Google accuses India antitrust body of protecting Amazon in Android probe
summary: Google has accused India's antitrust body, the Competition Commission of India (CCI), of protecting Amazon by ordering changes to its Android business model. The CCI fined Google $163 million in October for abusing its dominant position in the Android market, and ordered the company to allow modified versions of its operating system to be distributed without licensing restrictions. Google argues that the CCI's directive was unfair and only intended to protect Amazon, which had complained about the restrictions hindering its development of a modified version of Android.

images.alt_text: PwC has not publicly identified any client in relation to the scandal.
Google will also end its News Showcase programme in Canada, under which the company has agreements with 150 news publications across the country.
In 2021, Google was hit with a 220 million euro (S$324.6 million) fine by France’s antitrust watchdog for favouring its AdX sales platform.

Visitors cast their shadows past a Google logo at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France, June 15, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes
Google spokesperson Jose Castaneda says that the company is disappointed with the verdict and plans to appeal.

site_title: Australian shares log the worst day in two weeks on rate hike fears
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.2% to 7,163.4 points, their worst session in two weeks, due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike outlook and the Reserve Bank of Australia's potential rate hike on August 1. Heavyweight mining and financial stocks led the decline, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto falling 2.3% and 1.4%, respectively. Weak oil prices and reduced iron ore prices also contributed to the downturn.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index finished 0.9 per cent higher at 7,357.80, its highest closing level since April 20.

site_title: EU antitrust chief says no concerns about metaverse, sees no regulation yet
summary: EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager says there are no concerns about the metaverse, citing innovation and competition. She plans to present an initiative to help regulators understand the industry's dynamics. Vestager believes existing legislation for Big Tech, including privacy and market power rules, can also apply to the metaverse. She advises caution against rushing into regulation, noting the need for implementation and cooperation between the EU Commission and member states.

site_title: UK believes Thames Water will avoid state takeover
summary: The UK government believes Thames Water, the country's largest water company, can avoid a state takeover, as talks with investors aim to raise £1 billion to address its large debt burden and infrastructure needs. Contingency plans, including a temporary state takeover, have been considered but are now deemed unnecessary. The company's difficulties have raised concerns about the water industry's viability and the merits of privatization, but the government now thinks Thames Water can raise the necessary funds on its own.

images.alt_text: UK media said ministers were in talks about the possibility of temporarily bringing the utility company back into public hands under a so-called special administration regime.

site_title: Belarus leader Lukashenko says Prigozhin is back in Russia
summary: Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko stated that Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin is no longer in Belarus, contrary to his previous claims. Prigozhin had arrived in Belarus as part of a deal to end an armed mutiny in Russia. Lukashenko said Prigozhin is currently in St. Petersburg, Russia, and an offer for Wagner Group fighters to station in Belarus remains on the table, despite concerns from neighboring NATO countries. The terms of the deal and its implementation remain unclear.

images.alt_text: “If anyone in the West has any doubts, then that’s your problem,” Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said when asked if he could give assurances to the world that Russia was not slipping into turmoil.

site_title: Arabic calligraphy art, with a twist
summary: Indonesian artists have reinterpreted Islamic calligraphy in a modern and innovative way, blending traditional Arabic scripts with contemporary aesthetics. The exhibition "The Neglected Dimension" at the National Gallery Singapore showcases four artists who drew inspiration from their cultural heritage and modern art training in Bandung. The artworks feature unique adaptations of Arabic calligraphy, such as sewn flags with different script versions used in various South-east Asian languages, and fantastical paintings that combine Arab, Javanese, and Western iconography. The exhibition highlights the rediscovery of "the neglected dimension" in Indonesian art, where calligraphy and abstraction were used to reinterpret Islamic material traditions and expressions of spirituality.

images.alt_text: Wong Keen's Rainbow (2023, acrylic on paper laid on canvas, 158 x 223 cm) is one of the highlights of the exhibition.
Aki Hassan's solo debut at Yeo Workshop  celebrates the close friendships that help trans people heal from their traumas.

site_title: China releases its first open-source computer operating system
summary: China has released its first open-source desktop operating system, OpenKylin, built by a community of 4,000 developers and based on Linux. The OS is used in China's space program and industries such as finance and energy, and is part of the country's efforts to reduce reliance on US technology. This move aims to create a homegrown alternative to Microsoft's Windows and Apple's MacOS, with over a dozen Chinese companies working on similar operating systems.

site_title: China's Xi tells military to deepen war, combat planning
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has urged the military to deepen war and combat planning to increase the chances of victory in actual combat, as the world has entered a new period of turmoil and change. Xi emphasized the need to safeguard China's sovereignty and territory, particularly in the Taiwan Strait, where China has repeatedly called for opposition to pro-independence and secessionist activities. This comes amid heightened tensions with the US, following a visit by US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan last year, which China has staged war games and drills around the island in response.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 19, 2016, a Chinese soldier holds a Chinese flag during Peace Mission-2016 joint military exercises of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) in the Edelweiss training area in Balykchy, some 200 km from Bishkek. - During Xi Jinping's decade-long rule China has built the world's largest navy, revamped the world's largest standing army and amassed a nuclear and ballistic arsenal to trouble any foe. (Photo by Vyacheslav OSELEDKO / AFP)

site_title: Yellen begins China visit with both sides locked in confrontation
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen began a four-day visit to China on July 6, 2023, amid low expectations for easing tensions between the two nations. Despite a low-key welcome, officials acknowledge that safeguarding national security takes precedence over economic ties. Yellen will meet with China's Premier Li Qiang and former economy tsar Liu He, who is close to President Xi Jinping. The visit aims to address concerns over trade and security, but outcomes are uncertain due to both sides' prioritization of national interests.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is visiting China this week to re-establish contact with new Chinese leaders and officials; her trip marks the second by a US Cabinet official to China since ties deteriorated earlier this year

site_title: Adani Green weighs raising 123 billion rupees to fund expansion, sources say
summary: Adani Green Energy, a unit of Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's conglomerate, is considering raising approximately 123 billion rupees ($2 billion) to fund its expansion into renewable energy. The move comes after a damaging short-seller report and a subsequent market downturn. Adani Green plans to raise funds through a qualified institutional placement (QIP) to attract institutional investors and research analysts, with the goal of reducing its reliance on coal. A board discussion on the plan is set for July 6, with shareholder approval to follow.

site_title: 🥶 Overcoming first job jitters
summary: First job jitters are a common experience for young adults, characterized by uncertainty and self-doubt. According to psychotherapist Esther Oon-Bybjerg, it's normal to feel overwhelmed by the transition from school to the professional world. To overcome these jitters, experts recommend researching one's new role, being open to constructive criticism, and adopting a growth mindset. Additionally, being friendly with colleagues and managers, setting aside time to reflect, and reframing negative thoughts can help alleviate imposter syndrome and other challenges.

site_title: Tomb Raider games group Embracer raises 2 billion krona in share issue
summary: Swedish gaming group Embracer raised 2 billion krona (S$246 million) in a share issue, issuing 80,000 new shares at 25 krona per share. The move aims to strengthen its financial position and improve operational flexibility. Embracer's shares fell 13% after the announcement, following a month of cost-cutting measures and a cancelled partnership. The company, which owns the Tomb Raider game series, had previously announced plans for the share issue.

images.alt_text: Embracer, which owns several development studios and the intellectual property rights to a number of games including a new Tomb Raider game, says the deal would have “set a new benchmark for the gaming industry”.
The game will be set in Middle-earth, featuring stories from "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" literary trilogy written by J R R Tolkien.

site_title: Singapore Paincare brings Western treatment and TCM together in new Chinese JV
summary: Singapore Paincare Holdings, a medical services group, has partnered Chinese community hospital operator Puxiang Healthcare to set up a joint venture in China, capturing a new market for its specialist pain-care treatments. The 49-51% joint venture will offer Western treatments alongside traditional Chinese medicine, with training for doctors to deliver SPCH's treatment regimen in Puxiang's 15 community hospitals in Beijing, Hebei, and Tianjin. The partnership aims to raise SPCH's profile in the Chinese market and expand its patient base.

images.alt_text:
The shortage of healthcare staff, particularly nurses, in Singapore is a concern for healthcare players

ST PHOTO : MALCOLM MCLEOD
New hospital fee benchmarks have been introduced for 29 common surgical procedures and medical conditions in MOH's latest update, released on Jun 14.

site_title: Hong Kong slashes directly elected seats in local polls, further reducing democracy
summary: Hong Kong's legislature has voted to slash directly elected seats in local polls, reducing them from 452 to 88, and overall seats from 479 to 470. This move, critics say, further stifles democratic opposition, following the imposition of a national security law in 2020. The changes require candidates to pass a national security background check and secure nominations from committees, effectively barring most opposition democracy advocates from running, effectively removing "patriots" only.

images.alt_text: The notices accused the activists of asking foreign powers to impose sanctions on Hong Kong and China.

site_title: Patek Philippe and others auction watches for charity
summary: The 10th biennial Only Watch charity auction has unveiled 62 one-of-a-kind mechanical timepieces in multi-colored hues, featuring designs from prominent brands such as Patek Philippe, Audemars Piguet, and Louis Vuitton. The watches, valued from $16,500 to $880,000, will go on show from September in various cities before auctioning off in November. Patek Philippe, the largest donor so far, has kept its watch under wraps but hinted at a grand complication with a new movement, paired with a limited edition of 30 pieces.

images.alt_text: The bar counter in Panerai's boutiques is the watch brand's "bestselling spot", says CEO Jean Marc Pontroué.

site_title: Malaysia maintains 3% key rate as expected, amid easing inflation and growth
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, maintained the overnight policy rate (OPR) at 3% as expected, citing easing inflation and moderating economic growth. The decision, widely anticipated by economists, indicates the central bank is more sanguine about the country's growth and inflation outlook. Despite this, the decision may continue to impact the ringgit currency, with some analysts predicting further depreciation. Bank Negara reiterated its "slightly accommodative and supportive of the economy" stance, while also highlighting downside risks such as persistent core inflation and global commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's inflation continued to ease further in May, as food and transport prices rising at a slower pace
Maybank expects the Malaysian renewable energy sector’s earnings growth to peak in the second half of 2023.

site_title: Link Hotel owners stave off forced sale with financing to repay S$51 million loan
summary: Link Hotel Singapore, valued at S$140 million, has avoided a forced sale after its owner, Hang Huo Investment, secured a S$55 million loan to repay a S$51 million loan owed to DBS. The loan, secured by a mortgage over the hotel, will also cover working capital and loan process costs. The hotel will continue to operate and retain staff after its receiver and manager, FTI Consulting, was discharged. Hang Huo Investment plans to retake a loan at a lower interest cost from another commercial bank within the next few months.

images.alt_text: Located at 50 and 51 Tiong Bahru Road, Link Hotel Singapore comprises two four-storey blocks connected by a link bridge.

site_title: Taiwan chip giant sees no production hit from China curb on rare metals
summary: Taiwanese chip giant TSMC says it expects no direct impact from China's export controls on rare metals gallium and germanium, which are essential for making semiconductors. China's controls, aimed at securing its dominance in the global chip market, will require a license from August 1. Despite this, TSMC will monitor the situation closely, particularly for long-term indirect impacts on pricing and supply. Taiwan's economic minister downplayed the impact, citing that the country imports refined materials from the US and Japan.

images.alt_text: Tokyo-based SBI is eyeing the growing financing needs of chipmakers to create redundant production lines as manufacturers bow to political and investor pressure to diversify their suppliers.
China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.
China did not control an absolute amount of germanium in the world as it did with rare earths.
Gallium and germanium are used in a wide range of products such as solar panels, lasers, night-vision goggles and computer chips.
Gallium and germanium are used in a wide range of products such as solar panels, lasers, night-vision goggles and computer chips.

site_title: Thai stock investor mood improves ahead of formation of new government
summary: Thai investor confidence index rose to 81.62 in June, up from 77.70 in May, as hopes for a smooth new government formation and continued economic recovery boosted sentiment. Foreign investor confidence increased 33% from the previous month. The index has returned to the "neutral zone", indicating a stable market outlook. The survey, conducted by the Federation of Thai Capital Market Organisations, anticipates positive market conditions over the next three months.

images.alt_text: Assuming no street protests in the near term, Nomura recommends a focus on Thai stocks geared to the consumer, tourism, and reopening-related themes.

site_title: Keppel unit partners Petronas’ Gentari for sustainable energy solutions in South-east Asia
summary: Keppel Infrastructure has partnered with Petronas' Gentari to explore sustainable energy solutions in South-east Asia. The memorandum of understanding (MOU) aims to develop renewable and low-carbon energy projects, electric-vehicle charging infrastructure, and energy-as-a-service opportunities. The collaboration will also facilitate market access and mutual capability development. This partnership is part of Gentari's efforts to promote sustainable energy in the region, and Keppel Infrastructure's commitment to reducing carbon emissions.

site_title: Foxconn’s chairman holds talks with Sharp employees in Japan
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, reported a 56% decline in first-quarter net profit due to a $553 million writedown related to its 34% stake in Japanese electronics maker Sharp. Chairman Liu Young-way held talks with Sharp employees in Japan, discussing the companies' relationship, Sharp's global positioning, and the future of the Japanese company. The meetings were attended by over 100 employees and aimed to address concerns.
