site_title: Musk predicts Tesla self-driving cars ‘later this year’
summary: Elon Musk predicts Tesla will achieve fully autonomous vehicles "later this year," despite missing previous deadlines. The CEO stated that Tesla is "very close" to achieving full self-driving without human supervision, with the company working on levels 4 and 5 autonomous driving technology. Musk acknowledged past predictions had been incorrect, but expressed confidence in the company's progress. Tesla's driver-assistance technology has also faced regulatory probes in the US, while the company continues to expand its presence in China with a new factory.

images.alt_text: Deliveries from Tesla’s Shanghai plant rise almost 20 per cent from a year earlier in June to 93,680 vehicles
The Tesla Model 3. In addition to cutting prices across the lineup this year, Tesla has introduced perks such as three months of free fast-charging in the US to entice buyers.

site_title: More Manhattan homebuyers paying cash in sign of luxury strength
summary: More Manhattan homebuyers are paying cash in record numbers, with 65% of purchases completed without financing in the second quarter, up from 57% in the first quarter. This trend reflects the continued strength of the luxury market, where listings inventory declined year-over-year for the first time in four quarters. Median luxury prices rose 3.9% to $6.7 million, while median prices across all price ranges fell 4% to $1.2 million. Mortgage rates, which have nearly doubled from early 2022, may be driving buyers to opt for cash.

site_title: PBOC extends yuan support after offering reassuring rhetoric
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) extended support for the yuan by setting a stronger daily reference rate, 360 pips above average estimates, to curb speculation and stabilize the weakening currency. The move follows reassuring rhetoric from China's flagship newspaper, stating that authorities have sufficient tools to manage the yuan. The PBOC's actions aim to control the onshore yuan's 2% move and counter growing pressure on the currency due to rising global interest rates and weaker-than-expected growth.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending is flagging, the property market and stock markets are in the doldrums and cash is piling up in savings.

“Even if the yuan exchange rate market has a panic unilateral trend, there are abundant tools to calm the ‘herd effect’ and ensure the smooth operation of the foreign exchange market,” the Financial News says.

site_title: Tata weighs buying Temasek’s stake in pay TV platform, sources say
summary: Tata Group is considering buying back Temasek's 20% stake in its pay TV platform, Tata Play, amid plans to postpone the platform's initial public offering due to market conditions. Tata Play, a joint venture with Walt Disney's Twenty-First Century Fox, has received regulatory approval to proceed with the IPO. Discussions between Tata Group and Temasek are ongoing, and the deal could still fall apart, but Tata Play may opt for a listing if market conditions improve.

site_title: SMRT debuts AI-based safety system at Bukit Panjang LRT
summary: SMRT has launched its AI-based safety system, iSafe, at Bukit Panjang Light Rail Transit stations. The system uses 8 cameras to monitor tracks and detect humans with 99.8% accuracy, alerting staff in under 5 seconds. iSafe was developed by SMRT's business arm, Strides, and has already detected a person on the tracks, leading to an evacuation without injury. The system is designed to address the lack of platform screen doors at BPLRT stations.

images.alt_text: The Swedish capital is expanding its three-line metro network, with extensions as well as a fourth line being built, and these will come into service from 2025.

site_title: Government has the right to terminate funding for SPH Media if wrongdoings are found: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Government has the right to terminate funding for SPH Media Trust if misconduct or mismanagement is found, said Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo. The statement came after a report by SPH Media's audit and risk committee found the company overstated its daily circulation numbers. The first tranche of funding to SMT was disbursed in March after a similar incident, and Teo emphasized the government's intention to intervene if wrongdoings are found.

images.alt_text: The GRC system was implemented in 1988 to enshrine minority representation in Parliament.

site_title: An electrifying start to Singapore’s power sector liberalisation has turned into a damp squib
summary: Singapore's power sector liberalization has failed to regain its competitiveness two years after the market was turned upside down by sky-high prices and a gas crunch, driving out some electricity retailers. The number of players in the residential segment has shrunk to nine, with six being gentailers. The electricity futures market, where retailers hedge their positions, has evaporated, and consumers are now stuck with fewer options, with no genuine competition. The Energy Market Authority has proposed to raise the hedging requirement for retailers to 80% to ensure better resilience during volatile periods, but it may be hard to implement.

images.alt_text: Starting from Jul 1, the island’s Energy Market Authority has imposed temporary caps on wholesale power prices to tamp down exceptional volatility.
SP Group reviews the electricity tariffs every quarter based on guidelines set by the electricity industry regulator, Energy Market Authority.
The temporary price cap will kick in from Jul 1, 2023, said the Energy Market Authority in a paper published on its website.
Singapore's largest independent electricity retailer iSwitch powers down
Electricity retailers in Singapore hike rates amid surge in spot prices
Confusion reigns as Singapore's electricity spot prices spike

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust obtains S$419 million green loan with carbon credits from OCBC
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has secured a S$419 million green loan from OCBC with carbon credits, marking Singapore's first green financing solution combining a green loan and carbon credits. The loan proceeds will be used for decarbonization projects, including energy-efficient technology for Tampines 1 mall, aiming to progress towards carbon-neutral status. The trust will invest the carbon credits in Verra or Gold standard-certified projects, aiming to offset financed emissions.

images.alt_text: Frasers Centrepoint Trust reports 96.4% retail portfolio occupancy in Q1 FY21
FCT reports 96.4% retail portfolio occupancy for Q1 FY21

site_title: Stellantis wins bigger subsidies for Canada battery plant
summary: Stellantis and LG Energy Solution have agreed to resume construction of a Canadian electric vehicle battery plant in Windsor, Ontario, after the federal government and province increased subsidies. The C$5 billion project, which will create 2,500 new jobs, is now expected to begin production in 2024 with an annual capacity of 45 gigawatt hours. The agreement follows a dispute over US support under the Inflation Reduction Act, with Stellantis demanding Canada match the level of support. The project is part of Canada's efforts to woo companies in the EV supply chain.

images.alt_text: Stellantis plans to cut as many as 2,000 jobs in Italy this year as it retools plants to make electric and plug-in hybrid models.

The unit will offer a platform called Free2move Charge providing customer services including access to over 500,000 charging points in Europe “through partners” by the end of this year, the Stellantis says.

site_title: Emerging Asia bonds, currencies have lost their traditional link
summary: Asia's emerging-market currencies are losing their traditional link to local bonds, with the average 90-day correlation between currencies and government bond yields falling to 0.1 from 0.42 last year. This decline is driven by falling hedging costs and growing expectations for rate cuts in Asia, which are under pressure due to China's gloomy outlook. The cheaper cost of hedging is making it more attractive for global funds to offer dollars in exchange for Asian currencies, resulting in currency devaluation. This divergence is evident in Malaysia, where investors bought $842 million of debt in May despite the ringgit falling 3% against the dollar.

images.alt_text: “Even if the yuan exchange rate market has a panic unilateral trend, there are abundant tools to calm the ‘herd effect’ and ensure the smooth operation of the foreign exchange market,” the Financial News says.
Given that flexible exchange rates are no panacea, and that some version of original sin persists, EM authorities need to take additional steps to maintain domestic financial stability.

site_title: Companies play catch-up as cybersecurity attacks rise in digital India
summary: Cyberattacks in India have surged significantly over the past six months, posing a vital risk to the country's economic ambitions. High-profile incidents, such as a breach at Suzuki Motorcycle India and a ransomware attack on India's largest drugmaker, have boosted demand for security software. Experts warn that every company in India wants to go digital, increasing the risks. The spike in cyberattacks highlights the need for companies to prioritize cybersecurity measures to protect their operations and revenue.

images.alt_text: Mastercard is able to provide the risk score because it runs the infrastructure for real-time electronic transfers of funds through its subsidiary Vocalink.
HSBC says the trial will help it better analyse threats and work out how to protect data.

site_title: Sri Lanka cuts rate for second time as inflation halves
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank cut its benchmark rate for the second consecutive meeting, lowering the standing lending facility rate to 12% to ease disinflation and support the nation's recovery from its worst economic crisis in seven decades. The decision comes after inflation halved in June and a local debt revamp, bolstering the Sri Lankan rupee and boosting stocks and dollar bonds. The move aims to provide the impetus for market interest rates to adjust downwards and maintain accommodative monetary conditions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A vendor sells vegetables to a customer amid the rampant food inflation, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, July 29 , 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: TSMC does not expect direct production impact from China’s metal export curbs
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), the world's largest contract chipmaker, says it doesn't expect direct production impact from China's export curbs on metals gallium and germanium. The move, aimed at protecting national security, may limit exports to Taiwan and other countries. TSMC shares fell 2% on Thursday, citing worsening China-US trade tensions and concerns about US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's visit to Beijing. Analysts believe restrictions may have limited short-term impact on TSMC's production.

images.alt_text: Earlier this week, China put export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables.

FILE PHOTO: Worker miniatures are placed among the flag of China and printed circuit boards with semiconductor chips, in this illustration picture taken July 5, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.
Stock of Taiwanese chip giant TSMC has rallied strongly.

site_title: Deadline set by crypto’s Winklevoss looms for Genesis repayment deal
summary: The Winklevoss twins' largest creditor, Gemini, has set a final deadline of July 6 for Digital Currency Group (DCG) to agree on a restructuring plan for its bankrupt crypto lending unit Genesis. The plan, which includes a $275 million forbearance payment and $835 million debt tranche, must be accepted by DCG by 4 pm EDT on July 6 or Gemini will pursue litigation, seeking to recoup $1.1 billion. A bankruptcy court-appointed mediator has been unable to help the parties reach an agreement, and DCG has declined to comment on the proposal.

images.alt_text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is suing Gemini as regulators crack down on the industry.
Gemini has a crypto lending product called Earn in partnership with DCG’s crypto firm Genesis.

site_title: Singapore to change tax rules that attracted the super rich
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) plans to change tax incentives for single family offices to boost hiring of locals and investment in the country's equity markets. The changes include minimum asset under management and business spending requirements, and incentives for investments in climate-related projects and philanthropy. The move aims to increase the role of wealth in Singapore's society and economy, despite the current surge in family offices not investing much within the country. The MAS also plans to enhance surveillance and defense against money laundering risks in the sector.

images.alt_text: MAS believes the prevailing monetary policy stance was sufficiently tight and appropriate for securing medium-term price stability.
The facade of the Monetary Authority of Singapore Building on May 30, 2023.
Further, MAS will also recognise grants that SFOs give to support blended finance structures, as two dollars for every dollar of grant given.
Singapore's housing market has seen a buoyant run, after an influx of capital and a pandemic-induced supply shortage pushed prices and rents to record highs.

site_title: Career advancement platform NodeFlair raises US$2 million in Series A funding
summary: NodeFlair, a career advancement platform for technology talents, has raised US$2 million in Series A funding led by Iterative. The funding will be used to speed up product development, expand into new markets, and grow its team of 40 employees. Founded in 2018 by Ethan Ang and Adrian Goh, NodeFlair provides payslip-verified salary data and career information for technology roles across seniority levels. The company aims to be profitable by 2024.

site_title: India’s Jio set to sign US$1.7 billion  deal with Nokia for 5G equipment: Economic Times
summary: Reliance Jio Infocomm is set to sign a US$1.7 billion contract with Nokia to purchase 5G network equipment, according to a report by the Economic Times. The deal, which could be finalized as early as Thursday, comes after Jio snapped up US$11 billion worth of airwaves in a 5G spectrum auction last August. This marks the latest move by Jio to expand its 5G network, which it has already launched in several cities. The contract is backed by major lenders including HSBC, JP Morgan, and Citigroup.

images.alt_text: A pricing strategy for JioCinema is still under discussion internally, an industry source said, but Ambani has a reputation of disrupting rivals in the price-sensitive Indian market with cheap offers.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open tracking global losses; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% at Thursday's open, tracking global losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 6.08 points to 3,179.3. Losers outnumbered gainers 63 to 48 after 47.1 million securities worth S$61.4 million changed hands. The decline was influenced by overnight losses on Wall Street, where US Treasury bond yields climbed and the Federal Reserve's June meeting minutes hinted at possible interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The government says it will consider allowing SingPost to introduce postage rate adjustments.

site_title: FairPrice group aims to become part of platform company, 50 years after founding: new book
summary: NTUC Enterprise's FairPrice Group is aiming to become part of a platform company comprising its cooperatives, including NTUC Health and Learning Hub, through a single user ID called Linkpass. The platform model, favored by tech giants like Alibaba and Amazon, will utilize the group's over 1 million consumer data points and its "treasure trove of data" from the FairPrice app and Link Rewards loyalty program. The goal is to create a 360-degree view of individual customers, while NTUC prioritizes using data for the benefit of its members, not for profit.

images.alt_text: Chan Tee Seng was previously chief executive officer of the group’s food services businesses.
FairPrice backs national efforts to help community
'Even with money, you can't source for anything': Surbana Jurong CEO

site_title: Mandatory climate disclosures proposed for large non-listcos from FY2027, all listcos from FY2025
summary: Singapore may become the first Asian country to require mandatory climate-related disclosures from non-listed companies with annual revenue of at least S$1 billion, starting from FY2027. The Sustainability Reporting Advisory Committee recommends that these companies align their disclosures with the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) standards, with a view to mandating reporting by entities with an annual revenue of at least S$100 million by around FY2030. The move aims to drive change and create impact in the transition to a net-zero economy.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
South-east Asian governments must help their small and medium-sized enterprises to meet the accounting profession's new sustainability reporting standards.
Invest and grow charts concept Credit: PIXABAY
FILE PHOTO: A worker adjusts an ASEAN flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng
Generic shots of SGX
MAS and SGX will link their ESGenome disclosure portal with a global repository of climate transition-related data – Net-Zero Data Public Utility.
Companies should ensure they have a robust and effective governance structure and compliance system, as well as clear guidelines when making statements open for public scrutiny.

site_title: Asia: Tracks Wall St lower as US Fed minutes warn of more hikes
summary: Markets in Asia fell on July 6 as traders reacted to US Federal Reserve minutes indicating more interest rate hikes to combat inflation, sparking worries about a potential recession. The prospect of further rate hikes weighed on risk sentiment, despite healthy economic growth. Traders also await key US jobs data and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's visit to Beijing to stabilize relations between the US and China.

images.alt_text: Asian markets fell in early trade, with Hong Kong off more than one per cent.

site_title: Britain’s banks seek government roadmap to tokenise stocks and bonds
summary: Britain's banks and trade association UK Finance are calling for a government roadmap to tokenize stocks, bonds, and other assets using distributed ledger technology. The UK's role as a leading financial center is at stake if it fails to increase momentum in digital asset issuance. Tokenized assets can improve liquidity and reduce paper trails. A new financial services law approved last week will launch a platform for testing DLT in market infrastructure, and the finance ministry and Financial Conduct Authority should encourage experimentation with tokenized securities. Failure to act could lead to the UK losing its position as a top global financial center.

images.alt_text: Mastercard is able to provide the risk score because it runs the infrastructure for real-time electronic transfers of funds through its subsidiary Vocalink.

site_title: Kingsley Mansion up for sale again with unchanged S$52 million guide price
summary: Kingsley Mansion, a 10-storey freehold apartment development in Singapore, is back on the market with a guide price of S$52 million, unchanged from its previous attempt in March. The 14,350 square feet site has a gross plot ratio of 2.8 and can be redeveloped into a high-rise of up to 36 storeys. The property comprises 18 apartment units and has no land betterment charge payable if redeveloped for residential use. The market remains strong, with developers showing interest despite recent cooling measures, according to CBRE's head of capital markets.

images.alt_text: The second-quarter decline, based on the flash estimate, is the first drop in the price index since Q1 2020 as price momentum eased across all market segments, URA says.

site_title: Why Hong Kong wants to be a hub for the crypto sector
summary: Hong Kong aims to become a global crypto hub with the introduction of a new licensing system, regulating crypto exchanges offering Bitcoin and Ether trading. The regime prioritizes consumer protection, requiring platforms to assess users' knowledge and set trading limits. Despite initial positive reactions, few major investment pledges have been made. Beijing appears to support Hong Kong's approach, with low-key backing from China's Liaison Office. However, regulatory ambiguity and hurdles such as banking access, talent recruitment, and the potential impact on profitability remain significant challenges for the sector.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is now seeking to revive the industry, in part by opening up for crypto firms and seeking to lure more family offices with tax breaks.
Beijing clamped down on crypto over concerns about money laundering, the environmental impact of Bitcoin mining and currency outflows.

site_title: Zuckerberg posts first tweet in 11 years in Threads jibe at Musk
summary: Mark Zuckerberg posted his first tweet in over 11 years on Threads, a Twitter substitute launched by Meta, in response to a cage fight challenge from Elon Musk. The tweet featured a photo of identical Spider-Men facing off, seen as a playful jab at Musk. This move comes after Meta's Instagram unveiled Threads, a significant threat to Musk's Twitter.

site_title: Hot stock: SingPost hits 7-week high; to review costs and operating model with IMDA
summary: SingPost shares hit a 7-week high of S$0.49 after the Singapore government agreed to consider adjusting postage rates to reflect the true cost of the letter mail business. The company will review its costs and operating model with the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) to enhance efficiency and commercial viability. This move comes after the group's FY2023 profit plummeted 70.3%. SingPost aims to balance stakeholder interests and maintain quality postal services while ensuring commercial viability.

images.alt_text: SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.
(From left) Polytechnic student Nellie Titus and her friends Rebekah Loh, Megan Choy and Lynette Saw turned up at Lim Ah Pin Post Office in Kovan on Wednesday at 10.30 pm.
The board recommends a final dividend of S$0.40 per share, subject to approval from shareholders at its next annual general meeting.

Apart from individuals opting for paperless communications, most government agencies have also digitalised and are communicating with citizens through online channels, said Minister of State for Communications and Information Tan Kiat How.

The MOU signing ceremony took place at SATS Inflight Catering Centre. Present at the ceremony were Bob Chi, CEO of SATS' Gateway Services division, and Li Yu, CEO of International Business, representing SingPost.

site_title: Moderna signs deal in Shanghai with view to developing mRNA medicines
summary: Moderna has signed a memorandum of understanding and land collaboration agreement with the city government of Shanghai, China, to research, develop, and manufacture mRNA medicines exclusively for the Chinese market. The deal is worth around $1 billion and marks Moderna's first investment in China, as the company expands its presence in the country after registering a legal entity in May. The agreement comes as Moderna's revenue growth slows due to waning demand for its Covid-19 vaccine.

images.alt_text: The US biotech firm registers a unit called Moderna (China) Biotech in Shanghai on May 24 with capital of US$100 million.
FILE PHOTO: Test tubes are seen in front of a displayed Moderna logo in this illustration taken, May 21, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Mastercard’s new AI tool helps nine British banks tackle scams
summary: Mastercard has launched an AI-powered tool to help nine British banks detect and prevent authorized push payment (APP) scams, which involve tricking victims into sending money to scammers. The tool, Consumer Fraud Risk, assigns a risk score to any attempted bank transfer and can block transactions before they leave the victim's account. The system has seen a 20% increase in APP fraud detection at TSB Banking Group, where it was first implemented, and could save UK banks £100 million per year if rolled out across the industry.

images.alt_text: Each year, Mastercard estimates around 600 million cards are produced by the industry, each with a life span of around five years.

site_title: BlackRock wants to make it cheaper to trade Bitcoin, Larry Fink says
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink wants to make it cheaper to trade Bitcoin, calling it an "international asset" akin to "digitising gold". The money management giant has filed an exchange-traded fund application, which, if approved, would allow for direct investment in Bitcoin. Fink hopes regulators will consider the proposal as a way to democratize crypto, reducing costs and increasing accessibility. Nasdaq has refiled BlackRock's application, adding Coinbase Global as market surveillance provider.

site_title: Bank of America increases dividend by 9% after US Fed stress test
summary: Bank of America (BofA) increased its quarterly common stock dividend by 9% to 24 US cents per share, starting in the third quarter of 2023. This decision comes after a dialogue with the Federal Reserve to understand differing results between the central bank's stress test and the company's own under the Dodd-Frank Act. Unlike other major US banks, BofA had previously held back on a dividend hike, following the successful completion of the stress test by its rivals.

site_title: Gold listless as markets assess US Fed rate outlook
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,917.09 per ounce in early Asian trade on July 6, as investors digested the Federal Reserve's latest meeting minutes and positioned for upcoming economic data. The Fed agreed to hold interest rates steady, but investors expect a rate hike at its upcoming meeting. Gold is highly sensitive to rising US interest rates, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Investors now focus on the US Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey and non-farm payrolls report, which could influence the Fed's policy trajectory.

images.alt_text: High-interest rates discourage investing in non-yielding gold, which is otherwise seen as a safe investment amid economic uncertainties.

site_title: Innovation helps Singapore’s retailers sell the shopping experience
summary: Singapore retailers are embracing innovation to provide engaging shopping experiences for consumers. The industry is shifting towards sustainability, experiential shopping, and personalized services. Companies are incorporating technology, such as digital analytics tools and immersive retail spaces, to enhance the customer journey. Examples include Ipse Ipsa Ipsum's e-waste upcycled table collection and Madly's bespoke jewelry design experience. Retailers are also adopting innovative business models, such as upcycling and repurposing materials, to reduce waste and meet consumer demand for eco-friendly products.

images.alt_text: Mark Shaw, chairman of the Orchard Road Business Association (ORBA).
Joyce Orallo Lim, owner of Chokmah, which sells handcrafted homeware made from a sustainable material called jesmonite.

site_title: Qatar Airways reports lower profits despite World Cup
summary: Qatar Airways reported a 21% drop in annual profits for the 2022-2023 financial year, with net profits reaching 4.4 billion riyals (S$1.6 billion). Despite flying 71% more passengers and seeing a 45% increase in revenues to US$21 billion, profits were lower due to no explanation provided. The airline transported 1.4 million fans to Qatar for the World Cup, a significant boost to its business. Profits were down from the previous year's record US$1.54 billion.

images.alt_text: Germany’s biggest club had long faced criticism for its ties to Doha and the state-owned carrier in relation to alleged human rights issues, particularly surrounding the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.
For Akbar Al Baker, the future lies in business class, which Qatar Airways has branded its “Q-suite” product.

site_title: Why crypto and Wall Street are longing for spot Bitcoin ETFs
summary: US regulators are considering approval of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that directly hold Bitcoin, a move seen as a major development for the cryptocurrency industry. Major financial firms, including BlackRock, Fidelity, and Invesco, have submitted applications for spot Bitcoin ETFs, which would be physically backed by actual Bitcoin. The SEC has previously rejected similar applications due to concerns over volatility and potential manipulation. A potential approval could broaden participation in the cryptocurrency market and make it easier for investors to buy and sell Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: Nasdaq recently refiled BlackRock’s application, adding details about the proposal to indicate that Coinbase Global will provide market surveillance for the new product.
The SEC has rejected dozens of spot bitcoin ETF applications in recent years, including one from Fidelity in January 2022.
Fidelity is one of several big asset managers that have applied to list Bitcoin ETFs in recent weeks.

site_title: Chinese rush to buy Hong Kong insurance, dollars as confidence cracks, yuan weakens
summary: Chinese investors are rushing to buy Hong Kong insurance and dollar deposits, signaling a decline in domestic confidence and pressure on the yuan. Outflows have more than doubled to 814 million yuan, with new premiums collected on Hong Kong insurance policies increasing by 2,686% to US$9.6 billion. Analysts attribute the surge to concerns about China's economy, Sino-US frictions, and pessimism about the country's outlook, which is putting pressure on the yuan at eight-month lows.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Worker miniatures are placed among the flag of China and printed circuit boards with semiconductor chips, in this illustration picture taken July 5, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

“Even if the yuan exchange rate market has a panic unilateral trend, there are abundant tools to calm the ‘herd effect’ and ensure the smooth operation of the foreign exchange market,” the Financial News says.

site_title: SVB Financial gets court approval to sell investment bank
summary: US bankruptcy judge Martin Glenn has approved SVB Financial Group's plan to sell its investment banking business to the division's founder, Jeff Leerink, backed by the Baupost Group. The deal includes up to $100 million in equity financing and $30 million from Leerink's team. This sale is part of SVB Financial's efforts to sell remaining assets after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, which it owned before being seized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in March.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, SingPost, Penguin International, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: The Singapore government is considering allowing SingPost to introduce postage rate adjustments to reflect the cost of letter mail business, following a decline in domestic letter volumes since the pandemic. Frasers Centrepoint Trust has secured a S$419 million green loan from OCBC for decarbonisation projects. Penguin International has extended its closing date for a potential private takeover offer to July 20. Dasin Retail Trust's restructuring efforts have hit a speed bump after talks for a potential memorandum of understanding with a Chinese entity fell through.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust’s talks with ‘reputable Chinese entity’ for potential MOU fall through
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's talks for a potential memorandum of understanding (MOU) with a "reputable Chinese entity" to restructure its loan maturities have fallen through after a major unitholder expressed concerns that the proposed transactions were "illegal under Chinese law". The entity also criticized the trust's substantial unitholder, Zhang Zhencheng, for actions detrimental to the MOU. The trustee-manager's lead independent director, Tan Huay Lim, is currently being sued by Zhang, which has caused displeasure among existing lenders requesting the litigation be discontinued. Dasin Retail Trust's board will continue to explore available options for its restructuring exercise.

images.alt_text: Sino-Ocean Capital, an indirect stakeholder in both Dasin Retail Trust and its trustee-manager, is facing a winding-up petition in Hong Kong.
Substantial unitholder Zhang Zhencheng is suing to remove lead independent director Tan Huay Lim from the manager's board, alleging breaches of fiduciary duties.
Dasin Retail Trust’s trustee-manager’s hearing of the winding-up petition in the Hong Kong court is now postponed to Aug 17.

site_title: The moral bankruptcy of Ivy League America
summary: The US Supreme Court's ruling ending affirmative action in higher education is seen as a positive step, as it highlights the limited scope of educational opportunity in the US. Despite Ivy League schools' efforts to diversify, the majority of students who don't attend these elite institutions are from low-income backgrounds, with the 99.8% who don't attend elite colleges largely ignored in the debate. The ruling may not lead to soul-searching about the broader educational system, but rather reinforces the status quo of elite perpetuation.

images.alt_text: Affirmative action supporters walk through a gate at Harvard University, in Cambridge, Mass., on Saturday, July 1, 2023, the day after the U.S. Supreme Court made a precedent-setting ruling that race-conscious admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina were unconstitutional. (Kayana Szymczak/The New York Times)
In the Ivy League, a collection of eight highly selective schools in the northeastern US, prices have been running hot for years.
Harvard applications surge as students flock to biggest names
Why Stanford should clone itself
While US fiscal policy has generally been countercyclical, there is room for improvement.

site_title: Europe: Eurozone blue-chips slide on China weakness, rate worries
summary: European blue-chip stocks declined on July 5, with the Euro Stoxx 50 index falling 0.9% and the broader Stoxx 600 dropping 0.7%, as concerns over China's economic weakness and US Federal Reserve rate worries weighed on markets. China's services activity expanded at the slowest pace in five months, and eurozone business activity slipped into contractionary territory. Miners, luxury firms, and insurers fell, while automakers were among rare gainers. The US Fed will release minutes of its monetary policy meeting later in the day, adding to market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index inched 0.1 per cent higher at the close.

site_title: Parliament rejects PSP motion to abolish GRC system
summary: The Singapore Parliament rejected a motion by the Progress Singapore Party to abolish the group representation constituency (GRC) system. The GRC system, implemented in 1988, ensures minority representation in Parliament and prevents racial politics. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing argued that abolishing GRCs would risk inadequate multiracial representation and go against the founding philosophy of protecting minority communities. PSP Non-Constituency MP Hazel Poa proposed alternatives, including appointing minority candidates as NCMPs and adopting proportional representation, but Chan dismissed these as insufficient to prevent racial politics.

images.alt_text: The recent CPF scam cases were flagged in a joint statement by the CPF Board, GovTech and the police on Jun 29.

site_title: US says it opposes export controls by China on metals, will consult allies
summary: The US strongly opposes China's export controls on gallium and germanium products, used in electric vehicles and fibre optic cables, set to take effect on August 1. These metals are crucial for producing semiconductors and other electronics. The US will consult with its allies to address the issue, which has sent companies scrambling to secure supplies and driven up prices. The controls are expected to impact industries such as high-speed computing, plastics, and military applications.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Worker miniatures are placed among the flag of China and printed circuit boards with semiconductor chips, in this illustration picture taken July 5, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.
China did not control an absolute amount of germanium in the world as it did with rare earths.

site_title: Why are Russian oil products still being sold in America?
summary: The US should ban the import of all Russian-origin refined petroleum products, despite allowing the import of Russian crude oil, to reduce Kremlin revenue and pressure. The "laundromat countries" loophole, where refined products are sold at world prices, has created lucrative profits for Russian oil in India and Turkey, averaging $15-20 per barrel. Banning imports would minimize impact on US petrol prices and stigmatize trade with Russia, further pressuring the regime. Growing support on Capitol Hill for the ban could also encourage EU and UK allies to follow suit, aligning with long-term economic containment strategy.

images.alt_text: Saudi Minister of Energy Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman al-Saud speaks during a panel discussion at the 10th Arab-China Business Conference in Riyadh, on June 11, 2023. (Photo by Fayez NURELDINE / AFP)
India emerged as a key consumer of Russian oil following the invasion of Ukraine.
Asian refiners are grappling with lacklustre refining margins due to weaker demand, and some are mulling curbs to operations.
Pakistan’s purchase gives Russia a new outlet, adding to Moscow’s growing sales to India and China, as it redirects oil from Western markets because of the Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Samsung profit likely lowest in more than 14 years as chip glut persists
summary: Samsung Electronics is expected to report a 96% decline in June-quarter profit, the lowest in over 14 years, due to a chip glut driving losses in its cash cow business. The company's operating profit is likely to fall to 555 billion won (S$576.3 million), down from 14.1 trillion won last year. Despite a supply cut, the persistent chip glut is expected to continue impacting Samsung's profits.

images.alt_text: The latest orders bring this year’s combined tally of orders from Pfizer to US$1.08 billion.

In December, Samsung Display filed a complaint with the US International Trade Commission, alleging patent infringement by numerous companies selling OLED screens as replacement displays for mobile devices.

site_title: German cabinet approves first draft of 2024 budget
summary: Germany's cabinet approved the first draft of the 2024 budget, which aims to slash new public borrowing to within constitutionally mandated limits. The budget proposes 16.6 billion euros in net new debt for 2024, respecting the country's debt brake. Finance Minister Christian Lindner plans record investments and set clear priorities, with 54.2 billion euros allocated for investments in 2024. The budget also includes 51.8 billion euros for defence and 19.2 billion euros in extra-budgetary funds. The draft budget is seen as a prelude to further consolidation efforts.

images.alt_text: The report gives an initial hint of weakness in a pivotal week for data showing the health of manufacturing in Germany after it suffered a recession earlier this year.
Due to inflation, private consumption will fall by 1.7 per cent this year, Ifo says, adding that the figure will not rise again until 2024, when it is expected to post a 2.2 per cent increase.

site_title: Queues at SingPost outlets start two days ahead of general sale of Taylor Swift tickets
summary: Fans in Singapore are queuing up two days ahead of the general sale for Taylor Swift concert tickets, with many arriving at SingPost outlets in the early hours of the day. The queues started forming on Wednesday, with some fans camping out overnight to secure tickets. The pre-sale for United Overseas Bank (UOB) tickets sold out within three hours, leading to a frenzy of activity among Swifties. With the general sale set to begin on Friday, fans are bracing themselves for a potentially chaotic ticketing process, with some expressing anxiety and desperation for a chance to secure tickets to the American pop star's six shows at the National Stadium in March 2024.

images.alt_text: A queue for Coldplay concert tickets at the SingPost outlet in June.

(FILES) US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performs onstage on the first night of her "Eras Tour" at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, on March 31, 2023. Music megastars Taylor Swift and The Weeknd are among showbiz people invited to join the organization that votes on who gets Oscars, the body said on June 28.
Other invitees include Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, who directed "Everything Everywhere All at Once," which won seven Oscars this year including the prize for best picture.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its new crop of members of Tinseltown's most elite club numbers 398 people. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

site_title: Zuckerberg-Musk fight is on: Meta launches ‘Twitter Killer’ Threads app
summary: Meta's Mark Zuckerberg is launching Instagram's "Twitter Killer" Threads app, a clone of Twitter, in response to Elon Musk's chaotic decision-making at Twitter. The app is expected to gain a built-in user base and advertising apparatus, potentially siphoning ad dollars from Twitter. With over 2 billion monthly active Instagram users, Threads could rival Twitter's size if it convinces a quarter of them to join. Meta's move comes after months of Musk's struggles, and analysts predict investors will be excited about the prospect of a "Twitter-Killer" app.

images.alt_text: The limit took effect soon after Twitter began requiring users to log into an account on the social media platform to view tweets.
Threads, Instagram’s text-based conversation app, is expected to be released on Thursday.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as Fed minutes suggest more rate hikes ahead
summary: US stocks declined on July 5, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.4% to 34,288.64, as Treasury bond yields rose and minutes from the Federal Reserve's June meeting suggested more interest rate hikes ahead. The Fed voted to pause rate increases but policymakers believe two hikes are needed to bring inflation back down. The S&P 500 fell 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.3%. Despite the decline, some stocks rose, including General Motors and Meta Platforms, as investors await the launch of new services.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 29, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Banks move away from SMS OTPs in favour of app-based authentication methods
summary: Banks in Singapore are shifting away from SMS-based authentication methods, such as One-Time Passwords (OTPs), in favor of app-based authentication methods. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has required banks to phase out SMS OTPs for high-risk transactions, and the government is also working on a framework to share losses from digital banking scams. Several local banks, including Citi, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, are already implementing app-based authentication methods, which are considered more secure. The move aims to strengthen the security of digital banking services and reduce the risk of phishing scams.

images.alt_text: SMSes is weak as an authentication factor, and users should be prepared to accept some inconveniences in exchange for stronger protections for their online accounts.
Organisations will need to register SMS sender IDs with IMDA, with registrations opening on Oct 31, 2022.
Experts say that banks should re-examine their goals and culture to ensure that the development of their digital platforms are not compromised.

“The repeated inconvenience caused to the public is unacceptable. The additional capital requirement imposed at this time underscores the seriousness with which MAS treats this matter. DBS Bank must spare no effort in dealing with the underlying issues leading to these disruptions.,” said Ho Hern Shin, deputy managing director of financial supervision at MAS.

site_title: Coco Lee, Hong Kong-born singer-songwriter, dies at 48 after suicide attempt
summary: Hong Kong-born singer-songwriter Coco Lee, 48, died after a suicide attempt at a Hong Kong hospital on July 5, 2023. Lee's two sisters stated she had sought professional help but ultimately succumbed to depression. Her 30-year career included notable performances in Disney's Mulan and Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. Born in 1975, Lee's father passed away before birth, and her mother moved her and sisters to the US before she was 9.

images.alt_text: In the latest Indiana Jones film, the titular character – played by Harrison Ford – races to retrieve an artefact that can change the course of history.

site_title: Can climate change cooperation curb chill in China-EU ties?
summary: China and the European Union have a long history of cooperation on climate change issues, with the EU's emissions trading system influencing China's carbon markets. Despite recent concerns over Beijing's surge in coal power, EU officials, including European Commission vice-president Frans Timmermans, believe China is willing to tackle climate change. The EU and China have a 2015 climate change declaration that aims to develop a low-carbon economy, and cooperation is seen as a key driver of global warming action. China's planned investment in the green economy is significant, and EU officials recognize the opportunities for commercial collaboration in the clean technology sector.

images.alt_text: The biggest increase came from Asia’s emerging markets, in large part due to coal-fired power.
For France, China is an important trading partner, particular as one of the largest markets for French luxury goods makers.

site_title: ‘Almost all’ Fed officials agreed to skip June hike: minutes
summary: The US Federal Reserve agreed to hold interest rates steady in June, defying expectations of a hike, as officials sought to buy time to assess the economy's progress. Almost all Fed officials deemed it appropriate to maintain the federal funds rate at 5% to 5.25%, citing uncertainty about inflation and the economy. The decision marked a shift in strategy, with policymakers focusing on the amount of policy tightening needed rather than maintaining a steady pace of increases. Despite a mild recession expected later this year, avoiding a downturn is now seen as less likely than previously.

site_title: Djokovic celebrates 350th Grand Slam win at Wimbledon
summary: Novak Djokovic won his 350th Grand Slam singles match at Wimbledon, defeating Jordan Thompson 6-3, 7-6 (7/4), 7-5. The 36-year-old Serbian player is targeting an eighth Wimbledon title, which would draw him level with Roger Federer's men's record. Djokovic will meet Tomas Martin Etcheverry or Stan Wawrinka in the third round. This victory also puts him one win away from tying Margaret Court's all-time record for 24 career Grand Slam titles.

images.alt_text: Ten highlights from the 2023 French Open
Djokovic is the first man to win all four majors at least three times and is once again halfway to the first calendar Grand Slam since Rod Laver in 1969.

site_title: Union Investment puts VisionCrest Commercial on market; guide price above S$470 million
summary: Union Investment, a German asset manager, is putting VisionCrest Commercial, an 11-storey freehold office building in Singapore, on the market with a guide price of over S$470 million. The building has a net lettable area of 148,854 sq ft, valued at S$3,157 psf, and a strata area of 154,711 sq ft, valued at S$3,038 psf. The sale price reflects the building's prime location along Penang Road.

site_title: China’s metal export curbs reignites global companies’ hunt for stable suppliers
summary: China has restricted exports of gallium and germanium, key metals used in semiconductors and defence technology, to protect national security. The move has prompted global companies to re-evaluate their reliance on China as a supplier, with some looking to diversify to Australia, Europe, and the US. US and its allies are concerned, with a top Chinese trade advisor warning that this is "just a start" and the US will engage with its partners to address the issue. China's move is seen as a response to US export restrictions on key technologies, and tensions between the two countries are expected to escalate.

images.alt_text: China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.
China did not control an absolute amount of germanium in the world as it did with rare earths.

site_title: ChatGPT-maker OpenAI says it is doubling down on preventing AI from ‘going rogue’
summary: OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT, plans to invest in preventing its AI from "going rogue" by training systems using human feedback, assisting human evaluation, and conducting alignment research. Co-founders Ilya Sutskever and Jan Leike warn that superintelligent AI could arrive this decade, posing a threat to humanity, and emphasize the need for breakthroughs in alignment research to ensure AI remains beneficial.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of OpenAI is displayed near a response by its AI chatbot ChatGPT on its website, in this illustration picture taken February 9, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
ChatGPT set off a frenzied use of generative AI in daily tasks from writing to coding and reached 100 million monthly active users in January, two months after its launch.

site_title: EU pushes to slash food waste
summary: The European Union has proposed a plan to reduce food waste by 30% by 2030, targeting households, retailers, and restaurants. The EU estimates 59 million tonnes of food waste annually, valued at 132 billion euros. The plan aims to cut unnecessary water, fertilizer, and energy use in food production, processing, and preservation. No targets are set for the agricultural sector, but the European Environmental Bureau suggests a 50% reduction across all sectors would be more effective in cutting food waste to sustainable levels.

site_title: China’s FX market stable, cross-border flows basically balanced: state media
summary: China's foreign exchange market remains stable with cross-border flows balanced, according to a state media commentary. Despite the yuan's 5% decline against the US dollar, solid fundamentals are expected to support the currency. China's economic recovery is expected to continue, with policies stimulating the real economy and diminishing the impact of US interest rate hikes. The country has sufficient policy tools to deal with potential risks, including tools to calm market volatility and ensure market smooth operation.

images.alt_text: After growing at a faster-than-expected pace in the first quarter, China has lost steam amid steepening deflation, high youth unemployment and sluggish foreign demand.
Beijing has rolled out a raft of measures to prop up the economy, including asking big banks to lower their deposit rates at least twice in less than a year to boost lending, squeezing their margins.

site_title: More than just an annoyance to fans, scalpers threaten the economic case for concerts
summary: Scalpers are threatening the economic case for concerts in Singapore, with their automated bots and high demand prices potentially deterring overseas fans and weakening the country's tourism industry. The practice could also harm Singapore's reputation as a hub for live entertainment. The Singapore Tourism Board's efforts to secure major acts like Taylor Swift may not yield economic returns if scalpers dominate the ticket market, and the government should consider anti-scalping legislation to address the issue.

images.alt_text: With more tickets going to scalpers out to make a quick buck, concertgoers increasingly find themselves forced to fork out more money for scalped tickets – or be left out in the cold.
US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performs onstage on the first night of her "Eras Tour" at AT&T Stadium on March 31, 2023, in Arlington, Texas. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

site_title: US crude oil gains on supply cuts, focus shifts to holiday demand
summary: US crude oil prices rose 3% on Wednesday, narrowing the gap with global benchmark Brent after Saudi Arabia and Russia announced supply cuts. US crude stocks fell 4.4 million barrels last week, while petrol and distillate inventories rose. The price gain was attributed to the supply cuts and a post-holiday response, with Brent crude futures rising 0.5%. Analysts expect the market to remain cautious, with US and European central banks expected to increase interest rates to tame high inflation.

images.alt_text: The total cuts now stand at more than 5 million bpd, or 5 per cent of global oil output.

site_title: ChatGPT’s explosive growth shows first decline in traffic since launch
summary: ChatGPT, the popular AI chatbot, saw its first decline in monthly traffic since launch, with a 9.7% drop in June from May, according to analytics firm Similarweb. The decline is attributed to the novelty of the chatbot wearing off and increased competition from other AI-powered chatbots. Despite this, ChatGPT remains one of the top 20 websites in the world, with over 1.5 billion monthly visits, and has generated significant revenue for its parent company, OpenAI, projected at $200 million this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 15, 2023 this photo illustration shows the ChatGPT logo at an office in Washington, DC. - Shares in companies that specialize in publishing school textbooks and offering online classes took a big hit on May 2, 2023 after signs emerged that AI-bots such as ChatGPT were eating into their business. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: Penguin privatisation offer extended again to Jul 20
summary: The closing date for Penguin International's privatisation offer has been extended to Jul 20, allowing the consortium to acquire and delist the company. The offer, priced at S$0.83 a share, has garnered 87.83% of the total shares as of Jul 5. The original closing date was set for Jul 6.

site_title: ExxonMobil signals sharp profit drop, cites low natgas prices, refining margins
summary: ExxonMobil reported a sharp decline in second-quarter operating profits, dropping to about $7.8 billion, due to lower natural gas prices and weaker oil refining margins. This marks a significant decrease from the previous year's $17.85 billion, when surging energy prices boosted global results. The company's chemicals business performed better, with quarterly profits of $800 million, twice the level of the first quarter. ExxonMobil's second-quarter outlook also slipped from a record first-quarter profit of $11.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Exxon currently recovers about 10 per cent of shale resources from its operations.

site_title: Toyota US new car sales jump in sign of auto industry strength
summary: Toyota US new car sales jumped 15% in June to 195,448 vehicles, driven by increased demand for Camry sedans and RAV4 compact SUVs. This marks a 7.1% sales rise for the second quarter, with electrified vehicles also seeing a 29% jump. Despite higher interest rates, consumers remain interested in vehicles as production increases due to improved semiconductor supplies, indicating a strong auto industry.

site_title: US factory orders miss expectations in May
summary: US factory orders rose 0.3% in May, missing expectations, due to higher interest rates eroding demand and spending shifting to services. Manufacturing accounts for 11.1% of the economy and has been constrained by weak demand, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing PMI staying below the 50 threshold for the eighth straight month. Despite pockets of strength in transportation equipment and machinery, orders fell 0.5% excluding transportation, and unfilled orders increased 0.8%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee works on an assembly line at startup Rivian Automotive's electric vehicle factory in Normal, Illinois, U.S. April 11, 2022. REUTERS/Kamil Krzaczynski/File Photo

site_title: Business without borders: Navigating modern payment trends and consumer behaviours
summary: Singapore-based businesses are expanding into the US market, with 20% more having a presence there since the pandemic. Consumers expect seamless and simple online shopping experiences, with 63% willing to pay more for better customer service. To succeed, businesses must offer more payment options, such as loyalty rewards and local payment platforms, and prioritize transparency in building customer trust. The growth of live commerce, which is expected to triple in value by 2025 in the US, also presents opportunities for businesses to reach customers.

images.alt_text: US Consumer spending edges up 0.1 per cent last month, the Commerce Department says.

site_title: Catching tailwinds for business and investors : Why demographics matter more than ever
summary: The global population has crossed the 8 billion mark, but demographic trends suggest many countries are on the cusp of significant population decline. South Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Japan are expected to experience rapid population decline, with some projections indicating they could become "extinct" in the next 50 years. In contrast, countries in South Asia, the Middle East, and Africa are expected to continue growing. Understanding these trends can offer insights for businesses and investors, who can identify opportunities and avoid pitfalls by analyzing demographic data and trends.

images.alt_text: The working age population is expected to rapidly decline from 2027, according to the study by independent think-tank Recruit Works Institute.
South Korea faces the prospect of its population of 51 million people more than halving by the end of this century.
The proportion of Indonesians aged over 65 years old is estimated to rise to 14.6 per cent in 2045, from 6.2 per cent in 2020.
Vietnam will soon become the 16th country in the world with more than 100 million people.
The effects of ageing on Singapore's property market
With two-thirds of India’s 1.4 billion population in the working age, its “vibrancy” and “dynamism” contrast with many Asian peers grappling with shrinking populations.

site_title: China’s Xpeng sees sales turnaround in second half with new EV model
summary: Xpeng, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, forecasts sharp growth in deliveries in the second half of the year due to its newly launched G6 pure electric crossover. The company received a "significant" amount of orders for the G6, which is priced 20% lower than Tesla's Model Y. Xpeng expects to increase monthly sales to 15,000 units in the third quarter and over 20,000 units in the final quarter, nearly doubling sales from the previous quarter. The G6's advanced driver assistance system and smart-driving technologies are seen as key differentiators.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower ahead of Fed minutes
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Wednesday, July 5, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's June meeting minutes for clues on monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 73.75 points, or 0.21%, to 34,344.72, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. Sino-US tensions and weak economic data from Beijing contributed to the decline.

site_title: Freehold retail podium of 53 units at The Linq @ Beauty World up for sale at S$136 million
summary: A freehold retail podium at The Linq @ Beauty World in Singapore, comprising 53 strata-titled units, has been put up for sale through an expression of interest exercise at an indicative guide price of S$136 million. The retail units, with a combined strata area of approximately 29,676 square feet, are provisioned for restaurant use. The sale comes as the strata commercial market is stirring with activity, with several portfolios being put on the market and interest picking up from investors due to the removal of Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty (ABSD) on commercial properties.

images.alt_text: Monetising of Top Global's units at 15 Scotts Road should have taken place while the group was a public-listed entity.

Quality retail assets, such as established malls with good catchment or retail podiums of integrated developments, are tightly held, and such limited supply will provide room for capital appreciation.

Even though the current strata retail market is nowhere near the sales performances recorded in 2012 and 2013, there are promising signs that interest in strata-titled retail space could rekindle in the next 12 to 18 months. While the lingering threat of Covid-19 remains, Singapore has resolutely reopened at a time when revenge travel and shopping is gaining momentum.

site_title: Bank of America, Citigroup in talks with Fed after stress test results
summary: Bank of America and Citigroup are in discussions with the Federal Reserve to resolve discrepancies between the central bank's annual stress test results and the lenders' forecasts. The discussions aim to resolve differences in comprehensive income and non-interest income for Bank of America and Citi, respectively, to allow Bank of America to move ahead with its dividend plans. The talks are ongoing to address these discrepancies and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

images.alt_text: Small local banks and mid-sized regional banks were exempted from these tests.

site_title: EGMs on contentious issues must allow for more shareholder participation
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has revoked temporary measures allowing alternative arrangements for listed companies' general meetings, requiring them to hold physical meetings starting July 1. This change affects annual general meetings (AGMs) and extraordinary general meetings (EGMs), which will now have to return to physical mode. Some Singapore companies have announced holding only physical AGMs, limiting shareholder participation. Stricter rules around meeting formats, including EGMs, could benefit investors by allowing more shareholder participation and clarity on corporate issues.

site_title: PetroVietnam Gas talking to ExxonMobil, Novatek on LNG supply
summary: PetroVietnam Gas is in talks with ExxonMobil and Novatek to secure long-term LNG supplies for Vietnam's future LNG-fired power plants. The company aims to develop 13 LNG-fired power plants with a combined capacity of 22.4 gigawatts by 2030. PetroVietnam Gas discussed LNG supply opportunities with ExxonMobil, with the US company evaluating various LNG supply opportunities in South-east Asia. Novatek expressed interest in supplying LNG for the 2023-2026 period, with the terminal set to receive Vietnam's first LNG cargo next week.

site_title: SingPost may be allowed to ‘adjust’ postage rates to remain a viable business
summary: The Singapore government is considering allowing SingPost to adjust postage rates to remain a viable business, following a 70.3% decline in net profit to S$24.7 million in FY2023. The review, conducted by the Infocomm Media Development Authority, will examine SingPost's costs and operations, including optimizing post office services. The government aims to ensure the postal service remains relevant in a highly digitalized context, with a focus on logistics and e-commerce players. The adjustments must be sufficient to allow SingPost's business model to remain viable without requiring direct government funding.

images.alt_text: As a public postal licensee, Singapore Post needs to provide and maintain posting boxes and post offices throughout Singapore.
The board recommends a final dividend of S$0.40 per share, subject to approval from shareholders at its next annual general meeting.
