site_title: Europe’s biggest IPO raises 8.1 billion lei for Templeton-led fund
summary: Franklin Templeton-managed Fondul Proprietatea raised 8.1 billion lei (S$2.4 billion) in Romania's largest ever initial public offering (IPO) for hydropower utility Hidroelectrica, valuing the company at about 47 billion lei. The IPO, Europe's biggest since Porsche, will help increase liquidity for the Bucharest Stock Exchange, potentially securing a long-awaited upgrade to emerging-market status. The sale also fulfils a milestone in Romania's recovery and resilience plan, unlocking 29 billion euros in EU funding.

site_title: India looking at ways to broaden rupee's global reach
summary: India is exploring ways to broaden the global reach of its rupee currency, with a working group of the Reserve Bank of India recommending enabling the rupee as an additional settlement currency in multilateral mechanisms and promoting its use in international trade and capital account transactions. The group also suggested liberalizing the capital account, opening rupee accounts for non-residents, and strengthening financial markets. These measures aim to increase the rupee's international acceptance and promote India's economic progress, particularly in global trade.

images.alt_text: The world’s fastest-growing major economy is trying to use the rupee for its global payments to cut its US dollar demand

site_title: Indian state-run banks to be cautious buyers of government bonds as yields rise
summary: Indian state-run banks are likely to be cautious buyers of government bonds due to rising yields, which have jumped 14 basis points since the Reserve Bank of India's June monetary policy decision. Despite this, banks will continue to increase their exposure at a gradual pace. They net bought bonds worth nearly 285 billion rupees in June-July, with yields expected to rise further and potentially reach 7.20% in the coming months.

images.alt_text: South Korean bonds attracted net purchases of US$8.2 billion, the highest since June 2021.

site_title: Asia Vets’ clinics to close temporarily after licences expired due to ‘administrative oversight’
summary: Asia Vets Holdings' veterinary clinics have temporarily closed due to expired licences resulting from an "administrative oversight". The company, which operates AVH Animal Ark in Binjai Park and Tampines, has submitted licence renewal applications and expects new licences to be issued within a week. Measures have been implemented to strengthen internal control procedures, including an "auto-alert" system and monitoring by key management. The clinics are expected to reopen once the new licences are issued.

images.alt_text: Asia Vets Holdings proposes acquisition of fintech company that will result in reverse takeover

site_title: Soilbuild units bag S$118.7 million in contracts, including supplying precast parts for HDB
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group's subsidiaries have secured S$118.7 million in contracts, including supplying precast components for Housing and Development Board (HDB) projects in Singapore. Precast Concrete will deliver precast components to Tampines, Woodlands, Bishan, and Choa Chu Kang projects, while SB Procurement will build a sustainable logistics facility with four sustainability certifications. The contracts are expected to start in Q3 and be completed in Q2 2025, bringing the group's order book to S$693 million.

images.alt_text: Soilbuild's order book comprises S$384.6 million in construction projects and S$108.1 million in precast supply and delivery projects.

Myanmar was the first market that Soilbuild went into when it expanded overseas. It tapped into the lack of supply for high-end residential development project in Yangon and developed Rosehill Residences which was launched in 2015.
Soilbuild Construction appoints new CEO

site_title: American Equity accepts Brookfield’s US$4.3 billion takeover
summary: Brookfield Reinsurance accepted a US$4.3 billion takeover bid from American Equity Investment Life Holding, acquiring all remaining shares for US$55 apiece. The deal represents a 35% premium to American Equity's closing price on June 23. The acquisition boosts Brookfield Reinsurance's assets under management to around US$100 billion, and will allow the company to accelerate growth in collaboration with distribution partners.

images.alt_text: Brookfield emerges as the frontrunner to acquire the Network International after interest from a consortium including CVC Capital Partners and Francisco Partners cooled.

site_title: TikTok emerges as threat to Amazon with US$20 billion shopping pilot
summary: TikTok's shopping pilot, TikTok Shop, has emerged as a significant threat to Amazon with a projected US$20 billion gross merchandise value by the end of the year. The feature, launched in Indonesia in 2021, has become a hit among the young, mobile-savvy population, with over 100 million monthly users spending over 100 minutes on the app daily. TikTok's success in Indonesia has given the company a template to take on Amazon in the US market, where it faces a possible ban due to national security concerns. With a growing presence in the US, TikTok is poised to compete with Amazon and other e-commerce players, potentially disrupting the retail industry and creating new tech unicorns in the region.

images.alt_text: “Europe is completely reorganising its digital space to both better protect EU citizens and enhance innovation for EU startups and companies,” EU industry chief Thierry Breton says.

This picture taken on April 4, 2023 shows employees working for a TikTok channel offering merchandise for sale through a TikTok livestream at a room in Jakarta. Despite a potential US ban over national security concerns, data shows the Chinese-owned app's rapid growth in Southeast Asia with Indonesia accounting for 70 percent of TikTok's $4.4 billion gross merchandise value in 2022. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP) / TO GO WITH: Indonesia-internet-economy-livestreaming-Tiktok, FOCUS by Agnes ANYA
Shopee accounted more almost half of South-east Asia's GMV for 2022, taking top spot among e-commerce players.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says new oil cuts show teamwork with Russia is strong
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia have deepened oil supply cuts, aiming to boost prices. The move, part of the Opec+ alliance, comes as the global economy faces challenges. Despite the cuts, oil prices remained lower than the $80-$100 per barrel needed by most Opec nations to balance their budgets. Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz Salman stated that Opec would do "whatever necessary" to support the market, indicating the alliance's commitment to cooperation with Russia. The US has called for increased production, but Saudi Arabia has rebuffed these calls.

images.alt_text: Saudi Minister of Energy Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman al-Saud speaks during a panel discussion at the 10th Arab-China Business Conference in Riyadh, on June 11, 2023. (Photo by Fayez NURELDINE / AFP)

site_title: Violins in the sun: Stradivari’s home workshop reopens in Italy
summary: The Casa Stradivari, Antonio Stradivari's 17th-century home workshop in Cremona, Italy, has reopened to visitors after a restoration project. The workshop, where Stradivari lived with his family and created his iconic violins, has been transformed into a centre for learning and a musical pilgrimage site. Visitors can now hone their skills in the original house and workshop, with two work benches and masterclasses for young musicians. Experts believe that the secret to the Stradivarius sound lies in the violins' exposure to the elements on the rooftop covered terrace, where Stradivari would dry his instruments in the sun.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS recorded a record net loss of S$30.8 billion for FY 2023 due to the tightening of the Singapore dollar to combat inflation. Retail sales in Singapore grew 1.8% in May but declined sequentially. Malaysia's unity government faces a test of its mandate in August state polls. MAS has allocated S$8 billion to its climate transition program and STT is issuing S$300 million in perpetual securities. The STI fell 0.6% due to weak economic data from Singapore and China.

site_title: PwC Australia ties Google to tax leak scandal: sources
summary: PwC Australia has been linked to the tax leak scandal, with two sources claiming the firm provided confidential information about the start date of a new tax law to Google in 2015. The leak was sparked by a former PwC partner, Peter Collins, who shared confidential drafts with colleagues, including a Google employee. PwC has denied any wrongdoing and says its clients were not involved, but the scandal has led to the resignation of its CEO and the loss of several high-profile clients.

images.alt_text: Three of the partners were singled out for actions that “failed to meet their professional responsibilities”.

PwC's brand is damaged by revelations that a former partner shared with colleagues confidential government plans to prevent tax avoidance, which were then used to pitch multinational companies for work.
The firm has already placed nine partners on leave and named four former partners directly involved in the breach who have since left the firm.
PwC on Sunday announced the sale of its government business for A$1.
PwC is reportedly planning to sell off its government consulting arm to private equity investor Allegro Funds for just A$1 (S$0.90).

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades OCBC to ‘neutral’ on more conservative NIM
summary: RHB downgraded OCBC to "neutral" from "buy" due to limited upside potential and a more conservative net interest margin (NIM) forecast. The research team expects NIM to compress by 8 basis points for FY2024 and 5 basis points for FY2025, resulting in a 6-8% drop in OCBC's FY2024-25 net profit. The downgrade follows RHB's assumption of a slower macroeconomic recovery in China and peaking NIM ratios.

images.alt_text: OCBC group CEO Helen Wong notes that the bank has been in a good position to capture the flow business between Asean and China.

site_title: India in talks to supply green hydrogen to EU, Singapore
summary: India has discussed a possible deal to supply over 11 million metric tons of green hydrogen to the European Union and Singapore, with the EU and Singapore investing in Indian clean energy projects and claiming carbon credits. The proposed agreements would allow for the use of carbon credits linked to producing green hydrogen. India aims to become a major green hydrogen exporter, with plans to produce 5 million tonnes by 2030. The talks are ongoing, with Indian renewable companies and government officials involved in the negotiations.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on April 18, 2023 shows the Green Hydrogen Plant built by Spanish company Iberdrola in Puertollano. - From Andalusia to the Basque Country, green hydrogen megaprojects are multiplying in Spain, a leading country in this promising sector. A bet, while the economic model for this energy of the future remains to be found. (Photo by Valentin BONTEMPS / AFP)

site_title: China extends squeezed-out foreign pharmaceuticals firms an olive branch
summary: China's Commerce Minister Wan Wentao has extended an olive branch to foreign pharmaceutical firms, promising "more development opportunities" for them, including the pharmaceutical industry. The announcement comes after foreign companies, such as AstraZeneca and Pfizer, expressed frustration over government procurement policies pricing them out of the market. The government has maintained a drug procurement program that forces companies to slash their prices, but Wang's statement suggests a shift towards more cooperation. The meeting with representatives from 12 companies resulted in 25 specific suggestions to be taken forward.

site_title: Taiwan’s Powerchip to team up with SBI to build foundry in Japan
summary: Taiwan's Powerchip Semiconductor and Tokyo-based SBI Holdings are teaming up to build a foundry in Japan, aiming to meet growing demand for locally sourced chips. SBI will help raise funds for the venture, which plans to produce 40nm and 55nm automotive and industrial chips initially. The project, which is expected to begin with a 40nm and 55nm foundry, aims to help Japan regain semiconductor leadership. The foundry is part of Japan's efforts to triple domestic chip production by 2030, with the government investing billions of US dollars in subsidies.

images.alt_text: China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.
China did not control an absolute amount of germanium in the world as it did with rare earths.

The groundwork will include supporting promising startups and big enterprises, as well as pushing forward discussions on universal basic income as AI makes more jobs obsolete, says Japan's Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura.

site_title: Chinese AI startup Fourth Paradigm receives China’s nod for Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese AI startup Fourth Paradigm has completed procedural work for a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), becoming one of a handful of companies to receive approval from China's securities regulator since new rules became effective in March. The company, which has received investments from Goldman Sachs and state-backed funds, has successfully completed the offshore listing filing process and is expected to go public soon, despite regulatory scrutiny and the addition to the US "Entity List". This approval marks a significant milestone for the company, which has products used in various sectors including finance and healthcare.

site_title: US dollar steady before Fed minutes; yen hovers near 145-mark
summary: The US dollar remained steady against major currencies, holding at 103.15, ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes, which could provide insight into interest rate changes. The US dollar-yen rate hovered near 144.3 yen, below the 145 level that prompted intervention by Japanese authorities last autumn. Markets are pricing in an 86% chance of a quarter-point rate hike in July and a 20% chance of a 25-basis point increase in September. The euro and sterling were also relatively flat, while the Australian dollar fell 0.4% to US$0.6663.

site_title: Coaching great Ancelotti takes on Brazil challenge
summary: Carlo Ancelotti, a renowned Italian coach, is set to become the first foreigner in almost 60 years to coach Brazil's national team. Ancelotti, 64, will take over the team in time for the 2024 Copa America in the US, succeeding Fernando Diniz. The Brazilian Football Confederation was drawn to Ancelotti's successful European career and his ability to develop close relations with players. Ancelotti's appointment aims to deliver Brazil's sixth World Cup trophy in 2026, a goal that has been a long-standing ambition for the team.

site_title: Sweden real estate concerns are exaggerated, pension funds say
summary: Sweden's real estate industry has faced significant concerns in the past year due to rising interest rates and debt issues. However, some major pension funds, such as AMF and AP1, are pushing back against exaggerated worries, stating that the country's financial stability is not at risk. Despite this, commercial real estate companies face significant maturities and regulators warn of a potential negative spiral if forced sales occur. Fund executives believe the uncertainty will take time to clear, allowing for a more stable market in 2024.

images.alt_text: The SBB headquarters in Stockholm. Photographer: Jonas Ekblom/Bloomberg

site_title: Chinese automakers to take majority of home market for first time: forecast
summary: Chinese automakers are poised to control over 50% of the cars sold in their home market this year, marking the first time they have dominated the market. This shift is attributed to competitive pricing, faster rollouts of new models, and the rise of domestic electric carmakers like BYD, Nio, and Xpeng Motors. Established global brands like VW and Toyota, which previously dominated the market through joint ventures, are being surpassed by Chinese automakers.

images.alt_text: Deliveries from Tesla’s Shanghai plant rise almost 20 per cent from a year earlier in June to 93,680 vehicles

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower as weak economic data weighs on sentiment; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% on Wednesday, July 5, due to weak economic data from Singapore and China. Retail sales in Singapore grew 1.8% year-on-year in May, down from 3.7% in April. In China, the Caixin China General Services Business Activity Index fell to 53.9 in June, from 57.1 in May. Investors expect Chinese policymakers to support domestic demand, which could impact global markets.

images.alt_text: Local manufacturers are bracing for a dour outlook going into the second half of the year, amid uncertainties in the global economic environment, said SIPMM.
Economists expect tourism to support retail sales, after on-year growth eases to 1.8% in May
After growing at a faster-than-expected pace in the first quarter, China has lost steam amid steepening deflation, high youth unemployment and sluggish foreign demand.

site_title: COE prices dip in all categories except for Category A cars
summary: COE prices for July's first round of bidding showed minor decreases except for Category A cars, which rose 0.8% to S$97,000. Category B prices fell 2.5% to S$118,002, while Category C prices dropped 1.1% to S$82,223. Category D prices fell 5.8% to S$10,090, and Category E prices dipped 1.6% to S$121,000. Industry experts attribute the price fluctuations to soft demand for mainstream cars and relatively small COE quotas.

images.alt_text: The price for Category B COEs has reached a new record of S$121,000.

Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD and its Dolphin compact hatchback on display at Waterway Point. BYD's most compact car to date, the Dolphin is one of the cheapest EV on the Singapore market.

site_title: Thai stocks turning attractive as House Speaker appointment dampens political risk: Nomura
summary: Thai stocks are seen as more attractive for medium-term investors as the country's political environment improves following the appointment of Wan Muhamad Noor Matha as House Speaker. The selection is viewed as a compromise between coalition parties, reducing political uncertainty and increasing the chances of a stable, civilian-led government. Nomura recommends focusing on consumer, tourism, and reopening-related sectors, citing the recovery of the tourism industry as a key driver of economic growth. Preferred companies include Central Pattana, CP All, Airports of Thailand, and Central Retail.

images.alt_text: House Speaker Wan Muhamad Noor Matha has said parliament will vote for its prime minister on Jul 13.

Tourists and locals browse goods and food at a walking street market in Phuket, Thailand, on Sunday, Oct. 2, 2022. Thailand will end a nationwide state of emergency declared in the wake of Covid outbreak after the Southeast Asian nation downgraded the virus from a “dangerous” communicable disease to one that only requires surveillance. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: Tesla regains China momentum as clouds over EV sector disperse
summary: Tesla's China deliveries surged 20% in June to 93,680 vehicles, driven by improved market conditions after supply chain issues and weak consumer demand dissipated. This trend is expected to continue, with China's Passenger Car Association forecasting a 30% increase in new-energy vehicle sales. The rise in EV sales is attributed to growing interest in clean cars, as concerns over the industry's challenges dissipate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of car manufacturer Tesla is seen at a branch office in Bern, Switzerland October 28, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: NetEase’s 85% stock comeback defies China’s slowdown
summary: NetEase's stock has surged 85% since October, defying China's economic slowdown, driven by recent blockbuster video game hits such as Justice Mobile, Eggy Party, and Racing Master. The company's strong gaming pipeline, including the highly anticipated Where Wind Meets, is expected to boost sentiment, with analysts predicting a 17% rise in shares. NetEase has edged out rivals Tencent and Bilibili to become one of the best performers on the Hang Seng Tech Index, with analysts citing its attractive upsides and proven track record in expanding into new genres.

images.alt_text: The NetEase Inc. headquarters in Hangzhou, China, on Sunday, May 22, 2023. NetEase is scheduled to release earnings results on May 25. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Britain to set up real-time bond and stock trading record
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is proposing to create a real-time record of stock and bond prices, known as a "consolidated tape," to increase transparency, access to trading, and cut costs. The FCA aims to implement the regulatory framework by 2024, starting with a bonds market tape, followed by stocks. The move aims to bolster the UK's position as a global financial centre, particularly after Brexit. The FCA's plan is in line with the EU's plan to introduce tapes for stocks and bonds, and is expected to increase investor confidence and reduce trading costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, June 5, 2020.  REUTERS/Yves Herman//File Photo

site_title: Shipping needs nuclear power to solve its emissions problem
summary: Shipping's carbon emissions are expected to reach net-zero by 2050, with the industry relying on alternative fuels such as nuclear power, ammonia, and methanol. The sector's massive energy needs, equivalent to Brazil's consumption, make it difficult to achieve this goal with renewable sources like solar and wind. Nuclear power, already used in military vessels, is being considered as a zero-carbon alternative, but regulatory hurdles and public perception issues hinder its adoption.

images.alt_text: RINA has announced the approval in principle of Swedish designer FKAB Marine Design’s hydrogen powered medium range (MR) Tanker.
strait31 - Pic for Strait Talk 31 Aug 22. Ulsteins Thor project would use nuclear energy to fuel a fleet of electric powered expedition cruise ships.

site_title: Thailand cuts full-year inflation forecast as prices trend lower
summary: Thailand's inflation forecast has been cut due to lower energy and food costs, with consumer prices expected to rise 1-2% this year, down from 1.7-2.7% previously predicted. The Bank of Thailand is likely to stick with monetary tightening despite easing price pressures, citing risks from a tourism-led economic pickup and potential government spending. The central bank may pause rate hikes when it meets on August 2, with a softer core inflation reading in July providing more leeway.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand’s (BOT) new guidelines will outline sustainable ways to resolve the household debt, according to assistant director Suwannee Jatsadasak.

site_title: UK’s water watchdog says it should have stopped debt binge
summary: The UK's water regulator, Ofwat, says it should have stopped Thames Water's debt binge in the mid-2000s, as the company faces a £13 billion debt and is seeking £1 billion in equity funding. Thames Water's debt is considered acute due to "persistent poor performance" and "very high gearing." The regulator will rein in its debt target to 55% from 60% for the next cycle. Nationalisation of the utility has been considered, but Ofwat's head says this would not be done lightly.

images.alt_text: UK media said ministers were in talks about the possibility of temporarily bringing the utility company back into public hands under a so-called special administration regime.

site_title: ECB says consumer inflation expectations continue to decline
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported that consumer inflation expectations continued to decline in May, falling to 3.9% for the next 12 months and remaining unchanged at 2.5% for the next three years. This decline follows a drop in headline price gains, mainly driven by falling energy costs. However, underlying price pressures have remained robust. The ECB's president, Joachim Nagel, stated that the question of how much further interest rates need to rise cannot be answered at present, indicating that monetary tightening is likely to continue.

site_title: Ransomware attack cripples Japan’s biggest port, delaying cargo
summary: A ransomware attack on Japan's Port of Nagoya has crippled the country's biggest maritime port, disrupting cargo operations. The attack, which occurred on Tuesday morning, caused a container terminal to suffer an outage, with operations expected to resume Thursday. The attack, similar to others targeting major ports in Portugal and India, highlights the growing risk of cyberattacks disrupting supply chains. Toyota Motor, the world's largest carmaker, said the attack won't affect new car shipments but will delay the loading and unloading of parts.

site_title: Hues of Hope raises funds for The Salvation Army to provide trauma therapy for children
summary: An art auction, Hues of Hope, is raising funds for The Salvation Army to provide trauma therapy for children. The auction features 12 resin geode artworks created by children from The Salvation Army and volunteers from Peace of Art. The goal is to raise S$250,000 for specialized therapy for children who have experienced abuse or neglect. The artworks will be on exhibition until Jul 20, with the online auction closing on the same day.

images.alt_text: There were about 110 stalls at the event, which attracted about 10,000 visitors.
From left:  BT Editor Chen Huifen, Standard Chartered Bank, Tan Wei Zhi, Regional Head of Impact & Engagement, Singapore & Asia

site_title: AI marketing startup Needle raises US$1.2 million in pre-seed funding
summary: Needle, an AI marketing startup, has raised US$1.2 million in pre-seed funding led by Iterative, with participation from Ethos Fund, Goldbell Financial Services, and angel investor JJ Chai. The Singapore-based company will use the funds to grow its team, focusing on data scientists, AI trainers, and engineers. Needle uses generative AI to streamline ad campaigns for e-commerce brands, reducing overall marketing costs. Founded in 2022 by Kiyan Foroughi, Serene Gan, Jeannie Nguyen, and Rachelle Yee, the startup aims to bring down marketing costs using AI technology.

site_title: Malaysia’s unity government faces test of mandate in Aug 12 state polls
summary: Malaysia's unity government, led by Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, faces its first test of public support in six state polls on August 12, with rising support for the opposition's Parti Islam Se-Malaysia (PAS) described as a "green wave." Analysts expect the polls to indicate the strength of the opposition's challenge to the unity government, which has been in power since the 2022 general election. The polls will also affect future policy decisions, with some analysts suggesting the government may focus on religious concerns to regain support.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim waving to his supporters in one of the Hari Raya celebration events in Terengganu.

FILE PHOTO: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim leaves the lower house of parliament after receiving a vote of confidence, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia December 19, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: German services sector loses some shine as growth slows
summary: Germany's services sector experienced slower growth in June, with the composite PMI index falling to 50.6, a five-month low, from 53.9 in May. The decline is attributed to a recent loss of momentum in demand, following a similar trend in other European countries. Despite the slowdown, companies still expect growth and have hired slightly more staff, signaling confidence. The risk of a recession in the second half of the year has increased, according to chief economist Cyrus de la Rubia.

images.alt_text: The report gives an initial hint of weakness in a pivotal week for data showing the health of manufacturing in Germany after it suffered a recession earlier this year.

site_title: Fidelity, Abrdn hunt industries seen immune to China slowdown
summary: Fidelity Investments and Abrdn are focusing on China-related industries they expect to be resilient despite the country's economic slowdown. Fidelity is bullish on European luxury stocks and AI-related investments in China, while Abrdn favors state-owned property developers and electric vehicle manufacturers. Despite China's MSCI China Index falling 18% since January, these industries are seen as sheltered from the economic downturn. Abrdn also targets companies with strong earnings growth in the clean energy sector, which it believes will continue to grow in China.

images.alt_text: Fidelity is one of several big asset managers that have applied to list Bitcoin ETFs in recent weeks.

site_title: China bank shares slump in Hong Kong after Goldman downgrades
summary: China's banking shares in Hong Kong plummeted over 3% in the biggest daily drop in eight months, following Goldman Sachs' downgrade of top lenders including Agricultural Bank of China, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, and Industrial Bank. The downgrades raised concerns over local government debt, earnings risks, and diverging bank fortunes. Goldman expects Chinese banks' dividend yields to fall to 4-6% this year, down two percentage points from before, and revised down pre-provision operating profit estimates by 5-6%.

site_title: Foxconn Q2 sales slip 14%, Q3 outlook brighter ahead of year-end peak
summary: Foxconn's second-quarter revenue dropped 13.8% year-on-year to NT$1.3 trillion, in line with expectations. The company's smart consumer electronics products segment saw a decline, with June sales falling 19.7% year-on-year. However, Foxconn expects a brighter outlook for the third quarter ahead of the year-end peak shopping season, with revenue growth expected to be higher than seen in previous years.

images.alt_text: Foxconn also plans to set up a new factory in the central province of Nghe An.
Foxconn, formally called Hon Hai Precision Industry, says revenue last month reaches NT$450.7 billion, in line with its expectations.

site_title: Saudi oil cuts see buyers looking at crude from elsewhere
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia have pledged to prolong and deepen supply cuts, amounting to 3.1 million barrels a day, or 3% of global consumption, through August. This could lead Asia's oil refiners to seek alternative crude sources, such as the US, West Africa, and the North Sea, which could be a mixed blessing for Middle East producers.

images.alt_text: Oil pumping jacks, also known as "nodding donkeys", in an oilfield near in Russia. Russia, seeking to nudge up global oil prices in concert with Saudi Arabia, will reduce its oil exports by 500,000 bpd in August
Saudi Arabia in June unexpectedly raised prices for July-loading cargoes, eating into Asian refiners’ margins.

site_title: STB ‘remains confident’ in Jurong Lake District tourism potential despite lack of proposals
summary: Singapore's tourism board remains confident in the potential of a 6.8-hectare site in Jurong Lake District for a tourism development, despite no proposals being submitted last year. The site is adjacent to the new Science Centre and Jurong Lake Gardens. Minister of State Low Yen Ling stated that the board is monitoring market sentiments and exploring other possibilities to harness the site's potential. Upcoming transport links will enhance the area's attractiveness as a major employment centre, with plans to develop Jurong Lake District into a large mixed-use business district.

images.alt_text: Singapore Tourism Board seeks proposals for Jurong Lake tourism project
Despite the hefty price tag, leading developers should seriously consider participating in the tender for the Master Developer site at Jurong Lake District.

site_title: Japan's firms offer biggest pay hikes in 30 years; wage growth broadens
summary: Japan's largest trade union group reported that firms offered the largest pay hikes in 30 years, with an average increase of 3.6% or $99 per month. This trend is expected to revive anaemic consumer demand. The Bank of Japan is closely watching wage growth as it considers unwinding its ultra-loose monetary stimulus. Economists say rising wages will help stabilize inflation at 2% and put pressure on the central bank to scrap yield curve control sooner. The pay hikes, particularly among small and medium-sized enterprises, are seen as a positive sign for the economy.

images.alt_text: The government has scrapped strict pandemic-related border controls and reclassified Covid-19 as the same level as the seasonal flu.

site_title: MAS broadens tax perks to encourage single family offices to invest in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expanding tax incentives for single family offices (SFOs) to encourage them to invest in the country, particularly in environmental and social causes. MAS will now recognize grants for blended finance structures, overseas climate-related investments, and investments in non-listed Singapore operating companies. The incentives include up to two dollars of investments for every dollar of concessional capital invested and twice the amount invested in Singapore-listed equities. The move aims to increase contributions towards climate change and social causes, and expand the pool of available jobs for professionals in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Some 9 per cent of the world’s family offices are located in Asia, of which 59 per cent are in Singapore, according to the 2023 Global Family Office Compensation Benchmark Report.
The facade of the Monetary Authority of Singapore Building on May 30, 2023.
MAS believes the prevailing monetary policy stance was sufficiently tight and appropriate for securing medium-term price stability.

site_title: Seafood to beauty exports at risk over Japan’s Fukushima waste
summary: Japan's plan to discharge treated Fukushima wastewater into the Pacific Ocean is facing opposition, posing risks to key exports such as seafood and cosmetics. Despite existing curbs on some food products related to the 2011 meltdown, Japan's agricultural and seafood exports reached a record high last year. China has expressed grave concern over the plan, with Hong Kong planning to impose curbs on seafood from high-risk areas. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has confirmed the disposal strategy is safe and in line with global standards, but Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aims to gain international acceptance.

images.alt_text: Some neighbouring countries have also raised concern over the threat to the environment, with Beijing emerging as the biggest critic.
Japan plans to release 1.3 trillion tonnes of water used to cool the fuel rods of the Fukushima plant damaged by a massive earthquake and tsunami in 2011.

Japan has assured other nations that the release of the water is safe, is in line with standard industry practice and that it’s necessary, because about 1,000 storage tanks at Fukushima will hit capacity early in 2024.

site_title: Thai parliament to vote for prime minister on Jul 13: House Speaker
summary: Thailand's parliament will vote for a new prime minister on July 13, following Wan Muhamad Noor Matha's endorsement as House Speaker. The Move Forward party and Pheu Thai party, which secured 151 and 141 seats in the Lower House, respectively, are expected to propose Pita Limjaroenrat as the next premier. However, they are short of the 376 votes needed in the joint sitting, which includes a 250-member senate appointed during military rule, and Pita requires 312 votes.

site_title: Sembcorp ties up with Petronas renewables arm Gentari to explore clean energy solutions
summary: Sembcorp Industries has partnered with Gentari, the renewable energy arm of Petronas, to explore clean energy solutions in South-east Asia. The partnership aims to accelerate the expansion of renewables and hydrogen-related initiatives, including developing low-carbon hydrogen production facilities and transporting hydrogen to Singapore from Malaysia. Gentari's chief renewables officer, Low Kian Min, and Sembcorp's Singapore and SEA chief executive, Koh Chiap Khiong, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to drive clean energy adoption. The collaboration is seen as a strong potential for Malaysia's growing renewables sector.

site_title: Chinese developer’s US$1.8 billion distressed asset gets zero bids
summary: A US$1.8 billion project by defaulted Chinese developer Shimao Group Holdings failed to receive any bids at a forced auction, underscoring a lack of investment appetite in China's real estate sector. The land portfolio, equivalent to 34 football fields, was offered at a 20% discount to its appraised value. This sale comes amid a weakening economy and a fragile global commercial property market. China's real estate sector has failed to sustain a recovery, with investors becoming increasingly cautious about acquisitions and China Vanke stating the nation's home market is "worse than expected".

site_title: 5 Questions with the Grab alumnus building Asean’s expert network
summary: Grab's hyper-localized approach has inspired Benjamin Lee, co-founder of Sealed Network, to create a South-east Asia-focused expert network. Lee, formerly in business development at Grab and Huobi, aimed to fill the gap in expert networks for the Asean region. Sealed has since grown to 100,000 experts across four countries, with Lee emphasizing the importance of building connections and access, rather than linear networking. Lee attributes his success to being patient and taking stock of his experiences, and advises others to do the same.

site_title: German commercial property deals tumble 50% to five-year low
summary: Germany's commercial property market plummeted to a five-year low, with deal volumes declining 50% to €16.2 billion in the first half of 2023, a 50% drop from the previous six months. Rising interest rates have driven up borrowing costs, prompting buyers to demand higher yields and sellers to resist steep discounts. The effects are also visible in the residential market, with deals plunging 69% below the 10-year average. Industry experts predict a decade of limited earnings growth and a potential rebound if interest rates stabilize.

images.alt_text: One of the biggest retail property companies in the Nordic region has seen its credit rating cut to junk status. Citycon Oyj joined a growing list of so-called fallen angels within the region’s commercial property industry, including Swedish firms Samhallsbyggnadsbolaget i Norden AB (top) and Fastighets AB Balder.

site_title: Petrobras switches from asset seller to buyer as debt slumps
summary: Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil giant, is shifting from being an asset seller to a buyer after a decade of divesting refineries and oil-exploration blocks. The company's debt has dropped to its lowest level since 2010, and its CFO, Sergio Leite, plans to issue more debt to improve its profile. Petrobras will use the funds to buy assets, but will not go on an issuance spree to finance acquisitions, instead opting for partnerships and project finance. The company's debt ratios are expected to bottom out, and it aims to reduce its cost of capital by cancelling more expensive debt.

images.alt_text: Petrobras will shield consumers from sharp fuel-price swings and increase investments in refining projects to curb fuel imports.

site_title: Singapore property prices showing signs of moderating and stabilising: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore's housing market is showing signs of moderating and stabilizing, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Managing Director Ravi Menon. Prices have moderated and are stabilizing, with home sales reaching a one-year high in May before declining in the second quarter. The government's measures, including doubling stamp duties for foreign buyers, have helped curb investment demand. Rents for private apartments and public housing surged 27% and 25% respectively in May, but Menon expects the surge in rental prices to take time to resolve.

images.alt_text: Economists expect tourism to support retail sales, after on-year growth eases to 1.8% in May

site_title: MAS invests S$8 billion in climate transition
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has allocated S$8 billion, approximately 2% of its portfolio, to its climate transition programme. The investment excludes companies with significant asset stranding risks, but does not exclude entire carbon-intensive sectors. The programme aims to scale up as new data provides clarity, with plans to assess climate indices and their effectiveness in reducing climate risk. MAS also has a US$2 billion green investments programme and will focus on tilting its corporate bonds portfolio towards less carbon-intensive exposures.

site_title: UOL to sell Parkroyal Kitchener Hotel for S$525 million
summary: UOL Group has agreed to sell Parkroyal on Kitchener Road for S$525 million, a 24% premium to its latest valuation of S$423 million. The sale, expected to be completed on Oct 31, will allow UOL to "unlock the value of its investment" and reconstitute its property portfolio. The disposal will yield a S$446.2 million divestment gain, according to Citi's investment research arm, and has been described as a "pleasant surprise" by the firm.

site_title: MAS posts record S$30.8 billion loss following Sing dollar tightening to bring down inflation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) posted a record net loss of S$30.8 billion for the 2023 financial year due to monetary policy tightening to combat inflation. The loss, largely attributed to a strengthening Singapore dollar, is the largest in MAS's history. Despite this, MAS managing director Ravi Menon believes the prevailing monetary policy stance is sufficient for securing medium-term price stability. The central bank's capital and reserves stood at $34.3 billion, and it raised its issued and paid-up capital to ensure well-capitalization.

site_title: Philippine inflation slows in June, supports extended rate pause
summary: The Philippine inflation rate slowed in June, with a 5.4% increase, its slowest pace since April last year. This eased pressure on the central bank to raise interest rates, supporting expectations for a rate pause. The year-to-date average inflation rate is 7.2%, below the forecast of 5.5%. The central bank expects inflation to gradually return to its 2-4% target in the fourth quarter, barring supply shocks.

images.alt_text: A beach on the Philippine island of Boracay. Philippine tourism officials were left red-faced after the creators of a video promoting the archipelago nation as a holiday destination admitted that they had tried to pass off stock shots of other countries as Philippine ones.

site_title: Airline to rent clothing to passengers for vacations, business trips
summary: Japan Airlines and Sumitomo are launching a clothing rental service for tourists and business travelers visiting Japan, starting from July. The service, available on a trial basis through August 2024, allows customers to select and rent up to eight outfits for two weeks, with prices ranging from $37 to $127. The rental apparel will come from overstock, helping minimize waste and reducing carbon emissions.

site_title: Shares in K-Pop agencies fall after report of antitrust probe
summary: Shares in K-Pop agencies HYBE, SM Entertainment, and YG Entertainment fell on Wednesday after South Korea's antitrust watchdog began investigating potential infractions of subcontracting rules. The Korea Fair Trade Commission is looking into practices such as verbal contracts, unfair contracts, and delayed payments. No specific charges have been brought, but HYBE's shares fell 2.1%, SM Entertainment's fell 1.5%, and YG Entertainment's fell 0.4%. The agencies did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: India’s Genus Power partners with GIC affiliate for funding smart metering projects
summary: India's Genus Power Infrastructures partnered with GIC's affiliate to fund smart metering projects, with an initial commitment of $2 billion. GIC will hold a 74% stake, while Genus will hold 26%. Genus will supply smart meters and services, and GIC will invest $85.37 million in Genus Power through warrants. The platform aims to bid on projects under India's Revamped Distribution Sector Scheme, with plans to install 250 million meters by 2025 at a $30 billion investment.

site_title: New players can enter South Korea’s banking sector for first time in 30 years
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission has allowed new domestic players to enter the country's banking industry for the first time in 30 years, paving the way for competition and potentially lowering interest-rate costs for consumers. The move aims to address criticism of excessive profits by major lenders, who have been accused of rewarding executives with bonuses instead of returning profits to citizens. Five major lenders dominate the sector, but the regulator has expanded licensing to financial firms, including regional banks and online-only lenders.

images.alt_text: Core inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, slowed to 3.5 per cent from 3.9 per cent a month before, marking the slowest annual rise since May, 2022.

site_title: What are gallium and germanium? Niche metals hit by China curbs
summary: China is restricting exports of gallium and germanium, crucial metals used in chipmaking, communications equipment, and defense. Gallium and germanium have a vast array of specialist uses, with China's curbs potentially escalating the trade war with the US and Europe. The move may impact global supply chains and technology industries.

images.alt_text: China produces most of the world’s gallium and germanium.
China did not control an absolute amount of germanium in the world as it did with rare earths.
Gallium and germanium are used in a wide range of products such as solar panels, lasers, night-vision goggles and computer chips.

site_title: Economists expect tourism to support retail sales, after on-year growth eases to 1.8% in May
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 1.8% year-over-year in May, down from 3.7% in April, according to the Department of Statistics. On a month-on-month basis, sales were down 0.2%. Economists attribute the moderation to "less supportive base effects," indicating that retail sales growth has already peaked.

site_title: Osaka’s evergreen appeal
summary: Osaka, Japan's third-largest city, is gaining popularity among tourists, known for its laid-back appeal, friendly locals, and affordable prices. The city offers a unique blend of traditional and modern experiences, including its birthplace of popular street foods like okonomiyaki and takoyaki. Osaka is also a hub for foodies, with Michelin-starred restaurants, and art lovers can explore exhibitions at National Gallery, including a new show on calligraphy and abstraction in South-east Asian Islamic art.

site_title: Competing with the big boys in public relations
summary: Singapore-based PR firm Redhill Communications aims to list on the New York Stock Exchange in 2024. Founded in 2014 by Jacob Puthenparambil, the company has grown to over 200 employees across 20 countries, becoming the first Singapore company to rank in the PRovoke Media's Global Top 250 PR Agency Ranking. Redhill's success is attributed to its focus on the venture capital industry, securing contracts with firms like Jungle Ventures and Emirates, and its acquisition strategy, which has expanded its services and client base. The company plans to raise S$20 million through an IPO to fund further acquisitions and growth.

site_title: China’s services activity softens as recovery falters: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at the slowest pace in five months in June, with the Caixin-S&P Global services PMI easing to 53.9 from 57.1 in May. The slowdown was driven by weakening demand, steepening deflation, high youth unemployment, and sluggish foreign demand, raising pressure on the government to support growth. Business activity and new orders expanded at slower rates, while domestic travel spending and home sales fell below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: EV batteries remain major challenge for insurers: UK’s Thatcham
summary: UK's Thatcham Research finds EV batteries pose a challenge for insurers due to limited repair and diagnostic capabilities. Insurers often write off EVs after mild accidents, leading to higher premiums and reduced adoption. Replacement batteries are also uneconomical, as they can cost more than the used price of the vehicle after just one year. This lack of data hinders informed decisions on repairing or writing off EVs, resulting in longer repair times and increased costs, making EVs 25.5% more expensive to insure than fossil-fuel models.

site_title: Putin says Russian economy faring better than expected
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin said the country's economy is performing better than expected, with GDP growth potentially exceeding 2% this year and inflation below 5%. This contradicts the International Monetary Fund's forecast of a 0.7% growth. Putin credited the government's efforts to repurpose the economy and boost spending, despite sanctions imposed by Western countries. Finance Minister Anton Siluanov had previously predicted a budget deficit of 2% of GDP, but the IMF expects a wider deficit.

images.alt_text: The conflict between Russia and Ukraine – both major grain exporters – triggered fears of a global food crisis when major Ukrainian ports were blocked by Moscow’s warships.

site_title: Japan’s service activity maintains firm pace as demand picks up: PMI
summary: Japan's service sector activity maintained a brisk pace of growth in June, with the final au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 54.0 from a record-high 55.9 in May. The sector's expansion has continued for the 10th straight month, driven by consumer demand and easing pandemic-related restrictions. Business expectations for the coming year were firm but slightly down, and price pressures remained persistent, with input inflation dropping to the lowest level since March last year.

site_title: China’s metal export curbs a ‘warning’ to US and its allies: Global Times
summary: China has announced controls on exports of gallium and germanium products from August 1, seen as a warning to the US and its allies in the global semiconductor industry. The move aims to protect national security and is a response to Washington's efforts to curb China's technological advances. China will reject export applications involving military use or posing a national security risk, while exports for non-military purposes will be subject to controls. The curbs may disrupt global supply chains and escalate a trade war with the US.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as China data indicates further weakness
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday as China's June economic data showed further weakness, with little hope of a stimulus package to boost growth. The Caixin private survey of the services sector showed activity slowed sharply, adding to a string of soft data on trade and consumer activity. Hong Kong fell over 1% and Shanghai, Tokyo, and Seoul also declined. The focus shifts to the Federal Reserve's June policy meeting minutes and China's jobs creation data, which will provide insight into the country's economic struggles and potential policy responses.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Shanghai edged up, along with Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta, though Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul and Manila dipped.

site_title: Temasek’s STT to issue S$300 million in 5.5% perpetual securities
summary: Temasek-owned Singapore Technologies Telemedia (STT) plans to issue S$300 million in 5.5% perpetual securities, callable in 2030. The securities will be listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on or about Jul 12, 2023. The reset distribution rate will be based on the seven-year Singapore Overnight Rate Average overnight indexed swap rate at the time, plus a spread and step-up of 1% per annum. The issue is under STT's S$3 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, managed by DBS and UOB.

site_title: HSBC tests quantum tech in London to guard against future hacks
summary: HSBC is testing an advanced data-security system, quantum key distribution (QKD), in London to protect against future hacks. The system, developed by BT Group, Amazon's AWS cloud, and Toshiba, will send test data 62 kilometers to analyze threats and improve data protection. HSBC aims to stay ahead of increasingly sophisticated hackers, as QKD could potentially defeat current encryption methods. The trial is part of the bank's defense strategy against "Q-Day," a hypothetical future threat when quantum computers could breach modern encryption.

images.alt_text: Signage at the HSBC Holdings Plc India headquarters building in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Jan. 27, 2023. summary: Activist investor Quarz Capital is seeking support from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) to ensure the fair conduct of an upcoming extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit). The EGM will vote on removing Sabana Reit's current manager and replacing it with an internal one. Quarz argues that the proposed changes could undermine regulatory protection for unitholders and called for the MAS and SGX RegCo's support to ensure the removal resolution is conducted fairly.

site_title: Airbus presses Chinese airlines to order planes as widebody slots fill up
summary: Airbus is urging Chinese airlines to place orders for its widebody aircraft due to limited slot availability and supply-chain disruptions. Chinese airlines have ordered 332 single-aisle jets last year, but widebody orders have fallen off, with a backlog of less than two dozen planes. Airbus aims to deliver 720 aircraft this year, a target it missed in 2022, and is increasing output to meet demand. The company forecasts that Chinese airlines will need 9,440 new planes between 2023 and 2042, with the Asia region accounting for half of global demand.

images.alt_text: The new wings are part of Airbus’s roadmap towards its next workhorse model set to hit the market around the middle of next decade.

site_title: The Place Holdings’ potential deal for Realty Centre site falls through after long-stop date expires
summary: The Place Holdings' potential deal to sell up to 11% of its stake in the former Realty Centre site to Maximus Global Ventures has fallen through after the long-stop date expired. The group expected to receive S$8.8 million, or 18.7% of its market capitalization, from the deal. Despite the termination, The Place Holdings will continue to engage with other parties regarding the potential disposal of New Vision Holding, which owns the land and building formerly known as Realty Centre.

site_title: Beijing jabs in US-China tech fight with chip material export curbs
summary: China has imposed export curbs on gallium and germanium, two metals widely used in semiconductors and electric vehicles, in response to US efforts to curb China's technological advances. The controls, effective August 1, aim to protect national security and come as US Secretary of Treasury Janet Yellen visits Beijing. Industry suppliers are racing to secure supplies, with some companies applying for export permits. The move may lead to disruption in global supply chains and could prompt China to follow with restrictions on rare earth exports.

site_title: The Seafood Company invests to stay cool for less
summary: The Seafood Company is investing S$40 million to build a new cold room facility using cooling technologies and automation to reduce energy usage and lower costs. The move aims to bring sustainably sourced and stored seafood to customers while minimizing emissions. This initiative follows Singapore's efforts to reduce carbon emissions and adopt sustainable practices in various industries. The company's investment aligns with Singapore's goal of reducing carbon credits and promoting green finance.

images.alt_text: Some food manufacturers have seen their bills double, or even triple, in the past year.

While hybrid vehicles will likely still be the mainstay in the short term, EV take-up will likely pick up once more infrastructure and charging points are built by 2030, said Mark Goh, chief operating officer at Optima Carz Leasing.

site_title: Bank of England considers clampdown on foreign bank branches: FT
summary: The Bank of England is considering a plan to force more international banks to set up subsidiaries in the UK, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank earlier this year. The move aims to reduce the thresholds requiring foreign banks with corporate business in the country to establish subsidiaries, making it easier for local regulators to seize control in case of failure. This plan is part of the BOE's review of SVB's collapse and could impact the operations of foreign banks with a presence in the UK.

site_title: EU Commission revamps procedures to speed up Big Tech privacy probes
summary: The European Commission has introduced new rules to speed up Big Tech privacy probes, following criticism of tardy investigations and low fines. The new procedures require the main privacy authority to share a summary of key issues with peers, allowing for early feedback and common deadlines for cross-border cooperation. Complainants will have the right to be heard and access the file, while companies under investigation will also be able to appeal. The rules aim to improve the timely completion of investigations and delivery of swift remedies for individuals, addressing concerns raised by critics such as Max Schrems.

images.alt_text: “Europe is completely reorganising its digital space to both better protect EU citizens and enhance innovation for EU startups and companies,” EU industry chief Thierry Breton says.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOL, Lian Beng, Sabana Reit, The Place Holdings, Eneco Energy
summary: UOL Group sold Parkroyal on Kitchener Road for S$525 million to an entity of Worldwide Hotels. Lian Beng Group's shares will be suspended due to low public float. Sabana Reit faces pressure to remove its manager, while The Place Holdings continues talks on selling the Realty Centre site. Eneco Energy secured a contract to transport Heineken and Tiger brands in Singapore for three years.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,199.39, following cautious sentiments in the European market. Losers outnumbered gainers 47 to 37, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC opening lower. US markets were closed for the Independence Day holiday, while shares in Europe remained steady in thin trading. The decline was attributed to global economic uncertainties, with investors staying cautious due to the lack of fresh economic data from the region and uncertainty around global interest rates.

images.alt_text: UOL has entered into an agreement with an entity part of Worldwide Hotels Group to sell Parkroyal on Kitchener Road for S$525 million.

site_title: Japan to prepare for August start of Fukushima water release: report
summary: Japan is set to begin releasing treated radioactive water from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant as early as August, following approval from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). The water has been filtered to remove most radioactive elements, with tritium being diluted to international safety standards. The move has raised concerns from neighboring countries, particularly China, which has been the biggest critic. Japan aims to gain domestic and international acceptance for the plan, which has been opposed by local fishing unions and some countries that have banned Japanese food products due to radiation concerns.

images.alt_text: Japan plans to release 1.3 trillion tonnes of water used to cool the fuel rods of the Fukushima plant damaged by a massive earthquake and tsunami in 2011.

site_title: UK financial services minister urges caution over central bank digital currency
summary: UK financial services minister Andrew Griffith has urged caution over the potential issuance of a central bank digital currency (CBDC), citing privacy and other issues. The UK finance ministry and Bank of England have launched a public consultation on the matter, mirroring global central banks' moves. Griffith believes a thorough public policy debate is necessary, which is being achieved through the consultation process. The UK's decision on CBDC will be closely watched, but no timeline has been set for a potential decision.

site_title: China automaker BYD to invest 3 billion reais in Brazil industrial complex
summary: Chinese automaker BYD plans to invest 3 billion reais (S$836 million) in a new industrial complex in northeastern Brazil, boosting local production to offer competitive prices. The complex, comprising three plants, will be built in the Camacari industrial park, replacing a Ford plant that closed in 2021. Operation is expected to start in mid-2024, generating over 5,000 jobs, and will include production of bus and electric truck chassis, hybrid and electric cars, and lithium and iron phosphate for the foreign market.

The N7 launch follows the introduction of another BYD SUV early this year, the U8, which falls under the company’s Yangwang brand.

site_title: Stellantis unveils new EVs and touts Italian production
summary: Stellantis unveiled two new electric vehicles, the Fiat 600 compact SUV and a revamped Topolino mini car, in Italy. The company plans to cut up to 2,000 jobs in Italy this year to retool plants for electric and hybrid models. Stellantis aims to boost production in southern Italy and build a battery factory in Termoli, while also transforming its Turin facility into an EV hub. Italian officials pressure the company to keep local plants running amid concerns about job losses due to the shift to electric vehicles.

site_title: Gold holds steady amid caution ahead of US Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices held steady at $1,926.52 per ounce ahead of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting minutes, as a firmer dollar kept prices in check. The dollar index remained firm, making gold less attractive for overseas buyers. Despite being seen as a safe investment amid economic uncertainties, high-interest rates discourage investing in non-yielding gold.

images.alt_text: High-interest rates discourage investment in non-yielding gold.

site_title: Twitter CEO backs widely criticised tweet-reading rate limits
summary: Twitter CEO Linda Yaccarino defended the temporary tweet-reading rate limit, which was criticized by users and marketing professionals, stating that it's necessary to remove spam and bots from the platform. The limit, which restricts users to viewing a certain number of tweets per day, took effect after Twitter began requiring logins to view tweets. Despite heavy criticism, Twitter claims that advertising has remained stable, and only a small percentage of users have been affected by the limits.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk fired about half of Twitter’s 7,500 workers in November, following his US$44 billion purchase of the company.
Individuals must pay US$8 per month to verify their account, while organisations pay US$1,000 per month.

site_title: Oil prices rise 2% as market weighs supply cuts against economic outlook
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Tuesday, July 4, as markets weighed August supply cuts by top exporters Saudi Arabia and Russia against a weak global economic outlook. Saudi Arabia extended its voluntary output cut to August, while Russia and Algeria volunteered to lower their August output by 500,000 bpd and 20,000 bpd, respectively. Total cuts now stand at over 5 million bpd, or 5% of global oil output, with Brent crude futures settling up $1.60 at $76.25 a barrel. Despite the cuts, market concerns about high-interest rates and a gloomy economic outlook persist.

site_title: M&S food makes good start to new financial year, says boss
summary: Marks & Spencer's food business has made a "good start" to its 2023-24 financial year, growing sales by 8.7% despite a 130 basis point hit to its food margin due to not passing on full cost inflation to customers. The retailer remains Britain's fastest-growing food retailer after discounters Aldi and Lidl. CEO Stuart Machin expressed concern that food prices won't come down as quickly as they rose, but plans to pass on price increases to customers. M&S shares have risen 56% this year.

site_title: Airbus hints at narrowbody successor featuring folding wing tips
summary: Airbus is developing a new narrowbody aircraft featuring an elongated, carbon-composite wing with folding tips, aiming for improved fuel efficiency and a reduced environmental footprint. The design is part of the company's roadmap for its next-generation single-aisle model, set to enter service between 2035 and 2040, with 20-25% better fuel consumption. The folding wing tips will allow planes to have longer wings while operating within existing airport infrastructure, and production challenges will be addressed through collaboration with suppliers and research and development efforts.
