FILE PHOTO: Smoke rises from the chimneys of the Kosova A coal-fired power plant in the town of Obilic, Kosovo September 10, 2021. Picture taken September 10, 2021. Picture taken with a drone. REUTERS/Fatos Bytyci/File Photo
The responsible financing frameworks of all three local banks do not mention how they will accommodate early coal phase-out projects.
Gillian Tan, MAS’ Chief Sustainability Officer and Assistant Managing Director (Development & International) at her first interview with the media on Tuesday (May 30, 2023) at the MAS Building.

site_title: ICP to hold EGM on Jul 26 to vote on directors’ removal
summary: ICP Ltd will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on July 26 to vote on removing three directors, including Chairman Tan Kok Hiang, and appointing two new directors. Shareholder Ang Kong Meng has requisitioned the EGM to pass seven resolutions, citing a 10.99% direct interest in ICP. The company's board does not recommend shareholders vote in favor of the proposed resolutions, which also include removing directors appointed between the requisition date and the EGM date, and ceasing diversification activities.

images.alt_text: ICP is currently in an advanced stage of negotiations for an investment opportunity for which the funds from the proposed placement will be used.
The resolutions seek to remove four fellow board members and appoint two others to the board.

site_title: Coinbase surges after Cboe names crypto exchange in Bitcoin ETF application
summary: Coinbase shares surged 13% on Monday after Cboe named the platform in its application to launch a Bitcoin ETF, addressing SEC concerns about detecting fraud. The move follows Fidelity's filing to launch a Bitcoin ETF, with Cboe seeking to address SEC concerns about manipulation. Coinbase shares have more than doubled this year, while Bitcoin reached a one-year high. The SEC has rejected dozens of spot Bitcoin ETF applications, and the ETF industry is working to address concerns about fraudulent practices.

images.alt_text: The SEC has rejected dozens of spot Bitcoin ETF applications in recent years, including one from Fidelity in January 2022.

site_title: Twitter says users must be verified to access TweetDeck
summary: Twitter will require users to be verified to access TweetDeck, with individuals paying $8 per month and organizations paying $1,000 per month. The change, effective in 30 days, was announced in a tweet alongside an improved version of TweetDeck with new features. The company did not immediately respond to requests for comment on whether users will be charged for both the new and old versions of TweetDeck.

images.alt_text: Twitter is limiting verified accounts to reading 10,000 tweets a day. Non-verified users – the free accounts that make up the majority of users – are limited to reading 1,000 tweets per day.

site_title: Australia, Indonesia unveil visa, climate pacts as leaders meet
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Indonesian President Joko Widodo unveiled visa and climate pacts during their meeting in Sydney, aiming to boost economic ties and cooperation on critical minerals, green manufacturing, and security partnerships. Albanese introduced five-year business visas for Indonesians, while announcing a $50 million fund for climate investment in Indonesia. The two leaders vowed to push for a defense cooperation agreement and highlighted the strength of their security relationship, amid a backdrop of increasing competition between the US and China.

images.alt_text: Inflation in South-east Asia’s largest economy has gradually eased since peaking last September at 6 per cent.

site_title: Singapore’s power squeeze is tighter than its housing crunch
summary: Singapore's power market is experiencing exceptional volatility, with wholesale power prices subject to temporary caps starting July 1. The island's Energy Market Authority aims to tame the market, where 3,000-plus intraday spikes have become common since 2021. Despite efforts to liberalize the market, the power sector is expected to remain tight until 2026, with demand growing 4% annually and limited new capacity in the pipeline. The Energy Market Authority will commission two new power plants to address the shortage, but the market's resilience remains a concern, with experts warning of ongoing "greedflation" and the need for public investment.

site_title: NFT prices slump as popular collection tumbles following debut
summary: The NFT market experienced a significant selloff, with popular collections like Azuki, Bored Ape Yacht Club, and Mutant Ape Yacht Club seeing price drops of 14-31% and 60% respectively. The decline followed the launch of a new Azuki collection, Azuki Elementals, which raised $38 million but raised questions about the value of NFTs. The selloff led to a wave of collectors unloading their Azuki, causing a ripple effect in the NFT lending market, with default loan volumes hitting a record high.

images.alt_text: The auction is part of liquidating Three Arrows Capital.

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit wins A$200 million bus tender in New South Wales, Australia
summary: ComfortDelGro's indirect subsidiary, Red Bus CDC NSW, has won an A$200 million (S$180.3 million) bus contract in New South Wales, Australia for eight years, starting in July 2024. The contract covers the NSW Central Coast region. This contract win is expected to create employment opportunities, with ComfortDelGro estimating an increase of 150 employees to reach a workforce of over 2,500 across NSW.

images.alt_text: RHB raised its target price for ComfortDelGro to S$1.35 from S$1.20 and reiterated its "buy" call on the stock.
ComfortDelGro said the new platform fee will also apply to limousine transfers made through its app, but not for rides booked via phone calls or text messages, or for street hails.
Analysts from DBS Research and RHB Securities are positive on ComfortDelGro's decision to implement a S$0.70 platform fee charge for rides booked via its app.

Geographically, ComfortDelGro said Singapore is showing “signs of slowing economic growth”. Over in Australia, there are driver shortages but also new terms from successful re-tenders, the company said.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ComfortDelGro, Alpina, ICP
summary: ComfortDelGro's indirect subsidiary has secured an eight-year outer metropolitan bus contract worth A$200 million in New South Wales, Australia. The contract is a joint venture with Red Bus Services. Meanwhile, Alpina has secured S$216.9 million in contracts, mostly public sector projects, in the six months ended June 30.

site_title: China’s top diplomat urges greater cooperation with Japan, South Korea
summary: China's top diplomat, Wang Yi, urged greater cooperation with Japan and South Korea, calling for a "clear signal of regrouping towards cooperation" and resisting "coercion of bullying and domination". Wang emphasized the need for dialogue and consultation to solve disputes, opposing actions that could plunge the region into war. The remarks come amid heightened tension between China and its neighbors as the US strengthens ties with Japan and South Korea, with Wang stopping short of mentioning the US.

images.alt_text: Hydropower accounts for about 70 per cent of total power supply in the Yunnan province, which has about 5.25 million metric tons of aluminium-making capacity.

site_title: Top Credit Suisse banker in Qatar set to join staff exodus
summary: Credit Suisse's top banker in Qatar, Aladdin Hangari, is in talks to join HSBC Holdings as part of a staff exodus, following the near-collapse of the Swiss bank earlier this year. Four other staff members are also in discussions to leave alongside Hangari. The departure is a setback for UBS, which had aimed to build on its on-the-ground presence in the region. Hangari's role in handling the relationship with the Qatari royal family and its major shareholders will be taken over by existing team members.

images.alt_text: UBS is focused on the transfer of wealth between baby boomers to their heirs in the coming years. About US$18 trillion will be passed to younger generations in the US over the next seven years, and as much as US$84 trillion over the next two decades.
The government’s and UBS’s priority was to “minimise potential losses and risks so that recourse to the federal guarantee is avoided to the greatest extent possible”, the government said.

site_title: Samsung sues Chinese rival over alleged patent violation on iPhone displays
summary: Samsung Display has filed a lawsuit against Chinese company BOE Technology, alleging patent infringement on OLED displays used in mobile devices, including Apple's iPhone 12. Samsung claims five patents were infringed, seeking damages and an injunction to halt the import and sale of affected displays. The case was filed in a US federal court in East Texas, with Samsung Display seeking "irreparable harm" from the infringement, which it says affects its image quality patents.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest memory maker is looking to catch up with TSMC while also fending off a nascent challenge from Intel, which is pushing into the foundry market.

site_title: Mizuho on US hiring spree with top 10 underwriting goal in sight
summary: Mizuho Financial Group's US unit plans to hire over 100 people by March 2026 to boost its investment banking and trading business, aiming to become the first Japanese bank to rank among the top 10 US equity arrangers for a full year. Despite a global dealmaking slump, the bank is pursuing its hiring drive, focusing on debt capital markets, technology, media, and telecommunications sectors. Mizuho Securities USA aims to increase its headcount by 30% and is looking to recruit for fixed-income sales and equity research, with the goal of landing more deals to capture other relevant business.

images.alt_text: The developments at Mizuho and its peers come as Wall Street grapples with the unfolding AI revolution and its impact.

site_title: Oil settles lower as economic jitters outweigh supply cuts
summary: Oil prices settled down 1% on Monday as economic jitters outweighed supply cuts by top exporters Saudi Arabia and Russia. Brent crude futures fell to $74.65 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $69.79 a barrel. Despite Saudi Arabia extending its voluntary cut of 1 million barrels per day for August, concerns about a slowing global economy and possible US interest-rate hikes led to lower prices. Higher US interest rates could strengthen the dollar, making oil more expensive for buyers holding other currencies.

images.alt_text: Oil pumping jacks, also known as "nodding donkeys", in an oilfield near in Russia. Russia, seeking to nudge up global oil prices in concert with Saudi Arabia, will reduce its oil exports by 500,000 bpd in August
The cuts will take Saudi Arabia’s production to about 9 million barrels a day, the lowest level in several years.

site_title: Twitter accused of ducking a fight over Musk’s mass layoffs
summary: Twitter, now rebranded as X, is refusing to engage in arbitration with former employees who were fired after Elon Musk's acquisition, despite a court order requiring them to resolve grievances through private arbitration. The company has demanded arbitration but has not shown up to hearings, according to a lawsuit. Former Twitter employees, represented by lawyer Shannon Liss-Riordan, are now filing claims directly in court, arguing the company has not paid promised severance and bonuses. This move is seen as a strategic decision by Twitter to avoid the expense of arbitration, citing studies that show workers often give up in such disputes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk's photo is seen through a Twitter logo in this illustration taken October 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Individuals must pay US$8 per month to verify their account, while organisations pay US$1,000 per month.

site_title: Apple’s growing stock market heft poses dilemma for fund managers
summary: Apple's share price has surged 49% this year, making it the largest weighting in the S&P 500 at 7.6%. This has forced fund managers to reconsider their allocations to the stock, as owning too much of a single name poses significant risk. Only 26 of 418 US broad market funds tracked by Morningstar hold a greater weight in Apple than its S&P 500 weight, and 80% of actively managed mutual funds have underperformed the benchmark year-to-date. The issue has become more urgent as megacap companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Nvidia drive market gains.

images.alt_text: The Vision Pro will start at US$3,499, more than three times the cost of the priciest headset in Meta’s line of mixed and virtual reality devices.

site_title: From Reaganomics to Bidenomics
summary: US President Joe Biden has introduced his economic philosophy, dubbed "Bidenomics," which centers on an activist government directing social-economic policies. This approach contrasts with "Reaganomics," a free market-oriented approach that has been criticized for failing the middle class and hollowing out the American economy. Bidenomics aims to create a system that grows the economy from the middle out and the bottom up, with policies including industrial strategy, government oversight of markets, and measures to support green innovation and workers. However, the proposal has sparked concerns about a shift towards protectionism and harm to US relationships with its economic partners abroad.

images.alt_text: Pinning US distributional woes, such as inequality or stagnant middle-class wages, on trade is mistaken, even if it is easier to blame foreigners rather than take responsibility.

Polls have shown that voters broadly see President Joe Biden’s job performance on the economy as poor, despite low unemployment and the passage of pandemic relief, infrastructure, and climate spending legislation.
Four rules that should guide Bidenomics

site_title: Musk, Zuckerberg lead US$852 billion wealth surge among world rich
summary: The world's 500 richest people added $852 billion to their fortunes in the first half of 2023, with an average daily gain of $14 million. Billionaires like Elon Musk ($96.6 billion) and Mark Zuckerberg ($58.9 billion) led the surge, driven by a broad stock market rally. The gains coincided with a rebounding economy and investor enthusiasm for artificial intelligence. However, Gautam Adani's net worth sank the most, losing $60.2 billion, after being accused of accounting fraud and stock manipulation.

site_title: Singapore PMI inches up in June but remains in contraction for 3rd straight month
summary: Singapore's overall factory activity improved slightly in June, but remained in contraction territory for the third straight month, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) inching up to 49.7. The electronics sector, a crucial component, slipped 0.1 point to post a faster contraction at 49. Experts warn of a dour outlook for the second half of the year, citing weak global demand and uncertainties in the global economic environment.

images.alt_text: Economists flag risk of technical recession for Singapore as manufacturing contracts further in May

site_title: US manufacturing extends slump in June: ISM survey
summary: US manufacturing contracted for the eighth consecutive month in June, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 46.0, the lowest reading since May 2020. The sector's annualized rate of contraction was 5.3% in the first quarter, partly due to interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve. Despite some pockets of strength, manufacturing is struggling, with weak demand and inventory management issues affecting businesses.

images.alt_text: The downturn was broad-based, with surveys published on Monday (Jul 3) showing that factory activity in all four of the eurozone’s biggest economies contracted last month.
The survey showed expansion of both manufacturing output and new orders softened in June.

site_title: US: Wall St ends little changed in shortened session, Tesla jumps
summary: The US stock market closed little changed on Monday in a shortened session ahead of the July 4th Independence Day holiday. The S&P 500 gained 4.75 points, or 0.11%, to 4,455.13 points, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 29.01 points, or 0.21%, to 13,816.93. Tesla shares jumped after delivering a record number of vehicles in the second quarter, while major banks gained after raising dividends. The market kicks off the second half of the year on a subdued note, with concerns about the economy reflected in a widely watched section of the US Treasury yield curve.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 37.82 points, or 0.11 per cent, at the open to 34,369.78.

site_title: Rivian beats estimates for second-quarter EV deliveries
summary: Rivian Automotive exceeded Wall Street estimates for second-quarter electric vehicle deliveries, beating expectations with 12,640 vehicles delivered, a 59% increase from the previous quarter. The company's shares rose 10% in early trading, following a stable demand for its electric vehicles. Rivian reiterated its annual production target of 50,000 units and expects demand to remain stable throughout the year.

images.alt_text: Customers of Rivian, which has its own small network of fast chargers, will be able to access 12,000 Tesla Superchargers with adaptors in the US and Canada as early as spring 2024.
The company reaffirmed plans to build 50,000 vehicles this year.
The Tesla Model 3. In addition to cutting prices across the lineup this year, Tesla has introduced perks such as three months of free fast-charging in the US to entice buyers.
Tesla is expected to hit record sales in China, its second-largest market after North America, despite stiff competition from market leader BYD.

site_title: Morgan Stanley warns against bets on emerging-market rate cuts
summary: Morgan Stanley warns emerging-market investors that developing nations may fail to deliver interest-rate cuts as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates and strengthens the US dollar. The bank's strategists predict emerging-market central banks may act more cautiously, slowing the pace of rate cuts, despite low inflation and high real yields in the developing world. This could lead to a repricing of global risk assets and an unwinding of FX carry trades if US data indicates a higher risk of recession.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The corporate logo of financial firm Morgan Stanley is pictured on the company's world headquarters in the Manhattan borough of New York City, January 20, 2015.  REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: China’s Yunnan region ramps up aluminium production as power curbs eased
summary: China's Yunnan region is ramping up aluminium production as power curbs are eased due to a recent recovery in hydropower output. The region, which has 5.25 million metric tons of aluminium-making capacity, relies on hydropower for 70% of its power supply. After months of idled production capacity, smelters have started to increase production. The easing of power curbs is seen as a positive development for the aluminium market, which has been closely monitoring weather forecasts in Yunnan.

site_title: Shanmugam, Vivian have done nothing wrong and retain my full confidence: PM Lee on Ridout Road
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has defended Cabinet ministers K. Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan, saying they have done nothing wrong and retain his full confidence. The ministers had been under scrutiny over renting government bungalows from the SLA, but Lee stated that there is nothing wrong with the practice, provided it is properly done and all procedures are followed. Lee emphasized that ministers in Singapore are paid a clean wage, and he has the government's "full confidence and support" in its mission.

images.alt_text: For the black-and-white bungalows located in an area zoned for landed properties such as Ridout Road and Nassim Road, the room for redevelopment is limited.
The public service will reference the Ridout Road case as an additional example to reinforce the importance for public officers to act with integrity.
The bungalow at 26 Ridout Road rented by Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam.

site_title: US: Nasdaq rises as Tesla rallies on record EV deliveries
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Monday, with the Nasdaq rising as Tesla surged on record second-quarter vehicle deliveries. The Dow Jones fell 37.82 points, and the S&P 500 opened higher by 0.10 points. The Nasdaq Composite gained 10.78 points, or 0.08 per cent, to 13,798.70. Tesla's strong performance lifted the tech-heavy index on course to extend its rally into the second half of the year.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as healthcare declines outweigh miner gains
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 0.2% lower on its first day of the second half of the year, reversing earlier gains. AstraZeneca's 8.0% decline led healthcare stocks down 2.0%, while miners rose 2.2% due to hopes of China's economic stimulus package. Italy's FTSE MIB index rose 0.8%, its highest since 2008, despite a cautious market atmosphere. The broader Stoxx 600 had gained 8.7% in the first half of the year, but was weighed down by the eurozone's weak economic recovery and policy tightening.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closes 1.2 per cent higher.

site_title: UK economy shrank slightly less than thought in 2020: ONS
summary: The UK's Office for National Statistics (ONS) has revised its estimate of the country's 2020 economy, shrinking by 10.9% rather than 11.0%. This represents a fractionally less decline than initially thought, following ongoing work on the annual "Blue Book" data revisions. The UK's GDP still fell more than in most other G7 economies in 2020, largely due to differences in measuring public-sector output and other areas during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) falls to 46.5 from 47.1 in May, its lowest reading this year and one of the weakest since the 2008-09 financial crisis
Britain’s economic recovery since the Covid-19 pandemic has been much slower than almost every other big advanced economy.

site_title: Singapore birth rates hit record low in 2022; number of deaths the highest since 1960
summary: Singapore's birth rate hit a record low in 2022, with 35,605 live births, a 7.9% drop from 2021. The number of deaths reached a 62-year high, with 26,891 deaths in 2022, a 10.7% increase from 2021. The median age of first-time mothers rose to 31.9 years, while women with university degrees made up 63.6% of first-time mothers. The government has implemented measures to support families, including cash gifts and extended paternity leave, in response to the declining total fertility rate of 1.05.

images.alt_text: MOH said the adjustment comes after the Registry of Births and Deaths finalised its report for 2021.

By ensuring a productive economy, creating aged-friendly living environments, assuring retirement adequacy, reforming the healthcare system and continuing to practice good governance, Singapore can stay economically vibrant even as it ages, says Healthcare Minister Ong Ye Kung.
If Singapore wants to transcend its manpower crunch, it needs to get serious about raising its TFR.

site_title: Germany’s industry shows lasting weakness as global orders drop
summary: Germany's manufacturing industry continues to show weakness, with global orders dropping 10% in real terms in May compared to the same month in 2022, according to the VDMA. Demand from abroad declined 18% while domestic business increased. The VDMA's chief economist, Ralph Wiechers, states that the downward trend continues, confirming persistently weak global investment demand. The country's economy may struggle to recover from recession, with business surveys showing a deteriorating outlook.

images.alt_text: Germany's Finance Minister Christian Lindner is planning the 2024 federal budget to include record spending on defence, finance ministry sources have said.
Infineon, which recently broke ground for a fourth fab in the city, has employees from more than 50 countries in Saxony.
German consumer prices, harmonised to compare with other European Union countries, have risen by a more-than-anticipated 6.8 per cent on the year in June.

site_title: UBS goes on hiring spree for wealth managers catering to rich Americans
summary: UBS has embarked on a US recruiting drive for wealth managers catering to rich Americans, recruiting 50 financial advisers, including from major banks like Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, in the first half of the year. The move aims to capitalize on the transfer of wealth between baby boomers to their heirs, with an estimated $18 trillion passing to younger generations in the US over the next seven years. UBS expects to earn 63% of its profits from wealth management within four years, driven by the growth of ultra-high-net-worth clients.

images.alt_text: A sign reading "Bernard! Pay your social contributions!", in reference to LVMH's Bernard Arnault, as part of an event organised by CGT labour union members and Right of Housing group DAL activists in Paris on Jun 12.
The coming megatrend of inheritance allows Japan to set a positive example of how these riches can be used wisely for the creation of future prosperity.
Planning for family succession: open communication is key

site_title: World Bank, WTO chiefs seek to reignite services trade negotiations
summary: World Bank President Ajay Banga and WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala called for increased efforts to make global services trade more transparent and predictable, aiming to boost trade and investment for developing countries. The two institutions note that the WTO has a mandate to liberalize services but member states have not collectively improved market access since 1997. They aim to "recall the benefits of advancing the negotiating agenda on trade in services" and offer support to governments in implementing these efforts.

images.alt_text: Under a rare global deal to update trade rules struck a year ago, the WTO’s 164 members agreed to work towards eliminating billions of US dollars in “harmful” subsidies that are emptying the oceans of fish.

China imposes anti-dumping duties in July 2019 on stainless steel billets and hot-rolled plates and coils from Japan, South Korea, Indonesia, and the European Union, arguing that a surge of imports is damaging its domestic industry.

Sri Lanka is struggling with the worst financial crisis since its independence from Britain in 1948 after the country’s foreign exchange hit record lows and triggered its first foreign debt default last year.

site_title: Ambani’s Jio unveils US$12 phone that streams video, moves money
summary: Reliance Jio, owned by billionaire Mukesh Ambani, unveiled a US$12 Internet-enabled phone priced at 999 rupees, targeting India's 250 million "trapped" mobile users in the 2G era. The phone, "Jio Bharat," will offer unlimited voice calls and 14 GB of data for 123 rupees a month. The launch is part of Reliance's plan to roll out 5G services across India by December, with a US$25 billion investment. The move aims to boost Reliance's plans for its streaming service and further disrupt the Indian market.

site_title: Nasdaq refiles BlackRock’s Bitcoin ETF application with US SEC
summary: Nasdaq has refiled an application with the US SEC to list an exchange-traded fund (ETF) by BlackRock that tracks the price of Bitcoin. The move comes after the regulator expressed concerns over the initial filings, citing them as unclear and incomplete. Coinbase Global will provide market surveillance in support of the proposed ETF, which is expected to be listed on the exchange. The refiled application adds additional details to address the SEC's concerns.

images.alt_text: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission logo and representations of cryptocurrency are seen in this illustration taken June 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
The SEC has rejected dozens of spot bitcoin ETF applications in recent years, including one from Fidelity in January 2022.
Fidelity is one of several big asset managers that have applied to list Bitcoin ETFs in recent weeks.

site_title: Ridout Road rents stir debate on valuation of black-and-white houses in property circles
summary: The Singapore Land Authority's disclosure of rental rates for a state-owned "black-and-white" house on Ridout Road has sparked debate on the valuation of such properties. Minister K Shanmugam's house, rented at S$30.94 per square foot of GFA, has raised questions on the assessment and pricing method. The rent is comparable to neighboring houses, but the land area included under the lease agreement is significantly larger, sparking questions on why the rent was not increased upon renewal.

images.alt_text: For the black-and-white bungalows located in an area zoned for landed properties such as Ridout Road and Nassim Road, the room for redevelopment is limited.

PM Lee Hsien Loong said there is nothing wrong with Cabinet ministers K. Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan renting the bungalows from the SLA, provided it is properly done and all procedures are followed.
The bungalow at 26 Ridout Road rented by Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam as seen on June 29, 2023.
The public service will reference the Ridout Road case as an additional example to reinforce the importance for public officers to act with integrity.

pixridout ST20230523_202366754146 Ong Wee Jin / 

Generic photos of road signs showing Ridout Road.

Ongoing saga about Law and MHA Minister K Shanmugam and Foreign Minister, Vivian Balakrishnan renting two massive bungalows at Ridout Road.

Photographed on May 23, 2023.

The original rental rates for the Ridout Road properties – S$26,500 for Law Minister K Shanmugam and S$19,000 for Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan – were no lower than official guide rents.
One of 10 bungalows leased by Unilever for a development campus.

site_title: UK watchdog to crack down on home and car insurers
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is cracking down on home and car insurers for failing to improve their treatment of struggling customers. The watchdog found instances of insurers offering lower prices for cars after they've been written off, violating FCA rules. The FCA has told companies to address poor practices and provide redress, with the possibility of fines, bans, or intensified supervision if necessary. The regulator aims to ensure timely and fair claims handling, particularly during the cost-of-living squeeze.

images.alt_text: MAS said that the move was not in response to stresses faced by some banks abroad this year.
Understanding how advisers and their firms are remunerated is important because the compensation structure can pose a potential conflict of interest.

site_title: Yen weakens on intervention threat; slowdown fears weigh on euro
summary: The yen weakened 0.37% to 144.86 against the US dollar, its lowest level since November, amid concerns of Japanese intervention. The euro also fell, down 0.1% at $1.0897, as China's factory activity growth slowed and eurozone manufacturing contracted faster than expected. Investors are also watching the US Federal Reserve's June meeting minutes, which are due out this week, for clues on future interest rate hikes.

site_title: About 250 property buys a year by foreigners exempted from ABSD under FTA obligations: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong revealed that around 250 property transactions per year from 2018 to 2022 were exempted from the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for foreign buyers due to a "national treatment" obligation under the Singapore-European Free Trade Association (ESFTA) and US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA). This exemption resulted in approximately S$150 million in ABSD remitted annually, accounting for 2.5% of all property transactions with ABSD.

images.alt_text: At the recent launch of condominium Blossoms by the Park, four units were sold to US buyers and four to Chinese.

site_title: Forum on digitalisation to kick off SkillsFuture Festival 2023
summary: The SkillsFuture Forum 2023, organized by SkillsFuture Singapore, will be held on July 4 to discuss digitalization's impact on businesses. Minister for Education Chan Chun Sing will give the opening speech, and four guest speakers will share their expertise. The forum is part of the SkillsFuture Festival, which runs from July 4 to August 18, featuring online, physical, and hybrid events, including roadshows and webinars on topics like cloud computing, artificial intelligence, and extended reality.

images.alt_text: Minister for Transport Dr Tan See Leng encourages retailers to adapt to shifting consumer demands.

site_title: Philippines ends deal with ad agency after tourism video fiasco
summary: The Philippines has terminated its contract with advertising agency DDB Philippines over a tourism video promoting the country that used stock footage from other countries, including Brazil, Indonesia, and the UAE. The video was part of the "Love the Philippines" campaign, which aimed to boost tourist arrivals. DDB Philippines apologized for the mistake and took down the video after public backlash. The tourism department has made no payments to DDB under the contract, and the country is still aiming for 4.8 million international tourist arrivals this year.

site_title: Oil rallies on Saudi and Russian supply cuts for August
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia have announced supply cuts for August, reducing global oil exports by 1.5% to 5.16 million barrels per day. Saudi Arabia will extend its voluntary cut of 1 million barrels per day for another month, while Russia will cut exports by 500,000 barrels per day. This move has led to a 0.4% increase in Brent crude futures, reaching $75.73 a barrel. Analysts expect tighter oil balance and buoyant equities, suggesting a reduced risk of recession.

images.alt_text: The cuts will take Saudi Arabia’s production to about 9 million barrels a day, the lowest level in several years.
Prices have been under pressure from rising interest rates in key economies and a slower than expected recovery in Chinese manufacturing and consumption.
Higher interest rates could strengthen the greenback, making commodities more expensive for holders of other currencies, and also dampen oil demand.

site_title: Malaysia to simplify investment bodies to boost ease of business
summary: Malaysia aims to simplify its investment process by streamlining roles of its investment promotion agencies. The goal is to provide a "simple journey" for investors, defining clear roles and responsibilities for each approving authority. The move follows a 60% increase in approved investments in the first quarter of 2023, with foreign Direct Investment making up more than half of the flows. The trade ministry seeks feedback from investors to eliminate pain points and improve the investor experience in Malaysia.

site_title: Saudis and Russia extend oil supply cuts, sending prices up
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia have extended oil supply cuts by one month, with Saudi Arabia reducing production to about 9 million barrels a day, the lowest level in several years. The cuts, which started in June, will continue into August and may be extended further. Oil prices jumped 1.3% to US$76.39 a barrel, as Russia also announced fresh curbs on exports. The move is aimed at keeping supply in check despite concerns over demand, particularly in China. The extension was expected by traders and analysts, who forecast prices would rally but instead have sagged due to economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates could strengthen the greenback, making commodities more expensive for holders of other currencies, and also dampen oil demand.
Saudi Arabia in June unexpectedly raised prices for July-loading cargoes, eating into Asian refiners’ margins.

site_title: China to restrict exports of metals critical to chip production
summary: China is imposing export controls on gallium and germanium, two metals critical to chip production, starting August 1. The metals, used in products like solar panels, lasers, and computer chips, will require exporters to obtain licenses from the Ministry of Commerce. The move is seen as an escalation of tensions in the global battle for industrial and military technologies, particularly between China and the US. The restrictions are expected to raise costs for hardware manufacturers and worsen geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Troubled retailer Tesco picks Burberry boss as chair
summary: Tesco has named Gerry Murphy, former Burberry boss, as its new chairman, replacing John Allan who stepped down after misconduct claims. Allan denies allegations of inappropriate behavior, including touching a senior staff member at a shareholder meeting. He had previously faced similar accusations at the CBI, but admitted to making an offensive comment in 2019. Murphy will start at Tesco on September 1, while departing his role at Tate & Lyle.

images.alt_text: In February, Waitrose cut prices on more than 300 own-brand products.

A shopper pushes a shopping trolley at the Tesco Basildon Pitsea Extra supermarket, operated by Tesco Plc, in Basildon, U.K., on Tuesday, Dec. 1, 2015. Many European food retailers are coming to terms with persistently low inflation as well as consumers who remain frugal yet purchase food more frequently. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: Tesco Non-executive chairman, John Allan poses for a photograph in London, Britain, April 12, 2017. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: Alpina Holdings secures S$216.9m worth of contracts for Q1; majority are public sector projects
summary: Alpina Holdings secured S$216.9 million worth of contracts in Q1, with the majority being public sector projects. The contracts include S$117.2 million for designing and installing solar photovoltaic systems for Novasix, and S$93.4 million for providing mechanical and electrical systems maintenance. Other projects, including fire protection system servicing, are slated for completion from 2025 to 2027. The company's aggregate provisional contract sum may not accurately reflect its actual revenue.

images.alt_text: Alpina unit bags S$117 million HDB project to build solar panels

site_title: Crypto service providers not allowed to facilitate lending, staking services on retail clients’ assets: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed amendments to the Payment Services Regulations, banning crypto service providers from facilitating lending and staking services on retail clients' assets. The providers must also safe-keep customer assets under a statutory trust, segregate assets, and conduct daily reconciliations. MAS advises customers to exercise caution when trading in cryptocurrencies due to high risks and potential delays in asset recovery in case of insolvency. The proposed changes aim to enhance investor protection and market integrity in the crypto industry.

images.alt_text: The remarks come after Circle received a licence as a major payments institution in Singapore.

Coinbase was also sued over a “staking” programme where it pools crypto assets to support activity on the blockchain network, in exchange for “rewards” it provides customers after taking commissions for itself.

site_title: Sea offers highest growth among Internet plays but Alibaba has better valuations, DBS says
summary: DBS Group Research expects Sea to register a 27% compound annual growth rate in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) from 2022 to 2025, driven by "sharp growths" in e-commerce and fintech businesses. Sea offers the highest growth potential among internet plays, but has better valuations than Alibaba. Amazon is expected to be immune to growth risks due to a boost from artificial intelligence adoption in 2024, making it the safest choice among the three.

images.alt_text: In the coming weeks, the FTC, led by commissioner Lina Khan, plans to file a far-reaching antitrust suit focused on Amazon’s core online marketplace.
After Friday, Kindle users will no longer be able to purchase new books online – though they will still be able to download purchased books onto their local devices for another year.
The US investment curbs could throttle entrepreneurship and innovation in China, says Han Yuze, founding partner at Shanghai-based tech focused private equity firm NewMargin Ventures.

site_title: Indonesian LNG makes up less than 1% of Singapore’s natural gas imports: MTI
summary: Singapore's natural gas imports from Indonesia account for less than 1% of its total imports, according to Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong. The country sources LNG globally from Australia, Qatar, the US, and Indonesia to mitigate disruptions in any single supply source. This information was provided in response to a parliamentary question regarding reports that Indonesia may ban the export of LNG.

site_title: Deep-sea mining may soon ease the world’s battery-metal shortage
summary: Deep-sea mining, particularly for nickel, may alleviate the world's battery-metal shortage. The Clarion-Clipperton Zone (CCZ) in the Pacific Ocean holds an estimated 340 million tonnes of nickel, more than three times the US Geological Service's estimate of land-based reserves. Companies like TMC and Global Sea Mineral Resources plan to mine the seabed using robots, which could reduce environmental damage compared to land-based mining. However, the process still poses risks to marine life, and the amount of metal produced per hectare is lower than that from land-based mining.

images.alt_text: Materials such as lithium, used in EV batteries, can be found in raw state aross the world, but extracting and refining them can be costly. China dominates the entire value chain in many critical minerals.

In just three years, Jakarta has signed deals worth about US$15 billion for battery and EV production, while President Joko Widodo – who visited the nickel mining town of Sorowako on Sulawesi island this week – has personally tried to persuade Tesla’s Musk to invest.
Nickel smelting in South Sulawesi province. Indonesia produced one million metric tonnes of nickel in 2021 and earned US$21 billion in revenue from those exports.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Land Authority is studying the feasibility of longer leasehold periods for black-and-white bungalow estates, potentially allowing private developers to become master-leaseholders. Meanwhile, private home prices in Singapore fell 0.4% in Q2, marking the first decline in three years. The Monetary Authority of Singapore also banned crypto service providers from facilitating lending and staking services on retail clients' assets. Additionally, OCBC expects to add S$3 billion in revenue from its Asean-Greater China strategy by 2025, and HDB resale volumes declined to a three-year low in Q2.

site_title: Thai central bank mulls steps to lower ‘worrying’ household debt
summary: The Bank of Thailand is preparing guidelines to address the country's high household debt, with a goal of reducing it to 80% of GDP from 90.6% currently. The guidelines will include responsible lending, risk-based loan pricing, and macro-prudential measures to tackle non-productive loans, which account for two-thirds of the debt. The central bank aims to bring down indebtedness while managing the risk of non-performing loans, which have risen to 2.68% in the first quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: Tourists wait to check in for flights, ahead of brace of an influx of Chinese tourists as COVID restirction are dismantled, at Bangkok’s Suvarnabhumi airport, Thailand, January 4, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

The measures would include promoting the use of local currency in managing foreign exchange and investments of up to US$10 million would be permitted for Thai retail investors in foreign securities, up from US$5 million.

site_title: Vietnam bans Barbie movie over South China Sea map
summary: Vietnam has banned the release of Warner Bros' film Barbie due to a scene featuring a map that shows China's unilaterally claimed territory in the South China Sea. The "nine-dash line" is used on Chinese maps to illustrate its claims over the South China Sea, which Vietnam considers its continental shelf. This is the latest in a series of films to be banned in Vietnam for depicting the nine-dash line, following the 2016 international arbitration ruling that China refuses to recognize.

images.alt_text: Actor Margot Robbie is photographed during a photocall for the upcoming Warner Bros. film "Barbie" in Los Angeles, California, U.S., June 25, 2023.   REUTERS/Mike Blake

site_title: Zipmex sues investor, proposes new scheme after US$100 million deal fails
summary: Singapore-based crypto company Zipmex has sued its Thai investor, V Ventures, for allegedly backing out of a US$100 million rescue deal. The deal aimed to recover funds for over 70,000 creditors. With the plan unlikely to succeed, Zipmex has proposed a new scheme of arrangement. The company's financial woes stem from a US$53 million exposure to failed crypto lenders Babel Finance and Celsius last year.

images.alt_text: Zipmex is struggling to pay employees after its investor withheld an injection of cash.
Zipmex, which fell victim to last year’s bear market in virtual coins, plans to ask the court to extend its creditor protection period in Singapore to give it time to seek alternative investors.
While the question of recognising crypto as money remains unanswered for now, cases revolving around this issue will be something to watch.

site_title: Hong Kong May retail sales rise 18.4%, sees support from local consumption
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 18.4% in May, marking the sixth consecutive month of growth, with total sales reaching HK$34.5 billion (US$4.40 billion). The increase was driven by the revival of inbound tourism and positive consumption sentiment. The government's promotional campaigns, including the "Hello Hong Kong" and "Happy Hong Kong" initiatives, are expected to support further growth in the coming months. The city's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained at 3.0% in the March to May period.

images.alt_text: Cathay will be the sole airline offering in-town check-in services, and only from 6 am to 3 pm, Hong Kong train operator MTR says.
Hong Kong's exports to India fell 30.7 per cent; those to the US, Japan and Korea also recorded double-digit drops.

site_title: Tesla and BYD post record sales on surge in demand for electric cars
summary: Tesla and BYD Co set sales records in the second quarter, with Tesla delivering 466,140 cars worldwide and BYD selling 700,244 fully electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles. Tesla's stock rose over 6% and BYD's jumped 5% in Hong Kong. The deliveries mark a significant increase for Tesla, with 83% growth from the same period last year, and come as the company has introduced price cuts and perks such as free fast-charging to entice buyers. This surge in demand puts pressure on legacy carmakers and solidifies Tesla's lead as the world's best-selling electric-car maker.

images.alt_text: Tesla is expected to hit record sales in China, its second-largest market after North America, despite stiff competition from market leader BYD.
FILE PHOTO: BYD electric vehicles (EV) are displayed at a car dealership in Shanghai, China, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song//File Photo
Wednesday's announcement marks the fourth extension of China's NEV tax-break policy, which was introduced in 2014.
After Tesla kicks off a price war that quickly enveloped other manufacturers earlier this year, now some two-thirds of auto brands in the world’s largest car market are offering discounts.

site_title: Italy's manufacturing shrinks at steepest rate since Covid lockdowns
summary: Italy's manufacturing sector contracted at the steepest rate in over three years, with a survey showing a decline of 43.8 in June, the lowest since April 2020. This signals a recession ahead unless buoyant services can support the eurozone's third-largest economy. The manufacturing output sub-index plummeted to 42.7 and new-orders indicator dropped to 40.1. The Italian economy has been giving mixed signals, with industry and manufacturing sectors struggling, but services and employment growing amid a tourism boom.

images.alt_text: Shipments abroad rose above 3 billion euros in February, up 131 per cent from a year earlier.

The superbonus scheme allowed homeowners to either deduct the cost of work from their taxes over several years or sell the tax credit to their builder, who would sell it to a bank, which would then claim the money from the state.

site_title: You can’t mine the seabed without proper rules
summary: A two-year deadline for the International Seabed Authority (ISA) to finalize mining regulations for deep-sea mining is set to expire on July 10, 2023. Without regulations, member states may approve mining applications, despite environmental concerns and potential risks. A moratorium on deep-sea mining is being advocated for, citing the lack of environmental safeguards and the potential for habitat destruction and pollution. The ISA faces a difficult decision, as allowing unregulated mining would undermine the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and expose the organization to litigation.

images.alt_text: Greenpeace activists stage a protest demanding an end to deep sea mining, in front of the Ministry of Industry in Prague, Czech Republic, June 1, 2023. REUTERS/David W Cerny

site_title: Germany plans 16.6 billion euros in new borrowing for 2024
summary: Germany plans to borrow 16.6 billion euros in 2024, with the federal budget including record spending on defense. The country aims to comply with NATO's 2% GDP target for military spending, budgeting 51.8 billion euros for defense and 19.2 billion euros in extra-budgetary funds. The government also plans 445.7 billion euros in expenditures for 2024, with 54.2 billion euros in investments. This will be the second consecutive year following the pandemic in compliance with the debt brake, limiting the budget deficit to 0.35% of GDP.

images.alt_text: Infineon, which recently broke ground for a fourth fab in the city, has employees from more than 50 countries in Saxony.
Stubbornly high inflation and interest rate hikes by the European Central Bank have been significantly dampening people’s purchasing power in Europe’s biggest economy.

Shoppers at the Roemer Square Christmas Market in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Nov. 24, 2022. In Frankfurt, retailers are struggling to put shoppers in a festive mood as authorities curtail holiday lighting this season, as Russian aggression claims an unlikely sacrifice: Christmas lights. Photographer: Ben Kilb/Bloomberg

site_title: Eurozone factory downturn deeper in June as ECB hikes bit: PMI
summary: Eurozone factory activity contracted in June, with all four largest economies experiencing a downturn. The European Central Bank's policy tightening led to the decline, with the manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 43.4, its lowest since the COVID pandemic. This marks a broader-than-expected contraction, further from the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. The results paint an increasingly gloomy outlook for the eurozone's industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker transports packaged pasta at De Cecco's factory in Fara San Martino, Italy, November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Remo Casilli/File Photo
Largely healed supply chains and lower energy prices has led to input costs for factories falling at the fastest pace in over seven years.
Lower energy costs and healing supply chains did however mean input prices fell for the first time since July 2020 – just when the coronavirus pandemic was cementing its grip on the world.
FILE PHOTO: A worker transports packaged pasta at De Cecco's factory in Fara San Martino, Italy, November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Remo Casilli/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks begin second half of 2023 in the black; STI up 0.04%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.04% on Monday, July 3, to 3,207.10, driven by optimism over US economic data, including a 0.1% rise in personal consumption expenditures in May. The market sentiment is seen as a shift towards a "less hawkish mode" by the US Federal Reserve, amid concerns over recession. Gainers outpaced losers 303 to 238, with Singapore Airlines leading the gainers, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the biggest loser.

images.alt_text: US Consumer spending edges up 0.1 per cent last month, the Commerce Department says.
The US personal consumption expenditures (PCE) gained 0.1 per cent for mAYMay after an 0.4 per cent rise in April while advancing 3.8 per cent on an annual basis.

site_title: Are alternative investments for you?
summary: Alternative investments, such as private equity, private real estate, and hedge funds, can provide improved returns, lower volatility, and diversification for portfolios. These assets can offer alpha generation, an illiquidity premium, and leverage, making them attractive to individual investors. However, investors must approach alternatives with caution, considering risks such as liquidity, leverage, and cost. A diversified and risk-managed approach is crucial to unlocking the benefits of alternative investments. With the growth of digital platforms and lower minimum investment requirements, alternatives are becoming more accessible to individual investors, but a trusted adviser is still essential to guide investors and achieve good outcomes.

images.alt_text: Bonds provide solid income with much less risk than stocks — in theory, anyway.

site_title: OCBC expects to add S$3 billion in revenue from its Asean-Greater China strategy by 2025
summary: OCBC Bank expects to add S$3 billion in revenue by 2025 from its Asean-Greater China strategy, driven by investments in global wholesale banking, wealth management, and digital capabilities. The bank has identified opportunities to capture the flow of business between Asean and China, leveraging its "one-group" approach to add value to customers through scale and connectivity. OCBC aims to double its investment banking revenue in three years, enhance its wealth management capabilities, and increase its Greater China franchise revenue in Asean by 50% by 2025.

images.alt_text: A new digital account opening service has been launched by OCBC for its customers who are based overseas.
OCBC affirmed Great Eastern’s as a capability within the banking group.

site_title: Public servants with privileged info to declare before renting government properties: SM Teo
summary: Singapore's government will introduce a standard declaration requirement for public servants with access to government property leasing or valuation matters. The Public Service Division will work with relevant ministries and statutory boards to ensure officers declare any potential conflict of interest before renting government properties. This comes after a review of the rental of two black-and-white bungalows by Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam and Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan found no evidence of corruption or criminal wrongdoing. The government emphasizes the importance of integrity and accountability in its system of government.

images.alt_text: The bungalow at 26 Ridout Road rented by Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam.

The original rental rates for the Ridout Road properties – S$26,500 for Law Minister K Shanmugam and S$19,000 for Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan – were no lower than official guide rents.

site_title: Ridout Road bungalows: Shanmugam decided to put family home up for sale, Vivian wanted family under one roof
summary: Singapore's Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam and Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan have defended their decision to rent state-owned bungalows in Ridout Road, amid questions from MPs. Shanmugam rented his family home at 26 Ridout Road for S$26,500 monthly, while Balakrishnan leased his home at 31 Ridout Road for S$19,000. The ministers claimed they paid market rates and did not make a profit from the difference. They also stressed the importance of integrity and accountability as elected officials, while addressing allegations of wrongdoing related to a contract for works on the properties.

images.alt_text: The original rental rates for the Ridout Road properties – S$26,500 for Law Minister K Shanmugam and S$19,000 for Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan – were no lower than official guide rents.

site_title: UK factory downturn deepens in June despite lower costs: PMI
summary: The UK manufacturing sector experienced its 11th consecutive month of decline in June, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 46.5 from 47.1 in May. The sector's pace of decline steepened despite weakening price pressures, with costs for materials and energy falling by the most since February 2016. The services sector remains the main source of growth in the UK economy, and the Bank of England is closely monitoring indicators of price pressures to determine interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Britain’s economic recovery since the Covid-19 pandemic has been much slower than almost every other big advanced economy.
The BOE stepped up its campaign with a larger-than-expected half-point rise to 5 per cent, the highest since 2008.

site_title: In the shadow of peaking markets
summary: Singapore's office market is experiencing pockets of weakness, particularly in prime Grade A CBD space, with rents flattening in the second quarter. Shadow space, estimated at around 600,000 square feet, is emerging and competing with new office space for tenants. Meanwhile, the housing market is also seeing increased supply, with 5,160 residential units to be released through government land sales. The wider economic picture has dimmed, with economists warning of a technical recession and cutbacks in consumption.

site_title: Australian buy-now-pay-later firm Zip to streamline cost and operations
summary: Zip Co, an Australian buy-now-pay-later firm, is streamlining its operations and cost base following a recent review. The move comes amid increased regulatory scrutiny and falling valuations due to reduced customer spending and rising interest rates. The company has reportedly cut up to 20% of its workforce, from 1,498 employees as of June 30. This restructuring aims to improve efficiency and cost savings, helping the company navigate the challenging BNPL sector.

images.alt_text: The new laws will impact consumer credit firms from Zip to Afterpay, which compete with banks to provide interest-free credit that is typically repaid in instalments.
Closeup of woman holding color paper shopping bag at street. Summer sale and Black Friday shopping concept. Vintage tone film in cover size photo.
BNPL providers in Singapore like Atome are signatories in an industry code rather than coming under the purview of MAS.

site_title: China property developers buy less land in H1, June home sales drop 29%: survey
summary: China's top 100 property developers spent 10% less on land in the first half of 2023 compared to the same period last year, with sales staying flat. In June, property sales dropped 29.4% from a year ago, and land purchases decreased 10.2% to 592 billion yuan. This reinforces low confidence in the real estate sector, which has been weakened by a debt crisis since mid-2021. Despite local government support measures, investor sentiment remains fragile, with Goldman Sachs predicting "persistent weakness" in the property sector for years.

images.alt_text: China may relax some home-buying restrictions and down-payment requirements in non-core areas.
The average price of new homes in 100 cities fell 0.01 per cent in June, the same-sized decline that was seen in May, data from the China Index Academy shows.

site_title: Cash vs bonds: Find hidden gems in high-quality bonds
summary: Investors are weighing the pros and cons of holding cash versus government bonds amid a rapidly changing economic cycle. While short-term cash yields may be higher than bond yields, a new analysis suggests that bonds may be a more attractive option due to their ability to lock in returns for the long term. The study found that even with lower initial yields, bonds can outperform cash over a five-year period, especially when considering the impact of reinvestment risk. As a result, experts recommend considering high-quality bonds as a more optimal investment choice, despite the current yield advantages of cash.

images.alt_text: Global investors have been building positions in Korean debt this year with purchases accelerating in May and June to the tune of more than US$23 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong to reopen Cathay’s in-town airport check-in Wednesday
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways will reopen its in-town airport check-in services in Hong Kong's central business district on July 5, after a nearly three-year shutdown. The service will be available from 6 am to 3 pm, with Cathay being the sole airline offering in-town check-in. The resumption comes after a shortage of workers prevented the service from restarting in April 2020. The move aims to enhance convenience for passengers and is part of Hong Kong's efforts to address acute staffing shortages in the aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is one of only a handful of places in the world that have in-town check-in – others include Taipei and Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Temasek’s investments into Sembmarine were made after due diligence: Indranee Rajah
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean investment firm, made an independent commercial decision to invest in Sembmarine in 2020 after conducting due diligence based on publicly available information. The investment was made despite allegations of corruption against Sembmarine's Brazilian unit, Seatrium, as Temasek was not aware of the charges against an ex-employee. The rights issues were conducted during the pandemic to ensure Sembmarine had sufficient funding to complete existing projects.

images.alt_text: The Corruption Practices Investigation Bureau has commenced investigations on Seatrium for alleged corruption offences, said the agency in a Wednesday press release.
Seatrium, formerly Sembmarine, announced that the proceedings in Brazil into its subsidiary there has been suspended.
Sembmarine says it will continue to co-operate and work with Brazilian authorities on this matter.

site_title: JTC, Singapore fuel cell maker Spectronik to start hydrogen truck trials in Q4
summary: Singapore-based fuel cell manufacturer Spectronik will start trials of its hydrogen fuel cell-powered light commercial vehicle, the Cruiser, in the fourth quarter of 2023 at the Jurong Innovation District. The one-year trial aims to investigate the commercial feasibility of fuel cell technology in a real-life setting. Spectronik plans to introduce a fleet of fuel cell LCVs on public roads within the next five years, with a long-range version of the Cruiser expected to be developed. The trial is a new milestone for Singapore's development of mobility solutions and its goal to achieve net-zero emissions by 2045.

images.alt_text: A green hydrogen plant built by Spanish company Iberdrola in Puertollano.

site_title: EU lawmakers back plan to beef up remote-worker rights
summary: The European Union has backed a plan to boost remote-worker rights, with over 30 lawmakers signing a document aiming to ensure access to co-working spaces, prohibit tracking employees' computers at home, and protect them from excessive work-related emails outside working hours. The plan builds on the EU's "right to disconnect" proposal, which could become EU law later this year, and aims to promote a healthy work-life balance and prevent burnout rates and loneliness. The move comes as managers and workers debate the benefits and drawbacks of remote work, with some companies experimenting with four-day workweeks and flexible schedules.

images.alt_text: There is still a long way to go to make the modern office fully inclusive.

The entrance to Salesforce Tower in New York, June 15, 2023. The next stage of getting workers back at their desks includes incentives like $10 to the charity of their choice, and consequences like poor performance evaluations if they don't make the trek in.

Workers and employers need to agree on the ground rules of the new workplace and foster a culture and environment that promotes employee retention and engagement, as well as organisational performance.

site_title: Pakistan inflation eases in June amid record interest rates
summary: Pakistan's inflation eased in June for the first time in seven months, rising 29.4% from the previous year, according to the Pakistan Bureau of Statistics. This marks a decrease from the 39.5% increase in food inflation and 20.3% rise in transport prices. The easing of inflation is attributed to record borrowing costs and lower commodity prices, following the central bank's decision to raise its benchmark rate to a record high of 22% and the government's fuel price cuts.

site_title: Indonesia’s June inflation eases to lowest in 14 months
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate eased to 3.52% in June, its lowest in 14 months, meeting Bank Indonesia's target range for the second consecutive month. This decline follows the peak of 6% in September and the central bank's interest rate hikes between August and January to control prices. Transportation and food prices rose, while telecommunications and financial services prices eased. Experts expect Bank Indonesia to start easing policy rates, with some predicting a rate cut in the third quarter, but the central bank has maintained a stable stance amid global uncertainties.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on April 4, 2023 shows employees working for a TikTok channel offering merchandise for sale through a TikTok livestream at a room in Jakarta. Despite a potential US ban over national security concerns, data shows the Chinese-owned app's rapid growth in Southeast Asia with Indonesia accounting for 70 percent of TikTok's $4.4 billion gross merchandise value in 2022. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP) / TO GO WITH: Indonesia-internet-economy-livestreaming-Tiktok, FOCUS by Agnes ANYA

site_title: Asia: Markets follow Wall St higher as US inflation eases
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, July 3, driven by hopes that the US Federal Reserve is nearing the end of its interest rate hiking cycle. The PCE index, a key gauge of inflation, dropped sharply, fueling optimism. Tech firms, including Apple, which became the first to surpass $3 trillion in market capitalization, led the gains. However, analysts warn that the Fed may not be swayed by the data, and interest rate hikes are likely to resume this month.

images.alt_text: Asian investors largely followed Wall Street higher but shifted cautiously.

site_title: Local firms’ payment performance worsens further in Q2: SCCB
summary: Singapore firms' payment performance worsened further in Q2, with both prompt and slow payments increasing. Prompt payments declined 0.11 percentage point to 40.92%, while slow payments rose 0.10 percentage point to 44.32%. The manufacturing and wholesale sectors experienced higher payment delays, with slow payments up 0.26 and 0.12 percentage points, respectively. The construction sector saw a rise in slow payments, with the building construction sector accounting for the largest increase, to 56.23%.

images.alt_text: Both prompt and slow payments accounted for slightly more than two-fifths of total payment transactions

site_title: Couture week comes to Paris amid riot fears
summary: Haute couture week kicks off in Paris amidst concerns over violent riots in the city, following the police killing of a 17-year-old teenager. Fashion shows, including those by Schiaparelli and Saudi designer Mohammad Ashi, are set to proceed despite the unrest. Animal activists have mixed opinions on Schiaparelli's use of fake animal heads in its designs. The event marks a significant push for Saudi Arabia to establish its own fashion industry, with billions of dollars invested in various sectors.

site_title: Singapore exploring master leases of up to 60 years for black-and-white bungalow estates
summary: Singapore is exploring the possibility of granting 30- to 60-year master leases to private developers for entire black-and-white bungalow estates, allowing them to "rejuvenate" the properties and reap benefits over a longer period. The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) is studying the feasibility of this approach, which aims to balance heritage preservation with redevelopment. The master leaseholder will have autonomy to decide on the estate's use, and the SLA will provide more flexibility to tenants, such as longer tenancy periods. The move is seen as a way to maximize the state's benefits from these properties, but some experts warn that it may be too much of a risk for developers.

images.alt_text: One of 10 bungalows leased by Unilever for a development campus.
The public service will reference the Ridout Road case as an additional example to reinforce the importance for public officers to act with integrity.
The bungalow at 26 Ridout Road rented by Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam.

site_title: Fortune may favour the bold in Jurong Lake District mega site tender
summary: Singapore's Jurong Lake District mega site, a 6.5-hectare white site for a mixed-use development, is up for tender with a maximum gross floor area of 365,000 sq m. The site, expected to be developed over 10-15 years, could accommodate 1,700 private homes and 1.6 million sq ft of office space. Leading developers should consider participating despite the hefty price tag, as the site offers scale for place making efforts and potential for higher profit margins. However, financing costs and the large office component may weigh heavily on the appetite of developers.

images.alt_text: Mega Jurong Lake District site for 1,700 housing units, 1.6 million sq ft office space up for tender

site_title: Apple forced to make cuts to Vision Pro production plans: FT
summary: Apple has cut its production forecasts for the Vision Pro headset, citing a lower-than-expected demand, according to the Financial Times. The Vision Pro, priced at $3,499, will be assembled by Chinese contract manufacturer Luxshare, which is now expected to produce fewer than 400,000 units in 2024, down from initial forecasts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Apple Inc. logo is seen hanging at the entrance to the Apple store on 5th Avenue in Manhattan, New York, U.S., October 16, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: The world’s appetite for solar panels is squeezing silver supply
summary: The world's growing demand for solar panels is increasing silver consumption, widening a supply deficit due to limited mine production. Silver, used in paste form to conduct electricity in solar cells, is forecast to make up 14% of consumption this year, up from 5% in 2014. The industry's shift to more efficient cells requiring more silver is expected to boost demand, with a study predicting that the solar sector could exhaust 85-98% of global silver reserves by 2050.

images.alt_text: Singapore is “on track” to quadruple solar panel deployment from 2021, the government said in its statement.

site_title: Oil prices range-bound amid tighter supply, slow demand fears
summary: Oil prices remained largely unchanged on Monday, with Brent crude futures up 4 US cents to $75.45 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $70.67 a barrel. Concerns about global economic headwinds and possible interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve offset forecasts of tighter supplies amid Opec+ cuts. Analysts expect oil prices to rise in the second half of 2023, despite slowing demand growth and lower forecasts for Brent prices, averaging at $83.03 a barrel in 2023.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia in June unexpectedly raised prices for July-loading cargoes, eating into Asian refiners’ margins.

site_title: Japan leaning toward softer AI rules than EU, says source
summary: Japan is leaning towards softer AI rules compared to the European Union, with the aim of boosting economic growth and becoming a leader in advanced chips. The country is expected to adopt an approach closer to the US, which is more lenient than the EU's stringent rules, including disclosure requirements for copyrighted material used to train AI systems. EU industry chief Thierry Breton is visiting Tokyo to promote the bloc's approach to AI rule-making and deepen cooperation in semiconductors.

images.alt_text: Whether the world is ready for it or not, AI has become a democratic force for leaders to seek ways to extend the benefits of its capabilities across enterprises.
Interest in AI has risen exponentially since the launch of ChatGPT late last year, prompting technology companies to rush out competing tools and chips to power them.
Upbeat sales targets by Nvidia has bouyed its stock. About 1,300 ESG-registered funds hold more than US$20 billion in Nvidia, according to Bloomberg.

site_title: Asia’s factory output slumps as weak China demand weighs
summary: Asia's factory activity slumped in June due to weak demand in China and advanced nations. China's manufacturing PMI eased to 50.5, staying above the contraction threshold, while Japan's PMI fell to 49.8 and South Korea's PMI dropped to 47.8. The decline is attributed to China's slower-than-expected economic rebound and aggressive interest rate hikes in the US and Europe. The impact is expected to weigh on the global economy, with Asia's economy accounting for 70% of global growth.

images.alt_text: The survey showed expansion of both manufacturing output and new orders softened in June.
Manufacturing output and new orders contracted for a ninth consecutive month as customer and market demand remained weak.
Asia’s fourth largest economy posted slim growth in the first quarter and has struggled to motor on due to weak external demand.

site_title: Telstra partners with Elon Musk’s Starlink for Internet in remote Australia
summary: Telstra, Australia's top telecom firm, has partnered with Elon Musk's Starlink to provide fixed broadband and voice services to rural Australians. The partnership will offer an additional connectivity option for people and businesses in remote locations, with higher download speeds compared to traditional copper-based services. Telstra expects to launch the new service options towards the end of the year.

site_title: China Vanke says local property market is worse than expected
summary: China Vanke, the country's second-largest home developer, stated that China's home market is worse than expected. The company's chairman, Yu Liang, previously downplayed concerns about the housing recovery in March, but now acknowledges "pressure in the short-term." This sentiment is shared by investors and analysts, who are bearish on China's real estate sector. The relaxation of home-buying restrictions and down-payment requirements in non-core areas may be considered to alleviate the pressure.

images.alt_text: Vanke’s stabilisation underscores the importance of state-backing as China undergoes a record slump in the property market.

site_title: PwC Australia sacks eight partners over tax leak scandal
summary: PwC Australia has fired eight partners, including former CEO Tom Seymour, as part of an internal investigation into the leak of confidential government tax plans. The investigation found breaches of professional standards and a failure of leadership to address them. Three partners were singled out for actions that "failed to meet their professional responsibilities", while five were removed for failing to prevent the actions or hold others accountable. The firings are part of PwC's efforts to contain the fallout from the scandal and improve its culture.

images.alt_text: PwC's brand is damaged by revelations that a former partner shared with colleagues confidential government plans to prevent tax avoidance, which were then used to pitch multinational companies for work.
The firm has already placed nine partners on leave and named four former partners directly involved in the breach who have since left the firm.

site_title: India’s factory growth softened slightly in June but stayed strong
summary: India's manufacturing industry expanded at a 2-year high in June, with the PMI at 57.8, down from May's 58.7. Higher input costs due to labor and raw material prices led to a slight slowdown, but demand remained robust, with foreign demand growing for the 15th straight month. Employment rose for a third consecutive month, but at a moderate pace. Inflation was only minutely higher than May and below the long-run average, with the RBI's comfort zone of 2-6%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A labourer welds an iron pillar at a building material factory in an industrial area in Dasna, in the central Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, India, January 9, 2019. Picture taken January 9, 2019. REUTERS/Adnan Abidi
India emerged as a key consumer of Russian oil following the invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Lim & Tan expects LHN to benefit from co-living boom; initiates ‘buy’
summary: Lim & Tan Securities has initiated a "buy" call on LHN, citing the co-living sector's growth potential as the key driver for the company's success over the next few years. The analysts expect LHN to benefit from the co-living boom, with a target price of S$0.50 and a potential upside of 25% from its current share price. The company's strong occupancy rates, resilient balance sheet, and attractive valuations also support the "buy" call.

images.alt_text: LHN Logistics owns a fleet of 74 prime movers and 356 trailers across Singapore and Malaysia.
LHN Logistics reported a net asset value of S$0.0783 per share as at Mar 31, 2023.

site_title: India's Tata Motors hikes prices of passenger vehicles for third time in 2023
summary: Tata Motors, an Indian automaker, has announced its third price hike for passenger vehicles in 2023, increasing prices by an average 0.6% starting July 17. The price increase aims to offset the residual impact of past input costs. The company cited a 30% rise in total expenses due to increased material costs. This follows previous price hikes in January and April, also attributed to input costs and regulatory changes. Vehicle prices across segments have increased in India due to the government's mandate for emission monitoring devices.

site_title: Lawrence Wong to replace Tharman as chairman of MAS, GIC committee
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will replace Tharman Shanmugaratnam as chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and GIC's Investment Strategies Committee (ISC), effective July 8. Wong, who is also Minister for Finance, will serve until May 31, 2026. Gan Kim Yong, Minister for Trade and Industry, will succeed Wong as deputy chairman. The appointments follow Tharman's resignation as MAS chairman and GIC deputy chairman and ISC chairman.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.
