Going by election results, Tharman is one of the most popular politicians around.

site_title: China’s jobless youths may pose political risk: top adviser
summary: China's youth unemployment rate has reached a record 20.8% due to a stagnating private sector scarred by COVID-19 restrictions. Top adviser Liu Yuanchun warns that if not handled properly, this issue could spark social problems and trigger political risks. Experts suggest a more robust economic recovery and labor market recovery are needed to defuse pressure among unemployed young people. The country's slowing economy combined with a flood of new graduates in the market presents a challenge for policymakers with few easy fixes.

images.alt_text: High youth joblessness has weighed on consumer confidence, as households have chosen to repay their debt early to reduce risks.
Home prices in some neighbourhoods are down almost 30 per cent from a peak in late 2021, according to multiple real estate agents.

site_title: Swiss inflation dips to 1.7% in June, but rate hike still expected
summary: Switzerland's inflation rate dropped to 1.7% in June, below the 2.2% rate in May and the 1.8% forecast. Although this is the first month inflation has returned to the Swiss National Bank's target range, economists expect the central bank to raise interest rates at least one more time in September, with a 66% probability of a 25 basis point hike to 2%. Analysts believe the SNB will continue to tighten monetary policy due to expected changes in price components, such as rent and electricity prices.

images.alt_text: The SNB has recently been selling foreign currencies to strengthen the franc, whose high value has helped to dampen inflation caused by more expensive imports.
Chairman of the Swiss National Bank (SNB) Thomas Jordan pointed to rising inflationary pressures and the danger of price increases becoming entrenched.

site_title: UBS aims to avoid using US$10 billion Credit Suisse backstop amid backlash: FT
summary: UBS aims to avoid using a US$10 billion backstop for Credit Suisse amid a backlash. The bank is working to minimize potential losses and risks, aiming to publish its second-quarter results on Aug 31 without calling on the government backstop. This move follows an agreement in June between UBS and the Swiss government to guarantee up to 9 billion Swiss francs of losses from the sale of Credit Suisse's assets. UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti has stated that the bank's leadership would prevent Swiss taxpayers from bearing the costs of the takeover.

images.alt_text: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti opposes the option to take Credit Suisse’s domestic unit public because he believes it may inadvertently strengthen the bank’s international competitors, the Swiss newspaper Schweiz am Wochenende says.

site_title: South Korea factory activity suffers longest downturn in at least 19 years
summary: South Korea's factory activity shrank for the 12th consecutive month, with the S&P Global PMI for manufacturers falling to 47.8 in June, the lowest level in three months. Output and new orders dropped by the most in eight and six months, respectively, amid weak external demand and muted business confidence. The country's economy has struggled to recover, with slim growth in the first quarter, and manufacturers' optimism for future output hitting a 10-month low in June.

images.alt_text: Global investors have been building positions in Korean debt this year with purchases accelerating in May and June to the tune of more than US$23 billion.

site_title: Asia refiners expect Saudi Arabia to cut August crude prices
summary: Asian refiners expect Saudi Arabia to lower crude prices for August, following a June price hike that ate into their margins. Saudi Arabia is expected to cut its official selling price (OSP) by about 50 US cents a barrel, amid a broader Opec+ deal to limit supply into 2024. Profits at Asian refineries processing Dubai crude fell to an average of US$3.44 a barrel in June, down from US$4.78 a barrel last month. The move aims to support global prices depressed by rising interest rates and recessionary fears.

images.alt_text: India emerged as a key consumer of Russian oil following the invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Thai parliament convenes after election to kick off PM selection
summary: Thailand's parliament will convene on July 3, marking the start of the process to form a government after the May election. The House of Representatives will elect a Speaker and two deputies, with Move Forward leader Pita Limjaroenrat aiming to secure the prime minister position. Pita's coalition has 312 lawmakers, but is short of the 376 votes needed for a joint sitting. The appointment of a Speaker will set the date for the prime minister election, which is seen as crucial to ending the country's standstill in government formation and stabilizing the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Move Forward Party leader, Pita Limjaroenrat looks on during a press conference following a meeting with coalition partners in Bangkok, Thailand, May 18, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: EU, Japan to deepen chip cooperation: Breton
summary: The European Union (EU) and Japan are deepening their cooperation on semiconductors to strengthen control over a technology vital for defense, electronics, and automotive industries. EU industry chief Thierry Breton said the EU will support Japanese semiconductor companies operating in the bloc, including access to subsidies. Japan is also offering subsidies to revitalize its chip industry, which has lost global market share. The EU and Japan will monitor the chip supply chain and facilitate the exchange of researchers and engineers, aiming to secure the supply chain and reduce dependence on China.

images.alt_text: IBM provides Rapidus key process technology that enables 2nm chip nodes and beyond, using a new type of transistor composition called nanosheet

site_title: Japan factory activity slips back into contraction in June on soft orders
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted in June after expanding for the first time in 7 months in May, according to a private survey. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index fell to 49.8, below the 50.0 threshold, driven by weak orders for cyclical goods and labor suitability issues. Demand from China, Japan's largest trade partner, was particularly weak. Despite a rebound in business confidence, manufacturers' future output expectations remain the strongest since October 2021, driven by hopes for a recovery in demand and easing of semiconductor market disruptions.

images.alt_text: Private consumption, which makes up more than half Japan's economy, grew 0.6 per cent in January-March from the previous quarter, as the country’s re-opening from the pandemic boosted service spending.

site_title: Singapore’s star banker Piyush Gupta creates succession dilemma for DBS
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest lender, is facing a succession dilemma as CEO Piyush Gupta, 63, nears the end of his 13-year tenure. The bank has been preparing for his departure for about 10 years, but there's no clear favourite to succeed him. Gupta's long-term record of success has raised questions about how his successor will be able to replicate his achievements. The bank's internal candidates, including Tan Su Shan, Shee Tse Koon, Han Kwee Juan, and Lim Him Chuan, have been groomed for the top post. DBS has a deep bench strength and is committed to grooming talent from within, but analysts say the bank's biggest challenge is finding a successor who can execute strongly and build on Gupta's legacy.

images.alt_text: Gupta’s remarks underscore the growing importance of Dubai, which is emerging as a favoured destination for hedge funds and financial firms, drawn by its ease of doing business, tax-free status and its allure as a nexus for global travel.

site_title: Japan’s land prices rise for second year running in 2022: tax agency
summary: Japan's land prices rose for the second consecutive year in 2022, with an average increase of 1.5% according to the National Tax Agency. The recovery from the pandemic's impact, eased restrictions, and rebounding tourism helped drive the growth. The largest increase was seen in Hokkaido's northern region, with 25 out of 47 prefectures experiencing price rises. Twenty prefectures posted price declines, with Tokyo's Ginza district seeing a 1.1% increase, marking the first time in three years.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing output and new orders contracted for a ninth consecutive month as customer and market demand remained weak.

site_title: Shipping industry faces net-zero emissions target, draft document shows
summary: The International Maritime Organisation (IMO) is set to propose interim targets for 2030 and 2040, aiming to reach a 2050 net-zero emissions target, aligning with the Paris Agreement. Shipping, responsible for 3% of human-made carbon dioxide emissions, would need to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2050. The proposed targets include indicative checkpoints for emissions reductions and a 2030 target for a significant portion of energy to come from zero or near-zero GHG-emission sources.

images.alt_text: Shipping, which emits 2.9 per cent of total greenhouse gases, has largely escaped taxation because the high seas are not in the jurisdiction of any one government.
Dr Vivian Balakrishnan hailed the treaty as a victory for international law.
In Asia, demand for biofuels and renewable fuels is growing but varies across markets.

site_title: What SGX RegCo expects of independent financial advisers for listed issuers
summary: SGX RegCo has issued a Guide on Independent Financial Advisers to improve standards, clarity, and consistency in advice provided by independent financial advisers (IFAs) to listed issuers. The guide requires IFAs to provide independent and professional opinions on proposed transactions, including exit offers and interested person transactions, to ensure directors make informed decisions that protect the interests of the issuer and minority shareholders. The goal is to enhance transparency and accountability in the advisory process.

images.alt_text: While it has to be recognised that no single valuation methodology will bet met with universal acceptance, the crux of the problem lies in whether IFAs, who are appointed and paid by target companies, can be seen to be truly independent.
Gear's key units, Gems and Stanmore, have plainly observable market prices

site_title: Australia’s largest IPO of 2023, Redox, opens slightly lower on debut
summary: Australia's largest IPO of 2023, Redox, opened 2.3% below its issue price of A$2.55 on the Australian Securities Exchange, raising A$402 million. The shares underperformed the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index, which rose 0.25%. The IPO marks a decline in Australian IPOs, down 94% from last year, and follows a 14-year low in new share sales.

images.alt_text: Traders are pricing a 60 per cent chance of a pause following back-to-back hikes the RBA had described in minutes as “finely balanced” calls.

site_title: South-east Asian companies sharpen internal lens as ESG disputes rise
summary: South-east Asian companies are taking a more cautious approach to their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices amid rising litigation risks. Companies are conducting internal investigations to review their board of directors' and employees' actions, and are implementing measures to mitigate ESG-related disputes. Experts advise companies to have a robust governance structure, clear guidelines, and stay aware of market trends and regulatory standards to address ESG risks. This increased scrutiny reflects a growing awareness of ESG obligations and the need for companies to take proactive steps to manage ESG-related risks.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of greenery in city state Singapore. For stories regarding ESG, sustainability, sustainability investing, and business environmental governance
Generics of DBS building
FILE PHOTO: People use DBS automated teller machines (ATMs) in Singapore March 31, 2022. REUTERS/Caroline Chia/File Photo
The political attacks on ESG seem to be working—mentions of ESG on earnings calls have fallen of late. Or perhaps companies that are committed to ESG are just being quieter about it.

site_title: Big policy moves turn spotlight on South-east Asia’s renewables in H2 2023
summary: South-east Asia's renewable energy sector is gaining momentum, driven by supportive regulation and tariff policies. Vietnam approved a new power masterplan to boost wind and gas energy, while Malaysia lifted its ban on renewable energy exports. The Philippines is holding its second green energy auction, and Thailand is expected to increase its renewables sector. Indonesia, the world's fourth-largest emitter, is expected to see more investments in renewables due to the Just Energy Transition Partnership scheme. The region's largest emitter is expected to reconcile its opportunities with overcoming challenges, such as a congested grid and inadequate regulations.

images.alt_text: Power pact: Keppel Infrastructure CEO Cindy Lim and Royal Group Power chairman Neak Okhna Kith Meng display the power purchase and export agreement that was signed on Wed (Mar 15). Malaysian Minister of Economy Rafizi Ramli says reversing the ban will help firms build renewable-power generation capacity on a larger scale and take advantage of high demand from neighbouring Singapore.

To complete its transition to carbon neutrality with total phase-out of coal by 2050, the government estimates it needs a whopping US$658 billion, of which one-fifth would have to be disbursed this decade.

Wind turbines, including some from RWE's new Kaskasi offshore wind farm, are pictured during the opening of the RWE-Offshore-Windpark Kaskasi, north of Helgoland, Germany, March 23, 2023.    Christian Charisius/Pool via REUTERS
While the Asean 5 countries have made good progress in establishing emissions targets, they have been slow to translate their goals into regulatory frameworks and roadmaps.

site_title: Gold edges lower on prospects of hawkish US Fed rate-hike path
summary: Gold prices edged lower in early Asian trade on Monday, July 3, due to a stronger US dollar and prospects of further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $1,917.19 per ounce, while US gold futures declined 0.2% to $1,925.10. This marks the second quarter's decline, with gold ending 2.2% lower in June, as investors anticipate a longer Fed rate hike path.

images.alt_text: The dollar index was steady near a two-week high hit in the previous session, making gold expensive for holders of other currencies.

site_title: India’s oil imports from Russia climb to new peak as limit nears
summary: India's oil imports from Russia reached a new peak in June, standing at 2.2 million barrels per day, surpassing Saudi Arabia and Iraq. This marks the 10th consecutive month of rising imports, which could near its limit due to infrastructure issues and the need to maintain relations with other suppliers. State-owned Indian Oil and Reliance Industries were the top buyers of Russian crude over the past two months. However, imports may dip next month due to lower Russian supply.

site_title: Quarz’s internalisation proposal is an opportunity for Sabana Reit’s manager to show independence
summary: Sabana Reit's manager is facing a proposal by activist investor Quarz Capital to internalise the manager, a move that could lead to cost and risk for unitholders. The proposal comes amid a contentious relationship between the manager and ESR Group, which owns the managers of Sabana Reit and ESR Logos Reit. Unitholders must consider the potential implications of the proposal, including the impact on credit facilities from lenders such as UOB. A vote is set for an extraordinary general meeting.

images.alt_text: Sabana Reit owns New Tech Park, a six-storey industrial building with a ground level carpark at Lorong Chuan.
Sias lamented in a March commentary the "ridiculous lowball" offers that foment investor resentment and mistrust in the local market

In response to a query from The Business Times, Quarz Capital said on Friday (Jun 23) said that an internal manager model for Sabana Reit would help transfer “significant value” from ESR Group to the Reit’s unitholders.
The EGM will run for two hours starting from 2 pm and will take place at Hope@New Tech Park.
Quarz believes the move to replace Sabana Reit’s manager – an external manager controlled by ESR – with an internal manager will net cost savings for unitholders.
Proceeds from the facilities will go towards refinancing the Reit's existing debt, asset acquisition, asset enhancement initiatives and working capital requirements.

site_title: India and the global balance of power
summary: India and the US have a crucial partnership, but a formal alliance against China is unlikely. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and US President Joe Biden's meeting in June highlighted the evolving relationship, but Foreign Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar emphasized that a formal alliance is not possible due to India's postcolonial mistrust of alliances. The two countries have maintained long-term partnerships despite India's historical focus on China, and annual "Track Two" talks have been ongoing since 2001, addressing shared concerns about extremist threats and differing perspectives on regional security.

site_title: Hot stocks: OUE Healthcare, Healthway Medical jump after proposed privatisation
summary: OUE Healthcare has proposed a voluntary conditional offer to take Healthway Medical private at S$0.048 per share, with the goal of harnessing potential synergies to deliver comprehensive healthcare services. Shares of both companies rose significantly, with OUEH's up 11.5% and Healthway Medical's up 39.4%, following the announcement. The offer is conditional on Healthway Medical shareholders' approval and requires a maximum of 1.4 billion shares to be acquired, representing about 30.4% of the total issued shares.

images.alt_text: OUE Healthcare launches its new hospital in Changshu – a joint venture with China Merchant Group.

site_title: Directors should scrutinise IFA opinions, IFAs must not be swayed by conflicts: SGX RegCo
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has released new guidelines for independent financial advisers (IFAs) to ensure they provide unbiased opinions on proposed transactions, such as exit offers or interested party transactions. The guidelines require IFAs to be independent and competent, and to clearly explain their conclusions. Directors should scrutinize IFA opinions and ensure they are not swayed by conflicts of interest. The guidelines follow controversies surrounding IFAs in the past year, including a faulty opinion on Golden Energy and Resources' exit offer.

images.alt_text: Sias lamented in a March commentary the "ridiculous lowball" offers that foment investor resentment and mistrust in the local market
Gear's key units, Gems and Stanmore, have plainly observable market prices

While it has to be recognised that no single valuation methodology will bet met with universal acceptance, the crux of the problem lies in whether IFAs, who are appointed and paid by target companies, can be seen to be truly independent.
David Gerald president of Sias says that the IFA has conflated the two corporate actions to the detriment of minority shareholders.

site_title: China’s June factory activity slows as conditions weaken: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity growth slowed in June, with the Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) easing to 50.5, down from 50.9 in May. This indicates a marginal expansion in activity, but the figure is considered a leading economic indicator, showing China's economy struggling to sustain the post-Covid recovery amid a property downturn, high youth unemployment, and deflationary pressures. The slowdown adds to evidence of a lost momentum in the second quarter, prompting markets to anticipate more policy support to bolster the stuttering economic recovery.

images.alt_text: China is looking well into the future to avoid a repeat of energy shortages, while also seeking to fuel economic growth; last month, state-owned China National Petroleum sealed a 27-year deal with Qatar and took a stake in the exporter’s massive expansion project.

site_title: Japan business sentiment improves in second quarter: BOJ tankan
summary: Japan's business sentiment improved in the second quarter, with the headline index for big manufacturers reaching a two-year high of plus 5, and the sentiment index for big non-manufacturers hitting a 10-year high of plus 23. Companies expect to increase capital expenditure by 13.4% and project inflation to stay above the Bank of Japan's 2% target for five years. The economy is expected to continue expanding, driven by post-pandemic domestic spending and offsetting global growth headwinds.

images.alt_text: Japan has assured other nations that the release of the water is safe, is in line with standard industry practice and that it’s necessary, because about 1,000 storage tanks at Fukushima will hit capacity early in 2024.

site_title: IBM throws weight behind Japan chip startup it sees as vital
summary: IBM is investing heavily in Japan's chip startup Rapidus, providing key process technology to enable 2nm chip nodes and beyond. The venture-backed firm aims to fabricate such chips at scale by the end of the decade, aiming to secure a stable supply of the world's most advanced semiconductors. IBM sees Rapidus as vital to meeting growing demand and reducing reliance on industry leader Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC). The project has attracted significant investment, including from Toyota Motor and Sony Group, and is expected to create a world-class chipmaking foundry to catch up with TSMC.

images.alt_text: IBM says it will finance the deal with cash on hand and expects the transaction to close in the latter half of 2023.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE Healthcare, Healthway Medical, Keppel, ARA H-Trust, AP Strategic
summary: OUE Healthcare has proposed a conditional exit offer to take Healthway Medical private at S$0.048 per share. Keppel's shares rose 0.6% after a claimant appealed against a lawsuit against the company. ARA H-Trust will divest its Hyatt Place Oklahoma City Airport hotel for US$8 million. AP Strategic will no longer acquire Catapult Ventures, a personal financial marketplace. Sabana Reit's sponsor ESR Group criticized Quarz Capital's plan to internalize the Reit's manager, calling it "highly reckless and irresponsible."

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index fell 0.04 per cent or 1.37 points to end Friday (Jun 30) at 3,205.91.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How to achieve salary independence (Ep 146)
summary: BT Money Hacks discusses achieving salary independence with David Kuo, co-founder of The Smart Investor. The conversation explores the concept of salary independence, the difference between savings and investing, and the path to achieving it. Key takeaways include the importance of investing in the stock market and building a diversified portfolio to achieve long-term financial stability and independence from a paycheck.

images.alt_text: Find out where the experts feel you should put your money. India or China?
What is it about inflation that still worries many? And what more can you do?

site_title: China Life Overseas gears up to tap mainlanders as sales jump
summary: China Life Overseas, the overseas arm of state-owned China Life Insurance, is stepping up efforts to tap mainland clients as sales jump 136% in the first four months. The company has seen a 28-fold increase in insurance sales to mainland tourists in the first quarter, with mainland customers now contributing 15% of new business premiums. China Life Overseas is expanding its agent force and preparing to roll out more convenient services, including direct claim payments to mainland bank accounts, to capitalize on the growth of mainland tourists visiting Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: China’s top graft-busting watchdog earlier this year vowed to eliminate ideas of a Western-style “financial elite” and rectify the hedonism of excessive pursuit of “high-end taste”.

site_title: Singapore’s a magnet for mega stars like Taylor Swift, Jacky Cheung: Here’s why
summary: Taylor Swift's exclusive concert in Singapore showcases the city-state's ability to attract big acts. Close working ties between event organizers, sponsors, and partners, including government support, are key factors in Singapore's success as a top tour stop. The Singapore Tourism Board's Leisure Events Fund and the government's co-funding of the Singapore Grand Prix have generated significant revenue and tourism receipts. The event also highlights the country's vibrant entertainment and lifestyle scene, with integrated resorts like Marina Bay Sands collaborating with industry giants to bring in top acts.

images.alt_text: With more tickets going to scalpers out to make a quick buck, concertgoers increasingly find themselves forced to fork out more money for scalped tickets – or be left out in the cold.

According to chat groups on Telegram set up to discuss the concert, multiple Swifties said they rushed to open accounts or apply for credit cards with UOB the moment news of the presale broke in the morning on Wednesday (Jun 21).
Agoda regional associate vice-president for South-east Asia Eenric Casals says that searches for Singapore during Taylor Swift's concert dates have already surged, ahead of ticket sales next week.
US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift adds Australia to her Eras tour, bringing it to a total of 106 shows worldwide before bowing out in London in mid-2024.

site_title: Global funds have another window to buy Asia’s favourite bonds
summary: Global investors have been buying South Korean debt rapidly, with over $23 billion in purchases in May and June, and $37 billion year to date. Yields have risen for three straight months due to inflation concerns, but data to be released may show easing consumer prices, potentially leading to a rate cut by the Bank of Korea. Analysts predict a decline in yields, with some expecting the 3-year bond yield to fall to 3.25% and the 10-year yield to 3.2% by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: South Korean exports of chips slumped 28 per cent in June after falling 36 per cent in May, and exports of petroleum products were down 41 per cent.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday tracking global gains; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,212.63 on Monday, tracking global gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 38, with heavily traded securities including Seatrium, Thai Beverage, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS and OCBC advancing, while UOB lost 0.2%. The STI's gain follows a 1.2% rise in the S&P 500 and a 1.2% increase in the pan-European Stoxx 600 index on Friday.

images.alt_text: OUE Healthcare makes an offer to take Healthway Medical private.

site_title: Australian commodities exports surge to record US$300 billion, but set to tumble
summary: Australian commodities exports reached a record $300 billion in the financial year, driven by a surge in energy prices and a strong US dollar. However, exports are forecast to decline 15% to $390 billion and then 21% to $344 billion in the next two years due to falling energy prices and supply increases. The resumption of thermal coal exports to China will help offset weaker energy demand globally. Exports of iron ore, LNG, and energy transition metals like lithium and cobalt are also expected to decline.

images.alt_text: CoreLogic’s Tim Lawless says a lack of supply was still the main driver of price rises, adding that “the flow of new capital city listings was nearly 10 per cent below the previous five-year average” in June.

site_title: HDB resale volumes fall to three-year low in Q2; prices rise 1.4%
summary: HDB resale flat volumes declined 4.6% to 6,409 flats in Q2 2023, the lowest in three years. Resale prices rose 1.4%, driven by buyers seeking larger homes, with median prices of five-room and four-room flats increasing 1.9% and 1.5%, respectively. Higher borrowing costs and cooling measures may have deterred some homeowners from upgrading to private homes, while increased grants for first-timers may have boosted demand for HDB resale homes.

images.alt_text: This is the lowest quarterly growth since Q3 2020, when prices climbed 1.5 per cent.
HDB is also studying ways to maximise the available pool of flats under the Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme.
Resale prices rise at a moderate pace of 0.3 per cent in May.
The Singapore housing market is currently buttressed by the inter-generational transfer of wealth and the desire to upgrade homes.
The opportunity cost of delaying attempts to purchase a HDB BTO flat can be huge.

site_title: Singapore private home prices slip for first time in 3 years but it may be too early to call market peak
summary: Singapore's private home prices have slipped 0.4% quarter-over-quarter in Q2, marking the first drop in three years, according to a flash estimate by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). This moderation is attributed to a decrease in non-landed home prices in the city fringe region. Despite this, property consultants expect the market to continue growing, with forecasts ranging from 3% to 5% for the full year. The cooling measures, including the doubling of the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rate, have affected foreign buying, but a sharp price correction is unlikely.

images.alt_text: The Marina Gardens Lane site, zoned residential with commercial at first storey, can yield about 790  private housing units.
The Reserve Residences sold 83 per cent of its released units on launch day, making it the best performing property launch by unit sales in 2023.
The Continuum, a freehold development on Thiam Siew Avenue off Tanjong Katong Road.

Private residential properties in Singapore's prime areas are expected to be affected the most by the latest cooling measures due to the traditionally higher component of foreign buyers in these areas compared with the city-fringe and suburban locations.
URA's flash estimate has shown a 3.2 per cent quarter-on-quarter rise for its overall private home price index in Q1 2023.

Generic photograph of HDB flats and landed properties in Hougang as viewed from The Tembusu condominium along Tampines Road on Feb 14, 2023. site_title: Australia watchers split on RBA rate path as inflation lingers
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to divide economists and traders on its interest rate decision, with a 60% chance of a pause following back-to-back hikes. The RBA has described the calls as "finely balanced," and some economists, including the Commonwealth Bank, predict a rate hold, while others, including Goldman Sachs, expect a quarter-point increase. Factors driving a hike include stronger-than-expected jobs data, sustained global tightening, and core inflation above 6%. The RBA's decision comes after the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Bank of England also raised rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: CoreLogic’s Tim Lawless says a lack of supply was still the main driver of price rises, adding that “the flow of new capital city listings was nearly 10 per cent below the previous five-year average” in June.
Total receipts were A$8.5 billion higher than projected in the May Budget, while payments were lower by A$3.0 billion.

site_title: Yellen to visit China, raising need to ‘responsibly manage’ ties
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will visit China from July 6-9, marking the second trip by a Cabinet official to the country since deteriorating ties earlier this year. Yellen will discuss "responsibly managing" the relationship, global challenges, and economic cooperation, aiming to build longer-term channels of communication. Despite tensions over trade, human rights, and other issues, the US seeks to deepen and stabilize the relationship, with a focus on climate change, debt distress, and promoting global economic growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

site_title: Taylor Swift fans and other concertgoers should apply for debit cards over credit cards
summary: Taylor Swift fans and concertgoers are advised to opt for debit cards over credit cards to avoid negatively impacting their credit scores. Using a debit card linked to a savings account can help avoid annual fees and credit score implications. With multiple concerts on the horizon, individuals may find it challenging to manage multiple credit cards, potentially leading to overspending and a lower credit score.

images.alt_text: “People are willing to splurge because they know they will get quality content, plus who knows when or if she’ll do another tour after this one,” says a Beyoncé fan.
US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift adds Australia to her Eras tour, bringing it to a total of 106 shows worldwide before bowing out in London in mid-2024.
Agoda regional associate vice-president for South-east Asia Eenric Casals says that searches for Singapore during Taylor Swift's concert dates have already surged, ahead of ticket sales next week.
With more tickets going to scalpers out to make a quick buck, concertgoers increasingly find themselves forced to fork out more money for scalped tickets – or be left out in the cold.

site_title: Barclays seeks to stop being corporate banker to Odey Asset Management: FT
summary: Barclays is reportedly seeking to terminate its corporate banking relationship with Odey Asset Management due to allegations of sexual assault and harassment by founder Crispin Odey, which have led to redemptions from the hedge fund. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has been pressing other financial firms to cut ties with OAM, with asset management companies Schroders and Canada Life already distancing themselves. Odey has denied the allegations, and his firm is proposing to restructure two key funds as part of efforts to extract him from the business.

images.alt_text: Barclays is tapping an increasing appetite from Asia quantitative and multi-strategy hedge funds for its prime financing business.

site_title: Thailand’s Really Cool Airlines set to take flight, wants to be ‘most innovative’ carrier
summary: Really Cool Airlines, a new long-haul carrier in Thailand, plans to take flight in the first quarter of 2024. The airline aims to be the "most innovative" carrier, offering unique experiences and services. CEO Patee Sarasin, a well-known figure in aviation circles, is seeking to differentiate his airline from others in the sector. With a focus on regional destinations and European routes, Really Cool Airlines will use Airbus A330 and A350 planes. The airline's membership drive has seen 999 accounts sold, with benefits including seat upgrades and free hotel stays.

site_title: Biden to travel to UK, Nato summit, Finland
summary: US President Joe Biden will travel to the UK for a Nato summit and a meeting with Finnish leaders in Helsinki, focusing on reinforcing the international coalition supporting Ukraine's counteroffensive against Russia. Biden will meet with Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson at the White House on Wednesday to discuss Stockholm's Nato ambitions, amid Sweden's blocked membership bid. The Nato summit comes as Ukraine intensifies its campaign to join the alliance amid Russia's invasion.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden addresses the nation on averting default and the Bipartisan Budget Agreement, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, June 2, 2023.   JIM WATSON/Pool via REUTERS     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Japan set to pour Fukushima water into Pacific, irking China
summary: Japan is set to release over 1 million cubic meters of treated water from the Fukushima nuclear disaster site into the Pacific Ocean, sparking controversy with neighboring countries, particularly China. The move is necessary to avoid overflowing storage tanks at the site by early 2024. Japan has assured other nations that the release is safe and in line with industry practice. The International Atomic Energy Agency and a domestic nuclear regulator are set to review the safety of the process, with a final report expected to be delivered soon.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy is finally recovering from the scars of the Covid-19 pandemic, though risks of a global slowdown and rising food prices hang over the outlook for exports and consumption.

site_title: Tesla beats second-quarter delivery estimates as price cuts pay off
summary: Tesla delivered a record 466,140 vehicles in the second quarter, topping estimates of 445,000. The company's price cuts and US federal credits made its electric vehicles more affordable, leading to a 10% increase from the previous quarter and an 83% jump from a year earlier. Despite stiff competition from BYD, Tesla is expected to hit record sales in China, its second-largest market. The company's margins are expected to trough in the next few quarters, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Ford, General Motors and ChargePoint are among the companies that have signed up for Tesla’s charging design in the past few weeks.

site_title: Pimco preparing for ‘harder landing’ of global economy, says CIO
summary: Pimco's Chief Investment Officer Daniel Ivascyn warns of a "harder landing" for the global economy due to rising interest rates, citing a typical lag of 5-6 quarters for the impact to be felt. This prediction comes as top central bank chiefs continue their interest rate hikes. Ivascyn believes the market is too confident in central bank decisions, increasing uncertainty and risk to extreme economic outlooks.

site_title: Record ESG bonds sold by Japan firms as government set to debut
summary: Japanese companies have sold a record amount of yen sustainable bonds, with a 47% increase to 2.6 trillion yen (S$24.4 billion) in the first half of 2023, surpassing global and regional growth. Japanese issuers, such as Japan Airlines, have been the world's most active sustainable bond issuers in 2023. The government is set to debut its own environment note sale, highlighting its commitment to ESG fundraising, further driving growth in the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
Relatively newer sustainable bond markets around the globe are increasingly complementing sustained growth in more seasoned markets such as China, according to Moody's ESG Solutions.
MUFG and its partners are launching a platform that aims to impact nearly 20 million people across 25 countries.

site_title: The German chip sector’s next challenge: labour
summary: Germany's chip sector faces a skilled labor shortage, with over 76,000 employees in Saxony, but the EU aims to manufacture 20% of the world's semiconductors by 2030. To address this, universities like TU Dresden and research institutes are training talent, while companies like Infineon and Bosch are attracting foreign workers. The EU Chips Act allocates billions for research and subsidies, and programs like the European Chips Skills 2030 Academy aim to train 500,000 microelectronics experts. However, competition for skilled workers is high, with salaries in other industries and countries offering higher incentives, and convincing foreign workers to stay in Germany remains a challenge.

images.alt_text: ASML is Europe’s largest chip equipment company due to its dominance in lithography, one of the central steps in the computer chip-making process.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for June 30, 2023, highlights a relatively quiet week in the tanker and dry bulk market. In the Capesize sector, rates softened slightly despite activity, while the Pacific market experienced minimal activity leading up to the Singapore holiday. The Panamax market saw rates ease in all areas, with the Atlantic trans-Atlantic trades lacking. In the Ultramax/Supramax sector, the Asian arena remained buoyant, while the Atlantic lost traction. The handy sector declined due to lack of fresh enquiry, and the LPG market remained flat. The LNG market saw moderate rises, with the east and US having movement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker is tugged towards a thermal power station in Futtsu, east of Tokyo, Japan November 13, 2017. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: REPT’s US$1 billion IPO leads wave of auto startup filings in Hong Kong
summary: Chinese automotive startups have filed for initial public offerings (IPOs) in Hong Kong, marking a potential turnaround in the city's IPO market. Four companies, including REPT Battero Energy, RoboSense Technology, Black Sesame International Holding, and Autostreets Development, submitted applications for first-time share sales. The filings come as China seeks to support companies in hard tech areas such as AI and semiconductors, and Hong Kong's exchange operator introduced measures to make it easier for such companies to list. The IPO market in Hong Kong has been sluggish this year, with companies raising just $2.2 billion so far.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index is little changed.

site_title: ARA H-Trust to divest Hyatt Place hotel in Oklahoma for US$8 million
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) has agreed to divest its Hyatt Place Oklahoma City Airport hotel for US$8 million, representing a 7% discount from its last valuation of US$8.6 million. The divestment is attributed to the hotel's location in a market with declining economic conditions exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The sale is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2023 and will free up capital to redeploy to more accretive properties or pare down existing borrowings.

site_title: ‘Indiana Jones’ misses estimates in hit to theatres’ rebound
summary: The latest Indiana Jones film, "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny", underperformed in its North American weekend debut, earning US$60 million in ticket sales, missing the projected US$70.3 million. The film's distributor, Walt Disney, had forecast US$65 million for the US and up to US$145 million globally. The disappointing result is bad news for the movie's producer, Lucasfilm, and the theatre industry, which is trying to bounce back from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Indiana Jones (Harrison Ford) returns to the screen older and grizzlier, but still wisecracking and cracking his whip.
“I’m saying goodbye to a brilliant opportunity to bring joy to people,” Harrison Ford says.

site_title: Bullish momentum expected to continue for Nikkei 225
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 Mini Futures contract is expected to continue its bullish momentum, driven by structural tailwinds such as Japan's exit from deflation, the Bank of Japan's ultra-easy monetary policy, and corporate reforms. Despite a potential near-term correction due to a global economic slowdown, the contract is forecasted to reach 38.2% retracement level of 31,465-31,500 and then recover to resistance levels at 33,960-34,000 by the end of 2023, with a potential target at the August 1989 high of 35,192-35,200.

images.alt_text: Foreign investors are excited about the prospect of a new era of growth in corporate Japan and their buying help the Nikkei share benchmark to scale three-decade peaks.

site_title: French riots over killing start to ease as economic costs mount
summary: French riots over the killing of a 17-year-old teenager have started to ease, with tensions abating slightly as authorities deployed 45,000 police across the country. The unrest, which drew comparisons to the US reaction to George Floyd's murder, has resulted in 719 arrests and estimated damages of over 100 million euros. President Emmanuel Macron has called a meeting to discuss the situation, while the officer who fired the fatal shot remains in pre-trial detention. The economic costs of the unrest are mounting, with over 10 shopping malls, 200 supermarkets, and 250 bank outlets targeted or looted.

images.alt_text: More than two hundred police were injured and 875 people arrested overnight, authorities said, as rioters clashed with officers in towns and cities across France, with buildings as well as buses and other vehicles torched, and stores looted.

site_title: Xi’s central bank shake-up prioritises continuity over big change
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has appointed Pan Gongsheng as the new party chief of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), indicating a continuation of the central bank's recent approach of modestly cutting interest rates and encouraging targeted lending. This move signals that policymakers will avoid drastic shifts as the world's second-largest economy struggles to regain momentum. Pan's appointment leaves key questions unanswered about the PBOC's role under Xi's leadership, and his relatively weak party ranking may lead to less PBOC influence in economic decision-making.

images.alt_text: The central bank set its so-called fixing for the managed currency at a stronger-than-expected level on Friday, after the offshore yuan extended a seven-month low.

site_title: China stock investors see humble 2023 returns on growth fears
summary: Chinese stocks are expected to see modest gains in the second half, with the benchmark CSI 300 Index likely to climb about 3% this quarter and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index advancing less than 6%. Investors are cautious due to weak economic data and a potential US recession, with no clear solution to China's economic woes. The market is awaiting a ramp-up of fiscal support, particularly in reviving the property market, and a meaningful announcement from the July Politburo meeting.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index is little changed.

site_title: Australian home prices climb for fourth month in June
summary: Australian home prices rose for the fourth consecutive month in June, with national home prices increasing 1.1% from the previous month. The surge was driven by a sustained shortage of housing supply, with new listings nearly 10% below the five-year average. Sydney led the way with a 1.7% surge, followed by Brisbane at 1.3%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to raise interest rates to curb inflation, which has recently reached all-time lows due to high household debt.

images.alt_text: The data reinforces a picture of strong housing demand and limited property listings.

site_title: Food for thought for business leaders, because AI is here whether we like it or not
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) has become a "democratic force" for business leaders to leverage across enterprises, with 78% of Asian-Pacific employees viewing AI with optimism. By 2030, AI is expected to contribute up to $1 trillion to the South-east Asian economy, with 33.6% coming from Indonesia. To tackle the change, business leaders should use AI to enhance productivity, empower teams to experiment with new ideas, and provide training and upskilling opportunities for employees. If used responsibly, AI can elevate current standards and enable original thinkers and innovators.

images.alt_text: Generative AI rely heavily on substantial computational power, robust data processing capabilities, and extensive storage capacities -- all of which will drive increasing demand for data centres.
Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt (left, with Databricks co-founder Arsalan Tavakoli) warns that AI could be used by bad actors to "accelerate at scale".
It can be tough to write about machines without metaphors. But AI is too important for loose language.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments’ acquisition of MoneySmart falls through
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments' acquisition of MoneySmart, a personal financial marketplace, has fallen through due to "adverse current market conditions." The deal, valued at S$221.5 million, was set to lead to a reverse takeover of APS and the listing of Catapult Ventures on the Singapore Exchange. Both parties mutually agreed not to extend the long stop date, resulting in the deal lapsing on June 30. APS will continue to explore other acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Artificial intelligence companies hunt for San Francisco offices
summary: San Francisco's office vacancy rate surged to nearly 32% in the second quarter, with major tech companies like Okta and Uber Technologies pulling back. However, artificial intelligence companies, including Hive, are seeking space, with over 10 firms inquiring for 800,000 square feet. Hive plans to occupy 57,000 square feet at 100 First Street, marking a sign of life in the market. The city's office utilisation is less than half of its pre-pandemic levels, with concerns about safety and homelessness contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: South Korea posts first trade surplus in 16 months on car sales
summary: South Korea reported its first trade surplus in 16 months in June, driven by robust automobile exports and declining energy imports. Exports dropped 6% from the prior year, while imports fell 11.7%, resulting in a $1.1 billion surplus. The data suggests the slump in demand for South Korean goods is easing, but uncertainties remain over the chip industry's rebound, which depends on China's economic growth. The government plans to boost export efforts and energy efficiency to achieve a positive figure in exports within the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The all-industry production index, which includes both the manufacturing and services sectors, rose 1.3 per cent in May on-month, recouping April’s 1.3 per cent loss.

site_title: Sunak mulls rescinding EU-era water law to build more homes
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is considering rescinding an EU-era water law to build more homes, amid a housing shortage and pressure to meet a manifesto pledge. The proposed move, using the government's flagship regeneration bill, would override a 2018 ruling banning housebuilding in areas risking river pollution. The move could ease construction in areas like Kent and Wales but risks drawing attention to the Tories' poor record on pollution and environmental standards. Experts say the decision could have significant consequences for the environment and the housing market.

images.alt_text: Terraced residential housing in Sheffield, UK, on Friday, May 19, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK CPI Inflation data on Wednesday. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: Regulator probes ex-Credit Suisse CEO Gottstein: Swiss newspaper
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator Finma has triggered enforcement proceedings against four unnamed former Credit Suisse staffers over the lender's serious breach of risk management obligations in the Greensill Capital supply-chain financing affair. The investigation is also focusing on Thomas Gottstein, the former CEO of Credit Suisse. Finma concluded in February that Credit Suisse breached its obligations in the Greensill Capital scandal, which involved a US$10 billion group of funds linked to disgraced financier Lex Greensill. The investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti opposes the option to take Credit Suisse’s domestic unit public because he believes it may inadvertently strengthen the bank’s international competitors, the Swiss newspaper Schweiz am Wochenende says.

site_title:
US dollar turns softer on cooling 
consumer spending data
summary: The US dollar softened on Friday after cooling consumer spending data, raising doubts about the Federal Reserve's potential aggressiveness in fighting inflation. The US personal consumption expenditures (PCE) gained 0.1% in May, while the dollar index fell 0.426% to 102.880, snapping a two-session gain. This follows a 0.3% quarterly gain, marking the greenback's first quarterly rise in four months.

images.alt_text: The pound was broadly steady against the US dollar at US$1.2638 by 0928 GMT, and also flat against the euro, which was worth 86.35 pence.

site_title: Meet the French luthier making music out of mushrooms
summary: French luthier Rachel Rosenkrantz is creating environmentally friendly guitars using biomaterials, such as mycelium, a fungus that mimics the rind of soft-ripened cheese. Rosenkrantz trains bees to build a honeycomb guitar body and has successfully created a prototype that is lightweight, biodegradable, and has a unique sound. Her goal is to make these instruments more accessible, with prices starting at around $6,000. Rosenkrantz hopes to partner with major companies to produce these instruments at a lower cost, making music education more inclusive for students who cannot afford traditional instruments.

images.alt_text: Shahzad Ismaily in his Brooklyn studio preparing for a recording session, in New York on June 5, 2023. Born with a rare genetic disorder, the multi-instrumentalist felt like a permanent outsider as a child. He now wields those lessons as one of music's most coveted collaborators.

site_title: China is buying natural gas like there’s still an energy crisis
summary: China is aggressively buying natural gas, aiming to bolster energy security and fuel economic growth. The nation is on track to be the world's top importer of liquefied natural gas (LNG) in 2023, with long-term contracts offering a steady price. China's efforts will help underpin global export projects and increase its influence in the market. The government is pushing energy giants to increase domestic production, reducing reliance on imports, while also securing supplies from the LNG market.

images.alt_text: Throughout this month, Dubai crude has fluctuated heavily, largely due to aggressive bidding and offering from the trading units of Chinese oil refiners, PetroChina and Sinopec.

site_title: Payday just keeps getting sweeter, if you’re the boss
summary: Highly paid CEOs in the US continue to earn vast sums, with Sundar Pichai of Alphabet receiving $225.985 million in 2022, more than 808 times the median employee's pay. The median Google employee earned $279,802, and other top executives, such as Stephen Scherr of Hertz and Barry McCarthy of Peloton, received $182 million and $168 million, respectively. Shareholders at Live Nation recently voted against the company's executives' compensation, citing a pay ratio of 5,414. The Dodd-Frank Act requires companies to disclose executive pay, and some experts argue that CEO-worker pay ratios should be capped at 20 times to prevent income inequality.

images.alt_text: CEO Goh Choon Phong’s pay has risen 86 per cent compared with his S$3.6 million compensation from a year earlier, according to the company’s annual report.
This year, executive chairman Reed Hastings is set to receive a US$500,000 salary and US$2.5 million in stock.

site_title: MAS’ and other central bank moves are massively overrated
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) interest rate hikes have had minimal impact on the ST Index, which is 9% higher than its pre-October 2021 levels. Despite global interest rate hikes, including a 50 basis point increase in the UK, and speculation over MAS' future actions, central bank decisions are seen as having little effect. This is attributed to the fact that companies are not adjusting their strategies in response to these actions, rendering them "massively overrated."

images.alt_text: China is a major destination for Singapore's exports, but the former's economy has limited bearing on the latter's stock market.
Good gold returns require impeccable market timing — otherwise, long-term pain ensues.

A one kilogram gold bar sits on top of silver bars at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: A US$7.5 billion derivative trade shifts to India as SGX feud ends
summary: A US$7.5 billion derivative trade will shift from Singapore to India as a cross-border trading link between the two countries' top bourses becomes operational. The trading will be conducted on the NSE International Exchange at Gift City in Gujarat, with SGX and NSE splitting costs and revenues 50-50. The move marks a partial success for India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi-led administration in attracting trading to the country, following a five-year feud between India's National Stock Exchange and Singapore's Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: Once the merger is effective, a cut-off date will be announced to determine HDFC shareholders eligible to receive HDFC Bank shares.

site_title: Why mixing business and politics can be a powerful force for peace
summary: Business leaders have become key players in international trade negotiations, requiring a combination of commercial and political expertise. Historically, empires were built on trade, and today, the relationship between business and politics has been transformed by the availability of information. This shift has led to a growing recognition of the importance of business in governance, with politicians seeking to collaborate with business leaders to ensure smooth supply and market dealings. Effective communication and cooperation between businesses and governments can be a powerful force for peace, stability, and economic growth.

images.alt_text: The proliferation of AI in our lives and society is bringing up some tough questions about ownership.
Ask sincere questions, check your own biases, have empathy -- some ways to check if your business culture needs improvement.
Alleged rape at the Confederation of British Industry's (CBI) events suggests that perhaps the “alcohol explanation” is still alive and being used to cover unacceptable activities.
Older workers want one thing more than anything else. They want to make a contribution to their society.

site_title: China new home prices edge down in June for second consecutive month
summary: China's new home prices fell 0.01% in June for the second consecutive month, data from the China Index Academy shows. This decline is attributed to a slowdown in market recovery, with housing sales expected to remain weak over the summer. Despite efforts by local governments to support the sector, a severe debt crisis has persisted, with many developers defaulting on payments. If policy support is limited, home buyer confidence is unlikely to improve, according to the research firm.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings developed by China Evergrande Group in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, June 18, 2023. China Evergrande Group's property management unit posted a profit for 2022, reversing a loss in 2021 but lower than the gains in 2020, according to a delayed earnings report that may bring its shares closer to a resumption of trading. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg

site_title: The gender pay gap starts even before you get hired
summary: The gender pay gap starts even before a person is hired, with women more likely to participate in unpaid internships, setting the stage for future pay inequality. Research shows that 43% of internships offered by for-profit companies are unpaid, and these internships often lead to less secure job prospects and lower starting salaries. The gap begins years before the "motherhood penalty," when women's pay suffers due to childcare responsibilities. Experts recommend implementing salary transparency laws and conducting equity audits to mitigate this inequity, and colleges and universities can provide financial support to students.

images.alt_text: One potential explanation for the gender disparity: Women continue to shoulder the burden of housework and childcare.
The report noted that while American women have made gains in higher-paying jobs, they’re still overrepresented in lower-paying roles overall.
Willie Walsh, Director General of the International Air Transport Association (IATA), speaks during IATA annual meeting in Istanbul, Turkey June 5, 2023. REUTERS/Dilara Senkaya

site_title: UBS balks at potential IPO for Credit Suisse domestic unit: Swiss paper
summary: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti opposes taking Credit Suisse's domestic unit public, citing concerns it may strengthen international competitors. The decision comes after UBS agreed to buy Credit Suisse in March, with Swiss politicians urging UBS to split off the domestic branch and list it on the Swiss stock exchange to preserve jobs and increase competition. UBS is instead opting not to take the unit public, citing potential risks.

images.alt_text: epa10713232 Group Chief Executive Officer of Swiss Bank UBS Sergio P. Ermotti speaks at the Point Zero Forum at the Circle in Zurich, Switzerland, 27 June 2023.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL BUHOLZER

site_title: Malaysia’s EPF lifts its AEM stake, crossing 10% level
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) has increased its stake in AEM Holdings to over 10% after acquiring 680,300 shares at an average price of S$3.75 per share. The strategic benefits of AEM's operations in Penang, including its robust supply chain ecosystem, were highlighted by CEO Chandran Nair. The EPF's move comes as the company celebrates the grand opening of its new manufacturing plant in Penang, which spans over 365,000 square feet for assembly, quality assurance, and research and development.

images.alt_text: Nio's ES7 electric vehicle is displayed at the Chinese EV maker's showroom in Shanghai, China, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Standard Chartered brings June holiday cheer to 1,000 less-privileged children
summary: Standard Chartered Bank organized an event for less-privileged children, taking approximately 1,000 kids to the newly opened Bird Paradise, Asia's largest bird park, before the school holidays ended in June. The initiative aims to promote social inclusion and community development through volunteerism. This is part of the bank's efforts to support local causes, with over 3,000 employees contributing to various community initiatives in 2022.

site_title: 10 S-Reits buck the trend despite Reits lagging in June
summary: The US Federal Reserve signaled potential further rate hikes to curb inflation, but S-Reits bucked the trend with a 0.3% total return in June, outperforming the FTSE EPRA Nareit Asia ex Japan Index. Despite this, retail investors net bought S$100 million of S-Reits, while institutional investors net sold S$112 million. 18 out of 35 S-Reits outperformed the sector, with the top 10 best performers averaging 7% total returns, driven by stable operating performance and recovered shopper traffic in key markets.

images.alt_text: Daiwa House Logistics Trust is among the five trusts with the highest ICR.

site_title: China to name forex regulator Pan Gongsheng central bank head
summary: China plans to appoint Pan Gongsheng, a deputy governor of the People's Bank of China, as the central bank's head. Gongsheng, the country's chief foreign exchange regulator, is likely to be first appointed as Communist Party chief before being installed as governor, requiring government approval.

images.alt_text: The central bank set its so-called fixing for the managed currency at a stronger-than-expected level on Friday, after the offshore yuan extended a seven-month low.

site_title: In AI tussle, Twitter restricts number of posts users can read
summary: Twitter has restricted verified accounts to 10,000 tweets per day and non-verified users to 1,000 tweets per day, in an effort to curb data scraping by artificial intelligence companies. The move aims to address "extreme levels of data scraping" and "system manipulation" by third-party platforms. New unverified accounts are limited to 500 tweets. The restrictions, announced by Elon Musk, do not have a specified timeline and follow similar measures taken by Reddit to limit third-party developers' access to its data.

images.alt_text: Twitter hopes to renegotiate multiple contracts with tech companies such as Amazon.com, Salesforce and IBM into single broader partnerships.

site_title: We asked ChatGPT to write a company HR policy – and the results were promising
summary: Researchers tested the use of ChatGPT, an AI chatbot, in creating HR policy documents, specifically equality, diversity and inclusion (EDI) policies. They found that ChatGPT could generate reasonable responses, particularly when given a list of existing EDI policies to draw from. However, the AI struggled with synthesizing the policies into a cohesive document, and its responses often sounded mechanical and simplistic. The study concluded that ChatGPT works best as a tool to support human writers, rather than a replacement, and that its capabilities can be harnessed to streamline HR processes, such as writing policies for quality management, data protection, and other important processes.

images.alt_text: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt (left, with Databricks co-founder Arsalan Tavakoli) warns that AI could be used by bad actors to "accelerate at scale".
While financial technology and generative AI hold great promise, they can be exploited to cause widespread disruption, said Heng Swee Keat.

Such a marketplace could compete with app stores run by some of the company’s customers and technology partners – including Salesforce and Microsoft – and help OpenAI’s technology reach a broader customer base.
The application of artificial intelligence and machine learning in the investment world has so far yielded poor results.

site_title: United CEO apologizes for flying private while customers were stranded
summary: United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby apologized for taking a private jet to Denver while 751 flights were canceled, causing customer inconvenience. The decision was deemed insensitive to passengers waiting to return home. Kirby expressed regret in an emailed statement, acknowledging the hard work of team members who handled the disruptions. The incident highlighted the disconnect between airline executives and their employees and customers during times of crisis.

site_title: Chinese smartphone market may remain weak through 2023, IDC says
summary: China's smartphone market declined 2.1% in the second quarter, extending a market downturn that may persist throughout 2023. Shipments from Honor Device and Xiaomi fell over 17%, while Huawei Technologies saw a 76.1% increase. Apple was the only brand to grow, with a 6.1% increase. The market's decline is linked to a sputtering economy and consumers tightening their budgets. Analysts predict the market could bounce back in the fourth quarter, but growth may be weaker than expected due to weak demand and supply chain concerns.

site_title: China’s Victory Giant to buy Singapore’s MFS Technology for up to US$460 million
summary: China's electronics manufacturer Victory Giant Technology Huizhou agreed to buy Singapore's printed circuit board maker MFS Technology for up to US$460 million. The deal will diversify Victory Giant's products and improve competitiveness, as MFS specializes in flexible printed circuits. Victory Giant will pay in cash, with an equity value of US$365 million and debts worth up to US$95 million. The acquisition is pending registration procedures and approvals from Chinese authorities.

images.alt_text: Founded in 1989, Singapore-headquartered MFS manufactures circuit boards with applications focused on automotive, industrial, medical and data storage end-markets.

site_title: Hollywood faces possible second strike as actors' talks near deadline
summary: Hollywood is facing a possible second strike as actors' talks with the SAG-AFTRA union near a midnight deadline. The union, which represents 160,000 actors, is seeking higher base pay and safeguards around the use of artificial intelligence. A strike by SAG-AFTRA would add pressure to studios already grappling with a nearly two-month writers' strike, which has shut down a wide swath of television production and delayed the filming of movies including Marvel's "Thunderbolts" and "Blade."

images.alt_text: Film and TV writers have walked off their jobs at the start of the month after failing to come to terms with the Alliance of Motion Picture & Television Producers

(FILES) The Netflix logo is seen on top of their office building in Hollywood, California, March 2, 2022. - April 19, 2023, after shipping out more than five billion DVDs in trademark red envelopes, Netflix has finally called time on the movie mail-out subscription business that launched today's Hollywood streaming colossus.
The announcement, made in a letter to shareholders before this week's earnings call, was greeted with bafflement by some broadband binge-watchers who did not know Netflix's DVD business was still running -- or that it existed in the first place. (Photo by Chris DELMAS / AFP)

site_title: Best foot forward: Local shoe brands take on a post-Covid world
summary: Singapore's footwear industry is recovering from the pandemic, with local brands rising to meet demand. Palola, founded by Joshua Leong, has expanded its operations, moving into a permanent home and launching a boutique in Australia. The brand remains committed to handcrafted quality. Hope Rosa, founded by Suman Masciarelli, has also adapted to the pandemic, shifting to an online model and expanding its offerings to include handbags and watches. Oleah, founded by Clara Han, has capitalized on the pandemic's impact, with customers seeking better quality footwear. All three brands are now looking to expand internationally, with plans for Malaysia and other Southeast Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Frenz Brainband is an AI-powered sleep and concentration aid.
Ling Fu decided to start her own luxury handbag label when she got frustrated with the buying process of coveted handbags.
Abara's first boutique opened in Ngee Ann City shopping mall last week.

Skincare brand mtm labo, headed by managing director Kelly Keak (left), collaborated with Barbie collector Jian Yang (right) to showcase Barbie at her most diverse.  The dolls include Barbie on wheelchairs, albino Barbie and pregnant Barbie.

site_title: China to step up policy adjustments, focus on demand: Politburo
summary: China's Politburo, led by President Xi Jinping, has agreed to step up macroeconomic policy adjustments and focus on expanding domestic demand to address the post-pandemic recovery challenges. The economy faces new difficulties, including insufficient demand, enterprise operation difficulties, and risks in key areas. The government will implement precise and forceful adjustments, maintaining a prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy. Key adjustments include optimizing property policies, boosting consumption of auto and electronic products, and promoting tourism consumption. The aim is to prevent risks and promote economic improvement.

images.alt_text: Key Chinese indexes are down for the year, losing out on a rally seen across Japan, India and the US.

site_title: Lloyds braces for more bad loans as mortgage pressure grows
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported a pretax profit of £1.6 billion in the second quarter, below expectations due to higher bad loan charges and a decline in loans and deposits. The bank expects to generate £700 million in extra revenue and £1.2 billion in gross cost savings by the end of 2024. Net interest margin is forecast to rise to 3.1%, driven by rising interest rates and cost savings. Impairment charges for customers at risk of default doubled to £419 million. Lloyds' CEO Charlie Nunn defended the bank's decision to close customer accounts, stating policies reflect financial crime and staff safety.

images.alt_text: The test checks if banks were holding enough capital to cope with theoretical shocks under a scenario which BoE said was more severe than the global financial crisis of 2008.

site_title: Moody's cuts ratings of state-backed Chinese property giants Greenland and Sino-Ocean
summary: Moody's cut the credit ratings of state-backed Chinese property developers Greenland Holdings and Sino-Ocean, downgrading Greenland's corporate family rating to Ca- and Sino-Ocean's to Caa2, citing weak liquidity and recovery prospects. Greenland missed a bond payment and Sino-Ocean made a last-minute bid to stave off default. Moody's warns both companies face imminent default and expects weak recovery prospects for bondholders. This move sparks fears of another wave of Evergrande-style crises in China's property market, which has been struggling in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: Shanghai-based Greenland has failed to make a payment for the 6.75 per cent June 2024 bond with an outstanding US$432 million.
China's top leaders have said it is necessary to adapt to significant changes in market supply and demand and optimise property policies in a timely manner.
The property firm’s move last week to refinance part of a 2019 loan facility failed to assure investors of its ability to repay debt due in the coming months.
Evergrande, founded in 1996, relied on heavy borrowing to fuel its growth.

site_title: Alibaba to stay on sidelines of Ant’s US$6 billion stock buyback
summary: Alibaba has decided not to sell its one-third stake in Ant Group during the Chinese fintech leader's imminent share buyback, citing a desire to maintain its share of the important partner. The decision comes after regulators scrapped Ant's record IPO in 2020, resulting in a significant loss of value. Ant's share buyback plan, approved by its board, aims to repurchase up to 7.6% of its stock. This move follows a two-year crackdown on Chinese technology giants, including Ant and Tencent Holdings, which have faced fines totaling over $1 billion.

site_title: Singapore is ‘at the forefront’ of restructuring and insolvency thought leadership
summary: Singapore's insolvency and restructuring regime has been a subject of interest and study globally, particularly among Australia and Malaysia. Despite not yet achieving its goal of becoming an international debt restructuring hub, Singapore has made significant strides, including hosting the INSOL Conference in 2019 and the upcoming International Insolvency Institute Annual Conference. Notable success stories include Pacific International Lines and Pacific Radiance, and Singapore has been recognized for its expertise in insolvency practice. The government is currently undertaking a root-and-branch study to enhance the judicial management regime, and the country is expected to continue its growth trajectory in restructuring and insolvency thought leadership.

images.alt_text: Singapore has not yet achieved its aspiration of becoming an international debt restructuring hub, said insolvency practitioners.

site_title: Gold edges up ahead of US central bank rate decisions
summary: Gold prices rose 0.051 to $1,961.27 per ounce ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting, where investors await a possible pause in interest rate hikes. The US dollar index was steady, limiting gold's rise, while China's Politburo meeting may see more stimulus announced, though investors remain underwhelmed. Spot silver rose 0.2% and platinum fell 0.2%, while palladium remained unchanged. The focus will be on Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments on the future of interest rates, with markets already priced for a quarter-point hike.

images.alt_text: Russia’s gold reserves stood at 74.9 million troy ounces at the start of July, the central bank said on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong tightens radiation inspection of Japanese seafood imports: Kyodo
summary: Hong Kong has tightened radiation inspection of Japanese seafood imports, with customs clearance delayed by about three hours compared to normal. The move comes amid concerns over Japan's plan to release Fukushima treated water into the ocean. The Japanese government has confirmed that some shipments of seafood have been held up at China's customs. This is the latest development in the region's seafood import regulations, following increased scrutiny of radiation levels following Japan's nuclear disaster in 2011.

site_title: Analysts, investors must challenge status quo to unlock value, forge a more vibrant market
summary: Analysts and investors in Singapore must challenge the status quo to unlock value and create a more vibrant market. The widespread undervaluation of local stocks may have reduced the incentive for companies to prioritize minority investors. Initiatives such as increased media coverage and institutional investor involvement could help, but may face resistance from controlling shareholders. Tough regulatory measures and analyst independence are also crucial. Examples of the challenges include Quarz Capital's bid to internalize Sabana Reit's manager and OCBC's potential to take Great Eastern private, highlighting the need for companies to prioritize shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Sias lamented in a March commentary the "ridiculous lowball" offers that foment investor resentment and mistrust in the local market
Why Great Eastern’s undervalued shares still hold great potential.
Sabana Reit's manager ought to obtain clarity from UOB and other lenders on whether they plan to pull back their credit facilities in the event unitholders vote for internalisation.
